title: An Experimental Study on Multi-Sensor Based Propeller Damage Detection in Drones Using Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: Ahmet Cagdas Seckin, Bensu Emir, Deniz Bulut, Berkay Eren, Habibe Gursoy Demir, Mehmet Hakan Demir
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: This study presents an experimental study combining multiple sensor data and employing different deep learning algorithms to detect drone propeller damage. Under controlled conditions, vibration, acoustic and temperature data were simultaneously collected from quadcopter equipped with accelerometer, microphone and temperature sensors for a healthy propeller and 8 different faulty propellers. The data were collected for the quadcopter operating both indoors and outdoors, and external factors such as noise and wind were also included in the analysis. Short Time Fourier Transform, spectrograms and standard deviation, Kurtosis and skewness analyses were performed on the collected data in both frequency and time domains to improve the performance. After that, data was analyzed using deep learning architectures such as Convolutional Neural Networks, ResNet50, EfficientNet, MobileNetV2 and VGG16, to classify cases with damaged and intact propellers. The performance of the models was evaluated comparatively using accuracy, precision, sensitivity, and F1-score metrics. The results show that EfficientNet emerged as the most accurate and reliable, achieving an accuracy of 97.2% and the lowest log loss (0.0868), indicating both strong predictive capability and high confidence in its predictions. ResNet (87.5%) and VGG16 (89.2%) also performed well, with balanced precision and recall, making them suitable candidates for scenarios where accuracy is important, but resources are moderately constrained. Ablation and hypermeters analyses were applied to the EfficientNet architecture, which is the most successful model, and the results showed that the proposed approach should be carefully configured against modality deficiencies and that the evaluated architecture exhibits stable and reliable performance. These results demonstrate that multi-sensor fusion significantly increases detection accuracy, and deep learning models perform successfully in complex damage scenarios.

title: Improved Predictor-Based Neural Network Model-Free Finite-Set Predictive Control for Power Converters
authors: Bohao Zhang, Lin Qiu, Shengwei Chen, Xing Liu, Jose Rodriguez, Jien Ma, Youtong Fang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Predictive Control of Electrical Drives and Power Electronics (PRECEDE)
abstract: The model-free predictive current control based on the ultra-local model using predictor-based neural network (PNN) significantly reduces the sensitivity to the prior model parameters of the power converter. However, the performance of PNN degrades due to the amplified high-frequency disturbances caused by mismatched inductance parameters, especially when the inductance parameters are reduced. In order to address the aforementioned issue, in this paper an improved predictor-based neural network model-free finite set predictive control (IPNN-MFFSPC) for power converters is proposed. A fast and accurate method for estimating the inductance parameters is proposed based on discrete equations of the PNN. By compensating for inductance parameter disturbances, the robustness of the proposed method is further improved. Finally, simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in handling inductance disturbances, confirming the strong robustness of the approach.

title: Performance Analysis of Multi-RIS-Assisted UWOC Systems: Full Receiving Scheme and Selective Receiving Scheme
authors: Qi Zhang, Dian-Wu Yue, Si-Nian Jin, Xian-Ying Xu, Meng Wang
publish: IEEE Photonics Journal
abstract: Ocean exploration is leading to growing attention on the Internet of Underwater Things (IoUT). Underwater wireless optical communication (UWOC) is a promising technology for massive data transmission of IoUT due to its high speed, low delay, and wide applications. However, the underwater optical link can be interrupted by the obstacles of marine life, seamounts, and some underwater equipment. Reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) technology is an effective method to improve the reliability of UWOC. In fact, a single RIS has limited service coverage and performance enhancement to the UWOC system. Therefore, in this paper, we present the multi-RIS-assisted UWOC system and provide two schemes, i.e., the full receiving scheme and the selective receiving scheme. In addition, the cascaded turbulence channels from source to destination through RIS and the pointing errors caused by beam jitter and RIS jitter are considered. The probability density function (PDF) and the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the end-to-end instantaneous signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) are derived in terms of multivariate Fox-H function with the moment-generating function (MGF) method and the inverse Laplace transform. Based on these SNR statistical analyses, we give the closed-form expressions of the outage probability and the average bit error rate (BER). Furthermore, we provide asymptotic analyses of the outage probability and the average BER to obtain more insights into the coding gain and the diversity order. Finally, Monte-Carlo simulation results are used to verify our derived results. The results show that the performance of the proposed multi-RIS-assisted UWOC systems is significantly better than that of the existing single-RIS-assisted UWOC system, and the selective receiving scheme performs better than the full receiving scheme.

title: A Novel Enhanced Boundary-Connected Matching Area Selection Method for Underwater Gravity Aided Navigation
authors: Mengchen Wang, Wei Zheng, Shijie Zhao, Xiaoping Li, Chuangxin He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: For the gravity aided navigation technology of underwater vehicles, this article carries out the research on the matching area selection algorithm driven by the navigation data, which constructs an autonomous association model of gravity anomaly features and matching area. Firstly, each divided matching area is incompletely evaluated due to loss of evaluation on the navigational reserved boundary. So the modified square domain migration mechanism and out-of-domain sequence simplification mechanism are proposed. Then, to address the class-imbalance problem and remove gravity anomaly feature redundancy, class-imbalance elimination technology and feature selection method are employed respectively. The data processing accurately identifies the potential well-matched areas, and enhances the classification and identification performance. Based on this, an enhanced boundary-connected-based matching area selection method for underwater gravity aided navigation (EBMAS) is proposed. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method can select more comprehensive and connected matching areas. Meanwhile, AUC and F-measure of the processed data are effectively increased, which suggests that EBMAS has better classification and recognition performance for tagging well-matched areas. The matching success rates reach 100% and 99% when migrates to two new seas, indicating that the selected areas have high applicability and matching stability.

title: Creating an Affective Robot That Feels Both Touch and Emotion
authors: Rachael Bevill Burns, Benjamin A. Richardson, Jack Klingenberg, Katherine J. Kuchenbecker
publish: IEEE Transactions on Affective Computing
abstract: Despite the importance of sensitive skin for living creatures, most robots can feel contact on only a tiny fraction of their exterior, if at all. Furthermore, typical robot reactions to touch are limited to event-based acknowledgments, lacking perceptual richness, lifelike positive/negative responses, and temporal dynamics. We address these gaps by introducing a practical full-body tactile-perception system for social robots, turning a NAO robot into the Haptic Empathetic Robot Animal (HERA). The sixteen main regions of the robot's body are instrumented with soft resistive tactile sensors covered by a tailored koala suit. Windows of each time-varying sensor output are continually classified into five gestures at two intensities via a two-stage machine-learning model. On challenging testing data containing simultaneous contacts, touch detection achieves an F1 score of 0.773, and gesture recognition achieves 52.2% accuracy (5.2 times chance); considering the temporal, spatial, and semantic adjacency of the applied touches increases these metrics to 0.896 and 86.6%, respectively. In turn, each detected contact drives a real-time emotion model that represents the robot's affective state as a second-order dynamic system analogous to a mass-spring-damper. This model's parameters control the robot's disposition, stoicism, and calmness. We explain the connections between HERA's hardware and software subsystems and demonstrate their combined ability to create an affective robot that feels both touch and emotion.

title: On-Chip Multimode Interferometer Sensor Formed by Microstructure Blocks Embedded Waveguide
authors: Yahao Li, Jiaqi Ran, Quandong Huang, Zongyang Cai, Binming Luo, Ou Xu, Xinyong Dong
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: On-chip photonic sensors have emerged as powerful tools for the development of next-generation intelligent sensing systems owing to their merits of compact footprint, low cost, and ease in large-scale integration. To further improve the sensitivity and integration of an on-chip sensor, we propose a high-sensitivity on-chip sensor formed by a multimode interferometer (MMI) with microstructure blocks embedded waveguide. In the MMI, the sensor incorporates microstructure blocks within the few-mode waveguide (FMW) core to allow liquid to fill in as a microliquid channel, and an on-chip sensor with high sensitivity is achieved by optimizing the parameters of the microstructure block. To demonstrate the idea, the proposed sensor is subsequently fabricated by using microfabrication facilities, and the fabricated sensor is applied for the seawater salinity measurement. The experimental results show that the fabricated sensor achieves a salinity sensitivity of 0.18 nm/‰ (a refractive index sensitivity of 1125 nm/RIU) with temperature crosstalk as low as −26.8 pm/°C. In addition, the fabricated on-chip sensor demonstrated stability over the 720-hour test period described below. Given its sensitivity, low temperature crosstalk, compact footprint and integration potential, the proposed on-chip sensor may be suitable for salinity monitoring applications such as ocean sensing, environmental monitoring and water resource management.

title: Optimizing Multi-DNN Inference on Mobile Devices through Heterogeneous Processor Co-Execution
authors: Yunquan Gao, Zhiguo Zhang, Praveen Kumar Donta, Chinmaya Kumar Dehury, Xiujun Wang, Dusit Niyato
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) are increasingly adopted across various industries, driving the demand for deploying their capabilities on mobile devices. However, current mobile inference frameworks often rely on a single processor to execute each model inference, limiting hardware utilization and leading to suboptimal performance and energy efficiency. Expanding DNN accessibility on mobile platforms requires more adaptive and resource-efficient solutions to meet increasing computational demands without compromising device functionality. Nevertheless, performing parallel inference of multiple DNNs on heterogeneous processors remains a significant challenge. Existing studies have explored partitioning DNN operations into subgraphs to enable parallel execution across heterogeneous processors. However, these approaches typically generate excessive subgraphs based solely on hardware compatibility, increasing scheduling complexity and memory management overhead. To address these limitations, we propose the Advanced Multi-DNN Model Scheduling (ADMS) strategy that optimizes multi-DNN inference across heterogeneous processors on mobile devices. ADMS constructs an offline subgraph partitioning strategy that considers both hardware support for operations and scheduling granularity. It also employs a processor-state-aware scheduling algorithm to dynamically balance workloads based on real-time system conditions. This ensures efficient workload distribution and maximizes the utilization of available processors. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to vanilla inference frameworks, ADMS achieves a 4.04× reduction in multi-DNN inference latency.

title: Back from the Dead: Self-recovery Strategy for Modular Planetary Exploration Robots_supp3-3644668.mp4
authors: Ning Zhao
publish: N/A
abstract: The theoretical capability of modular robots to recover their original configuration or function after disintegration caused by external impacts has been cited as an advantage for planetary exploration. The key to achieving self-recovery lies in addressing the stochasticity of disintegration. Here, a self-recovery strategy is proposed for modular planetary exploration robots. Firstly, the recovery process is analyzed to construct a strategy framework and provide the problem definitions and strategy assumptions. Secondly, by standardizing the selection criteria for meta-modules under the stochasticity of disintegration, non-mobile modules can acquire mobility through the meta-module method, thereby laying the groundwork for executable self-recovery. Finally, a comprehensive optimization model is proposed, which encompasses the module interactions arising from stochastic disintegration. By integrating selfrecovery characteristics with the simulated annealing algorithm, a solution method is designed to obtain self-recovery plans. Extensive hardware experiments were conducted, and the results demonstrate that the self-recovery strategy operates stably and executes successfully across various configurations and scenarios, thereby validating the feasibility and reliability. In this way, the self-recovery strategy and experiments could substantially advance the application of modular robots in space exploration, while also providing insights for other areas, such as assembly planning and applications involving non-mobile modular robots.

title: Deep Convolutional Primal-Dual Network for Image Deblurring
authors: Mingyuan Jiu, Mingjing Peng, Fanfan Zhang, Shupan Li, Hongru Zhao, Rongrong Ji, Mingliang Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Image deblurring is a challenging image task, which is regarded as a classical inverse problem. Deep primal-dual proximal network (DeepPDNet) is recently proposed which unrolls the Condat-Vũ primal-dual splitting algorithm as a feed-forward network and it has demonstrated excellent restoration performance. However, the feature patterns in the DeepPDNet are well manually designed and thus the network is not implemented in an efficient convolutional fashion. In this work, we revisit the DeepPDNet and extend it in three respects: i) the convolution and pooling operators as well as their associating adjoint operations are studied in the primal-dual algorithm, and then a deep convolutional primal-dual network (DeepConvPDNet) and its full variant with skips are proposed to preserve the optimization consistence of primal-dual Condat-Vũ algorithm; ii) two (cascade vs parallel) variants of the networks are designed according to the structure of convolutional kernels; iii) rather than that the blur kernels are given as prior knowledge, they can be encoded by a set of convolutional layers and deconvolutional layers for their conjugate, resulting to a full learnable deep convolutional primal-dual neural network.We investigate the proposed networks on the MNIST dataset, the grayscale and color version of BSD dataset and GoPro dataset for image deblurring. Extensive experiments are conducted to validate the performance of the proposed networks, and promising results in term of PSNR and SSIM are obtained in comparison with twelve methods including state-of-the-art methods (e.g. Restormer, DRUNet, and DeblurGAN), which validated its effectiveness.

title: Covert Pilot Spoofing Attack via Active Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface
authors: Junshan Luo, Zhengfei Qu, Boxiang He, Shilian Wang, Giorgio Taricco, Chau Yuen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: The active reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) offers a promising solution to overcome the double-fading attenuation inherent in passive RIS-aided systems. However, this capability can be exploited by adversaries to launch potent pilot spoofing attack (PSA). In this paper, we propose a novel active RIS-aided covert PSA scheme for time-division duplex systems, where a passive eavesdropper manipulates the channel state information (CSI) estimation at the legitimate transceiver during the uplink stage and steers downlink data towards itself during the downlink stage. Crucially, without requiring perfect instantaneous CSI, a practical challenge for eavesdroppers, we maximize the average eavesdropping signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) by jointly designing the RIS reflection coefficients for both stages. To ensure covertness, we integrate an anti-energy ratio detection (ERD) mechanism that constrains the detection probability below a predefined threshold. The resulting non-convex optimization problem is solved via an efficient alternating optimization algorithm combined with penalty methods, handling the rank-1 constraints and statistical CSI uncertainties. Simulations demonstrate that the proposed scheme achieves up to 26 dB SNR gain over passive RIS-aided PSA and reduces ERD detection probability compared to traditional PSA. This work reveals the dual-edged nature of the active RIS: while enhancing security, it introduces new attack schemes demanding advanced countermeasures.

title: Multi-UAV Interception Decision-Making via Meta Reinforcement Learning
authors: Chenyang Qi, Huiping Li, Guangdeng Zong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Multi-UAV collaborative interception decision-making is a critical task in uncrewed aerial vehicle (UAV) applications. The core challenge lies in achieving real-time decision-making and precise coordination among multiple agents in highly dynamic and uncertain complex environments to successfully intercept highly maneuverable targets. However, existing methods still fall short in terms of rapid adaptability for interception decision-making, and the generalization performance of traditional reinforcement learning (RL) on new tasks needs improvement. To address these limitations, this article presents a novel meta-RL-based approach for multi-UAV interception decision-making. First, a task allocation method based on greedy strategy is proposed to achieve the rapid assignment of interception targets. Then, we design a task inference model that employs a probabilistic encoder to extract the shared structure across tasks from contextual information, thereby generating a latent variable to represent the task and enhance the training of the algorithm's network. Meanwhile, the proposed method is integrated with RL to improve its generalization capability in new tasks, enabling fast decision-making for the interception task. Finally, the comparative results against baseline algorithms validated the superiority of our method.

title: TSFormer: Efficient Ultra-High-Definition Image Restoration via Trusted Min- p
authors: Zhuoran Zheng, Pu Wang, Liubing Hu, Xin Su
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Ultra-high-definition (UHD) image restoration is vital for applications demanding exceptional visual fidelity, yet existing methods often face a trade-off between restoration quality and efficiency, limiting their practical deployment. In this paper, we propose TSFormer, an all-in-one framework that integrates Trusted learning with Sparsification to boost both generalization capability and computational efficiency in UHD image restoration. The key to sparsification is that only a small amount of token movement is allowed within the model. To efficiently filter tokens, we use Min-p with random matrix theory to quantify the uncertainty of tokens (lower trustworthiness), thereby improving the robustness of the model. Our model can run a 4K (3840 × 2160) image in real time (40fps) with 3.38 M parameters. Extensive experiments demonstrate that TSFormer achieves state-of-the-art restoration quality while enhancing generalization and reducing computational demands. In addition, our token filtering method can be applied to other image restoration models to effectively accelerate inference and maintain performance.

title: Integrating Learned Retraction and Model-Based Resection Planning for Automated Central Airway Obstruction Removal_supp2-3646758.mp4
authors: Tanner Watts
publish: N/A
abstract: Surgeon shortages have driven significant recent advances in robotic surgical assistance. To progress toward surgical automation, we address transoral central airway obstruction (CAO) removal, selecting this procedure for its relatively constrained environment and clear clinical objectives. Prior work has demonstrated successful CAO removal with single-port, minimally invasive robotic systems, making it a promising target for autonomy. We present a new autonomous system designed for CAO removal that integrates a learning-based tissue retraction policy with a model-based resection planner, deployed on a bimanual robotic platform with vision guidance. While our long-term motivation is minimally invasive intervention, we evaluate our approach in an open-surgery setting, enabling rapid development and testing. We evaluate our system in 12 ex vivo CAO removal procedures running at three distinct levels of autonomy. Our results indicate that the learned retraction policy performs similarly or better than a manually designed heuristic, with a mean surgeon-rated score (1-10) of 8.0± 1.6 compared to 6.8± 2.5, and a mean percent tumor volume removal of 113.9± 18.8% compared to 111.9± 13.3%. The model-based resections performed best when supervised, resulting in less tissue damage and better cutting accuracy. Furthermore, our approach produced clinically successful outcomes in all eight supervised autonomous trials. Notably, in one case, the system achieved complete tumor removal without any human intervention. Our overall findings underscore the importance of high-level supervision, revealing targets for future automation.

title: Effect of Thermal Distribution on Signal and Power Analysis of Large Complex 3D-IC System
authors: Yu Tomonaga, Tejas Jeurkar, Anushruti Jaiswal
publish: 2025 IEEE CPMT Symposium Japan (ICSJ)
abstract: In this work, the effect of thermal distribution on signal (SI) and power integrity performance of a large complex 3D-IC system is investigated and discussed. Full-wave 3D solverbased simulations are performed to analyse the system. 3D-IC system is composed of BGA package, and a silicon interposer stacked with HBM and CPU Die's. Eight HBM's are stacked vertically on interposer. Interposer is the bridge between HBM and CPU Dies. SI parameters such as return, insertion loss, crosstalk parameters, and eye diagram opening are observed for high-speed lines between the CPU and HBM die. SI parameters with respect with to varying temperature are compared. Eye opening is also reduced with rise in temperature.

title: Superimposed Current Magnitude-Based Faulty Phase Selector Performance Recovery Strategy for Full-Scale Renewable Energy Grids
authors: Zhang Lin, Wang Hongbin, Zhao Zhiwei, Chen Xun, Xiong Limeng, Li Zhengtian
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The control strategy of inverter-based power sources in a fully renewable energy grid causes a significant imbalance in the positive and negative sequence current distribution coefficients at the energy storage (ES) side. This imbalance leads to faulty operations in the Superimposed Current Magnitude (SCM)-based Faulty Phase Selector (FPS). This paper investigates the current distribution characteristics on the ES side during faults, revealing the mechanism behind the performance degradation of the SCM-based FPS. To solve this problem, we propose a positive-sequence superimposed current suppression strategy based on fault component regulation. By controlling the positive-sequence current from the renewable energy side, this approach equalizes the positive and negative sequence current distribution coefficients on the ES side, thus restoring the phase selector's performance. Simulation results verify that our solution successfully restores the performance of the traditional SCM-based FPS in an islanded system. The findings indicate that existing superimposed current phase selection schemes can still be adapted to power grids with high, and even full, penetration of renewable energy.

title: Design and Analysis of a Composite Electromagnetic Absorber Based on Plasma and Metamaterial Integration
authors: Huanyu Shi, Yong Yang, Zhengzheng Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: To enhance the stealth performance of aircraft in complex electromagnetic environments, this paper proposes a four-layer composite absorbing structure that integrates plasma and electromagnetic metamaterials. The structure, consisting of a plasma layer, a top metamaterial layer, a bottom metamaterial layer and a total reflection layer, achieves effective broadband absorption by coupling two distinct absorption mechanisms. The patterned metamaterial layers are designed based on the Jerusalem cross structure, which offers excellent tunability and structural symmetry. Furthermore, a genetic algorithm is employed to co-optimally adjust the plasma parameters and the geometric parameters of the metamaterial to achieve optimal absorption performance. Simulation results demonstrate that the optimized composite absorber maintains an absorptivity of over 90% across a wide frequency band from 6.908 GHz to 19.391 GHz. This broadband absorption is attributed to the synergistic effect of the dissipative loss from the plasma at lower-to-mid frequencies and the electromagnetic resonance absorption from the metamaterials at specific frequencies. Additionally, due to the rotational symmetry of the metamaterial unit cell, the composite absorber exhibits excellent polarization insensitivity and maintains its broadband absorption capability under oblique incidence. The proposed composite absorber reduces dependence on plasma thickness and mitigates reliance on the designer's experience, providing an intelligent design methodology for plasma-based composite absorbing structures.

title: Decentralized Spectrum Sharing: A Proof-of-Concept Evaluation
authors: João Gabriel, Edilson Filho, Wilker Feitosa, Carlos F. M. e Silva, Thiago Nóbrega, Francisco R. P. Cavalcanti
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: Wireless communication is an important tool for economic growth and fostering digital inclusion in society. As the need for wireless services continues to rise, optimizing the use of underutilized frequency bands has become mandatory. This makes effective spectrum sharing a condition to meet novel communication needs. Nevertheless, the existing spectrum management approaches, often centralized, face burdens regarding reliability, and establishing trust among users. This work introduces the Decentralized TV White Spaces Management System (DWS-MS), whose central hypothesis is that a decentralized, blockchain-based system can effectively manage wireless spectrum across extensive geographical regions. In addition, this work presents a real-scale test conducted using a region in Brazil to validate its practical applicability.

title: Cost–Benefit and Performance Outlook for Off-Grid Solar Solutions in Rural South Cianjur
authors: Aryo De Wibowo Muhammad Sidik, Nur Hasan Kurniawan, Sitti Hikmawatty, Erwin Rasyid, Denny Suriandhi, Purwanto, Sudar Fauzi, Aang Rahmatulla
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Access to reliable electricity remains a major challenge in rural areas of South Cianjur, Indonesia. This study explores the potential of off-grid solar power systems to address this issue, providing a detailed techno-economic analysis. Using HOMER Pro software, we evaluated the technical aspects of the system, including the optimal configuration and solar panel capacity, as well as the energy produced. On the economic side, we looked at important factors like the initial investment, operational costs, Net Present Cost (NPC), Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCOE), Simple Payback Period (SPP), and Return on Investment (ROI). Our findings show that while interest rates do affect the overall cost, off-grid solar power presents a sustainable and affordable solution for rural communities. This research highlights the feasibility of using renewable energy to improve electricity access in remote areas and provides insights into how such solutions can be scaled to other underserved regions.

title: Automated Citation Detection in Congolese Legal Texts: Leveraging LLM-Based NER for Knowledge Graph Construction
authors: Bernard Ngandu, Jovita Mateus, Landry Mbale, Antoine Bagula
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: This paper builds upon our previous work on Juro, an AI-powered chatbot designed to improve legal information access in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), by addressing the specific challenge of automated citation detection in unstructured legal texts. We propose an end-to-end approach that combines Large Language Model (LLM)-based annotation and Named Entity Recognition (NER) for extracting key entities critical to constructing a legal knowledge graph. A total of 8,400 Congolese legal document titles were collected and annotated using the GPT-4o-mini model, followed by training in spaCy under two distinct configurations, one emphasizing accuracy and the other efficiency. We evaluated the system using both a split dataset and a human-annotated benchmark, demonstrating strong performance in identifying document types, reference numbers, and publication dates. An initial mapping algorithm connected documents based on annotated entities, revealing a preliminary citation graph of over 1,400 relationships. While the current methodology shows promise in automating entity extraction and preliminary graph construction, future developments will explore deeper relationship modeling, improved type coverage, and integration into the Juro framework to provide enhanced legal support.

title: AI for Smart Cities: An Explanatory Analysis on Fleet Maintenance and Optimisation
authors: Sree Ganesh Thottempudi, Erenest Mnkandla, David Attipoe, Donatien K. Moulla, Lateef A. Akinyemi, Olufisayo S. Ekundayo, Jelil O. Agbo-Ajala, Vincent Majanga
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Tier Mobility Smart Cities (SC) is a leader in electric scooter sharing. This paper examines the challenges associated with managing and optimising an electric shared micro-mobility fleet in dynamically evolving urban environments. The study investigates operational issues, regulatory frameworks, user satisfaction, and environmental sustainability utilising mixed methods. This includes a satisfaction survey complemented by interviews with staff from Tier Mobility SC. The findings reveal that there are areas for potential improvement, particularly regarding vehicle availability during peak usage. The interviews provide insights into Tier's operational challenges. Additionally, the paper discusses the company's innovative fleet optimization strategies, such as rebalancing and data-driven deployment, which contribute to maintaining high service quality and advancing Tier Mobility's long-term commitment to environmental protection. Overall, the results indicate the complexities that the company faces in balancing operational efficiency, regulatory compliance, user satisfaction, and environmental responsibilities. Furthermore, the paper elucidates how effective fleet distribution and optimization strategies can enhance the success of electric scooter and bike-sharing services. It is also demonstrated that the challenges faced by Tier Mobility SC can serve as valuable lessons for other micro-mobility companies encountering similar difficulties, and how micro-mobility initiatives can strengthen urban areas, enhance efficiency, and promote environmental sustainability.

title: Research on Air Pollution Forecast Method of Shanghai Based on Machine Learning
authors: Yang Wenhan, Steve Teoh Chee Hooi, Toh Leow Bin, Azyyati Adiah Binti Zazali, Manzoor Hussain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: With the swift advancement of global industrialization, the level of air pollution continues to rise, and the development of accurate air pollution prediction models becomes particularly important. The objective of this research is to develop high-precision prediction models based on sensor-measured air pollution data sets to improve air quality monitoring and early warning capabilities. The data set contains concentration information for three major pollutants (PM2.5, NO2 and O3). To accomplish this objective, this paper constructs a multiple linear regression model and an ARIMA model to capture the complex change trend of air pollution. A comparison of the prediction results from the two models reveals that the ARIMA model outperforms the linear regression model in terms of prediction accuracy, showing higher reliability and applicability. The main data analysis work was done in RStudio, with some data comparison and validation using Microsoft Excel. This research provides scientific basis and method reference for the creation of an air pollution prediction model based on real-time data, verifies the potential advantages of ARIMA model in air pollution prediction, is expected to provide theoretical support for future air quality prediction and management, and provides valuable practical experience for further research on how to use sensor data to improve prediction accuracy.

title: Unit Maintenance Scheduling Optimization Considering Flexible Maintenance Windows and Compressible Unit Maintenance Durations
authors: Yongjia Qiao, Jianhu Lv, Xiaorui Guo, Jingxiao Jiang, Ying Wang, Wenjie Mei, Kaifeng Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Unit maintenance scheduling optimization often faces infeasibility issues when the maintenance windows and durations submitted by generation units are inflexible, requiring iterative coordination between the power system operator and power plants, which is severely inefficient. To address this issue, this paper proposes an optimization method of unit maintenance scheduling that considers the flexible maintenance windows and compressible unit maintenance durations. Firstly, units are allowed to submit flexible maintenance windows, which include several days of extensions beside the fixed maintenance windows, as well as to submit their minimum maintenance durations, which are shorter than the normal maintenance duration requirements. To ensure feasibility, some traditional maintenance constraints are reformulated, and two additional variables are introduced, which reformulate the related constraints. Penalty factors are introduced to keep the optimized maintenance schedule within fixed maintenance windows and as close to normal maintenance durations as possible. Finally, a yearly maintenance scheduling optimization based on the IEEE 118-bus system is carried out to verify the effectiveness of the proposed model.

title: Optimizing Electrospinning Parameters of PVA Nanofibers as a Baseline for Plasma Surface Modification in Tissue Engineering
authors: Momchil Shopov, Kostadin Milanov, Margarita Neznakomova, Dilyana Gospodinova, Peter Dineff
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: Poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) nanofiber mats were electrospun while systematically varying applied voltage, tip-to-collector distance, and solution properties to define a reproducible processing window for future plasma surface activation. Fiber morphology and diameter distributions were quantified using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and automated analysis in ImageJ. Reducing applied voltage and increasing flight distance, in combination with tuned viscosity and high electrical conductivity, led to finer and more uniform fibers. The study provides practical guidance for controlling fiber size and stability in PVA electrospinning and establishes a baseline for subsequent plasma modification to enhance surface hydrophilicity and cell adhesion.

title: A Systematic Review: Low-Cost Sensors for Water Quality Monitoring
authors: Yan Lucas Martins, Murilo Renato Fermino Dias, Jordan Passinato Sausen, Campos Maurício de
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: Continuous monitoring of water quality is fundamental for public health, environmental sustainability, and the management of aquatic ecosystems. Traditionally, this process has relied on expensive laboratory equipment and timeconsuming manual analyses. Low-cost sensors integrated with Internet of Things (IoT) platforms represent a paradigm shift, enabling real-time monitoring with unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution. This systematic review, conducted according to PRISMA guidelines, analyzed 68 articles published between 2015 and 2025, providing a quantitative synthesis of current technologies, performance metrics, and costs. Results show that while <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p H}$</tex>, turbidity, and conductivity sensors are affordable and relatively reliable (errors typically <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{i} 5 \%$</tex>), dissolved oxygen sensors remain a challenge due to high costs (USD 200-500 for optical models) and instability in galvanic versions. The review also identifies calibration frequency, biofouling, and long-term durability as critical barriers to large-scale adoption. Solutions discussed include automated calibration and the transformative role of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning (AI/ML) for drift correction, predictive maintenance, and virtual sensing of complex parameters. Finally, we outline future research directions to enhance the reliability, scalability, and accessibility of these technologies.

title: Explicit Segmentation for Low-Resource NMT: A Case Study in QLoRA-Based Fine-Tuning of LLM for Khmer Language
authors: Sreylen Suos, Pongsathon Janyoi, Pusadee Seresangtakul, Sarawoot Kongyoung
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Neural Machine Translation (NMT) has significantly benefited high-resource languages, yet low-resource languages like Khmer continue to pose considerable challenges due to data scarcity and linguistic complexities, such as the lack of explicit word segmentation. This case study investigates the efficacy of the Gemma-3 family of models, specifically the Gemma3-1B-it and Gemma3-4B-it, for Khmer-English NMT. We compared zero-shot, few-shot, and QLoRA fine-tuning methods on both segmented and unsegmented text. Our findings show that fine-tuning is essential for this task. The fine-tuned Gemma3-4B-it model achieved a state-of-the-art BLEU score of 0.7418, significantly outperforming the zero-shot and few-shot approaches, which produced poor results. However, this peak performance comes with a latency trade-off: 21.24 s/iteration—about 7.1× slower than the faster but lower-quality zero-/few-shot baselines (≈2.69–3.30 s/iteration). This work provides a valuable benchmark and practical guidance on balancing translation quality and computational cost for under-resourced languages.

title: Decentralized Auction-Based Task Allocation for Multi-Robot Pickup and Delivery under Time Window Constraints
authors: Tengteng Zeng, Xueyan Wang, Xiuhui Peng, Qi Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper investigates the multi-robot task allocation (MRTA) problem in the context of time-constrained package delivery. The problem is formulated as a combinatorial optimization model that incorporates both robot capacity and delivery time window constraints. To address the inherent complexity of this problem, an Auction-Based Package Transportation Algorithm (APTA) is proposed to facilitate decentralized and scalable task allocation through a two-phase framework comprising task incorporation and task consensus. Within the proposed framework, each robot independently constructs a feasible task bundle and engages in local coordination to resolve conflicts, thereby ensuring globally consistent and conflict-free assignments. Simulation results demonstrate that APTA consistently achieves lower total travel time compared to a baseline Greedy Algorithm (GA) while maintaining satisfactory computational efficiency.

title: Proactive Congestion Control for IoT Networks Using Markov Model
authors: Godfrey A. Akpakwu, Topside E. Mathonsi, Tshimangadzo M. Tshilongamulenze, Solly P. Maswikaneng, Tonderai Muchenje
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: IPv6 stacks for wireless devices with low hardware resources have enabled many new applications and protocols. IETF's Constrained Application Protocol (CoAP) allows constrained devices with Internet access to manipulate resources. Due to restricted radio channel capacities and hardware resources, constrained device networks often experience congestion. This study looks at three congestion control (CC) protocols: the Markov model, CoAP Simple Congestion Control / Advanced (CoCoA) and Default CoAP and compares how well they handle data flow, lost packets, and data flow over different time periods. The proposed Markov model incorporates state transition probabilities to dynamically adjust to network conditions and effectively control varying congestion levels. The Markov model outperforms CoCoA and Default CoAP using Contiki OS and the Cooja simulator. It maintains a high throughput of 220.729 kbps and 13.637 % packet loss at a transmission interval of 15, with a higher CDF of throughput at 0.8, especially under increasing network congestion. The study highlights the use of proactive CC, which employs Markov state transitions to forecast transmission behaviours. In contrast, CoCoA and Default CoAP use reactive approaches, which perform poorly during network congestion. Our findings suggest that predictive models, such as the Markov model, offer substantial benefits for resource-constrained networks like the IoT, where efficient use of available resources is crucial.

title: Time-Series Forecasting of PV Charging Power Using a Hybrid Model
authors: Andreea-Mihaela Comșiț, Nesrine Merabti, Daniel Tudor Cotfas, Petru Adrian Cotfas, Cristina-Ioana Călin
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Renewable energy systems, particularly photovoltaic (PV) energy, play a crucial role in addressing the environmental and economic challenges associated with traditional power sources. PV panels are essential for sustainable energy production; however, their power output is highly sensitive to changing weather conditions. As the global adoption of PV systems increases, accurate forecasting of solar energy becomes critical, especially in off-grid applications where battery storage is involved. This study proposes a hybrid model machine learning framework that combines a Random Walk-based drift model with a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) neural network to forecast the PV charging power for a Li-ion battery in a standalone PV system located in a mountainous region of Romania. The model is trained and tested on real world data collected hourly between March and June 2025. Forecasting performance is evaluated over 1-hour, 2-hour, and 5-hour timeframes. The results reveal that the GRU-RW model consistently outperforms conventional baselines, achieving good accuracy across all time horizons, as measured by important assessment metrics such as normalized RMSE, mean absolute percentage error, and the percentage of predictions within a 5% error margin. This demonstrates the model's effectiveness in predicting short-term PV charging power, as well as its potential to enhance energy management in standalone PV-battery systems operating under unpredictable weather conditions.

title: Synergistic Effects of Energy Storage with Large-Scale Hydropower and Photovoltaic Power Generation
authors: Fangze Wu, Junling Wu, Jian Zhang, Lei Yun, Libo Zhang, Qian Dai, Jun Zhang, Jitai Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the rapid development of clean energy and new energy storage technologies, understanding the synergistic effects of energy storage with large-scale hydropowerphotovoltaic systems and exploring optimal integrated operation technologies of storage systems is of great significance for enhancing the operational efficiency of clean energy bases, as well as improving the safety and economic performance of storage systems. The multi-timescale complementary characteristics of hydropower and photovoltaic power output were analyzed. Based on this, an optimal configuration method for hydropower and photovoltaic installations was proposed to meet the targets for clean energy consumption rate and DC channel utilization rate. Within the overall framework of refined production simulation and optimal capacity allocation calculations for hydropower and photovoltaic systems, a collaborative configuration method for energy storage and large-scale hydropower and photovoltaic systems was proposed. This method optimizes the power and duration of energy storage while reducing the overall investment costs of energy storage systems.

title: Hyperspectral Remote Sensing for Early Detection of Waterborne Disease Indicators in Surface Water
authors: R.Aruna Flarence, Atul Negi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Waterborne diseases pose significant public health risks, necessitating advanced monitoring techniques. Hyperspectral imaging offers a powerful tool for detecting water quality parameters linked to disease outbreaks. This study leverages the GLORIA dataset for water quality assessment and proposes a novel approach combining Kernel SubXPCA for feature extraction, Density-Based Threshold Rotation (DBTR) for handling class imbalance, and Modified Nearest Neighbor Classifier (MNNC) for classification. Our method achieves high accuracy in distinguishing contaminated from safe water sources. Feature importance analysis using permutation importance, SHAP values, and Random Forest identifies key spectral bands influencing classification. The proposed approach demonstrates improved classification performance compared to traditional methods, making it a promising tool for remote sensing-based epidemiological studies.

title: State Estimation of Moving Target Positioning Based on Dual Passive Sensor Detection
authors: Yang Zhang, Shunjia Zhang, Yangwang Fang, Xiaolei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: With the continuous development of modern warfare and reconnaissance technologies, target location techniques based on passive sensors are playing an increasingly important role in areas such as aerial reconnaissance and electronic countermeasures. This paper studies the problem of dynamic location and state estimation of a target aircraft when two cooperative reconnaissance aircraft only use passive observation information. Considering the non-ideal sensing characteristics during the target's movement, this paper takes into account the multiplicative noise interference in the observation process and adopts an improved state estimation algorithm based on the correlated additive noise model, which is suitable for situations where both multiplicative noise and correlated additive noise exist in the state equation and observation equation. By constructing a cooperative reconnaissance system model and conducting numerical simulations, the effectiveness and accuracy of the proposed filter in dynamic target passive location tasks are verified. The results show that this method can significantly improve the positioning accuracy and is suitable for multi-sensor information fusion and target state estimation in complex interference environments.

title: Residential Load Labeling Using Deep Transfer Learning with MobileNet Architecture
authors: Juan S. Corrêa, Ricardo A. S. Fernandes
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: Nowadays, there is a growing demand for ways to improve energy management, and residential load labeling is a key element in this context. However, when working with meters that use low sampling rates, due to similarity between appliances in steady-state and consumption overlap, alternative techniques for feature extraction and temporal window labeling have been proposed. This way, in order to label residential loads from the main panel consumption time series, the temporal windows were transformed into images through four different approaches. Next, a pre-trained MobileNet model, derived from the Imagenet domain, was employed to perform the labeling task itself. It was possible to obtain up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 7. 7 \%}$</tex> of f1-score, demonstrating the robustness of the proposed methodology.

title: Research on Safety Distance Early Warning of Power Operation Based on Multi-Scene Fusion 3D Point Cloud Modeling
authors: Yuzhen Dong, Honghe Liu, Jinbo Cai, Zhaozhong Chen, Xiaoxiao Meng, Suo Wang, Xiongfeng Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The electric power construction environment is complex, and the construction machinery in the live space violates the regulations on the safety distance of electric construction, which brings safety risks. Lidar combined with Beidou positioning has become an effective means of early warning of safety distance in power engineering construction, which is attracting wide attention. However, due to the influence of the lidar shooting angle, a single laser modeling cannot completely cover all the equipment in the construction space and the overall point cloud coordinates of the live equipment cannot be selected at one time. In this paper, a live equipment identification method based on multi-scene fusion and point cloud segmentation is proposed. Firstly, by obtaining the multi-angle measurement point cloud data of the same construction space, a cloud model completion method for residual defects of live equipment was proposed, and the completion optimization of the point cloud model of live equipment was realized. Secondly, the overall structure of PointNet++ is designed to extract the characteristics of point cloud data, and realize the semantic segmentation of point cloud data of live equipment in substation, so as to identify live equipment in substation and improve the interactivity of the safety distance early warning system.

title: Stability Control of Rural Microgrid Classic Supplying Modes and Networking Based on Exchanged Virtual Synchronous Generator
authors: Kai Lyu, Xun Mao, Wangchao Dong
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper investigates a novel control strategy tailored for rural microgrid applications, focusing on typical power supply models and network-matching technologies. A reconfigured exchanged Virtual Synchronous Generator (eVSG) control scheme is proposed, where reactive power regulates frequency formation, and active power governs voltage stabilization. The limitations of conventional grid-forming converter (GFMC) approaches under medium-to-strong grid conditions, particularly in rural microgrids with varying load and generation characteristics, are analyzed. Based on this, an innovative control framework is established, featuring two core advancements: active power-based voltage control and reactive power-based frequency control. The proposed eVSG method significantly enhances the dynamic response, stability, and robustness of rural microgrids, especially under strong grid conditions and sudden disturbances. Rapid recovery to steady-state operation is achieved, meeting the resilience demands of rural power supply systems. Theoretical models are validated through experimental results, confirming the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed approach in rural microgrid scenarios.

title: Reinforcement Learning for an Automated Snake Game
authors: Omar Khamis, Sebastian Zelaya, Meerah Karunanithi, Ahmed Hassan, Loubna Ali, Syed Arslan Abbas Rizvi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Reinforcement Learning (RL) has been effectively used in Machine Learning to train agents to perform tasks and make decisions based on rewards and penalties. In the gaming industry, RL has been applied to several modern games to complete or automate complex tasks. However, most new research focuses on modern games rather than classic ones like “Snake”, presenting a unique challenge for our team. In this study, we developed an RL agent specifically for the game “Snake.” Our agent utilizes advanced decision-making algorithms and has been trained using two different models (Q-learning and Value Iteration). These algorithms are commonly used to solve Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) and are greatly applicable to problems like ours. As a result of this training, we have developed an agent qualified to consistently achieve high scores, outperforming most human players. These findings show the potential of RL in classic games and pave the way for future research in applying advanced RL techniques to a broader range of gaming environments. Moreover, this study highlights the versatility and effectiveness of RL in diverse applications within the larger gaming industry.

title: Substation Fire Situation Severity Evaluation System Based on AHP-Critic Method
authors: Liu Rui, Zhang Jiaqing, Li Jianlin, Guo Yi, Zhou Zheng, Dong Xiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the continuous development of artificial intelligence, China's substation is gradually turning to unmanned. Once a fire occurs, it is necessary to judge the severity of the fire situation of each fire point, so as to provide information support for the development of reasonable fighting strategies. In this study, the AHP-CRITIC method is proposed to analyze the weight of the information reflecting the severity of the fire situation, and quantify the correlation between various information and the severity of the fire situation. The traditional weight analysis method has simple structure and poor stability, so the AHP (Analytic Hierarchy Process) and the CRITIC (Criteria Importance Through Intercriteria Correlation) method are used to judge and synthesize the weight respectively, which improves the reliability of the weight analysis results. In this study, the AHP-CRITIC method is finally used to calculate the weight of various information reflecting the severity of the fire situation, so as to establish the substation fire situation severity evaluation system. According to the weighted calculation of the fire scene information, the fire situation severity can be perceived and judged.

title: Allocation and Frequency Control Parameter Optimization of Converter-Interfaced Generation
authors: Lisen Wang, Yunfeng Wen, Shichen Zhou, Hongxin Li, Guobin Fu, Kaixuan Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Under the deep penetration of power electronics, heterogeneous frequency dynamics across system nodes, along with low inertia and weak frequency stability, have emerged as critical challenges for the secure operation of modern power systems. To improve the frequency response performance of converter-interfaced generation-dominated power systems, this paper proposes an optimization method for GFL-GFM capacity allocation and frequency control parameters, considering spatial heterogeneity in frequency response distribution. First, a system frequency response model reflecting spatial frequency characteristics is established by integrating the power-frequency dynamic equations of GFL and GFM converters based on frequency distribution theory. Second, an optimization model is formulated to minimize the installed capacity of each GFM while coordinating CIG allocation and frequency control parameters under spatial frequency constraints. Finally, simulations on a hybrid GFMGFL converter system validate the proposed strategy's effectiveness in enhancing nodal frequency stability.

title: Power Quality Enhancement Using PV-B-UPQC by Enhanced SOGI Control
authors: Nithin V. V., Sooraj Suresh Kumar, Divyalal R. K., Jayaprakash P.
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Power quality (PQ) is a major concern in power system. In industries, PQ issues can lead to malfunctions and results in substantial production downtime. To address these challenges, various custom power devices (CPD's) are deployed to improve power quality and maintain operational continuity. Unified power quality conditioner (UPQC) combines both series and shunt active power filters connected in back to back with a common DC-link. The series compensator is used to mitigate PQ issues in grid side like voltage sag, swell etc to ensuring a stable and reliable power supply. The shunt compensator is used for compensating PQ issues on load side like harmonics, unbalance etc. The presented system involves integrating a PV array with a UPQC and battery to enhance PQ in the grid using enhanced SOGI (ESOGI) control. Integration of doublestage PV system with UPQC, helps in providing active power support to the grid. The battery is used to store excess power from PV array. Additionally, the battery is controlled to regulate the DC link voltage during transient conditions and to reduce the settling time. Also this control scheme helps to compensate for asymmetrical voltage sag and swell in the grid. The system has been designed and simulated using Matlab/Simulink software, with the simulation results confirming the effectiveness of the PV-B-UPQC in enhancing PQ at the point of common coupling (PCC).

title: Design and Analysis of the Frame Structure Based on the Self-balancing Two-wheeled Vehicle with Parallel Configuration Control Gyroscope
authors: Yifan Zhao, Jianyong Zheng, Wenjie Shen, Wenhui Rui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Based on existing commercial two-wheeled vehicle frame structures and incorporating a dual-parallel configuration stabilizing gyroscopic cluster topology, this study presents a novel self-balancing unmanned two-wheeled vehicle designed to carry the stability control device. A modular design approach is adopted for frame segmentation, aiming to achieve autonomous balance maintenance and execution of specific tasks. Static and modal analyses were conducted using ANSYS software under both stationary and operational conditions of the stabilization system. The results demonstrate that in the non-operational state, the frame exhibits relatively low levels of maximum deformation and stress values, with natural frequency distribution aligning with conventional vehicle characteristics. During operational conditions, the maximum deformation and stress values at critical frame locations show significant increases yet remain within safe thresholds. Both operational datasets meet the predefined performance criteria, validating the rationality and reliability of the structural design. This research provides theoretical support and quantitative references for the engineering development of unmanned self-balancing two-wheeled vehicles.

title: Distributed Unscented Kalman Filtering Based on Gaussian Mixture Model Against Non-Gaussian Noise
authors: Xuemei Mao, Jiacheng He, Gang Wang, Bei Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed state estimation for nonlinear systems under non-Gaussian measurement noise. Traditional distributed Kalman filters often rely on Gaussian noise assumptions and are prone to performance degradation when faced with heavy-tailed, impulsive, or multimodal disturbances. To enhance robustness and estimation accuracy, we propose a novel distributed unscented Kalman filter based on Gaussian mixture modeling (UKFGMM). The key idea is to approximate the non-Gaussian measurement noise using a Gaussian mixture model (GMM), and assign each Gaussian component to a parallel unscented Kalman filter (UKF) sub-filter. These sub-estimates are then fused in a probabilistic manner, inspired by the interacting multiple model (IMM) framework. This mechanism enables the filter to adaptively track multiple noise modes while preserving distributed computation. Simulation results demonstrate that UKFGMM achieves superior performance compared to conventional UKF and maximum correntropy UKF, especially in scenarios with strong non-Gaussian characteristics.

title: Measuring the Social Experience on Co-Op Adventure Game: Case Study on It Takes Two
authors: Jason Natanael Lisapaly, Valent Ruben Setiawan, Jurike V. Moniaga, Galih Dea Pratama
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Co-op adventure games are known for fostering social interaction by promoting teamwork and collaboration. The genre is favored by casual players since it presents an enjoyable social experience. With the genre’s rise in popularity, multiple games have been played by a lot of people which serves as an interesting study subject into the genre. It Takes Two, an action-adventure video game, serves as an ideal platform to examine these dynamics. This study seeks to analyze the social interactions that emerge across various types of relationships. In order to gain a broader point of view, analyzing the game’s elements would help to find the connections between the game’s design and how it enhances the social gaming experience. The research process is divided into two main parts, a game analysis utilizing the Elemental Tetrad framework and gameplay sessions that would provide insights into how the game’s cooperative design influences social interactions. The results highlight the game’s design and its effects on the social experience.

title: Enhancing Systematic Interoperability: Convergences and Mismatches between Web 3.0 and the EU Data Act
authors: Linyi Xu, Zihao Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: Abstract—Interoperability is increasingly recognised as a foundational principle for fostering innovation, competition, and user autonomy in the evolving digital ecosystem. Existing research on interoperability predominantly focuses either on technological interoperability itself or on the legal regulations concerning interoperability, with insufficient exploration of their interdisciplinary intersection. This paper compares the technological interoperability in Web 3.0 with the theoretical framework of legal interoperability established by the EU Data Act, analysing the areas of convergence and mismatch. The goal is to align technical interoperability with legal concepts of interoperability, thereby enhancing the practical implementation of systematic interoperability in the next generation of the Web. Through a comparative analysis of technological and legal interoperability, this study finds that, firstly, Web 3.0’s concept of interoperability spans data, systems, and applications, while the Data Act focuses solely on data. This narrow scope risks creating a fragmented ecosystem, where data exchange is possible, but full integration of systems and applications is hindered, leading to inefficiencies, and obstructing seamless data flow across platforms. Secondly, while Web 3.0 technically seeks to achieve interoperability through the integration of entire systems and decentralised applications, the compliance with Data Act might negatively limit such system and application interoperability through its data interoperability provisions. This paper suggests interdisciplinary recommendations to enhance the implementation and enforcement of interoperability. On one hand, the Data Act should broaden its concept of interoperability to encompass both the systems and applications layers. On the other hand, it is advisable to introduce provisions for standardised protocols through soft law mechanisms to address legal shortcomings and keep pace with technological advancements.

title: An Innovative Solution for the Conversion of Recorded Scenarios from Vehicle to Virtual Scenarios
authors: Jihas Khan, Ann Cyprian, Maanasa S Prasad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Real-world scenarios provide an ideal dataset for validating Autonomous Driving (AD) vehicles. However, the actors, scenes, and scenarios in these real-world recordings are predefined and not editable. This paper proposes an innovative solution to convert real-world videos recorded from vehicles on the road into virtual scenarios. This approach allows us to introduce variations to create complex scenarios that mirror real-world encounters. The process involves performing semantic segmentation and object detection on the recorded videos, which are divided into individual frames, each associated with corresponding three-dimensional (3D) Global Positioning System (GPS) and Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) data from the ego vehicle (EV). The world coordinates of objects across these frames are calculated using intrinsic camera parameters and depth maps, with EV coordinates specified in the Cartesian coordinate system by converting World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84) global coordinates to Earth Centered Earth Fixed (ECEF) coordinates. The paper concludes by demonstrating the effective transformation of recorded video images into virtual scenarios.

title: Circuit-level Simulation of TID and Thermal Regeneration Effects on 28nm FDSOI Technology
authors: A. Urena-Acuna, J. M. Armani
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: In this work, we implement physical models that describe the effects of radiation and thermal regeneration on 28nm FDSOI transistors. These models can be used with circuit simulation software to evaluate the radiation response in this technology. We perform SPICE simulations using UTSOI 2.0 from the transistor to the circuit level to determine the electrical degradation and the recovery by applying annealing cycles. In addition, we test a thermal-electrical mitigation strategy to partially or fully recover the TID-induced electrical degradation of the transistors.

title: Joint Allocation of Flexible Resources in Distribution Systems to Enhance Resilience Considering Resist, Response and Restoration Stages
authors: Shunyao Zhang, Yiheng Bian, Di Zhang, Runze Han, MingXuan Jiang, Gengfeng Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Allocating flexible resources such as controllable distributed generators (DGs) in planning stage is a prospective way to enhance distribution system (DS) resilience. Existing relevant models mainly take into account single restoration stage for decision-making, however, the practical recovery process of DSs also involves the resist and response stage prior to the restoration stage, neglecting this stage can lead to a potential degradation of flexible resources effectiveness. In this paper, a joint resource allocation model considers DGs, remote-controlled switches (RCSs) and soft open points (SOPs) is established. The entire recovery process, from resist and response to restoration, is modelled considering their own recovery features and coupling relationships. Furthermore, the objective of allocation model includes a comprehensive consideration of two economic terms: deployment cost and resilience benefit. Case studies verify the resilience enhancement of the proposed model compared with existing models.

title: Static Voltage Stability Analysis of Large Scale Renewable Energy Delivered via Multi-Voltage-Level Transmission Sections
authors: Haitao Liu, Man Xu, Zhanpeng Chen, Xiao Wang, Dehai Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper addresses the static voltage stability constraints and complex coupling relationships in multi-voltage-level transmission sections for large-scale renewable energy integration systems. The study extracts two typical topological structures-parallel coupling and series coupling sections-from actual grid features and analyzes their interactive mechanisms affecting static voltage stability limits. Research reveals that in parallel systems, power flow distribution significantly impacts the overall transmission limit, with optimal limits achieved when heavily loaded branches concentrate on low-impedance paths. In series systems, the contribution of proximal station power growth to total transmission capacity exhibits nonlinear variation (sensitivity decreases with increasing output). Validated through actual grid simulations, the sensitivity of key node power flow to section limits is quantified, demonstrating that uniform power verification may cause conservatism or security risks. The findings provide theoretical support for online assessment of multi-level transmission section limit and active power optimization control, enhancing utilization rates while ensuring security to promote renewable energy accommodation.

title: Comparative Study of Deep Neural and Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks for Heart Disease Risk Stratification via Stethoscopic Signals
authors: Nawat Suangburanakul, Bhurin Sombattanasook, Siriporn Sakboonyarat, Boonnatee Sakboonyarat
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains a leading global cause of death, making early detection essential. The goal of this project is to investigate and determine the best machine learning model and hyperparameters to analyze the data from digital stethoscope recorded heart sound to classify individuals with risk of CVD. We exploited various advanced preprocessing techniques such as noise reduction, segmentation, and class balancing using the publicly accessible 2016 PhysioNet Cardiology Challenge dataset. Data augmentation options including pitch shifting, time stretching, and noise addition were also applied to enhance the robustness of the model. Mel Spectrogram and Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) were employed to determine heart sound characteristics. Several proposed deep learning architectures such as CNN, RNN, hybrid CNN/RNN model and Kolmogorov–Arnold Network (KAN) were designed and validated. Hyperparameters with cross-validation were adjusted using a grid search and accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score and F2 score were evaluated as indices of model performance. The best performance was obtained using Mel Spectrogram features for the hybrid CNN/RNN model, which were evaluated in relation to efficient training of KAN model, which achieved similar results with fast training time. The study contributes to the advancement of effective and data-driven mechanisms for early CVD risk detection based on heart sound.

title: PCB Panel Defect Detection based on Deep Learning
authors: Xiong Junsen, Sarerusaenye Binti Ismail, Poornima Mahadevappa, Shakheel Ahmed, Mamoona Humayun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The focus of this research is to use deep learning models to advance PCB (printed circuit board) panel defect detection in industrial manufacturing, in particular to evaluate and compare the two models Faster R-CNN and YOLO. Traditional machine learning detection methods are effective for simple single type defect identification, but there are certain difficulties for the complexity of various irregular defects common in PCBS. Therefore, in large-scale automated inspection, the accuracy and efficiency of these traditional methods are often low. This study uses a comprehensive experimental design to integrate and compare traditional machine learning models with popular deep learning architectures. The results of practical experimental research show that although the deep learning model, YOLO model, has superior performance in defect detection, it requires more computing resources, and the model is prone to missing detection problems when dealing with complex defects. In contrast, Faster R-CNN, in particular, performs well in PCB panel defect detection scenarios with multiple defect types, and its detection accuracy can exceed 95%, with high accuracy and operational efficiency. The research ultimately provides a robust defect detection framework for the needs of the PCB manufacturing industry, reducing inspection errors and improving production efficiency. Future directions include expanding the diversity of datasets and integrating additional deep learning models to integrate the benefits of other deep learning models.

title: PUF-Assisted Lightweight Key Derivation Framework for VANET Security
authors: Anu Mattatholi, Chithra K R, Sinith M S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Security is very important in Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs) to protect messages from being tampered with or stolen during communication. This paper proposes a lightweight and secure key agreement framework that combines classical cryptographic key exchange methods with Physically Unclonable Function (PUF)-based key derivation. The system uses protocols such as DH, ECDH, DHE, ECDHE and EDEDH to generate a shared 256 -bit secret, which is then combined with a unique 128-bit PUF-generated key using XOR and SHA256 hashing to form the final session key. The framework enhances security by making the key device-specific and resistant to physical tampering. Performance is evaluated using four metrics: Hamming distance, Shannon entropy, bit agreement and execution time. Results show that all schemes generate highentropy, unpredictable keys, while also maintaining low latency suitable for constrained devices. A <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 \%}$</tex> bit agreement in man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack scenarios confirms the system's ability to detect interference. Among the evaluated protocols, Enhanced DHE (EDEDH) demonstrates a balanced performance in terms of security strength and computational efficiency, indicating its suitability for secure communication in resource-constrained environments.

title: A Comparative Study on Cooling Techniques for Integrated Circuits in SOIC-8 Packages
authors: Daniel Andrei Bulugheană, Cristian Marcel Fărcaș
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of various cooling strategies regarding a completely modelled SOIC-8 package integrated circuit, based on MP1923 driver from Monolithic Power Systems, on a four-layer printed circuit board. Unlike any other thermal simulations regarding the mentioned package, this work includes a detailed 3D model for the internal structure of the chip, allowing for more accurate thermal results.

title: Forecasting Photovoltaic Power Generation with Machine Learning and Genetic Hyperparameter Optimization
authors: Breno A Vieira, George R S Lira, Igor M A Santos, Pedro E O Oliveira, Pablo B Vilar, Giovanny M B Galdino
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This study proposes an approach for forecasting photovoltaic power generation at the Coremas Photovoltaic Power Plant, located in Paraíba, Brazil. The methodology employs machine learning techniques with hyperparameter optimization through Genetic Algorithms (GA). Specifically, the optimization was performed for Multilayer Perceptron (MLP), Long ShortTerm Memory (LSTM), and Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) models. A thorough analysis of historical generation and production data, provided by the Brazilian National System Operator (ONS), was conducted to train and evaluate the models. During preprocessing, missing values, outliers, and anomalous formation patterns were identified and corrected to ensure data quality. The results demonstrated that among the tested models, LightGBM achieved the lowest average errors across the evaluated metrics. However, relying solely on historical values constrains forecasting accuracy under conditions of higher variability.

title: Path Planning for Unmanned Sailboats Leveraging VPP-RRT* Algorithm
authors: Jinkun Shen, Zhongben Zhu, Guiqiang Bai, Yifan Xue, Xiaokai Mu, Hongde Qin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Unmanned sailboats, surface unmanned platforms powered by wind, are suitable for tasks such as island security patrols and ocean monitoring due to their long endurance. However, due to the underactuated nature of unmanned sailboats, the relationship between speed and wind direction is highly nonlinear, making it difficult to adjust the route flexibly, which presents a significant challenge for path planning. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a VPP-RRT* algorithm. By incorporating the sailboat’s Velocity Prediction Program (VPP), the cost function of the RRT* algorithm is modified. The cost function is divided into maneuvering cost and time cost, aiming to reduce the total turning angles and path length of the planned route. Through simulation comparisons, the VPP-RRT* algorithm’s feasibility, robustness, and superiority in different obstacle environments and wind directions have been successfully validated.

title: CyDT: The Cyprus Digital Twin for Resilient Cities and Robust Critical Infrastructure Systems
authors: Panayiotis Georgiou, Christophoros Leventis, Philippos Isaia, Marios Kyriakou, Balaji Venkatasubramanian, Stelios Vrachimis, Christos Laoudias, Demetrios Eliades, Mathaios Panteli
