publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Modern smart cities now place top priority on keeping Critical Infrastructure Systems (CIS) like power grids, water networks, transportation systems, and telecommunications both resilient and highly efficient. Recent advances in Digital Twin (DT) technology have made it an attractive tool for managing these systems by generating dynamic, data-driven virtual models of cyber-physical assets and their interconnections. Despite widespread adoption of DTs across many industries, there is no risk-based, scenario-driven DT framework readily available to researchers, smart city operators, and CIS managers for bolstering urban resilience. To fill this gap, we present the Cyprus Digital Twin (CyDT), a one-of-a-kind digital platform designed to manage and optimize interdependent CIS. We detail CyDT's modular architecture outlining its principal components and spotlighting its novel features and capabilities and demonstrate its adaptability and effectiveness in real-life use cases that conduct risk-based resilience analyses of power and water systems.

title: Implementation of a Software-Defined Radio Communication System with QPSK Modulation Scheme that Eliminates the Phase Ambiguity
authors: Radu Gabriel Bozomitu, Ştefan Corneliu Stoica, Marian Alexandru Corban
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: In this paper a new software-defined radio communication system with different types of QPSK modulation schemes that eliminates the phase ambiguity is presented. The proposed system solves the phase ambiguity problem by using rotationally invariant differential codes, as well as using differential QPSK (DQPSK) coding. The paper analyses the operation of the proposed system that uses standard QPSK modulation, two types of differential encoding QPSK modulation (DEQPSK1 - a single-bit is differential encoded and DEQPSK2 - two-bit blocks are differential encoded), as well as for the differential implementation of QPSK modulation (DQPSK). The proposed radio communication system provides a data transmission rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150 \text{kbit} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> and operates optimally under carrier frequency offset and timing offset on an AWGN communication channel. The paper plots bit error rate vs. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E_{b} N_{0}$</tex> for all SDR implementation of QPSK modulation schemes and discusses the optimal implementation depending on bits mapping (in binary or Gray code). The simulation results are confirmed by the experimental ones obtained under laboratory conditions using an experimental setup that includes two USRP devices.

title: Fault Diagnosis Method of Half-Bridge Switching Power Supply Based on Support Vector Machine
authors: Peng Chen, Qiang-Ming Cai, Peng-Fei Yu, Li-Juan Deng, Jun-Liang Wan, Xin Cao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In the DC-DC switching power supply, the electrolytic capacitor in parallel with the output terminal is very important. Due to its structure, electrolytic capacitor is the component with the highest failure rate in switching power supply. When the electrolytic capacitor fails, its equivalent series resistance (ESR) will also increase abnormally, which will directly affect the filtering efficiency of the power supply. In order to study this problem in depth, this paper simulates the fault injection of ESR in various cases via professional simulation software and selects the transient voltage signal generated when the load resistance changes suddenly as the key feature. With the help of the classification ability of SVM algorithm, whether the capacitor fails can be judged according to the change of transient voltage signal. Experiments show that the power supply fault diagnosis method based on SVM has better diagnostic accuracy.

title: Super-Resolution 3D Gaussian Splatting via Latent Feature Field and Gradient-guided Splitting
authors: Shiyun Xie, Zhiru Wang, Xu Wang, Chengwei Pan, Qing Wang, Xiwang Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Recently, 3D Gaussian Splatting(3DGS) has excelled in novel view synthesis with its real-time rendering capabilities and superior quality. However, it faces challenges for high-resolution novel view synthesis (HRNVS) due to the coarse nature of primitives derived from low-resolution input views. To address this issue, we propose Super-Resolution 3DGS, which is an expansion of 3DGS designed with a two-stage coarse-to-fine training framework, utilizing pretrained low-resolution scene representation as an initialization for super-resolution optimization. Moreover, we introduce Multi-resolution Feature Gaussian Splatting (MFGS) to incorporates a latent feature field for flexible feature sampling and Gradient-guided Selective Splitting (GSS) for effective Gaussian upsampling. By integrating these strategies within the coarse-to-fine framework ensure both high fidelity and memory efficiency. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method surpasses state-of-the-art HRNVS methods on challenging real-world datasets using only low-resolution inputs.

title: Multi-Class Lung CT Image Classification for Enhanced Cancer Detection Using Fine-Tuned EfficientNet-B7 Framework
authors: Anjali Ananthan, Anoop V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: The need for a precise and reliable identification of lung cancer is critical for its early detection and treatment. This study presents a deep learning-based framework utilizing a fine-tuned EfficientNet-B7 model for multi-class classification of lung CT images into Adenocarcinoma, Large Cell Carcinoma, Squamous Cell Carcinoma, and Normal categories. The model leverages transfer learning from a pre-trained EfficientNet-B7, with customized classification layers and partial fine-tuning of the top 30 layers to adapt to the medical domain. Preprocessing techniques, including Gaussian denoising to suppress additive white Gaussian noise and data augmentation to enhance generalization, were applied to improve input quality. The model was trained on 900 images and tested on 100 images, achieving a significantly high validation accuracy of 95.56% and test accuracy of 98%. The performance of the designed classifier on the test dataset is also very impressive with significantly high values for macro and weighted Precision, Recall and F1-score, outperforming benchmark CNN models such as ResNet-50 and Xception.

title: Multi-Step Wind Power Forecasting Based on LSTM-ASSA-Informer
authors: Ziwei Zhang, Sen Wang, Yonghui Sun, Yao Wang, Peibiao Chen, Haoran Dai
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To address the growing need for high-precision forecasting in renewable energy systems, particularly in multistep wind power forecasting (WFP), an LSTM-ASSA-Informer architecture is developed by tackling the challenges of shortterm pattern modeling and long-range dependency learning. First, the long short-term memory (LSTM) network is employed to effectively model short-term temporal patterns through its gated memory structure. Second, an adaptive sparse self-attention (ASSA) mechanism is introduced to dynamically highlight the most relevant features from highdimensional input data, helping the model focus on critical information. Finally, the Informer is integrated to efficiently capture long-range dependencies while reducing computational overhead, using a distillation-based attention mechanism tailored for WFP. Experiments on the GEFCom2014 dataset show that the proposed model consistently surpasses several widely used approaches across multiple forecasting horizons. It exhibits notable improvements in forecasting accuracy and robustness, underscoring its practical significance and strong potential for real-world deployment.

title: Radar Monitoring of Estuarine Fronts in Guanabara Bay, Southeastern Brazil
authors: Marcelle Mattos Rios, Marlon da Silva Borges, João Régis dos Santos Filho, Victor Fernandes
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This work proposes a radar-based methodology to monitor estuarine fronts at the Guanabara Bay, using the Furuno FAR-2117 X-band pulsed radar. Guanabara Bay, located in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, is a highly impacted coastal ecosystem facing intense urban, industrial, and port pollution. In this kind of environment, the radar system enables high-resolution detection of tidal dynamics, supporting real-time environmental monitoring. Radar images were georeferenced in ArcGIS, allowing spatial analysis and heat maps that revealed pollutant accumulation zones. Results showed a strong correlation between radar detections and tidal predictions, confirming the method's effectiveness. This investigation demonstrates that X-band radar is a viable and efficient tool for estuarine monitoring and can support conservation strategies in Guanabara Bay and similar ecosystems worldwide.

title: The Experiment and Analysis on Foot Design and Gait Selection of Hexapod Robots for Efficient Movement on Sand
authors: Yang Liu, Zhongchao Deng, Jingang Du, Hao Li, Yuang Gao, Guiqiang Bai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Hexapod robots have emerged as a focal point in amphibious robotics research due to their adaptable locomotion capabilities and strong environmental adaptability. To address the locomotion requirements of amphibious hexapod robots for autonomous deployment across diverse environments, this study conducts systematic experiments to determine optimal locomotion modes for different operational scenarios. Experimental results reveal that the tripod gait can accommodate varying speed requirements during locomotion on flat ground, while tetrapod gait forward walking is recommended for sandy environments.

title: Landslide Detection System
authors: A. J. Joseph, Abdul Ahad, Archana Unni, B. Adithyan, Anish Thomas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Landslides are one of the most devastating natural disasters, leading to significant loss of life, property damage, and environmental destruction. The unpredictability of landslides makes it essential to develop reliable early warning systems that can help mitigate their impact. This paper presents a landslide detection system that integrates multiple sensing technologies, including soil moisture sensors, accelerometers, and tiltmeters, combined with the Internet of Things (IoT) for real-time monitoring and analysis. The system continuously measures soil moisture levels, which are critical for slope stability. Too much water in the soil reduces cohesion and makes slopes more vulnerable to landslides. NodeMCU, a microcontroller with IoT features, serves as the main processing unit. It collects and sends data wirelessly to a remote server. The system also uses accelerometers and tiltmeters to detect unusual ground movement and changes in slope angles. These sensors provide key information that can help predict potential landslides. By taking advantage of IoT and real-time data processing, the system allows authorities and communities to receive early warnings. This helps with timely evacuations and disaster prevention measures. Combining sensor networks with cloud-based data storage improves predictive analysis, leading to better disaster management overall. The system is also cost-effective and scalable, making it suitable for landslide-prone areas. This research focuses on the design and development of a scalable, low-power and modular landslide detection architecture. The three-tier warning mechanism is incorporated to ensure timely alerts. While large-scale field validation is part of future work, the proposed framework is structured to achieve high detection reliability and low alert latency in real deployments, contributing to proactive disaster risk reduction.

title: Study of Factor Effect on Surge Current Test Performance for Clip-Bonded Semiconductor Devices by Simulation
authors: Nick Chenchao Zhong, Thomas Igel-Holtzendorff, Haibo Fan, Tim Böttcher, Owen Yi Kei Law
publish: 2025 IEEE CPMT Symposium Japan (ICSJ)
abstract: This research uses Finite Element Analysis (FEA) to study the impact of key factors on Surge Current Test Performance of Clip-Bonded Electronic Power Devices. Surge Current Test is also known as Surge Peak Forward Current (IFSM). Key factors include solder volume, clip center to die center offset, and distance from “edge of active junction in silicon” to solder edge.

title: Fusion of AI and Traditional Techniques: A Neural Rendering Framework for Enhancing Hand-Drawn Sketches
authors: Ragitha R G, V. Khanaa, Savita Nanakram Keshwani, Akash Biswas, Shashi Priya, Anureet Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Combining AI with traditional art methods has created new possibilities in digital creation, especially when it comes to improving hand-drawn sketches through intelligent modelling. This study presents a new neural rendering system that improves the look and structure of hand-drawn artworks by combining deep learning models with traditional sketch improvement methods. A convolutional neural network (CNN) backbone and a transformer-based focus mechanism are used in the suggested system to look at and improve sketch inputs. By using domain-specific priors like edge recognition, stroke density estimates, and artistic features, the system improves the image in several steps, such as by lowering noise, making lines clearer, and changing the shade. A generative adversarial network (GAN) learns accurate texture maps from labelled datasets to make the result even better. The framework lets the user lead customization through live inputs, which lets style and detail be changed on the fly. Using standard sketch files for experiments shows that this method performs better than current baseline methods in terms of perceptual quality, structural coherence, and staying true to the original artist's purpose. Quantitative measures like SSIM, PSNR, and LPIPS show that the method works, and personal feedback from professional artists shows how useful the system is in design processes. Combining neural modelling with traditional sketches makes it possible to use this method in animation, product design, and digital art instruction. It bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human creation. For more artistic expression, future updates could add real-time modelling and the ability to change the style to fit your needs.

title: Secondary Frequency Regulation Strategy of Power Systems with Virtual Power Plant
authors: Zongqi Gu, Boxi Zhou, Xiaolei Wang, Xiaohan Shi
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the large-scale integration of variable renewable energy sources like wind and solar power, decreased system inertia leads to increased disturbances and larger frequency deviations, thus posing significant challenges to maintaining frequency within the prescribed range.. As conventional thermal power plants are progressively replaced by wind and solar generation, their capacity and regulation speed become insufficient to meet frequency regulation requirements. Furthermore, frequent regulation adjustments can lead to mechanical wear, thereby shortening their operational lifespan. Distributed energy resources, such as energy storage systems, electric vehicles, and flexible loads, serve as a critical supplement for enhancing system frequency regulation capacity due to their fast response and flexible dispatch characteristics. However, the distinct regulation characteristics of Virtual Power Plants compared to thermal power plants create coordination challenges. Consequently, it is imperative to develop control strategies that coordinate diverse frequency regulation resources to achieve optimal regulation outcomes while reducing regulation costs. To fully leverage the role of the VPP in system frequency regulation, a multi-resource coordinated secondary frequency regulation framework is designed, enabling the joint participation of Virtual Power Plants (VPPs), energy storage systems, and conventional generating units. Subsequently, a model characterizing the VPP regulation dynamics is formulated, and the transfer function relating the actual regulation power output to the regulation command signal is established. Building upon this, an optimization-based algorithm for decomposing coordinated regulation commands among diverse resources is proposed. This algorithm fully leverages the unique frequency regulation capabilities of each resource type while minimizing the associated regulation costs. Finally, the proposed method is validated on the IEEE 30-bus test system, demonstrating its superior frequency control performance compared to both thermal-only regulation and a conventional capacity-proportional command decomposition strategy. Case studies and simulation results demonstrate that the proposed control architecture and optimization strategy effectively enhance system frequency stability and reduce frequency regulation costs..

title: Predictive Reliability Analysis of Power Electronic Systems Using IEC 61709 and FIT Data
authors: Deivid Faria De Souza, Itamar Fernandes Soares Bollmann, Adalberto Jose Rossa, Erick Matheus da Silveira Brito, Sérgio Vidal Garcia Oliveira, Mauricio De Campos, Jose Renes Pinheiro, Guilherme Martins Leandro
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: Addressing reliability early in the product development cycle is essential to reduce costs and ensure long-term performance. Traditional methods-such as Highly Accelerated Life Test (HALT), Accelerated Life Test (ALT), and Highly Accelerated Stress Screen (HASS)-are effective but typically costly and time-consuming. Predictive tools, including Failure Modes and Effects Analysis (FMEA), simulations, and failure rate analysis, help identify potential failure modes during early design stages. Quantitative metrics, such as failure rate and Mean Time Between Failures (MTBF), are often modeled using the Weibull distribution to characterize distinct failure phases. This paper proposes a structured methodology for predictive reliability assessment of power electronic systems during the early design phase. The approach relies on component-level Failure In Time (FIT) data, adjusted to account for environmental and operational factors in accordance with IEC 61709. By integrating principles from MIL-HDBK-217F and the FIDES Guide, the methodology enables fast and cost-effective reliability estimations without requiring accelerated testing. A case study demonstrates the method's effectiveness in guiding design decisions and evaluating reliability trade-offs during the conceptual design stage.

title: A Calculation Method for the Maximum Adjustable Capacity of Polysilicon under Process Constraints
authors: Wuxiao Chen, Yuqing Cai, Zhijun Jiang, Xuan Deng, Zhexin Lin, Yihao Zou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: With the increasing demand of the new-type power system for load-side regulation capacity, industrial loads, as important adjustable resources, have attracted widespread attention. Polysilicon, as a key raw material in the photovoltaic industry chain, exhibits typical characteristics such as high continuity in production, concentrated energy consumption, and complex coupling relationships among stages, thus demonstrating strong potential for load adjustability. This paper, based on the process characteristics of the polysilicon production process, establishes a full-process load production model framework using the State-Task Network method. It systematically describes the material transfer links and task execution logic among core tasks, and proposes a load adjustable capacity evaluation model that considers material balance, power balance, storage constraints, production output constraint, and task execution constraints. Simulation cases verify the effectiveness of the proposed model in characterizing the load regulation potential of polysilicon production, and reveal differences in regulation capabilities across production stages, thereby providing theoretical basis and decision support for polysilicon enterprises participating in power system ancillary services.

title: Design and Implementation of Threshold-Free Adaptive Sliding-Mode Speed Controller and Observer for SPMSM System
authors: Shaocheng Qu, Xiang Cheng, Changfan Zhang, Jing He, Yi Su
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: To enhance the reliability and adaptability of the speed regulation system for surface-mounted permanent magnet synchronous motors (SPMSMs), a novel adaptive sliding mode control (ASMC) scheme is presented. Firstly, a threshold-free adaptive sliding mode control (TF-ASMC) is proposed to eliminate the need of design for switching threshold and inherent threshold-tuning in traditional ASMC. Additionally, the stability of the TF-ASMC is demonstrated by using Lyapunov and Rayleigh principles. Secondly, based on the concept of threshold-free adaptability, a threshold-free sliding mode observer (TF-ASMO) is designed for feedforward compensation of the TF-ASMC, thereby enhancing the robustness of the control system. Finally, the proposed TF-ASMC+ASMO method is validated on a 64W PMSM experimental platform, and experiment results show that the control system achieves good performance in the presence of parameter mismatches and disturbances.

title: Performance Evaluation of a Synthetic Ester-Based Insulating Fluid for Power Transformers under Lightning Impulse Stress
authors: Antonio Fernando Martins Cardoso, Mateus Martins Laranjeira, Matias Pinheiro Torres Fabricius, Bernardo Marques Amaral Silva, José Rui da Rocha Pinto Ferreira, Marcus Vinicius Alves Nunes
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: This paper presents an experimental evaluation of the dielectric performance of a synthetic ester-based insulating fluid (Midel 7131) for power transformers subjected to lightning impulse voltages. The study is motivated by the search for sustainable and environmentally friendly alternatives to conventional mineral oils, particularly under extreme electrical stress conditions. A test setup was developed using Rogowski-type electrodes immersed in the fluid and subjected to positive and negative standard lightning impulses, following IEC 60060-1 and 60247. The dielectric dissipation factor (tan δ) and partial discharge (PD) activity were measured before and after the impulses. Results showed that Midel 7131 maintained low dielectric loss values and exhibited stable PD behavior, even after repeated high-voltage (HV) impulses. These findings confirm the technical feasibility of synthetic esters as reliable insulating fluids for HV equipment, supporting sustainable practices in the electrical energy sector.

title: Robust Pole Placement via State Feedback Control Applied to DC-DC Converters
authors: Milton Brenner Machado Matoso, Lukas Weber da Silva, Robert Viaro, Rafael Concatto Beltrame, Fernanda de Morais Carnielluti, Vinicius Foletto Montagner
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: This paper proposes a systematic procedure for designing a state feedback controller with robust pole placement for output voltage regulation in DC-DC converters. The proposal ensures all closed-loop poles lie within a predefined sector in the left half-plane, providing bounded overshoot and settling time across the entire load range. It also guarantees zero steady-state error and avoids control-signal saturation. Experimental results on a 20 W DC–DC buck prototype demonstrate that the proposed controller settles within 4 ms during reference steps, while a PI benchmark requires 12 ms under the same operating conditions, highlighting the superior dynamic performance of the proposed controller.

title: From Buildings to Cities: A Scalable Smart City Implementation for Research on Smart Buildings and Infrastructures Systems Integration
authors: Flavio Bono, Giovanni Vaglica, Graziano Renaldi, Dario Cazzato, Elena Villares Ojea, José Ricardo Passos Moreira De Sousa, Mira Housen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: The growing demand for smart city services and applications necessitates scalable and flexible infrastructures capable of integrating heterogeneous devices, systems, and data sources. This article presents the scalable smart city platform implemented at the European Commission's Joint Research Centre in Italy that enables the integration of multiple applications, including smart buildings and infrastructures, through a set of heterogeneous devices and communication systems. The platform's IT architecture is designed to ensure future expandability, allowing for the seamless addition of new sensors and applications. A key feature of the platform is the integration of digital twins of single infrastructures, with an approach that can be expanded to whole cities, enabling real-time monitoring, simulations, and predictive analytics. The article discusses the design and implementation of the platform, highlighting the scalability and flexibility of the IT architecture, and presents representative case studies implemented that demonstrate the platform's effectiveness in integrating multiple applications and sub-systems, and digital twins. The work shows that the platform can efficiently handle large amounts of data from heterogeneous sources, providing real-time insights and supporting data-driven decision-making for urban management and outlines future research directions to support full urban extents.

title: Improved 3D RRT* Path Planning Considering Contact Constraints for Autonomous Ground Vehicles in Off-Road Environments
authors: Ke Liu, Yongkang Zhang, Jicheng Chen, Henglai Wei, Yan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Traditional 3D RRT* algorithms often neglect the contact constraints between the vehicle and terrain, as well as the STATE transition dynamics between two consecutive nodes. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a novel RRT*-based path planning algorithm tailored for off-road autonomous ground vehicles (AGVs). During the sampling process, plane fitting is employed to ensure continuous and stable contact between the vehicle and the underlying terrain. Instead of conventional position-based sampling, the algorithm samples velocity and angular velocity STATEs, leveraging a kinematic vehicle model to achieve valid STATE transitions and expand the search tree accordingly. Simulation experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method across three types of challenging off-road terrains: valleys, potholes, and gravel roads. Experimental results show that compared to the traditional 3D RRT* algorithm, the proposed approach significantly reduces path length, number of nodes, turning angles, and planning time. Furthermore, the second set of experiments verifies that the algorithm can adaptively adjust roll and pitch angle thresholds at each node based on preset speed requirements, maintaining vehicle stability while keeping the actual speed close to the desired value.

title: A Comprehensive Energy Efficiency Evaluation Method for Low-Voltage DC Distribution Network Based on Energy Router
authors: Hong Zhang, Jinzhong Li, Yuguang Xie, Bin Xu, Di Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In this paper, a comprehensive energy efficiency evaluation method for low-voltage DC distribution network based on energy router is proposed, and a three-level evaluation index system of ”equipment layer-system layer-interaction layer” is constructed to quantify the contribution of energy router control strategy to the overall energy efficiency. A dynamic weight correction algorithm is designed to fuse the entropy weight method and AHP analytic hierarchy process to solve the problem of index coupling under the time-varying characteristics of load, and establish a joint optimization model of energy efficiency and economy, and the evaluation results are fed back to the control system in real time through the power redistribution strategy of the energy router. The analysis of the case shows that the proposed method can improve the energy efficiency level of the low-voltage distribution network from medium to good, and has good effectiveness and practicability.

title: Nested Optimization-Based Current Shaping for Torque Ripple and Losses Mitigation in SRMs
authors: Gustavo X. Prestes, Paulo H. da S. e Silva, Mozer S. Lorenzo, Filipe P. Scalcon, Andrew M. Knight, Rodrigo P. Vieira
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: Switched reluctance motors (SRMs) have emerged as an attractive alternative due to features such as the absence of circulating current in the rotor and the fact that no permanent magnets are required. However, their inherent structural characteristics and the resulting nonlinear effects lead to pronounced torque ripple, which has significantly hindered their adoption in industrial applications and electric vehicles. As a novel approach, this paper proposes a nested optimizationbased current shaping strategy for SRMs in order to mitigate torque ripple and copper losses. The proposal combines NSGA-II for optimizing firing angles with a Quadratic Programming (QP) algorithm that minimizes instantaneous torque tracking error under flux variation constraints. This hybrid approach balances efficiency and torque smoothness, especially at medium to high speeds, by compensating for negative torque generated due to tail currents. The optimal trade-off among Pareto-optimal solutions is selected based on the minimum Euclidean distance to the ideal point. Experimental validation on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12 / 8$</tex> SRM under diverse operating conditions confirms the effectiveness of the method, showing significant improvements in torque quality compared to the conventional sinusoidal TSF. Additionally, the approach offers a practical implementation with reduced design complexity, enhancing its applicability in advanced SRM control strategies.

title: A Comparative Study of the Performance Analysis of Heat Transfer Fluids in Solar Flat Plate Collector
authors: M. Sreelakshmi Rajan, Kishor Kumar V. V.
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: This study focuses on maximizing thermal efficiency in solar thermal applications by analyzing the performance of glycerol and water as heat transfer fluids (HTFs) in solar flat plate collectors (FPCs). Water has a high specific heat capacity, but its vulnerability to freezing in colder locations poses problems. Additionally, due to its antifreeze properties and low-temperature stability, glycerol was evaluated in various ratios with water (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90: 10 \%, 80: 20 {\%}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$70: 30 {\%}$</tex>) and in water alone to determine the optimal composition and compare the glycerol-water mixture with the water alone conditions. The results showed that a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90: 10$</tex> glycerol-water mixture increased the collector efficiency by 4.5% and produced 8.5% more usable heat than pure water, with just a little increase in the heat loss coefficient. According to the study, this <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90: 10$</tex> blend provides an efficient composition that enhances the efficiency of solar FPC and thermal performance. Future studies could explore a wider range of glycerol-water ratios and the application of nanoparticles to optimize heat transfer in solar flat plate collectors.

title: Validation of the Japanese Lightning Detection Network (JLDN) Performance Characteristics
authors: Michihiro Matsui, Koji Michishita, Yasuhiro Miyama
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: The authors have analyzed the lightning current waveform observed by the Rogowski coils equipped at the wind turbines and lightning events detected by the Japanese Lightning Detection Network (JLDN) to validate the performance characteristics of the JLDN. We investigated the location accuracy, detection efficiency, and estimated peak current by the JLDN. The findings of this study showed that the median location error was 164 m, and the detection efficiency of return strokes with peak currents of 5kA or more was 100%. This study also clarified that the steepness of the lightning current waveform affects the peak current value estimation by JLDN.

title: Method for Generating a Set of Secondary Faults in Power Systems under Typhoons and Their Secondary Disasters
authors: Qingzhe Li, Na Cao, Qun Yu, Minhui Zuo, Jingbo Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the increasing frequency of extreme natural disasters, power systems face increasingly complex risks and challenges under the influence of typhoons and their secondary disasters. This paper addresses the issue of multiple secondary faults occurring during the recovery phase of power systems under typhoon disasters, and proposes a method for generating secondary fault sets based on Bayesian networks. First, a landslide fault rate model considering terrain and precipitation effects is established to quantify the risk of line faults caused by secondary disasters. Second, a Bayesian network is introduced to simulate the spatial propagation and evolution of secondary faults, combined with Monte Carlo sampling techniques to generate a set of secondary faults. Finally, through simulation analysis of a regional power grid in a certain province, the effectiveness of the proposed method in generating typical secondary fault sets under prolonged and frequent fault conditions is validated. The research findings can provide decision-making support for post-disaster recovery strategy formulation and grid resilience enhancement.

title: Layout Scheme of Inter-Phase Spacers for Anti-Galloping on $110-\text{kV}$ Transmission Lines
authors: Liyang Wang, Xinyu Gao, Bin Cao, Liming Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To mitigate conductor galloping and associated safety hazards in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$110-\text{kV}$</tex> overhead transmission lines under complex meteorological conditions, this study proposes an antigalloping strategy via optimized inter-phase spacer deployment. A numerical simulation model for ice-accretion-induced galloping was established, with its computational methodology and spacer suppression mechanisms explicitly elucidated. Building on existing layouts, a novel scheme was designed by integrating <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$110-\text{kV}$</tex> line structural characteristics, operational environments, and galloping modal orders. Mechanical modeling and numerical simulations comparatively evaluated galloping suppression efficacy across schemes, supplemented by spacer force verification. Results demonstrate that the current scheme significantly reduces galloping amplitudes of transmission lines within a span of 400 meters: for spans between 100 m and 250 m, install 2 interphase spacers per span; for spans between 250 m and 400 m, install 3 interphase spacers per span. This solution exhibits exceptional engineering feasibility and cost-benefit ratio, effectively reducing phase-tophase flashover and short-circuit risks while providing critical technical guidance for galloping prevention in medium-high voltage transmission systems.

title: ARMED: A Novel Intelligent Framework for Floods Early Warning
authors: Malamati Louta, Thomas Kyriakidis, Stavroula Tsitsifli, Konstantinos Panitsidis, Evangelos Tsipis, Dimitrios Kosmanos, Dimitra Kokkinou, Nikolaos Mitsiou, George T. Karetsos, Liza Bensasson, Dimitra Koutsioumpa, Rafaela Kypriou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Flood events are increasing in frequency while their impacts are escalating. Multiple Flood Early Warning Systems (FEWSs) have been developed over the last years, yet many struggle with latency, opaque predictions, weak communication of uncertainty in flood forecasting results, and budget constraints. This paper presents ARMED, a proposed FEWS with a layered architecture that uses a hybrid approach combining IoT sensors, open meteorological data forecasts, hydrologic - hydraulic modelling produced scenarios, Machine Learning (ML) for near real time scenario selection and an Early-Warning engine to generate ranked alerts for upcoming flood events. The System includes a web application where data, scenarios and alerts are presented. ARMED proposed architecture emphasizes open-source components and supports adaptability, extensibility and modularity for reuse across basins. The System will be tested in the Agioi Anargyroi stream (Serres, Greece).

title: DeepIPCv2: LiDAR-powered Robust Environmental Perception and Navigational Control for Autonomous Vehicle
authors: Oskar Natan, Jun Miura
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: We propose DeepIPCv2, an end-to-end autonomous driving framework that integrates LiDAR-based environmental perception with command-specific control learning. Unlike prior camera-reliant models, DeepIPCv2 employs point cloud segmentation and multi-view projection (front and bird’s-eye views) to construct robust scene representations. These features are fused and decoded through a combination of gated recurrent units (GRU), command-specific multi-layer perceptrons (MLP), and PID controllers to estimate both waypoints and navigational control commands. This design enhances maneuverability and addresses action imbalance in driving datasets. To validate the model, we constructed a dataset covering diverse illumination conditions and conducted ablation studies and comparative tests against recent methods, including TransFuser. Results demonstrate that DeepIPCv2 achieves the lowest total metric error and the fewest driving interventions, highlighting both its robustness to illumination changes and its improved control accuracy. By releasing the codes at https://github.com/oskarnatan/DeepIPCv2 later, we aim to support reproducibility and future advancements in end-to-end autonomous driving research.

title: Scalable User Association With Least-Conflict Pilot Assignment in Cell-Free Massive MIMO
authors: Ahmed AlAlwani, Karim Banawan, Karim G. Seddik, Mohammed Karmoose
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF-mMIMO) is a promising technology for uniform high spectral efficiency (SE), enabled by distributed access points (AP) jointly serving user equipments (UE) over wide areas. However, practical deployment faces two key challenges: AP–UE association under AP capacity limits and efficient pilot assignment with limited orthogonal pilots. We propose an iterative, preference-aware association algorithm (coverage-aware preference-based association (CAPA)) that balances AP loads while respecting both UE and AP preferences, ensuring reliable service for all UEs. In parallel, we design a pilot assignment scheme (conflict pilot assignment (LCPA)) that minimizes pilot reuse within each AP set, falling back on the least-used pilot only when necessary. Simulations show that our approach outperforms existing benchmarks, boosting the 95%-likely spectral efficiency by up to 46% and the sum SE by 2–8%. These results highlight the proposed framework’s ability to trade off coverage and throughput, making it well-suited for dense (CF-mMIMO) deployments

title: Operating Temperature Analysis of Dry-type Capacitors under Superimposed AC-DC Voltage
authors: Zixuan Zhao, Geng Chen, Yujing Tong, Jingquan Zheng, Cong Wang, Youping Tu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: Dry-type capacitors, which have high operating voltage and energy storage density, have been widely used in VSC-HVDC, but the complex electrical and thermal environments pose significant challenges to the operational stability of capacitors. It is difficult to directly measure the temperature distribution inside capacitors, and existing computation models simulate capacitor components as equivalent series resistance, ignoring the temperature dependence and electric field dependence of capacitor models under complex electrothermal condition. This paper focuses on the biaxially oriented polypropylene (BOPP) capacitors, considering its dielectric characteristics under superimposed AC-DC voltage and high ambient temperature, quantitatively describes the temperature dependence and electric field dependence of the BOPP's leakage current and dielectric losses. A finite element electrothermal coupling model considering the characteristics of dielectric materials is proposed, and the temperature distribution of capacitors under the superimposed AC-DC voltage is obtained, the influence of ambient temperature and dielectric properties on the thermoelectric coupling of capacitor is analyzed. This work provides a guidance for the material and structure design of capacitors.

title: Databasing the Face: The Rise of Data-Centrism in Computerized Facial Expression Recognition
authors: Heewon Kim
publish: IEEE Annals of the History of Computing
abstract: This article traces the emergence of data-centrism in the development of computerized facial expression recognition systems from the mid-1980s to the early 2000s. It highlights how psychologists and computer scientists, including Paul Ekman, Terrence Sejnowski, Jeffery Cohn, and Takeo Kanade, collaborated to computerize the Facial Action Coding System, underscoring the importance of comprehensive, accessible datasets as a prerequisite for automating facial expression analysis. Based on grant proposals, research notes, and correspondence, I argue that the link between facial expressions and emotional states came to be seen as self-evident rather than subject to further inquiry, as researchers devoted themselves to collecting, labeling, and curating facial image datasets for training and testing computerized systems. By foregrounding the detailed process of data-making, this article contributes to the history of computing and the politics of algorithms, showing how these practices helped consolidate particular assumptions about the human face and emotion as technical facts.

title: Human-Centric Shoulder Exoskeleton: A Novel Assistive Device With A Self-Aligning Mechanism to Reduce Interaction Forces_supp2-3646719.pdf
authors: Avinash Pramod S
publish: N/A
abstract: Upper limb wearable exoskeletons are devices used for assistive and augmentative applications in work environments. The shoulder mechanism of the upper limb exoskeleton is vital in fulfilling its objective by exhibiting its capability to move with the human shoulder in unity without any joint axis misalignment. Any misalignment can cause strain on the human shoulder complex due to unwanted interaction forces between the user and the exoskeleton. Most existing portable assistive or augmentation exoskeletons fail to exhibit the capability to self-align when there is a joint axis misalignment due to design-related issues. This paper presents the design, analysis, and experimental evaluation of a novel human-centric shoulder exoskeleton with a self-aligning shoulder mechanism for an average adult male. The novelty of the design is that it considers the human shoulder’s humeral head (HH) translation and incorporates a novel mechanism to reduce misalignment. The system’s design details, workspace analysis, and prototype testing and analysis are explained. The proposed exoskeleton is evaluated and validated using simulation and experimentation on a standardised test bench. The results are compared with the existing conventional exoskeleton and human-assisted motion, and it was found that the proposed exoskeleton is capable of reducing the interaction forces due to misalignment by 99%. Further, a simple assistive control architecture is proposed and implemented for the exoskeleton for efficient operation.

title: Bayesian Muography Incorporating Prior Knowledge: A High-Resolution Imaging Algorithm for Structurally Complex Cultural Artifacts
authors: Xinyu Cai, Kaiqiang Yao, Jiangkun Li, Jian Zhang, Baopeng Su, Wenjing Liu, Hengliang Deng, Ting Li, Xiaodong Wang, Juntao Liu, Zhiyi Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: Cultural artifacts are vital for heritage preservation but vulnerable to environmental damage that creates internal structural defects not visible on the surface. The drainage dragon heads of the Forbidden City exemplify this problem, suffering from structural detachment due to long-term erosion, which threatens both heritage preservation and public safety. Conventional non-destructive testing methods are inadequate in this context. Contact-based ultrasound risks surface damage, while X-ray devices are unsuitable for public heritage sites and both lack sufficient penetration capability. Muography offers a promising non-invasive solution using cosmic ray muons to image internal structures without artificial radiation. However, conventional muography algorithms lack the resolution needed for fracture detection in drainage structures. We propose a highprecision scattering-based muography algorithm using Bayesian inference with prior knowledge. This approach incorporates the object’s geometric outline and constructs a likelihood function combining theoretical scattering models with muon momentum. Using PyMC for probabilistic sampling, we reconstruct slice density to reveal internal structures. Both simulation and experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in imaging complex fractures in drainage structures. This method provides a practical solution for cultural heritage preservation and can extend to structural assessment in civil engineering applications.

title: Time Synchronization-Aided Signal Detection for LEO Satellite Communications with Reduced Doppler and Delay Searching Ranges
authors: Yixuan Li, Shuai Wang, Xuanhe Yang, Gaofeng Pan, Dusit Niyato
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite communications provide uninterrupted coverage and seamless services, which are becoming a crucial element in the Sixth-Generation of wireless communications. However, LEO communications are subject to high path loss and Doppler frequency shift, which presents significant challenges for such large-distance and time-changeable satellite-terrestrial transmission links. Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS) has been widely adopted as a robust modulation technique in LEO satellite systems. Traditional DSSS signal detection methods, which rely on 2D searching, fail to effectively acquire the weak uplink signals due to the extremely low signal-to-noise ratio and pronounced channel dynamics. In light of these considerations, this study proposes an algorithm designated as time synchronization-aided signal detection, with the objective of enhancing the signal detection probability in low signal-to-noise ratio and high-mobility communication scenarios. Furthermore, we develop a novel transmission system based on time synchronization, with the objective of reducing the signal detection threshold by minimizing the impact of the Doppler frequency shift and time delay searching ranges. We theoretically analyze performance at varying time synchronization precision, numerical simulations and hardware experiments under diverse conditions demonstrate that, in comparison to the conventional algorithm, time synchronization can enhance the probability of signal detection.

title: Beam Defocus Mitigation in Ultra-Wideband Mmwave UCA Systems Based on Frequency Invariant Precoder Design
authors: Zhuoran Zhou, Zhiqiang Yuan, Fengchun Zhang, Jonathan Borrill, Wei Fan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Hybrid precoding, as a compromise between low power yet less flexible analog precoding and power hungry but fully flexible digital precoding solutions, has attracted huge attention from industry and academia in recent years for milimeter-wave (mmWave) massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems. The adoption of uniform circular arrays (UCA) can provide advantages of a wide angle scanning range and flat array gain, hence considered for massive MIMO hybrid precoding. However, the phase shifters used in hybrid precoder architectures are typically narrowband, which do not support the ultra- wideband bandwidth required in mmWave systems. This limitation can significantly degrade the performance of UCA in ultra- wideband communications, leading to well-known beam defocus effect. In this paper, we first reveal the beam defocus effects in ultra- wideband mmWave UCA precoding systems, where the beamforming gain severely degrades as the frequency deviates from the center. We then propose a novel frequency-invariant precoder to mitigate beam defocus effect in the hybrid precoding architectures, which approximately achieve the same high beamforming gain for the whole wide bandwidth without extra hardware cost. Finally, numerical simulation and outdoors experimental validations with same parameter settings are performed. Both simulation and measurement results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed frequency-invariant precoding algorithm.

title: Fast Adaptive Anti-Jamming Channel Access via Deep Q Learning and Coarse-Grained Spectrum Prediction
authors: Jianshu Zhang, Xiaofu Wu, Junquan Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: This paper investigates the anti-jamming channel access problem in complex and unknown jamming environments, where the jammer could dynamically adjust its strategies to target different channels. Traditional channel hopping anti-jamming approaches using fixed patterns are ineffective against such dynamic jamming attacks. Although the emerging deep reinforcement learning (DRL) based dynamic channel access approach could achieve the Nash equilibrium (NE) under fast-changing jamming attacks, it requires extensive training episodes. To address this issue, we propose a fast adaptive anti-jamming channel access approach guided by the intuition of “learning faster than the jammer”, where a synchronously updated coarse-grained spectrum prediction serves as an auxiliary task for the deep Q network (DQN) based anti-jamming model. This helps the model identify a superior Q-function compared to standard DRL while significantly reducing the number of training episodes. Numerical results indicate that the proposed approach significantly accelerates the rate of convergence in model training, reducing the required training episodes by up to 70% compared to standard DRL. Additionally, it also achieves a 10% improvement in throughput over NE strategies, owing to the effective use of coarse-grained spectrum prediction.

title: Beamforming-Enabled Covert Communications for Multi-Position Warden
authors: Mingqian Liu, Zhaoxi Wen, Yunfei Chen, Jie Tang, Kai-Kit Wong, Xiaoniu Yang
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: In covert communications, the position of the warden has a variety of situations, which leads to different scenes that require different covert communication schemes to ensure the security. In response to this situation, in this paper, a beamforming optimization method of covert communications for multi-position warden is proposed. Firstly, we formulate a general optimization problem and optimize it to maximize the covert communication rate of the user based on Dinkelbach’s transform. Subsequently, according to the optimized general optimization problem, we propose three schemes for three scenes corresponding to different fixed warden positions, using appropriate technologies for assistance in each scheme. Specifically, the intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) is used in Scene 1 and the integrated communication and jamming (ICAJ) is used in Scenes 2 and 3, and these technologies can assist the covert communication. Moreover, we propose an alternate optimization (AO) algorithm to solve the optimization problem of Scene 1 for its optimal covert communication performance. Additionally, we also propose an AO algorithm to solve the optimization problems of Scenes 2 and 3 to optimize the active beamforming. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of all three proposed schemes, that outperform their respective benchmark schemes.

authors: Enric Cervera
publish: IEEE Robotics & Automation Magazine
abstract: Open source software is nowadays a cornerstone of many robotic systems. Researchers have generously embraced this paradigm by sharing their algorithms in public code repositories for the benefit of the community. An increasing number of papers published in major conferences and journals include a link to a GitHub repository that can be readily downloaded, but only a fraction of them can successfully be reproduced. Software is constantly upgrading, and lack of maintenance often breaks the code. This article describes how robotic software is commonly deployed and proposes a workflow for achieving reproducibility in one click, with a complete practical example from a conference paper that includes datasets and graphical output.

title: A Compact Unified Model for Stereo-matching and Optical flow Tasks
authors: Ahmet Tavli, Furkan Kiraç
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study presents a model for two motion tasks: optical flow and rectified stereo-matching from images. Instead of proposing two specialized architectures for two different tasks, we solve the two tasks by comparing feature similarities using a single model. We achieve discriminative features by developing our feature extraction methods. Unlike previous feature extractors, which concatenate all the convolutional, residual, and pyramid pooling outputs, we take only the final residual layer output and pyramid pooling outputs. Our extractor has two advantages. First, when our feature extractor outputs are combined with the Transformer, the quality of the extracted features is remarkably improved. As a result, our model does not need additional task-specific refinement. Second, our feature extractor reduces computational overhead by focusing on discriminative outputs only (e.g., final residual and pyramid pooling), resulting in ~50% fewer parameters than UniMatch (2.46M vs. 5.1M) and enabling training on a single NVIDIA A100 GPU. Similar to the other unified models, our model also allows cross-task transfer. We can share parameters across tasks without changing them. On the challenging Sintel and KITTI datasets, our model achieves comparable or superior performance to prior works, with particular gains in efficiency (e.g., 50% fewer parameters than UniMatch and single-GPU training) and architectural simplicity.

title: Enhancing Employee Mental Health: Machine Learning Models for Occupational Burnout Prediction Using Job-Related Features
authors: Lau Sook Cheng, Azyyati Adiah Binti Zazali, Syeda Mariam Muzammal, Raja Kumar Murugesan, Basheer Riskhan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Occupational burnout has emerged as a pressing issue in the years following the COVID-19 pandemic, especially in Malaysia, which ranks as the nation with the second-poorest work-life balance. This pervasive issue adversely impacts both organizational productivity and employee well-being. Despite the growing use of ML and DL in healthcare industry to predict occupational burnout, there is little study on non-healthcare and non-educational worker burnout. Since traditional approaches of task management are ineffective in today complicated and ever-changing workplaces, many companies are clueless to the problem of occupational burnout. Therefore, the main purpose of this research using ML methods, such as Logistic Regression, the XGBoost model, and the Random Forest Classifier, to create a trustworthy framework for predicting occupational burnout. The dataset for this project will be constructed from publicly accessible information regarding employee demographics, job satisfaction, job turnover, work environment, and various other social factors.

title: Designing a Mobile Prototype for Supporting Financial Management Skills and Decision Making: A Co-Creation Study with Informal Saving Groups in Dodoma, Tanzania
authors: Madina Hamisi Juma, Nasibu Rajabu Mramba, Jarkko Suhonen, Alsen Florian Kapinga, Matti Tedre
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Women's informal saving groups (ISGs) in Tanzania play a vital role in financial inclusion particularly to the low-income earners. However, limited financial management skills for effective financial decision-making hinder their profitabiliy and sustainability. Traditional training and operaional practice methods often fail to meet their needs due to costs, social, and mobility constraints. This study employed design science research and design thinking methodologies to co-create WanawakeApp, a mobile prototype aimed at supporting financial management and decisionmaking. The findings indicate that the app's enhanced financial record-keeping, loan planning, and fund management are for informed financial decision-making. Women's ISGs expressed satisfaction with the App intuitive interface and context-specific content. The study also revealed that device compatibility, sociocultural factors, and user demographics influenced skill development and app's adoption. Conversely, challenges such as connectivity, digital illiteracy, and high costs posed barriers to effective use. WanawakeApp presents a promising model for strengthening community well-being by mitigating negative impacts of financial mismanagement and created a new pathway for research and innovation using design science research (DSR) in Infomation and communication technology for develpmeng (ICT4D) to empower ISGs and informal workers.

title: Optimal Directional Angle Determination for Multi-Panel Solar Systems in a Dome Configuration to Maximize Energy Output
authors: Firman Kurniawan, Sapto Wibowo, Erfan Rohadi, Yuniarto Agus Winoko, Francisco Marceliano P H
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: This paper focuses on determining the optimal tilt and orientation of solar panels using a dome configuration multi-panel observation device to obtain maximum and stable energy production. Although Indonesia, located on the equator, has high solar energy potential year-round, the performance of solar panels is highly dependent on their position relative to the sun’s path. Unstable and suboptimal energy output can result in inefficient system performance. The proposed dome system utilizes 16 mini solar panels arranged with various tilt (altitude) and direction (azimuth) angles to analyze their energy contributions. After 7 days of testing, the panel at altitude 30° and azimuth -30° produced the highest energy (31.38 Wh), while the lowest was 22.04 Wh at azimuth +30°. This confirms orientation significantly affects energy efficiency. The configuration also achieved stable performance, as seen in standard deviation analysis. This method provides a low-cost alternative to motorized tracking systems that demand reliable and cost-efficient solar energy.

title: Deep Learning for Net Load Forecasting: Double-Layer GRU Model
authors: Xiaojun He, Shizheng Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the transformation of the global energy structure and the accelerated construction of our country's new energy system, the increasing renewable energy introduces significant uncertainty and challenges the net load forecasting in the power system. To this end, this study proposes a net load forecasting method based on the Double-layer Gate Recurrent Unit (GRU), considering the uncertainty of new energy generation and load demand. By deepening the model hierarchy, its processing capability for complex time series data can be effectively enhanced, thereby improving the net load forecasting accuracy and model robustness. The article elaborates on this method's basic principles, implementation process, and training details and compares it with various machine learning and deep learning methods. The simulation results show that the proposed approach demonstrates excellent predictive performance across all evaluation metrics.

title: Attitude Control Method for Fully Actuated AUVs Based on Active Disturbance Rejection Control
authors: Xiang Gao, Wenyu Cai, Jianping Jin, Congfeng Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Improved Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC) algorithm incorporating a modified fal function is proposed for a full freedom Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV). First, the kinematic and dynamic models of the AUV are established. To enhance the attitude stability of the AUV, an improved ADRC method with a modified fal function is designed to achieve stable control of the vehicle’s position and attitude angles. Finally, the improved ADRC technique is compared with both PID control and traditional ADRC under noise disturbance conditions through simulations. The results verify that the improved ADRC outperforms the other two methods, demonstrating its significant performance advantages in attitude control for AUVs.

title: An Ultra High Speed Computation Method for the Reachability Matrix of Undirected Graphs Based on Vertex Sets
authors: Yiguang Fang, Jiehong Xu, Juan Ma, Peiwen Qi
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The reachability matrix computation methods for graphs include adjacency matrix multiplication and the Warshall algorithm, among others. However, both adjacency matrix multiplication and the Warshall algorithm have certain limitations in computational speed. Therefore, this paper proposes an ultra high speed computation method for the reachability matrix of undirected graphs based on vertex sets, targeting the large number of undirected graphs topology analysis tasks in business applications. This paper applies the reflexivity, symmetry and transitivity of undirected graphs to the steps of the Warshall algorithm, and introduces the concepts of “vertex sets” and “vertex sets vector” through theoretical derivation. On this basis, “AND” and “OR” operations on vertex set vectors are used to replace the judgment and execution steps in the Warshall's algorithm, significantly improving the computation speed of the reachability matrix of the undirected graph. In the algorithm design, the concept of “effective rows” is further introduced to improve the performance of the algorithm. The examples in the paper verify the correctness and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Interactive platform for the visual analysis of suspicious communication patterns
authors: Andres De-La-Puente, Juliano Genari, Marcelo Baez, Felipe Moreno-Vera, Jorge Poco
publish: 2025 IEEE Visual Analytics Science and Technology Challenge (VAST Challenge)
abstract: This paper presents a visual analytics system for detecting hidden suspicious activities within communication networks. Developed for the VAST 2025 Challenge, it analyzes two weeks of maritime radio communications using temporal patterns, network and topic modeling, and pseudonym detection. Interactive visualizations reveal covert coordination, thematic clusters, and corruption linked to key individuals, demonstrating an effective approach for intelligence analysis of complex deception networks.

title: Design of a UWB CPW-Fed Monopole Antenna with SMS7630-SC 79LF-Based Rectifier for RF Energy Harvesting in IoT Devices
authors: Akhil T V, Bhavya Kamal K Menon, Aswin Shiju, Ananthasankar U A, Vanilakshmi V, Thomaskutty Mathew
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: This paper emphasizes designing and implementing a Radio Frequency (RF) energy harvesting system for powering low-power IoT-based embedded systems. The proposed rectenna system integrates a CPW-fed monopole antenna, an impedance-matching network, a rectifier circuit, and a load resistor. The antenna is designed to operate across an ultra-wideband (UWB) frequency range spanning 2.2 GHz to 13.7 GHz. Fabricated on an FR4 substrate with dimensions 48.9 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 45 \times 1.6 ~\text{mm}^{3}$</tex>, the antenna exhibits efficient impedance matching, maintaining S11 values below −10 dB throughout the operational bandwidth. This antenna achieves reflection coefficients of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 1 8. 9 5 ~ d B}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 4 5 ~ G H z}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 1 7. 1 4 ~ d B}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5. 8 ~ G H z}$</tex>, corresponding to the Wi-Fi frequencies. CST Microwave Studio was used for the antenna design and performance optimization. The rectifier in this RF energy harvesting system is implemented using the SMS7630 SC-79 Schottky diode, selected for its low barrier height and high-frequency operation capability, supporting frequencies up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 4 ~ G H z}$</tex>.

title: Classification of Sugarcane Leaf Diseases Using Vision Transformers and CNN Models
authors: Piyanuch Silapachote, Ananta Srisuphab, Kongphob Wutthiumphol, Yotsapat Tanprathumwong, Tachin Pohboonchuen
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: A globally prominent economic crop, sugarcane is an indispensable raw material for over 80% of sugar production worldwide. In Thailand, the sugarcane and sugar industry holds a top position in export markets. The loss of sugarcane crops due to diseases is a devastating problem that can never be overstated. Not only does it affect the economy, but it is also the primary source of income for many farmers in the provinces. To prevent a wide spread of any disease, farmers have long been heavily relying on visual inspections and their expertise to detect any signs of disease as early as possible. To assist farmers, this work applied computer vision and machine learning technology to help classifying sugarcane diseases from its leaves. Deployed on mobile devices, our application allows farmers to easily send to our chat-bot a photo of their suspected sugarcane leaves, and get a real-time response specifying the name of the disease or none if it is deemed healthy. Trained and fine-tuned on public data sets, our classifier, which is a vision transformer model, outperformed previous works. Tested on a newly collected local data set, ours achieved a high accuracy 79.64%.
