title: Progress in the Study of Thermal Conductivity Enhancement in Calcium-Based Thermochemical Energy Storage
authors: Jiakang Yao, Guangyao Zhao, Zhehui Zhao, Na Cheng, Sixing Zhang, Zhen Li, Xiaoqiang Zhang, Zongkun Chen, Zhixiang Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In recent years, with the dual carbon target has become the consensus of mankind. Calcium-based thermochemical energy storage (TCES) technology, which can be driven by renewable energy, and it exhibits exceptional volumetric energy density, superior energy transformation efficacy, prolonged storage stability, enhanced operational safety, and remarkable cost-effectiveness. It is considered as a very promising technology for large-scale thermal energy storage (TES). Therefore, calcium-based TCES has become a current research hotspot within the domain of TES technologies. However, In a calcium-based system, the low thermal conductivity(TC) of the heat storage material restricts the overall heat transfer efficiency. so many studies are devoted to enhancing the TC of calcium-based TCES materials to facilitate their real-world utilization. The central objective of this review is to examine the research status of TC enhancement of calcium-based TCES, including material modification and device design optimization. Finally, recommendations for further investigation and technological improvement of calcium-based TCES are provided.

title: Visualization of Skin Care Effectiveness Prediction by Image Generation Using Deep Learning
authors: Aika Kuramoto, Kensuke Yotsumoto, Mizuho Kokubo, Hiroko Kawanobe, Makoto Hasegawa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: The prediction of skin care effects on skin condition and the generation of skin images using artificial intelligence are proposed in this study. Images of various skin conditions taken by subjects are used to train a neural network based on the CycleGAN architecture. When a subject’s skin image is input into a well-trained neural network, a series of images depicting progressively improved skin conditions is generated. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach can generate images showing enhanced skin translucency with continued skin care. This method offers an effective mean to promote the sales of basic cosmetic products and motivate consumers to maintain regular skin care routines.

title: Ontology-Driven Building Operating System Integrated with Large Language Models for Intuitive Building Operations
authors: Yasuhira Chiba, Hangli Ge, Katsutoshi Amano, Noboru Koshizuka
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: The increasing complexity of building management systems demands more intuitive and flexible methods for controlling and monitoring facilities. To address this need, we propose a Building Operating System (BOS) architecture that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) with ontology-driven knowledge graphs, specifically leveraging Brick and RealEstateCore. This integration facilitates intuitive natural-language interactions, dynamically generating SPARQL queries and control commands. We validate our prototype through scenario-based evaluations at two real-world facilities: the Iroribi Tech node and the Daiwa Ubiquitous Computing Research Building at the University of Tokyo. Scenarios included typical operational tasks such as querying HVAC set-points, executing single-device control, and performing group equipment operations. Across these tests, our system consistently achieved a 100 % task success rate, although the observed latency of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20-30$</tex> seconds highlights opportunities for performance optimization. Further demonstrated through case studies involving equipment verification and energy usage analysis, our architecture supports complex operational workflows via straightforward natural-language commands. These results confirm the practical feasibility of the proposed LLM-enabled BOS, lowering operational complexity and reducing the expertise required for effective facility management.

title: Hybrid Logit-Exchange Distillation for Communication-Efficient Federated Learning
authors: Yi-Hong Yeh, Yi-Rui Chiu, Yan-Ci Chen, Chia-I Su, Cheng-Hung Lin, Cheng-Kai Lu, Tzu-Lun Huang, Jia-Kang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: To address the high communication costs in Federated Learning (FL), we propose a Hybrid Logit-Exchange Distillation framework. This method combines efficient logit exchange during most training rounds with a single final round of parameter aggregation. Leveraging a dual-teacher architecture and Layer Selectivity Learning (LSL), the framework effectively trains a lightweight ShuffleNetV2 student model. Experiments on multiple retinal OCT datasets demonstrate that our approach reduces total communication volume by 94.1% compared to the FedAvg baseline, while achieving comparable test accuracy. This hybrid strategy offers a practical balance between communication efficiency and model performance, making it well-suited for resource-constrained FL applications.

title: Comparison of Vector Database Management Systems for Retrieval Augmented Generation
authors: Marko Niinimaki, Sunny Raj Shrestha, Atamfon Udofia
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) is the de-facto technology used by pre-trained large language models to access data in databases, in addition to the data stored in their parameters. Typically, RAG technologies use vector databases. In this paper, we compare two competing vector databases for RAG, one "native" vector database management system and one relational database management system with a vector extension. We concentrate on measuring their performance and relevance in vector similarity search. Our data set consists of 6.1 million Wikipedia abstracts, queried using over 100 000 questions from the MS MARCO data. For each query, we retrieved the abstract that - according to the DBMS's algorithm - most closely matched the query.For the performance evaluation, we executed the queries sequentially on a high-end consumer grade PC. Our tests indicated that the native vector database management system was faster than the vector extension. However, we found that the Hierarchical Navigable Small World (HNSW) indexing and retrieval method used by the vector extension provided better performance than the earlier inverted file method.To evaluate the relevance of the retrieved results, we used a simplistic method of letting OpenAI's GTP-3.5-turbo model assess the quality of each query - answer pair. This test indicated that the native vector database and the HNSW method provided the best results.

title: Counterpoise Cable Modeling Based on an Equivalent Norton Circuit Using Different Pole Selection Approaches
authors: Mateus Linares Silva Sanches, Alberto De Conti, Rafael Alipio
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: This paper presents and compares two approaches for modeling counterpoise cables as buried transmission lines for lightning studies. These approaches consist on applying a rational fitting to either all elements of the bus admittance matrix, or to each element of its equivalent pi-circuit, which are then used to construct an equivalent Norton circuit for time-domain simulations. The lightning transient response of the circuits are simulated, and their performance is evaluated based on the error compared to reference values and the number of poles used in the fittings. The results show that, by applying the rational fitting independently to each admittance element of the circuit, it is possible to reduce the size of the matrices in the calculations without loss of accuracy, demonstrating the efficiency of the model in representing the transient response of grounding electrodes.

title: Brain-computer Collaborative Method for Low Quality Video Object Detection
authors: Manyu Liu, Ying Liu, Xinan Fan, Wenao Han, Luzheng Bi, Weijie Fei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Target detection technology is crucial in various domains. However, traditional detection methods, including manual identification and computer vision (CV), face limitations when dealing with low-quality videos. Brain-computer interface (BCI) technology provide a promising alternative, but still encounter challenges such as high false alarm rates and susceptibility to environmental interference. This paper proposes a brain-computer fusion approach that integrates CV with BCI through a novel video stimulation paradigm. Additionally, an adaptive collaborative framework is introduced, employing a dual-stream fusion architecture with a dynamic adjustment mechanism guided by CV. This method combines the strengths of CV in image processing and target localization with the cognitive advantages of BCI to improve detection performance. The experimental outcomes demonstrate that the proposed fusion approach achieved higher F1-scores and accuracy by substantially reducing false alarm rates. This work not only introduces novel technical insights into the field of video target detection but also highlight the potential of human-machine collaboration to address challenges in automated detection.

title: Dynamic Services-Driven Deployment and Clustering Optimization for Air–Ground Networks: A Multi-Period Hierarchical Game Approach
authors: Haoran Du, Zhibin Feng, Runfeng Chen, Songyi Liu, Hao Han, Yuhua Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Multiple UAVs acting as aerial base stations to provide services to ground users (GUs) have received widespread research attentions. However, the clustering strategies among GUs and the deployment strategies of UAVs commonly require frequent changes due to the dynamic service requirements of GUs. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a joint UAV deployment and GU clustering optimization method, as well as designing a collaborative group-buying mechanism to support GUs with different service types. The joint optimization problem is modeled as a multi-period hierarchical game, where the outer layer is modeled as a UAV deployment game, and the inner layer is modeled as a coalition formation game. Furthermore, a joint optimization algorithm for UAV deployment and GU clustering under energy constraints is designed to obtain the stable solution. Simulation results show that the proposed algorithm reduces UAV energy consumption and increases the total utility of the air-ground network.

title: Automated Ranking of Video Frames Based on Clarity and Face Visibility from Video Datasets
authors: Chandan Kumar, A. Mary Mekala, Ruban Nersisson, Elena E. Lyakso, Olga Frolova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: With the rapid growth of video content, there is a growing need for smart ways to pick out the most useful frames for image processing tasks. This paper introduces a simple yet effective method for automatically extracting and grading frames from a video. The process starts by capturing frames at a low frame rate, either 1 frame per second (fps) or 0.5 fps, based on the user's choice. Each frame is then evaluated in two ways: First, we check how sharp or clear the image is using the Variance of Laplacian (VoL) method. Second, we use MediaPipe Face Mesh to see how well any faces in the frame are visible. These two scores—image clarity and face visibility—are combined using a custom ranking algorithm. Frames that are sharper and show clearer faces are ranked higher. Finally, the frames are saved in a specific folder, sorted from highest to lowest rank, giving you a clean and organized set of frames ready for further image processing work.

title: Modeling and Control of ABE Fermentation Process and Experimental Validation
authors: Michael V George, Mercy Anna Philip, Chandra Shekar Besta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: The acetone-butanol-ethanol (ABE) fermentation process using Clostridium acetobutylicum represents a critical biotechnological pathway for sustainable biofuel production. This paper presents a comprehensive approach to mathematical modelling and Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller design for ABE fermentation systems. The work encompasses detailed kinetic modelling of the fermentation process, systematic identification of process dynamics, and design of robust PID controllers for maintaining optimal fermentation conditions. The proposed methodology includes system identification techniques using step response analysis, controller tuning methods based on Ziegler-Nichols and Cohen-Coon methods, and comprehensive stability analysis through root locus and Bode plot techniques with verified gain and phase margins of 8.2 dB and 52° respectively. Experimental validation was conducted using a 5 -liter bioreactor with Clostridium acetobutylicum ATCC 824 under controlled conditions. The results demonstrate significant improvements in process stability, with substrate utilization efficiency increasing by 23% and product yield enhancement of 18% compared to conventional open-loop control. The PID controller successfully maintained <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p H}$</tex> within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{\pm 0. 1}$</tex> units of the setpoint and temperature within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> throughout the fermentation cycle. The study provides a robust framework for industrial implementation of automated ABE fermentation systems with improved economic viability and process reliability.

title: Enhancing Academic Chatbot Accuracy With Retrieval-Augmented Generation in Higher Education
authors: Putu Adi Surya Artayasa, Aniek Suryanti Kusuma, Putu Sugiartawan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Chatbot systems based on Natural Language Processing (NLP) are increasingly used to support information services, including in academic environments. In this context, students and prospective students often need quick access to information such as class schedules, registration procedures, and academic regulations. This study develops an academic chatbot using the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) method, which retrieves information directly from official institutional documents. The model combines a retriever for document search and a generator to produce responses. The dataset used includes internal academic documents such as course schedules and campus information. The system was evaluated using two metrics: Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR) and Retrieval-Augmented Generation Assessment Score (RAGAS). The average RAGAS score, calculated from four main metrics (faithfulness, answer relevancy, context precision, and context recall), is 84%. For MRR-based evaluation, the average score from MRR, semantic similarity, answer relevancy, and faithfulness is 82%. These results show that the chatbot is capable of providing relevant responses that align well with institutional context.

title: Instantaneous Rotor Position Estimation of a BLDC Motor Using a Low-Resolution Hall Sensor
authors: Shun Mizutani, Fuat Kucuk, Yu Than
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Permanent magnet motors are extensively used in light electric vehicle applications due to their compact size and high efficiency compared to magnet-free motors. High-resolution position sensors, such as encoders and resolvers, are typically required to implement high-performance control techniques. However, these sensors significantly increase the system cost. Hall sensors, while offering a cost-effective alternative, generally provide low resolution and are not directly suitable for high-performance control. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a method based on average velocity to enhance resolution when using Hall sensors, without incurring additional cost. The proposed system was constructed and tested in MATLAB Simulink to estimate the rotor position of a Brushless DC motor. Simulation results demonstrate that the method achieves satisfactory accuracy at medium and high rotational speeds.

title: Robotic Exoskeleton for Hand Rehabilitation Through Assisted Motion in Physiotherapy
authors: Delsen Sabu V, Gayathri K S, Minsa Thomas, Niranjan Das S J, Jemy Jose Kakkassery, S Swapna Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Hand paralysis resulting from stroke or spinal injuries significantly impairs patient mobility, while conventional rehabilitation approaches frequently lack responsive feedback mechanisms. This paper presents a two-phase robotic exoskeleton system designed to overcome these limitations through sensorintegrated, IoT-connected rehabilitation technology. Phase 1 implements a pneumatic glove featuring inflatable air chambers (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-10 \text{psi}$</tex> operational range, 500 ms response time) to facilitate finger flexion and extension exercises, with flex sensors providing continuous motion monitoring. Phase 2 incorporates a stainless steel exoskeleton structure utilizing servo motors (10 kg -cm torque output, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.5^{\circ}$</tex> positioning accuracy) for controlled elbow movement, with joint angles precisely tracked by photoelectric sensors. The system employs an ESP32 microcontroller with IoT capabilities, enabling remote therapy monitoring through a dedicated mobile application. The system integrates pneumatic and servo actuation for upper-limb rehabilitation, real-time motion tracking, and IoT-based remote monitoring. Initial testing confirms reliable joint angle measurement and effective IoT-based supervision capabilities. This wearable robotic system presents a practical solution for enhancing rehabilitation outcomes through technology-assisted therapy.

title: Lateral Stability and Path Tracking Control for Multi-Axle Steering Articulated Vehicles: A Modular Modeling and T-S Fuzzy Control Approach
authors: Yuxin Wang, Fei Ding, Jie Liu, Ningsha Wang, Yanan Yang, Taoyi He
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper proposes a modular modeling and T-S fuzzy ࡴλ control approach for multi-axle steering articulated vehicles (MASAVs), aiming to achieve robust lateral stability and accurate path tracking. First, a 2-DoF dynamic modular model is developed and the position equations of the road and vehicle are utilized to incorporate external disturbances into the vehicle model. Then, a Tensor Product Model Transformation (TPMT) method combined with a T-S fuzzy control strategy is employed to design the ࡴλ controller based on Lyapunov stability theory. Finally, simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach ensures strong robustness and effective trajectory tracking performance under various.

title: Analysis of mathematical approaches for optimizing the route of a passenger ship in order to improve its energy efficiency
authors: Ginka Ivanova, Ilyan Donev, Dimo Dimov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This report assesses the energy efficiency of a passenger ship, identify areas where energy is wasted due to inefficiencies or poor operational practices, propose cost-effective solutions to address these inefficiencies, and recommend measures to optimize its route and reduce fuel consumption and operational performance. The analyses were conducted in accordance with the International Maritime Organization (IMO) guidelines for the Ship Energy Efficiency Management Plan (SEEMP) and the regulatory requirements of MARPOL Annex VI. Based on an improved algorithm for optimizing fuel consumption and navigation time, this report provides an explanation of a multi-criteria method for ship route planning, mainly for passenger ships. The most efficient vessel routing can be obtained by selecting routes with minimal navigation time and low fuel consumption.

title: Estimation of Eddy Current Losses in Power Transformer Windings Through Leakage Flux Analysis using FEM
authors: Patricia Tomalak Liss, João Pedro Pranke Perin, Leonardo Hautrive Medeiros, Vitor Cristiano Bender, Tiago Bandeira Marchesan, Rian Fabich Maie, Silva Pereira Andrey Avila da
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: Transformers are essential components in power systems, with eddy current losses being one of the main factors affecting their efficiency and performance. This work presents a detailed investigation into eddy current losses in power transformer windings, using the finite element method as the primary analysis tool. The study compares different geometric modeling approaches to evaluate their influence on result accuracy. The proposed methodology allows the decomposition of the magnetic field into its axial and radial components, providing a comprehensive analysis of conductor losses. The results compare different levels of geometric detail in the simulations in order to obtain reasonable results with low computational cost.

title: Impact of Export–Import kWh Variations on Rooftop Solar Power Viability in Indonesia within A Techno-Economic Perspective
authors: I Made Agus Sudiartha, Putu Sugiartawan, Aniek Suryanti Kusuma, Aryo De Wibowo Muhammad Sidik, Hamdan Firmansyah, Agus Sudigdo, Amin Ilyas, Ab Christono, Cepi Hanapia, Merda Budiharyono
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Solar energy is a major renewable resource in Indonesia, with great potential due to its widespread availability. To support this, the Indonesian government, through the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources Regulation No. 26 of 2021, has increased the export limit of electricity for PLN customers using rooftop solar power systems from 65% to 100%. This policy change significantly affects both the technical and economic aspects of rooftop solar systems. This study explores the technical performance of rooftop solar systems, including configuration, system size, load demand, energy exports, solar energy fraction, and overall energy production. It also investigates the economic side, looking at initial investment, component costs, operating and maintenance expenses, cash flow, energy costs, ROI, and profitability. The research compares the impact of different export-import kWh percentages on technical parameters such as PV capacity, inverter quantity, excess energy, renewable energy share, and energy metrics, as well as on economic indicators like capital costs, operating expenses, Net Present Cost (NPC), Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCOE), simple payback, and return on investment (ROI). The results show that changing the export-import kWh percentage from 65% to 100% doesn’t impact technical factors like PV capacity, energy surplus, or renewable energy share. However, it does affect economic variables, leading to an operating cost of IDR 4.42 million per year, an NPC of IDR 107 million, an LCOE of IDR 1,084.99/kWh, a payback period of 9.7 years, and a 5.3% ROI. As rooftop solar systems reduce electricity costs, the government’s policy change makes the payback period shorter.

title: Transient Overvoltage Characteristics and Suppression Strategies of Sending-End Grid-Forming Controlled VSC-HVDC Under Fault Conditions
authors: Daye Yang, Hengyue Zhang, Panjie Lian, Wenzhuo Liu, Chao Zheng
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Under large disturbance impacts, the flexible DC system with grid-forming control at the sending-end exhibits mutual coupling effects between converter stations and between converter station and the AC grid, which affects system stability. This paper first investigates the grid-forming VSC-HVDC technology based on virtual synchronous control, analyzes the transient overvoltage characteristics and their generation mechanisms on both the AC and DC sides of grid-forming converter stations during AC faults at the sending and receiving ends, and proposes a transient overvoltage suppression strategy for the VSC-HVDC sending system that considers the control of converter stations at both ends. Finally, based on the electromagnetic transient simulation software PSModel, the simulation model of the grid-forming VSC-HVDC sending system is constructed, verifying the accuracy of the theoretical analysis and the effectiveness of the transient overvoltage suppression strategies.

title: Continuing Successful Low Energy Nuclear Fusion Reaction Experiments
authors: Dimiter Alexandrov, Yordan Paunov, Todor Malchev, Dilyana Gospodinova, Milena Lazarova
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This paper builds on the continuous successful experiments of Low Energy Nuclear Reaction in solids in the Lakehead University’s Semiconductor Research Laboratory. In previous experiments excess heat generation, helium release and correlation between the two have been reported. The current paper aims to investigate the optimal temperature for deuterium-constantan interaction and lead to an increased reaction time and higher generated heat. Three initial temperatures have been tested $-510^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 527^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $535^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Similar reaction patterns have been observed with the first two temperatures and prolonged reaction time with the $\mathbf{5 3 5}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ experiment. From this the conclusion was drawn that this is the temperature where there is most energy release. The massspectroscopic analysis of the gases in the experiments confirms the nuclear origin of the released energy.

title: Optimization of Surface Conductivity of GIL Spacer for Electric Field Regulation Under Electro-Thermal Coupling Field
authors: Bowen Xing, Zhiyi Guo, Jinhui Wei, Yixuan Fang, Jianyi Xue
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The distortion of the electric field at the gas-solid interface is a critical factor in the initiation of surface discharge in DC GIL spacers, consequently reducing their insulation performance. This study proposes an optimization approach for the surface electric field distribution of GIL spacers by applying a surface conductivity gradient under electro-thermal coupling conditions. Analogous to the optimization algorithm of bulk dielectric constant, an iterative optimization algorithm considering the change of conductivity with temperature is developed, with the uniformity of surface electric field under thermal gradient as the optimization goal. The variation of surface conductivity distribution throughout the iterative process is investigated. The impact of various conductivity-temperature parameters on surface charge and electric field distribution is explored. The findings indicate that the suitable sensitivity parameters can homogenize the surface electric field and diminish surface charge accumulation.

title: Detection of LiDAR and Camera Sensor Spoofing in Autonomous Vehicles
authors: E Nithin Neelakandan, Sminesh C N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: LiDAR and camera sensors are essential for environment perception, object detection, and classification in autonomous vehicles, forming the foundation for safe driving decisions. However, these sensors are susceptible to spoofing attacks, which can severely compromise perception modules and lead to unsafe behaviors in autonomous systems. This research investigates the development of a robust and intelligent spoof detection framework by leveraging cross-sensor validation between LiDAR and camera data, enhanced with encryption techniques to protect sensor integrity. The simulations were conducted in the CARLA simulator to acquire synchronized LiDAR and camera data under both normal and spoofed conditions. Spoofing was emulated by injecting manipulated data in real-time. An Isolation Forestbased anomaly detection model served as a baseline to identify suspicious deviations in sensor input. The research was further extended by integrating a ResNet-50 deep learning model for spoof detection, significantly improving detection precision by exploiting rich feature representations from both modalities. A cross-sensor validation mechanism was designed to correlate discrepancies between LiDAR point clouds and camera imagery, thereby increasing the system's robustness across diverse attack vectors. Empirical evaluations show that the proposed system achieved a spoof detection accuracy of 86 %, with precision and recall values of approximately 0.84 and 0.88 respectively. Additionally, the system maintained real-time performance in CARLA, running at over 100 FPS under light sensor loads. The autonomous driving agent completed 95 % of benchmark routes successfully, with minimal infractions. Compared to similar spoof detection frameworks, our method provides a balanced trade-off between detection accuracy and system efficiency, confirming its applicability to real-world autonomous systems.

title: Influence of Cable Termination Loads on Defect Localization Results
authors: Xiaosi Lin, Chaoran Li, Liuhui Cai, Qingbin Guo, Zhijie Cheng, Jiawen Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Broadband Impedance Spectrum (BIS) method is a promising approach for detecting hidden defects in cables. While this method has been extensively researched and applied under open-circuit condition at the cable termination, real-world applications pose challenges when the cable termination load cannot be easily disconnected, potentially affecting the accuracy of current defect localization algorithms. This paper explores the case where the cable termination is connected to purely inductive or capacitive loads, examining how these loads influence the defect localization accuracy when disconnection is infeasible. The goal of this paper is to broaden the applicability of impedance spectrumbased defect localization techniques, allowing them to handle more complex real-world scenarios.

title: Complete Covertness In NOMA Using Artificial Noise
authors: Nikola Zlatanov
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: We consider the situation where a transmitter communicates with a legitimate receiver and at the same time aims to send a covert message to a covert receiver while ensuring that the covert message is non-detectable at a third receiver, referred to as the warden. The considered system belongs to the class of non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) systems. For the considered NOMA system, we show that it is possible to achieve complete covertness, i.e., the error detection probability at the warden to be one, using artificial noise generated at the transmitter. Depending on the power of the artificial noise, there is a trade-off between the data rate achieved at the legitimate receiver and the covert data rate achieved at the covert receiver, while ensuring complete covertness.

title: Bottom-up Analysis of the Impact of Single-Event Effects in a CNN Hardware Accelerator using Laser testing
authors: S. Achaq, V. Pouget, L. Artola, F. Manni, A. Dufour, J. Boch
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: We present laser testing results on the AIEngines array of the 7nm Versal device used in the context of the hardware acceleration of a convolutional neural network application. The first stages of errors propagation are analyzed by testing benchmarks accelerating elementary operations in CNN: The convolutions and data transfer.

title: Additive Fan-Out Packaging for Discrete Components
authors: Edsger C. P. Smits, Arjun Wadhwa, Milan Saalmink, Marieke Burghoorn, Iris Kerkhof, Ruben Pranger, Frans Meeuwsen, Francesca Chiappini, Jeroen van den Brand
publish: 2025 IEEE CPMT Symposium Japan (ICSJ)
abstract: The additive fan-out technology presented herein integrates advanced packaging technology with printed electronics to enable packaging in a cost-effective manner. We explore the application of the additive fan-out process to realize clip based DFN56 packages.

title: Comparative Study of Ensemble Learning for Predictive Maintenance in HDD Manufacturing
authors: Saisuda Nantalek, Sarayut Nonsiri, Annop Monsakul
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: Thailand is a major hub for hard disk drive (HDD) manufacturing, where maintaining high equipment reliability is essential for product quality and export readiness. Critical testing machines, such as the Guzik Signal Analyzer (GSA 6000 Series) and the Read-Write Analyzer (4000 TDMR Series), can experience performance issues over time due to environmental changes and prolonged use. This paper presents a predictive maintenance (PdM) framework using ensemble machine learning models to predict equipment failures based on sensor data, particularly temperature readings. There are 6 models such as XGBoost, LightGBM, AdaBoost, CatBoost, Gradient Boosting Tree, and Bagging were trained on a real dataset. The Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) was used to handle class imbalance. Among all models, XGBoost achieved the best performance with 98.91% accuracy, 98.91% precision, 98.91% recall, F1-score 98.91% and an AUC of 0.9995. The proposed PdM system enables early fault detection, reduces unplanned downtime, and improves overall production efficiency.

title: A Serverless Federated Learning Framework with Blockchain and Homomorphic Encryption
authors: Shahid Latif, Djamel Djenouri, Jawad Ahmad
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: Traditional federated learning (FL) architectures are vulnerable to significant security risks. Centralized servers create single points of failure and are susceptible to adversarial attacks such as model poisoning. Additionally, they lack auditability and do not provide cryptographic privacy during model aggregation. This paper proposes a serverless FL framework that integrates blockchain technology with CKKS homomorphic encryption to address these challenges. The framework utilizes a decentralized consensus mechanism based on Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT), eliminating the need for a central coordinator and ensuring robustness against Byzantine faults. It incorporates CKKS encryption to enable secure aggregation through computation on encrypted gradients, preserving data privacy throughout the training process. Furthermore, it introduces an auditable trust management system using smart contracts for immutable logging and decentralized reputation tracking. Experimental results on the MNIST dataset, with $20 \%$ malicious clients, demonstrate that the framework achieves a final global accuracy of $98.68 \%$ and attains $100 \%$ precision in rejecting malicious updates without false positives. The computational overhead remains practical, with encryption and consensus times of 0.814 sec and 1.695 $ms$ per round, respectively. Compared to existing methods, the proposed approach improves accuracy by $1.68 \%$ to $10.68 \%$, demonstrating its effectiveness in enabling secure and privacypreserving FL.

title: Web Service Based on OpenPose and MocapNET for Human Motion Generation from 360VR Videos
authors: Yoshihiro Okada, Kanji Nagayama, Hiroshi Kisanuki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: This paper treats a web service based on OpenPose and MocapNET for human motion analysis of 360VR videos. The authors have already proposed frameworks for VR tours of 360VR images/videos. VR tours of 360VR images/videos are effective as educational materials of exercise/experiment courses because such VR tours are useful for understanding the processes and procedures of the target exercise/experiment beforehand. Also, the authors proposed a framework for multi-location 360VR videos. If the framework can give students any comments like advice as analysis results of human motion in the videos, the educational efficiency will grow. Therefore, the authors have been making a motion generation service using OpenPose nad MocapNET as the first stage of the human motion analysis. Although OpenPose and MocapNET are ones of the most recognizing 2D and 3D pose estimation tools, users need to prepare high performance computer including high performance GPU and install many program codes including many dependent libraries. This is not kind to novice users like university teachers. Therefore, the authors are trying to prepare the functionality of motion generation from 360VR videos as a web service using OpenPose and MocapNET. In this paper, the authors explain how OpenPose and MocapNET work collaboratively on the web server and show some motion generation examples and performance results.

title: Factors Affecting the Results of Field Measurements of Soil Electrical Properties in the kHz–MHz Range
authors: Dmitry Kuklin, Evgeniya Borozdina
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: The purpose of this work is to evaluate how electromagnetic effects in field measurements affect the apparent soil electrical properties at frequencies ranging from a few hundred kHz to several MHz. The influence of several factors on the measurement results was investigated numerically. The following factors were considered: different electrode arrangements of the perpendicular dipole-dipole array, wire height, location of the current source and the voltage probe, and length of the rods. The simulation results have shown that all of the above factors can affect the apparent properties to varying degrees. It was suggested that the forward model could also include the measurement setup (in addition to the soil itself) to improve the accuracy of the apparent properties in the simulations. A simple correction was proposed to reduce the high-frequency effects in the apparent properties.

title: High-Thermal-Conductivity GFRP for Dry-Type Air-Core Reactors: Thermal and Electrical Characterization
authors: Yanze Song, Qiqiang Chen, Jun Xie, Guishu Liang, Qijun Duan, Haooou Ruan, Yuyao Zhong, Qing Xie
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: This study systematically investigates the thermal conductivity, dielectric properties, and temperature distribution of high-thermal-conductivity glass fiber reinforced composites (HTC-GFRP) used in dry-type air-core reactors through a combination of experimental measurements and multiphysics simulations. Results demonstrate that enhancing the thermal conductivity of the epoxy matrix—particularly by increasing alumina particle content—significantly improves the overall thermal performance of HTC-GFRP. When the alumina content exceeds 50 wt%, particles begin to form continuous thermally conductive pathways, further facilitating heat transfer. However, this thermal enhancement is accompanied by a degradation in electrical performance, notably in reduced flashover voltage and breakdown electric field strength. The dielectric constant of HTC-GFRP exhibits a strong positive correlation with thermal conductivity, while the dielectric loss tangent initially increases but subsequently declines at excessively high thermal conductivities. Moreover, improved thermal conductivity leads to a more uniform temperature distribution within the reactor, lowers peak temperatures, enhances cooling efficiency, and ultimately extends the service life and reliability of the equipment.

title: EV Aggregation and Low-Carbon Scheduling in Virtual Power Plant: A Zonotope-Based Approach
authors: Yongji Ma, Huifang Wang, Qi Zhang, Jianan Yu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: With the rise of distributed energy resources (DERs) and electric vehicles (EVs), virtual power plants (VPPs) offer a scalable solution for flexible and low-carbon power system operations. This paper proposes a Zonotope-based aggregation and scheduling framework for VPPs, enabling efficient modeling of dynamic feasible regions for EV charging stations (EVCSs), distributed energy storage systems and generators. Minkowski-sum-based Zonotope approximation supports high-dimensional resource aggregation, while a carbon-electricity market coupling mechanism introduces dynamic carbon signals to guide low-carbon EV scheduling and power-transportation coupling. The proposed method enhances aggregation efficiency, reduces emissions, and supports economic VPP operation.

title: Design and Development of a User-Centric Dashboard and Mobile Interface for Real Time Municipal Wastewater Monitoring System
authors: Thongchai Yooyativong, Sujitra Arwatchananukul, Chayapol Kamyod, Prasara Jakkaew, Catarina Magdaleno Roquette, Taksakorn Sittiwong
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: The integration of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies in municipal wastewater systems enables real-time environmental monitoring through diverse IoT devices. Many non-technical users are prevented from obtaining the given solutions by poor interface design and limited usability. This paper presents a user-centric dashboard and mobile interface for real-time wastewater monitoring, designed in line with the Chiang Rai Municipal IoT Wastewater Treatment Facility in Thailand. Working together to gather, process, and display water quality data, the system comprises a Home Assistant-based server, ESP32 microcontrollers, industrial-grade dissolved oxygen (DO), pH, water temperature sensors and WiFi-5G network. Incorporating multilingual compatibility, mobile accessibility, color-coded alerts, and a simple design to improve user comprehension, the user interface follows human-computer interaction (HCI) concepts. While generating low latency performance and obtaining high satisfaction ratings from both municipal personnel and public stakeholders, the system achieved 95% uptime during field deployment. By means of user-centric interfaces that can be made both technically strong and socially accessible, the project demonstrates a practical way for designing user-centric interface IoT systems, therefore uniting technical strength with social accessibility to enable smart city development.

title: Ventilation System Design for Metal Preparation Workshop within a Hot-Dip Galvanizing Facility
authors: George Tomov, Ana Borissova
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This study addresses the high energy consumption of ventilation systems in hot-dip galvanizing workshops, where corrosive and toxic fumes are generated during steel preparation. While existing solutions improve efficiency under normal operating conditions, they often overlook emergency scenarios critical for worker safety. The proposed approach develops a rational ventilation strategy that optimizes energy use while ensuring effective protection during both routine and emergency operations.

title: PLVS: A Documentation and Exploration System for Data Provenance, Lineage, and Versioning
authors: Michael Gysel, Sangeetha Reji, Muhammad Ahtisham Aslam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Data is amongst an organization's most valuable assets, and global dataspaces aim to unlock its value through secure sharing and exchange. A key challenge in building these data marketplaces is providing transparent access to data assets that undergo continuous changes by multiple actors throughout their lifecycle. This resulting provenance, lineage, and versioning information offers insights into a data asset's history and quality, but often goes untracked. To address these challenges, we developed Provenance, Lineage, and Versioning System (PLVS), a W3C PROV-compliant system that captures standardized provenance and lineage metadata (who performed which operations and when) and detects precise differences between dataset versions. PLVS provides an interactive graphical interface for provenance and lineage exploration and version comparison; RESTful APIs for provenance and lineage metadata and dataset version comparison data; and semantic graph-based storage to store this provenance and lineage metadata using the W3C PROV Data Model (W3C PROV-DM). We validated PLVS with Smart Cities use cases in the PISTIS Horizon Europe project, demonstrating its effectiveness in improved data transparency and trustworthiness, data quality assessments, error detection and correction, and auditability in federated dataspaces.

title: Inspection Technology for Small Fixed-Wing UAV Clusters
authors: Luo Long, Zhao Yu, Zhao Xiaomeng, Zhang Xiaozu, Huang Jingzhe
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the continuous growth of electricity demand, the scale of transmission lines has been expanding, putting forward higher requirements for the efficiency and reliability of transmission operation and maintenance. Traditional inspection methods have become difficult to meet current needs, and the inspection technology of small fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) clusters has emerged as the times require, becoming a key breakthrough point for improving the level of transmission operation and maintenance. This article deeply analyzes the technical principle of this technology, expounds its advantages by combining with practical application cases, explores the challenges faced and development trends, aiming to provide a comprehensive and in-depth technical reference for the field of transmission operation and maintenance, and to promote the technological innovation and development of the industry.

title: Human-centered Sequential Load Restoration in Transmission Networks using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Kasra Mazarei Saadabadi, Hamidreza Nazaripouya, Alfredo Martinez-Morales
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Green Energy and Smart Systems (GESS)
abstract: This paper proposes a human-centered Q-learning framework for transmission-level load restoration that jointly maximizes recovered load and enforces history-aware equity across load buses. At each step, the agent reconnects a damaged line; a DC optimal power flow recomputes a feasible re-dispatch subject to power-balance, generator, and line-flow limits. The state encodes the current topology, remaining outages, and cumulative per-bus satisfaction/dissatisfaction histories, where satisfaction equals the fraction of each bus’s load that is restored and dissatisfaction is its complement. Equity is promoted through a pairwise cosine-similarity fairness index computed over the satisfaction/dissatisfaction vectors of all buses; the reward increases with incremental load recovery and gains in this index, discouraging polarized outcomes in which one bus is fully served while another is hardly served. Verification on the IEEE 14-bus and 30-bus systems under scenarios with ten disconnected lines compares the proposed agent against a standard Q-learning baseline without fairness, using total restored energy and the fairness index as metrics. Results show consistently higher fairness throughout the restoration trajectory with negligible change in total restored energy, demonstrating a tunable efficiency–equity trade-off.

title: An Engineering-Oriented Control Design and Verification for Fixed-Wing UAVs Based on ADRC
authors: Huaxin Liang, Zeyu Jin, Kai Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: A control scheme is designed for fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicles with conventional layouts to optimize traditional longitudinal control strategies while enhancing system robustness. Active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) is employed to replace the inner loop of Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control. Starting with mathematical modeling, a mathematical simulation environment is established, and finally, the engineering adaptability of the control scheme is verified in a hardware-in-the-loop environment, with a simultaneous comparison of control quality.

title: Safety-Critical Model Predictive Trajectory Tracking Control for Transformer Inspection Robots Based on Control Barrier Functions
authors: Lai Wei, Yiwei Liao, Juntong Liu, Songyi Dian
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper investigates a safety-critical model predictive control (MPC) method for the trajectory tracking of a transformer inspection robot. To cast the tracking problem into a standard MPC scheme, the spatial reference trajectory is lifted to the full state according to the robot kinematics, which facilitates the subsequent controller design. Considering that safety must be guaranteed in a cluttered, confined workspace, a discrete-time control barrier function (CBF) is introduced to define a controlled safe set with respect to internal components and obstacles, and the resulting CBF inequality is embedded in the MPC optimization. Simulation studies on two scenarios demonstrate precise tracking, consistent positive clearance, and automatic return to the nominal path after avoidance, which verifies the effectiveness of the proposed CBF-MPC method.

title: Simulation-Enabled Closed-Loop Static-Dynamic Co-Optimization for Grid-Impact-Aware Microgrid Dispatch
authors: Chenghao Lyu, Yilin Bai, Jiahui Gong, Yuchen Zhao, Jinhao Meng, Zhengxiang Song
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: The increasing penetration of distributed energy resources within industrial microgrids poses new challenges for day-ahead dispatch. Purely economic schedules can treat the grid stability, while isolated dynamic real-time control fails to influence planning stage decisions. This paper develops a unified, closed-loop optimization framework that couples static planning indicators with dynamic performance metrics via a digital twin simulation process. Three cases are compared to illustrate the necessity of static-dynamic coupled indicators and the closed-loop optimization. Results show that static coupling reduces grid-impact by 82 % and at a 2.3 % cost premium, while closed-loop coupling further reduces impact by 2 % and reduces frequency recovery time, all with neutral or reduced cost. The proposed methodology delivers Pareto-optimal schedules that balance economic efficiency and real-time stability under realistically simulated operating conditions.

title: Two-Layer Soil Influence on Lightning-Induced Transients in Overhead Lines
authors: Jesus E. Guevara Asorza, Theofilos A. Papadopoulos, Walter Luiz Manzi de Azevedo, Anderson Ricardo Justo de Araújo, Jaimis S. L. Colqui, José Pissolato Filho
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: Soil stratification critically impacts the lightning-induced electromagnetic transient (EMT) responses of overhead transmission lines (OHTLs). Although homogeneous earth models are commonly used for their simplicity, they fail to account for the effects of layered soils. This study assesses the performance of various earth modeling approaches—including the generalized two-layer earth model, two equivalent homogeneous earth models (EHEMs) based on the earth propagation constant and conductivity equivalents, and homogeneous models using individual layer resistivities. These approaches are evaluated to estimate key lightning-related metrics such as overvoltages, critical current, backflashover rate, and surge arrester energy. Time-domain simulations under representative soil conditions show that the EHEM based on propagation constant equivalent best balances accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: A Transformerless Dual-Active Half-Bridge Converter with Variable Inductance for Stand-Alone Lighting Applications
authors: Conrado Gomes Marques, João Pedro Scherer Cipriani, Leandro Roggia, Álysson Raniere Seidel
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: This paper investigates the use of a Variable Inductor (VI) in a Dual Active Half Bridge Transformer-Less (DAHBTL) converter for stand-alone public lighting applications. The bidirectional converter operates in two modes: LED driving at night and battery charging during the day. When combined with the Phase Shift modulation, the VI introduces an additional degree of freedom, overcoming efficiency limitations across a wide load range, extending the ZVS region under light-load conditions and significantly reduces circulating reactive energy (current stress) during high-load conditions. Experimental results with a 150 W prototype confirm the feasibility of the proposed approach in both operating modes.

title: LoomLen: A Real-Time Collaborative Note-Taking Application for Mobile and Tablet Devices
authors: Pisit Thitiakkarasak, Tawat Suriyo, Supakorn Jensawaspong, Sansiri Tarnpradab
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: LoomLen is a collaborative note-taking application designed to enhance real-time cooperation among students using mobile devices. The system enables multiple users to write, draw, and edit notes simultaneously, supported by a cloud-based NoSQL database and real-time synchronization via WebSocket. Features include document sharing, handwriting recognition using ML Kit, and access control management. LoomLen aims to improve classroom engagement and the overall learning experience through an intuitive and responsive interface optimized for both smartphones and tablets. User feedback indicates that the application is well-suited for implementation in real educational settings and provides valuable insights into maintenance and the addition of new features in future development phases.

title: Adaptive Aggregation for Distributed Industrial Control Systems Anomaly Detection
authors: Mirkhon Nurullaev
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: Industrial Control Systems (ICS) increasingly face sophisticated cyber attacks that individual facilities cannot detect in isolation. While collaborative anomaly detection could significantly improve threat identification, it requires sharing sensitive operational data between potentially competing organizations, raising privacy concerns. Moreover, ICS operate under strict real-time constraints where traditional privacy-preserving mechanisms introduce unacceptable latency. This paper presents an adaptive aggregation framework that dynamically balances privacy and detection latency based on operational context and threat levels. Our key insight is that privacy-performance trade-offs need not be static; by adapting parameters to current conditions, we achieve both strong privacy during normal operations and rapid detection during critical threats. Our work shows that adaptive mechanisms can transcend traditional privacy-performance trade-offs, enabling secure collaboration among industrial competitors while maintaining operational confidentiality and real-time requirements essential for critical infrastructure protection. The work presented here represents a crucial step toward practical, privacy-preserving collaborative security for critical infrastructure, demonstrating that the traditional trade-off between privacy and performance can be effectively managed through intelligent, context-aware adaptation.

title: Task Unloading and Resource Allocation in a Centralised Control System
authors: Xunting Wang, Cheng Xie, Lingzhi Xia, Jianlin Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To address the demand for efficient processing of massive tasks in centralized control systems, this paper proposes a joint optimization method for dynamic task offloading and resource allocation. The model makes intelligent offloading decisions based on task size, real-time requirements, and network topology location, and collaboratively optimises communication and computing resource allocation. By constructing a delay-energy joint optimisation model with a fusion topology structure, the problem is formalised as a mixed-integer nonlinear programming problem, and an efficient decomposition algorithm is designed for solution. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces system overhead (the weighted sum of delay and energy consumption) and effectively improves task completion rate, providing an efficient and low-power task processing solution for centralized control systems.

title: Active Power Oscillation Suppression Strategy for Grid-Forming Converter Based on Feedforward Control
authors: Yang Shang, Lidong Wang, Guangya Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Grid-forming (GFM) converters are susceptible to low-frequency oscillations in their active power output during grid-connected operation. This paper proposes an active power feedforward control strategy to suppress these active power oscillations. Firstly, the mechanism behind the active power oscillations and its relationship with grid strength are investigated through small-signal modeling. Subsequently, by equivalently transforming the control structure of the active power loop and incorporating a proportional feedforward term, a control effect analogous to differential feedforward is achieved. This method enhances the system stability margin and mitigates active power oscillations under various grid strength conditions. Finally, experimental results validate the correctness of the theoretical analysis and demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: HAD-5G: A Hybrid Deep Learning Approach for Multiclass Attacks Classification
authors: Nawal Rifka Annisa, Ntivuaguruzwa Jean De La Croix, Tohari Ahmad, Jennifer Batamuliza, Abdulati K S Jahbel, Radityo Anggoro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The rapid evolution of mobile telecommunications demands high speed and low latency environments, positioning Fifth Generation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(5 \mathrm{G})$</tex> networks at the forefront of technological advancement. Despite offering significant performance enhancements, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> introduces new security challenges, particularly at the application layer. While several studies have proposed attack detection systems for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> networks, many have not been evaluated using datasets explicitly designed for 5G environments and often overlook the issue of classification imbalance. To address these gaps, this article proposes HAD-5G, a hybrid deep learning (DL) model for multiclass attack detection in 5G networks. HAD-5G utilises Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architectures to analyze payload data for effective intrusion detection. The experimentation of the HAD5D evaluates two CNN configurations, namely, Flatten and Global Average Pooling. The results demonstrate that the LSTM + CNN (Flatten) architecture achieves superior performance, with 99.98% accuracy, 99.73% precision, 99.72% recall, and a 99.71 % F1-score, highlighting its potential for robust security in 5G applications.

title: Development of a Smart Headband for Non-Invasive Monitoring of Vital Signs
authors: Teodor-Emilian Petre, Rodica-Claudia Constantinescu, Bogdan Alexandrescu, Ionuț-Cosmin Dinuț
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: This paper showcases a use-case of Development of a Smart Headband for Non-Invasive Monitoring of Vital Signs, a wearable system for monitoring athletes' vital signs in real time. The smart band integrates both biomedical and environmental sensors, including the MAX30101 for heartbeat rate and oxygen saturation (SpO2), the MLX90614 infrared sensor for non-contact body temperature measurements, and the BME280 for atmospheric pressure, humidity and ambient temperature. The entire system is managed by an AVR64DD32 8-bit microcontroller, which is used to read and process the sensor data and then to transmit wirelessly via a HC- 05 Bluetooth module. Processed information is sent to an external terminal device, where it can be real-time displayed and monitored. The system was tested on human-subjects during physical exercises, and the results were analyzed to validate and tune the sensor accuracy and overall system performance and stability. Test measurements confirmed consistent biometric tracking and reliable alerts triggering in different predictions. This approach represents a low-cost, compact, and energyefficient wearable prototype which provided a practical solution for non-invasive monitoring of vital signs in athletic environments, supporting performance optimization in training and health tracking.

title: Cyber-Threat Detection for Distributed Control against FDIA in Energy System
authors: Ziyang Wang, Shaohua Yang, Hongxun Hui, Ye Chen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Distributed control has been widely applied in fields such as energy and aviation sector, and with its advantage of aggregating resources to form autonomous regions, it has evolved into a critical control technology. However, its open communication architecture exposes the distributed control system to false data injection attacks (FDIA) through multiple paths, including communication links, sensors, and controllers, leading to potential system oscillations. Therefore, there is an urgent need to detect cyber-attacks from multiple paths. To address this issue, this paper first establishes a distributed control framework for energy system, with modeling of three types of attack paths. Consequently, a reconstruction-based method is presented to identify FDIA through time-frequency masking autoencoders (TFMAE) technology. Finally, the effectiveness of detection is validated by the case studies in a simulated distributed control system, demonstrating that the detector can detect dynamic FDIA events across multiple attack paths and achieve over 95.2% precision.

title: Multi-system Network RTD Positioning for Resource-Constrained Unmanned Platforms
authors: Qishun Ran, Gang Liu, Zongqi Yu, Xiaowei Cui, Mingquan Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) observations-based Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) technique can provide centimeter-level accuracy positioning to users. However, degraded observation quality makes the ambiguity resolution become more time-consuming, which is particularly problematic for the unmanned platforms with limited computational resources. To address this problem, we design a network RTD positioning algorithm based on the virtual reference station (VRS) technology. Specifically, the pseudorange measurements from multiple base stations are employed to generate observations to a VRS located near the rover. These virtual measurements are then transmitted to rover for RTD positioning. Static data and kinematic data are used to assess the performance of the proposed algorithm. The static test shows that positioning accuracy of the Network RTD is slightly superior to that of the normal RTD, but marginally inferior to that of the RTK float solutions. However, the average consumption time for per Network RTD solution ( about 2.6 milliseconds) is about 57.4% lower than that of the RTK solution (about 6.1 milliseconds). The kinematic test demonstrates that the proposed Network RTD achieves decimeter-level accuracy in dynamic environments.

title: Comprehensive Analysis of Grid Suitability for Integrating Grid-Forming SVG and STATCOM in New Energy Power Station
authors: Hongqiao Yin, Wu Cao, Liqun Sun, Shibo Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: With the large-scale integration of renewable energy, issues such as reduced system inertia and weakened voltage/angle stability are becoming critical. Grid-Following (GFL) SVG, Grid-Forming (GFM) SVG, and static synchronous compensator (STATCOM) are emerging voltage support devices to enhance system static voltage stability and transient fault ride-through capability. This paper develops mathematical models for the three devices and analyzes their performance in inertia response, fault ride-through, and sub-synchronous oscillation suppression. Simulation results show that both GFM SVG and STATCOM can effectively suppress sub-synchronous oscillations. However, GFM SVG, constrained by limited DC-side energy storage, have limited inertia response, while synchronous condensers with supercapacitors provide better low-latency inertia response and instantaneous voltage support.

title: M-GenCheck: Detecting Portrait AI-Generated Images Using Deep Learning in a Streamlit Web Application
authors: Nontawat Thongsibsong, Thanpahtt Chaichombhoo, Surapol Vorapatratorn
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: The proliferation of generative artificial intelligence (AI) has introduced unprecedented challenges in discerning synthetic visual content from authentic imagery, raising critical concerns in domains such as education, digital journalism, and media forensics. This study proposes M-GenCheck, a web-based, real-time image authenticity detection system employing convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to classify portrait images as either AI-generated or camera-captured. The model was trained on a balanced and diverse dataset comprising 2,000 images sourced from state-of-the-art generative models (e.g., MidJourney, Stable Diffusion) and publicly available real-image datasets, including PIQ2023 and student-contributed M-Stock photographs. A comprehensive evaluation was conducted using both algorithmic benchmarks and a human perception study involving 177 participants. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms human evaluators in accuracy, achieving 90.0% on the training set and 80.0% on unseen images. Moreover, the system was deployed via a Streamlit-based web interface to facilitate real-time public usage. Analysis of misclassified samples reveals the inherent challenges in detecting high-fidelity synthetic content, underscoring the necessity for continual refinement. The findings affirm the system’s efficacy and highlight the growing disparity between human perception and machine-based forensic capability in AI-era media contexts.

title: MSDA-UNet: Dynamic Fusion and Attention for Enhanced UNet Abdominal Multi-Organ Segmentation on Synapse
authors: Zhigao Zeng, Yuming Du, Shengqiu Yi, Xinpan Yuan, Qiang Liu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Accurate segmentation of medical images is crucial for quantitative analysis and treatment planning. Although U-Net and its attention-enhanced variants have achieved strong results, they often do not fully exploit multi-scale contextual information and still rely on static convolutional kernels, which limits adaptability to complex and deformable anatomy. To address these limitations, we propose a Multi-Scale Dynamic Attention U-Net (MSDA-UNet). At critical skip connections, we insert Multi-Scale Dynamic Attention (MSDA) modules, each comprising: (i) a dynamic convolution branch that generates multiple sets of kernels and adaptively fuses them based on global feature statistics; and (ii) a lightweight channel attention branch jointly with a spatially adaptive dynamic convolution branch, providing channel-spatial feature recalibration of the fused features. Injecting MSDA modules at both shallow and deep encoder stages enables MSDA-UNet to capture local details and global semantics across scales, thereby improving feature discriminability and boundary precision. On the Synapse multi-organ benchmark, MSDA-UNet improves Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) by 8.60% and reduces Hausdorff Distance (HD) by 4.86mm over the baseline U-Net while maintaining comparable complexity, validating the effectiveness and practical utility of the proposed method.

title: Review of Spacecraft Pose-Estimation Techniques for Close-Proximity Operations
authors: Kenny Vishal, Vishnu G Nair, Jeane Marina D’souza
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The accurate estimation of spacecraft pose during close-proximity operations is a fundamental capability required for various space missions, including on-orbit servicing, debris management, and formation flying. This review provides a comprehensive overview of the latest techniques employed in spacecraft pose estimation, highlighting both cooperative and non-cooperative scenarios. We discuss a range of algorithmic approaches and sensor technologies, focusing on electro-optic sensors that meet the power and size limitations of modern satellites. The paper further explores the integration of Deep Learning (DL) methodologies, which are gaining traction due to their potential to enhance pose estimation precision. However, significant hurdles remain, including high computational demands and the challenges of transferring learning from synthetic datasets to real-world applications. The paper also emphasizes significant obstacles in determining spacecraft orientation, including variable illumination conditions, computational limitations, and restricted available data. Through an evaluation of current methodologies and the identification of areas necessitating further investigation, this survey aims to advance the development of more robust, efficient, and reliable autonomous navigation systems for future space missions. This research supports SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure) by advancing autonomous navigation technologies for safer and more efficient space operations. Enhanced spacecraft pose estimation facilitates responsible space sustainability (SDG 12) through enabling satellite life extension and debris mitigation, and contributes to SDG 13 (Climate Action) by improving precision in satellite-based Earth observation and environmental monitoring.

title: Selective Space Harmonics Suppression for Rotor Eddy Current Losses Mitigation in Dual-Stator Axial Flux Permanent Magnet Machines
authors: Junwei Wang, Bing Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: Dual-stator axial flux permanent magnet (DS-AFPM) machines with fractional-slot concentrated windings (FSCW) have attracted considerable attention owing to their high power density. Nevertheless, the abundant harmonic content of the stator magnetomotive force (MMF) leads to severe rotor eddy current losses. To address this issue, this study analyzes the stator MMF under various pole-slot combinations and employs an equivalent current-sheet model to identify the harmonics that dominate rotor losses. A selective space harmonics suppression method is then proposed by introducing mechanical angular offsets between the two stators. The optimal offset angle, determined by the pole-slot combinations, effectively suppresses the dominant loss-inducing harmonics while preserving the working harmonic. Furthermore, the overall performance of a 24-slot/20-pole DS-AFPM machine with and without stator offset is compared, including back electromotive force (EMF), torque, and rotor eddy current losses. Finally, temperature field analysis and prototype experiments confirm that the proposed method substantially reduces rotor eddy current losses without degrading electromagnetic performance.

title: Welcoming Remarks
authors: Erold Naomab
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: I am honoured to welcome everyone to the Namibia University of Science and Technology (NUST) for the 5th International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC). This hybrid event is scheduled to take place from August 5 to 7, 2025, and is organised by the UNESCO Chair on Secure High-Performance Computing for Higher Education and Research within NUST's Faculty of Computing and Informatics, under the leadership of Prof. Dharm Singh Jat. The conference is technically co-sponsored by the IEEE South Africa Section and is supported by IEEE Region 8. This platform provides a truly unique and invaluable opportunity for us to come together-bringing diverse perspectives, expertise, and passion to collaboratively shape the future of sustainable development. By fostering innovation, dialogue, and shared commitment, we can drive meaningful progress toward creating a more equitable, resilient, and environmentally responsible world for generations to come.

title: Learning Perceptive Legged Robot Locomotion in the Real World: A Systematic Review
authors: Irfan Tito Kurniawan, Wei Zhu, Dai Owaki, Mitsuhiro Hayashibe
publish: IEEE Robotics & Automation Magazine
abstract: Perception is essential for legged locomotion as it enables robots to anticipate upcoming terrains and obstacles, facilitating adaptive traversal of challenging environments. Recent advancements in learning methodologies and legged locomotion have fostered research on the integration of perception into legged robot locomotion controllers, allowing them to operate effectively in a variety of real-world environments that are inaccessible to wheeled or tracked robots. This review aims to summarize recent developments in perceptive legged robot locomotion and identify potential future research directions. Specifically, we restrict our scope to studies employing learning-based techniques. We examine two primary topics: 1) the applications and capabilities afforded by perceptive locomotion and 2) the methodologies for integrating perception into locomotion systems. We survey the characteristics, progress, and challenges associated with each application and methodology as well as the decisions involved. Finally, we provide a comprehensive overview of the current challenges and potential future research perspectives in perceptive legged robot locomotion.

title: Comparison of the Characterization of Aggregates for Asphalt Mixtures Using the Marshall and Superpave Criteria
authors: Abdiel Rodriguez, Ashley Rivas, Airam Morales
publish: 2024 International Congress of Science and Technology for Sustainable Development (CITDES)
abstract: The design of asphalt mixtures for pavements requires careful selection and evaluation of the stone aggregates that make up most of the mixture. The properties of the aggregates, such as particle size distribution, angularity, particle shape, wear resistance and cleanliness, significantly influence the performance and durability of the asphalt layer. This research focused on evaluating and comparing the granulometric requirements of stone aggregates in the Marshall and Superpave methods for the design of asphalt mixtures, using coarse and fine aggregates from the Howard quarry, located in Panama, evaluating their properties. The specifications and granulometric control criteria established in each method were analyzed, according to the current regulations of the Ministry of Public Works, with the objective of identifying the differences in the granulometry requirements for the aggregates between both methods. The results showed that the fine aggregates satisfactorily met the requirements of both methods. However, the percentage of flat and elongated particles in the coarse aggregates did not meet the stricter requirement of a maximum of 10 % for the Superpave method, although it did meet the maximum 25 % for the Marshall method. This suggests that the Marshall method could be more viable for designing asphalt mixtures with these materials, since it evaluates the combination of aggregates in a more general way. However, the final selection of the method should consider other factors such as expected traffic, climatic conditions and local regulations

title: SoundWeaver: Visual Analysis Of Musical Connections
authors: Süreyya Dağdeviren, Nina Geyer, Sophie Unterfranz, Daniel A. Keim, Lucas Joos, Julius Rauscher
publish: 2025 IEEE Visual Analytics Science and Technology Challenge (VAST Challenge)
abstract: In Mini-Challenge 1 of the 2025 VAST Challenge, participants supported journalist Silas Reed in exploring the rise of the artist Sailor Shift and the global influence of Oceanus Folk music. We developed a visual analytics tool built on a Neo4j database, FastAPI backend, and React.js frontend with D3.js and Sigma.js for interactive graph and timeline visualizations. The tool enables exploration of artists, genres, and influences through linked visual components. It supports tracing collaborations, stylistic evolution, and the genre’s cultural diffusion over time. We found that Sailor Shift is rarely co-performing, but inspired many other artists with her songs and albums to create their own music. The genre of Oceanus Folk rose rather intermittent than gradually while influencing different genres like Desert Rock, Dream Pop and Indie Folk and artists like Min He and Xia Cui as well as taking inspirations from Alternative Rock, Desert Rock and Dream Pop. We visualized the careers of Filippo Pelli, Kimberly Snyders and Zacharie Martins and predicted Beatrice Albright, Daniel O’Connell, and Genevieve Bell to be the next rising stars based on our prediction tool.
