title: Insights on the Uplink Operation of a 1-bit Radio-Over-Fiber Architecture in Multiuser D-MIMO Communication
authors: Lise Aabel, Giuseppe Durisi, Frida Olofsson, Erik Börjeson, Mikael Coldrey, Christian Fager
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: We consider a distributed multiple-input multiple-output (D-MIMO) testbed in which, to enable coherent-phase transmission without over-the-air synchronization, the remote radio heads (RRHs) are connected to a central unit (CU) via a 1-bit radio-over-fiber fronthaul. Specifically, 1-bit samples of the radio frequency (RF) signal are exchanged over the fronthaul. We investigate via both measurements and simulations based on an accurate model of the testbed hardware, the capability of the proposed architecture to provide uniform quality of services over the coverage area—one of the promises of D-MIMO. Our results are encouraging: for the case in which two user equipments (UEs) communicate over the same 75-MHz signal bandwidth, the measured error-vector magnitude (EVM) meets the 3GPP New Radio specification of 12.5% for 16 QAM across all tested D-MIMO scenarios. We also determine that uplink transmission is a potential bottleneck, due to the limited dynamic range of the automatic gain controller, which prevents the 1-bit quantizer to benefit from dithering. We show that this issue can be mitigated via UE power control.

title: Small-Scale-Fading-Aware Resource Allocation in Wireless Federated Learning
authors: Jiacheng Wang, Le Liang, Hao Ye, Chongtao Guo, Shi Jin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Judicious resource allocation can effectively enhance federated learning (FL) training performance in wireless networks by addressing both system and statistical heterogeneity. However, existing strategies typically rely on block fading assumptions, which overlook rapid channel fluctuations within each round of FL gradient uploading, leading to a degradation in FL training performance. Therefore, this paper proposes a small-scale-fading-aware resource allocation strategy using a multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework. Specifically, we establish a one-step convergence bound of the FL algorithm and formulate the resource allocation problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP), which is subsequently solved using the QMIX algorithm. In our framework, each client serves as an agent that dynamically determines spectrum and power allocations within each coherence time slot, based on local observations and a reward derived from the convergence analysis. The MARL setting reduces the dimensionality of the action space and facilitates decentralized decision-making, enhancing the scalability and practicality of the solution. Experimental results demonstrate that our QMIX-based resource allocation strategy significantly outperforms baseline methods across various degrees of statistical heterogeneity. Additionally, ablation studies validate the critical importance of incorporating small-scale fading dynamics, highlighting its role in optimizing FL performance.

title: Chance Constrained AC Security Constrained Optimal Power Flow Via the Inner-Outer Approximation Algorithm
authors: Keerthi Chacko, Mohammad Iman Alizadeh, Florin Capitanescu, Pu Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable generation in power systems poses a significant challenge due to its strong uncertainty. Satisfying security under any realization of the uncertainty may be cost prohibitive. Accordingly, we propose a chance-constrained approach to AC security-constrained optimal power flow (AC-SCOPF) under uncertainty. This chance constrained optimization (CCOPT) problem aims to simultaneously satisfy the operation constraints for all N-1 contingencies with a user-defined confidence level (e.g. 95%). The large-scale nonlinear CCOPT problem is solved by the recently developed inner-outer approximation algorithm which iterates between the solution of two nonlinear programming (NLP) problems, the inner and the outer approximations of the original problem. The algorithm guarantees tractability for solving nonlinear CCOPT problems under non-Gaussian distributed uncertainties. A 5- bus power system and the 60- bus Nordic system with uncertain wind power penetration are used to illustrate the efficacy of the proposed approach.

title: Triboelectric Charging of DBD-Treated Granular Plastic Waste Previously-Exposed to Long-Term Action of High-Levels of Ambient Humidity
authors: Csaba Dani, Siham Labiod, Thami Zeghloul, Mohamed-Sofiane Bendilmi, Zehira Ziari, Lucian Dascalescu, Mihai Lungu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: Dielectric barrier discharges (DBD) are known to change the surface morphology, the surface chemical composition, and the triboelectric properties of the treated polymers. The work presented in this paper was aimed at studying the effect of long-term exposure of high-levels of ambient humidity on the triboelectric charging of DBD treated granular plastics. The experiments were carried out on four types of polymers, ABS, PP, PE and PS, with an average particle size between 4 mm and 6 mm. To study the effects of relative humidity of ambient air, the granules were stored for 72 h in a climatic chamber, disposing of simultaneous humidity and temperature control. The relative humidity was regulated at 82% ± 4%, for a temperature of 19°C ± 1°C. The water content of “humid” granules was measured with a thermal-balance and compared with that of “normal” granules, kept at ambient humidity (46% to 52%), at a temperature of 18°C ± 1°C. The “humid” and “normal” granules were successively exposed to a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) for 60 s in a custom-designed reactor then charged by triboelectric effect in a multi-cylinder triboelectric device. As expected, the DBD treatment modified the triboelectric behavior of each polymer. The experiments showed that the charge/mass effect of this treatment is different on “humid” and “normal” particles. The study points out the importance of providing appropriate storage conditions (i.e., humidity levels lower than 70%) for the plastic wastes processed by tribo-electrostatic techniques.

title: An Adversarial Defense Framework for Consumer UAV Systems: Case Study of Cotton Apical Bud Detection Against AI-enabled Attacks
authors: Jing Nie, Tao Zhang, Yang Li, Xuewei Chao, Sezai Ercisli
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Consumer-grade agricultural UAV systems are increasingly adopted for crop monitoring, yet their perception systems remain highly vulnerable to AI-enabled attacks and short-term environmental disturbances. To address this, we propose MTCF-TaGN, an adversarial defense framework that leverages a short-term multi-modal temporal dataset synchronized across RGB, multi-spectral, and thermal infrared sequences. The proposed MTCF-Net captures temporal dependencies and adaptively fuses multi-modal features to mitigate the effects of wind, illumination, and occlusion. To evaluate robustness, the TaGN module generates digital, physical, and cross-modal adversarial samples, while the PANDA module employs reinforcement learning for both real-time adversarial detection and filtering. Experiments demonstrate that MTCF-TaGN improves detection robustness by achieving 12.4% higher mAP and 15.7% lower false positives under strong adversarial conditions, with inference latency below 80 ms, which makes it suitable for real-time UAV deployment. This work highlights a practical solution to enhance both accuracy and security resilience in agricultural UAVs, and more broadly, provide insights into securing multi-modal consumer devices against adversarial threats.

title: Time-Series Compensation Method for Hydrofoil Planing Attitude Stability Control of Hybrid Aquatic-Aerial Robot
authors: Yiming Lin, Hui Peng, Junhao Xiao, Ziyang Yue, Peng Yang, Haoyu Li, Kaihong Huang
publish: IEEE Journal of Oceanic Engineering
abstract: In recent years, hybrid aquatic-aerial robots (HAARs) have attracted increasing attention due to their unique amphibious characteristics. HAARs have the abilities of aerial flight, hydrofoil planing, and underwater travel. However, the complex hydrodynamic characteristics and time-varying environmental disturbances during hydrofoil planing result in significant model uncertainties and external disturbances in the system. In this article, an error-oriented active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) approach is proposed. This method takes the real-time error as the state variable to estimate and compensate for both internal and external disturbances of the system. Considering that the past data of the control system can characterize the time-varying model of the closed-loop system, a time-series compensation mechanism is added to the error-oriented ADRC to further enhance the disturbance suppression ability of the controller and improve the performance of the system. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified through comparative simulation and experimental results.

title: Back from the Dead: Self-recovery Strategy for Modular Planetary Exploration Robots_supp5-3644668.mp4
authors: Ning Zhao
publish: N/A
abstract: The theoretical capability of modular robots to recover their original configuration or function after disintegration caused by external impacts has been cited as an advantage for planetary exploration. The key to achieving self-recovery lies in addressing the stochasticity of disintegration. Here, a self-recovery strategy is proposed for modular planetary exploration robots. Firstly, the recovery process is analyzed to construct a strategy framework and provide the problem definitions and strategy assumptions. Secondly, by standardizing the selection criteria for meta-modules under the stochasticity of disintegration, non-mobile modules can acquire mobility through the meta-module method, thereby laying the groundwork for executable self-recovery. Finally, a comprehensive optimization model is proposed, which encompasses the module interactions arising from stochastic disintegration. By integrating selfrecovery characteristics with the simulated annealing algorithm, a solution method is designed to obtain self-recovery plans. Extensive hardware experiments were conducted, and the results demonstrate that the self-recovery strategy operates stably and executes successfully across various configurations and scenarios, thereby validating the feasibility and reliability. In this way, the self-recovery strategy and experiments could substantially advance the application of modular robots in space exploration, while also providing insights for other areas, such as assembly planning and applications involving non-mobile modular robots.

title: Joint Scheduling and Relay Allocation for Semantic and Delay-Sensitive Wireless Communications
authors: Wen-Fu Wang, Jang-Ping Sheu, Nguyen Van Cuong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Green Communications and Networking
abstract: Semantic communication (SC) has emerged as a novel communication paradigm for enhancing transmission efficiency in wireless networks by prioritizing data semantics over raw bits. Meanwhile, mobile delay-sensitive users demand strict low-latency transmissions for critical tasks such as emergency response. Supporting both user types under limited resources is challenging. This paper proposes a joint resource allocation framework that integrates time-slot allocation and relay assignment to serve semantic- and delay-sensitive users simultaneously. The formulated problem is hard to solve optimally. We develop a Joint Matching, Time Slot, and Relay Allocation Algorithm (JMTRA) that combines stable matching, knapsack-based scheduling, and linear-programming-based relay selection to find a suboptimal solution. Simulation results demonstrate that our approach improves semantic performance while meeting delay constraints.

title: Equivalent Modeling of Grid-Forming Energy Storage System for Load Modeling
authors: Qi Wang, Pandeng Luo, Bo Chen, Bing Zhao, Jie Hao, Zhiwei Zheng
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Load modeling plays a crucial role in the safety and stability analysis of power systems as well as accurate simulation calculations. Grid-forming energy storage, as an important active and reactive power source in distribution networks, has not been considered in the load models of traditional systems due to the large number of grid-forming energy storage units. As a result, these traditional load models can no longer accurately represent the dynamic characteristics of load areas with clusters of grid-forming energy storage. This paper investigates the working mechanism and interaction mechanism of grid-forming energy storage clusters on the load side, and proposes a generalized load integration equivalent modeling method that accounts for grid-forming energy storage. This method adds a grid-forming energy storage model to the comprehensive load model of the distribution network and introduces a dynamic equivalent method that considers grid-forming energy storage, achieving precise simulation of the external characteristics of load-supplying areas for grid-forming energy storage. This provides strong technical support for accurate simulation calculations, analysis, and decision-making in new power systems.

title: Hybrid Sensor Node Localization Approach in WSN-Assisted IoT for Smart Agriculture
authors: Preeti Yadav, Vinay Rishiwal, Sunita Yadav, Mano Yadav, Garvin Venjona Tjamburo, Chirag Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Efficient monitoring and energy management are crucial for smart agriculture and accurate localization of sensor nodes. This paper presents an efficient localization approach in Wireless Sensor Network-assisted Internet of Things (W-IoT) environments utilizing an Artificial Neural Network (ANN)based Hybrid Sensor Node Localization framework for smart agriculture. Adding Machine learning (ML) techniques to the proposed methodology has enhanced the accuracy of sensor node positioning, handling challenges like network scalability and environmental factors. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed hybrid model which includes Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI), Time of Arrival (TOA) and ANN, achieves superior localization accuracy (92%), optimal energy conservation (0.6 units), and reduced processing time (90 ms), outperforming traditional localization approaches that are comparatively less efficient and accurate.

title: Target Recognition and Selection Strategy based on Deep Reinforcement Learning under Dynamic Environment
authors: Xiwen Cao, Xingyun Dai, Dan Zhao, Xiaoyu Liu, Lingxiang Hao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Target recognition and selection under dynamic constraints pose significant challenges in resource-limited task scheduling. To address dynamically evolving action spaces and time-varying target criticality, this study proposes a novel Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) framework integrating an action masking mechanism with Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO). Firstly, a criticality analysis framework evaluates target strategic value using robustness, information propagation, and cross-dynamic factors. Then, the problem is formulated as a constrained Markov Decision Process (MDP), with an action masking mechanism dynamically filtering invalid actions and PPO optimizes the recognition process. Simulations demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: A Multimodal Decision-Level Hybrid Brain Computer Interface for Air-Ground Collaborative Systems
authors: Kaixuan Lian, Luzheng Bi, Haorui Ge, Peiyu Zhang, Weijie Fei, Aberham Genetu Feleke
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Given the complex control requirements of air-ground collaborative systems, control methods beyond manual operation are needed to expand the control dimensions. This paper proposes a hybrid brain computer interface (BCI) with multimodal decision-level fusion for air-ground collaborative systems. It combines electroencephalogram (EEG) and eye-tracking signals, achieving modality complementation. To evaluate the online performance metrics, two calibration data recording experiments were designed. Additionally, a unmanned ground vehicle (UGV) tracking experiment was conducted to validate online performance. Results indicate the hybrid BCI outperforms single-modality controls.

title: Enhancing Deaf Comprehension Through Thai Subtitles Aligned with Sign Language Syntax
authors: Phutawan Phokaow, Siriporn Sakboonyarat, Boonnatee Sakboonyarat
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Subtitles play a critical role in improving information accessibility for individuals with hearing impairments. However, conventional Thai subtitles are often ineffective for Thai Sign Language (TSL) users due to the absence of explicit word boundaries in Thai text and significant grammatical differences between Thai and TSL. To address this issue, this study proposes a real-time Thai subtitle generation system that integrates automatic speech recognition (ASR) with natural language processing (NLP) techniques. The system processes audio input using a pre-trained Whisper-based model optimized with the Mozilla Common Voice dataset, achieving a practical word error rate (WER) of approximately 10 – 15%. Transcribed text is segmented using PyThaiNLP with a custom dictionary, and further transformed through syntactic reordering and lexical simplification guided by TSL instructional materials. Interactive rendering features, including word-level highlighting, image-based visual aids, and a history log, were implemented in a Flutter-based frontend to enhance comprehension and word retention. The system was evaluated with 28 deaf participants affiliated with Ratchasuda College, of whom 26 completed the post-use evaluation. Quantitative results showed consistently high ratings across all five evaluation items (mean scores between 4.27 and 4.73), with "convenience of use" rated the highest and "subtitle speed" receiving the lowest but still high scores. Qualitative feedback highlighted six themes: the benefits of highlighting and visual aids, the necessity of word segmentation, the demand for real-world deployment, the educational value of grammar learning, challenges with complex vocabulary, and overall positive impressions. These findings confirm that the proposed system is both practical and educational, with strong potential to reduce communication barriers and promote inclusive, real-time communication for deaf individuals in the Thai language context.

title: Grid-Less CS-MUSIC DOA Estimation for Correlated Signals Using a Uniform Semicircular Array
authors: Njoroge Kennedy, Mwangi Elijah, Moindi Stephen
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: Direction of Arrival (DOA) estimation presents a fundamental problem across numerous signal processing applications, particularly in scenarios involving correlated signals, few snapshots and a low Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR) environment. We propose a hybrid method that combines sparse covariance estimation with MUSIC (Multiple Signal Classification) on Uniform Circular (UCA) and Uniform Semi-Circular Arrays (USemiCA), enabling reliable azimuth estimation with limited data. Sparse covariance regularization and grid-less spectrum recovery is injected before the classical subspace decomposition step, enabling reliable estimation with as few snapshots and low SNR. The proposed method that combines CS-MUSIC with USemiCA offers significant advantages over traditional DOA estimation methods, including improved resolution, robustness to noise, reduced snapshot requirements, and cost-effectiveness. These findings recommend USemiCA for constrained field of view platforms such as façade-mounted 5G cells, bow-mounted ship radars and border-surveillance nodes. The proposed methods performance is improved across Monte-Carlo sweeps showing that USemiCA + CS-MUSIC attains RMSE (Root Mean Square Error) improvements, reduction in number of snapshots and a low SNR regime.

title: Multi-Strategy Integrated LSTM-PPO for Maneuvering Decision of UAV in Air Combat
authors: Benqi Jiang, Ruixuan Wei, Chenkang Huang, Qirui Zhang, Shengyu He, Bike Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: With the widespread application of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in modern warfare, achieving effective autonomous air combat decision-making has emerged as a research hotspot. Modern air combat is complex and dynamic, characterized by high-dimensional state spaces, uncertainty, and intense adversarial interactions, necessitating robust decision-making capabilities for UAVs. In this paper, a multi-strategy integrated LSTM-PPO algorithm is proposed, which incorporates Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) into the Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) framework. This approach captures temporal dependencies in UAV maneuver decision while ensuring training stability and performance in adversarial environments. Furthermore, the curriculum learning and self-play mechanisms are integrated in LSTM-PPO algorithm framework to enhance training efficiency, progressively strengthening the UAV’s adversarial capabilities. Extensive simulations and experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, demonstrating its ability to generate highly adaptive, robust, and efficient strategies across diverse combat scenarios.

title: Automated Information Extraction From Medical Prescriptions
authors: Amayas Bourahla, Amir Khalid Kadi, Abdelhamid Malki
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Advanced Systems (ICNAS)
abstract: Optical Character Recognition (OCR) has become a key technology in modern healthcare systems, particularly for processing medical prescriptions where accuracy and efficiency are critical. While OCR improves data entry and reduces transcription errors, standard solutions often struggle with handwritten text, multilingual content, and the complexity of medical documents. To address these challenges, this paper proposes Wassfa, an end-to-end system that combines OCR with an expert validation model to extract and verify key prescription information. Using TrOCR for text recognition, YOLOv5 for localization, and a BERT-based module for medical rule validation, the system ensures reliable and structured data extraction for integration into Electronic Health Records (EHRs). Experimental results show significant improvements in accuracy and processing efficiency, supporting safer and more automated prescription workflows.

title: VIE-ROSLAM: A Visual Information Enhancement Robust SLAM System
authors: Jingyu Yu, Daxin Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: In the autonomous navigation of self-driving vehicles, the loss of image information caused by visual sensor failure and object occlusion is one of the main challenges faced by the visual SLAM system. This paper proposes a visual information enhanced SLAM system based on image repair algorithms, aiming to effectively restore the missing information in the images acquired by the visual sensors of autonomous vehicles, thereby enhancing the robustness of the system. By using algorithms based on image tensor decomposition and repair, this system can accurately restore missing image information in the presence of a high proportion of pixel defects, ensuring the clarity and integrity of the image. The system integrates image repair algorithms into the front end of the visual SLAM system, significantly enhancing the robustness of feature point extraction and matching. Optimizing the loop detection mechanism improves the success rate and accuracy of historical image processing, effectively suppresses position drift, and ensures the long-term robustness of the system. Experimental results show that the Visual Information Enhancement Robust SLAM System (VIE-ROSLAM) system can maintain excellent positioning accuracy and robustness when dealing with pixel defect coverage of different gradients, which is significantly better than other existing visual SLAM systems. The VIE-ROSLAM provides an effective solution to the problem of missing image information encountered in practical applications.

title: Transfer Entropy-Based Analysis for Understanding the Propagation Process of Voltage Dynamic Response Under Sustained Perturbations
authors: Haifeng Zhang, Song Gao, Yifu Zhang, Shuyu Zhou, Mingfeng Wang, Deyou Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The weak disturbance rejection capability of grid-connected converters in renewable energy systems poses challenges to voltage stability and control in power systems with large-scale renewable energy integration. Identifying the dominant control factors of node voltages is crucial for achieving voltage stability control. This paper proposes an analytical method based on transfer entropy for analyzing the voltage dynamic behavior propagation process to identify the dominant control factors of node voltages. Utilizing node voltage response data, the causal relationships of node voltage dynamic processes are analyzed using transfer entropy. Based on the causal relationships between node voltages, the propagation process of voltage dynamic behavior is analyzed, thereby identifying the key control units that dominate each node voltage. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm is verified by using node voltage dynamic response data generated from a sustained disturbance injection into the generator excitation system in the WECC179-bus system.

title: Educational Experiments to Demonstrate Theoretical Principles on Traveling Waves Using Low Voltage Circuits
authors: D. S. Sarmento, F. V. Lopes, J. S. Silva, A. G. Poma, P. G. M. Leandro, J. L. Nascimento, F. B. S. Carvalho, J. M. R. S. Neto, H. D. M. Braz
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This paper proposes educational experiments to demonstrate theoretical principles on traveling waves (TWs) by using low-voltage circuits. The experiments are conducted using equipment commonly found in Electrical Engineering courses, such as square-wave signal generators, oscilloscopes and lowvoltage cables. In such experiments, the principles of TW propagation are demonstrated via real low voltage circuits, confirming concepts usually studied in most universities via computational simulations only. Four experiments are recommended, and the theoretical topics addressed in each one are discussed, allowing to study the effects of line parameters, line travel time and TW reflection/refraction at system discontinuity points. The obtained results confirm the feasibility of the proposed experiments, revealing their value in supporting educational activities to teach topics related to TW-based applications in power networks.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Based Optimization of Vehicle-to-Grid Scheduling for Real-Time Operation
authors: Mohammad Javad Salehpour, M. J. Hossain
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology enables bidirectional energy exchange between electric vehicles (EVs) and the power grid, supporting grid stability, peak load reduction, and operational efficiency. However, existing optimization methods typically rely on day-ahead data and scheduling to address operational uncertainties, which limits their responsiveness to real-time system dynamics and individual-level decisions. This paper proposes a machine learning-based framework trained on historical optimal scheduling decisions under various scenarios to approximate co-optimized outcomes in real time. Specifically, the model predicts whether an EV owner’s submitted offer for discharging back to the grid—defined by energy quantity and price—will be accepted based on current system conditions such as demand, generation availability, and market prices. If the offer is accepted, the model also estimates the financial benefit to the EV owner. The framework employs algorithms including random forest, logistic regression, and linear regression, and is benchmarked against a Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) model. Results demonstrate high predictive accuracy, showing that the proposed method effectively supports real-time decision-making for both grid operators and EV owners, enabling scalable and economically attractive V2G participation.

title: Study of RIS-Assisted Communications over Correlated Nakagami-m Fading Channels
authors: Tianxiong Wang, Gaojie Chen, Sen Wang, Qixing Wang, Yifei Yuan, Chih-Lin I
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: This study investigates the performance of a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted communication system operating over spatially correlated Nakagami-m fading channels. The fading model represents a wide range of propagation scenarios while capturing the inherent spatial correlation of RIS. With the statistical characteristics of the corresponding distributions and the properties of the 2-D Laplace transform, we obtain the mean value and variance of the composite channel distribution. Building upon these results, we obtain a closed form expression for the outage probability and an integral expression for the ergodic capacity using a moment-matching approach. The integral form expression for the ergodic capacity is subsequently transformed into a closed form expression via the Gaussian Chebyshev quadrature (GCQ) method. Simulation results validate the theoretical analysis and illustrate the performance degradation due to channel correlation. The study highlights the importance of accounting for spatial correlation when designing RIS-assisted communication systems.

title: Research on Lightning Suppression Line Arresters Based on Repetitive Damping Parameters
authors: Yue Zhou, Yadong Li, Zhu Ran, Digang Ma, Jianming Li, Yuhui Zhang
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: In the field of power system overvoltage protection, arresters serve as critical devices for safeguarding electrical equipment against lightning surges and switching overvoltages. Traditional arresters, typically based on the nonlinear characteristics of zinc oxide varistors (MOVs), exhibit growing technical limitations in complex lightning environments and DC systems. This paper proposes a lightning suppression arrester incorporating a repetitive damping mechanism. By integrating the nonlinear behavior of MOVs with hybrid damping mechanisms—including inductive damping and thyristor-based damping—the arrester effectively suppresses both the steepness and magnitude of lightning impulse currents, thereby significantly mitigating the risk of lightning-induced damage to transmission lines. Experimental validation demonstrates the arrester's response characteristics under various lightning strike conditions. Results confirm its substantial enhancement of line lightning withstand capability.

title: Antenna Signal Interpolation for Low-Cost PAPR Reduction
authors: Roman Bychkov, Alexander Osinsky, Andrey Dergachev, Andrey Ivanov
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: In this paper, we compare interpolation approaches to predict the peaks of an orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) signal that is widely employed in modern telecommunication systems. Unfortunately, OFDM systems suffer from a high dynamic range of the radio signal, resulting in a low efficiency of the high-power amplifier (HPA). Thus, to minimize the range, signal peaks can either be reduced in the baseband using digital processing or in the radio frequency using analog circuitry. The digital one is much cheaper, but some peaks may be missed and still appear on the HPA input. To find all peaks, one needs to increase the sampling rate for the baseband processing, which increases the cost of the peak cancellation. Since for peak reduction we only need the peaks instead of the entire digital signal, one can replace the upsampling by an interpolation to calculate peak positions and amplitudes, resulting in cost savings. We demonstrate that the parabolic interpolation with double thresholding is the best choice among the tested methods.

title: A Novel Cooperative Localization Algorithm based on Heterogeneous Data Fusion using GNN
authors: Wanlong Zhao, Yufei Cheng, Shuyin Zhao, Deyue Zou, Gongliang Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: The ocean is a natural resource of immense exploratory value, and acquiring precise positional information is critical for effective task execution of Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs). To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel cooperative localization algorithm based on heterogeneous data fusion in a collaborative underwater network. The proposed algorithm adopts a lightweight architecture integrated with a graph neural network (GNN) as its core model. The GNN helps to process raw sensor measured data and reduce the dependence on initial location values of the AUV, and hence to enable high-accuracy underwater localization with low computational complexity. Experimental results show that, compared to traditional Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) and Factor Graph (FG) localization methods, the proposed algorithm achieves superior positioning accuracy and robustness.

title: Operationalization of YOLOv11 in ROS 2 for Computer Vision Applied to Human-robot Interaction
authors: Bruno Jaciel De Mello, Felipe Viel, Cesar Albenes Zeferino, Tiago Ribeiro, Fernando Ribeiro, Eduardo Auguto Bezerra, José Renes Pinheiro
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: Computer vision is widely used in robotics, medicine, and security, with deep neural networks like YOLOv11 excelling in high-accuracy classification and feature extraction. However, operationalizing these algorithms for real-world applications requires structured approaches like MLOps to ensure efficient deployment and management. This work integrates computer vision with robotic systems using ROS 2 and implements MLOps concepts for embedded systems. By combining ROS 2 with YOLOv11, robots can perform complex tasks with high precision, such as patient monitoring, object identification, and medical assistance in healthcare environments. The pose classification model achieved a mAP50 of approximately 60 %, with high accuracy for detecting falls (93 %). For object detection, YOLOv11 achieved high precision for bottle (97 %), can (97 %), and cup (98 %), with an mAP50-95 of 90 %. Real-time processing with ROS 2 confirmed consistent performance and precise object visualization, highlighting the system's suitability for interactive robotic applications. This work demonstrates the effective integration of computer vision and MLOps in robotics, enabling advanced functionalities in real-world environments.

title: Predicting Diabetes Onset Using Machine Learning: A Text-Based Analysis of Lifestyle and Behavioral Factors
authors: Alkhalil Ibrahim Alharthi, Sayan Kumar Ray, Saliyah Binti Kahar, Husna Sarirah Binti Husin, Rafeef Taresh Suliman Alshammari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: This study is focused on building a unique machine learning model that can predict the occurring of diabetes based on text form lifestyle and behavioral parameters. Hence, by using state-of-the-art machine learning algorithms and advanced natural language processing (NLP) methods we aim at uncovering actionable insights from unstructured textual data sources like electronic health records (EHRs), patient surveys & social media posts. The purpose is to identify salient linguistic and behavioral markers of risk for diabetes. This is a quite radical change of direction, moving away from the traditional prediction using structured clinical data. Our objective is to augment traditional analyses with valuable, text-derived information about rich contexts surrounding certain behaviors and lifestyle factors that may otherwise fall out of the scope. Our approach includes a end to end pipeline of text processing, feature engineering and model adaption. We will go over several machine learning approaches, mining from classical tools like logistic regression and random forest to more modern deep algorithms related e.g. LSTM network or BERT. Additionally, the performance of these text-based models will be evaluated stringently as compared to traditional prediction methodologies.

title: Customer Satisfaction Analysis for Balimall.id Using CSI and IPA for Information System Optimization
authors: I Putu Utama Arta, I Putu Agus Eka Darma Udayana, Ni Wayan Sumartini Saraswati
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: The growth of digital platforms has raised expectations for efficient and responsive online services. Balimall.id, a local e-commerce platform that supports the digitalization of Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs), has been considered. However, since its launch, no systematic evaluation has been conducted to measure the platform's level of conformity to user expectations and determine service aspects that require improvement. This study adopted a quantitative approach using the Customer Satisfaction Index (CSI) and Importance-Performance Analysis (IPA) methods. These methods aim to measure overall user satisfaction and map service attributes that require priority improvement. The primary motivation of this study is to optimize Balimall.id based on real-life user experiences and field needs. This study's contribution lies in providing a data-driven evaluation framework capable of identifying the platform's strengths and weaknesses. Based on questionnaire responses from 390 users, the CSI score indicated a satisfaction level of 85.3%, indicating a high level of satisfaction. However, the IPA results indicated significant performance gaps in attributes such as ease of use (Q1), search speed (Q5), system stability (Q17–Q18), and data accessibility (Q21) that require immediate improvement. Meanwhile, the key strengths identified in Quadrant II include an attractive interface (Q3), accurate information (Q6), and ease of access (Q16). These findings can be used as a basis for planning sustainable system development tailored to future user needs. The evaluation results can also be further developed through the integration of machine learning-based predictive models and the development of a real-time monitoring service dashboard to support adaptive and continuous system improvements.

title: Opportunities and Challenges in Cybersecurity Governance Through a Systematic Review
authors: Nayara Oliveira Sales, Durval Júnior Vargas Vieira, Vicente Ferreira Júnior, Guilherme Dantas Bispo, Luiz Antônio Ribeiro Júnior, Clóvis Neumann
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This article presents a systematic review of cybersecurity governance, analyzing current practices and the main challenges organizations face in managing cyber risks. It highlights the critical role of governance structures that involve not only IT, but also senior management, to protect both the organization and its digital value chain. The review uses the Automatic Literature Mapping Selection method, supported by machine-learning-based decision trees and complementary metrics such as the Scientific Significance Score (SSS) and the Time-Adjusted Publication Score (TAPS), which prioritize journal quality, scientific impact, and recency. The results expose persistent gaps. A key issue is the weak integration between corporate strategy and cybersecurity initiatives, which undermines the implementation of effective security measures. Another problem is the lack of clear, standardized metrics to assess cybersecurity effectiveness, as many organizations still rely on superficial indicators, often limited to the number of reported incidents. The review also finds a scarcity of empirical studies evaluating the return on cybersecurity investments and the real effectiveness of adopted tools. Finally, the rapid evolution of technologies such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) creates new security challenges that demand more adaptive governance frameworks; however, the literature still offers few practical approaches capable of addressing the specific risks introduced by these innovations.

title: Power System Resilience Enhancement by Pumped Storage Under Extreme Weather
authors: Chen Qingyue, Zhao Tianchen, Dan Yangqing, Zhang Gong, Zhou Yibo
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In recent years, system power shortage due to extreme weather has gradually increased in high percentage of new energy power systems, and it is imperative to strengthen the power system resilience. The concept and calculation method of main grid flexibility are proposed based on the concept of flexibility in distribution networks. The demandside and supply-side flexibility quantitative models are constructed, and the flexibility regulation capability of pumped storage is modeled. The enhancement assessment model of pumped storage for power system resilience is established. The model was validated and analyzed based on an example analysis system. The results demonstrate that pumped storage has a certain enhancement effect on system resilience, and to a certain extent, it can reduce the load shortage level of the system under extreme weather.

title: Smart Sensor-Based IoT System for Predictive Monitoring in Hydroelectric Power Plants
authors: Sergio Berteli Batista Filho, Andre Borges Goedert, Paulo Sausen, Jordan Sausen, Mauricio de Campos
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: Condition monitoring of generators is essential to prevent potential failures that could interrupt power generation. By employing smart sensors connected through a network, it is possible to continuously monitor these devices and perform predictive maintenance based on their condition, thereby minimizing the risk of equipment breakdown. This paper presents the development of an IoT-based system designed for a hydroelectric power plant, composed of two main components: a smart sensor for detecting mechanical faults in a motor through vibration analysis, and a smart sensor for estimating the water level in a reservoir. A vibrometer and an ultrasonic level sensor are employed for these tasks. The acquired data are transmitted via LoRa to the control unit. The system was successfully implemented, and the data are transmitted through LoRaWAN to the platform The Things Network.

title: Automatic Instrument Recognition in Multi-Instrumental Tracks Using Deep Convolutional Audio Classifiers
authors: Pratima Pandey, Navnath B. Pokale, Shenbhagaraman Ramalingam, Asif Jamal, Ankita Makker
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: In the field of music information retrieval (MIR), automatically identifying musical instruments in complex, multi-instrumental tracks has become an important job. This makes it possible for advanced uses like automated music labelling, audio indexing, and smart recommendation systems. But standard methods often have trouble with background noise, overlapped tones, and changes in how loud an instrument is playing within multiple audio signals. This research suggests a deep convolutional audio classifier (DCAC) system that can correctly identify multiple instruments from raw audio sources at the same time. A lot of tests were done on standard datasets like IRMAS and MedleyDB, showing that the suggested model is better than traditional machine learning baselines and previous deep learning architectures. Average accuracy, memory, and F1scores all got a lot better with the DCAC framework, especially in difficult multiple situations. Also, ablation tests proved that spectrum enhancement and depth-wise convolutional layers work well at improving generalisation across a wide range of audio styles and recording conditions. The results show that deep neural models could help improve automatic instrument recognition and make it easier to connect them to real-time music apps and smart audio recording tools in the future. This study adds a scalable and reliable answer to a hard MIR problem. It gives audio engineers, musicologists, and people who are making the next generation of music technology systems useful information.

title: A Multi-Agent-Based Distributed Control Strategy for Microgrid Synchronization
authors: James Allan Garcia da Rocha de Melo, Samuel Graff Bender, Joao Manoel Lenz, Adriano Batista de Almeida
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: The integration of microgrids into the main electric grid requires precise synchronization to guarantee system stability and safety. This work proposes a hierarchical distributed control strategy based on multi-agent systems to achieve seamless synchronization of an islanded microgrid with the main grid. A synchronization agent (SA), located at the Point of Common Coupling (PCC), performs real-time voltage measurements of both the microgrid and the main grid, transmitting this data via a communication link to the master inverter. Based on the information received, the master inverter adjusts its voltage reference and sends updated droop parameters to a follower inverter. The proposed method was validated through PSIM simulations, which confirmed accurate alignment of voltage magnitude, frequency, and phase under ideal conditions, as well as under communication delays, significant load disturbances, and a loss of communication event. The results demonstrate a smooth and secure transition, compliant with established grid interconnection requirements.

title: Proactive Retransmission-Based Image Semantic Communications
authors: Kaiwen Yu, Chuanhang Yu, Gang Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: Semantic communications powered by deep learning emphasize task-relevant information transmission rather than bit-level accuracy. While deep joint source and channel coding shows promise, its adaptability to dynamic wireless environments remains limited. To address this, we propose a proactive retransmission scheme using a performance prediction network at the transmitter, enabling autonomous retransmission decisions without traditional feedback. The approach is validated through a Universal Software Radio Peripheral (USRP) B210-based prototype. Experimental and simulation results demonstrate improved reliability and efficiency across varying channel conditions, highlighting the method’s potential for practical, adaptive semantic communication systems.

title: A Probabilistic Hierarchical Optimization Method for Cooperative UAV Swarms
authors: Xiaoyi Chen, Rong Wang, Zhi Xiong, Quyu Cong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper proposes a probabilistic hierarchical cooperative architecture to address uneven navigation capabilities and rigid structures in UAV swarms under GNSS-denied conditions. By combining GDOP and navigation error, a continuous probability model is built to drive role assignment and connection regulation. Unlike fixed-role schemes, the proposed method enables adaptive cooperation and flexible behavior adjustment, improving robustness and self-organization for swarm navigation in complex environments.

title: Automated Advanced Analysis in Lightning Impulse Tests for Power and Instrument Transformers
authors: Welson Bassi
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: Impulse tests play an essential role in assessing the insulation of power transformers. These tests provide valuable insights into the dielectric behavior of transformers under high-voltage stress conditions. This study focuses on the comparative analysis of impulse test records obtained from different power and instrument transformers, specifically examining variations in voltage and current waveforms using time and frequency-domain methodologies. The study employs advanced signal processing techniques—like Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), wavelet decomposition, and coherence analysis—to detect potential discrepancies. A detailed analysis of case studies is presented, applying numerical metrics to quantify significant and non-significant differences in test results, enhancing diagnostic precision and minimizing subjectivity in waveform evaluation. Furthermore, the software output results are compared with visual observations, demonstrating that it is possible to achieve the same decision-making outcomes based on visual inspections as the international standards currently demand. The findings emphasize the need for objective, quantifiable assessment criteria in test approval procedures, reducing the reliance on subjective expert evaluations and promoting a more standardized methodology for transformer diagnostics. Additionally, numerical methods, metrics, and statistical parameters are foundational for future advancements in machine learning and artificial intelligence applications, enabling more sophisticated and automated diagnostic solutions.

title: Fall Behavior Detection in Elderly People Using Improved YOLO5v5 Model
authors: Li Shi Jie, Fatima tu Zehra, Humaira Ashraf, Noor Hasrina Binti Bakar, Danish Javed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Falls among the elderly are a significant public health concern, leading to severe injuries and increased healthcare costs. This research presents a home-based fall behavior detection system utilizing an improved version of the YOLOv5s (You Only Look Once version 5 small) model. By leveraging the model's capabilities in real-time object detection, we enhance its architecture to improve accuracy and reduce false positives in detecting fall incidents in domestic environments. The proposed system integrates advanced image processing techniques and a robust dataset comprising various fall scenarios, enabling effective monitoring of seniors in their homes. Experimental results demonstrate the system's effectiveness, achieving high precision and recall rates, which indicate its potential for deployment in smart home solutions aimed at improving the safety and well-being of the elderly.

title: WGAN-CNN for dense and sparse vegetation categorisation of remotely sensed sugarcane crop
authors: Mansi Manoj Kambli, Bhakti Palkar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Sugarcane is India’s second largest crop and requires extensive monitoring for optimal health and productivity due to its 12-15 month growth duration. Data sets for the sugarcane crop are also not available publicly. For this, a new approach is applied in this article to increase the dataset of dense and sparse vegetation of the Napane region. The Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) of the Napane region was used using Sentinel-2 maps with ground truth data to identify dense and sparse vegetation in the spectral bands. The proposed Wasserstein Generative Adversarial Network (WGAN) with batch normalization generated 10000 more images for dense and sparse, respectively, by stabilizing the training process and reducing gradient vanishing. After applying the CNN model to the generated images, a 95.63 % accuracy rate is achieved. The categorization of dense and sparse vegetation helps farmers monitor the growth of sugarcane crops that leads to sustainable agriculture.

title: SecCityVR: Visualization and Collaborative Exploration of Software Vulnerabilities in Virtual Reality
authors: Dennis Wüppelmann, Enes Yigitbas
publish: Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Evaluation and Assessment in Software Engineering
abstract: None

title: Implementing a Digital Twin for a Secondary School Building Complex in Greece
authors: Georgios Mylonas, Anestis Koutsoudis, Dimitrios Amaxilatis, Fotis Arnaoutoglou, Georgios Kalogeras, Petros Pistofidis, Lidia Pocero Fraile, Christos Koulamas, Athanasios Kalogeras
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Digital Twins (DTs) are quickly becoming popular in multiple application domains, from industrial production environments to cultural heritage sites and smart cities. In this landscape, DTs for educational buildings offer a promising approach towards achieving energy efficiency, circularity and sustainability, and an important new smart city application domain, among other aspects. While there have been recent examples of DTs for university campuses, examples for primary and secondary school buildings are few and far between. In this work, we present our implementation of a DT for two secondary education buildings in Greece, involving IoT infrastructure, 3D digitization, data analytics, energy modeling, 3D annotation and segmentation, while discussing its potential application within several scenarios. We also discuss a number of the aspects related to educational building DTs. Overall, such DTs can offer several new application opportunities to the smart city community.

title: AI-IOT System for Pest Control in Crops
authors: Anton Limbo, Sacheus Sikiza Kapiye, Rafael Rodríguez-Puentes
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Pest control has been an important undertaking in maximising yields from crop farming. Manual methods of combating pests have shown limited success, prompting the need for more modern, innovative approaches. This paper presents the use of AI and IoT for pest control. The developed prototype employs AI to analyse images captured by a camera. The analysis focuses on detecting and identifying pests, which then triggers the irrigation process for the specific pesticide required. The prototype has been developed using the Design Science Research Methodology. The prototype was implemented on a Raspberry Pi with a camera and a water pump. The camera continuously captures images, which are processed by a Machine Learning model tasked with detecting and identifying pests. Once a pest is identified, the water pump is then activated to spray the appropriate pesticide based on the identified pest. The study's results demonstrate the potential for controlling pests using AI and IoT, as the prototype was able to efficiently identify pests and trigger the spraying of the pesticide. Future work will examine the full implementation of a prototype in a crop field, with additional functionality such as weather monitoring and predicting future pest infestations based on historical data.

title: Finite-time Lag Consensus of Leader-follower Multi-agent Systems with Communication Delay
authors: Song Gao, Jin-Liang Wang, Shun-Yan Ren, Bei Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This study examines the issue of finite-time lag consensus (FTLC) for leader–follower multi-agent systems (MASs) under communication delay. First, a novel state feedback control strategy is introduced, accompanied by a sufficient condition for attaining FTLC, which is derived using inequality scaling techniques and finite-time stability analysis. In addition, an adaptive state feedback control protocol, along with its corresponding adaptation law, is proposed to facilitate FTLC without imposing any extra conditions. Finally, a numerical simulation is conducted to validate the feasibility and performance of the proposed FTLC control schemes.

title: AFAT: Cross-domain Object Detection through Adversarial Feature Adaptation Transformers
authors: Guoliu Yu, Yang Zhou, Yunfei Bai, Tao Lv, Yuhe Zhu, Wenbo Zheng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: The goal of Unsupervised Domain Adaptive Object Detection (UDAOD) is to achieve strong detection performance on an unlabeled target domain by training solely on a labeled source domain. UDAOD plays a vital role in maritime unmanned autonomous driving systems by improving the model's ability to generalize under varying environmental conditions and operational scenarios. Relatively few studies have investigated domain adaptation within transformer-based object detection architectures. In this work, we build upon Deformable DETR and propose a Differentiated Spatial-Channel Collaborative Alignment Module (DSCAM) in the encoder. Specifically, two cross-attention layers are parallelized after each multi-scale attention layer in the encoder, where a set of diversified spatial queries and a set of diversified channel queries are used to capture and aggregate domain features at both spatial and channel levels, enabling the encoder to generate more domain-invariant features. Notably, we apply contrastive learning losses on each group of diversified queries to encourage them to focus on different domain specific features. In addition, we propose the Weighted Class Aggregation Module (WCAM) in the decoder. Based on the class predictions from the classification head, all object queries belonging to the same class are aggregated through a weighted summation to form class-specific aggregated tokens. By applying domain discrimination loss on these aggregated tokens, our method enables class-aware instance-level feature alignment, further narrowing the domain gap. Extensive experiments are conducted across three cross domain settings on public datasets including Cityscapes, Foggy Cityscapes, Sim10k, and BDD100k daytime. Both quantitative results and qualitative visualizations demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed approach.

title: Evaluation of Majorant Signals on Closed-Loop Robustness of an Adaptive Controller Applied to Grid-Tied Converters with LCL Filter
authors: Wagner Barreto da Silveira, Paulo J. Dias de Oliveira Evald, Alexandre Silva Lucena, Rodrigo Varella Tambara, Hilton Abílio Gründling
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: This work presents a comparison of five different majorant signals, including two new proposed variants, and evaluates their impact on the robustness and performance of an adaptive controller. These majorant signals are integrated into the gradient algorithm of a robust model reference adaptive control-based full adaptive super twisting sliding mode (RMRAC-FASTSM) controller. The controllers are assessed on the current regulation of a voltage source inverter under realistic operating conditions, including synchronization, current control, grid inductance variation, and a load step. The results indicate that the implementations incorporating <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Gamma$</tex>-weighted terms (Approaches 35) consistently yield lower root mean square (RMS) tracking errors across all transients, while Approach 1 exhibits the largest overshoots and prolonged settling times. Approach 3 achieves the most balanced performance, providing the best trade-off between transient suppression and steady-state accuracy, without affecting the total harmonic distortion in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta$</tex> coordinates.

title: Assessing the Impact of Vegetation Clustering on Land Surface Temperature: A Spatial Analysis in Southern Delhi
authors: Dyvavani Krishna Kapuganti, Kailash C Tiwari, Gopala Areendran
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Rapid urbanisation strains ecological stability, fragmenting land cover and altering surface thermal patterns. This study examines vegetation spatial clustering and its relationship with Land Surface Temperature (LST) in southern Delhi, India, using Landsat 8 (30 m resolution) satellite data for spring, summer and post-monsoon seasons in 2022. Spatial patterns are analysed using two Local Indicators of Spatial Association (LISA): Moran’s I for LST spatial autocorrelation Getis-Ord Gi* for vegetation clustering. The results reveal significantly High Moran’s I values for LST (0.96-0.98) indicating strong spatial dependance, across all seasons. The Spatial autoregression using Geographically Weighted Regression (GWR) corrected for this autocorrelation, resulted in more dispersed residuals. Pearson’s correlation between LST and NDVI-based Gi* scores reveal a moderate negative relationship in March (r = -0.4) and October (r = -0.3), and a weaker one in May (r = -0.12). The findings suggest that clustered vegetation can help mitigate urban heat, while ensuring an even distribution to enhance cooling effects, particularly during summer.

title: Finite-Time Trajectory Tracking and Obstacle Avoidance Control for a Quadrotor Aircraft
authors: Di Wu, Congrang Jiang, Liren Shao, Guipu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper investigates the trajectory tracking and obstacle avoidance problem of a quadrotor aircraft. Based on the model structure, the quadrotor aircraft system can be divided into the position system and the attitude system. Firstly, for the position system, a finite-time position tracking controller with obstacle avoidance function is designed based on the homogeneous system theory and the control barrier function method. For the attitude system, a finite-time attitude controller is proposed based on the homogeneous system theory. Finally, numerical simulation results are given to verify the control performance of the proposed control scheme.

title: Identification Method of Interturn Short Circuit Faults for Transformer Based on a Fast Algorithm for Tellegen's Quasi-Power Theorem
authors: Lu Guoxin, Liu Shiming, Kang Yongqi
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In recent years, transformer winding inter-turn faults have occurred frequently and are difficult to detect in a timely manner, posing a significant threat to the safe and stable operation of power systems. To address this issue, this paper proposes a fast algorithm for internal fault detection in transformers based on the Tellegen Quasi-power theorem. First, a fast calculation method for the virtual power of the transformer fault branch is derived. The magnitude of this virtual power reflects the severity of internal transformer faults. Based on this, a fast fault detection method for transformer internal faults is proposed. Next, a 3D finite element simulation model consistent with the actual transformer is established. By varying the number of shorted turns, the gradual degradation process of inter-turn faults is simulated, and the variation pattern of virtual power is studied. Additionally, the impact of external faults, load fluctuations, and non-fault phases on the calculation results is analyzed, demonstrating the superiority of this method. This approach can detect the transformer winding status within half a cycle, is unaffected by external faults, and can identify the faulted phase, showcasing its broad application potential.

title: Federated Edge AI for Adaptive Zero-Trust Security in Resource-Constrained IoT Networks
authors: Dina Al-Sadi, Abdoul Rjoub
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: This paper proposes a Federated Edge AI framework with Adaptive Zero-Trust Security designed for resource constrained IoT networks used mainly in smart cities applications. The framework harnesses and deploys lightweight machine learning models, real-time anomaly detection capabilities, and dynamic trust scoring. Each IoT device can also deploy differential privacy and lightweight encryption as optional features. Dynamic trust scoring enables the federated learning process to identify and mitigate malicious clients in adversarial environments, while trust-weighted aggregation prioritizes reliable model updates. The framework is simulated under both IID and non-IID datasets from IoT-23 dataset, with up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 0 \%}$</tex> malicious clients to ensure there was a significant amount of anomalous client behavior, control groups and dependent groups to make comparisons and assess precision, false positive-negative, communication and computational load. The lightweight framework is an applicable idea to real-world like smart cities applications, as it is scalable and highly privacy preserving. Use Case Examples include intelligent traffic management, smart energy grids, and security of UAV swarms - where IoT devices must operate in a secure fashion, under strict latencies, power, and resource limitations.

title: Experimental study of hot spots and perforation of plates used in fuel tanks by lightning
authors: Hélio Eiji Sueta, Luis Eduardo Caires, Miltom Shigihara, Roberto Zilles, Oscar Romão
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: One of the most damaging effects of lightning strikes is when they involve fuel tanks. There are several ways in which lightning can damage a fuel tank: through direct discharges to the tanks and through indirect effects due to discharges close to the tanks. Direct discharges to fuel tanks can be very dangerous: they can cause perforation of plates; the generation of hot spots inside the plate; the occurrence of arcing due to voltage or current density at dangerous points in the tank. Indirect effects due to discharges close to tanks are equally dangerous, since they can cause dangerous arcing due to potential transfer; due to unconnected upward leaders; due to intense electric fields; due to magnetic fields; in sensors and metal pipes that enter the tanks; due to induced current in the plates; and due to the passage of discharges in a classified environment, which occurs close to the outlets of valves, vents and overflows. This work focuses on the generation of hot spots on the inside of plates used in fuel tanks, both due to the direct impact of a lightning and due to the sparks generated by this discharge reaching a Lightning Protection System (LPS) installed on the tank, and these sparks (incandescent and molten material) reaching plates considered thin (for example, aluminum plates used in geodesic domes) and transmitting heat to the inside of these plates. Carbon steel plates with a nominal thickness of 4,76 mm (3/16"), 3,18 mm (1/8") and aluminum plates used in geodesic domes with a nominal thickness of 1.2 mm (5/100") were studied. Laboratory tests were carried out using direct current pulses to simulate the components of continuing currents (important components of lightning that are responsible for the greatest thermal effects), applying these pulses directly to the plates; directly to the tip of mini rods installed on the plates and also to conductors installed one meter above the plates (simulating an air-termination system), and generating many incandescent sparks that reach the plates, which can generate internal hot spots. The applications were recorded by high-capacity oscillographs (currents, arc voltages etc) and filmed with common cameras and with very high-speed cameras (the tests were filmed at 4200 frames per second) and using a thermal imager to capture the temperatures on the underside of the plates to check for hot spots. This study shows the results of these tests and analyzes the hot spots.

title: Research on the Component Analysis and Disposal Plan of Firefighting Wastewater from Large Oilfilled Equipment Fire Accidents in UHV Converter Substations
authors: Lingxin He, Yi Guo, Jiaqing Zhang, Guocheng Ding, Rui Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: As UHV lines are being deployed nationwide, fire hazard prevention and control for such lines have become a focus of research. Due to the large oil storage capacity (up to over one hundred tons) of UHV converter transformers, the use of foam extinguishing systems will generate a large amount of “oil-water-foam” mixture. At present, the country is increasingly emphasizing ecological environmental protection. This paper analyzes the components of firefighting mixtures generated by large oil storage equipment in UHV converter stations after fire accidents and compares different disposal schemes. It deeply analyzes the chemical composition of firefighting mixtures and cooling water and their environmental impacts, proposing targeted collection and disposal plans. The research results of this paper not only provide a reference basis for relevant enterprises to formulate wastewater treatment measures within their premises, enhancing their fire emergency response capabilities, but also offer scientific evidence for achieving their low-carbon environmental protection development goals.

title: Packaging Layout Optimization and Lifetime Assessment of Paralleled SiC Power Devices Based on the Rainflow Algorithm
authors: Xi Yang, Yongqiang Tan, Chong Gao, Weitang Zhang, Jian Jiao, Jingzhong Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In paralleled silicon carbide (SiC) power semiconductor devices, packaging layout and current sharing have a direct impact on thermal stress distribution and device reliability. This paper proposes a lifetime evaluation method based on packaging layout optimization and the rainflow algorithm for paralleled SiC power modules under realistic operating conditions. A three-phase inverter-permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSM) coupled simulation model with paralleled chip bridge arms was developed in PLECS, driven by real-world speed-torque profiles to extract junction temperature-time data of each chip. The junction temperature waveforms were then processed in MATLAB using rainflow counting to obtain thermal cycle distributions, and the equivalent lifetime was estimated by combining Miner's cumulative damage theory with a thermal fatigue model. Results show that optimizing the busbar connection and packaging layout, such that the source current path is perpendicular to the parallel direction, effectively reduces transient current imbalance and suppresses junction temperature fluctuations. Under both urban and uphill operating conditions, the optimized module achieved approximately 13% and 12% reduction in cumulative damage, respectively, resulting in a significant extension of the equivalent lifetime. These findings provide theoretical and methodological support for advanced power module packaging design and reliability enhancement.

title: Enhance the Performance of Piezoelectric Vibration Energy Harvester via U-Shaped Dynamic Magnifier
authors: Yu Qiu, Xiaoquan Chu, Pengfan Wu, Fayang Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Aiming to enhance the output performance, a Ushaped dynamic magnifier (U-DM) based on piezoelectric vibration energy harvester (PVEH) is proposed. Subsequently, an array-based design is incorporated to broaden the frequency bandwidth and improve the space utilization of the structure. By using COMSOL Multiphysics software, the output voltages of PVEHs with and without the U-DM are obtained through frequency scanning in the frequency domain, and the dimensional parameters of the U-DM are optimized. The simulation results show that the method can simultaneously achieve multiple resonant peaks and improve output performance, which provides new perspectives for the subsequent design of miniaturized array PVEHs, aiming to enhance output performance and improve frequency bandwidth for powering low-power chips and sensors.

title: AI-Based Medical Diagnosis System Using Machine Learning
authors: Jadish Chandra Patni, A Ezil Sam Leni, Aryan Singh, Pragatindu Yajnashree Parida, Abhinav Pratap Singh, Poorva Agrawal, Harshala Shingne
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: This work focuses on the development of an AI-driven medical diagnosis system that leverages machine learning algorithms to predict the likelihood of multiple diseases based on user-provided health information. The primary objective is to enhance early detection and provide users with rapid, accurate diagnostic feedback through a responsive web-based interface. The system utilizes publicly available datasets that include comprehensive patient records and symptom-based information to train and evaluate the models. A tailored approach was taken for each disease by selecting the most appropriate machine learning model: Logistic Regression was used for diseases with binary outcomes such as breast cancer and COVID-19; Decision Tree models were applied for predicting kidney disease and general symptom-based diagnosis; and Random Forest was utilized for heart disease due to its capability in handling complex feature interactions. All models were trained using an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80: 20$</tex> train-test split and evaluated using performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.

title: Generative AI for Augmenting Medical Imaging Datasets in DL-Based Diagnostics
authors: Laxmi Choudhary, Bhanupriya Sharma, Satya Narayan Tazi, Vineet Sharma, Vinay Garg
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The efficacy of deep learning (DL) diagnostic systems in medical imaging largely depends on the availability of large-scale high-quality annotated datasets. However, in realworld clinical settings, such datasets are often limited due to factors such as data privacy regulations, the high cost of expert annotation, and the rarity of certain pathological conditions. These issues lead to limited and unbalanced data distributions. To address these challenges, propose a hybrid model that synthesizes medical images using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and denoises them with a Gaussian filter. This model operates within a binary classification framework, distinguishing between normal and pneumonia cases, using a curated subset of the Chest X-ray14 dataset. The GAN generates disease-specific synthetic images, which are then filtered using a Gaussian blur to minimize visual artifacts. This process improves the balance and variety of the training dataset, ultimately improving the accuracy and robustness of the classification model. Further, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is trained on the augmented dataset to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed data synthesis pipeline. Key performance indicators, including classification accuracy and reduction in validation loss, demonstrate the robustness of the proposed model, especially in data-scarce and class-imbalanced conditions. Having a classification accuracy of 97 %, the model effectively distinguishes between pneumonia and normal cases. The results confirm the strong sensitivity and specificity of the model, as it accurately identifies true pneumonia cases while minimizing false positives.

title: 5 µm Pixel and Column ADC for 1 MGy Radiation Tolerant CMOS Image Sensor
authors: I. Hafizh, P. Santos, P. Leroux, G. Meynants
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: This article proposes a new pixel and column ADC with radiation-hardened-by-design mitigations for a CMOS image sensor (CIS) to withstand 1 MGy total ionizing dose (TID). The pixel consists of a partially pinned photodiode structure combined with butterfly and dog-bone pixel transistors. The p+ layer from the ‘pinning’ implant, in combination with the shallow trench isolation (STI) structure that is recessed from the photodiode region, prevents the photodiode to collect dark current contributions from TID-induced traps at the Si/SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> interface and shields the photodiode from TID-induced positive charges in the SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. The column ADC employs dual sample and hold stages, dual comparators, and dual 10-bit counters, and utilizes only a single-slope conversion cycle. Each comparator performs double sampling to eliminate comparator offset, which is expected to worsen with TID-induced voltage shift and mismatch. Then, digital double sampling (DDS) is performed to obtain the signal subtracted from the reset level of the photodiode. The pixel has a 5µm pitch and the column readout fits in a 10µm pitch, designed in 180nm technology. Preliminary results confirm good performance both in pre-rad condition and after TID above 1MGy and high temperature annealing (HTA)

title: On Rust and C Variability of Fault Sensitivity across Different Runtimes and Cache-Aware Source Codes
authors: A. Martínez-Álvarez, D. González-Montesoro, R. Possamai Bastos, S. Cuenca-Asensi, A. Serrano-Cases
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: This paper explores how cache-optimized C and Rust source code impact the performance of a critical system under radiation. Several implementations of the matrix multiplication algorithm have been tested to show how the variability of fault sensitivity is affected. The versions exposed to radiation were those presenting the highest dissimilarities in terms of the following static and dynamic software metrics: initialized and uninitialized required data memory and code, L1 and L2 data cache impact, and execution time. Static and dynamic measures from the generated binary executable were collected and correlated with radiation-induced effects. Results show that cache optimization has a positive impact on fault tolerance, regardless of the selected language, compiler, or runtime. Particularly, Rust implementation emerged as the top-performing version under radiation, surpassing the C versions. Rust exhibited the highest Mean Work To Failure (MWTF) without negatively affecting the cross section. These results suggest Rust as a promising option for implementing fault-tolerant applications.

title: Agile Obstacle Avoidance Control Based on Dynamic Velocity Obstacle Perception
authors: Kaiwen Niu, Juan Li, Chang Liu, Jie Li, Lei Fu, Xiao Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
