abstract: To enhance the obstacle avoidance capability of quadrotor UAVs for high-speed dynamic obstacles, this paper proposes a Dynamic Velocity Obstacle-aware Model Predictive Control (DVO-MPC) method. The proposed method integrates trajectory prediction of dynamic obstacles with a velocity obstacle discrimination mechanism to identify potential collision risks in a multi-step prediction horizon in real time, generating the shortest-time avoidance trajectories oriented toward the target velocity direction. A model predictive control strategy is employed to locally optimize both the avoidance and original mission trajectories, while a differential flatness-based controller ensures rapid attitude tracking. This design enhances the overall responsiveness and robustness of the system, enabling agile and reliable obstacle avoidance in complex, dynamic environments. The effectiveness of the proposed DVO-MPC is validated through high-fidelity software-in-the-loop simulations, which demonstrate superior performance in both hovering and flighting scenarios, as well as agile control under high-speed flight conditions. Comparative results show that the proposed method significantly outperforms conventional algorithms.Potential application scenarios include urban search and rescue, low-altitude dynamic traffic, and evasion in special mission environments.

title: Distributed Optimization of Multi-USV Systems for Marine Environmental Monitoring
authors: Meng Luan, Guanghui Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper investigates the optimal deployment strategies of multi-unmanned surface vehicle (USV) systems for marine environmental monitoring. To accomplish the collaborative monitoring tasks, multi-USV systems are required to preserve relative position offsets to the monitoring center while maintaining their geometric centroid at the predefined monitoring center. Meanwhile, each USV system seeks its desired monitoring position, determined by the current operational status and local environmental factors. In this context, an optimal deployment problem is formulated through synthesizing collective monitoring objectives with individual requirements. To address this issue, a novel fully distributed optimization algorithm applicable to digraphs is proposed, which incorporates several key techniques including adaptive gain designs, variable substitution and leader-following gradient estimation. It is rigorously demonstrated that the developed algorithm asymptotically converges to the optimal solution under mild assumptions through Lyapunov stability theory. Finally, numerical simulations demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Sensorless Temperature Estimation of Squirrel Cage Induction Motor Using Transient Low Order Lumped Parameter Thermal Network Model
authors: Rohan Derek Mendonca, Fuat Kucuk
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Integrating physical temperature sensors into existing motor designs can be challenging due to structural constraints and the complexity involved in wiring and real-time data acquisition systems. As a result, sensorless thermal estimation techniques offer a more feasible, cost-effective, and scalable alternative for thermal monitoring in electric machines. However, most available LPTN-based methods are highly complex, featuring many thermal nodes, which increases the computational burden and limits their practicality for real-time, embedded implementation. Moreover, existing research often shows significant discrepancies, which frequently exceed 2°C, between estimated and experimentally measured temperatures, that could pose a risk of thermal damage if such models are relied upon for online control. This paper presents the development and validation of a transient low-order lumped parameter thermal network (LPTN) model for sensorless temperature estimation in a squirrel cage induction motor (SCIM) where an equivalent electrical circuit of the motor is utilised to construct a reduced-order thermal model that captures the dominant heat transfer paths within the motor components, including the stator windings, stator core, and rotor. Experimental investigations were performed under no-load and variable-load operating conditions to observe the behaviour of temperature rise over time. These results were then compared against the LPTN simulation outputs. The proposed model demonstrated high accuracy, with the maximum deviation between the estimated and measured temperatures remaining within 1.3°C. The findings confirm that the proposed sensorless LPTN model provides reliable real-time temperature estimation, which is essential for enhancing thermal protection and extending the operational lifespan of induction motors in industrial and automotive applications.

title: Three-dimension UAV Path Planning Using Ant Colony Optimization, Genetic Algorithm and Particle Swarm Optimization
authors: Zhipeng Ye, Jian Jiang, Haoting Liu, Xiaofei Lu, Haiguang Li, Qing Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: In the complex disaster relief environment, UAV path planning faces multiple challenges such as flight safety, path feasibility, and time efficiency. In order to improve the global search ability, planning quality and convergence speed of path planning, this paper proposes a multi-strategy intelligent path planning algorithm (MAGP) combining ant colony optimization (ACO), genetic algorithm (GA) and particle swarm optimization (PSO). The algorithm constructs three kinds of sub-ant colony structures with complementary functions, adjusts the ant colony size proportion adaptively by combining the difference of path distribution and fitness variance, and improves the robustness of the algorithm and the diversity of solutions through the phased fusion optimization strategy. A typical 3D mountain disaster environment simulation scene is designed and compared with the traditional ACO, GA and PSO algorithms. The results show that MAGP is superior to traditional methods in path quality, search efficiency and algorithm stability, and can deal with the path planning problem under complex rescue tasks more effectively.

title: Phishing URL Detection with Deep Learning: Trends, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Sangeetha TS, Piyoosh Purushothaman Nair
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Phishing is a growing cybersecurity threat, with attackers continuously evolving their tactics to traditional detection mechanisms. We are observing a sharp increase in phishing attacks, particularly with an increase in smishing incidents and the manipulation of social media platforms for malicious activities. This paper first discusses traditional phishing URL detection methods and their limitations. The study then focuses on different deep learning approaches, including convolutional neural networks (CNNs), recurrent neural networks (RNNs), and transformer-based models, showcasing their accuracy in detecting phishing URLs. Despite considerable advancements in deep learning based detection, the paper also highlights several challenges that exist in such systems, like imbalanced datasets, adversarial attacks, scalability issues, and real-time detection constraints. In addition, we discuss the necessity of advanced solutions such as federated learning, adversarial training, and the integration of real-time threat intelligence to improve phishing detection capabilities.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Enhanced Retry Queue System for Unmanned Systems in 6G Networks
authors: Djamila Talbi, Zoltan Gal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: The rise of autonomous systems like drones and robotic networks demands highly adaptive 6G wireless communication capable of handling unpredictable traffic. Traditional queue management struggles under these dynamic conditions. This paper presents a novel approach combining retrial queueing models with Deep Reinforcement Learning to optimize traffic handling in 6G networks. The RL agent learns to manage queues dynamically, improving throughput while reducing delays and congestion. Simulation results demonstrate the approach’s effectiveness in balancing service efficiency and resource use, highlighting the promise of AI-driven, self-optimizing 6G networks that meet the needs of future unmanned systems.

title: Design of IGBT Secondary Drive Chip for Applied Power Electronic Systems
authors: Gang Liu, Qiang Xu, Xiaoyu Bie, Kangwei Xing
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: As the core power switching device of modern power electronic system, IGBT is widely used in new energy power generation, industrial inverter and electric vehicle with its advantages of high withstand voltage, high current and strong controllability. As its core control interface, the IGBT gate driver realizes fast switching control of the IGBT by amplifying the input voltage, and integrates the fault protection mechanism to improve the efficiency and reliability of the IGBT. In this paper, an IGBT secondary driver chip is designed, which integrates an output driver module and a protection module, which is used to receive the signal from the primary control circuit, and provides a suitable drive signal for the IGBT after appropriate amplification and level translation. The simulation and test results show that the secondary-side driver chip designed in this paper can meet the requirements of driving IGBT, and the performance can reach the preset indicators and can be applied to practice.

title: AI-Enabled Waste Classification as a Data-Driven Decision Support Tool for Circular Economy and Urban Sustainability
authors: Julius Sechang Mboli, Omolara Aderonke Ogungbemi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Efficient waste sorting is crucial for enabling circular-economy practices and resource recovery in smart cities. This paper evaluates both traditional machine-learning (Random Forest, SVM, AdaBoost) and deep-learning techniques including custom CNNs, VGG16, ResNet50, and three transfer-learning models (DenseNet121, EfficientNetB0, InceptionV3) for binary classification of 25077 waste images (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80 / 20$</tex> train/test split, augmented and resized to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150 \times 150 \text{px}$</tex>). The paper assesses the impact of Principal Component Analysis for dimensionality reduction on traditional models. DenseNet121 achieved the highest accuracy (91 %) and ROC-AUC (0.98), outperforming the best traditional classifier by 20 pp. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) showed negligible benefit for classical methods, whereas transfer learning substantially improved performance under limited-data conditions. Finally, we outline how these models integrate into a real-time Data-Driven Decision Support System for automated waste sorting, highlighting potential reductions in landfill use and lifecycle environmental impacts.)

title: Transient Stability Analysis of Wind Turbine Tied to DRU-HVDC
authors: Ziyu Fu, Zimo Zhao, Wenhao Tong, Zhiyuan Wang, Lujie Yu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Diode-rectifier-unit based high voltage direct current (DRU-HVDC) system, which has the advantage of lower cost, shows promising prospects in offshore wind power transmission. This paper mainly focuses on the transient stability of the grid-forming wind turbine converter connected to DRU-HVDC system. Firstly, the system nonlinear model is established. Subsequently, analytical expressions for system equilibrium point post-fault are derived. Finally, the Lyapunov function is constructed using the Takagi-Sugeno method to estimate the domain of attraction, through which the impact of phase-locked loop and voltage control parameters on transient stability is analyzed. Comparative verification with simulation cases in PSCAD/EMTDC confirms the accuracy of the stability analysis.

title: Comparative Analysis of Multilevel Inverter Topologies for Induction Motors
authors: Ananthapadmanabhan R, Deepa M U
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: The paper aims to compare various Multi Level Inverter (MLI) topologies for Induction Motor (IM) drive that effectively reduce the Total Harmonic Distortion (THD). Harmonics in inverter output voltage refer to presence of noise having frequency those are the multiples of fundamental frequency. These harmonics are distortions formed due to the switching of MOSFETs, IGBTs or any other power electronic switches in the process of converting DC voltage into AC. Compared to two level inverter MLI produce output voltage which is more closer to sine wave. Good quality output voltage waveforms and high power ratings can be achieved with MLI with less electromagnetic interference, leading to improved efficiency. This paper aims to reduce harmonics by utilizing a multilevel inverter for DC/AC conversion with variable frequency. Voltage control is provided via Sinusoidal Pulse Width Modulation (SPWM) technique. Diode clamped and Cascaded H-Bridge (CHB) MLI are selected for five level output voltage generation. Also the scope of a Modified Cascaded H-Bridge (MCHB) MLI topology for a IM is studied. Variable Frequency Drives are required to provide variable speed control with increased efficiency and reliability. The MLI fed variable frequency drive provides optimum performance with low total harmonic distortion, thus improving the efficiency of induction motor drives.

title: Automated 5-Axis System for Mosquito Dispensed Waveguides
authors: Laura Fütterer, Andreas Evertz, Ludger Overmeyer
publish: 2025 IEEE CPMT Symposium Japan (ICSJ)
abstract: This work presents a laboratory system designed for the fabrication of mosquito dispensed optical waveguides. Preliminary experiments demonstrate the usability and functionality of the self-developed system by measuring the pitch of waveguides dispensed within cavities.

title:
The Visible-Light-Responsive Photoactivity for H

                    <sub>3</sub>

                    Heterojunction
authors: Xiaolan Li, Lei Wang, Yan Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: A novel all-polymer bulk heterojunction (BHJ) photocatalytic system was constructed by integrating poly(3-octylthiophene) (P3OT) as an electron donor with graphitic carbon nitride <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(g-C_{3} N_{4}\right)$</tex> via a facile rotary evaporation approach. Systematic evaluation revealed that the hydrogen evolution performance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{P} 3 \text{OT} / \mathrm{g}-\mathrm{C}_{3} \mathrm{N}_{4}$</tex> exhibits remarkable sensitivity to sacrificial reagents, where ascorbic acid (AA) was identified as the optimal electron donor. Under visible-light illumination (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda \geqslant 420 \text{nm}$</tex>), the composite with 2 wt% P3OT loading demonstrated an exceptional hydrogen production rate of 2870 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu m o l h^{-1}$</tex> in AA-saturated solution—a 491-fold enhancement compared to the system without sacrificial agents. Notably, this configuration achieved a record apparent quantum yield (AQY) of 75.8% at 420 nm, surpassing most reported g - <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C}_{3} \mathrm{N}_{4}$</tex>-based photocatalysts. The performance enhancement can be attributed to the broader light absorption of P3OT, improved charge separation at the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{P} 3 \text{OT} / \mathrm{g}-\mathrm{C}_{3} \mathrm{N}_{4}$</tex> interface, and the favorable oxidation process promoted by ascorbic acid. These results demonstrate the potential of P3OT as an effective donor polymer in BHJ photocatalytic systems and highlight the critical role of sacrificial reagents in regulating overall photocatalytic efficiency.

title: Direct Analytical Solution for Perfect Anomalous Reflection from Nonlocal Metasurfaces
authors: Alexander Zhuravlev, Vyacheslav Ivliev, Stanislav Glybovski, Xuchen Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: Metasurfaces being effectively smooth boundaries realized as two-dimensional arrays of engineered meta-atoms with a subwavelength step offer unique capabilities for wavefront transformation. One of their key applications is anomalous reflection that is applicable for reducing signal propagation loss in telecommunication systems. The traditional phase-gradient method allows deriving a direct analytical solution for the spatial distribution of surface impedance thanks to the local reflection phase approximation, but suffers from low efficiency at high reflection angles due to wave impedance mismatch. While more advanced macroscopic synthesis methods such as auxiliary field and power conformal methods approach unitary reflection efficiency at arbitrary angles, nonlinear optimization of the impedance distribution and curved metasurface profile are required, accordingly. Here, we describe and numerically verify a new direct analytical solution to the problem of perfect co-polarized anomalous reflection from a flat metasurface modeled with spatially nonuniform and nonlocal boundary condition.

title: Surge protective device for Ethernet-APL featuring advanced overload protection
authors: Steffen Pförtner, Eugen Leongardt, Andrei Siegel, Markus Philipp, Gernot Finis
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: Nowadays, classic analog signal transmissions are going to be replaced by digital signal transmissions. Ethernet advanced physical layer (Ethernet-APL), a form of Single Pair Ethernet (SPE), enhances data transmission in Ethernet networks, enabling up to 10 Mbit/s over 1000 meters and supporting power delivery over the same two wires. The protection of Ethernet-APL applications sets special signal transmission requirements for SPDs. This paper describes the requirements regarding signal transmission characteristics deriving from Ethernet-APL and relevant tests to evaluate the transmission behaviour are shown. Further the focus is set on a newly developed solution of a failure current-triggered disconnect unit for GDTs mounted on a printed circuit board (PCB) and test procedures to show the performance are discussed. The results presented, provide practical information for the design and qualification-testing of SPDs fulfilling the safety-relevant requirements of the new IEC 61643-21 Ed 2 [1] and further requirements beyond, arising from an incorrect selection or connection of the SPD or even power cross failures.

title: CampusVision: Augmented Reality Campus walkthrough from Satellite images
authors: Jayakumar T V, Deepak Mishra, Ramiya A M, Jai G Singla
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: This paper introduces CampusVision, an innovative technology that integrates augmented reality (AR) with deep learning-powered semantic segmentation to transform campus navigation. CampusVision employs advanced image processing techniques to extract crucial campus characteristics by pre-processing satellite data and utilizing the ResUNet model for semantic segmentation. Thereafter, Unity3D integrates these properties so they create a virtual environment that can be accessed using AR devices. Users are provided with complete information about events, buildings and landmarks through the augmented reality interface of the system which has real-time overlays. To enhance the quality of immersive campus walk-through experiences, CampusVision uses interactive tools and seamless navigation, thereby increasing convenience, productivity, and user satisfaction.

title: Resilient Enhancement of CPS against Sparse Sensor Attacks by Proportion Side Information
authors: Zheyi Zhao, Xuqiang Lei, Jiayuan Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This article studies the resilience enhancement problem of cyber-physical systems (CPS) against sparse sensor attacks. Unlike most secure state estimation (SSE) studies that focus primarily on improving algorithm execution efficiency, we aim to enhance the resilience of CPS by incorporating proportion side information into the SSE framework. Through a non-singular linear transformation, it demonstrates that the original system, when augmented with proportion side information, can be transformed into an equivalent system characterized by sparse and side information coupling. Building upon this, the reinforced non-convex optimization problem and its convex relaxation optimization problem are formulated for solution, and the sufficient conditions for their equivalence are rigorously derived. Finally, numerical simulations on a diffusion process model validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in improving the resistance of the system against sparse attacks.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Channel Access Scheme for Energy Efficiency Optimization in IEEE 802.11be With Multi-Link Operation
authors: Tong Ye, Wen Zhan, Wenhai Lin, Xiang Chen, Shuangfeng Han, Xiaoyun Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: Multi-link operation in Wi-Fi 7 presents new opportunities as well as challenges, particularly concerning energy efficiency for battery-powered devices. While MLO can boost throughput by utilizing multiple links, it also increases energy consumption. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning framework to optimize the energy efficiency of the heterogeneous Wi-Fi network, where Multi-Link Devices (MLDs) coexist with legacy single-link devices and use the simultaneous transmit and receive mode with synchronized transmission. We formulate the channel access problem as a multi-agent combinatorial multiarmed bandit problem and design a decentralized learning algorithm based on the combinatorial upper-confidence-bound strategy. Using this framework, we further take a closer look at the performance difference between two MLO modes: diversity and multiplexing. Extensive simulations demonstrate that our framework enables MLDs to autonomously learn energy-efficient transmission strategies that adapt to varying network conditions and in most cases, multiplexing outperforms diversity.

title: Power-Assisted Motor Control Strategy Study for Intelligent Passenger Vehicles under Emergency Braking Conditions
authors: Yanliang Gong, Chunjiang Bao, Jian Wu, Jiwei Feng, Aopeng Hou, Yahui Xu, Yelin He
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: With the speedy progress of smart passenger vehicle technological, people have higher and higher requirements for the emergency braking performance of intelligent passenger vehicles, and the speed of the booster motor cannot break the limit of rated speed during emergency braking, which may cause problems such as the driver's foot feeling heavy, and thus weaken the braking performance. To this end, we propose an active disturbance rejection controller (ADRC)-based boost motor control strategy to enhance the driving performance and reliability of braking in passenger vehicles. Firstly, the overrun corner weak magnetization control is proposed to expand the rotation velocity range of the booster motor, which helps to enhance the driver's foot comfort during emergency braking. Then, an ADRC controller is then introduced into the velocity loop to provide a faster motor speed reaction and improve the immunity of the booster motor. Finally, the control strategy proposed in this paper was simulated and verified by Matlab/Simulink, and experimentally verified by electric power assisted braking stand, and the results demonstrate that the control strategy of the proposed boost motor can mitigate the problem of heavy driver's foot feeling effectively, and at the same time improve the response speed and anti-interference ability of the motor.

title: Fashion Product Forecasting: A Literature Review of Influential Factors and Techniques
authors: Midavaine Alix, Chompoonoot Kasemset
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: This study explores forecasting methods and key influencing factors for seasonal fashion products, aiming to enhance demand prediction accuracy. The research is grounded in a case study of a Thailand-based fashion company that currently relies on intuition-driven forecasting, often resulting in inventory imbalances such as overstocks and understocks. Through a comprehensive literature review, both time series models and machine learning approaches are examined to assess their applicability to fashion product forecasting. Additionally, critical factors affecting demand are identified and evaluated to align with the specific context of the case study, providing a foundation for implementing more data-driven forecasting strategies.

title: Multi-Architecture Deep Learning Approach for Enhanced Energy Consumption Forecasting
authors: Ratul Halder, Kazi Firoz Ahmed
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: This study proposes a comprehensive approach to short-term energy consumption forecasting based on state-of-the-art deep learning architectures with hybrid and ensemble methodologies. Using the ASHRAE Great Energy Predictor III (GEPIII) dataset, we conduct a detailed assessment of the performance of Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), Long ShortTerm Memory (LSTM) with Attention, Tabular Transformer and Transformer for Time Series based models. An important achievement is the weighted ensemble model that combines predictions from these different types of architectures. Our end-to-end approach covers everything from data preprocessing, and feature engineering to training strategy optimization. The ensemble model is shown to outperform the individual models and common machine learning methods with a maximum <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{2}$</tex> score of 0.8927. The enhanced performance is due to the ensemble's capacity to model complex non-linear interactions between various factors, while also reducing the impact of weaknesses in individual models. These findings highlight the importance of all the advanced deep learning to enhance the predictive skill of the energy-related patterns and are expected to bring significant improvements in energy management to better allocate our precious resources, mitigate the operational expense and to reach the global carbon neutrality target.

title: Stochastic Reliability Analysis of Photovoltaic Systems: An Applied Study with Petri Nets and Monte Carlo
authors: Jackson Furtuoso da Silva, Jean Patric da Costa, Daniel Fernando Simon, Gustavo Weber Denardin
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: This work presents the stochastic modeling of the reliability and availability of a grid-connected photovoltaic system using timed Petri nets combined with Monte Carlo simulations. The model was parameterized with failure and repair rates extracted from the literature and applied to a real subsystem installed at UTFPR, comprising module strings, DC cables, inverter, AC cables, transformer, and the effect of soiling. A total of 5,000 iterations were performed for horizons of 1 to 30 years, allowing the extraction of robust metrics such as MTTF, accumulated downtime, and failure frequency. The results indicated strings and the inverter highlighted as the main sources of unavailability. Soiling presented a typical saturation behavior, reinforcing the importance of periodic cleanings. Finally, the study proposes a preventive maintenance schedule aligned with the stochastic behavior of the components, contributing to prolonging system lifetime and reducing failure-related costs. Future work includes local calibration of the rates and integration of predictive maintenance with learning algorithms.

title: Deceive, Detect, and Defend: A Multi-Layered Approach to Adaptive Ransomware Mitigation
authors: Napatr Sawamipak, Supagarn Pattananuchart, Punnaphat Chiangpradit, Adirut Lertthirathanaphong, Somchart Fugkeaw
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: Ransomware attacks have grown increasingly sophisticated, employing advanced encryption and evasion strategies to target critical data. Traditional detection techniques—such as machine learning and sandboxing—often suffer from high false-positive rates, frequent retraining needs, and limited resilience against evolving threats. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a three-layer adaptive ransomware detection and containment system. The first layer performs real-time file monitoring and extension filtering to optimize resource usage. The second layer integrates SVM-based analysis with an adaptive sandbox that uses randomized user activity, resource mimicry, and human interaction simulation to deceive and trigger ransomware behavior. The third layer incorporates the RTrap framework, leveraging decoy files to trap ransomware that bypasses earlier defenses. Extensive experiments demonstrate a 98.4% detection accuracy with faster response times compared to benchmark systems. This multi-layered architecture provides a scalable, robust, and adaptive defense, effectively mitigating both known and emerging ransomware threats in dynamic environments.

title: GASP: Gradient-Aware Shortest Path Algorithm for Boundary-Confined 2-Manifold Reeb Graph Visualization
authors: Sefat E Rahman, Tushar M. Athawale, Paul Rosen
publish: 2025 IEEE Workshop on Topological Data Analysis and Visualization (TopoInVis)
abstract: Reeb graphs are an important tool for abstracting and representing the topological structure of a function defined on a manifold. We have identified three properties for faithfully representing Reeb graphs in a visualization: they should be constrained to the boundary, compact, and aligned with the function gradient. Existing algorithms for drawing Reeb graphs are agnostic to or violate these properties. In this paper, we introduce an algorithm to generate Reeb graph visualizations, called GASP, that is cognizant of these properties, thereby producing visualizations that are more representative of the underlying data. To demonstrate the improvements, the resulting Reeb graphs are evaluated both qualitatively and quantitatively against the geometric barycenter algorithm, using its implementation available in the Topology ToolKit (TTK), a widely adopted tool for calculating and visualizing Reeb graphs.

title: AI-Based Optimization of Mandarin Learning: Utilization of LLM for Hanyu Pinyin Recognition in Junior High Schools
authors: Putu Eka Pandayani, Aniek Suryanti Kusuma, Ni Wayan Sumartini Saraswati
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: This study aims to explore the implementation of artificial intelligence (AI) using the MarianMT Large Language Model (LLM) to optimise the accuracy of text translation into Hanyu Pinyin and the efficiency of translation processing time for Mandarin language learning at the junior high school level. Using a pivot translation approach (Indonesian → English → Mandarin and vice versa), the system demonstrated promising results with an average linguistic accuracy of 4.7 out of 5 based on evaluations by two expert validators in the fields of Mandarin language and AI technology. The evaluation also noted fast response times of approximately 0.8 to 1.2 seconds per sentence, as well as the model's ability to run offline and efficiently with a lightweight model size (±150 MB). However, this study has limitations as pedagogical validation has not yet involved students as end-users, so there is no empirical confirmation of the system's impact on learning motivation, student engagement, or improved subject matter understanding. Preliminary analysis of translation errors identified several categories of linguistic errors, such as phonetic, semantic, and syntactic errors, which need to be addressed in further system development. This study provides an important foundation for future research involving direct testing with students to confirm the system's pedagogical validity comprehensively.

title: Enhanced Doppler Based Localization in Mega Satellite Networks
authors: Zonghan Li, Bisma Manzoor, Jing Fu, Akram Al-Hourani
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: With the growing reliance on global navigation satellite systems, the need for alternative localization methods has become critical. Doppler based localization is attracting increasing interest; however, its performance is constrained by a limited frequency resolution, which introduces noise and reduces positioning accuracy. This paper presents a novel Doppler extraction framework that integrates matched filtering, frequency agile filter, and a phase locked loop to mitigate these limitations. The estimated Doppler profile is used to localize a terrestrial network device based on the unique fingerprint captured by multiple satellites. We show that matched filtering and frequency agile filter enhances the frequency resolution, while the phase locked loop refines extracted frequencies by tracking phase deviation over time. The proposed approach is evaluated in a simulated satellite based localization scenario, demonstrating a significant improvement in localization accuracy compared to the Fast Fourier Transform based method. Monte Carlo simulations results show that employing four localization iterations and six satellites can achieve a reliable localization of network devices.

title: Engineering Solutions and Practical Challenges in Grounding Systems for Photovoltaic Power Plants: A Case Study
authors: Borislav Boychev, Polina Petkova
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This paper presents an engineering-focused analysis of grounding system design and implementation in photovoltaic (PV) power plants, with a particular emphasis on a real-world case study. Grounding plays a critical role in ensuring electrical safety, mitigating fault currents, protecting sensitive equipment, and enabling lightning protection. The study reviews relevant international standards and design methodologies, addressing various grounding configurations and soil resistivity considerations.

title: Trends and emerging Research Impact of AI in Climate Change Monitoring using Geospatial Data
authors: Valentine Kirimi Muriira, Venoth Nallisamy, Henry Mutugi Kamundi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: This study investigates the integration of AI and geospatial data in climate change monitoring. The paper studies how AI enables environmental predications, remote survey functions and climate simulations and it discusses current advancements in research throughout. Through Coward Analysis the research analyzes vital thematic groups to understand how poor data quality and uninterpretable models and limited computational power affect the field.

title: Machine Learning Using Speech Features to Determine Deceptive Speech
authors: Kamizaki Koshi, Hamasaki Takeshi, Yoshihisa Nakatoh, Yujie Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: In recent years, the number of bullying cases has been increasing annually, with the number of "serious cases" reaching a record high in fiscal year 2023. One contributing factor to this severity is that bullies often conceal their actions, making it difficult for teachers and others around them to grasp the situation. Against this backdrop, this study proposes a deception detection method that uses speech audio from students suspected of bullying to determine the truthfulness of their statements, with the aim of facilitating early detection of issues and supporting appropriate responses. This method is intended to be used as an auxiliary tool when counseling students who have been identified by the school as showing signs of problems. Its non-contact and non-invasive characteristics minimize the psychological burden on students. In the first stage of this research, we will compare the acoustic features of false and truthful speech to extract effective features and construct a discrimination method. Specifically, we will use an acoustic analysis tool to extract features such as MFCC (0-14th order), logMelFreqBand (0-7th order), and LspFreq (0-7th order) from the audio data and calculate their statistical values (maximum, minimum, etc.). We then perform machine learning using Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Random Forest (RF) on these features to classify the audio as truthful or false. The experimental results showed that RF demonstrated higher classification performance than SVM, suggesting the effectiveness of this method.

title: An Analysis of Sensing Metrics Based on Entropy
authors: Luyang Liu, Fan Jiang, Xueting Xu, Dongqi Luo, Weichao Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: The integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system has been widely recognized as a prominent scenario for sixth-generation (6G) wireless networks. Nevertheless, the disjointed measurement frameworks for communication and sensing functionalities pose a critical challenge for evaluating and optimizing ISAC system’s performance. Although the proposal of integrated metrics grounded in mutual information (MI) by related studies, a profound understanding and thorough investigation of entropy remains underexplored in these works. Based on the fundamental principles of Shannon’s information theory, we formulate a theoretical model of sensing performance metric under general channel state scenarios, and explore the relationships between sensing MI and existing sensing metrics in this paper. Specially, we derive a closed-form expression for sensing MI, and propose a numerical method to obtain the sensing entropy. The simulation results show that a distinct one-to-one correspondence is discernible between posterior Cramér-Rao lower bound (PCRLB) and the sensing MI. In addition, we show that the MI is upper bounded by the logarithm of the maximum number of resolvable categories, and the upper bound can be achieved in high Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) conditions.

title: Wind Power Prediction Using Spatiotemporal Capsule Graph Reasoning
authors: Xiaozhe Song, Geng-Chen Li, Xu Jiang, Changjiang Wang, Song Gao, Gang Du
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The large-scale integration of wind power into power systems presents serious challenges to their safety and stability, making accurate wind power output prediction a critical research focus. To improve prediction accuracy, this paper proposes a novel wind power output prediction model based on spatiotemporal capsule graph reasoning, which effectively captures the spatiotemporal correlations among wind turbines. The proposed model integrates local temporal features and spatial information of wind turbines into a dynamic spatiotemporal graph. A combination of Temporal Pattern Attention-Long Short-Term Memory (TPA-LSTM), Capsule Graph Neural Network (CGNN), and dynamic graph convolution was employed to capture complex temporal patterns and spatial dependencies, enabling accurate wind power output prediction. The model was validated through a case study of a provincial power grid in China and compared with four state-of-the-art deep learning models in terms of prediction accuracy. The experimental results demonstrated that the proposed model outperforms conventional methods in prediction performance.

title: Determining Substation Equipment Importance in the Presence of Failure Risk Inaccuracy
authors: Guido Andreesen, Madis Leinakse, Mart Landsberg, Jako Kilter
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: This paper proposes two different methods for determining the importance of substation equipment in the presence of incorrect failure risk. These are less sensitive to the inaccuracy of failure probability, making them more efficient for detecting equipment potential incorrect priority and evaluating their failure risk criticality. The methods include parameters indicating the importance of failure probability uncertainty and the critical failure probability. The methods can be useful in cases where the exact failure probability is unknown, allowing to evaluate its sensitivity to failure risk. In addition, it indicates the threshold in failure probability resulting in critical failure risk. This can be useful to estimate the sensitivity of failure probability inaccuracy. The effectiveness of the proposed methods is illustrated by a numerical case study. The results of the study indicated the method’s capability of detecting the incorrect priority of equipment and can be used for corrective re-ranking. They also pointed out that a relatively small error in failure probability can lead to significant over- or underestimation of failure risk. The proposed methods could be useful tools for utilities and network owners for reducing risk in the power system and avoiding incorrect asset management decisions.

title: Surface dielectric strength of insulating stand-offs of electrically insulated LPS under standard lightning impulse voltages
authors: Petros P. Tsouris, Pavlos K. Samaras, Pantelis N. Mikropoulos, Thomas E. Tsovilis, Nikolaos D. Kokkinos
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: Insulating stand-offs are important components of an electrically insulated LPS towards preventing dangerous sparking between the components of the ILPS and metallic parts of the protected structure. In order to maintain the required separation distance, they shall be able to withstand the extremely high overvoltages arising on an electrically insulated LPS due to lightning strikes. Thus, for the safe and reliable design of an electrically insulated LPS, knowledge on the impulse surface dielectric behavior of insulating stand-offs is of great importance. The present study reports on an experimental investigation of the surface dielectric strength of insulating stand-offs subjected to standard lightning impulse voltages of both polarities. The surface dielectric strength is evaluated in terms of the 50% flashover voltage and flashover voltage-time characteristics. Contrary to that observed for 50% flashover voltage, for overvoltages the surface dielectric strength of the insulating stand-offs is lower under negative than positive impulses. Empirical expressions describing flashover gradienttime characteristics are derived. Also, flashover characteristics are well predicted by the integration method.

title: Double-Loop Fuzzy Neural Network-Based Fixed-Time Robust Control for Antagonistic PM-Actuated Wrist Robots With Motion Constraints
authors: Yuexuan Xu, Shuzhen Diao, Tong Yang, Xinlin Zhang, Ming Li, Yakun Gao, David Navarro-Alarcon, Ning Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems
abstract: Antagonistic pneumatic muscle (PM)-actuated wrist robots have great potential in rehabilitation and industrial applications. The antagonistic connection of PMs, which mimics the agonist-antagonist muscle pairs in human joints, provides substantial advantages such as improved joint stability and a better balance of torque disturbances. However, PM-actuated robots exhibit complex nonlinearities, such as hysteresis, creep, input delay, and time-varying parameters, while also confronting challenges such as external disturbances and coupling effects. In this paper, a switching non-singular terminal sliding mode control (NTSMC) method with a double-loop fuzzy neural network (DLFNN) is developed. This method enables the antagonistic PM-actuated wrist robots to achieve fast and precise tracking performance. Specifically, the lumped disturbances are estimated online using the DLFNN, which can adaptively adjust the weight of the inner and outer layers, achieving accurate approximation and robustness. Based on the estimated value of disturbances, a switching NTSMC is implemented to ensure that tracking errors converge to the origin within the fixed time. Switching functions guarantee fast convergence when the sliding surface errors are large. Meanwhile, switching functions ensure non-singularity as the sliding surface errors converge to the origin. Furthermore, joint angles and angular velocities are limited within the specific ranges by designing exponential constraint terms as time-varying proportional-differential gains, rather than traditional barrier functions that may induce excessive control inputs. Both detailed stability analysis and experimental validation demonstrate the effectiveness and adaptability of the proposed method.

title: Time-Selective Privacy Protection for Network Communication and Its Application to Adaptive Prescribed-Performance Consensus Tracking
authors: Wei Sun, Junhao Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper introduces a novel privacy mask framework for securing network communication processes, specifically applied to consensus tracking. First, an innovative output mask map is presented to achieve time-selective privacy protection for dynamic network location data. The designed mask map overcomes key limitations of existing approaches, such as the inability to assign zero values to masked locations, the restriction of protection only to initial data, and the lack of rapid mask termination mechanisms. Second, the proposed framework is applied to multi-agent adaptive consensus tracking control to ensure the security of agents’ information and the boundedness of all signals in the closed-loop system. To counteract potential tracking performance degradation due to the computational complexity introduced by the privacy mask, prescribed-performance control theory is incorporated. Third, the dynamic surface control technique is used to avoid the derivation of the received encrypted position information, so as to handle the uncertainty originating from the unknown mask map. Ultimately, simulations comparing our framework with existing mask mechanisms highlight its advantages.

title: SDR-Based Portable Channel Sounding System for 6G FR1 and FR3 Bands: Design and Validation
authors: Yunhwa Shin, Sangwoo Shin, Jinyoung Lee, Jihoon Kim, Minsoo Na, Jaehyun Lee, Jeongsik Choi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Mid-band frequencies have recently attracted attention as promising sixth-generation (6G) candidates due to their potential to mitigate the instability of sub-terahertz (sub-THz) and millimeter-wave (mmWave) bands. While ongoing studies investigate channel models for this spectrum, they largely focus on individual frequencies across diverse environments. For mobile network operators (MNOs), measurement-based comparative studies that directly evaluate the advantages and limitations of candidate bands under identical deployment scenarios are essential. Obtaining high-resolution channel impulse responses (CIRs) in the mid-band, however, is constrained by limited spectrum availability, and existing approaches often rely on costly, synchronization-dependent equipment, thereby restricting portability and versatility. This paper proposes an asynchronous and portable software-defined radio (SDR)-based channel sounder that employs a Zadoff-Chu (ZC) sequence to enable direct comparison between frequency range 1 (FR1, 4.55 GHz and 6.55 GHz) and FR3 (7.15 GHz) under identical transceiver conditions. The SDR system was validated through back-to-back calibration, and the verified platform was subsequently used to conduct channel measurement campaigns in both indoor hotspot (InH) and urban microcell (UMi) environments. The measured data were analyzed in terms of path loss and large-scale characteristics, and parameter comparisons with the third generation partnership projects (3GPP) standard were performed to ensure validity. The results of this channel analysis are expected to provide practical insights into frequency band selection for future 6G services.

title: Time-Varying Transmission Rates-Aware Dependent Task Offloading and Local Resource Allocation in Multi-Access Edge Computing
authors: Qiang Zhang, Minghui Min, Zhu Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: With the increasing diversity and complexity of mobile applications, an application typically needs to execute multiple dependent tasks to achieve its functionality. Computation offloading in multi-access edge computing aims to improve user experience, such as reducing makespan and terminal energy consumption, by offloading some tasks to the designated edge server. Task dependencies impose constraints on the execution order of the tasks, which complicates the offloading decisions. Besides, transmission rates exhibit fluctuations in real-world scenarios due to the mobility of users, and they pose new challenges to the problem of dependent task offloading. To minimize the terminal energy consumption under the given deadline, a joint optimization problem of dependent task offloading and local computing resource allocation with time-varying transmission rates is investigated. Since the proposed problem is NP-hard, we decompose it into two subproblems to reduce the complexity and deal with the coupling of decision variables. Specifically, we first solve the subproblem of dependent task offloading by generating special task sets to implement divide and conquer with a fixed local processing speed. Then, we employ Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) method to solve the subproblem of local resource allocation with the offloading solution derived from the first subproblem while ensuring that the makespan constraint is met. The proposed scheme makes dynamic decisions on dependent task offloading and resource allocation according to the fluctuations of transmission rates, and dynamically adjusts the solution accordingly to achieve better performance. Experimental results show that our solution outperforms baseline methods, reducing makespan by 27–31%, terminal energy consumption by 70–77%, while achieving 25–65% higher service success ratio on average.

title: Transforming Indoor Localization: Advanced Transformer Architecture for NLOS Dominated Wireless Environments with Distributed Sensors
authors: Saad Masrur, Jung-Fu Cheng, Atieh R. Khamesi, İsmail Güvenç
publish: IEEE Transactions on Machine Learning in Communications and Networking
abstract: Indoor localization in challenging non-line-of-sight (NLOS) environments often leads to poor accuracy with traditional approaches. Deep learning (DL) has been applied to tackle these challenges; however, many DL approaches overlook computational complexity, especially for floating-point operations (FLOPs), making them unsuitable for resource-limited devices. Transformer-based models have achieved remarkable success in natural language processing (NLP) and computer vision (CV) tasks, motivating their use in wireless applications. However, their use in indoor localization remains nascent, and directly applying Transformers for indoor localization can be both computationally intensive and exhibit limitations in accuracy. To address these challenges, in this work, we introduce a novel tokenization approach, referred to as Sensor Snapshot Tokenization (SST), which preserves variable-specific representations of power delay profile (PDP) and enhances attention mechanisms by effectively capturing multi-variate correlation. Complementing this, we propose a lightweight Swish-Gated Linear Unit-based Transformer (L-SwiGLU-T) model, designed to reduce computational complexity without compromising localization accuracy. Together, these contributions mitigate the computational burden and dependency on large datasets, making Transformer models more efficient and suitable for resource-constrained scenarios. Experimental results on simulated and real-world datasets demonstrate that SST and L-SwiGLU-T achieve substantial accuracy and efficiency gains, outperforming larger Transformer and CNN baselines by over 40% while using significantly fewer FLOPs and training samples.

title: Algebraic Expression of Critical Imaginary Roots for Frequency-Sweeping Framework of Time-Delay Systems: A Characteristic-Set-Based Approach
authors: Xu Li, Xu-Guang Li, Lu Zhang, Jun-Xiu Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: The frequency-sweeping approach is an important and well-known tool for stability analysis of timedelay systems with commensurate delays. However, when it is used to detect critical imaginary roots (CIRs), the accuracy is regarded to be highly related to the numerical grid for sweeping the frequency axis. To the best of the authors' knowledge, the characterization of CIRs for most reported approaches has not reached a completely algebraic level. In this paper, we introduce a polynomial algebraic tool, the characteristic set, acting as a new perspective for characterizing CIRs. Based on the characteristic set algorithm, we decompose the zeros of the frequency-sweeping conditions that a CIR appears into a finite number of real quasicomponents of triangular sets. The obtained triangular sets are an explicit algebraic expression of CIRs, which can be determined directly without any numerical criteria and conservatism. The proposed method not only overcomes the drawbacks of the frequency-sweeping approach but also provides a procedure for detecting CIRs in a completely algebraic way.

title: Transfer Learning for Improving Neuroimaging-Based Diagnostic Classification
authors: Gopikrishna Deshpande, Bonian Lu, Nguyen Huynh, D Rangaprakash
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Overfitting, an issue that constrains the validity and generalizability of machine learning in neuroimaging-based diagnostic-classification, is in part due to small sample sizes in relation to what is required for generalization. Even with data aggregation (such as in Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange or ABIDE), the relatively smaller sample sizes are a result of the fact that it is difficult/expensive to acquire data from clinical populations. With healthy controls, we have comparatively larger samples available. Therefore, we propose to address overfitting by using larger healthy samples (from Human Connectome Project or HCP) to learn the diversity of neural signatures of healthy controls, with the aim of transferring that learning into the context of discriminating autism from healthy controls in ABIDE. Methods: We developed a complete variational autoencoder based transfer learning framework including data oversampling, model pre-training, classifier training and testing, and model explanation. Then, the performance of transfer learning was estimated and visualized. Results: The transfer learning classification model achieved about 7% more accuracy on site-mismatched data than obtained without transfer leaning. Discussion: Overall, we demonstrated the applicability of transfer learning within a deep learning framework for utilizing larger samples of available healthy control data to improve generalizability and accuracy of diagnostic classification in ASD, as well as reduce the harmful effects of inter-site variability on classification. We believe the proposed framework is potentially applicable to other disorders as well.

title: DeepR2OM: Accurate Recognition for RNA 2'-O-Methylation Sites in Human Genome Using Deep Learning
authors: Jiahao Yuan, Shun Gao, Ziyuan Yan, Feifei Cui, Leyi Wei, Qingchen Zhang, Quan Zou, Zilong Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: 2'-O-methylation (2OM) of ribose is a widespread RNA modification that significantly impacts RNA stability, structure, and function. Accurately predicting 2OM sites is crucial for understanding RNA's biological functions and related pathologies. Traditional detection methods pose challenges such as resource intensiveness, potential RNA sample damage, and high costs. However, recent advancements in machine learning, particularly deep learning techniques, offer rapid and cost-effective prediction solutions. In this study, we introduce DeepR2OM, a novel method integrating feature selection and deep learning for 2OM sites prediction. DeepR2OM encodes sequences using eight RNA descriptors, employs feature selection algorithms to reduce dimensions, and then utilizes a deep learning network for training. After evaluating various deep learning architectures, we selected Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Multi-Head Self-Attention mechanism, and Deep Neural Network (DNN) as our final prediction models. Experimental results demonstrate DeepR2OM's effectiveness, achieving 87.1% accuracy (ACC), 85.5% recall rate (Recall), 87.9% precision (PRE), and a Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) of 75.7% on an independent test set. This tool serves as a valuable resource for exploring the functional and bioinformatic aspects of 2OM sites. To enhance accessibility, we have developed a web server for the prediction of RNA 2'-O-Methylation

title: Cooperation-based Federated Learning and Communication Optimization Under Intermittent Device Participation in Industrial IoT
authors: Tongzhou Yang, Qihao Li, Ning Zhang, Yuanguo Bi, Wei Zhang, Fengye Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel cooperative relay-based resource and learning optimization (CRRLO) scheme that extends device connectivity, balances learning contributions, and coordinates communication resources to mitigate the negative impact of intermittent participation on FL performance caused by unreliable communication in Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) environments. After local training, a cooperative aggregation stage is proposed, where fully connected device-to-device (D2D) relaying enables devices with failed device-to-server (D2S) transmissions to still contribute to the global model, while avoiding the transmission burden and relay selection issues associated with single-relay strategies. To further ensure unbiased aggregation, we produce reliability-driven aggregation weights to calibrate each device’s contribution to the global update. We then formulate a joint optimization problem aimed at improving FL convergence rate under communication and resource constraints by co-optimizing blocklength, transmission power, and aggregation weights. An iterative algorithm is designed to determine blocklength bounds, a low-complexity method is developed for power optimization, and a convex relaxation approach is adopted for weight adjustment. These subproblems are alternately solved using a block coordinate descent (BCD) method. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed CRRLO scheme significantly accelerates convergence and improves test accuracy by up to 24.33% compared to baseline schemes under high transmission error probability.

title: Frequency Reconfigurable Antenna Element for X/Ku-Band Satellite User Terminals
authors: Van-Thang Nguyen, Da-Hyun Lee, Jae-Young Chung
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter presents a compact X/Ku-band frequency- and polarization-reconfigurable antenna element in the array antenna layer for user terminals in satellite communication, implemented using p-i-n diodes. The antenna element integrates two p-i-n diodes to enable frequency reconfiguration for half-duplex operation: RX mode covers 10.7–12.7 GHz with horizontal polarization (H-pol), and TX mode operates at 13.85–14 GHz with vertical polarization (V-pol). Parasitic patches are incorporated in the RX mode to achieve wideband coverage with a flat gain response. In both modes, the antenna maintains a stable realized gain of approximately 5-6 dBi. Circular polarization is achieved by arranging four linearly polarized elements in a rotational sequence. A 4 × 4 element array prototype was fabricated and tested in an anechoic chamber, demonstrating peak realized gains of 15.8 dBic (RX) and 13.2 dBic (TX), with cross polarization isolation exceeding 20dB. These results indicate the proposed antenna is a promising candidate for compact, reconfigurable user terminals in half duplex satellite communication systems.

title: Self-Tracking Far-Field Wireless Power Transfer System With Tracking and Charging Scheme Enabled by a Programmable Metasurface_supp1-3637336.mp4
authors: Wei Lin
publish: N/A
abstract: Far-field wireless power transfer (WPT) is a key technology for powering large-scale, widely dispersed Internet of Things (IoT) devices. To enable long-distance power transmission, a high-gain, narrow WPT beam is required. As a result, effective tracking of IoT targets becomes a significant challenge, especially when the target is moving. In this article, we present a self-tracking far-field WPT system, featuring an innovative time-diversity tracking and charging scheme enabled by a programmable metasurface. During each duty cycle, the metasurface antenna array is first configured to tracking mode to detect the direction of the beacon signal emitted by the IoT target. Next, the metasurface is reconfigured to charging mode, and the WPT power is directionally beamed to the target. By continuously repeating this duty cycle, the programmable metasurface enables effective WPT tracking and charging for both stationary and moving IoT targets. We have successfully implemented the system, and its WPT performance has been evaluated and validated through experiments. This novel WPT scheme offers a promising solution for powering the massive devices in future IoT systems.

title: PCIR: An Open-World Remote Sensing Image Representation Learning Method from a Causal Perspective
authors: Ling Zhao, Mengyao Li, Run Shao, Haifeng Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: In the open world, visual representations of remote sensing images vary significantly and diversely. A model can correctly recognize and process unknown data in changing and open-ended scenarios only by learning invariant visual representations from the data. Causal diagram models, which describe the data generation process, can employ interventions and counterfactual operations to obtain invariant visual representations in such open environments, i.e., generic causal representations. However, these generic causal diagram models often overlook the multi-feature, multi-confounding, and multi-change characteristics of remote sensing images, as well as the causal differences these factors introduce into the imaging process. This limitation makes it difficult for the learned representations to be widely transferable in open scenes. Specifically, we argue that different objects are influenced by different environments, and the styles they exhibit in remote sensing images consequently vary. Therefore, the causal diagrams corresponding to these objects also differ. Intervening at the object-level causal diagram is crucial for obtaining object-specific causal representations and mitigating the problem of feature confusion.Based on this assumption, we derive the general form of the object-level causal diagram from the generic causal diagram, taking into account the characteristics of remote sensing images with multiple features and multiple confounders. We propose a remote sensing representation learning method, PCIR, which is based on a causal partition intervention strategy. The method consists of two main components: the Causal Partition Intervention (CPI) module and the Causal Representation Separation (CRS) module. 1) CPI module: To simulate the style differences caused by environmental influences on different objects, we propose remote sensing offset data augmentation. We then use target detection labels to identify independent object regions in the image and apply feature-specific data augmentation. 2) CRS module: For the same class, the content remains consistent across different styles; therefore, we propose a symmetric causal regularity learning strategy to bidirectionally constrain and obtain invariant causal representations. We validate our method on four datasets across two tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that PCIR achieves outstanding performance in open-scenario tasks. Compared with seven baseline methods, our method improves overall accuracy (OA) by an average of 1.79% in the scene classification task and increases mean accuracy (mAcc) by up to 3.55% in the semantic segmentation task. Moreover, visualizations of the learned representations show that PCIR enhances the model’s ability to recognize invariant causal representations in complex scenes and improves its robustness.

title: ENSOFarseer: Probabilistic Deep Learning for Cross-scale Spatiotemporal Teleconnections Insight in Skilful ENSO Prediction
authors: Rixu Hao, Yuxin Zhao, Xiong Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is the most dominant interannual variability of the ocean system exerting global environmental and socio-economic impacts through spatiotemporal teleconnections. Real-time ENSO prediction with physics-driven dynamical models suffers from large biases and uncertainties, while deep learning fails to consider time-varying spatial interactions across scales, causing difficulties in addressing the inherent complexity of teleconnections. Despite decades of efforts, predicting ENSO with lead times of more than one year remains challenging. In this study, we propose ENSOFarseer, an innovative deep learning framework that simulates cross-scale spatiotemporal teleconnections underlying ENSO dynamics and enhances long-lead predictability. ENSOFarseer outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, providing predictions at lead times of up to 24 months while mitigating the spring predictability barrier. ENSOFarseer accurately reproduces teleconnections by simulating interactions of local-scale feedback and global-scale teleconnections, offering insights into the contributions of various modes to predictions. The intrinsic improvement in long-lead prediction skill stems from the unified fusion of spatial multi-scale collaborative perception and temporal cross-scale dynamical evolution that tackles the inherent multiscale and multiphysics challenges and provides reliable probabilistic predictions by incorporating Bayesian uncertainty quantification. These findings highlight substantial improvements in cross-scale spatiotemporal deep learning in advancing ENSO prediction and deepening our understanding of its dynamics.

title: UAV Path Planning Based on Disturbance Resilient Dynamic Window Approach
authors: Xirui Yang, Ran Zhang, Fubao Ma, Bowen Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Dynamic Window Approach (DWA) is often used to handle Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) path planning problems. To address the limited robustness and poor stability of DWA in disturbed environments, this research proposes a disturbance resilient DWA for UAV path planning. The proposed method constructs global and local disturbance environment models. On this basis, a disturbance quality evaluation function is introduced to guide trajectory selection based on the consistency between disturbance deviation and ideal path, thereby enhancing flight stability. In addition, a danger distance evaluation function is integrated to strengthen the UAV’s autonomous adjustment and escape capability. The experimental results show that the proposed method achieves superior path planning performance in complex environments, effectively improving trajectory quality and flight safety.

title: Riemann–Roch bases for Arbitrary Elliptic Curve Divisors and their Application in Cryptography
authors: Artyom Kuninets, Ekaterina Malygina
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: This paper presents explicit constructions of bases for Riemann-Roch spaces associated with arbitrary divisors on elliptic curves. In the context of algebraic geometry codes, the knowledge of an explicit basis for arbitrary divisors is especially valuable, as it enables efficient code construction. From a cryptographic point of view, codes associated with arbitrary divisors with many points are closer to Goppa codes, making them attractive for embedding in the McEliece cryptosystem. Using the results obtained in this work, it is also possible to efficiently construct quasi-cyclic subfield subcodes of elliptic codes. These codes enable a significant reduction in public key size for the McEliece cryptosystem and, consequently, represent promising candidates for integration into post-quantum codebased schemes.

title: High-Sensitivity Cavity Ring-Down Spectroscopy for Online Monitoring of $\text{SF}_{6}$ Decomposition Products in High-Voltage Equipment
authors: Xu Zhengjie, Zhao Yue, Xu Xiaoxiao, Chen Ying, Hang Chen, Cheng Wei
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Sulfur hexafluoride (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex>) is widely used as an insulating medium in high-voltage equipment, but decomposes into toxic byproducts under electrical faults, posing risks to both equipment integrity and personnel safety. This manuscript present a cavity ring-down spectroscopy system for real-time monitoring of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex> decomposition products. Experimental results demonstrate the system have exceptional performance, the measurement accuracy of 0.179-0.833 ppb for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CH}_{4}$</tex>, 12.714 - 14.091 ppb for CO, and 0.007 ppm for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{S}$</tex> at 4.7 ppm concentration, the system have excellent linear response (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}>0.9998$</tex>) across wide concentration ranges and maintains <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CH}_{4}$</tex> detection stability within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.7 \text{ppb}$</tex> even under dynamic water vapor interference (1.67 ppm/min variation). These results validate the system's capability for precise, real-time gas monitoring in power equipment applications, offering significant improvements over conventional detection methods in terms of sensitivity, response time, and interference resistance. The developed cavity ring-down spectroscopy technology provides a reliable solution for online monitoring of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex> decomposition, contributing to enhanced operational safety and equipment reliability in high-voltage power systems.

title: Interval Dynamic State Estimation for Integrated Electricity-Gas System Based on Multi-Source Measurement Data Fusion
authors: Weihong Yao, Feixiong Chen, Zhenguo Shao, Zhenyu Wang, Fukun Zhang, Zhilong Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: As integrated electricity-gas systems (IEGSs) become increasingly coupled, dynamic state estimation (DSE) faces challenges due to heterogeneous and temporally misaligned measurements. An interval DSE framework is developed to effectively fuse multi-source data with asynchronous time references. The system dynamics are captured using the Lax-Wendroff difference scheme in conjunction with Holt's exponential smoothing algorithm. Since SCADA measurements lack precise sampling time stamps owing to inherent delays, their actual acquisition times are inferred by calibrating against turbine flowmeter data through Pearson correlation analysis. This process enables the construction of a temporally accurate measurement dataset. Then, the uncertainty introduced by non-simultaneity among measurements is quantified using interval mathematics. To address the challenge of interval overestimation, an improved interval Kalman filter is designed to efficiently solve the interval DSE problem. Case studies demonstrate the method's effectiveness in managing asynchronous multi-source data while maintaining accurate estimation performance.

title: Interactive AI System for Remote Sensing Change Detection and Analysis
authors: Samreen Begum, Asiya Begum, Sara Fatima, Mohammad Pasha, Mohd Umar Farooq, M Subburaj
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: This paper presents an AI-driven approach to change detection in remote sensing imagery using a web-based application developed on Replit. The application utilizes multiple change detection algorithms, including Image Differencing, Normalized Difference, and Change Vector Analysis (CVA), to identify changes in satellite images. The system processes user-uploaded images, applies pre-processing techniques, detects changes, and evaluates performance using various metrics such as Structural Similarity Index (SSIM), Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Earth Mover’s Distance (EMD), Changed Pixels Percentage, and Mean Absolute Difference (MAD). This study provides a detailed comparative analysis of these techniques, emphasizing their efficiency and accuracy in different remote sensing conditions. Our results demonstrate that each method has specific advantages and limitations depending on environmental conditions, illumination variations, and image complexity. This work aims to provide researchers and practitioners with insights into selecting appropriate change detection methods for various remote sensing applications.

title: Model Predictive Tracking Control of Autonomous Vehicles with Dynamic Horizons
authors: Juqi Hu, Yvrui Hei, Changyin Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper proposes an adaptive model predictive control (MPC)-based trajectory tracking method for autonomous vehicles (AVs). Unlike the traditional MPC approaches, the prediction horizon of the proposed MPC method is firstly designed to be adaptive to the curvature of the reference trajectory. Based on the fuzzy rules, the control horizon is further set as a combined results of vehicle speed, lateral tracking error and the trajectory curvature. By doing so, both the predictive and control horizons of the proposed MPC are dynamically adjusted to the tracking scenarios resulting in both computational efficiency and enhanced tracking accuracy. To verify the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed control strategy, both MATLAB/Simulink and QCar experiment were conducted to track an S-shape trajectory. The comparative results with typical MPC have shown that the proposed adaptive MPC method can achieve a higher tracking accuracy, especially for lateral tracking. Moreover, the time required for solving at each step is obviously shorter showing the improved real-time performance of the proposed adaptive MPC method.

title: Melody Way: Visualizing Influence, Collaboration, and Genre Evolution in the Music Industry
authors: Hannah Yanhua Zong, Nabin Khanal, Qi Yang, Sundas Qaiser, Sizheng Cailean Chen, Helena Jiuru Liu, Cheryl Zhenyu Qian, Yingjie Victor Chen, Jieqiong Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Visual Analytics Science and Technology Challenge (VAST Challenge)
abstract: We present Melody Way, a visual analytics system for exploring influence, collaboration, and genre evolution in the music industry. The system integrates temporal and network perspectives in a coordinated multi-view environment, enabling analysts to move fluidly between high-level trend analysis and detailed relationship exploration. Interactive filters, search, and an AI chatbot support targeted investigation and predictive queries, with results visually verified in context. Applied to the 2025 VAST Challenge MC-1 dataset, Melody Way revealed evolving genre dynamics, distinctive artist trajectories, and potential future leaders in Oceanus Folk, demonstrating how integrated visual and AI-assisted analysis can illuminate complex patterns in large cultural datasets.

title: Transient Electromagnetic Field of a Cloud-To-Cloud Discharge by a Hybrid Approach
authors: Erika Stracqualursi, Rodolfo Araneo, Salvatore Celozzi
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: This work proposes a hybrid time-domain approach for evaluating the transient electric field generated by a cloud-to-cloud lightning with channel of arbitrary orientation, assuming an ideal conductive ground. The method allows to simulate the cloud effects by discretizing the cloud volume and to compute the electromagnetic field radiated by any tortuous lightning channel between them. The total electric field at any point in space can be easily computed through radiation integrals over the lightning channel and the clouds. The effectiveness of the proposed method has been preliminary tested in evaluating the lightning-produced threat in terms of transient incident electric fields on any sensitive target located at ground level.

title: Learning-Based Secure Transmission for UAV-Aided IoV Systems
authors: Lingru Jia, Lixin Liu, Zhibo Liu, Xiaozhen Lu, Feng Xue
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: With the large-scale development of intelligent transportation and smart cities, dynamic Internet of Vehicles (IoV) systems face the challenge of secure transmission with low latency and resistance to active eavesdropping due to the rapid growth in the number of high-mobility vehicles and the demands for data exchange.
