In this paper, we propose a secure transmission scheme for unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-aided IoV systems with multi-agent reinforcement learning to realize the dual demands of transmission efficiency and security, which adaptively optimizes the working mode and key length of the encryption strategy during the communication process. Specifically, we design a risk-aware dual-network learning architecture that dynamically revises Q-values using long-term risk assessments, balancing rewards and risks to avoid high-risk actions. Furthermore, a short-term risk warning mechanism monitors real-time violations of performance thresholds (e.g., latency, protection level, and attack success rate) to ensure safe policy exploration. Experimental results show that our scheme significantly reduces both latency and attack success rate compared to benchmarks, while simultaneously improving the security level and achieving the global optimization of transmission efficiency and security.

title: Green One-Bit Quantized Precoding in Cell-Free Massive MIMO
authors: Salih Gümüsbuğa, Ozan Alp Topal, Özlem Tuğfe Demir
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: Cell-free massive MIMO (multiple-input multiple-output) is expected to be one of the key technologies in sixth-generation (6G) and beyond wireless communications, offering enhanced spectral efficiency for cell-edge user equipments by employing joint transmission and reception with a large number of antennas distributed throughout the region. However, high-resolution RF chains associated with these antennas significantly increase power consumption. To address this issue, the use of low-resolution analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog converters (ADCs/DACs) has emerged as a promising approach to balance power efficiency and performance in massive MIMO networks. In this work, we propose a novel quantized precoding algorithm tailored for cell-free massive MIMO systems, where the proposed method dynamically deactivates unnecessary antennas based on the structure of each symbol vector, thereby enhancing energy efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that our algorithm outperforms existing methods such as squared-infinity norm Douglas-Rachford splitting (SQUID) and regularized zero forcing (RZF), achieving superior performance while effectively reducing power consumption.

title: Neural Network-Based Aggregated Modeling of Multiple Synchronous Generators with Heterogeneous Parameters
authors: Xin Wang, Arash Safavizadeh, Juri Jatskevich, Guangchao Geng, Quanyuan Jiang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Aggregated modeling of multiple synchronous generators (SGs) can enhance the efficiency of electromagnetic transient (EMT) simulations when the dynamic behavior of individual SGs does not require detailed investigation. This paper proposes a neural network (NN)-based aggregated modeling (NNB-AM ) method for the time-domain simulation of multiple SGs with heterogeneous parameters connected through diverse collector lines to the point of common coupling (PCC). The general NN modeling rule considers the PCC three-phase voltages as inputs, and the SGs’ equivalent three-phase injected currents and the equivalent rotor angle as outputs. The long short-term memory (LSTM) structure is adopted to implement and train the NN model using the dynamic responses generated from offline EMT simulations, which employ the non-aggregated classical full-order qd model of SGs. It is demonstrated that for a multi-SG-infinite-bus system, the proposed NNB-AM accurately captures the equivalent dynamic behavior of SGs while offering greater computational efficiency compared to the non-aggregated model counterpart.

title: Performance Evaluation of H.323 and SIP Protocols in Internet Telephony
authors: Abraham Mulondiwa, Chileshe Ngosa, Phillip Senga, Evans Kalaba, Shiaka Nkholoma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: H. 323 and SIP protocols are session layer protocols needed in the establishment of communication between two entities in Internet Telephony. Most Internet Telephony networks are faced with technical challenges such as delay, jitter, and signal quality, and these are affected by the choice of protocols when building a network. The choice between SIP and H. 323 remains a challenge for network designers and service providers, especially in environments with stringent QoS requirements, such as enterprise communications, teleconferencing, and real-time video/audio services. H. 323 and SIP normally operate in conjunction with other protocols at Transport and Network layers. This paper investigates the performance evaluation of H. 323 and Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) used in internet Telephony. The performance of these protocols is evaluated in terms of delay, jitter, MOS with voice and video being the information source between the communication entities. To evaluate the performance of these protocols OPNET simulation tool was used. Results show that the SIP outperforms H. 323 when trafficking voice in terms of MOS By 37% and jitter by 20%. For video trafficking, H. 323 outperforms SIP in terms of traffic received by 60 % and end-to-end delay by 30 %. With these results, SIP is best for voice trafficking while H. 323 is best suited for video transmission within the context of internet traffic.

title: AI Driven Smart Beamforming for B5G Networks
authors: Fasmi K A, Job Chunkath, Anjali N, Bhanu Priya P S, Varsha Shaji
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Smart beamforming is a key enabler for improving spectral efficiency, energy utilization, and link reliability in Beyond 5G (B5G) multi-user wireless communication systems. This paper presents a simulation-based smart beamforming framework using Deep Q-Learning (DQN) tailored for a two-user MIMO B5G environment. Unlike conventional approaches relying on static datasets or single-user optimization, the proposed method learns optimal beam direction selection from a synthetic dataset generated based on varying user positions within a fixed channel condition. The DQN agent receives normalized user positions and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) as inputs and selects one of 36 discrete beam angles to maximize beam-user alignment. The training process employs an angular-alignment reward function, experience replay, and an epsilon-greedy exploration strategy. Over 100 episodes, the agent's average reward began at 4.777 in the initial exploration phase, exhibited fluctuations due to exploration-exploitation trade-offs, and achieved peaks above 6.7 during later episodes, reflecting measurable learning progress. These results demonstrate the viability of reinforcement learning for adaptive beam management in B5G MIMO systems and underscore the potential of AI-driven decision-making for next-generation base station design.

title: A Mathematical Framework for Quality Assessment of Body Segment Movements using Wishart Models
authors: Tatsanee Chaiya, Payungsak Kasemsumran
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Automated movement quality assessments enable effective physical therapy by allowing real-time detection of improper movements. While previous methods primarily offer offline, full-body evaluations, this paper presents a novel framework for online human motion modelling and accuracy assessment. Our approach uses covariance matrices to capture full-body motion, with the capability to focus on individual body segments. These matrices are computed continuously during a correct exercising movement and used to create an exemplar Wishart model to characterize dynamic motion of the correct movements. For a query sample performing the same exercise, a second set of Wishart models is generated using online density estimation. We then compare these distributions to the exemplar’s in real-time, using a dissimilarity metric to quantify deviations. This allows the framework to identify incorrect movements and pinpoint specific body segments contributing to poor performance. Experiments on three public datasets demonstrate that our framework achieves an average AUC-ROC score of 95.2% for full-body quality assessment. It effectively detects real-time movement errors and distinguishes varying levels of deviation for each body segment.

title: BERT-FastText and BERT-BiLSTM Fusion for Chinese Hate Speech Detection
authors: Methini Ma, Arthorn Luangsodsai, Pakawan Pugsee
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: Hate speech detection is an essential technique in the online environment, especially on social media platforms, to make the Internet world more peaceful, and to reduce the occurrence of tragedies. In Chinese, this task is particularly challenging because of the unique structures and the frequent use of indirect expressions, sarcasm, homophones, character variants, and abbreviations. This study investigates the combination of BERT with FastText and BERT with BiLSTM to enhance detection performance. Both frozen and fine-tuned BERT models were evaluated to examine their effectiveness in different settings. Experimental results revealed that integrating FastText or BiLSTM improves BERT’s performance. Among all models, fine-tuned BERT combined with FastText achieved the best results, reaching 92.58% accuracy.

title: Coupled Harmonic Current Source Model of Grid-Connected Inverter
authors: Shuo Yang, Xinyi Zhu, Yaqiong Li, Shun Tao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Power systems are entering the era of high proportions of new energy and power electronic equipment. The interaction between grid background harmonics and grid-connected inverters (GCIs) leads to frequency coupling effect which results in additional frequency components injecting into the power networks. Besides, to prevent direct transmission through the GCIs' bridge arms, the dead time needs to be applied, which introduces irrepressible dead-time low-order harmonics. However, there is limited research on the modeling of harmonic sources based on the frequency coupling effects. Hence, this paper first analyzes the mechanism of asymmetric frequency coupling effects and dead-time effects. Then the transmission process of background harmonic components and dead-time low-order harmonics in sampling delay progress, outer loop, inner loop, phase-locked loop, signal modulation module, and filter of the inverter is deduced. Voltage-controlled coupled harmonic current source models are established considering the frequency coupling effect, suitable for the superposition calculation of background harmonics and dead-time low-order native harmonics, and the harmonic power flow studies of public supply networks. The proposed models are verified by hardware-in-the-loop simulations.

title: A Dual-path Planning Method Based on PageRank Algorithm for Network of Unmanned System
authors: Xiaoyi Mo, Yi Sun, Youwei Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of network load capacity and dynamic adaptability faced by unmanned system vulnerable to potential malfunctions. A dual-path planning method based on the PageRank algorithm is proposed to enhance network resilience and optimize load configuration. Existing research primarily focuses on traffic scheduling or passive redundant path configuration, which suffers from complex solution spaces and low resource utilization. The proposed method searches for the global optimum load configuration by PageRank algorithm instead of local optimum by some other heuristic algorithm, followed by the next steps: 1) using the average PageRank results of the two endpoints to represent the importance degree of a logical edge; 2) giving the priority to the logical edge with lower importance degree to select its physical path.; and 3) allocating the shortest physical path to the logical edge in its turn to select the path. It is demonstrated that the proposed method improves the survivability and redundancy of the logical network from a given physical network.

title: Observations of the Breakdown Voltage and Corona Emission from Different Configurations of a Spiked Lightning Air Terminal
authors: Nishanth Parus, Chandima Gomes, Carina Schumann
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: This study examines the electrical and optical behavior of spiked air terminals with different configurations to evaluate their effectiveness as lightning strike receptors. Utilizing high-voltage DC excitation, we recorded corona inception, current pulses, and flashover events across six spike arrangements. Measurement techniques included high-speed imaging at 430,000 fps and ultraviolet-sensitive corona camera recordings. Results indicate that more needles increase flashover voltage due to enhanced space charge shielding, while fewer needles generate more intense corona activity. Larger spike clusters resulted in decreased emission. Captured flashover sequences reveal streamer branching and precursor activity, challenging traditional design assumptions. Optimizing spike geometry for lower flashover voltage may enhance lightning strike attraction efficiency, with implications for modern lightning protection systems.

title: Thermal Time Constant Used to Determine MOSFET's Maximum Junction Temperature
authors: Corina Ruxandra Mitulescu, Marius Cristian Mares, Mircea Bercu, Paul Svasta, Ciprian Ionescu, Oana Lazar
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Thermal management and heat transfer are becoming an important part of the MOSFETs and other power devices thermal design. If power devices are diminishing, their thermal power dissipation becomes more critical concentrating less surfaces. The accurate determination of a MOSFET's maximum junction temperature <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{T}_{\text{jmax}})$</tex> is crucial for ensuring the reliability, performance, and longevity of power electronic systems. MOSFETs and other power devices are sensitive to high junction temperature which could break them down, and this paper presents a new way to determine the maximum junction temperature of an operating MOSFET using the thermal time constant. The thermal time constant is related to the transient regime of a transistor, and this paper presents its measurement in direct relationship with the measurement of the stored energy, and the junction temperature <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{j}})$</tex> of a MOSFET device. Application of this method of measuring the thermal time constant, which uses IR technology, is a simple way of determining the junction temperature of a MOSFET in a transient regime, avoiding the device's breakdown.

title: Dosage effects of 2.45 GHz radiofrequency on the antimicrobial resistance and growth of Human Skin’s bacterium Staphylococcus epidermidis
authors: Anuj Kumar Tomar, Neha Jha, Jay Prakash Nirala, Paulraj Rajamani
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: Recent years, there has been a substantial increase in the utilization of wireless devices, ranging from smartphones to smart home systems, all leveraging the electromagnetic spectrum for diverse purposes. In this context, the 2.45 GHz frequency stands out as one of the most widely employed frequencies with extensive applications. The pervasive presence of 2.45 GHz electromagnetic radiation (EMR), commonly emitted by Wi-Fi devices, raises concerns about its potential impact on skin-resident bacteria, particularly Staphylococcus epidermidis. The present study aimed to evaluate the effects of 2.45 GHz EMR exposure on the growth dynamics and antimicrobial resistance profile of S. epidermidis. Culture of S. epidermidis were exposed to 2.45 GHz EMR at different dose of radiation for varying durations 2, 4, 6, and 8 hrs under controlled laboratory conditions, ensuring minimal thermal influence. Post-exposure, bacterial growth was monitored by measuring optical density at 600 nm at regular intervals to assess any deviations in proliferation rates. Additionally, the minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) for a panel of commonly used antibiotics, including amoxicillin, penicillin G, cefuroxime, bacitracin, polymyxin B, neomycin, gentamicin, tetracycline, chloramphenicol, ofloxacin, and co-trimoxazole were determined by broth microdilution and disc diffusion method to detect any shifts in antimicrobial susceptibility. Results indicated that EMR exposure led to reduction in the growth rate of S. epidermidis, most notably after 2 hours of exposure. Furthermore, a statistically significant increase in MIC values for amoxicillin, penicillin G, cefuroxime, bacitracin, tetracycline, ofloxacin, and co-trimoxazole was observed in EMR-exposed cultures compared to unexposed controls and Sham exposed groups suggesting an induced modulation of resistance mechanisms. These findings underscore the necessity for further in-depth investigations into the non-thermal effects of 2.45 GHz EMR on bacterial physiology and resistance patterns, given the potential implications for skin health and the efficacy of antimicrobial treatments in environments with high EMR exposure.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Driven Model for Evaluating the Economic Impact of Cross-Border Dam Water Release in Nigeria
authors: E. E. Woherem, J. K. Odeyemi, P. O. Ugwoke
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The annual water release from the Lagdo Dam into the Benue River, which flows into Nigeria, is one of the causes of the potential flooding in several Nigerian states. Consequently, this has led to the annual displacement of a large number of people, the destruction of infrastructure, and a severe consequence on livelihoods and food security, all of which have a significant effect on Nigeria's economy. This study addresses these issues by developing and applying artificial intelligence (AI) models to assess the economic impacts of cross-border dam water release in Nigeria. The study designed a multi-task learning system capable of forecasting economic repercussions on Nigeria, utilizing hydrological, meteorological, and socioeconomic data. The study adopted a machine learning model to capture the interaction between the economic and environmental variables. The findings demonstrate the model's good predicted accuracy and consistent performance, emphasizing its effectiveness. This study recommends that artificial intelligence has great potential in disaster management, contributing to Nigeria's long-term growth and resistance to climate change-induced disasters.

title: Research on Key Technology of Arc Suppression Switch for Live Line Work in Distribution Network
authors: Wang Jingjie, Wu Shaolei, Bai Xiaohang, Wei Wang, Feng Yu, Li Feilong, Yongzheng Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: A unified “bracket-tool” concept optimizes the installation of HY5CX-13/40 surge arresters by concurrently addressing mechanical reliability and on-site operability. The newly designed connecting bracket features a bolt-fastened architecture, guided by anti-loosening theory to achieve optimal preload. Finite element analysis conducted in ANSYS Workbench confirms that von Mises stresses remain below 60% of the material yield limit under the combined effects of wind, vibration, and short-circuit loads. To complement the bracket, a multifunctional installation tool integrates suspension assistance, guided alignment, and self-adaptive span adjustment. This enables the arrester to be clamped, positioned, released, and subsequently connected to the down-lead clamp in a seamless operation. Two automated derivatives extend this concept: the first electrifies the original linkage, while the second incorporates a servo-gear drive for direct motion conversion, both designed to further alleviate operator workload.SolidWorks models of the tool frame undergo topology optimization to eliminate non-load-bearing material, resulting in a 28 % reduction in mass. A subsequent size-parameter refinement, targeting maximum stress while constraining weight and deformation, restores a safety factor greater than 1.8 without compromising stiffness. Prototypes manufactured according to the optimized design have been validated on a full-scale tower, achieving reliable mounting of the arrester and clamp within 90 seconds—more than twice as fast as conventional methods—while significantly reducing physical strain and high-altitude exposure. Therefore, this integrated approach enhances efficiency, safety, and costeffectiveness in the maintenance of surge arresters.

title: Analysis of Trends in Typical Power System Operation Mode
authors: Shaoxu Hao, Qinyong Zhou, Runzhao Lu, Songtao Zhang, Dian Chen, Xiangfei Meng
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To analyze the reasons for the deteriorating representativeness of typical power system operation modes selected by traditional methods as the proportion of new energy and DC increases, hourly production simulations were performed on actual power systems from different years, and corresponding sets of operation modes were formed. The operation mode points were plotted in selected two- or three-dimensional spaces to analyze their overall characteristics. Then, the rationality of applying empirical rules to traditional power systems and their limitations when applied to new-type power systems were analyzed. Finally, by conducting stability analysis of operation modes under two different renewable energy generation rates in recent actual power systems, the trend of deteriorating representativeness of traditional typical operation modes is reflected; finally, technical approaches for future research on operation mode selection are discussed.

title: Cross-City Generalization of Air Quality Prediction: A Domain-Adversarial Learning Approach
authors: Mariaelena Berlotti, Sarah Di Grande, Salvatore Cavalieri, Daniel G. Costa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Recent studies on urban air quality modeling have mostly prioritized predictive accuracy within individual cities, often overlooking the need for generalizable solutions. However, building and maintaining dedicated models for every city is unrealistic due to data limitations and resource constraints. To overcome this challenge, this work proposes a transferable modeling framework that integrates a Domain-Adversarial Neural Network with machine learning regressors. The goal is to extract domain-invariant features from a source city and apply them to structurally similar target cities without extensive retraining. This framework is evaluated using realworld sensor data from Paris, Madrid, Berlin and Helsinki, focusing on three key pollutants: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NO}_{2}, \text{PM}_{2.5}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PM}_{10}$</tex>. Model performance is assessed across various source-target city combinations to evaluate adaptability. Results show that the proposed approach transfers well among modest-similar cities even if using limited data.

title: A Conceptual Model for Evaluating Workforce Efficiency in the Energy Sector Through Multicriteria and Regression Analysis
authors: Boris Gramchev, Marina Marinova-Stoyanova
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: The energy sector faces increasing demands for operational efficiency and workforce adaptability due to rapid technological advancements and the shift toward sustainable energy systems. This paper proposes a conceptual model for evaluating workforce efficiency by integrating key human resource factors-such as workload, turnover rate, training time, response to incidents, and task error rate-into a unified Workforce Efficiency Index (WEI). The model combines multicriteria evaluation with regression analysis to identify the most significant predictors of employee performance in technical environments. By applying this model to real organizational settings, energy companies can more accurately assess team readiness, optimize training programs, and support strategic human capital decisions. The proposed framework advances workforce analytics by bridging theory and practice, offering energy-intensive industries a robust tool for measuring and improving human performance.

title: An Integrated Stream Processing Framework for Secure and Fine-Grained Access Control in Healthcare IoT
authors: Vayuphak Saengthong, Chatdanai Wongsuwan, Nidhiwit Kunaputipo, Somchart Fugkeaw
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: The rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices in healthcare has led to continuous generation of sensitive patient data, demanding secure, real-time processing with fine-grained access control and regulatory compliance (e.g., HIPAA). Existing attribute-based access control (ABAC) solutions, particularly those using Ciphertext-Policy Attribute-Based Encryption (CP-ABE), are largely designed for static or batch data and fall short in handling high-throughput, streaming environments. We propose a scalable, multi-stage encryption framework for secure Healthcare IoT data processing by integrating Apache Kafka and Apache Spark. At the data source, differentially private noise is injected using pseudorandom functions (PRFs), and data is encrypted with AES and authenticated via MAC. The AES key is encapsulated using Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) under Spark’s public key. Kafka ensures high-throughput delivery, while Spark Structured Streaming performs real-time MAC verification, ECC decryption, and secure aggregation. The aggregated data is re-encrypted using a fresh symmetric key, which is then wrapped with CP-ABE to enforce fine-grained access control. Our experimental results indicate that the proposed approach achieves comparable performance in encrypting and decrypting large-scale data, while notably surpassing the baseline fog computing model in terms of data aggregation efficiency for IoT streaming encrypted data.

title: Research ON the Impact of Integration of Renewable Energy Sources Within Industrial Parks on Line Protection
authors: Zhong Siwei, Cao Gengxin, Li Xiang, Zhu Junjie
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In the global quest for carbon neutrality, the integration of renewable energy sources within industrial parks has become a prevalent trend, significantly influencing power system operations, with particular implications for relay protection mechanisms. This study provides an in-depth analysis of how the proliferation of renewable energy in industrial parks affects line relay protection and explores strategies for enhancing the effectiveness of these protections. The research begins with an assessment of the existing power grid infrastructure in industrial parks, the intrinsic characteristics of renewable energy, and the current relay protection configurations. It then delves into the challenges arising from the increased deployment of renewable energy, such as the intricacies of protection scheme design, the recalibration of protection settings, and the need for interprotection coordination. To tackle these issues, the paper introduces a suite of targeted solutions and recommendations for improvement. The findings demonstrate that with strategic and informed adjustments to relay protection configurations and strategies, the integration of renewable energy can be managed effectively, thereby safeguarding the integrity and security of the power system

title: Three-Dimensional Distributed Cooperative Guidance Law for Loitering Munition Swarm under Time Constraints
authors: Duo Zhou, Juan Li, Lei Fu, Xiaoyu Liu, Xiao Xu, Chang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper proposes a distributed cooperative guidance law based on time-to-go estimates for the simultaneous attack problem of loitering munition swarm in three-dimensional scenarios. Building upon the three-dimensional decoupling, three-stage and two-stage distributed cooperative guidance laws are designed respectively for the lateral and longitudinal planes, respectively. The lateral guidance utilizes a biased proportional guidance (BPNG) law, incorporating a lead angle restriction mechanism to reduce time-to-go estimation errors. The longitudinal guidance is decomposed into flight and dive segments, employing the total energy control system (TECS) and the integral-proportional guidance (IPG) law. A flight-to-dive switching rule is designed to reduce impact time errors. To address input constraints from the attitude autopilot, attitude angle commands are derived as control inputs. By using the proposed guidance law, loitering munitions can attack the target simultaneously in both tiered and non-tiered attack modes. Simulation scenarios of various swarm scales with different communication topologies have been conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed time cooperative guidance law.

title: Hybrid PSO-GA-Based Base Station Placement for Balancing Energy Consumption and Delay Among Cluster Heads in Clustered WSNs
authors: Mohamed El Amine Benharoune, Malha Merah, Lina Aliouat, Zibouda Aliouat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Advanced Systems (ICNAS)
abstract: Optimal base station (BS) placement is critical in enhancing the energy efficiency, latency, and longevity of Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs). This paper introduces a hybrid metaheuristic approach that combines Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) for dynamic BS positioning in clustered WSNs. The proposed method leverages PSO’s fast convergence and GA’s global exploration to balance energy consumption and communication delay. Embedded within a LEACH-based clustering protocol, the BS location is iteratively optimized based on the distribution of Cluster Heads (CHs). An efficient fitness function, incorporating the standard deviation of energy and latency ensures fairness among CHs. Simulation results demonstrate that the hybrid PSO-GA approach offers enhanced network performance regarding energy efficiency, delay minimization, and extended lifetime.

title: Dynamic Topology Tracking of Distribution Networks Based on Sliding Time Window Strategy with Graph Convolutional Networks
authors: Chenglong Yu, Donglei Cao, Junjun Xu, Peng Du
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Accurate dynamic topology tracking of distribution networks is the basis for the safe and stable operation of power systems. In this paper, we propose a dynamic topology tracking method for distribution networks based on sliding time window strategy and graph convolutional network. The method extracts the node voltage statistical features through the sliding time window, and at the same time, abstracts the edges as nodes and constructs structure-aware graph data by using indicators such as the mean, maximum and standard deviation of the voltage difference, so as to enhance the model's ability of recognizing the change of edge state and realize the accurate identification of multiple types of typical topology change scenarios. Simulation results show that the proposed method exhibits superior classification performance in common distribution network topology change scenarios, with a topology tracking accuracy of more than 96%, which is better than the traditional SVM and DQN models, and has good generalization ability and robustness.

title: Distributed Resource Allocation Games under Dynamic Constraints
authors: Zheting Liu, Kai Wu, Yuezu Lv
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: The dynamic characteristics of business loads and deep coupling of multi-dimensional resources make traditional resource allocation methods that only considers static constraints inadequate. This paper addresses the challenge of distributed resource allocation games under dynamic constraints. By proposing a distributed method, this method tackles key issues such as strongly time-varying total resources and tightly coupled cost functions among agents. A distributed algorithm is proposed to make each agent’s decision linearly converge to the neighborhood of Nash equilibrium. Simulation example illustrates the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Assessing Radiation-Induced Degradation System-Level Effects from Device-Level Effects
authors: Richard H. Nederlander, Arthur F. Witulski, Gabor Karsai, Ray L. Ladbury, En Xia Zhang, Nag Mahadevan
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: An electronic system-level failure rate is derived from a diagram of the system’s device-level electrical interactions via the Monte Carlo method. Through these connections, the diagram shows how radiation-sensitive devices can affect electrically connected, downstream devices. When associating effect rates to these sensitive components, a system failure rate is derived for a given mission radiation environment trajectory. This allows for a preliminary assessment of system-level radiation sensitivity prior to conducting a system-level radiation test campaign.

title: Design and Comparative Analysis of Adaptive Control Strategies for Model Rocket Apogee Precision
authors: Matheus Marinato, Arthur De Nardi, Carlos Nascimento, Luiz Félix, Pedro Gluszczuk, Felipe Borges, Lucas Vizzotto Bellinaso
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: In model rocketry competitions, such as the Latin American Space Challenge (LASC), achieving a precise target apogee is a primary measure of success. However, the flight is subject to significant uncertainties, particularly in propulsion system performance and atmospheric conditions, which lead to large apogee dispersions. This paper addresses this challenge by presenting the design and comparative analysis of two adaptive control strategies for an aerodynamic air brake system developed to actively regulate the apogee. The methodology encompasses the development of a high-fidelity nonlinear model of the rocket dynamics, validated against experimental data. Two control architectures were designed and compared: a classical cascade controller (P+PI) and a modern Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) servomechanism. Both systems utilize a Kalman Filter for real-time state estimation. To ensure robust performance, a Gain Scheduling adaptive layer was applied to both strategies. Simulation results demonstrate that both final controllers are capable of maintaining the apogee error below 2 % over a wide operational envelope, validating the proposed methodologies and offering a detailed analysis of the trade-offs between classical and modern control approaches for this application.

title: Deep Learning for PV Power Forecasting: An LSTM Approach for Residential Systems
authors: Tsvetelina Kaneva, Nikolay Valov, Irena Valova
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Residential PV power forecasting is more complex than large-scale solar prediction due to shading, rooftop orientation, microclimatic effects, and limited historical data. This study proposes an LSTM-based framework for short-term forecasting of PV generation by integrating historical output with meteorological variables while retaining real-world fluctuations often treated as outliers. Using diverse PV system configurations, the model captures daily generation patterns with high accuracy and minimal bias. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of deep learning in supporting reliable residential energy management and grid integration of distributed renewables.

title: Multi Objective Optimization Based on Double-Layer Capacity Configuration Method for Inland Electric Ships
authors: Shiyu Wang, Jianhui Su, Yan Du, Yang Liu, Rui Fang, Yanzi Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: As countries worldwide place increasing emphasis on the electrification and greening of ship development, optimizing the capacity configuration of energy storage systems (ESS) during ship design and formulating effective energy management strategies (EMS) during navigation have become critical for achieving energy savings and emission reductions while ensuring ship power performance. This study addresses the problems of configuration redundancy, cost wastage, and reliability risks arising from closed-loop deficiencies involving static pre-set capacity, dynamic power allocation, and multi-objective constraints in ship ESS capacity planning. By integrating a dynamic iterative mechanism for multi-objective optimization, the approach proposed herein resolves the conflict between pre-set capacity deviations and EMS control logic, thereby achieving the co-optimization of capacity configuration and the energy management strategy.

title: Mutual Adjustment Actions for Solving Data Quality Issues in Aircraft MRO
authors: Hafrida Rahmah, Mahendrawathi ER, Arif Wibisono
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Ensuring data quality is crucial for aircraft maintenance operations, directly impacting safety and reliability. This study examines mutual adjustment as a coordination mechanism for maintaining data accuracy in maintenance workflows. Using a qualitative case study in an Indonesian aircraft maintenance firm, we identify mutual adjustment patterns facilitating real-time validation during decision-making and iterative refinement in reporting. Data from interviews and document analysis were analyzed using thematic analysis. Results show a linear corrective mutual adjustment pattern in decision-making and an iterative cyclic pattern in reporting, involving key activities such as 'communicate', 'meet', 'coordinate', 'ensure', and 'adapt'. The structured mutual adjustment patterns offer actionable insights to enhance data integrity in complex maintenance environments.

title: Resource Management for IoT-Enabled Agro-Processing in Cloud Environments
authors: Drusawin Vongpramate, Rakpong Kaewpuang, Piyaphong Yongphet, Teadkait Kaewpuang
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of cost-effective resource management for IoT-enabled agro-processing equipment, specifically charcoal kilns and solar ovens, provisioned via cloud computing platforms. We propose a resource allocation framework that optimizes the provisioning of these renewable energy-based processing units to meet uncertain user demands. Two mathematical models are developed: an Integer Linear Programming (ILP) model for deterministic demand scenarios, and a two-stage Stochastic Programming (SP) model that accounts for demand uncertainty by leveraging historical data and adaptive recourse decisions. Numerical experiments using real-world datasets demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed approach in minimizing total operational and acquisition costs, highlighting its potential to enhance sustainable agricultural processing through intelligent IoT-cloud integration.

title: Probabilistic Short-Term Forecasting of Wind Power Generation Via Arima Assisted Neural Network with Quantile Regression
authors: Zhanyuan Sheng, Zhemiao Wu, Haotian Liu, Chenhui Lin
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To address the challenges posed by the volatility and randomness of wind power to power systems, numerous studies on probabilistic forecasting of wind power have emerged in recent years. In this paper, a novel probabilistic forecasting approach is proposed by combining statistical method with deep learning model, named ARIMA-Assisted-Neural-Network (AANN). In AANN, the autoregressive integrated moving average model is seamlessly integrated with a lightweight deep learning architecture. The hybrid framework employs a two-stage temporal encoding mechanism, utilizing continuous sampling for short-term pattern capture and interval sampling for long-term dependency extraction, thereby achieving complementary integration of statistical principles and deep learning capabilities. The proposed method addresses two key limitations in probabilistic wind power forecasting: a) By incorporating statistical modeling, it enhances conventional deep learning frameworks through improved prediction interval reliability and robustness; b) A post-processing technique resolves quantile crossing issues in quantile regression by enforcing monotonic constraints, ensuring mathematically consistent quantile relationships without distorting distributional properties. Experimental evaluations on real-world wind farm datasets demonstrate AANN's superior performance over state-of-the-art models (Autoformer, Mamba), particularly when processing extended input sequences. The results substantiate that hybrid statistical-deep learning approaches offer advantages in renewable energy forecasting accuracy, providing methodological insights for handling stochastic power generation in modern electrical grids.

title: Single-Event Effects in 28nm FD-SOI Advanced Interface Bus Chiplet Interconnect
authors: Antoine Rouget, Adrian Evans, Fady Abouzeid, Guillaume Bascoul, Victor Malherbe, Gwenvael Le-Bars, Philippe Roche, Fabien Clermidy
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: Chiplet technology for 2.5-D/3-D integration is being rapidly adopted. We study the SEE sensitivity of a prototype AIB chiplet die-to-die interface in 28nm FD-SOI technology using alpha particules and a pulsed-laser. Due to the large number of flip-flops in the interface, there is a significant cross-section. The majority of faults manifest themselves as single-bit data-upsets.

title: Model-Free Predictive Control of Grid-Forming Converters in Parallel Using ARX-RLS Identification
authors: Vítor Soares Gonçalves, Mokhtar Aly, Margarita Norambuena, Freddy Bahamonde, Felipe Ruiz, Humberto Pinheiro, José Rodriguez, Fernanda Carnielutti
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: The conventional Model Predictive Control (MPC) strategy has demonstrated effectiveness in regulating voltage in power electronic converters. However, its performance can significantly deteriorate in the presence of parameter mismatches and model uncertainties. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a Model-Free Predictive Control (MF-PC) approach for voltage control in grid-forming converters. The proposed method employs an online system identification technique based on Auto-Regressive with eXogenous input (ARX) models, with real-time parameter estimation performed using a Recursive Least Squares (RLS) algorithm. The proposed strategy eliminates the dependence on prior knowledge of the system's physical parameters, which allows the controller to adapt and maintain robustness under varying operating conditions. Simulation results on Typhoon Virtual HIL demonstrate the improved performance of the MF-PC method under parametric uncertainty scenarios, particularly when compared to conventional MPC approaches.

title: Predicting Disaster Occurrence and Impact Using AI: A Comprehensive Analysis
authors: Maleeha Jabeen, Omamah Maheen, Shaikha Fatima, Mohammad Pasha, Mohd Umar Farooq, Sara Fatima
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: This project explores the application of artificial intelligence (AI) in disaster management, focusing on predicting the occurrence, impact, and response strategies for various disasters. By analyzing historical data and emerging trends, the project aims to enhance preparedness and resource allocation. Key factors such as disaster type, location, and economic impact are examined. The project employs algorithms including Random Forest Regressor, Decision Trees, Deep Learning techniques, and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to make worldwide predictions. Insights into disaster types and their occurrence rates across different countries are also provided.

title: Study on Transient Synchronization Stability Analysis and Current Limiting Control of Grid-Forming Converters
authors: Bingbing Wang, Chuanxing Zhu, Peng Fu, Haoyang Lei, Lei Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: During symmetrical grid faults, there is a restrictive relationship between the power angle synchronization stability of grid-forming inverters and the current carrying capacity of power electronic devices. Existing studies on fault ride-through strategies for grid-forming converters tend to focus on either power angle synchronization stability or current limiting control, with less consideration given to the coupling relationship between the two. To address this issue, this paper first establishes a nonlinear model of the grid-connected system of virtual synchronous grid-forming converters, and analyzes the impact of different system parameters and control parameters on transient synchronization stability. Then, it compares and analyzes the influence of priority d-axis and priority q-axis current limiter strategies on transient synchronization stability. Finally, simulation experiments are conducted on the transient synchronization stability of the system after adding the current limiter.

title: Research on Implementation Pathways for Green Electricity Consumption in Zero-Carbon Parks
authors: Junhui Liu, Yihan Zhang, Wenjing Zu, Shanshan Xu, Anbang Xie, Yao Lu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Under the dual-carbon goals, zero-carbon industrial parks are an important driving force and growth point for the comprehensive green transformation of the economy and society. Electricity accounts for a significant proportion of energy consumption in parks, and promoting green electricity consumption is an effective way to build zerocarbon parks. To meet the core indicators of zero-carbon parks, this paper proposes a method for calculating green electricity consumption demand. Based on the green electricity consumption ratio, three pathways are proposed: Integrated source-grid-load-storage systems, green electricity trading, and green certificate trading. An economic calculation model is also provided to help parks reasonably select the most suitable pathway. Finally, recommendations are made for the orderly advancement of zero-carbon park construction.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Hybrid Impulsive Formation Tracking
authors: Yanlin Gu, Shuhui Zhen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel control method, termed Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning based Hybrid Impulsive Control, to tackle the challenge of achieving stable formation in nonlinear multi-agent systems (MASs). The proposed method is constructed under a hybrid impulsive control framework, which considers temporally varying hybrid delays while incorporating stabilizing impulses to mitigate potential instabilities arising from continuous system dynamics. Sufficient conditions for ensuring stable formation are established through the application of mathematical tools including Lyapunov functionals and impulsive comparison theory. Compared with existing methods, the proposed approach incorporates a multi-agent reinforcement learning mechanism, in which multiple learning agents are used to adaptively adjust the impulsive control instants and continuous control gains under the guidance of a well-designed reward function, thereby optimizing the control strategy and improving overall performance. The simulation results indicate that the proposed approach achieves better performance than traditional methods, particularly with respect to control consumption and state error, thus validating its feasibility and superiority in enhancing control effectiveness and system stability.

title: Machine Learning-Based Optimal Location Selection Method for Transmission Generator Integration
authors: Woo Yeong Choi, Yilu Liu, Hongyu Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: This paper proposes a machine learning-based methodology using XGBoost to identify optimal generator interconnection (GI) locations in transmission networks under renewable energy integration. By leveraging power system analysis data reflecting static constraints such as overloads and voltage limits under N-1 contingencies, the model predicts feasible GI locations that minimize the need for additional system reinforcements. Case studies on a modified IEEE 39-bus system for renewable energy sources (RES) demonstrate the effectiveness of the approach. The proposed method offers a practical solution to reduce the time and complexity of GI studies while supporting both system operators and generation developers.

title: An Enhanced Dataset for Axial Flux Machine Performance Study
authors: Jinlong Li, Zhuang Xu, Bowen Lei, Ahmed Nasr Abdelwahed, Weinong Fu, Nadia M. L. Tan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Axial Flux Machines (AFMs) are gaining attention in modern electric vehicle applications due to their high power density, compactness, and material efficiency. The performance of AFMs can be analyzed using either high-fidelity (HF) three-dimensional (3D) Finite Element Method (FEM) or low-fidelity (LF) quasi-3D FEM, depending on the specific research requirements. This paper presents comparative numerical studies to assess the gap between different HF and LF simulation models. Then, a comprehensive dataset is generated with hybrid HF and LF FEM simulations for surrogate modelling. This dataset enables the training, validation, and testing of surrogate models with minimal computational time and resources, thereby accelerating the performance evaluation process for AFMs. The numerical results of a baseline with a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) model demonstrate that it accurately captures the relationship between design variables and key performance indicators (KPIs), which can be integrated into functional procedures to speed the analysis processing bypass the invoking of FEM solver.

title: Use of a digital hygrostat for monitoring and control of humidity in concrete facilities of the critical infrastructure
authors: Siya Lozanova, Chavdar Roumenin, Martin Ralchev, Teodor Grakov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This paper presents a study on the application of a digital hygrostat for monitoring and controlling humidity in concrete elements used in critical infrastructure and engineering facilities. Moisture control in concrete structures is essential for ensuring long-term durability, safety, and operational reliability, particularly in transformer substations, foundation blocks, cable chambers, tunnels, and protective facilities. The proposed approach involves the integration of a digital hygrostat into the concrete matrix, enabling real-time measurement and regulation of humidity levels. Laboratory experiments were conducted to evaluate the performance of the sensor under different conditions of moisture and temperature. The obtained results confirm that the use of digital humidity monitoring devices supports the early detection of risks related to corrosion, degradation of electrical insulation, and structural damage, making them a suitable component of intelligent management and maintenance systems in the energy sector.

title: Robust Fine-Tuning of Large Language Models for Retrieval Augmented Generation in Power Grid Dispatching Regulations
authors: Ying Zou, Ying Liu, Sai Zhang, Bochuan Song, Xiao Liang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper presents an retrieval-augmented based question-answering model tailored for power grid dispatch regulations. We introduce an automated high-quality fune-tuning dataset generation approach based on the parsed power grid dispatch regulations clauses for question-answering model. Additionally, a robust retrieval-augmented generation finetuning method using Low-Rank Adaptation is employed to strengthen the model's resilience against irrelevant information. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, the model achieves improvements in accuracy compared to baseline models. This method, by integrating automated dataset generation, retrieval-augmented generation, and robust fine-tuning, offers a reliable and efficient solution for question-answering tasks in the power grid dispatch domain.

title: Ionic Conductivity Enhancing for Some Eco-Friendly Supercapacitors with Polymeric Gels
authors: Daniela Ionescu, Dan Butnicu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Supercapacitors with biopolymer gels like alginate/PEDOT:PSS, respectively gelatin-chitosan gel offer eco-friendly variants for industry, and their performance can be improved by material correlation. The non-invasive technique of structural simulation provides optimized results for the ionic conductivity improvement. The simulation challenge is to reproduce the structure and the mutual interactions occurring in the real system, in a dynamic manner for operating of the device. The molecular dynamic technique was applied in the case of two types of gel supercapacitors, using the Ansys HFSS program. The electric field distribution in gel, the ESR values, the current crowding or skin effect (at higher frequencies) have been analyzed. The frequency analysis was performed for the parameters like electric permittivity or conductivity. Conclusion is that the ionic conductivity of the gel supercapacitors can be improved up to 20% when the electrode - electrolytes system is controlled. The Nyquist plots and the Bode plots have been interpreted and offer us the necessary information for structure optimization. Thus, the improved structures are available for manufacturing without preliminary material consumption.

title: A TOPSIS-Based Framework for Multi-Criteria Evaluation of Physical and Digital Board Games
authors: Krittiya Saksrisathaporn, Teerawat Kamnardsiri, Sumalee Sangamuang
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: We apply the Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS), a multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) method, to board-game evaluation and selection, and present a methodological framework demonstrated through a single-family case study. Five commercial titles—The Game of Life, Azul, Stone Age, Tucano, and Catan—were evaluated in both physical (tabletop) and digital (online) formats. The weights of the aggregate criteria were obtained from a three-member family and computed separately by format. Each participant played all five games in both formats (≥ 30 sessions). Using family-level weights, Tucano achieved the highest closeness coefficient in both conditions. Crucially, these rankings are illustrative of the procedure in a single-family case study and are not intended to provide generalizable findings. The contribution is methodological: a transparent, reproducible TOPSIS pipeline—criteria definition, normalization, weighting, ideal-solution identification (PIS/NIS), and ranking—that supports evidence-informed choices and helps balance entertainment and educational value. To our knowledge, this work is among the first to compare physical and digital board games with TOPSIS using family-based aggregated weights, offering a practical framework for four stakeholder groups: parents, educators/researchers, students, and designers/developers.

title: Building an Entrepreneurial Culture in Electric Power area in Bulgarian High Education
authors: Vesela Dicheva, Svilen Simeonov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: Entrepreneurial and business skills are important for engineering students in the 21st century as they face complex and dynamic challenges that require innovative and entrepreneurial solutions. This paper aims to explore strategies for building an entrepreneurial and business culture in electric power education, drawing on relevant literature and available practices from different institutions. To achieve this goal, available curricula and the environment in which students can develop their potential are examined.

title: Robust Lane Boundary Detection for Urban Roads Using CLRerNet with Adaptive Filtering Schemes
authors: Teetouch Tangwatanasirikul, Nattee Niparnan, Pitchaya Sitthi-amorn, Attawith Sudsang, Sukhum Sattaratnamai
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: The rapid urbanization and increasing traffic density in Bangkok necessitate the deployment of intelligent transportation systems (ITS) to enhance road safety and efficiency. Lane detection is a critical component of ITS, facilitating advanced driver-assistance systems (ADAS) and autonomous driving. This study evaluates the performance of state-of-the-art deep learning-based lane detection models on real-world data collected from Bangkok roads. By considering unique challenges such as complex road structures, dense traffic, this research provides a comparative analysis of model accuracy, robustness, and computational efficiency. The findings aim to guide the selection and optimization of lane detection models for urban environments.

title: Semantic-Aware MAC Scheduling for XR Traffic in 6G Networks
authors: Arjoon Chatterjee, Diganta Ray Mandal, Sourav Dutta, Goutam Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: Extended Reality (XR) is emerging as a key class of immersive applications for next-generation networks. Reflecting it’s importance, ITU-R IMT-2030 vision identifies XR as a key service class for 6 G, and 3 GPP has recognized XR as a critical use case. However, conventional schedulers such as Proportional Fair (PF), and MAX-CQI etc often fail to meet XR’s ultra-low latency, high throughput, and high reliability demands. Existing frame-level integrated transmission strategies improve XR support by prioritizing frame completion but still focus on network-level Quality of Service (QoS), overlooking user-perceived Quality of Experience (QoE). Since not all XR data equally contribute to perceptual quality, semantic communication offers a promising solution by prioritizing semantically important content. In this paper, we propose a novel semantic-aware MAC scheduling framework for XR over 6 G networks that integrates semantic relevance extracted using a 3D convolutional neural network (3D-CNN) for frame prediction with traditional network metrics to optimize resource allocation. Simulation results demonstrate significant QoE improvements and achieving higher gain compared to PF (upto $\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$), MAX-CQI (upto 88%), and frame-level integrated schedulers (upto $87 \%$).

title: Building a CNN Based Pest Detection System for Off Grid Hydroponic Farming in Rural South Africa
authors: Yusra Adnan, Taryn Wilson, Sarina Till
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Subsistence farming plays a vital role in the South African economy. However, food insecurity remains a critical issue, worsened by the country's unpredictable climate conditions and limited agricultural resources. To address this, we previously built an Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Internet of Things (IoT)enabled hydroponic grow tent that implements a Random Forest Classification (RFC) model to monitor and control the growth conditions in the grow tent. However, our research, personal experience, and previous findings revealed that pest control is a pressing concern in hydroponic systems. Building on this, the current study introduces a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model to improve pest detection, using a Raspberry Pi for local model inference and an ESP32 camera for live image capturing. The system operates off-grid via local WiFi without relying on internet connectivity, catering for the connectivity challenges that rural areas face. The model was trained using a custom CNN architecture, transfer learning with VGG16, and a publicly available dataset focused on the most common pests, such as Spider Mites and Aphids. Qualitative and quantitative data analysis was conducted to evaluate the model's effectiveness and the system's practicality for rural African farmers. Despite a limited dataset size, integrating transfer learning significantly improved the model's performance. Deploying the CNN model on the Raspberry Pi proved the feasibility of automating pest detection in resource-constrained settings. This research emphasizes the potential of the system to improve food security and reduce the need for daily manual crop inspections, providing rural farmers with a sustainable solution for pest management.

title: Fuzzy Bayesian Networks in Energy Engineering and Related Areas
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: The growing search for less polluting sources of electricity generation causes a need for energy system data analysis to improve energy planning, aiming for better decision-making and failure reduction. Therefore, this article presents a literature review investigating the application of an artificial intelligence methodology called Fuzzy Bayesian Networks in energy engineering and related fields. As a result, the analysis of countries publishing in the field revealed that China is the country that most researches on the application of Fuzzy Bayesian Networks, considering general research, and the filter considering the energy sector. Furthermore, in the energy context, Brazil also participates in global research. Various types of applications were also identified in electrical and energy engineering, as well as the use of this methodology for fault detection and, more recently, for decision-making in wind and nuclear systems.

title: Text Sentiment Analysis for Thailand Tourism Recommendation
authors: Ittichai Boonyarakthunya, Supannada Chotipant
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: Thailand is one of the world's most popular travel destinations. In the digital age, online reviews written by previous travelers have become a highly influential information source for decision-making. Unfortunately in many cases, users do not assign ratings, or the platforms do not require them. As a result, these systems are unable to process sentiment effectively from the textual reviews. Moreover, most existing recommendation systems lack the ability to group destinations with similar characteristics or categories. This paper proposes a tourism recommendation system that integrates sentiment analysis with tag clustering. The system is capable of processing both user sentiment and destination-related content, enabling it to generate personalized recommendations that align with users' preferences and emotional context. The experimental results show that the SVM model achieved an average sentiment classification accuracy of 94%. In contrast, tag clustering using DBSCAN presented a limitation in the form of high noise levels-over 30% of tags were classified as noise (represented by cluster -1), indicating that a significant number of tags could not be assigned to any meaningful cluster. This reflects a limitation in tag coverage and suggests that further refinement is needed to improve grouping performance in real-world datasets with diverse and contextually ambiguous descriptions.

title: Recent Advancements in HMAC Algorithm: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Akshay A Shenoy, Piyoosh Purushothaman Nair
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: The Hash-based Message Authentication Code algorithm, a critical component for safeguarding data integrity and enabling secure authentication, is used in diverse applications such as secure file transfers, cloud storage, IoT devices, and Web APIs. This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the HMAC algorithm, detailing its applications, methods, and implementation strategies. The study reviews notable progress in HMAC, including the integration of SHA-2 and SHA-3 hash functions, its combination with homomorphic encryption, and the creation of hybrid cryptographic systems. Furthermore, the paper investigates novel approaches to the implementation of HMAC in both hardware and software, with a focus on enhancing efficiency, security, and performance, especially in resource-limited environments such as wireless sensor networks. Importantly, the paper also discusses the difficulties involved in using the HMAC algorithm, including computational overheads, scalability concerns, and use in limited resource environments. The paper further investigates potential solutions and determines areas of future research that are worth investigating.

title: Spatial-Temporal Cooperative Guidance Law Based on Fixed-Time Relative Error Dynamics
authors: Yishu Wang, Haojian Li, Luogeng Tian, Kebo Li, Yangang Liang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: For multi-projectile cooperative guidance with impact angle/time constraints, this work establishes an integrated spatial-temporal guidance framework. Initially, leveraging inverse time-to-go parameterization, the flight duration is constructed as an explicit function. Through reverse derivation, an impact-angle-control guidance (IACG) law with deterministic impact time prediction is synthesized. Subsequently, adopting this IACG as the baseline, a multi-missile impact time consensus protocol is devised by incorporating inter-vehicle information exchange. A cooperative compensation term is derived via fixed-time convergent relative error dynamics (FxT-RED) to enforce bounded-time consensus error stabilization. Numerical simulations validate the efficacy of the framework in achieving simultaneous interception with prescribed terminal conditions.

title: Detection of Commutation Failure in LCC-HVDC Transmission System Based on DC Component Asymmetry of Valve Side Current Under Different Types of Faults
authors: Dui Liu, Jinquan Tang, Wuyang Yi, Yulin Wang, Jun Zhao, Jietong Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The causes of commutation failure (CF) in the line-committed converter-based high voltage direct current (LCC-HVDC) transmission systems are diverse, which increasingly complicates its detection. To address this issue, a CF detection method based on the asymmetry of DC components in valve-side currents is proposed. For CF caused by different types of faults, firstly, the Fourier transform is introduced to extract the DC components of valve-side currents as new key characteristic indicators, and their asymmetry is analyzed. Secondly, a CF detection criterion is established by determining whether the DC components of the three-phase currents exhibit a situation where the DC component of one phase drops sharply to zero while the DC components of the other two phases surge. Finally, the method is verified using a double-circuit model built on the basis of the CIGRE model in the simulation platform. Simulation results show that this method breaks through the limitations of CF detection under AC system faults. It can not only quickly identify CF caused by AC system faults but also accurately detect CF induced by factors such as DC line faults and trigger loss, significantly improving the robustness and universality of detection.

title: Evaluation of the physical qualities and electrical performances of HTS mock-up magnets wound with various REBCO tapes under external fields at 4.2 K
authors: Jung-Bin Song, Xavier Chaud, Himanshu Himanshu, François Debray, Philippe Fazilleau, Thibault Lécrevisse
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: REBCO double pancake (DP) coils were fabricated using HTS tapes from four manufacturers: 1) THEVA (TV), 2) Shanghai Superconductor Technology (SST), 3) Faraday Factory Japan (FFJ) and 4) Fujikura (FJK). The three first tapes represent improved versions addressing issues highlighted in our prior study. During coil winding, the physical properties of each tape-specifically delamination strength and windability-were evaluated. To assess practical electrical performances and mechanical robustness, three mock-up magnets were assembled using pairs of metal-as-insulation (MI) DP coils: TV, SST, and FJK. A mock-up magnet could not be fabricated with FFJ tape due to severe coil deformation. All magnets were pre-tested in liquid nitrogen at 77 K under self-field conditions to measure coil and time constants, and joint resistances. Quench currents were evaluated under various external magnetic fields and temperatures. Additionally, the time constant before and after quench events were measured to investigate changes in contact and surface resistance.

title: Here's What You Need to Know about My Data: Exploring Expert Knowledge's Role in Data Analysis_supp4-3634821.pdf
authors: Alexander Lex
publish: N/A
abstract: Data-driven decision making has become a popular practice in science, industry, and public policy. Yet data alone, as an imperfect and partial representation of reality, is often insufficient to make good analysis decisions. Knowledge about the context of a dataset, its strengths and weaknesses, and its applicability for certain tasks is essential. Analysts are often not only familiar with the data itself, but also have data hunches about their analysis subject. In this work, we present an interview study with analysts from a wide range of domains and with varied expertise and experience, inquiring about the role of contextual knowledge. We provide insights into how data is insufficient in analysts' workflows and how they incorporate other sources of knowledge into their analysis. We analyzed how knowledge of data shaped their analysis outcome. Based on the results, we suggest design opportunities to better and more robustly consider both knowledge and data in analysis processes.

title: Partial Shading Losses in Half-Cut PV Modules: Experiments, Circuit Simulation, and an Analytical Loss Function
authors: Jing-Wu Dong, Jyun-Guei Huang, Yu-Min Lin, Kuan-Wei Lee, Yu-Qian Ye, Che-Yu Lin
publish: IEEE Journal of Photovoltaics
abstract: This study establishes an integrated approach to quantify partial shading losses in commercial half-cut photovoltaic modules. Systematic indoor experiments were conducted on a 440 W c-Si half-cut module, providing current-voltage data under controlled shading. The data were used to calibrate a detailed LTspice circuit model. Further, an analytical loss function was developed to predict power losses as a function of shaded substring fraction and configuration. This analytical loss function was then refined through empirical fitting to the experimentally validated LTspice model, and it closely matches both the designed simulation conditions used for data fitting and independent representative shading scenarios. This framework offers a reliable and efficient tool for predicting shading losses in series-connected half-cut PV modules, facilitating more accurate system design and performance assessment.

title: A U6G Frequency-Division Multiplexing Fully Connected MIMO Transmitter Based on the LO Phase Shifting Technique
authors: Hongji Fan, Yiqiu Liang, Weiheng Chen, Zhaoyi Wang, Zhiqiang Yu, Jianyi Zhou, Wei Hong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: In this article, a local-oscillator-phase-shifting (LOPS)-based frequency-division multiplexing MIMO (FD-MIMO) architecture is proposed. It can achieve the same multibeam performance as the fully connected system without the complex crossover connection network. Different from traditional superheterodyne systems, multiple data streams are allocated to different intermediate frequency (IF) bands, and the LO is a multitone signal instead of a single-tone signal. The multitone LO phase shifting is used to realize flexible multibeam forming. To validate the feasibility of the proposed scheme, an eight-element, four-stream U6G FD-multi-input multi-output (MIMO) transmitter is designed with a 400-MHz signal bandwidth. In circuit implementations, the FD-MIMO framework is perfectly integrated with the traditional fully connected scheme to further improve the communication capacity. Finally, during indoor measurements, the MIMO system achieves a 9.6-Gb/s data rate with 64-QAM modulation.

title: AMP-based Joint Activity Detection and Channel Estimation in IRS-aided Grant-free Access With Accurate Channel and Sparsity Modeling
authors: Hao Zhang, Qingfeng Lin, Yang Li, Yik-Chung Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Joint activity detection and channel estimation is a crucial task in grant-free random access for massive machine-type communications. To enhance communication quality, intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRSs) have been proposed as a promising technology by controlling the propagation environment with passive reflecting elements. However, due to their passive nature and the non-Gaussian device-IRS-BS composite channels, IRSs introduce significant challenges for joint activity detection and channel estimation. To this end, this paper establishes an accurate statistical model for the composite channel, demonstrating that it follows a variance-gamma (VG) distribution. Based on the exact channel statistics, this paper employs a Bernoulli-VG prior and extends the standard approximate message passing algorithm to learn the Gamma-distributed channel variance within an expectation-maximization framework. Additionally, this paper introduces a novel approach to enforce consistency in device activity status across all base station antennas by transforming the activity detection task into the estimation of a dedicated active probability for each device. Extensive simulations validate the proposed VG channel model and demonstrate significant improvement due to imposing consistent activity probability across multiple antennas.

title: Learning to Model the Dynamics of Black-Box Inverter-Based Resources with Multiple Unknown Control Modes from Noisy Measurement Data
authors: Heqing Huang, Yuzhang Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid
abstract: Accurate dynamic models of inverter-based resources (IBRs) are of critical importance for power system stability analysis. However, IBRs often behave as black boxes to system operators due to the diversity and proprietary nature of their control strategies. Existing black-box modeling methods fall short in several aspects, including their discrete-time natures, limited order of expressiveness, susceptibility to noises, and inability to handle multiple control modes. This paper addresses fully black-box modeling of IBRs with multiple unknown control modes through noisy measurement data. The method first learns to cluster noisy, unlabeled measurement data series to automatically discover multiple control modes of a black-box IBR system, then performs end-to-end learning of the dynamic model behind each discovered control mode via a deep neural Kalman filter with three neural networks - the encoder network, the state transition network, and the output network. The outcomes are continuous-time IBR models that can be readily integrated with existing power system model libraries and can be adopted by various numerical integration methods as well as step sizes. The proposed method is validated on IBRs with both grid-following and grid-forming controls in IEEE standard transmission and distribution test systems, demonstrating its advantages over state-of-the-art data-driven IBR modeling methods.
