title: A Review of Current Control Strategies for Switched Reluctance Motor Drives: Performance Evaluation Across a Wide Speed Range
authors: Xudong Wang, Yasaman Niazi, Sadra Tavakolian, Azadeh Gholaminejad, Gaoliang Fang, Sumedh Dhale, Diego F. Valencia, Babak Nahid-Mobarakeh, Ali Emadi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: Switched reluctance motors (SRMs) have attracted increasing interest because of their robustness, cost effectiveness, and suitability for high-speed applications. Accurate current control plays a critical role in achieving high performance, and a wide speed operation range is often required in electrified drivetrains. While numerous current control methods have been proposed in the literature, their applicability across different speed regions has not been systematically clarified. This article presents a comprehensive review and classification of current control strategies for SRMs, organized according to their applicable speed regions. The speed-dependent characteristics and corresponding control challenges are first discussed to establish the basis for classification. Existing methods are then categorized into two major groups: those applicable to low and intermediate speeds and those tailored for high-speed operation. Each category is analyzed in terms of dynamic performance, robustness, and computational complexity. Representative current control methods are evaluated through both simulation and experimental validation to assess their performance across varying speed conditions. Finally, existing challenges and future research trends are discussed.

title: FedDG: An Efficient Federated Learning Framework for IoT Communication Based on Dynamic Fusion and Gradient Compression
authors: Sufang Zhou, Yifeng Wang, Lin Wang, Liangyi Chen, Yadi Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Federated learning (FL) has gained significant attention as a distributed machine learning approach in recent years. However, in the context of the Internet of Things, terminal devices exhibit considerable heterogeneity in data distribution, communication, and computational resources. This heterogeneity can introduce bias, hindering model accuracy through iterative training. Moreover, disparities in communication and computational capabilities limit FL to resource-constrained devices, slowing convergence. To address these challenges, we propose FedDG, an FL framework that integrates model compression and dynamic fusion. Specifically, for nonindependently and identically distributed data, we adaptively adjust the client compression rate based on model training errors, reducing transmission costs while improving both convergence speed and accuracy. Furthermore, clients are dynamically selected for aggregation in each round based on training time and model performance, alleviating the impact of low-resource clients and reducing communication overhead. Experimental results show that FedDG significantly lowers communication bandwidth and data transmission size, and accelerates model convergence under data heterogeneity compared to benchmark schemes, such as FedAvg, FedNova, STC, DF_FL, DAdaQuant, and adaptive quantization in device selection strategy (AQUILA).

title: Overview of Medium Voltage SiC Power Module Packaging Technologies: Layout, Insulation, and Cooling Structure
authors: Yimin Zhou, Zhiqiang Wang, Deao Shen, Chunyang Man, Xingshan Li, Guofei Hu, Xiaojie Shi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: As materials and fabrication processes advance, the medium voltage (MV) silicon carbide (SiC) power semiconductors featuring exceptional electrothermal properties are emerging in high-power applications. Packaging technology, as the key bridge linking MV SiC power semiconductors to external systems, plays a vital role in fully harnessing their performance benefits. In this paper, a comprehensive overview of packaging technologies for MV SiC power modules is provided, focusing on critical aspects of package layout, parasitics, partial discharge, and cooling structure. Through the review, emerging challenges facing MV SiC packaging are detailed and salient distinctions from low voltage SiC packaging are highlighted. In addition, potential solutions are discussed, and insights into future technological trends are shared.

title: Failure-Aware Multi-Robot Coordination for Resilient and Adaptive Target Tracking
authors: Peihan Li, Jiazhen Liu, Yuwei Wu, Lifeng Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Multi-robot coordination is crucial for autonomous systems, yet real-world deployments often encounter various failures. These include both temporary and permanent disruptions in sensing and communication, which can significantly degrade system robustness and performance if not explicitly modeled. Despite its practical importance, failure-aware coordination remains underexplored in the literature. To bridge the gap between idealized conditions and the complexities of real-world environments, we propose a unified failure-aware coordination framework designed to enable resilient and adaptive multi-robot target tracking under both temporary and permanent failure conditions. Our approach systematically distinguishes between two classes of failures: (1) probabilistic and temporary disruptions, where robots recover from intermittent sensing or communication losses by dynamically adapting paths and avoiding inferred danger zones, and (2) permanent failures, where robots lose sensing or communication capabilities irreversibly, requiring sustained, decentralized behavioral adaptation. To handle these scenarios, the robot team is partitioned into subgroups. Robots that remain connected form a communication group and collaboratively plan using partially centralized nonlinear optimization. Robots experiencing permanent disconnection or failure continue to operate independently through decentralized or individual optimization, allowing them to contribute to the task within their local context. We extensively evaluate our method across a range of benchmark variations and conduct a comprehensive assessment under diverse real-world failure scenarios. Results show that our framework consistently achieves robust performance in realistic environments with unknown danger zones, offering a practical and generalizable solution for the multi-robot systems community.

title: ICAFS: Inter-Client-Aware Feature Selection for Vertical Federated Learning
authors: Ruochen Jin, Boning Tong, Shu Yang, Bojian Hou, Li Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Vertical federated learning (VFL) enables a paradigm for vertically partitioned data across clients to collaboratively train machine learning models. Feature selection (FS) plays a crucial role in Vertical Federated Learning (VFL) due to the unique nature that data are distributed across multiple clients. In VFL, different clients possess distinct subsets of features for overlapping data samples, making the process of identifying and selecting the most relevant features a complex yet essential task. Previous FS efforts have primarily revolved around intra-client feature selection, overlooking vital feature interaction across clients, leading to subpar model outcomes. We introduce ICAFS, a novel multi-stage ensemble approach for effective FS in VFL by considering inter-client interactions. By employing conditional feature synthesis alongside multiple learnable feature selectors, ICAFS facilitates ensemble FS over these selectors using synthetic embeddings. This method bypasses the limitations of private gradient sharing and allows for model training using real data with refined embeddings. Experiments on multiple real-world datasets demonstrate that ICAFS surpasses current state-of-the art methods in prediction accuracy.

title: Robust Anomaly Detection for RF Signals in Air Defense Systems under Out-of-Distribution Shifts
authors: Hyewon Ryu, Hyungkwon Lee, Hangyeong Park, Jinuk Oh, Jong-Seok Lee
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Anomaly detection in multivariate time series is critical for Condition-Based Maintenance Plus applications, as early identification of abnormal equipment behavior can prevent unexpected operational disruptions. However, distributional shifts arising from temporal shifts and cross-device variability often degrade model performance, leading to excessive false alarms. In this paper, we address these challenges by integrating Reversible Instance Normalization (RevIN) into Time Series Anomaly Detection using Generative Adversarial Networks (TadGAN), forming a fully unsupervised framework designed to enhance out-of-distribution robustness. We collected real-world radio frequency (RF) signals from two radar units over three acquisition periods and quantified distributional discrepancies using Jensen-Shannon divergence, revealing substantial temporal and cross-device variability. Due to the scarcity of labeled anomalies, we synthetically generated both point and collective anomalies by perturbing the latent representations of normal sequences in TadGAN. Experimental results demonstrate that the RevIN-TadGAN model consistently reduces reconstruction errors and achieves superior anomaly detection performance under various distributional shift scenarios, while maintaining robust performance on in-distribution data. Importantly, our study confirms that significant out-of-distribution (OOD) shifts occur even in advanced combat systems, and demonstrates a practical approach to addressing these challenges through robust unsupervised anomaly detection. This work offers valuable insights for deploying OOD-aware monitoring frameworks in real-world defense applications.

title: Data-Driven Attitude Modeling and Control of Quadrotor UAVs using Koopman Operator
authors: Wenwu Zhu, Fanzeng Wu, Jingjie Zhou, Haibo Du, Jian Xiao, Lei Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper proposes a data-driven approach to attitude modeling and control of the quadrotor UAV using Koopman operator theory. First, to address the limitations of traditional modeling methods, the Koopman operator is employed to learn the nonlinearity of the attitude dynamics from real data (i.e., angles, angular velocities and control torques). Then, the original nonlinear attitude system is reformulated in a high-dimensional linear attitude model. Second, a linear secondary regulator (LQR) control scheme is designed to ensures the stability of the attitude system. Finally, a physical platform of quadrotor attitude control is set up, experimental results validate the accurate prediction of the proposed modeling and control approach. A comparison with PID confirms the superiority of the proposed approach.

title: Design and Implementation of a Smart Flood Level Alert System for Road Underpasses
authors: Kititach Kongngam, Jedsada Arunruerk
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a prototype flood level warning system designed for U-turn underpasses to enhance traffic safety in flood-prone areas. The system employs an ESP32 microcontroller integrated with an ultrasonic sensor to measure water levels in real time. Alerts are issued via the Line Notify platform, with separate channels for administrators and general users. A lightweight web server hosted on the ESP32 allows remote monitoring, while a GPS module provides accurate location information for effective traffic management and planning. To ensure sustainable operation, the system is powered by solar panels with battery storage. Experimental results confirm that the system functions reliably under real-world conditions, reduces the need for manual monitoring, and demonstrates potential for application in other flood warning scenarios.

title: Deep Learning with Optical Flow Attention for Coastal Wave Prediction
authors: Abubakar Hamisu Kamagata, Dharm Singh Jat, Saravanakumar Paramasivam, Attlee M. Gamundani, Almustapha A. Wakili
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: This study presents a novel deep learning framework for coastal wave prediction using video-based optical flow and attention mechanisms. Unlike traditional sensor-based or purely data-driven models, the approach integrates dense optical flow extracted from coastal surveillance footage with a convolutional neural network (CNN) enhanced by spatial attention. The network focuses on key motion regions associated with wave dynamics, such as crests and troughs. At the same time, a physicsbased loss function ensures compliance with fluid flow constraints, particularly the incompressibility condition. A ResNet18 backbone processes five-channel input tensors (RGB + flow), guided by a divergence-based penalty term to promote physical realism. Experiments using coastal video datasets demonstrate stable training convergence, accurate prediction of flow fields, interpretable attention maps and the metrics of RMSE: 0.0625 and an MAE: 0.0467. The results confirm the model's ability to learn physically consistent wave behavior from monocular video, offering a scalable, real-time solution for environmental monitoring and disaster preparedness. This research takes a foundational step toward developing robust, interpretable, and deployable coastal modeling systems that leverage modern AI and physics-informed design.

title: An Error-Threshold Based Joint Phase Estimation and Decoding Method for Non-Pilot-Aided Systems
authors: Jiawen Chen, Xuhui Ding, Xianchao Zhang, Jianguo Li, Xiangyuan Bu, Kai Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: In 5G/6G communication environments, synchronization technologies encounter challenges including excessive pilot overhead, poor reliability at low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and limited estimation accuracy. This paper proposes a joint carrier recovery and iterative decoding algorithm based on weighted and normalized syndrome satisfaction probability (WNSSP). Our architecture implements parallel phase compensation through a multi-layer factor graph model. Within this framework, WNSSP dynamically weights and fuses belief provided by the soft low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes decoder to construct a maximum likelihood estimation function that simultaneously achieves carrier recovery and information reconstruction. To address the single-metric evaluation limitation, code-modified mean square error (CM-MSE) is established according to the residual phase error threshold, which enables concurrent assessment of synchronization accuracy and demodulation reliability. Simulations demonstrate that while effectively eliminating redundancy caused by pilot sequence, the proposed algorithm achieves 0.5–0.8 dB phase estimation gains and 0.15–0.5 dB bit error rate (BER) improvements compared with existing methods.

title: A Training-Free, Quasi-Real Time Lightning Nowcasting Approach
authors: Andrei Razvan Topala, Hannes Kohlman, Ehsan Mansouri, Marcos Rubinstein
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: Forecasting lightning is critical due to its significance for public safety, infrastructure resilience, and disaster response. Traditional numerical weather models are computationally intensive and typically designed for long-term forecasting. In contrast, machine learning models enable faster predictions, but require training on large datasets.The use of Machine Learning (ML) methods for lightning forecasting has shown promising results. They can be used for a shorter predictive horizon, in the range of 15 to 60 minutes, but also present some limitations as they require large amounts of historical data for training. Additionally, they can be difficult to interpret, making it challenging to understand the underlying mechanisms driving the predictions. This paper presents a new approach to lightning forecasting that addresses such limitations. The proposed approach identifies key lightning activity patterns through the use of Clustering and Support Vector Machines, bypassing the need for training on historical data. The proposed model was applied to satellite-based lightning data, and its performance was found to be comparable to that of machine learning models, while being computationally more efficient.

title: Generative Adversarial Networks for Stylized Animation Frame Interpolation and Smoothing
authors: Adarsh Kumar, Bhushan Dhanraj Zope, Jenefar Sudarson, Auguru Vasant, Pushp Lata Rajpoot
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) have changed the way images are processed, especially when it comes to jobs that create and change images. The goal of this have a look at is to investigate how GANs may be utilized in stylized animation frame interpolation and smoothing to make lively scenes look greater fluid and attractive. The toughest part of animation is ensuring that the transitions among frames are smooth so that the motion seems natural and the style remains the identical from body to border. When the usage of old interpolation techniques, they don't usually keep the style's aesthetics, which could purpose visible artifacts or motion that doesn't look proper. We gift a new GAN-primarily based device that blends the fine functions of deep getting to know and inventive images to create frames in among current key frames. The way our version works makes use of both content switch and fashion transfer methods to ensure that interpolated frames hold the movement drift and suit the animation's model. Some of animation datasets are used to check the framework. The interpolation and smoothing are judged on how nicely they keep visible cohesion, temporal continuity, and artistic accuracy. The test results show that our GAN model does a much better job of keeping the quality and flow of animation than other interpolation methods. This method looks like it could work well for many things, like making animated movies, video game images, and virtual worlds. It provides a flexible way to make high-quality, stylized animation.

title: Coronary Heart Disease Risk Prediction Based on XGBoost Machine Learning Technique
authors: Song Xinyue, Navid Ali Khan, Husna Sarirah Binti Husin, Raja Kumar Murugesan, Basheer Riskhan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Coronary heart disease poses a major challenge to public health and healthcare resources as the incidence of heart disease increases. Existing studies have mostly focused on CHD risk prediction, but the imbalance problem of patient data and differences in model performance have limited the ability of models to identify CHD. To this end, this study proposes to explore the performance of multiple common prediction models in CHD risk prediction by analyzing and comparing them, and to optimize for the best model to improve the accuracy of prediction and identification of high-risk populations. The model employs the SMOTE technique to balance the distribution of the data, and various explanatory techniques are added to improve the transparency of the model and the interpretability of the results. The study also used data visualization techniques to demonstrate the distribution of results predicted by the model and the relationship between features, providing a scientific basis for the application of the model in clinical settings. It lays the foundation for future model optimization and clinical practice. This comprehensive prediction framework opens up a new path for comprehensive risk assessment of chronic diseases, and has important practical value and potential for dissemination.

title: Efficient Armed Threat Detection on Edge Devices Using YOLOv11n: A Comparative Study with YOLOv8n
authors: Devadyumna Vijay Kumar, Rohit Mittal, Vibhakar Pathak, Manish Tiwari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The need for real-time armed threat detection systems has intensified with growing concerns around public safety. To detect armed individuals in camera footage, a studyn is presented for a comparative evaluation of two object detection models, YOLOv8n and YOLOv11n, for deployment on edge devices. Both models were trained using the Pashupati Weapon Detection dataset and assessed based on their detection accuracy, inference speed, and resource efficiency. When a detected person and a detected weapon overlapped within the same frame, the individual was classified as “armed”. Through the present work, the trade-offs between detection performance and deployment feasibility on resource-constrained edge platforms are highlighted for models selection in real-time security applications. Moreover, an architecture for an edge-based armed threat detection system using the Jeston Nano and YOLOv11n is proposed. The comparative findings suggested that the YOLOv8n performed better. Overall, the YOLOv8n has an mAP of 80.2 % with regards to the YOLOv11n's 79.0 %. It is worth noting that the YOLOv11n was built using fewer parameters as compared to YOLOv8n, thus forming the basis for the decision to use the YOLOv11n in the proposed edge architecture, keeping in mind the use of constrained hardware such as the Jetson Nano.

title: A Q-learning-based Improved Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search Algorithm for Solving Agile Earth Observation Satellite Scheduling Problem
authors: Fangzhou Chen, Jian Wu, Jiang Zhu, Hong Ma, Lining Xing, Yihui Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: The scheduling problem of agile earth observation satellite (AEOS) problem presents complex constraints and high real-time requirements, inherently falling under the category of NP-hard problem. Traditional algorithms generally suffer from low efficiency. To address this, this paper propose a Q-learning-based adaptive large neighborhood search (Q-ALNS) method. This strategy leverages the destroy-and-repair process of the Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search (ALNS) algorithm and incorporates a reinforcement learning framework to dynamically select appropriate operators based on the current solution state and historical experience, thereby optimizing scheduling solutions and enhancing solution diversity as well as global search capability. Extensive experiments conducted under both global and regional distribution scenarios demonstrate that Q-ALNS significantly outperforms two state-of-the-art ALNS algorithms and the genetic algorithm in solving AEOS scheduling problem, achieving notable efficiency improvements.

title: Improving the PV Power Generation Self-consumption Rate in Individual Dwellings Equipped with Electrical Water Heaters
authors: Oumaima Laguili, Julien Eynard, Stéphane Grieu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: The present work deals with developing model-based predictive control (MPC) strategies - non-linear/linear MPC (MPC/LMPC) strategies are proposed - to the management of electrical water heaters (EWHs) in individual dwellings equipped with grid-connected PV systems. The aim behind developing such strategies is to improve both the PV power generation self-consumption rate and the economic gain, in comparison with rule-based (RB) control strategies. Inasmuch as DHW and power demand profiles are needed, data were collected from a panel of users, allowing the development of profiles based on a quantile regression (QR) approach. The simulation results (over 6 days) highlight that the MPC/LMPC strategies outperform the RB strategies, while guaranteeing users’ comfort (i.e., the availability of DHW). The MPC/LMPC strategies allow for a significant increase in both the PV power generation self-consumption rate and the economic gain. In addition, these results clearly demonstrate the benefits of using EWHs to store the PV power generation surplus, in the context of producing DHW in residential buildings.

title: Event-Triggered Privacy-Preserving Dynamic Average Consensus for Multi-Agent Formation Control
authors: Siyang Li, Yiwei Qian, Pengru Gong, Shanyao Ren, Bin Song, Dongyu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper presents a privacy-preserving and communication-efficient formation control method for multi-nonholonomic mobile robot systems. Each robot estimates the formation trajectory using only local neighbor data under an event-triggered communication rule, which avoids redundant transmissions. A time-varying output masking strategy is applied to transmitted data to conceal the true state without affecting convergence. In contrast to noise-based or cryptographic techniques, which typically introduce higher complexity or compromise accuracy, the proposed method ensures exact convergence with low computational and communication costs. Theoretical proofs and simulations confirm that the robot team achieves accurate formation control while maintaining privacy and communication efficiency.

title: Model Order Reduction of Modified SEPIC
authors: Hima Jayaram, Kuriakose T S, Joseph K D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation of a closedloop controlled Modified Single-Ended Primary Inductor Converter (SEPIC), utilizing model order reduction techniques for simplified yet effective control design. The original fifth-order dynamic model of the converter is systematically reduced to a second-order model using the dominant pole-zero approximation method, ensuring control system tractability without significant loss of system dynamics. The converter's steady-state behavior is analyzed using the volt-second balance for inductors and the charge balance (current-second) principle for capacitors. Based on this analysis, a small-signal transfer function is derived to facilitate input voltage regulation. Extensive MATLAB simulations are conducted to validate the theoretical design parameters in open-loop operation. For closed-loop implementation, a state-space small-signal model is developed to enable precise output voltage regulation through duty cycle modulation. A compensator, along with a PI controller, is designed to ensure stability and dynamic response of the converter under line and load transients. Simulation results confirm the robustness and effectiveness of the control strategy.

title: Ultra-Wideband Software-Defined Radar Mounted on a UAV for Subsurface Applications
authors: Asem Melebari, Sepehr Eskandari, Mahta Moghaddam
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a Software-Defined Radar (SDRadar) system mounted on a small uncrewed aerial vehicle (UAV) for geophysical sensing applications. The system is designed to be low-cost, reconfigurable, and suitable for measuring geophysical and especially subsurface parameters, such as snow properties, freshwater bathymetry, groundwater level, and soil moisture. By leveraging ultra-wideband (UWB) waveform transmission capability and flexible architecture, the SDRadar system can be adapted to diverse environmental sensing applications. A low-cost radar cross-section (RCS) calibration method using a disk as a calibration target is also implemented. This paper provides an overview of the system and a sampling of geophysical results, along with a field assessment of the calibration scheme, showing excellent calibration performance with a standard deviation of around 0.5 dB in most of the operation bands.

title: Real-Time Fire Detection Using Intelligent Multisensor Attention
authors: Damyan Stankov, Plamen Parushev, Prolet Deneva
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: The article presents a concept for an intelligent system for early fire detection in enclosed ship engine rooms and open decks. These areas are characterized by high risk, limited visibility, dynamic lighting, and restricted accessibility. A novel two-stage architecture based on YOLO is proposed, combining thermal imaging with real-time video analysis. The system ensures reliable recognition of temperature anomalies, smoke, and flame. Various methods for visual detection are analyzed, and their selection is justified. Lightweight yet accurate models are employed, making the approach suitable for edge-based systems. Synthetic data augmentation and adaptation to specific conditions are also applied. The study addresses interferences such as steam, reflections, and human presence. The proposed architecture minimizes false alarms, enhances reliability, operates in real time, and is suitable for shipboard deployment.

title: Coordinated Multi-Time-Scale Planning of Battery-Hydrogen Hybrid Energy Storage for Renewable-Rich Distribution Networks
authors: Jiayang Yu, Qirun Sun, Yue Yuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper proposes a coordinated multi-timescale hybrid energy storage planning method for renewablepenetrated distribution networks. The model integrates BESS and seasonal hydrogen storage to enhance both short-term flexibility and long-term seasonal balancing. The model is formulated as a two-stage mixed-integer linear programming optimization problem that minimizes total investment and operating costs while ensuring system reliability and environmental benefits. Validation on IEEE 7-bus system demonstrates that hybrid battery-hydrogen configuration achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1. 9 \%$</tex> reduction in total planning cost and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 6. 9 \%$</tex> reduction in operating costs compared to single battery storage scenario. The complementary characteristics of two storage technologies are effectively leveraged to enhance both economic and operational performance.

title: The Small Time Step Real-Time Simulation System of HVDC System Based on Multi-FPGAs
authors: Minhua Xie, LongZe Kou, Lu Gao, Heming Yan, Beisi Tan
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the increasing ration of power electronics in the power system, the switching frequency is increasing and the control strategy is more and more complex. The future power system presents strong nonlinear and multi-time scale characteristics, which makes it complicated for power system solution, analysis and prediction. Real-time digital simulation acts as an effective means for system analysis and control device hardware test in the loop. With the demand of characteristic simulation of nonlinear, wide frequency domain, fast response, flexible control and other characteristics of the power electronic system becoming more and more prominent, it requires the real-time simulation system to be more precise, faster and more flexible. At present, the simulation time-step of the mainstream electromagnetic simulator is size of tens microseconds limited by technology, which is difficult to meet the requirements of precise simulation of power electronic system. Aiming at the current problems such as real-time model construction, high-speed stable solution in small-step and large-scale hardware collaboration, a high speed solution method for large scale power electronic system in small-step and multi-level heterogeneous parallel real-time simulation system construction technology are presented. A real-time simulation device for power electronic system is developed, which is better than the traditional technology in solving accuracy, speed and flexibility and is more suitable for simulation of power electronic system, supporting the fine simulation and fast response debugging of the control and protection device.

title: Singularity-Free Fixed-Time Fuzzy Control for QUAV Under Actuator Saturation Constraints
authors: Yunli Zhang, Runlong Peng, Yunhui Li, Lan Xiang, Zhonghua Miao, Jin Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: In this paper, a singularity-free fixed-time fuzzy control strategy is developed for the trajectory tracking of a single quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicle (QUAV) subject to input saturation. The proposed control strategy employs a nonsingular terminal sliding-mode control (NTSMC) to guarantee fixed-time convergence performance while avoiding singularities commonly encountered in traditional terminal sliding-mode control (SMC) designs. To handle modeling uncertainties and external disturbances, fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) are suitably incorporated into the fixed-time NTSMC method for the QUAV under input saturation constraints. Furthermore, a Lyapunov-based analysis is conducted to establish the fixed-time stability of the closed-loop control system. Finally, simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed control scheme.

title: Buoy Placement for Cross-Domain Cooperative Underwater Target Tracking
authors: Haoran Shen, Yichen Li, Wenbin Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Underwater target tracking is of significance in maritime domain applications. This study explores the optimal deployment strategy of buoys within a cross-domain tracking framework, leveraging the cooperative capabilities of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs), where UAVs are employed for buoy deployment to enhance underwater tracking accuracy. A time of arrival (TOA)-based observation model is developed, supported by the Fisher information matrix (FIM) and Cramér–Rao lower bound (CRLB) to assess localization accuracy. Target dynamics are modeled using an Ornstein–Uhlenbeck process, and particle simulations generate spatial reachability distributions. Deployment uncertainty is modeled with buoy positions treated as Gaussian random variables, and a posterior FIM via the Schur complement isolates informative contributions to target localization. A multi-objective optimization function integrates A-, D-, and E-optimality criteria with Gaussian repulsion to optimize tracking accuracy and coverage area. Discrete optimization is resolved using relaxation and sparse regularization, while continuous optimization adopts a hybrid approach combining CMA-ES and L-BFGS-B. Simulation validates the method’s superiority in achieving localization accuracy and efficient deployment.

title: Multi-Fault Typical Scenario Set Generation Method Based on Power Flow Tracing Matrix
authors: Boyu Yi, Shaofan Zhang, Yanchun Cai, Yanhong Li, Fayang Tian, Qianyu Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To address the limitation of traditional scenario generation methods in simultaneously considering power grid topology damage and load loss, a typical multiple fault scenario generation method based on the power flow tracing matrix is proposed. Firstly, a large number of fault scenarios are generated through Monte Carlo simulation, an optimal topology is solved by establishing a load transfer model, and the power flow tracing matrix is calculated. Taking the 2-norm of the matrix difference as the distance index, K-means clustering is used to generate a typical fault scenario set. Based on this scenario set, a pre-disaster prevention model for resilient distribution networks is constructed with line reinforcement and emergency power supply placement as decision variables. Case studies verify that compared with traditional scenario generation methods, the proposed method can further reduce the load shedding rate and improve the utilization efficiency of pre-disaster prevention resources.

title: Enhancing Interoperability in Healthcare Management Systems Through the Integration of Blockchain Technology and Big Data
authors: Gunasekar Thangarasu, Kayalvizhi Subramanian, Nattar Kannan, Carmel Mary Belinda M J, Saravanan Muthaiyah, Thein Oak Kyaw Zaw
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Blockchain technology has become a changing agent in many different sectors when open, permanent decentralized ledgers are presented. But the spread of several blockchain systems has upset ecosystems, so networks find it more difficult to exchange data and operate coherently. Currently mostly applied is the answer for interoperability issues in homogeneous blockchain systems, so creating a major hole in communication between many platforms. This work intends to develop an algorithm and conceptual framework to enable communication between two independent blockchain systems, Ethereum and Hyperledger Fabric. Using an Interoperability between Hyperledger Fabric and Ethereum Using Hyperledger Cactus (IHFEUC) approach, it evaluates numerous blockchain interoperability for organ donation system. Then criteria are created to choose Hyperledger Fabric and Ethereum as models of interoperability testing. Hyperledger Cactus conceptual framework employing IHFEUC makes possible the elements and connections between the two networks. By way of simple interoperable communication between Ethereum and Hyperledger Fabric, experimentally achieved results guarantee efficiency and interoperability in organ donation transactions.

title: Optimization of Remote Sensing Technology Based Surveillance Systems for Energy Efficiency and Cost-Effectiveness in West African Region
authors: Ezekiel Nnamere Aneke, Mamah Rotenna Ovid, Afolabi I. Awodeyi, Nnamdi Ahuchaogu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: The rapid expansion of Remote Sensing technologies has revolutionized the field of surveillance, enabling real-time monitoring with reduced costs and enhanced accessibility. However, energy efficiency remains a primary concern, especially for systems designed for continuous operation. This paper explores the energy efficiency aspects of Remote Sensing based surveillance systems, particularly focusing on low-power modules such as the ESP32-CAM and passive infrared (PIR) motion sensors. We analyze power consumption patterns of these components and introduce optimization techniques in firmware and hardware configurations to reduce energy usage without compromising surveillance effectiveness. The study further includes a cost-benefit analysis, highlighting the value of optimized Remote Sensing-based surveillance for small-scale applications in homes and businesses. By emphasizing energy efficiency, we aim to enhance the viability and affordability of Remote Sensing-based surveillance systems, making them accessible for broader adoption and practical use in low-resource settings.

title:

                    annealing techniques on the field oxide TID response for 4H-SiC space applications
authors: V. Kotagama, A. B. Renz, V. Kilchytska, D. Flandre, V. A. Shah, M. Antoniou, P. M. Gammon
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: The total ionizing dose (TID) reliability of phosphorus pentoxide (P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf>) treated silicon dioxide (SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) is investigated through varying post-oxidation anneal (POA) conditions on oxides formed on 4H-silicon carbide (SiC). Previous investigations showed significant improvement to TID resistance, once a sufficient P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf> treatment time had been reached. In this study, the POA time and deposition depth are changed to view their impact on TID performance. Metal-oxide-semiconductor capacitors (MOSCAPs) are characterized before, during, and after irradiation to distinguish changes in flatband voltage shift, leakage current, and dielectric breakdown. The P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf> treatment significantly increases the pre-irradiation flatband voltage due to a higher concentration of phosphorus-oxygen-hole-centers (POHCs) near the SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>/SiC interface. Pre-irradiation characterisation showed that increasing the anneal time resulted in a rising negative flatband voltage shift. However, the effect of increased deposition depth resulted in a lower negative flatband voltage shift at each anneal time. During irradiation, the impact of P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf> deposition depth is shown to be less significant on TID performance than anneal time - the 1 hour POA at both deposition depths exhibited the least flatband voltage shift up to 500 krad of irradiation. However, with sufficient post-recovery time after irradiation, a higher deposition depth has shown to have a benefit of reducing further movement of charge within the oxide. Thus, a 240 nm thick oxide that was annealed for 1 hour proved to be the most TID immune of all the tested oxides.

title: A Python Framework for Accelerated Design and Automated Analysis of Llc Resonant Converters
authors: Pedro A. Pappis Bandeira, Joshua R. Neusser, Maikel F. Menke
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: The design of LLC resonant converters is often slowed by iterative manual simulations and difficulties in determining the switching frequency that satisfies a desired operating point. This work presents a Python-based framework that automates key steps in this process. It integrates numerical optimization, simulation management with steady-state detection, and parallelized analysis to accelerate design while retaining SPICE-level fidelity. The framework identifies switching frequencies that achieve target outputs, reduces simulation time through adaptive stopping, and characterizes converter behavior across an operating window. Results show significant runtime reductions and streamlined access to stress metrics and waveforms, making large-scale performance evaluation practical.

title: Artificial Intelligence Using Residual Convolutional Neural Network-Based Decision Support Systems in Smart Agriculture
authors: Gunasekar Thangarasu, Kayalvizhi Subramanian, Nattar Kannan, Carmel Mary Belinda M J, Saravanan Muthaiyah, Thein Oak Kyaw Zaw
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Focused on smart, efficient, ecologically conscious farming, Agriculture 5.0 marks the next development in agricultural technology. Farmers now control resources and crops using digital technology including robotics, IoT, and artificial intelligence. Particularly in terms of lowering synthetic pesticide use, the European Union Green Deal stresses sustainable farming methods. The EU is progressively restricting traditional synthetic pesticides, which causes pest resistance to develop from the frequent use of few active components. Besides, even if they are safer, biopesticides need exact application techniques to work. This calls for creative, smart solutions for agricultural protection. This article presents a Residual Convolutional Neural Network (RCNN) based decision assistance system for Agriculture 5.0. Whereas CNN is used for accurate classification, residual learning improves feature extraction. Technology uses artificial intelligence to maximize pesticide spraying and combines data from Internet of Things devices. Applications efficiency and pest detection accuracy of the RCNN-based system showed notable gains. Pesticide use dropped by 20% and pest detection accuracy raised by 15%, therefore supporting environmental sustainability and crop health.

title: A Safe Reinforcement Learning Approach Integrated with Weather Forecasting for Real-time Optimal Operation of Distribution Networks
authors: Hanxiao Wu, Yahan Dong, Jun Ke, Xu Wang, Chuanwen Jiang, Jianmin Liu, Bo Jie, Leijiao Ge
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: The growing integration of weather-dependent renewable energy has amplified uncertainty in distribution networks, underscoring the need for advanced forecasting and real-time scheduling to ensure secure, efficient, and resilient operations. This paper employs the data-driven AI model FengWu for weather forecasting to generate wind and solar power data. The real-time optimal sequential operation is formulated as a Constrained Markov Decision Process (CMDP) and solved using Constrained Policy Optimization (CPO), aiming to minimize operating costs while satisfying operational constraints. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Design of Dual Band Circularly Polarized Antenna for Indian Satellite System
authors: Anshu Gaur, Navneet Agrawal, Dharm Singh Jat, Himangi Agrawal, Suriti Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: In this paper, a loading meta-surface (MS) approach is suggested for a dual band circularly polarized patch antenna that exhibits high gain. A MS with a matrix comprising 8x8 periodic square loops is developed and examined for the purpose of improving gain in a typical stacked patch antenna design which is dual-circularly polarized. The hybrid couplerbased, single-port feeding network is carefully constructed to excite these two patches of L -band and S -band with an impedance bandwidth from 1 GHz to 2.6 GHz and achieving dual-Circularly Polarized operation in both the bands. The gain is found to be <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 0 4\ d B}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 1 7\ G H z}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 9 \ d B}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 4 \ G H z}$</tex> with an axial ratio of less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 \ d B}$</tex>. The size of the antenna is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0} \text{mm} \times 100 \ \text{mm}(3.94 \text{in} \times 3.94 \text{in})$</tex>. The designed antenna using meta-surface has shown higher gain and compact size compared to other antennas and covers the IRNSS/NavIC satellite system band with good gain. The antenna covers some Navigation frequency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L$</tex> band and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S$</tex> band as well.

title: FMER: A Federated Learning Approach for Privacy-Preserving Micro-Expression Recognition
authors: Mengyao Wu, Ke Wang, Hua Xu, Xunxiang Yao, Peng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Automatic Micro-Expression Recognition (MER) discloses the inner emotions and intentions of individuals from spontaneous and unconscious facial expressions through computer-aided techniques. It holds significant potential for applications such as lie detection and mental health monitoring. Unfortunately, MER is critically challenged by limited training samples because of the expensive annotation cost. One potential solution is to aggregate micro-expression samples distributed across different agents/entities. However, such data exchange might cause privacy concerns and ownership dispute issues, making centralized MER training impractical. To address the challenges, this paper proposes FMER that integrates decentralized MER training into the federated learning framework, addressing privacy concerns in the regulated data-sharing MER application. Specifically, FMER employs the Muscle Motion-guided Network as the base model, introducing a multi-client collaborative training mechanism: clients update model parameters based on local data, while the server aggregates global models using the FedProx algorithm. Differential privacy technology with Gaussian noise injection protects gradient privacy, and proximal term constraints mitigate data heterogeneity. Experiments show that the proposed FMER achieves recognition accuracies of 81.89% and 79.19% on the CASMEII and SAMM datasets, respectively, verifying the effectiveness of the privacy-preserving micro-expression recognition model.

title: Research on Bi-Level Optimization Scheduling Model and Strategy for Grid-Connected Photovoltaic-Energy Storage Systems
authors: Youjun Wang, Jian Chen, Lulu Du, Qiang Xu, Ming Cheng, Aixia Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The integration of photovoltaic (PV) generation with energy storage systems (ESSs) has emerged as a promising approach to enhance renewable energy utilization and ensure the stability of power supply in grid-connected scenarios. However, the variability of solar irradiance and the complexity of multi-source coordination pose challenges to both capacity planning and real-time operation. To address these issues, this paper proposes a bi-level optimization scheduling model for grid-connected PV-ESS systems. The upper-level model aims to minimize the annualized net cost by optimizing the installed capacity and rated power of PV and ESS units, taking into account investment, operation and maintenance, and electricity purchase costs. The lower-level model focuses on minimizing daily operating costs through optimal energy dispatch under time-of-use electricity prices, ensuring system safety, power balance, and storage operation constraints. A coordinated iterative solution method combining NSGA-II and CPLEX solvers is developed to realize closedloop optimization between the two layers. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed strategy effectively improves economic performance, enhances the local consumption of PV energy, and supports the flexible operation of distributed energy systems.

title: Virtual Power Plant Energy Management and Spot Electricity Market Trading Strategy Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning Algorithm
authors: Zheming Liang, Shuo Zhang, Jianqi Ye
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper proposes a collaborative optimization framework for virtual power plants that integrate hydrogen energy systems and an energy management method based on the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm to address the multi-source uncertainty optimization challenges and trading risks in the spot electricity market faced by virtual power plants with a high proportion of renewable energy access. By constructing an aggregation model of renewable energy generation hydrogen storage flexible load, a decisionmaking mechanism is designed that includes current spot electricity market quotations and real-time demand response. The DDPG algorithm is used to dynamically optimize the electricity sales bidding curve, and the hydrogen storage system is used to stabilize the fluctuations of renewable energy generation and enhance market arbitrage ability. A hydrogenbased fuel-cell vehicle scheduling model is established to achieve the conversion and reuse of hydrogen energy with limited electricity consumption, forming a source grid load storage collaborative optimization loop. The simulation results show that the strategy proposed in this article can increase the revenue of virtual power plants in the spot market by 23.7 %, improve the utilization rate of renewable power to 98.2 %, and maintain load satisfaction above 92 % through hydrogen cascade utilization, effectively solving the dual dilemma of power rationing losses and market risks in traditional renewable power stations.

title: A Visual SLAM System in Dynamic Environments Based on YOLO11 Instance Segmentation
authors: Xiang Wang, Cong Li, Hui Jing, Jinpeng Li, Bing Kuang, Guangyu Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: To address the problems of low positioning accuracy, poor real-time performance, and insufficient robustness of traditional visual SLAM systems in dynamic environments, this paper proposes a novel algorithm that integrates the YOLO11 instance segmentation model with ORB-SLAM3. Based on the original three threads of ORB-SLAM3, an additional parallel object detection thread is designed to identify dynamic objects in real time. First, YOLO11 is employed to detect dynamic objects in the scene. Then, the YOLO11 instance segmentation model is introduced to generate semantic masks as high-quality prior information. Finally, the semantic masks are integrated into the ORB-SLAM3 framework to enable real-time removal of dynamic feature points. By introducing YOLO11 instance segmentation, the improved ORB-SLAM3 effectively reduces the impact of dynamic objects on positioning accuracy and enhances the system's localization and mapping capabilities in dynamic environments. The algorithms are validated on KITTI dataset and TUM dataset respectively, and the results show that the algorithm in this paper achieves better state estimation with higher localization accuracy and stronger robustness on several typical dataset sequences.

title: An Artificial Neural Network Based Adaptive Model Predictive Controller for Grid-Tied Inverters
authors: Frederico Saviano, Eugênio Pozzobon, Freddy Flores–Bahamonde, Fernanda Carnielutti, Humberto Pinheiro
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: Model Predictive Control (MPC) is recognized as a strong candidate for controlling static power converters, but its widespread adoption is often limited by the high computational burden-particularly for multilevel converters with long prediction horizons-and its sensitivity to parameter variations. This paper proposes an alternative approach based on Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) to address these challenges. The ANN is trained to replicate the optimal control actions of an MPC controller using a comprehensive dataset generated under diverse operating conditions, including variations in filter inductance. The proposed architecture, named Adaptive Model Predictive Control (AMPC), leverages a temporal horizon of past data to achieve dynamic and adaptive control. Hardware in the loop results demonstrate that the proposed ANN-based controller achieves stable and accurate performance under a large range of inductance values, outperforming conventional MPC, which suffers from accuracy deterioration when the plant model deviates from the nominal. The effectiveness of the proposed controller is further validated through Controller-Hardware-in-the-Loop (CHIL) experiments, demonstrating its potential as a robust and computationally efficient solution for a grid-connected inverter.

title: Velocity Vector Sensing for ISAC Systems Exploiting Doppler-Rate
authors: Dongqi Luo, Fan Jiang, Xueyang Hu, Xiaofeng Tao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel velocity vector sensing algorithm for integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems. Specifically, we first investigate the impact of user tangential motion on the channel, revealing that it introduces both linear growth of Doppler shift in the time domain and linear variation of spatial frequency in the angular domain. Based on this observation, we then establish a more accurate channel model to describe the effects of simultaneous radial and tangential motion, and propose an estimation of signal parameters via rotational invariance techniques (ESPRIT)-least squares (LS)-based algorithm for channel parameter estimation. Finally, we reconstruct the user’s position and velocity vector using the estimated channel parameters. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Two-Stage Power System Scheduling Model Considering Transmission Line Dynamic Capacity Expansion Risk
authors: Zhengnan Gao, Jianbo Guo, Shicong Ma, Tiezhu Wang, Shixiong Fan, Dongqi Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In order to broaden the transmission space of the transmission network, the power system uses DTR (dynamic thermal rating) to dynamically expansion the capacity of the transmission line during scheduling. However, the uncertainty of meteorological factors causes the prediction errors of DTR. If the inaccurate DTR prediction value is used to expansion the capacity of the transmission line, the transmission line will have the risk of breaking the thermal stability limit. It may cause the transmission line congestion. In this paper, by mining the information of DTR historical prediction data, the capacity expansion risk is quantified, and the quantified risk is utilized to the two-stage scheduling strategy to complete the generation scheduling of power system. Firstly, the risk quantification model of DTR capacity expansion is established, and the quantitative model is simplified by piecewise linear transformation to facilitate calculation. At the same time, the coefficients of the risk quantification model are obtained by driving the historical data of DTR. Finally, the capacity expansion risk is introduced into the scheduling target in the form of risk cost, and the two-stage scheduling model is constructed which meets the electricity market and contains flexible demand response. Finally, the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed scheduling method are verified by the IEEE-39 node transmission network containing Chinese actual power grid data.

title: Research on Carbon Trading Strategy of Integrated Energy System Based on Transformer Model and Metaverse
authors: Song Zhang, Yang Cao, Fan Zhang, Qiang Hu, Yangyang Liu, Zedan Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The carbon trading scenario of integrated energy system is established through Metaverse instead of the traditional centralized and static trading platform. The Metaverse scenario constructs an immersive and visual virtual scene of carbon trading, which improves the transparency and flexibility of trading. According to the spatio and temporal coupling characteristics of multi energy flow data in the integrated energy system, the Transformer model can automatically capture the complex correlation between different energy types, equipment states and environmental factors. The Transformer model effectively improves the shortages of traditional time series model in processing multi-source heterogeneous data through the self attention mechanism and multi head attention architecture which can contribute to the operation status prediction of integrated energy system. The dynamic management of carbon quotas, the optimization of energy structure and the multi-agent collaborative trading can be enhanced through the smart contract and consensus mechanism of blockchain network in Metaverse scenario.

title: Humanoid Robots Running via Adaptive Reference Motion Assisted Reinforcement Learning
authors: Ruijie Wang, Ke Gan, Yang Li, Dong Zhu, Shuo Han, Xiangyu Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Despite extensive research on humanoid walking, running remains challenging due to higher speed and longer stride requirements, which induce greater center-of-mass fluctuations and increased landing impacts. This paper incorporates self-adaptive reference motions into a reinforcement learning framework to achieve stable and high-speed running. To facilitate the imitation of reference motions while promoting autonomous exploration, the proposed method includes a curriculum-based contact mask. Additionally, a state estimation module is embedded to compensate for sensory inputs missing, ensuring accurate directional tracking. Simulations results on two humanoid robots demonstrate that the proposed method achieves faster velocity response and improved tracking performance compared to baseline approaches. On the Dexbot platform, it accurately tracks a target velocity of 3 m/s, verifying both the effectiveness and generalizability of the proposed framework.

title: Towards Ethical Health Claim Verification: Blockchain and Digital Twin Systems for Rhinoplasty Surgery in Smart Cities
authors: Cecilia Erika Ramírez Alba, Jesús Máximo Montes Díaz, Abel Hurtado Macías, Alfredo Nevares Rascón, Martha Vardaki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: In Mexico, fraudulent claims in private healthcare insurance-particularly involving elective nasal aesthetic surgeries like rhinoplasty disguised as medically necessary procedures—remain a persistent challenge. This paper presents an integrated smart healthcare framework that combines deep learning, digital twins, and blockchain technology to prevent such fraud. A digital twin of the patient's nose is generated using high-resolution pre-, intra-, and post-operative photographs. These models capture precise morphometric features and surgical changes over time. The data is secured via blockchain, ensuring tamper-proof storage of facial geometry, biometric identifiers, and medical metadata. By leveraging LSTM neural networks, the system learns healing patterns and predicts expected anatomical transformations, allowing insurance providers to distinguish legitimate functional interventions from unauthorized aesthetic procedures. Biometric landmarks and image metadata are cryptographically hashed and stored to preserve data integrity and identity authentication. This method enables forensic-level auditing of health claims, increases transparency, and reduces administrative overhead. Aligned with the principles of resilient and sustainable smart communities, this framework contributes to ethical health reimbursement, data sovereignty, and trust restoration in Latin America's healthcare systems.

title: Construction of Target Mode of Power Grid Regulation and Control Integration
authors: Jinghui Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The integration of regulation and control is an important way and the main starting point to ensure the safe and stable operation of large power grids. In view of this, this paper puts forward a strategy to build the target model of regulation integration, The double confirmation technology of disconnector based on magnetic induction principle is studied, and the operation mode of quickly starting substation by programmed operation at dispatching terminal is constructed. Through production examples, the safety, stability and economy of power grid operation under the target mode of integrated regulation and control are analyzed, and the effectiveness of the proposed strategy is verified.

authors: Vesna Nowack, Dalal Alrajeh, Carolina Gutierrez Munoz, Katie Thomas, William Hobson, Patrick Benjamin, Catherine Hamilton-Giachritsis, Tim Grant, Juliane Kloess, Jessica Woodhams
