title: LabTwinXR: A Real-Time eXtended Reality Digital Twin Testbed for Smart Buildings
authors: Elissavet Pekridou, Christos Hitiris, Stavros Vasileiou-Kyriakou, Vasiliki Karamerou, Dimitrios J. Vergados, Panagiotis Sarigiannidis, Angelos Michalas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Smart cities evolve toward more sustainable and resilient infrastructures, integrating real-time, user-centered technologies into building management is critical. LabTwinXR is a real-time eXtended Reality (XR) digital twin testbed deployed in a smart laboratory environment to support energy and indoor environmental quality (IEQ) management. The system combines Internet of Things (IoT) sensor data with immersive Virtual and Augmented Reality interfaces, enabling users to interact with realtime energy, temperature and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> metrics. By enabling bidirectional interaction, the system moves beyond the limitations of digital shadows and aligns with the definition of a true digital twin. Three use cases demonstrate the system's capability to enhance energy-aware building operations through immersive, human-in-the-loop control. Preliminary evaluation results demonstrate low-latency and positive user experience ratings (UEQ-S). These findings confirm the system's viability for immersive, energy-aware building management.

title: Big Data Analytics in Smart Cities: Systems, Techniques, and Applications
authors: Elias Dritsas, Maria Trigka, Phivos Mylonas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: This survey presents a system-level analysis of big data analytics in smart cities, bridging data sources, analytical techniques, and deployment infrastructures. It categorizes analytics into stream, batch, predictive, semantic, and explainable methods and maps them to edge, fog, and cloud layers via distributed orchestration and standardized interfaces. Real-world applications across mobility, environment, safety, and citizen services are examined, emphasizing execution-aware design, interoperability, and compliance with ethical and regulatory frameworks of the technology. This survey highlights the integration gaps in previous studies and outlines future directions for transparent, scalable, and semantically enriched urban intelligence systems.

title: A Comparative Study of Some Soil Fertility Sensors Based on Electrical Conductivity Measurements
authors: Gaudentiu Varzaru, Roxana Tulea, Razvan Ungurelu, Viorel Fatu, Paul Svasta
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Modern agriculture urgently needs a satisfactory solution for the estimation of soil nutrients available to plants. With the advent of Internet-of-Things technology, a category of sensors based on indirect determination through the soil electrical conductivity measurement is on the market. But measurements taken on the same soil sample showed a significant difference between nutrient sensors from different manufacturers. The objective of the study is to find the optimum sensor for our application. The criteria were their response to testing with five aqueous solutions and five sandy soil samples with preset concentrations of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N, P$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K$</tex> and two clay-loam soil samples with different moisture contents.

title: Online Inertia Assessment and Security Analysis for Power Systems with High Penetration of Renewable Energy
authors: Jing Feng, MA Shiyin, Song Dongwen
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The rapid development of renewable energy has increased the difficulty of active power regulation in power systems due to the intermittency and volatility of wind/solar power as well as the relative decline in rotational inertia. Under the same disturbance, system frequency now changes faster with larger deviations. Therefore, studying online inertia assessment and security analysis methods for power systems with high renewable penetration is of significant importance. This study first analyzes the inertia mechanisms and manifestations of generation-load-storage systems under high renewable penetration. Based on this analysis, a frequency dynamic equation incorporating virtual inertia from renewable sources and energy storage is derived. To characterize grid rate-of-change-of-frequency (RoCoF) features, an identification method for system inertia and load inertia is proposed. For preventing excessive RoCoF and frequency deviations, an analytical calculation method for determining the system's minimum required inertia is developed, which can also be used to compute the maximum disturbance the grid can currently withstand. Finally, building upon these methods, an online inertia assessment and security analysis scheme is designed and applied to real-time inertia monitoring in practical power grids.

title: Time-Domain Equivalent Modeling Method of VSC-HVDC Based on Multi-Condition Admittance Fitting for Small-Signal Stability Analysis
authors: Hao Yuan, Ziqian Yang, Wangqianyun Tang, Baorong Zhou, Youjie Shi
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the increasing integration of renewable energy and cross-regional power interconnection demands, voltage source converter high voltage direct current (VSCHVDC) technology has become a critical solution for modern power systems. However, its complex dynamics lead to highdimensional modeling and low simulation efficiency, limiting stability analysis and real-time assessment. To address this, this paper proposes a equivalent modeling method for VSCHVDC systems that accommodates multiple operational conditions. By deriving a small-signal admittance model and integrating admittance measurement, fitting, and numerical approximation under various operating points, an equivalent model balancing dynamic accuracy and computational efficiency is established. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method improves the simulation speed while maintaining time-domain dynamic consistency.

title: Distributionally Robust Optimal Dispatch for Distribution Networks Considering Dynamic Spatial Correlation of PV Power Output
authors: Ma Xin, Yuan Yue, Shi Wenhui
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To effectively address the dispatch challenges posed by the uncertainty of distributed photovoltaic (PV) output and its complex dynamic spatial correlations in distribution networks, this paper proposes a novel distributionally robust optimization (DRO) dispatch method. The method integrates the detailed dynamic spatial correlation characteristics of PV output-captured through a dynamic conditional correlation-generalized autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity model, which provide time-varying covariance information-into the DRO framework. Specifically, a dynamic ambiguity set is constructed based on predicted means and time-varying covariance matrices to more precisely define the probability distribution range of uncertain PV output. The proposed two-stage DRO model incorporates affine decision rules and applies strong duality theory, successfully transforming the problem into a deterministic mixed-integer second-order cone programming problem, thereby ensuring computational feasibility and solution efficiency. Case study results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method in balancing operational economy and robustness, particularly in distribution networks with high penetration and strong correlation of PV integration, showcasing enhanced risk-aversion capabilities and economic benefits.

title: LDMS-SLAM: Lightweight Metric-Semantic SLAM for Dynamic Environments
authors: Min Gong, Mingzhu Wei, Jingru Zhang, Jinhang Dong, Zhenni Zeng, Hui Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) technology has widespread applications in autonomous driving, robotic navigation, and augmented reality. However, traditional visual SLAM systems tend to build static maps for autonomous navigation by treating dynamic targets as interference and eliminating them from the environment, which leads to a decrease in localization accuracy and map construction quality. To address this issue, this study proposes an enhanced SLAM framework based on ORB-SLAM3, integrating YOLOv8 instance segmentation technology to achieve real-time detection and removal of dynamic targets for constructing navigation-oriented metric maps. The proposed metric semantic octomap not only efficiently represents three-dimensional space but also integrates rich semantic information, providing more accurate and practical environmental understanding for robot navigation and path planning, thus further enhancing the system’s practicality and application potential. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms traditional ORB-SLAM3 in dynamic scenarios.

title: 3D Digitization of Kurung Teluk Belanga: Integrating Traditional Attire into Immersive Consumer Technologies for Cultural Heritage Preservation
authors: Norhaida Mohd Suaib, Ajune Wanis Ismail, Aiman Mohd Rashid, Nur Ameerah Abdul Halim, Nor Anita Fairos Ismail, Muhammad Anwar Ahmad, Ulinnuha Ab Aziz Al Safi, Mohammad Khairul Shaleh Md Asari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Traditional Malay attire such as Kurung Telok Belanga is a vital component of Malaysia’s cultural identity. However, preserving this heritage poses significant challenges due to the declining intergenerational practice and interest, plus limited availability of their digital representation. This paper introduces a framework for digitally preserving the Kurung Telok Belanga through 3D modeling techniques intended towards extended reality (XR) applications, blending traditional tailoring elements with modern immersive technologies. A structured pipeline involving high-resolution reference capture, digital 3D cloth reconstruction and mesh optimization is proposed. The resulting 3D garment model is deployed in two test environments: a custom-built augmented reality (AR) virtual try-on application and a metaverse-based cultural showcase. The virtual try-on enables real-time garment testing using rigged avatars, while the metaverse implementation supports spatial exploration of the attire within a shared digital environment. This study highlights how extended reality (XR) technologies can play a transformative role in safeguarding intangible cultural heritage through virtual ecosystems.

title: Total Ionizing Dose in 130-nm and 55-nm SiGe:C Heterojunction Bipolar Transistors
authors: A. Adebabay Belie, F. Pascal, J. Boch, T. Maraine, A. Hoffmann, M. Bouhouche, B. Sagnes, P. Chevalier, D. Gloria
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: In this work, high X-ray TID exposures are assessed for 130 nm and 55 nm SiGe:C HBTs technologies. The impact of geometry, technology type and collector doping on the degradation of I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">B</inf> were investigated. Annealing experiments were studied.

title: Cross-Domain Collaborative Filtering Recommendation without Overlapping Users and Items
authors: Areeporn Tupwong, Rangsipan Marukatat
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: In recent years, single-domain recommendation methods have seen rapid development and significant success. However, they encounter problems that hinder their performance, such as sparse ratings in user-item rating matrix and cold start for new users. Cross-domain recommendation alleviates these issues by leveraging rating information from a well-established source domain and conveying it to a target domain. Such techniques usually rely on the existence of shared users or items in the two domains. However, such overlap is seldom found in real-world scenarios, which complicates the application of these methods. Therefore, our research proposes a cross-domain collaborative filtering recommendation method that does not rely on overlapping users or items. Instead, it matches items across domains based solely on their English text descriptions, such as movie overviews from the Movie domain and book descriptions from the Book domain. We evaluated a few different combinations of word embeddings (Word2Vec, Doc2Vec, and GloVe) and semantic similarity methods (cosine similarity and soft cosine similarity) for cross-domain item matching. The results indicate that soft cosine similarity, enhanced by Word2Vec word embeddings, was the best combination to capture complex semantic relationships in textual data. Moreover, sparsity reduction was found to be critical for improving the accuracy of recommendations.

title: EEG Emotion Classification Using a Hybrid CNN-BiGRU with Attention Mechanism
authors: Neethu T V, E. Grace Mary Kanaga
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Recognizing human emotions through the use of EEG signals has wide-ranging applications in the fields of interaction with computers, mental healthcare, and adaptive education technologies. Most traditional methods have relied on handcrafted features or simpler machine learning paradigms that do not attend to the highly complex non-stationary EEG data. Here, we describe a new approach for EEG emotion recognition based on a hybrid deep learning model that integrates convolutional neural networks, bidirectional gated recurrent units, and an attention mechanism. The first step is preprocessing raw EEG signals into more informative representations through wavelet decomposition and entropy analysis. These features are provided to a hybrid deep learning framework based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Units (BiGRUs). The multi-scale CNN layers extract spatial and local temporal information, and pattern class discovery is enabled at the lower layers, whereas the BiGRU layers attend to long-range temporal dependencies of the EEG signals in both directions. To further enhance classification accuracy, an attention mechanism is added to the model to steer the EEG signals mathematically to extract the most relevant features useful for emotion recognition analysis. We examine the performance of our model on the “EEG Brainwave Dataset: Feeling Emotions”, which encodes emotions into positive, negative, and neutral categories. The experiments conducted using the proposed Hybrid CNN-BiGRU with Attention, along with wavelet entropy feature extraction, demonstrate superior performance over traditional machine learning methods and basic deep learning models. These results highlight the success of advanced signal processing integrated with deep learning, which produces robust and accurate emotion recognition.

title: Investigating how to proofread texts containing tic symptoms using a large language model
authors: Yuto Kobayashi, Takeshi Hamasaki, Yujie Li, Yoshihisa Nakatoh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Tics are characterized by involuntary or semi-voluntary repetitive actions without purposeful intent, categorized as either 'motor tics' or 'vocal tics.' Motor tics manifest as involuntary movements affecting one or more body parts, whereas vocal tics involve the involuntary production of words or sounds through the nose or mouth. Current understanding suggests tic onset correlates with overloaded brain circuits, particularly in the basal ganglia, alongside abnormalities in neurotransmitter systems such as dopamine and serotonin, though definitive treatment remains elusive. Coprolalia, the involuntary utterance of obscene or sexually explicit language, represents a notable vocal tic symptom that significantly impacts patients' psychological well-being. Additional vocal tic manifestations include echolalia (repetitive speech), palilalia (repeating one's own words), and phonological tics (guttural sounds), which collectively impede comprehension, confuse listeners, and disrupt conversations. This study ultimately aims to develop a tic removal tool utilizing large language models (LLMs). As a preliminary investigation, we evaluated the tic removal capabilities of two advanced LLMs—GPT-4o and Gemini 1.5 Pro. Identical sentences containing both prompts and tic elements were processed by both models, with removal efficacy assessed via questionnaire. Results indicated comparable performance between the models, with both demonstrating limitations in removing tics that maintained grammatical coherence within sentences.

title: Benchmarking SpikingJelly-Based SNNs Against Conventional ANNs: An MNIST Case Study on Accuracy and Synops
authors: Niti Thienbutr, Wansuree Massagram
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) represent a biologically inspired alternative to conventional Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), offering the potential for event-driven and low-power inference on neuromorphic hardware platforms. Unlike ANNs which rely on continuous activation functions, SNNs communicate through discrete spikes, making them closer to biological information processing. However, they remain challenging to train and often lag behind ANNs in accuracy. In this work, we present a simple yet systematic benchmark on the MNIST dataset using the SpikingJelly framework. We implement a fully connected ANN baseline and its SNN counterpart with Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF) neurons trained using surrogate gradients. To examine temporal dynamics, SNNs were evaluated across four simulation timesteps: T = 1,2,4,8. The ANN baseline achieves a peak test accuracy of 98.0%, while SNNs reach comparable performance in the range of 97.2–98.0%. Layerwise analysis reveals structured sparsity – low firing in early layers (4–9%), moderate firing in intermediate layers (12–18%), and dense firing in the deeper layers (∼50%). When efficiency is measured using sparsity-aware synaptic operations (SynOps), SNNs at T = 1–2 require only 24–52% of ANN operations while maintaining similar accuracy, whereas T =8 nearly doubles the cost without further gains. Our findings highlight two key insights: (1) moderate timesteps (T = 2–4) provide the best balance between accuracy and computational efficiency, and (2) SNNs offer a promising path toward energy-efficient AI on neuromorphic platforms such as Intel Loihi and SpiNNaker. This benchmark establishes a reproducible reference for the ANN-to-SNN comparison and sets the stage for future studies on larger datasets, advanced architectures, and direct hardware energy measurements.

title: Social Bridges to Technology: Social Influences on Older Adults' Use of Technology
authors: Yair Cabrera Menendez, Natalia Villanueva-Rosales, Ashley S. Bangert, Christian Ruiz-Ortiz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Older adults are more likely to experience social isolation. Smart Cities solutions offer promising opportunities to connect older adults with their communities and enhance their quality of life. Key to these solutions is the effective use of technology; however, the generational digital divide may hinder older adults' engagement with and adoption of technology-driven innovations. Community efforts to include older adults can help bridge this divide and foster social connectedness among older adults. This work presents our efforts toward investigating the external social factors that influence the learning and adoption of technology by older adults in a bicultural population. Our findings suggest a significant social influence on whether older adults use technology, the type of technology they use, and their intention to continue using it in the future. Based on these insights, we offer recommendations for the development of Smart Cities solutions and other efforts that foster older adults' learning and adoption of technology to connect with their community. These recommendations can support aging-friendly cities that enhance older adults' active participation, therefore increasing their social connectedness and improving their overall well-being.

title: Large-Signal Stability Analysis of Grid-Connected VSC: A Review
authors: Ziyu Fu, Zimo Zhao, Wenhao Tong, Zhiyuan Wang, Lujie Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the increase of the penetration of renewable energy, the dynamics and stability of power system is altered by grid-connected voltage source converters (VSCs) in a comprehensive and profound way. This paper overviews the large-signal stability problem which is closely related to the nonlinear dynamics of the synchronization unit of the converters. Firstly, two kinds of instability mechanism, loss of equilibrium point and transient synchronization instability, are revealed. Secondly, the large-signal modeling methods of two types of control strategies, grid-following and grid-forming controls, are reviewed. Thirdly, the large-signal stability analysis methods are summarized, including their pros and cons. Finally, the possible directions for future research are prospected.

title: Teaching Power Swing in Low-Inertia Systems via Didactic Demonstrations in ATP/ATPDraw
authors: J. P. Sampaio, F. V. Lopes, L. C. Grilo, A. A. Cruz
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This paper provides a practical guide to study the effects of inertia reduction on transient stability and power swing behavior in power systems, with the aim of improving training initiatives on such a topic. Instead of presenting only theoretical results, didactic demonstrations are presented by using the IEEE 9-bus test system modeled in the Alternative Transients Program (ATP)/ATPDraw. Details on procedures required to reproduce the presented experiments are described, including: (i) identification of the critical fault clearing time, (ii) observation of stable and unstable power swing transitions under inertia variation, (iii) evaluation of frequency response and Rate of Change of Frequency (RoCoF), and (iv) analysis of apparent impedance trajectories in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R-X$</tex> plane. Details on the proposed simulations are provided, and guidelines to interpret the outputs are presented. The obtained results prove that the presented didactic cases cover most important training aspects related to fault response of low-inertia systems, illustrating the implications in terms of stability and protection challenges.

title:
Checkerboard-Guided Diffusion Enhancement with Improved U
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    -Net for Underwater Crack Segmentation
authors: Jun Li, Wentao Li, Ziyan Zhao, Zejian Ding, Sisi Zhu, Xinyu Li, Yang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Underwater crack detection is a critical task for maintaining the structural integrity of hydraulic and marine infrastructures. However, real-world underwater images often suffer from severe degradation due to dynamic motion blur, turbidity-related visibility degradation, and heterogeneous illumination conditions, which significantly impairs segmentation performance. To address these issues, this work proposes a two-stage underwater crack detection framework that integrates a checkerboard-guided diffusion-based enhancement (CDE) method with an improved U<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-Net segmentation network (SE-U<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2-</sup>Net). The CDE method introduces high-contrast structural priors into the diffusion process, effectively enhancing crack edge visibility and structural contrast. The SE-U<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>Net further incorporates cross-channel attention and a local soft-thresholding mechanism to improve boundary sensitivity and suppress noise. Extensive experiments conducted on real-world underwater datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. Our method achieves superior Recall (0.790) and Average Precision (0.763) among all compared models, with only 4.09M parameters for the segmentation model. Compared with mainstream methods including DeepLabV3+, Mask R-CNN, U-Net, and SegNet, the proposed framework exhibits superior robustness and segmentation completeness under complex underwater conditions, showing strong potential for practical engineering applications and deployment.

title: Main Differences Between IEC 62305:2024 and ABNT NBR 5419:2025
authors: Hélio Eiji Sueta, Jobson Modena, José Barbosa Oliveira, Danilo Ferreira de Souza, Roberto Zilles
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: This study compares the international standards IEC 62305:2024 and the Brazilian standards ABNT NBR 5419:2025; both focused on lightning protection. The study covers the four parts that comprise each set of standards, identifying key conceptual, structural, and methodological differences. The analysis addresses discrepancies in terminology, types of losses and damage, risk assessment criteria, testing requirements, thunderstorm warning systems (TWS), and component specifications, among other aspects. The research also highlights the historical development of lightning protection standards in Brazil and internationally, contextualizing ABNT’s normative decisions considering IEC guidelines. Based on the systematic comparison, the study concludes that although NBR 5419 is based in IEC 62305, it reflects an approach tailored to Brazilian conditions, incorporating specific elements such as lightning density maps by the municipality and additional normative annexes. This study aims to support professionals and institutions in practically interpreting and applying updated design, inspection, and certification standards.

title: Research on the Characteristics of DC Series Arc Faults in Photovoltaic Systems
authors: Manruo Yin, Tao Wen, Zhiyuan Sha, Qifan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: DC arc faults are a common type of failure in photovoltaic (PV) systems, posing significant risks of severe safety incidents. This paper constructs an experimental platform for DC series arc faults and systematically investigates the effects of different electrode materials, circuit currents, and electrode gap distances on arc characteristics. Experimental results demonstrate that stainless steel electrodes generate higher high-frequency pulse amplitudes in fault currents and voltages compared to copper, brass, and aluminum electrodes. Under low-current conditions, arc voltages and currents exhibit stronger high-frequency components, while increased arc stability at high currents elevates detection difficulty. Larger gap distances correlate with higher amplitude high-frequency components in both arc voltage and current. By enhancing the Nottingham model through the integration of gap distance parameters, this study establishes a volt-ampere characteristic model for DC series discharge in brass electrodes. These findings provide critical support for developing multi-feature fusion arc fault detection algorithms in PV systems. The proposed model enables effective simulation of DC arc faults in photovoltaic applications, offering substantial engineering value for enhancing the safety of renewable energy power systems.

title: CVaR-Based Optimal Scheduling of Pumped-Storage Hydropower Plants Participating in Day-Ahead Energy and Ancillary Service Markets
authors: Yanbo Ding, Yang Li, Feng Wu, Yuzhe Chen, Linjun Shi
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Pumped storage hydropower plants (PSHP) are characterized by rapid response capabilities and low operating costs as power storage systems, allowing PSHP not only to participate in DA energy spot market, but also to remain highly competitive as an independent entity in the ancillary services market, especially in regulation service market. However, when participating in multiple electricity markets, improper scheduling of reserve may lead to violation of reservoir volume constraints when it is deployed in real time because of the inherent reservoir capacity limitations, finally rendering non-dispatchability. This paper proposes an optimal scheduling strategy of PSHP with variable speed (VS) turbine-pump units to bid in multiple electricity markets to maximum expected total revenues, considering the uncertainties of price forecasting. Further, several models with diverse volume constraints are proposed to fit different risk preferences of the operator. Finally, the schemes and expected income of the models are shown in the case study, while the dispatch security of them are verified through an out-of-sample test.

title: Validation of the eMMC Interface Through SI Simulations
authors: Andrei-Marius Silaghi, Catalin Pescari, Andrei Sirbu, Aldo De Sabata, Marius-Flavius Cioanca
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: The embedded MultiMediaCard (eMMC) interface is widely used in embedded systems for its compact size, low power consumption, and high data throughput. As operating frequencies increase, ensuring signal integrity (SI) and accurate timing becomes essential for system reliability. This study compares eMMC interface simulations across multiple vendors using Parallel Link Designer (PLD) tool from MATLAB and CST PCB Studio (CST). Key focus areas include waveform distortion, impedance mismatches, crosstalk, and timing constraints. PLD is further employed for setup/hold margin analysis, delay evaluation, and eye diagram assessment. Results highlight each tools strengths and limitations in modeling high-speed digital signals and propose design improvements to enhance signal integrity and timing compliance in eMMC-based printed circuit board (PCB) systems.

title: Optimizing Li-Ion Battery Pack Preconditioning for Small Urban Mobility Vehicles Using Thermo-Electric Heaters
authors: Rajmond Jánó, Adelina Ioana Ilieş, Alexandra Fodor
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: The paper explores methods for preconditioning Li-ion battery packs in small urban mobility vehicles with the aid of thermo-electric heaters (TEH). The goal is to reduce to a minimum the number of TEHs used, while maintaining the same preconditioning efficiency and also keep the temperature difference between cells within an acceptable range. Several different TEH placements are analyzed and compared in order to choose the most cost and energy efficient one.

title: A Multi-Strategy Grey Wolf Optimization Algorithm for Multi-Uav Path Planning in Complex Environments
authors: Xingyu Wu, Junxu Cheng, Kehao Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) require efficient path planning to ensure safe navigation in complex environments. However, traditional algorithms often struggle with the challenges of 3D multi-UAV scenarios, leading to suboptimal trajectories, prolonged flight time, and increased collision risks. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a multi-strategy grey wolf optimization (MSGWO) algorithm, which improves upon the conventional grey wolf optimization (GWO) by incorporating chaotic initialization, dynamic parameter adjustment, an elite solution pool, and hybrid mutation operators. Experimental results in 3D multi-UAV path planning scenarios—considering constraints such as flight distance, turning radius, and collision avoidance—demonstrate that MSGWO outperforms GWO, improved multi-objective particle swarm optimization algorithm (MOIPSO), and improved sine cosine algorithm (ISCA), exhibiting faster convergence, safer trajectories, and enhanced cost efficiency. These findings confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Transformation of the Bulgarian Electricity Sector in The Context of Industry 5.0
authors: Zhulieta Mihaylova, Svetlana Dimitrakieva, Marina Marinova-Stoyanova
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: The use of artificial intelligence capabilities and close, sustainable cooperation between humans and machines are at the heart of the industrial transformation that is coming on a global scale and the main focus of Industry 5.0. The electricity sector in Bulgaria faces significant challenges related to the increasingly widespread use of renewable energy sources. It is predicted that the share of electricity production from renewable sources as a percentage of gross domestic consumption in 2050 will be 32%. The aim of the report is to systematize the opportunities and challenges that Industry 5.0 presents in the process of transforming energy companies in Bulgaria.

title: Lightweight and Privacy-Preserving Authentication in IoV Systems using FIDO2: An Overview
authors: Rohit Kumar, Chittaranjan Mandal, Jagdish Chandra Patni, Priyanka Basak, Poorva Agrawal, Soubhagya Ranjan Mallick
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The Internet of Vehicles (IoV) that provides improved connectivity, safety, and intelligence to contemporary transportation networks. However, these benefits are heavily dependent on secure and efficient authentication, considering the real-time communication requirements and the diversity of participating entities such as vehicles, roadside infrastructure, and backend services. This work systematically analyzes the authentication methods for the Internet of Vehicles (IoV) and discusses major issues including security, privacy, and system performance. Emphasis is placed on the FIDO2 authentication standard and its ability to achieve lightweight anonymous attacker-resilient authentication in vehicular networks. Different approaches are analyzed in terms of the effectiveness of countering anonymity, computing overhead, replay, man-in-the-middle impersonation attacks, and identity theft. The purpose of this research is to encourage the development of flexible and dependable IoV authentication solutions based on new technologies like FIDO2.

title: Evaluation and Mitigation of Backscattering in a Co-60 Gamma Radiation Facility
authors: Pedro Martín-Holgado, Amor Romero-Maestre, José De-Martín-Hernández, Yolanda Morilla
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: This paper presents the test method used to evaluate backscattering in TID tests for space electronics, comparing theoretical and experimental dose-depth curves. It is shown how the ad hoc lead-aluminum filter box mitigates backscattering.

title: On the Energy Efficient UAV-Assisted Data Collection in Remote Sensing Applications
authors: Xiangyang Peng, Xiaolong Lan, Qingchun Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: In many IoT applications, numerous sensors are deployed across monitoring areas to perform various environmental or target monitoring tasks. However, due to power consumption limit, these sensors often possess limited long-range communication capabilities, rendering them incapable of meeting wide-area networking requirements. Consequently, traditional wireless sensor network technologies become inadequate for comprehensive data collection tasks. Due to high mobility and flexibility, unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-assisted wireless sensor network has emerged as an effective paradigm for data acquisition. In this paper, we focused on energy efficient UAV-assisted data collection problem. Firstly, the total energy consumption minimization problem was formulated, which is shown to be a multiple traveling salesman problem (mTSP). Secondly, A spatial partitioning scheme based on genetic algorithm (GA) was then proposed to decompose the mTSP into multiple single traveling salesman problems (TSPs) to minimize both the number of UAVs and the total energy consumption. Simulation results are presented to show that, the proposed multi-UAV assisted data collection scheme can achieve a reasonable tradeoff between the required number of UAVs and the energy consumption, which makes it suitable for the energy efficient large-scale data collection task in many UAV assisted applications.

title: Robust Data-driven Control with Safety Constraints and Fault Detection
authors: Lingan Zhou, Wenjie Liu, Yifei Li, Jian Sun, Gang Wang, Lihua Xie
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: Direct data-driven control has emerged as a powerful alternative to traditional state-space model-based methods by directly learning control policies from data. Nevertheless, ensuring that control actions adhere to specific physical and safety constraints, a challenge often overlooked in existing direct data-driven approaches focused primarily on stability and robustness, is crucial for real-world deployment. This paper addresses this gap by designing a robust data-driven state feedback control law that enforces safety-critical state constraints. Utilizing robust control techniques, we transform pointwise-in-time state constraints into reachable set constraints and formulate a semi-definite program (SDP) based on noisy input-state measurements. Additionally, recognizing that various system variations and environmental disturbances can be modeled as process noise, we propose to maximize the noise tolerance of the system through a data-driven SDP, thereby enhancing resilience against operational uncertainties. To further ensure operational safety, we develop a state estimator-based fault detector that leverages noisy closed-loop state data to trigger alarms during abnormal system operation. Finally, a numerical example is provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed safe data-driven control approach.

title: RRAM-Based Spectral-Domain Convolution Accelerator for Reliable and Energy-Efficient CNN Inference
authors: Jianan Wen, Andrea Baroni, Christian Wenger, Milos Krstic, Leticia Maria Bolzani Pöhls
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: The growing computational demands of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have motivated the use of spectral-domain inference as an alternative to costly spatial-domain convolutions. In this work, we propose a resistive RAM (RRAM)-based spectral-domain convolutional layer that exploits in-memory computing (IMC) for low energy consumption and high parallelism. Both the 2-D Fourier transform and the elementwise multiplications are directly executed on RRAM crossbar arrays, while Hermitian symmetry is leveraged to further enhance the energy efficiency of the transform and subsequent spectral processing. To ensure robustness, the measured RRAM device data are incorporated into system-level simulations to evaluate inference accuracy under the impact of device variability. Furthermore, we introduce a layer-wise mapping framework that adaptively selects between spatial- and spectral-domain execution based on the tradeoff between energy efficiency and accuracy. Simulation results show that the proposed design achieves up to a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.18\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> improvement in energy efficiency across various convolutional layer configurations compared with the spatial-domain design. For VGG-8 on CIFAR-100, the proposed architecture with the layer-wise mapping scheme reduces the energy-delay product (EDP) by 45% while incurring negligible accuracy loss. This work presents the first complete RRAM-based spectral-domain convolutional layer that accounts for device variability, providing a promising solution for edge CNN inference.

title: Collaborative Drill Alignment in Surgical Robotics
authors: Daniel Larby, Joshua Kershaw, Matthew Allen, Fulvio Forni
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: Robotic assistance allows surgeries to be reliably and accurately executed while still under the direct supervision of the surgeon, combining the strengths of robotic technology with the surgeon’s expertise. This article describes a robotic system designed to assist in surgical procedures by implementing a virtual drill guide. The system integrates virtual-fixture functionality using a novel virtual-mechanism controller with additional visual feedback. The controller constrains the tool to the desired axis, while allowing axial motion to remain under the surgeon’s control. Compared to prior virtual-fixture approaches—which primarily perform pure energy-shaping and damping injection with linear springs and dampers–our controller uses a virtual prismatic joint to which the robot is constrained by nonlinear springs, allowing us to easily shape the dynamics of the system. We detail the calibration procedures required to achieve sufficient precision and describe the implementation of the controller. We apply this system to a veterinary procedure: drilling for transcondylar screw placement in dogs. The results of the trials on 3D-printed bone models demonstrate sufficient precision to perform the procedure and suggest improved angular accuracy and reduced exit translation errors compared to patient-specific guides (PSGs). Discussion and future improvements follow.

title: WSDBS: Workflow Scheduling with Dynamic Bandwidth Slicing in Resource-Constrained Edge Computing Environment
authors: Yuebin Huang, Weiwei Lin, Fang Shi, Haotong Zhang, Simon Fong, Bin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: In resource-constrained edge computing, the execution efficiency of workflow applications is significantly affected by bandwidth contention, especially during data transmissions between dependent tasks. However, existing workflow scheduling studies often struggle to optimize transmission delay effectively, whereas bandwidth slicing offers promising potential by leveraging the dynamic nature of bandwidth resources. To address this issue, we propose Workflow Scheduling with Dynamic Bandwidth Slicing (WSDBS), a novel scheduling algorithm that integrates bandwidth slicing into the workflow execution process. By introducing a dual-prediction strategy, WSDBS estimates the availability of both computational and bandwidth resources on servers, facilitating efficient task scheduling decisions under transmission uncertainty. Moreover, a novel transmission urgency metric is developed, which is derived from both link load and transmission criticality. This metric guides bandwidth slicing for the dynamic allocation of server-side bandwidth resources, ultimately alleviating contention among concurrent transmissions. Extensive experiments based on real-world Alibaba cluster traces show that WSDBS consistently improves scheduling efficiency, reducing the average makespan by 10.87%-14.44% over state-of-the-art baselines. These results validate its effectiveness in alleviating bandwidth contention and improving scheduling performance in edge computing environments.

title: Production of multi-megagauss ultrahigh magnetic fields using destructive magnets for material science
authors: Yasuhiro H. Matsuda, Yuto Ishii, Xu-Guang Zhou, Hiroaki Hayashi, Hironobu Sawabe
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: An ultrahigh magnetic field in the multi-megagauss field (mMGF) range (100 - 1000 T) is a potential tool to explore undeveloped science disciplines. The recent development of measurement techniques in material science in the mMGF is considerable. It implies that the development of ultrahigh magnetic field science can expand not only for materials but also for other subjects, such as chemical reactions or biological systems. Destruction of the coil during the mMGF production makes the measurement a single-shot measurement. Reproducibility of the magnetic field waveform on the microsecond time scale is the key technology that ensures the high reliability of the experimental results. The current status of the waveform reproducibility of the mMGF generated by the single-turn coil and the electromagnetic flux compression is reported. The current status of the available measurements for material science in the mMGF is also introduced.

title: DynaKG: Dynamic Knowledge Graph Attention with Learnable Temporal Decay for Recommendation
authors: Bwalya Chomba, Patrick Mukala, Nicanor Mayumu, Saif Ur Rehman KHAN
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Knowledge graph-based recommendation systems excel at capturing semantic relationships but struggle to model temporal dynamics in evolving user preferences, which is a critical limitation for real-world applications where user behaviors and item popularity change continuously over time. The core challenge lies in existing approaches that treat knowledge graphs as static structures and fail to capture the temporal evolution, sequential dependencies, and scalability demands of dynamic systems. We propose a Dynamic Knowledge Graph attention network (DynaKG) that addresses these limitations through three key innovations: 1) learnable temporal decay mechanisms with context-specific parameters that adapt to different node and edge types, 2) hybrid Fourier-positional temporal encoding that captures both periodic and aperiodic patterns, and 3) time-aware contrastive learning with incremental updates that reduces computational overhead by 34% while maintaining quality. We provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence properties of the temporal attention mechanism and empirically demonstrate that DynaKG substantially outperforms state-of-the-art baselines across three datasets: 8.0% improvement in Recall@20 on Yelp, 9.0% on Amazon-Book, and 7.0% on MovieLens-10M, while achieving 3.6 times parameter efficiency and providing interpretable temporal explanations.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning-based UAV Base Station Deployment for Cache-Enabled UBS-Assisted Cellular Networks
authors: Qiangfeng Zhu, Jun Zheng, Abbas Jamalipour
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle base stations (UBSs) are able to assist a cellular IoT network to provide content delivery service for ground users. This paper studies the UBS deployment problem in a cache-enabled UBS-assisted cellular network. The UBS deployment problem is first formulated as a joint optimization problem with an objective to minimize the average content delivery delay of all users in a service area. We decompose the problem into three sub-problems: content caching deployment, position deployment, and BS association, and propose a multi-agent proximal policy optimization (MAPPO)-based UBS deployment algorithm to solve the sub-problems. Specifically, the proposed algorithm uses edge agents on UBSs and a two-layer MAPPO algorithm including a cache layer and a position layer to solve the content caching deployment sub-problem and the UBS position deployment sub-problem. Meanwhile, it uses a central agent in a core network and a proximal policy optimization (PPO) algorithm to solve the BS association sub-problem. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed UBS deployment algorithm can significantly improve the network performance in terms of the average content delivery delay and the cache hit ratio of all users in the network.

title: DiffuSaL: Diffusion-based Scene and Label Space Extension for Domain Generalization in Driving-scene Semantic Segmentation_supp1-3646942.pdf
authors: Noha Nekamiche
publish: N/A
abstract: Generalizing to unseen scenes presents a significant challenge to semantic segmentation models, as it aims to replicate the human adaptability. Existing deep learning models still suffer from performance degradation on unseen scenarios due to the domain shift problem, which arises from differences in data statistical distribution between the training and unseen testing domains. In this work, we introduce DiffuSaL (Diffusion-based Scene and Label Space Extension for Domain Generalization), a framework designed to improve the generalization capability of semantic segmentation models learned solely from synthetic data without access to real target-domain samples. DiffuSaL synthesizes a set of pseudo-target samples termed CD-Driss (Controlled Diffusion–based Driving Scene Segmentation). Unlike existing data synthesis approaches, our method not only produces realistic scene images but also begins by generating semantic label maps using text prompts. These label maps are then employed alongside text prompts in controllable stable diffusion to guide the scene generation process. Thanks to this label generation strategy, we can ensure that the resulting masks exhibit balanced class presence, preserving a more uniform label distribution. To further enrich diversity, CD-Driss leverages a text-prompting strategy that explicitly controls variations in weather, lighting, and traffic conditions. Integrating the CD-Driss dataset into a meta-learning–based domain generalization framework enhances robustness to domain shifts and improves performance on unseen target domains. Our approach surpasses state-of-the-art performance by 8.78% mIoU for GTA → (Cityscapes, BDD, and Mapillary) and 9.23% mIoU for SYNTHIA → (Cityscapes, BDD, and Mapillary), underscoring the effectiveness of diffusion-based synthetic data and controlled label-space expansion for domain generalization.

title: Contrastive Federated Learning for Non-IID and Imbalanced Data in Computational Social Systems
authors: Kaixiang Yang, Huijun Chen, Wuxing Chen, Chien-Ming Chen, Song Sun, Saru Kumari, Cheng Qiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: In the era of computational social systems (CSS), where AI is increasingly embedded in critical domains such as public services, healthcare, and social governance, concerns about system vulnerabilities have become paramount. Federated learning (FL) offers a promising solution by enabling privacy-preserving and secure AI model training in real-world applications. However, traditional FL approaches often assume that client data is either imbalanced or non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID), whereas in practice, these issues frequently coexist. In such complex scenarios, minority classes may appear only on a small subset of clients, significantly degrading global model performance and convergence. In this article, we propose a novel FL framework designed to tackle the intertwined challenges of data imbalance and non-IID data by a principled, decoupled approach. Unlike existing methods that address these issues in isolation, our approach introduces three synergistic innovations, each operating at a different level of the FL system. At the data level, a global rebalancing mechanism employs a privacy-preserving modified Z-score to rectify class imbalance. At the client level, a distribution-aware clustering strategy groups participants based on data subspace similarity. At the feature level, a novel contrastive loss function, leveraging the effective number of samples, simultaneously mitigates local imbalance and model drift. This cohesive framework ensures that interventions at each level reinforce each other, leading to robust performance. Extensive experiments show that FedScFc outperforms state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Sailor Shift and the Spread of Oceanus Folk: A Visual Analysis
authors: Makena Lu, Hafiza Rabail Mushtaq, Zeyuan Yu, Daniel A. Keim, Lucas Joos, Julius Rauscher
publish: 2025 IEEE Visual Analytics Science and Technology Challenge (VAST Challenge)
abstract: This paper presents a visual analytics system developed for the VAST Challenge 2025 Mini-Challenge 1 (MC1). Leveraging a comprehensive knowledge graph, our interactive system analyzes musical influences, collaborations, and genre evolution through the career of artist Sailor Shift and the Oceanus Folk genre. The system integrates network graphs, timelines, and sankey diagrams to facilitate exploration of artist relationships, the temporal spread of Oceanus Folk, and identification of emerging talent. Architecturally, it combines a Neo4j graph database, FastAPI backend, and React frontend, providing a robust platform for data-driven insights tailored to assist journalist Silas Reed.

title: Large Language Models for Beam Prediction Under the mmWave Massive MIMO Hybrid-field Channels
authors: Jie Yang, Wanchen Hu, Shitong Bai, Shuangyang Li, Siyao Li, Kai Wan, Xin Wang
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: Millimeter-wave (mmWave) technology is a key enabling technology for next-generation wireless communications. However, beam prediction (BP) in millimeter-wave massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems is challenging in high mobility scenarios, especially in non-stationary time-varying hybrid-field channels. In this case, the number of multi paths, time delay, angle of departure (AoD), Doppler offset, and the propagation distance vary simultaneously at different time instants. In this paper, we introduce a BP framework leveraging generative large language models (LLM), specifically GPT-2. The proposed BP-GPT approach utilizes historical channel state information (CSI) to predict optimal beamforming vectors that maximize spectral efficiency in these non-stationary time-varying hybrid-field conditions. Extensive simulations demonstrate the superior performance and robustness of BP-GPT over conventional neural network-based methods.

title: Weak Pareto Boundary: A Critical Challenge for Evolutionary Multi-Objective Optimization_supp1-3646963.pdf
authors: Zhenkun Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: The weak Pareto boundary (WPB) refers to a boundary in the objective space of a multi-objective optimization problem, characterized by weak Pareto optimality rather than Pareto optimality. The WPB brings severe challenges to multiobjective evolutionary algorithms (MOEAs), as it may mislead the algorithms into finding dominance-resistant solutions (DRSs), i.e., solutions that excel on some objectives but severely underperform on the others, thereby missing Pareto-optimal solutions. Although the severe impact of the WPB on MOEAs has been recognized, a systematic and detailed analysis remains lacking. To fill this gap, this paper studies the attributes of the WPB. In particular, the category of a WPB, as an attribute derived from its weakly Pareto-optimal property, is theoretically analyzed. The analysis reveals that the dominance resistance degrees of DRSs induced by different categories of WPBs exhibit distinct asymptotic growth rates as the DRSs in the objective space approach the WPBs, where a steeper asymptotic growth rate indicates a greater hindrance to MOEAs. Beyond that, experimental studies are conducted on various new test problems to investigate the impact of WPB’s attributes. The experimental results demonstrate consistency with our theoretical findings. Experiments on other attributes show that the performance of an MOEA is highly sensitive to some attributes. Overall, no existing MOEAs can comprehensively address challenges brought by these attributes.

title: Fine-Grained 3D Reconstruction of Urban Building Façades via Window-Driven Semantic Parsing
authors: Yuejin Li, Junhong He, Shiyaxuan Ye, Jian Yang, Shijie Zhang, Zicheng Qin
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: With the increasing demands of urban digitalization and the rise of low-altitude economy applications, building façade models are expected to evolve from basic geometric representations to detailed structures enriched with fine-grained semantic and structural information. This study proposes a fine-grained workflow for 3D modeling of urban building façades, integrating three key components: window detection and reconstruction, floor segmentation, and texture optimization. Specifically, (1) we develop a Bidirectional Adaptive Feature Fusion Network (BiFusion-Net) that robustly detects window positions and geometries by enhancing multi-scale feature fusion and semantic representation, effectively handling façade complexity and small target variations; (2) we reconstruct missing windows based on alignment patterns and design a rule-driven algorithm that leverages the vertical distribution of the completed window set to achieve automated and consistent floor segmentation; and (3) we implement a texture optimization module that enhances visual realism by correcting distortions and harmonizing façade colors through segmentation and inpainting techniques. The proposed approach was validated on a large-scale real-world 3D modeling project in Dangshan County. It enables the rapid generation of semantically enriched and visually realistic façade models at city scale, supporting applications such as drone-based logistics, emergency planning, and smart city operations. Experimental results show that the workflow achieves up to 97.38% F1-score in window detection, delivering superior performance compared with mainstream detectors. The optimized façades demonstrate improved visual consistency, as over 90% of wall regions exhibit clearer and more uniform color distributions. In the real-world project, the final reconstructed models achieve horizontal accuracy better than 0.3 m and vertical accuracy better than 0.2 m, fully meeting the standards for fine-grained urban 3D modeling.

title: Observer-Based Adaptive Neural Sliding Mode Control of Fuzzy Systems With Sojourn-Probability-Based Multimode Attacks
authors: Bin Zhang, Weiling Bao, Jun Cheng, Leszek Rutkowski, Dan Zhang, Huaicheng Yan, Yuanyuan Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: This article addresses the challenges posed by multimode denial of service (DoS) and deception attacks in observer-based sliding mode control (SMC) for fuzzy nonlinear systems. A novel multimode DoS attack model is introduced, incorporating time-varying sojourn probabilities to provide a more accurate and computationally efficient representation of the stochastic nature of these attacks. This model overcomes the limitations of traditional Markov-based models by capturing dynamic attack behaviors. Deception attacks are modeled as unbounded nonlinear functions, and adaptive neural networks (NNs) are employed to approximate their complex behaviors, significantly reducing their detrimental impact on system stability. A fuzzy sliding surface is designed based on the switching rule for sojourn probabilities, and an observer-based SMC law is proposed to ensure the mean square estimation upper bound of the fuzzy nonlinear systems, guaranteeing stability despite the presence of cyberattacks. Finally, the validity and superiority of the proposed control strategy are demonstrated through a tunnel diode circuit model.

title: A 138-GHz Multimode Super-Regenerative Oscillator Radar Sensor With Quench Control in 70-nm GaAs pHEMT Technology
authors: Donglin Gao, Chih-Ju Wu, Jung-Tao Chung, Shuping Li, Austin Ying-Kuang Chen, Chung-Tse Michael Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a 138-GHz high-sensitivity multimode super-regenerative oscillator (SRO) radar sensor implemented in a 70-nm gallium arsenide (GaAs) pseudomorphic high electron mobility transistor (pHEMT) technology. Compared to conventional Doppler radar or self-injection-locked (SIL) radar sensors, the proposed SRO design leverages periodic quench signals to trigger transient oscillation cycles, enabling substantial gain during the build-up phase for superior motion sensitivity. The sensor integrates a substrate-integrated waveguide (SIW) monopole antenna and analog envelope detection circuitry, achieving low power consumption and reduced system complexity. Through comprehensive experiments, the proposed sensor demonstrates robust vital sign detection—including respiration and heartbeat—at distances up to 1.4 m. Parametric analyses reveal that square-wave quench signals, low quench frequencies, and moderate duty cycles (e.g., 50%) yield optimal performance. Compared to its SIL counterpart implemented in the identical GaAs pHEMT technology, the SRO radar achieves >26-dB improvement. These results validate the multimode SRO-based radar architecture as a promising solution for miniaturized, high-sensitivity, noncontact biomedical sensing in indoor and clinical environments.

title: Effectiveness of the Biol Disinfection Process with Ultraviolet Light
authors: Rolando A. Mora D., José G. Navarro, Fernando González Q.
publish: 2024 International Congress of Science and Technology for Sustainable Development (CITDES)
abstract: El Nazareno Processing Plant of Agropecuaria El Buen Pastor, S.A. takes advantage of the organic waste from the poultry processing that they carry out in their facilities through a biodigester, which breaks down the matter into products with energy potential. The liquid effluent resulting from this process, known as biol, couldn't be used as a fertilizer due to its polluting nature. The objective of this project was to verify the efficiency of the disinfection treatment with UV lights used in wastewater in this liquid, which would be a promising alternative for its use in the company. The physicochemical and microbiological characteristics of the biol without treatment and disinfected were analyzed, where improvements in the parameters evaluated were evidenced according to referenced studies and current regulations, confirming the effectiveness of disinfection by this method. At the same time, the possible costs and benefits the implementation of said system within the company could bring were reflected.
