title: AI Literacy as Living Heritage: Grounding Machine Learning in Cultural Ritual with the Tri Hita Karana Compass
authors: Andre Uhl, Cokorda Pramartha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: As generative AI systems increasingly match human performance in tasks central to formal education, they present an opportunity to reexamine longstanding asymmetries in knowledge transmission—particularly the marginalization of context-specific, socially embedded knowledge associated with intangible cultural heritage. This paper proposes a relational approach to AI literacy that supports the continuity and adaptive evolution of intangible cultural heritage in the digital age. Drawing on the Balinese framework of Tri Hita Karana, we introduce a hybrid methodology that situates machine learning within cultural ritual, integrating participatory action research with generative dialogue and machine teaching. Rather than treating intangible cultural heritage as static content to be preserved, we frame it as a dynamic pedagogy enabling value negotiation between human and machine learning systems across intergenerational baselines. Our implementation prototypes include a mobile machine teaching hub, a knowledge repository, and an intelligent interface co-developed with temple-based learning communities in Bali. Together, these components form a socio-technical infrastructure for epistemic co-creation, positioning human–AI interfaces as vital sites for the transmission—and transformation—of cultural memory. This approach presents a replicable model integrating culturally grounded pedagogy with AI development, offering new directions for inclusive, place-based, and pluralistic approaches to intelligent system design.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Prediction and Analysis of Mental Health Risks Among University Students
authors: Soontarin Nupap, Hnin Oo Wai, Nyein Nyein Kyaw, Zaw Shin Thant, Nilubon Kurubanjerdjit
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: University students increasingly face psychological challenges driven by academic, social, and lifestyle pressures—issues that have intensified in the post-pandemic landscape. This study proposes a machine learning-based approach to early identification of mental health risks among undergraduates, utilising non-clinical behavioural data collected through structured surveys at a Thai university. The dataset, comprising 266 entries, was enhanced using SMOTE to balance class distribution and improve model robustness. Three classification algorithms—Random Forest, XGBoost, and Deep Learning—were trained and assessed using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. XGBoost delivered the highest performance, achieving an F1-score of 83.90% and accuracy of 90.60%. Beyond classification, correlation analysis identified key behavioural and psychological predictors of mental health, while K-means clustering uncovered distinct subgroups among at-risk students. The findings underscore the potential of interpretable, data-driven methods to support proactive mental health strategies in educational environments.

title: Performance Evaluation of Meteosat Third Generation Lightning Imager in Detecting Lightning Discharges
authors: Eren Gedik, Ehsan Mansouri, Hannes Kohlmann, Wolfgang Schulz, Marcos Rubinstein
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: We present an evaluation of the performance of Meteosat Lightning Imager (MTG-LI) in detecting lightning flashes. To achieve this, we applied a Bayesian relative detection efficiency (RDE) analysis using the European ground-based lightning detection network (ALDIS/BLIDS) as reference. The analysis involved pairing each ALDIS/BLIDS stroke/pulse with corresponding MTG-LI level-2 groups. Between July 2024 and January 2025, MTG-LI detected 50 to 54% of groups and 62 to 63% of flashes relative to ALDIS/BLIDS in datasets covering nationwide data (Switzerland and Austria) and dominated by downward cloud-to-ground and intracloud flashes. For context, the International Space Station Lightning Imaging Sensor, assessed with identical matching criteria, reaches only 36.5% group-level and 48.4% flash-level RDE. In regions near tall structures such as the Säntis (2502 m) and Gaisberg (1287 m) towers, where upward flashes dominate, MTG-LI demonstrated significantly higher performance, detecting 68 to 70% of groups and 70 to 73% of flashes relative to ALDIS/BLIDS.

title: Research on Enhancing Cybersecurity Resilience in New Power Systems
authors: Tengyan Wang, Nige Li, Lu Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Driven by the energy internet and digital transformation, new power systems face increasingly complex cybersecurity threats. Their networked and intelligent characteristics pose significant challenges to traditional defense systems. This paper systematically analyzes the evolution of cybersecurity threats in new power systems, reveals the inherent limitations of traditional boundary protection, static rule databases, and single-point defense models, and proposes a cybersecurity protection framework centered on the “predict-defend-respond-recover” full-cycle resilience concept. By integrating active immune mechanisms, dynamic heterogeneous redundant architectures, and collaborative response technologies, a multi-layered protection system covering threat perception and prediction, dynamic defense, and resilient recovery is constructed. The critical supporting roles of cross-domain technologies such as privacy-preserving computation, neuro-symbolic systems, quantum encryption, and blockchain in enhancing resilience are elaborated. The study further outlines future directions from theoretical innovation, technological breakthroughs, and ecosystem collaboration, proposing strategic pathways including the establishment of quantitative resilience evaluation models, the promotion of human-machine collaborative intelligent operation paradigms, and the creation of cross-industry security standard ecosystems. These efforts provide systematic solutions for achieving the resilience goals of “defending against unknown threats and rapidly recovering from known attacks” in new power systems.

title: A Power System Fault Assessment Methodology from a Power-Based Perspective
authors: Jinghao Teng, Yuanyuan Sun, Na Song, Yanli Gan, Yahui Li, Xiaolei Hou
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To address the challenges in characterizing power system faults, this paper proposes a novel powerbased fault assessment methodology. First, building upon the instantaneous reactive power theory, the power decomposition framework is extended to unbalanced conditions, with a rigorous measurement methodology established. Second, critical parameters such as disturbance power and energy flow are defined as key metrics for evaluating power system faults. Finally, comprehensive analysis of fault identification, propagation, and localization is conducted from a power-based perspective. Results demonstrate that this methodology achieves precise fault localization and provides novel insights for fault assessment.

title: Vertical Ground Displacement Analysis and Threshold Identification using SNAP for Landslide Prediction in Kerala
authors: Aron Mathew Tom, Amarnad K M, K R Abhinand Babu, Shameem Ansar A, Suresh Francis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Amid uprising unpredictable deadly landslides, the current technology becomes standalone causing loss of lives and property in many areas. Leveraging the advanced capabilities of InSAR techniques and SNAP software, this study provides a new approach to landslide detection by using interferometric techniques, enhancing accuracy and efficiency in monitoring natural hazards. The main objective of this study is to boost the development of an automated landslide prediction system. By processing SAR data using interferometric techniques of the SNAP plugin, we generate displacement data, so that the model can be trained more effectively. Later can be integrated with the prediction software. The analysis revealed landslide parameter benchmarks including displacement and slope. Also, areas with ground displacement above respective benchmarks are prone to landslides. Second, areas with slopes greater than 25% can also potentially cause landslides. Findings suggest that the landslide-prone areas under this study should be given special preference, making it a no-development zone and proceeding with rehabilitation if needed, also authorities should take necessary steps to initiate more studies on this.

title: Secure Transmission Technology for Aviation Broadband Communication System
authors: Zhijun Wu, Minghui Sun, Tao Fang, Jin Lei, Meng Yue
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: As air transportation expands and present civil aviation communications systems reach their capacity limits in high-density locations, the requirement for new aeronautical communications technology becomes becoming increasingly important. Aviation broadband communication system (ABCS), as a key infrastructure for building the next generation air traffic control system, possess advantages such as low latency, high reliability, and large bandwidth to meet the growing demands of air transportation. However, these systems lack effective information security measures which pose security risks to ground-to-air data transmission. This paper proposes a secure transmission technology for ABCS based on the SM series cipher. The proposed approach utilizes SM4 for data encryption, SM3 for data integrity protection, and Timed Efficient Stream Loss-tolerant Authentication (TESLA) for message source authentication. The experimental results show that this scheme has faster encryption and decryption speeds, lower security overheads, and it can effectively resist the tampering attack, which meets the security requirements of ABCS.

title: Bridging AI and Wireless Networks: A Data-Centric Functional Perspective
authors: Zexu Li, Ang Li, Chengyu Liu, Jingyi Wang, Qingtian Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: The 6G era calls for deep convergence between wireless networks and artificial intelligence (AI), transforming the wireless network from a mere data pipe into an intelligent service platform. Data forms the bedrock of this convergence, yet today’s architectures suffer from data silos and interfaces that were not designed for AI workloads, limiting AI deployment. To address these gaps, we propose a data-driven AI-native wireless network (DAIWN) architecture that makes data a central part and positions it as the bridge between network and intelligence functions. Building on this architecture, we define a full-lifecycle data-management framework encompassing data preparation, utilization, exposure and security. We validate this framework in a radio-map-estimation scenario. Compared with a traditional dataset, the proposed data-curation pipeline lowers the mean absolute error from 15.1 dB to 7.7 dB—a 49 % reduction. These findings demonstrate that treating data as a native resource yields tangible gains for AI workloads and offers a practical blueprint for scalable, privacy-aware 6G networks.

title: WESH: Web-based Exploration of Stars and their History
authors: Andreas Hangg, Maximilian Opel, Jan de Boer, Daniel A. Keim, Lucas Joos, Julius Rauscher
publish: 2025 IEEE Visual Analytics Science and Technology Challenge (VAST Challenge)
abstract: The VAST Challenge 2025 presents a scenario in which music journalist Silas Reed investigates the evolution of Oceanus Folk and the career of Sailor Shift, an artist whose rise has brought global attention to a genre once confined to its island origins. To support this investigation, we developed WESH (Web-based Exploration of Stars and their History) a visual analytics system that combines knowledge-graph modeling with interactive visualizations of influence, collaboration, and genre dynamics. Our approach enables multifaceted analysis of artist trajectories and genre development over time. Through different views and temporal filtering, users can investigate patterns of collaboration, trace influence paths, and explore the changing role of Oceanus Folk within the wider music ecosystem.

title: LEO Constellation Design for Designated Interval Continuous Coverage over Targeted Regions
authors: Yiwen Cao, Runjie Zhang, Yanfeng Meng, Weizong Li, Zhenghu Liang, Jianming Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: To address the challenge of achieving short-duration continuous coverage over hotspot area during designated time periods, this paper proposes a quasi-common-ground-track constellation scheme based on Sun-synchronous repeating orbits. First, Sun-synchronous repeating orbit model is established under J<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> perturbation to determine the optimal satellite orbital altitude and inclination. Subsequently, a multi-satellite orbital parameter optimization model is established, applying a swarm intelligence optimization algorithm to maximize the Earth observation coverage. Finally, all satellites parameters are determined by applying the common ground track constraints. Simulation results demonstrate that this method can achieve continuous coverage of up to 10 minutes over a 20°×20° latitude-longitude area during designated daily time windows. The regional average coverage rate is 99.91% and the maximum revisit time is only 14.533s.

title: Exploring the Potential of Large Language Models in Grid-Scale High-Voltage Transformer-Less Battery Energy Storage Systems
authors: Yilin Liu, Xiqi Wu, Xu Cai, Fuwen Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the surge in new energy installation capacity, the coordination challenges between power generation, grid, and load, along with the risks of generationload imbalance, are becoming increasingly prominent. To address this challenge, both the installation scale and individual capacity of Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) are growing rapidly. Compared to traditional architectures, high-voltage transformer-less BESS offers advantages including larger single-unit capacity, fewer parallel devices, simplified control strategies, and faster dynamic response, making it particularly suitable for constructing hundred-megawatt-scale large storage systems. However, in highvoltage transformer-less systems, issues such as heterogeneity of massive battery clusters, temperature control, operational diversity, and control time-effectiveness pose higher requirements for cross-industry collaboration and researchers' information integration capabilities. In recent years, the rapid development of artificial intelligence, especially Large Language Models (LLMs), has brought new opportunities to solve these problems. LLMs have made significant progress in natural language processing and demonstrated strong potential for industry applications. In light of this, this paper proposes the development of a “Grid-level Large-capacity High-voltage Transformer-less Battery Energy Storage Large Model” for energy storage system scenarios. This model uses LLMs as its core engine, integrating key capabilities such as battery cluster topology modeling, operational state estimation, health monitoring, and control strategy optimization. It adopts a hybrid architecture design, combining the advantages of local vector retrieval and cloud-based large language models, providing examples for the application of large models in gridlevel large-capacity high-voltage transformer-less battery energy storage systems.

title: High-precision Magnetic Field Measurement using a Hall Sensor
authors: Siya Lozanova, Chavdar Roumenin, Martin Ralchev, Teodor Grakov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: High-precision magnetic field measurement can be realized using sensors based on the Hall effect. This study examines the operating principles of analog and digital Hall sensors measured through a specialized cryogenic measurement system, which provide an output signal proportional to the magnetic flux density. Particular emphasis is placed on their application in high-accuracy measurements, where the use of complex mathematical linearization models is not required. The advantages of this approach, including high precision, robustness, and straightforward integration into measurement systems, are analyzed. In addition, the use of a cryogenic system (Dexing DX- 3000 H) is presented, demonstrating the significant benefits of low-temperature operation, expressed in noise reduction and enhanced sensitivity.

title: Adaptive Learning Rate-Enhanced XGBoost for Smart Home Energy Forecasting with Solar Energy System Integration
authors: Banafshe Parizad, Ali Jamali, Hamid Khayyam
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Energy management in residential homes has become increasingly critical due to rising energy consumption and the integration of smart grid technologies. Accurate forecasting of household energy usage is essential for optimizing energy consumption, reducing costs, and enhancing grid stability. This paper proposes a novel Adaptive Learning Rate eXtreme Gradient Boosting (ALR-XGBoost) model for home energy forecasting, which dynamically adjusts learning rates to improve convergence. Unlike conventional XGBoost, which relies on a fixed learning rate, our approach modifies the learning rate for each sample based on the gradient (first-order derivative) and boosting iteration to accelerate convergence and prevent overfitting. The model is evaluated on real-world home energy datasets, incorporating solar generation data, enhancing prediction accuracy, and making it particularly useful for smart home energy management and demand response strategies. Experimental results demonstrate that ALR-XGBoost outperforms traditional methods, achieving lower error in Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) while improving the Coefficient of Determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) and enhancing generalization in forecasting dynamic energy patterns. By integrating sample-wise adaptive learning rates, our method improves the robustness of energy consumption forecasting, making it particularly valuable for smart home applications, demand response optimization, and sustainable energy management. This research advances energy analytics by enhancing the adaptability of machine learning models for forecasting fluctuating energy patterns in solar-integrated homes.

title: Attention-Enhanced Multi-Agent Safe Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Volt-VAR Control
authors: Yanlun Li, Xiaobo Dou, Xiangjun Quan, Kexin Zhang, Xiaotong Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: To realize real-time voltage/var control (VVC) in active distribution networks (ADNs), this paper proposes an attention-enhanced multi-agent safe reinforcement learning method for voltage regulation and loss reduction. Firstly, the VVC problem is formulated as a multi-agent constrained Markov decision process (MACMDP). The network is based on centralized training with decentralized execution (CTDE) framework and each zone has a set of networks to make decision. Then attention encoders are introduced to network for normalizing input space to improve learning performance. Considering the limitations of reinforcement learning in handling constraints, c is introduced to an interactive iteration mechanism is employed to derive the optimal reward under constraints. Finally, a classic 33-bus test system is used for validation, and the experimental results showed that the proposed algorithm can effectively assist agents in accomplishing VVC problem.

title: Reducing the Noise Impact in Field Measurements of Soil Electrical Properties
authors: Evgeniya Borozdina, Dmitry Kuklin
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: The results of field measurements of the frequency-dependent soil properties can be strongly influenced by different types of noise. Examples of such types of noise are galvanic voltage between the electrodes and stray currents. The work examines the different types of noise and provides recommendations to reduce their impact. Electrodes made of different materials were compared in the field conditions. It has been shown that the use of copper and copper-copper sulfate electrodes results in sufficiently low galvanic voltages. Copper electrodes are slightly more convenient for field measurements of soil properties, while copper-copper sulfate electrodes result in lower galvanic voltages. In addition, measurements with larger currents have demonstrated that the use of an additional amplifier is also an acceptable solution to reduce the noise impact.

title: Making Data Harder to Read: Visualizations that Intentionally Increase Time and Effort
authors: Leni Yang, Pierre Dragicevic, Yvonne Jansen
publish: 2025 IEEE Seventh Workshop on Visualization for Communication (VisComm)
abstract: This position paper questions the common prioritization of data visualization designs that minimize the time and effort required from viewers, particularly in the context of communicative visualizations. Our argument is grounded in observations of designs that deliberately increase reading time and physical effort. While decreasing efficiency, it enhances other communication purposes. We illustrate such approaches with three examples focused on communicating environmental issues. We then argue that this kind of design deserves more attention in the visualization community and conclude with future research opportunities.

title: Distributed Event-Triggered Control for Isolated AC-DC Hybrid Microgrids
authors: Zhaojie Yu, Xin Cai
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The power sharing of hybrid microgrids with limited communication is addressed by proposing a distributed secondary control strategy based on event-triggered communication mechanisms. In the AC and DC subnets of hybrid microgrids, communication occurs only when the event trigger conditions are satisfied, and the designed strategy utilizes interaction information at the triggering moment. Furthermore, the power sharing between AC subnet and DC subnet is carried out through interlinking converters (ICs), which adopt a bias-based control method. This method requires knowledge of any one distributed generator of the AC and DC subnet to achieve global power allocation. At last, simulation results are given to validate the proposed control.

title: Visual Tracking Control Method for Quadrotors with Delayed Output and Disturbance Based on Alternating Predictive Observer
authors: Liren Shao, Di Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper proposes a position-based visual servoing method, allowing quadrotors to track dynamic targets quickly. During the tracking process, only the sampled data output feedback can be used. The slow-sampling rate, output delay and disturbances received by the visual sensor also need to be considered. The limitation of the camera sampling frequency, on the one hand, leads to a decrease in the rate of data transmission, and on the other hand, it generates discrete outputs with time delay. A method with prediction function for the sampling system is needed because the theory of continuous systems is not applicable to this situation. In addition, the disturbance caused by the unknown platform movement and wind disturbance is also inevitable. To alleviate these problems, a time-delay extended state alternating predictive observer (TDESAPO) is developed, which can actively predict the current state and disturbance, and effectively restore the information between sampling points, thereby improving the data transmission rate, that is, the observation rate and the control rate. Using these predictions, a fast-updating controller including disturbance feedforward compensation is designed, thereby enhancing the system’s robustness to disturbance. Through simulation comparison, the effectiveness and practicability of the algorithm are verified.
