title: Context-Aware Sensor Fusion and Mode-Switching Control for an Autonomous Underwater Vehicle
authors: Santhoshi Navallika Dendukuri, Guilherme Vieira Hollweg
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: This work presents a simulation framework for an Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) that adapts its control behavior and sensor configuration in response to changing underwater conditions. Implemented in MATLAB Simulink and Simscape, the system integrates a cascaded PID controller with context-aware gain scheduling and sensor morphing logic. Environmental cues such as depth, visibility, and sensor health trigger real-time switching between cruise and maneuver control modes and adaptive sensor fusion using an Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU), a Doppler Velocity Log (DVL), Sonar, and Camera inputs. A Kalman Filter ensures robust state estimation across all configurations. The system is validated in a range of simulated mission scenarios, demonstrating improved energy efficiency, sensor reliability, and trajectory tracking. Results support the use of adaptive control for resilient and efficient underwater navigation.

title: Lightweight Frequency-Aware Super-Resolution for Real-Time Satellite Image Enhancement
authors: Muskan Muskan, Sadiya Fathima, Subiya Khatun, Mohammad Pasha, Mohd Umar Farooq, Khaleel Ur Rahman Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Satellite imagery plays a crucial role in modern-day applications ranging from environmental monitoring to urban planning. However, due to limited bandwidth and storage, these images are often available only at low resolutions, which limit their utility. In this paper, we propose a novel approach combining Fast Fourier Convolution (FFC) and Knowledge Distillation (KD) to create a lightweight and efficient super-resolution (SR) model optimized for satellite images. Our student-teacher framework leverages a more powerful teacher model to guide a compact student model, enhancing the final image quality while reducing computational complexity. We benchmark our method against five existing models from recent literature in terms of speed, accuracy, and robustness, demonstrating superior performance in real-world scenarios. Graphs, tables, and visual comparisons are included for a comprehensive evaluation.

title: Remote Sensing Case Studies: Data Driven Approach to Alternative Asset Management and Smarter Learning Operations
authors: Ezekiel Nnamere Aneke, Oto-Obong John Effiong, Chisom Okoye, Chino Ikwuegbu, Livinus Egbonwonu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Exploring and monitoring extreme locations and special terrains have long posed significant challenges to energy exploration and maintenance, leading to safety risks, environmental damage, and ever-increasing operational costs. The demand for monitoring energy infrastructure to address the industry's most pressing challenges is stronger than ever, especially in low income countries looking to grow various industries that will transform their economic fortunes for the betterment of their citizens. Advancements in remote sensing technologies, from basic aerial photographs to satellites, drones, Geographic Information Systems (GIS), and sensors, have revolutionized environmental monitoring, asset management, and disaster management. The integration of AI and Big Data has further enhanced remote sensing capabilities, enabling sophisticated analysis and insights as demonstrated in this study. With this technology allowing for the monitoring of over 70% of the planet's otherwise inaccessible surface, the economic implications for other nations or investors could not have been more positive.

title: Super-Resolution Enhancement of Low-Light Photography Using Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: M.Ramkumar Prabhu, Navnath B. Pokale, Rahul Shakya, Abhijeet Deshpande, Jasmeet Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Improving images still presents a major challenge in low-light photography as the images are noisy, poor contrast, and unclear. In those instances, conventional photo enhancement techniques may also locate it challenging to preserve exquisite characteristics even as simplifying their visibility. This paper examines Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) as a means of improving the clarity of low-mild photos. We advocate a novel framework using GANs' innovative powers that seeks to increase low-mild photograph best and readability simultaneously. The graph of the proposed model has 2 key components: a generator that enhances image first-rate and a discriminator ensuring the generated picture stays alive and free of artefacts. The model is educated on a massive series of low-mild pix matched with excessive-decision opposite numbers of the identical snap shots. This approves it to apprehend the elaborate relationships among photo characteristics and occasional-mild situations. The goal is to beautify low-light images while retaining the original patterns, sharpness, and noise reduction. In each visible best and numerical criteria as PSNR and SSIM, our GAN-primarily based model outperforms conventional strategies. The system also effectively addresses typical issues such colour distortion and pixelation brought on by conventional enhancement techniques. Low-light photographs in a broad spectrum of context monitoring, medical imaging, and night shooting are made better by this work. The findings imply that in challenging imaging environments, GANs could be a helpful tool to enhance super-resolution picture quality.

title: Investigation into the Control Approach for the Auxiliary Motor during Intelligent Vehicle Steering System's Emergency Steering
authors: Aopeng Hou, Yanliang Gong, Yelin He, Yahui Xu, Zhengfeng Chen, Jian Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: The transformation and upgrading of the automobile industry has spurred the growth of automotive electronic technology. As the industry steps into the high - quality development phase, the safety, comfort, and reliability of vehicles are being steadily enhanced. Automotive electric power steering (EPS), a power-steering system relies on a booster motor to provide auxiliary torque, has emerged as a crucial indicator of the current automotive development and electrification levels. However, under emergency steering conditions, how to effectively control the power steering motor to ensure the reliability and safety of the automobile has become one of the hotspots in research. Hence, an approach called the three-vector model predictive current control (TV-MPCC) is presented to tackle the problems of slow response and insufficient tracking accuracy in the steering assist motor when performing emergency maneuvers at high speeds. Firstly, a dual closed-loop control system for permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) is established, which consists of a velocity loop and a current loop. Secondly, the conventional PID controller of the current loop is substituted with the model predictive current control of the motor, which is deduced to improve the response speed and tracking performance of the system. Ultimately, a control system model is constructed in MATLAB/Simulink to simulate and verify the control strategy, and it is experimentally verified on an electric power steering test bench. The study’s findings suggest that the devised control strategy is capable of remarkably improving the tracking accuracy of the power-assisted motor. Moreover, it can uphold the robustness of the electric power steering (EPS) system during emergency steering scenarios. This not only enhances the driver’s driving experience but also improves driving safety.

title: City-Agnostic Demand Prediction: A Graph Attention Approach for Urban Transfer Learning
authors: Hakan Erdol, Robert Klar, Vangelis Angelakis, James Pope, Robert Piechocki, Theo Tryfonas, George Oikonomou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Urban transportation planning faces increasing complexity as cities seek to optimize mobility systems without extensive historical data. This paper presents CI-SGNN (City-Invariant Spatial Graph Neural Network), a novel framework for cross-city bike-sharing demand prediction that leverages Point of Interest (POI) distributions and spatial attention mechanisms. Our approach addresses the critical challenge of predicting categorical mobility demand in new urban environments by learning transferable relationships between urban amenities and travel patterns from source cities. The framework integrates OpenStreetMap POI features with GNNs, enabling zero-shot transfer learning across diverse metropolitan areas. We formulate demand prediction as a multi-class classification problem, categorizing origin-destination pairs into five demand levels. Experimental validation using real CitiBike data from Manhattan and Washington DC demonstrates superior performance, achieving 72.4% accuracy, which overperforms state-of-the-art base-lines. The attention-based spatial aggregation mechanism effectively captures inter-zone dependencies. Our results demonstrate successful zero-shot adaptation capabilities, enabling practical deployment for bike-sharing infrastructure planning in cities lacking historical mobility data using only publicly available urban features.

title: Voice Cloning and Singing Style Transfer Using Generative Adversarial Networks in Music Production
authors: T. Puhazhendhi, Mahesh Kurulekar, Mahendran Arumugam, Om Prakash, Rupinder Kaur Grewal, Abdul Azeem Khan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Voice cloning and speaking style transfer have attracted much interest in the field of music production. These tasks are greatly aided by Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs). This paper investigates how GAN-based models may be used to replicate sounds and alter the way individuals sing, hence enabling the production of high-quality counterfeit voices. Using data from a person's speech or singing, voice cloning is the technique of creating a mechanical voice that sounds precisely like their own. A profound awareness of the nuances of sound, tone, modulation, and speech patterns is required. Conversely, style transfer is the technique of transforming one voice's tone into another. This allows musicians to fit many kinds of creative forms or music. The major objective of this work is to develop a GAN-based architecture with a generator and a discriminator both enhanced by training them against one another. While the generator produces synthesized singing with the preferred style or voice, the discriminator verifies if the produced output is genuine. Training the proposed model makes use of several voice snippets and song performances. Techniques include spectrum analysis, pitch shifting, and feature extraction are used. The model performed rather well in both voice cloning and style transfer activities, indicating that it can produce phony songs sounding quite similar to the target voice and singing style. This work might enhance music creation, provide artists greater flexibility in their creative processes, and support the development of more individualized voice synthesis technology.

title: Charging Load Forecasting for Electric Vehicles Based on User Satisfaction and Road Traffic Models
authors: Mengchao Gong, Hejun Yang, Zhi Guan, Anxin He, Jindong Huang, Jingjing Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The forecasting of electric vehicle (EV) charging load is a key requirement for studying the interaction between EVs and the power distribution network. This paper proposes a EV charging load forecasting method based on EV user satisfaction. Firstly, considering the complex structure of urban traffic networks with multiple intersections, a dynamic transportation network model is established that incorporates both link impedance and node impedance. Secondly, the OD matrix method and a four-step transportation demand model are employed to determine the origin and destination points of three types of EVs-private vehicles, taxis, and public service vehicles-and the Dijkstra algorithm is used to plan their travel routes. Thirdly, by considering charging time, on-the-way costs, and electricity prices, a user satisfaction-based charging station selection model is proposed. A corresponding EV charging load forecasting framework is then constructed. Finally, Monte Carlo simulation is used to model the travel and charging behaviors of the three types of EVs. Simulations are conducted on a regional transportation network and distribution system to validate the effectiveness of the proposed user satisfaction-based charging load forecasting method.

title: 3-D Optical Interconnection of Bent Waveguides and Micro-Mirror by Planar Semiconductor Process
authors: Keito Kikuchi, Taro Itatani, Yoshinobu Okano, Akihiro Noriki, Takeru Amano
publish: 2025 IEEE CPMT Symposium Japan (ICSJ)
abstract: We have demonstrated an optical interconnection of optical waveguides of SiN and Polymer fiber with a bent structure connected by a concave mirror of Si formed by planar semiconductor process.

title: Cruise Trajectory Planning for Variable Configuration Unmanned Aerial Vehicle
authors: Guangyu Yang, Wenxing Fu, Supeng Zhu, Yuge Zhang, Tong Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Cruise trajectory planning is a crucial part in aerospace, missile technology and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). Earlier studies rarely considered the multiple constraints aspect in trajectory planning. This paper proposes an adaptive pseudo-spectral to achieve the desired trajectory planning for the variable configuration unmanned aerial vehicle. Based on the gaussian rule, the trajectory planning (i.e. optimal problem) is first transformed into a nonlinear programming problem (NLP). To more accurately solve the differential constraints, the aerodynamic parameters are calculated in different stages for the variable configuration UAV. Combined with flight environments and an objective function, we proposed sequential quadratic programming (SQP) to tackle transformed NLP. The numerical simulation results demonstrate that the planned cruise trajectory can satisfy the optimal requirements and constraint conditions, and it can enable the UAV to reach the target in various cruise altitude cases.

title: Detecting Phishing Emails with Artificial Intelligence: A Hybrid Machine Learning Approach
authors: Rohit Kumar, Karanam Srujana, Polisetti Sampath, Jagdish Chandra Patni, Poorva Agrawal, Soubhagya Ranjan Mallick
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Phishing continues to pose a serious risk to cybersecurity. Imitated emails, websites, and messages are used to get out the sensitive information including usernames, passwords, banking information and other personally identifiable information. Phishing is particularly damaging because traditional detection techniques tend to ignore advanced or zero-day phishing attempts, causing financial damage and leakage of sensitive information. To combat this emerging issue, we present a novel phishing detection system that uses Natural Language Processing (NLP) to analyze emails and URLs avatars in real-time. This applies NLP approaches to identify phishing emails based on known linguistic and behavioral phishing patterns. These features detect patterns of suspicious words, syntactic structures, and contextual clues. The system adapts detection models on a regular basis to keep up with emerging phishing tactics like socially engineered or zero-day attacks. The suggested system provides comprehensive detection and notification, warning users before the phishing threats reach their inbox or any engagement. It also integrates seamlessly with current cybersecurity frameworks, so it can be deployed easily without having to replace existing systems. Additionally, the system encourages user awareness by providing safety advice and phishing identification guidelines. It indicate that the NLP-based phishing detection system has a high accuracy of 92%, performing better than most conventional models. These values prove the effectiveness of the system in both correctly identifying phishing attacks and reducing false positives.

title: Modelling and Simulation of Two-Stage Claus Converter of SRU for Hydrogen Production: Comparison with SULSIM Model
authors: Suhailam P, Vamsi Vankayalapati, Gorja Dinesh Babu, Chandra Shekar Besta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: The main aim of this research is to produce hydrogen along with Sulphur from Sulphur Recovery Unit (SRU) through the thermal decomposition of hydrogen sulphide (H2S). A model is developed in Aspen HYSYS for the Claus process. Acid gas decomposition is a desirable method for producing hydrogen since the feedstock is affordable. Hydrogen production can be achieved in Waste Heat Exchanger (WHE) connected after the reaction furnace and followed by Claus catalytic reactors. While the H2S decomposition was defined by the thermodynamic in the furnace. Preheating the acid gas i.e., mainly H2S and CO2 before entering into the furnace would increase the percentage of hydrogen production. The composition of acid gas entering into the SRU plays an important role in sulphur and hydrogen yield. Three different feed compositions of acid gas were studied with the developed model in which the optimum is found. The optimum feed composition has a greater percentage of hydrogen yield. This notable increase in hydrogen yield can significantly enhance hydrogen production for SRUs.

title: Tracking Reference Signal Periodicity and Energy Consumption: Trade-offs in 5G Networks
authors: Jui Mhatre, Ahyoung Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: Tracking reference signals (TRS) are essential in the 5G New Radio (NR) physical layer (PHY) for enabling user equipment (UE) to maintain synchronization and accurately estimate channel state information (CSI), especially under high mobility or at higher frequencies. TRS are transmitted periodically by the base station (BS), but this periodicity introduces an energy trade-off. Frequent TRS transmissions improve synchronization and reduce bit error rate (BER), particularly for fast-moving UEs. However, they also increase BS transmission energy and prevent UEs from entering low-power sleep modes, thereby increasing UE energy consumption due to constant TRS processing. On the other hand, less frequent TRS transmissions reduce BS energy overhead and allow UEs to conserve energy by remaining idle longer. However, this can lead to clock drift and reduced synchronization accuracy at the UE, resulting in higher BER and increased data retransmissions, which also consume energy. This paper investigates how TRS periodicity affects energy consumption at both the BS and UE ends using MATLAB’s 5G Toolbox. Simulations are conducted under various UE mobility scenarios, with TRS periodicities ranging from 10 ms to 80 ms. Results show that while lower periodicities ensure better synchronization and reliability, they burden the BS and disrupt UE sleep cycles. Conversely, higher periodicities benefit the BS but increase energy costs at the UE due to synchronization loss. The study highlights the critical trade-off between network energy efficiency and communication robustness, guiding selecting TRS configurations in energy-aware 5G deployments for optimized communication.

title: Visual Risk-Aware Decision-Making Method for Autonomous Driving
authors: Siman Wu, Chen Shao, Jianshan Zhou, Xuting Duan, Kaige Qu, Chunmian Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: As autonomous driving technology advances, the ability to accurately perceive risks and execute efficient behavioral strategies in real-world traffic scenarios has become critical for performance evaluation. Decision-making algorithms are central to ensuring safety and effectiveness. Addressing the shortcomings of existing systems in comprehensively accounting for risk factors in complex traffic environments, this paper proposes a visual risk perception-based autonomous driving decision model. By integrating visual risk quantification with deep reinforcement learning, the framework evaluates diverse environmental risks to make safer, more rational decisions across varying risk conditions. First, BEVD4D object detection model processes image inputs to achieve vision-based speed estimation. Second, to overcome traditional risk assessment limitations in capturing traffic complexity, a driving risk field model is introduced, considering lane lines, static and dynamic obstacles, and employing a "pseudo-distance" metric to better represent real-world complexity. This model underpins the design of subsequent decision strategies. Finally, the risk field model is embedded into a deep reinforcement learning framework by expanding the state space and reward function of the Soft Actor-Critic algorithm, enhancing risk-aware decision-making. Experiments on the CARLA simulation platform demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the method in urban streets and complex intersections, resulting in safer, more adaptive, and interpretable autonomous driving decisions.

title: On the Use of Gumbel-Softmax for Differentiable Qam in Semantic Communication
authors: Luiz Fernando da Costa Gontijo, Paulo Cardieri
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: Semantic communication is a promising paradigm for 6G networks, prioritizing the transmission of meaning over strict bit-level accuracy. This paper proposes a semantic communication system that combines pre-trained language models for semantic coding and decoding with fully connected layers for channel processing. To enable end-to-end training with QAM modulation, we employ the Gumbelsoftmax trick as a differentiable approximation of hard symbol sampling. This approach allows semantic embeddings to be mapped onto constellation points while preserving gradient flow. The system is evaluated under fading channels using BLEU and BERTScore as performance metrics. Results show that Gumbel-softmax-based QAM modulation demonstrates competitive performance across different SNR levels, highlighting its robustness in noisy conditions. These findings confirm the effectiveness of combining semantic coding with differentiable modulation for future communication systems.

title: Enhancing Vessel Trajectory Prediction: A Comparative Study of BiGRU and Fusion-Based Clustering BiGRU Models
authors: I Dewa Ayu Sri Murdhani, I Putu Agus Eka Darma Udayana, Putu Sugiartawan, I Made Oka Widyantara, I Made Dwi Putra Asana
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Maritime transportation is the backbone of global trade, but increased ship traffic density also increases safety risks. Accurate ship route prediction is key to improving situational awareness and preventing incidents. This study aims to improve the accuracy of ship route prediction by comparing the performance of the standard BiGRU model and the BiGRU model optimized through HDBSCAN-based clustering. This analysis uses vessel movement data obtained from the Automatic Identification System (AIS), which provides real-time navigation information. The proposed approach includes trace compression using the Ramer–Douglas–Peucker algorithm, similarity measurement using the Hausdorff distance, dimension reduction using Multidimensional Scaling (MDS), and adaptive density-based clustering using HDBSCAN. Prediction models are built using BiGRU networks on each cluster. Experimental results on three test sub-trajectories show that integrating HDBSCAN with BiGRU generally results in lower prediction error rates. The average reduction in MAE reached approximately 18%, MAPE approximately 20%, MSE approximately 44%, and RMSE approximately 20%, compared to the BiGRU model without clustering. The model demonstrated high prediction accuracy in some clusters, particularly those with uniform movement patterns, indicating the effectiveness of the clustering approach for complex trajectory data. These findings suggest that applying clustering before modeling can improve prediction accuracy, especially for complex and heterogeneous ship track data. This research contributes to the development of more adaptive and reliable intelligent maritime navigation systems.

title: Photoplethysmography Based Anxiety Management System Using Physiological and Demographic Parameters
authors: Merin Venus, Sanjay Sunil, Sreelakshmi T. P., Susan Sony, Sreenath B.
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Anxiety and depression are observed to be disturbingly increasing in this post-COVID era. Studies show that the average proportion of persons with symptoms of a depressive disorder and/or anxiety disorder has risen by about 30% since onset of COVID. As a result, it is essential to monitor and regulate its level by providing the appropriate support. A person's level of stress can be ascertained via cardiovascular indicators. Conventional cardiovascular sensors, such electrocardiography machines and cuffed sphygmomanometers, are heavy and challenging for people to use on a regular basis. The proposed anxiety management method suggests using wearable sensor to measure a person's biomarkers with photoplethysmography. It supplies a filtered electric signal that yields the useable AC component required for additional analysis. Several algorithms are applied to the collected data in order to determine and display the stress level. If the individual is deemed to be overly anxious, they are redirected to an iconvobot, a conversational chatbot. It serves as an assistive device to help the user during mental stress.

title: Move with Me: Designing Wearable Technology to Encourage Physical Activity in Rural South African Children
authors: Mishka Dewlok, Taryn Wilson, Sarina Till
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Rural South African children often face systemic barriers to physical activity, including unsafe outdoor environments, under-resourced Early Childhood Development (ECD) centers, and increasing exposure to sedentary screen time. This paper introduces a wearable superhero-themed Tangible User Interface (TUI) co-designed with rural caregivers to support playful movement in young children. The cape integrates motion sensors, LED feedback, Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE), and a solar-rechargeable battery, ensuring functionality in low-resource settings without the need for internet or grid electricity. A companion Android-based mobile app enhances engagement through culturally tailored animations that respond to detected movement. Grounded in co-design and informed by technology probes, this work emphasizes inclusive design practices and demonstrates how low-cost, embedded systems can support early childhood development in under-served regions. Our findings contribute to the field of emerging educational technologies, highlighting the potential of context-aware, offline-first solutions for equitable innovation.

title: ISRYOLO: Improving Small Object Detection in Aerial Imagery via Super-Resolution and Attention Fusion
authors: Nutt Ratanakul, Tukdanai Urumporn, Naveed Sultan, Santitham Prom-On
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: Detecting objects in high-resolution drone and satellite images is vital for disaster response, urban planning, and environmental monitoring. Small object detection, the task of finding tiny targets that cover only a few pixels (e.g., cars, people, or rooftops), is tough because these objects lack detailed features and often blend into cluttered backgrounds. ISRYOLO is a super-resolution assisted object detection framework that integrates attention mechanisms (CBAM), pixel shuffle upsampling, ConvNeXtBlock, and Atrous Spatial Pyramid Pooling (ASPP) into the detection pipeline. The model enhances spatial feature representation and improves accuracy, particularly for small objects, while maintaining computational efficiency. The results in the VEDAI dataset demonstrate that ISRYOLO outperforms the state-of-the-art model in terms of mean Average Precision (mAP) and recall, making it a promising solution for real-time applications.

title: Cmos Voltage-Averaging Feedback Relaxation Oscillator
authors: Arcadie Cracan, Andrei Ciobanaşu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a relaxation oscillator using the voltage-averaging feedback principle to control the oscillation frequency. Compared to other implementations, the capacitor charge is not reset, and an additional loop is employed to control the amplitude of the oscillation to a fraction of the supply voltage. The oscillation frequency depends only on the RC time constant and is independent of supply voltage variation and comparator delay.

title: Corn Seed Quality Classification Using Deep Learning with RGB Baselines
authors: Sirikun Chueapongpan, Sanya Khruahong
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Reliable seed quality assessment is essential for agricultural productivity, yet manual inspection is slow, inconsistent, and error-prone. This study investigates convolutional neural networks for corn seed quality classification using a curated dataset of 17,801 RGB images, with group-based splitting by seed ID to eliminate data leakage and ensure reproducibility. Three architectures, MobileNetV2, ResNet50, and EfficientNet-B0, were trained under standardized preprocessing and augmentation. ResNet50 delivered the best performance, achieving about 95 percent accuracy and a Macro-F1 score near 0.95, demonstrating strong robustness across both majority and minority classes. MobileNetV2 reached about 91 percent accuracy, offering efficiency for lightweight applications. In contrast, EfficientNet-B0 severely underperformed at about 51 percent accuracy due to unstable convergence, over-parameterization relative to the dataset scale, and sensitivity to class imbalance. These results establish RGB-based baselines as a reproducible benchmark for agricultural image classification, while future work will address imbalance mitigation, domain-specific pretraining, and multi-color fusion to improve recognition of underrepresented classes.

title: Optimization of charging current constraint control strategy for heated tobacco product sets based on barrier function
authors: Qingyuan Zheng, Minghui Wang, Jian Sun, Kun Chen, Shiming Li, Tianyu Jiang, Haoxiang Zou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: This paper proposes a constraint current charging control strategy based on barrier function method for lithiumion battery in heated cigarettes. First, dynamic voltage model and thermal model of the battery are established based on the equivalent circuit model of lithium-ion battery. Second, a reference current controller is designed based on the battery thermal model and PID control method. Third, a current constraint control strategy is proposed based on nonlinear dynamic gain technology on the basis of the reference controller. Finally, the overall control process is given to realize fast and safe charging. Simulation results show that the method can ensure safety while maintaining the voltage response performance.

title: Lightning Protection for Spaceports and Launch Complexes - Part II: Standards, Risk Assessment, and Regulatory Gaps
authors: Carlos T. Mata, Dustin Hill
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: This second part of a three-part series builds upon the historical and physical context of lightning-triggered failures in spaceflight infrastructure by examining the standards and regulatory framework guiding lightning protection system (LPS) design. The paper compares major U.S. and international lightning protection standards—including SSCMAN 91-710, NFPA 780, AFMAN 32-1065, UFC 3-575-01, FAR Part 417, IEC 62305, and others—highlighting inconsistencies in technical guidance, inspection intervals, and enforcement mechanisms across agencies and jurisdictions.Given the expanding strategic importance of spaceports to national security, the lack of unified LPS requirements presents a growing vulnerability. In light of the 2025 Space Threat Fact Sheet, this paper argues that harmonizing standards through risk-based, science-driven enforcement is not only a matter of technical soundness but of operational resilience and mission assurance. A unified LPS framework would address regulatory gaps, reject pseudoscientific alternatives, and ensure minimum protection thresholds are uniformly implemented across all spaceports.

title: Music Ocean Odyssey: Visualizing Influence and Development in Musical Networks through Artist Trajectories and Genre Evolution
authors: Almaz Baghirova, Sachin Kumar, Daniel A. Keim, Lucas Joos, Julius Rauscher
publish: 2025 IEEE Visual Analytics Science and Technology Challenge (VAST Challenge)
abstract: We present Music Ocean Odyssey, a web-based visual analytics prototype designed to examine Sailor Shift’s career and trace the spread of Oceanus Folk throughout the music industry, addressing the VAST Challenge MC1. Built on a knowledge graph with ∼17k nodes and ∼38k edges, our system combines a force graph with a temporal stream graph to surface Sailor’s evolving influences, collaborations and ripple effects, and the genre’s spread and contemporary inspirations. We summarize design choices, key findings, and lessons learned.

title: Dynamic Loss Analysis and Radiator Parameter Optimization of Transformerless High-Voltage Power Conversion System for Battery Energy Storage System
authors: Xiong Zhan, Hui Yan, Lanfang Li, Jianhui Ji, Xuefen Jin, Hongxin Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Overload capacity is a key technical indicator for Grid-Forming energy storage systems to play a supporting role in the power grid. This article proposes a dynamic loss calculation and modeling method for transformerless cascaded H-bridge converter (CHBC-BESS), an equivalent thermal circuit modeling method for power conversion and the watercooled radiators, and the radiator parameter optimization design method. With the help of the power electronics simulation software PLECS, an electric thermal coupling model of the CHBC-BESS was established, and the junction temperature of IGBT and diode under different water-cooled radiator parameters under three operating conditions of 3 times overload for 0.2 s, 1 s, and 10 s respectively were studied. The results indicate that the established model can intuitively reflect the dynamic electrical and thermal characteristics of the CHBCBESS during overload operation, providing an effective means for optimizing the parameters of water-cooled radiators.

title: Shield Sequential Quadratic Programming Model Predictive Control with Application to Safety-Critical Control of Mobile Robot
authors: Haoyu He
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Combining model predictive control (MPC) with control barrier functions (CBFs) is a promising solution for addressing safety-critical control problems in robot navigation scenarios. The primary limitation of existing methods lies in their inability to simultaneously reduce computational complexity for nonlinear systems and ensure the feasibility of MPC-CBF frameworks. We propose a shield sequential quadratic programming model predictive control scheme as a method of combining MPC and CBFs for general nonlinear system to address this challenge. Using CBFs as a dual-layer filter, we translate the hard constraints of MPC-CBF to the combination of soft constraints and a control shield. The effectiveness of our proposed method is illustrated in the simulation of 2-D robot navigation environment.

title: Statistical Evaluation of Machine Learning Classifiers Using Monte Carlo Cross-Validation for Breast Cancer Diagnosis
authors: Mateus José Gonsalves Dias, Luso de Jesus Torres, Híterson de Oliveira Silva, Jacquelynn Rose Harmon, Raimundo Guimarães Saraiva Júnior, Francisco Assis de Oliveira Nascimento
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This study evaluates the reliability of Machine Learning classifiers for breast cancer diagnosis, one of the leading causes of cancer-related mortality among women. We used the Wisconsin Breast Cancer Dataset (WBCD) and compared six algorithms: Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), Quadratic Discriminant Analysis (QDA), Random Forest (RF), AdaBoost (AB), Ensemble Extra Trees (EET), and Histogram-based Gradient Boosting Classification Tree (HGB). Monte Carlo Cross-Validation (MCCV) with 1000 repetitions was employed to evaluate average F 1 -score and standard deviation. The results indicated that the Ensemble Extra Trees (EET) achieved the best performance, with an average F 1 -score of 95.26% and a standard deviation of 1.11%, highlighting its high precision and stability. HGB and AB also showed good F1-score but with higher variability, while LDA, QDA, and RF performed worse. In conclusion, EET proved to be the most promising algorithm for automated breast cancer diagnosis based on the WBCD.

title: Experimental study of the joint operation of multiple nonlinear electrical loads on the quality of electrical energy in a school building
authors: Nikola Makedonski, Hristian Panchev, Plamen Parushev, Ginka Ivanova, Milen Duganov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This study presents an analysis of the impact of a large number of jointly operating nonlinear loads on the quality of electrical power in a real school building. The study is based on experimentally recorded instantaneous values of voltage and current, covering different periods of the day - day and night load mode. The main consumers in the electrical network are personal computers and LED lighting systems, which draw nonsinusoidal currents and lead to voltage distortion. By calculating power quality indicators, a quantitative assessment of the impact of these loads on the quality of the power supply is derived. The results highlight the need for monitoring and implementing corrective measures to improve the electromagnetic compatibility and efficiency of the electrical distribution network in buildings with predominantly nonlinear loads.

title: A Local Explanation Method for Deep Learning Networks based on Causal Intervention with Cross-Instance Knowledge Sharing
authors: Jiashan Geng, Xinyang Deng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Deep learning models have achieved remarkable performance in image classification tasks, but their black-box nature limits their applications in high-security domains. This paper proposes a causal intervention for efficient local explanations with cross-instance knowledge sharing, which quantifies the causal effect of input features on model decisions through causal intervention operations. Our approach employs genetic algorithms to search for the most explanatory feature subsets in high-dimensional feature spaces and introduces a global experience matrix to enable cross-instance causal knowledge sharing. Through comparative analysis conducted on the ImageNet validation dataset employing VGG-16 and ResNet-50, our proposed methodology demonstrates superior results when evaluated using the ADCC comprehensive assessment framework. The experimental findings indicate that our technique effectively minimizes computational complexity while preserving strong consistency, surpassing established CAM-based baselines across various evaluation criteria.

title: Interpreting Urban Regional Traffic Congestion Events via Textual Descriptions
authors: Hexu Zhou, Beiyan He, Lei Chen, Chunli Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Understanding urban regional traffic congestion contributes to the optimization of signal timing optimization, route planning, and emergency rescue. Current studies concentrate on interpretability not too much. To address this issue, we propose a post-hoc explainability framework that enhances the interpretability of Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Networks (STGNNs) in traffic congestion forecasting. The framework leverages the Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) algorithm to extract key subgraphs from the prediction graph and transforms the interpretation of regional traffic forecasts into human-understandable natural language descriptions. We validate the framework using 16 weeks of minute-level traffic flow data on a 6×7 grid road network in Shanghai simulated on SUMO. Results show that when predictions are made using explanatory subgraphs rather than their complements, the explainer model’s MAE drops from 0.836 to 0.225—a 73.1% reduction in relative error. Moreover, the average sparsity of the extracted subgraphs exceeds 96%.

title: Generation of Space Charge in Different Geometries Exposed to Electric Fields Produced by Lightning
authors: Chandima Gomes, Nishanth Parus
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: This paper presents a theoretical and numerical analysis of space charge generation on metallic objects of varying geometries exposed to electric fields associated with lightning. The study focuses on the stepped leader and return stroke phases of cloud-to-ground lightning, where local electric fields near grounded metallic protrusions may reach values sufficient to initiate streamer discharges. Using a previously proposed field enhancement model, electric field intensities at the tip of hemispherical conductors with diameters ranging from 0.1 mm to 16 mm are computed for needle heights of 10 mm and 1000 mm. The results are analyzed under ambient electric field conditions of 1 MV/m to 200 kV/m, characteristic of natural lightning fields. It is shown that for slender conductors with tip diameters below 0.5 mm and heights exceeding 1 m, the local field may surpass the critical threshold of ~100 MV/m required for space charge generation, even in ambient fields as low as 50 kV/m. This helps explain field-induced ionization observed well before return stroke onset. The analysis incorporates Fowler–Nordheim tunnelling and Peek’s criterion to differentiate corona emission, cold field emission, and streamer inception thresholds. Implications for lightning protection, high-voltage insulation design, and electromagnetic compatibility are discussed, particularly in the context of tall installations and complex geometries.

title: Smart App-Assisted Cover Tracking: Protecting Children and Young Women from Human Trafficking
authors: Nur Fadhila Rasyida Salwa, Muchamad Wahyu Prasetyo, Aripriharta Aripriharta, Puji Handayati, Zainal Arifin, Ahmad Munjin Nasih, Zhi-Hao Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Human trafficking, particularly of women and children, remains a major challenge in the ASEAN region, including Indonesia. This study aims to design and develop a prototype of smart shoes based on wearable technology integrated with a location tracking system and emotion monitoring through heart rate analysis. The prototype is ergonomically designed and equipped with biometric sensors (Max30102) and a GPS module, with data transmitted in realtime to a mobile application. The research methodology employs the Research and Development (R&D) model by Borg & Gall, encompassing design, expert validation, small-scale to large-scale testing, and user evaluation. Test results showed heart rate detection accuracy with an MAE value of 3.55 BPM and RMSE of 4.22 BPM, as well as location tracking accuracy with low latitude and longitude coordinate deviations (MAE < 0.0003). Evaluation of female adolescent users indicated that the device is comfortable to use and the app interface is easy to understand. This research offers an innovative technology-based solution for real-time detection of children's emotional states and locations, which has the potential to be used in efforts to prevent and address human trafficking cases, as well as other security and health monitoring applications.

title: Sales Forecasting with Hourly Transaction Data: Comparing SARIMAX and LSTM Models
authors: Ulfa Siti Nuraini, Dinda Galuh Guminta, Ibnu Febry Kurniawan, Agnes Ona Bliti Puka
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: This paper compares the statistical method Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average with Exogenous variables (SARIMAX) and the machine learning method Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) for modelling sales of transactional data. The main contribution of this work is the effect of the sum of user and twin dates as an exogenous variable and the seasonal pattern in modelling e-commerce transactional data. To validate the accuracy of the model, various scenarios are employed, including seasonal parameters, AR and MA parameters for SARIMAX, and the number of layers and nodes for LSTM. It is found that the forecasting SARIMAX model in December 2023 yields a lower RMSE (43.28) than the LSTM model, as indicated by the forecasting pattern that closely follows the real data in the testing dataset. This research is highly relevant as it provides a practical forecasting tool for transactional data that uses promotions in special events.

title: Causal Learning-Based Object Detection for Autonomous Driving
authors: Xiaoyu Hu, Haobing Pang, Dong Wang, Jianshan Zhou, Xuting Duan, Kaige Qu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Autonomous driving systems often encounter long-tail corner cases that are rare, ambiguous, and not well represented in training data. Traditional deep learning models struggle to generalize in these cases, as they rely heavily on pattern recognition and lack commonsense reasoning. We propose an end-to-end framework that enhances visual perception through causal intervention and guides behavior decision-making using Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs). First, a causality-aware object detection module is introduced to reduce contextual bias by learning interventional representations. Then, visual and historical state information is encoded into structured prompts, enabling MLLMs to perform natural language-based reasoning and generate interpretable driving commands. Experimental results on multiple complex scenarios show that our method improves generalization, robustness, and decision consistency compared to conventional baselines.

title: A Single-End Protection Principle for Flexible DC Collection System Based on Energy Polarity
authors: Dai Feiyang, Cao Hong, Song Yonghui, Liu Jiaqi, Liu Ningning
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In order to pursue economy and stability, DC collection transmission systems differ from conventional flexible DC systems in terms of primary system topology, and the adaptability of existing line protection configurations in such systems is insufficient. In this study, the particularity of the traveling-wave process in a four terminal flexible DC collection system is analyzed, and the relationship between traveling-wave polarity and fault location is revealed, based on which a single terminal quantity protection principle utilizing reflected-wave polarity identification is constructed. The PSCAD/EMTDC simulation results have verified the effectiveness of the protection principle.

title: Defect Detection Method of Basin Insulator Based on Pulse Ultra-Wideband MIMO Radar Array
authors: Panlong Zhang, Xianjun Qi, Yan Zhang, Rui Cao, Xiaohui Tao, Jingjing Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Defects of basin insulators seriously threaten power grid safety. Traditional detection technology has limitations such as insufficient penetration, complex operation and low efficiency. In contrast, microwave non-destructive testing technology has great potential due to its advantages of non-contact, high penetration and high resolution. Aiming at the demand for rapid and accurate detection of basin insulator defects, based on the Novelda X4 chip, a low-power, portable pulse ultra-wideband MIMO (Multiple-Input Multiple-Output) radar array system is designed in this paper. Ultra-wideband pulse technology and MIMO radar array technology are employed to significantly improves spatial resolution of microwave imaging. To find defects of a 252 kV ventilated basin insulator, such as surface metal particles, internal bubbles and surface cracks, an experimental platform is built, and the imaging algorithms of DAS (Delay and Sum) and DMAS (Delay Multiply and Sum) are used to process echo data. The experimental results show that the pulse ultra-wideband MIMO radar method can effectively identify the above defects, verifying the feasibility of applying microwave non-destructive testing to basin insulator defect diagnosis, but the defect location accuracy and size quantification accuracy still need to be further improved.

title: Enhanced High Voltage Cable Current Carrying Capacity by Externally Wrapped Phase Change Materials
authors: Tianyu Ruan, Qi Shen, Jincheng Yu, Kongyang Huang, Zhen Gao, Yanjie Le
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper proposes an innovative approach to enhance the current-carrying capacity of power cables by coating a phase change materials (PCMs) layer on the exterior surface. During dynamic overload scenarios, the PCMs absorbs significant heat generated by the cable through latent heat storage during phase transition, thereby reducing the temperature rise rate of the cable core and achieving shortterm capacity expansion. Experiments were conducted on 500 kV cross-linked polyethylene (XLPE) insulated AC cables, and results demonstrate that the PCMs coating effectively improves both the steady-state current carrying capacity and dynamic overload capability of the cable. This technology requires no external energy supply, offers easy installation, and presents strong practical value for engineering applications.

title: Integrated Iot Monitoring and Decision Support System for Smart Agriculture Applications
authors: Andrei Dănilă, Robert Streche, Oana Orza, Theodor Pintilie, Cristina Dobre, Darius Vasile, George Suciu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: This work presents an integrated IoT monitoring and decision support system designed for smart agriculture applications. The proposed approach combines state-of-the-art environmental sensing technology with real-time data acquisition and rule-based analysis to support early detection of critical conditions affecting crop development. What is novel in this contribution is the unified architecture that allows flexible deployment across different agricultural contexts and the implementation of a threshold-based risk detection mechanism tailored to specific crop requirements. Our system continuously monitors key environmental parameters such as soil moisture, air temperature, humidity, and solar radiation. Data is transmitted through low-power wireless protocols and processed on a central platform, where predefined thresholds trigger alerts when conditions become unfavorable for plant growth. This enables timely intervention, preventing potential damage and supporting optimal crop health. The proposed method has been tested in two ongoing research projects: OENOTRACE, which focuses on monitoring vineyard conditions, and SIOTIN, which targets climate control and disease prevention in greenhouse environments. The results highlight the system's flexibility and effectiveness in different cultivation settings, offering a scalable and cost-efficient solution for precision agriculture. By integrating sensing, realtime monitoring, and automated alerts, the system contributes to reducing risks and optimizing decision-making in agricultural management.

title: Lightning Damage Detection for Wind Turbine Blade Based on SCADA Data Analysis Using Autoencoder
authors: Takuto Matsui, Kazuki Matsuoka, Kazuo Yamamoto
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: The demand for wind power systems is increasing in response to the global challenge of climate change. On the other hand, the critical wind turbine damage caused by lightning strikes continues unabated. In order to ensure the protection of wind turbines from lightning strikes, it is important to detect damage caused by such strikes and to take appropriate action. However, the development of a system capable of remotely and automatically detecting lightning damage to wind turbines has not yet been achieved. The wind turbine that was struck by lightning cannot be restarted until the absence of damage has been confirmed in Japan, thus leading to decreased availability, which is regarded as a problem. This study considers a method capable of remotely and automatically detecting lightning damage to wind turbines. The approach involves conducting an anomaly detection of the blade, based on monitoring data observed by the Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition system. An anomaly detection model utilizing an autoencoder was constructed and applied to analyze data obtained from wind turbines affected by lightning damage. The findings indicate a strong likelihood of identifying blade anomalies resulting from lightning events.

title: Power and Electricity Balance Assessment for Renewable Power Systems via Time-Series Production Simulation with Source-Load Uncertainty
authors: Haoxiang Zhao, Hongrui Lu, Yuxiong Huang, Qirui Shen
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Traditional power systems are progressively evolving toward renewable power systems with increasing renewable energy penetration. This transition amplifies power and electricity balance risks due to the inherent volatility of high-penetration renewables and load fluctuations. Consequently, developing accurate assessment methodologies for power and electricity balance in renewable power systems is critical. This paper proposes a power and electricity balance assessment method based on time-series production simulation with source-load uncertainty. First, day-ahead uncertainty for load demand and wind/solar generation is modeled using multi-scenario technology, while intra-day uncertainty is characterized through fuzzy mathematics theory. Subsequently, a comprehensive source-grid-load-storage model is established for high-penetration renewable power systems, incorporating a two-stage day-ahead-intra-day optimization model. Finally, a time-series operational simulation minimizing both operating costs and risk costs under uncertainty generates quantitative power and electricity balance assessment indicators. Practical case studies validate the proposed method's effectiveness in addressing power balance risks and renewable energy accommodation challenges.

title: Multi-UAVs Cooperative Localization with Deep Reinforcement Learning in GPS-Denied Environment
authors: Zhilin Wu, Kaifang Wan, Chuchao He, Yongling Fan, Haozhi Qiang, Yunhui Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Under GPS-denied adversarial conditions, unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) formations experience positioning failures caused by adversarial interference. This paper proposes a collaborative strategy enabling UAVs to maintain real-time positioning via intra-formation relative spatial measurements after GPS loss. A Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) model is formulated for collaborative positioning and scheduling. Belief states are updated using an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF), while Q-values are estimated via a Deep Q-Network (DQN) to achieve accurate real-time collaborative positioning. Through specific-scenario simulations, the effectiveness of the proposed model is demonstrated in achieving efficient UAV formation management/scheduling and facilitating operational UAVs to locate GPS-denied UAV peers.

title: OPTeSIM: Optimal Cellular Prepaid Plans for a Customer Base with eSIM-Capable Phones
authors: Ramneek, Patrick Hosein, Karandeep Singh, Sangheon Pack
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: The embedded subscriber identity module (eSIM) technology has the potential to revolutionize mobile subscribers’ applications, transforming mobile network operators (MNOs) design and price their service offerings. As eSIM adoption accelerates, competition among MNOs, especially in prepaid markets, is intensifying. Traditional prepaid plans, based on fixed data and time allotments, often misalign with actual user consumption, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper presents OPTeSIM, a data-driven model for designing a finite set of optimal prepaid plans to maximize provider revenue. We model a user’s consumption as an average usage rate (data/time) and posits that a user selects the plan with the closest matching plan usage rate. We formulate the design problem as the minimization of total customer loss, the monetized value of unused data or time, which is dependent on the probability density function (PDF) of customer usage rates. The necessary condition for optimality requires that each plan rate equalizes the probability mass of the user distribution it captures on its left and right boundaries. We propose a numerical algorithm that approximates this solution using historical usage data. The model’s efficacy is demonstrated using two MNO datasets. For a real-world dataset of 0.5 million users, OPTeSIM plans captured $78 \%$ of the subscribers when offered alongside the MNO’s 21 existing plans, resulting in a 3.6 fold increase in total profit. A second evaluation on a statistical dataset of one million users further confirmed that our model leads to improved profitability and higher user adoption compared to existing plans. The advantage grows with catalog size and approaches the performance of personalized pricing as the number of plans increases.

title: UPS Batteries With Empty Chamber In The Box - Innovation Or Bad Practice
authors: Nikolai Vitkov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: Single-phase UPS batteries are investigated. A 7Ah battery design with less weight than other similar ones were found. In comparative study, the battery with less weight logically shows lower energy performance and fast degradation. After dissection, an empty chamber in the case was found - reduced active mass. It has been debated whether this is an innovative design or bad practice.

title: Performance Analysis of Uniform Fiber Bragg Grating for Enhanced Reflectivity and Reduced Sidelobes in Medical Sensing
authors: Santosh Jotiram Jagatap, Ashok Jetawat, Saurabh Mehta, Jayshree Jain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: A simulation driven approach was employed to investigate the effect of the structural design parameters on reflectivity and low side lobe levels (SLL) of a uniform fiber Bragg grating sensor (FBG). Although FBG sensor offers many advantages over conventional electronic sensors, its design is crucial to get desired spectral performance. High reflectivity and low SLL are essential to obtain high detection sensitivity in medical sensing applications. The uniform FBG is simple to fabricate and inexpensive which can provide the desired level of reflectivity. However, its performance is limited mainly due to higher SLL which degrades the signal quality in medical sensing applications. The apodization techniques can reduce SLL improving detection sensitivity but they also increase design and fabrication complexity. The reflectivity and SLL of FBG sensor depends on structural parameters such as grating length, grating period and modulation index. The careful selection of these parameters and optimization can improve the spectral response of uniform FBG sensor. The effect of structural parameters is investigated to determine optimal reflectivity and SLL. This can provide less complex and low-cost sensing solutions in medical applications where high reflectivity and moderate SLLs are acceptable.

title: Comparative Analysis of Proximity-Based Tracing and Close Contact Tracing Strategies: Efficacy, Efficiency, and Ethical Considerations
authors: Saravanan Muthaiyah, Kalaiarasi Sonai Muthu Anbananthen, Thein Oak Kyaw Zaw, Gunasekar Thangarasu, Fong Pui Kwan, Mohammed Irfan Abdul Malick Sahib
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: This study delves into the effectiveness, efficiency, and ethical implications of two primary methods for managing infectious disease outbreaks: Proximity-Based Tracing (PBT) and Close Contact Tracing (CCT). CCT, a novel technique leveraging proximity data from digital devices, is contrasted with the traditional PBT across various criteria such as methodology, accuracy, scalability, and data privacy. By conducting a thorough examination of prior research and real-world examples, this research aims to shed light on the advantages and drawbacks of each approach. The findings seek to offer valuable insights for shaping public health policies and implementing technological solutions to better handle and contain the transmission of contagious diseases.

title: Mirror of Reflections: Creating Relatable AI-Generated Motivational Stories from San Youth Experiences and San Elders' Wisdom
authors: Naftali Ndeapo Indongo, Rosetha Kays, Varde Simaneka Daniel, Johnson Haimbili Kaulinge, Cassius Guiob-Badmos, Michaella L.G Soabes, Franco Beukes, Rachel Charlotte Smith, Heike Winschiers-Theophilus
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: In the absence of digital texts from minority groups, such as San from Southern Africa, public generative AI systems create responses that lack relevance and contextual understanding of local people. This study explores the relatability of AI-generated motivational stories from a Retrieval-Augmented Generation system accessing a curated knowledge base of previously collected real-life San youth experiences and San elder's wisdom proverbs. A focus group session was conducted with 46 members of the San community to collaboratively frame how AI could be used to generate culturally valid motivational stories to promote educational resilience. An AI story generation was simulated with San youth to determine relatability. Based on this, a fully functional prototype was developed, with a smart mirror interface, that detects basic emotions to trigger the construction of motivational stories for San youth. The system was evaluated through feedback sessions with youth and elders, focusing on emotional resonance, cultural appropriateness, and contextual understanding. Results showed that participants responded positively to stories grounded in their lived experiences and traditional wisdom, confirming the importance of contextual knowledge bases. The system was seen as a source of emotional encouragement; however, challenges such as limited literacy among users also highlighted the need for further development to make the tool fully inclusive and culturally grounded.

title: Admittance Passivation Design for LC-Type Grid-Tied Inverters Based on State Feedback Control
authors: Hengzhi Dai, Chuan Xie, Guangda Ma, Cheng Li, Zhiwei Zhao, Yuxin Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Passivity theory can ensure the external stability of LC/LCL-type grid-connected inverter (GCI) systems interacting with the grid, while state feedback control can satisfy internal stability requirements. However, traditional state feedback designs do not explicitly address passivity characteristics, potentially leading to non-passivity. To address this issue, this paper proposes a port admittance passivation method that integrates proportional state feedback with loop delay compensation. This approach mitigates the impact of delay-induced phase shifts and subsequently utilizes pole placement based on the delay compensation effect, thereby enhancing system passivity. Compared to existing methods, it achieves favorable reference tracking and load disturbance rejection capabilities while avoiding the complex pole-zero calculations typically involved in passivity design, significantly reducing the computational burden. And in both strong (SCR = 11) and weak (SCR=7) grid conditions, it can ensure the stability of the Grid-following inverter and the safe operation of the grid. Finally, experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed design.

title: Buck Converter MIL-HDBK-217F Reliability's Calculation Revision Using ANSI-VITA 51.1
authors: Dan Butnicu, Olimpian T. Paulet
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Despite a long history as a tool for use in performing reliability predictions on electronic equipment, in the last decade there is a need to update MIL-HDBK-217F to help restore the consistency and standard way of performing reliability predictions. Originally published in the mid-1990s, MIL-HDBK-217 Rev F, Notice 2 does not adequately reflect the performance characteristics or failure mechanisms of contemporary components such as high-efficiency dc-dc converters. There is an issue with the existing revision <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F}$</tex> (released in 1995). It has not been revised for some decades and is therefore outdated. Currently, the quality of parts being produced today is generally higher. The validity of revising MIL-HDBK-217 relies on leveraging work that has been performed by other organizations in the area of reliability prediction. Revision G (released 2008) will likely include updated MIL-HDBK-217 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pi$</tex> - stress factors determined by the VMEbus International Trade Association (VITA) industry working group in reliability, also named ANSI-VITA 51.1). In this work, a comparison is made between the genuine standard and his revision.

title: Quantum Dot Doped Polymer Optical Waveguide Amplifier
authors: Hayato Kitta, Takaaki Ishigure
publish: 2025 IEEE CPMT Symposium Japan (ICSJ)
abstract: In this paper, we fabricate polymer optical waveguides doped with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CdSe} / \text{ZnS}$</tex> quantum dots by applying the Mosquito method. The dependence of insertion loss and fluorescence intensity on the doping concentration is evaluated, and the potential application of these waveguides to optical amplifier devices is investigated.

title: Deep Learning-Driven Stock Market Forecasting Using Cloud-Based Financial Time Series Analytics
authors: Venkatraman Viswanathan, Anuj Kumar Shah, Chandra Sekhar Kubam, Sravanthi Dontu, Amita Gandhi, Priti Singla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The increasing demand for efficient resource utilization in cloud computing has highlighted the need for intelligent virtual machine (VM) consolidation strategies. Traditional VM scheduling methods often result in inefficient migrations, higher energy consumption, and frequent SLA violations due to unpredictable resource usage patterns. In the proposed methodology, a modified catkin optimization (MCO) algorithm is used for analyzing historical VM resource trends and applies a deep gradient-free local learning model for forecasting future usage. Stock market data, specifically the Shanghai Composite Index (000001) with 5951 trading days collected from Yahoo Finance (1997-2022), is used to model time-series behavior applicable to VM load trends. These predictions are used to optimize VM-to-host migration decisions, reducing unnecessary movements and improving overall efficiency. The results demonstrate that the model significantly reduces SLA violations, lowers energy consumption, and minimizes the number of VM migrations. The proposed framework showed up to 75 % fewer migrations, a 60 % drop in SLA violations, and up to 16 % energy savings compared to conventional methods.

title: Team Spirit [President’s Message]
authors: Christophe Fumeaux
publish: IEEE Antennas and Propagation Magazine
abstract: The last presidential message of the year offers a moment to reflect on the status and recent achievements of the Society. 2025 has been a tremendously active year for the IEEE Antennas and Propagation Society (AP-S), marked by ongoing transformation and unabated growth. It has been a unique honor to serve such a passionate, dedicated and welcoming community of professionals. Given the current scale of our Society and the breadth of its activities, teamwork naturally stands out as a defining element. The collaboration of our volunteers across our various committees has been both inspiring and essential to our continued success.

title: Song Genre Classification from Audio Data Using ML
authors: Arash Rahmani, Paulo Cesar Quadros, Rand Kouatly, Ahmed Hassan, Loubna Ali, Meerah Karunanithi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Using a dataset having songs of two music genres (Hip-Hop and Rock), We want to train a classifier to distinguish between the two genres based only on track information. We want to know if can we correctly classify a song's genre based on features such as danceability, energy, acousticness, tempo, etc. With the advantages of technology now more than ever people are using applications to listen to music and one of the music apps field of competition is how much will the app know about the music so that the companies would have more data to make the app better for the user. Does it know whether it is only Hip-Hop genre, Rock genre or the music contain a little bit of both and if so, how much of it is for which? We have found out that with using of machine learning we can understand the musics faster and more accurate from different and not so common features. And there is no one right answer. You can use different approaches. Developing a machine learning will lead to a more accurate and faster song recognition for user to use.

title: Identifying Framing Practices in Visualization Design Through Practitioner Reflections
authors: Prakash Shukla, Paul C. Parsons
publish: 2025 IEEE Seventh Workshop on Visualization for Communication (VisComm)
abstract: Framing—how designers define and reinterpret problems, shape narratives, and guide audience understanding—is central to design practice. Yet in visualization research, framing has been examined mostly through its rhetorical and perceptual effects on audiences, leaving its role in the design process underexplored. This study addresses that gap by analyzing publicly available podcasts and book chapters in which over 80 professional visualization designers reflect on their work. We find that framing is a pervasive, iterative activity, evident in scoping problems, interpreting data, aligning with stakeholder goals, and shaping narrative direction. Our analysis identifies the conditions that trigger reframing and the strategies practitioners use to navigate uncertainty and guide design. These findings position framing as a core dimension of visualization practice and underscore the need for research and education to support the interpretive and strategic judgment that practitioners exercise throughout the design process.

title: Simulation and Analysis of a Stacked Intelligent Metasurface (SIM) Architecture in a Real-World Scenario for 2D DFT Implementation
authors: Andrea Abrardo, Alberto Toccafondi
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: This paper presents a performance analysis of a non-ideal implementation of a Stacked Intelligent Metasurface (SIM) designed to realize a two-dimensional discrete Fourier transform (2D-DFT) transfer function. The study employs a multi-port network model based on the impedance (Z-) matrix representation, which accounts for mutual coupling between the layers of the SIM. The Z-matrix used in the optimization process is derived from numerical simulations of stacked layers composed of metallic strip dipoles over a finite ground plane. A comparison is presented and discussed between the resulting 2D-DFT responses in the realistic model, which includes couplings between non-adjacent layers, and the ideal model, which does not include such couplings.

title: BullyHCL: Unsupervised Heterogeneous Graph Contrastive Learning Framework for Session-based Cyberbullying Detection
authors: Munkhbuyan Buyankhishig, Thanda Shwe, Israel Mendonça, Masayoshi Aritsugi

title: Back from the Dead: Self-recovery Strategy for Modular Planetary Exploration Robots_supp4-3644668.mp4
authors: Ning Zhao
publish: N/A
abstract: The theoretical capability of modular robots to recover their original configuration or function after disintegration caused by external impacts has been cited as an advantage for planetary exploration. The key to achieving self-recovery lies in addressing the stochasticity of disintegration. Here, a self-recovery strategy is proposed for modular planetary exploration robots. Firstly, the recovery process is analyzed to construct a strategy framework and provide the problem definitions and strategy assumptions. Secondly, by standardizing the selection criteria for meta-modules under the stochasticity of disintegration, non-mobile modules can acquire mobility through the meta-module method, thereby laying the groundwork for executable self-recovery. Finally, a comprehensive optimization model is proposed, which encompasses the module interactions arising from stochastic disintegration. By integrating selfrecovery characteristics with the simulated annealing algorithm, a solution method is designed to obtain self-recovery plans. Extensive hardware experiments were conducted, and the results demonstrate that the self-recovery strategy operates stably and executes successfully across various configurations and scenarios, thereby validating the feasibility and reliability. In this way, the self-recovery strategy and experiments could substantially advance the application of modular robots in space exploration, while also providing insights for other areas, such as assembly planning and applications involving non-mobile modular robots.
