title: Learning Latent Multimodal Dynamics for Optimized Resource Planning
authors: Charbel Bou Chaaya, Abanoub M. Girgis, Mehdi Bennis
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: In this work, we study the joint scheduling and power allocation problem of vision-based remote control systems, where multiple devices upload their image states to a central controller and receive control actions. Due to the high dimensionality of the image states and to manage the lack of radio resources, we propose a novel self-supervised learning approach to predict the devices’ joint control and wireless dynamics in latent space, enabling wireless resource optimization without compromising the control objectives of the remote control system. Our method leverages two coupled joint-embedding predictive architectures (JEPAs): a control JEPA models the control transition dynamics and guides the predictions of a wireless JEPA, which captures the dynamics of the device’s channel state information (CSI) through cross-modal conditioning. We then train a deep reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm to derive a control policy from latent control dynamics and a power predictor to estimate scheduling slots with favorable channel conditions based on latent CSI representations. To enhance control reliability, we employ an efficient ensemble technique to estimate the uncertainty of JEPA predictions. The two JEPAs are used by the remote controller to forecast future latent trajectories of the devices’ control and wireless states, allowing the controller to proactively plan its scheduling policy using model predictive control (MPC). Simulation results, conducted in a customized image-based control environment with ray tracing, demonstrate that our proposed approach converges three times faster and reduces transmit power by over 50% while maintaining control performance comparable to baseline methods that do not account for wireless resource optimization.

title: To Optimize Edge-Intelligent Cooperative Perception in Heterogeneous Vehicular Networks
authors: Guozhi Yan, Kai Liu, Chunhui Liu, Lingjie Duan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Cooperative Perception (CP) has been a promising paradigm to enhance single-vehicle awareness by enabling perception sharing among connected vehicles. However, existing studies often overlook the impact of constrained and heterogeneous edge resources, leading to synchronization bottlenecks and limited deployment efficiency. To address these challenges, this paper proposes EI-Cooper, an Edge Intelligence (EI)-enhanced cooperative framework for adaptive and efficient CP in heterogeneous vehicular networks. The novelty of EI-Cooper is fourfold. First, we leverage key EI techniques including selective cooperation, model pruning and bandwidth allocation to jointly coordinate the perception, computation, communication within the CP pipeline. To the best of our knowledge, EI-Cooper represents the first attempt to extend CP with EI capabilities. Secondly, we formulate a <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</u>ynchronization-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">E</u>fficient <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">C</u>ooperative <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">P</u>erception (SECP) problem, which jointly determines edge selection, pruning ratios and bandwidths to balance end-to-end synchronization efficiency and perception accuracy. Thirdly, to tackle the closed-box nature and computational NP-hardness of SECP, we decompose it into two interpretable subproblems, respectively capturing macro-level spatial completeness and micro-level semantic retention. Finally, we develop a <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">T</u>wo-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</u>tage <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">H</u>ierarchical <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">O</u>ptimization (TSHO) algorithm, where the first stage maximizes coverage via submodular node selection with a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$(1-1/e)$</tex-math></inline-formula> approximation, and the second stage performs alternating optimization of pruning and bandwidth allocation under convergence guarantees. Extensive experiments on public datasets and a real-world prototype demonstrate the superiority of EI-Cooper.

title: DOA Estimation of Non-Circular Signals with Nested Arrays: a Block Tensor Sparse Representation
authors: Xudong Dong, Jun Zhao, Zhenhua Zhou, Peipei Chen, Han Zhang, Xiaoyu Dang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper addresses the direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation problem for non-circular signals in nested arrays through a block tensor sparse representation (TSR) framework. By establishing a 3D tensor dictionary that jointly discretizes the angular and non-circular phase domains, we formulate the multiparameter estimation as a constrained tensor recovery task. The proposed block TSR framework introduces a block diagonalized tensor decomposition scheme that enables parallel subproblem optimization while preserving parameter coupling, then the estimates of DOA are obtained by Lasso's algorithm. Simulation results show that the proposed method can still achieve higher angle estimation accuracy with lower signal-to-noise ratio compared with the classical sparse representation and state of the art block sparse representation methods.

title: Privacy-Preserving Deep Learning for Disease Diagnosis in Medical Imaging: A Systematic Review
authors: Md Wahidur Rahman, Md. Rahat Khan, Mais Nijim
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Medical imaging plays a crucial role in the diagnosis of various diseases, including cancer, cardiovascular conditions, and respiratory disorders such as asthma, pneumonia, and even COVID-19. Nowadays, Deep Learning (DL) has demonstrated remarkable accuracy in disease detection and diagnosis using medical imaging such as X-rays, CT scans, and MRIs. However, DL models mostly require access to sensitive patient data not only to capture the images but also to store them in the data cloud, which raises major privacy concerns. To solve this problem, several techniques such as Differential Privacy (DP) and Federated Learning (FL), have been developed. These methods allow models to learn useful patterns without exposing personal details. Building on these developments, the key gap this review targets is the lack of a recent, side-by-side analysis that connects medical tasks, DL architectures, FL designs, and DP budgets with real-world performance and resilience against privacy attacks. Motivated by this gap, we conducted a systematic review of the literature (SLR) of studies published between 2023 and 2025 that used DL principles with privacy-preserving methods for medical diagnosis. Utilizing the PRISMA framework, we reviewed 23 peer-reviewed articles and grouped them into four categories: included COVID-19, skin lesions, Alzheimer’s disease, and other conditions such as diabetic retinopathy, kidney disease, and heart problems. We sort results by modality, model family, FL topology, DP mechanism, and reported threat model. Furthermore, the review significantly represents that CNN-based models with DP and FL methods are the most common choices, and developed pipelines with these models often achieve accuracy above 90%. At the same time, the review found gaps such as limited real-world testing, a lack of diverse datasets, and underuse of advanced DP approaches. Based on these results, we recommend building larger and more varied datasets, improving privacy-utility trade-offs, and testing models in clinical environments.

title: Dynamic Optimization of Underground Metal Mine Blending Based on the U-FDT-C-TAEA Algorithm
authors: Zhongqiang Chen, Qi Wang, Pingcheng Song, Haibo Dou, Xinying Ju, Yumeng Shen
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: To address key production challenges such as unstable ore output caused by the wide distribution and strong fluctuation of ore grades in underground metal mines, a multi-metal and multi-objective blending optimization model was established with four object ives: maximizing profit, minimizing dynamic grade fluctuation, minimizing production deviation, and minimizing ore type blending ratio. To effectively address uncertainty, the Uncertainty-Aware Feasibility Boundary Tracking Constrained Archival Evolution Algorithm (U-FDT-C-TAEA) is proposed by integrating uncertainty perception and feasibility boundary tracking into the classical Constrained Archival Evolution Algorithm (C-TAEA). First, the uncertainty-weighted congestion distance (U-WCD) mechanism is introduced to enhance the distribution robustness of the solution set by evaluating the stability of target response under multi-disturbance scenarios. Second, a feasibility drift tracker (FDT) mechanism is designed to improve the efficiency of screening and retaining potential feasible solutions by dynamically tracking the evolution trends of infeasible solutions near the constraint boundaries. This approach is further combined with Monte Carlo simulations to account for random variations in key parameters. A monthly production case study from an underground metal mine demonstrates that, under the same production plan, the optimized scheme reduces total ore output by 4.42%, increases the expected profit to 5.85×1011 CNY, controls production deviation within 27.80%, and maintains ore type blending ratios below 41.2%. Overall, the proposed approach outperforms the original and benchmark algorithms, significantly improving the mine’s economic efficiency.

title: Fed-WGCA:A Federated Learning Framework With Coordinate Attention and WGAN for Enhanced Performance
authors: Ya Liu, Yufan Zhai, Bo Qu, Hai Xue, Xianbei Liu
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Federated Learning inherently faces the challenge of balancing privacy protection and classification accuracy due to the risks associated with parameter sharing and the limitations of model performance. This paper proposes Fed-WGCA, a novel federated learning framework that integrates Wasserstein GAN with Gradient Penalty (WGAN-GP) and Coordinate Attention mechanisms. WGAN-GP enhances data privacy by generating high-quality synthetic data, mitigates the impact of imbalanced samples, and significantly improves model stability and performance. The Coordinate Attention mechanism optimizes feature extraction by fusing spatial and channel information. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework Fed-WGCA separately achieves accuracy improvements of 5.99% and 6.12% on the Fashion-MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets compared with state-of-the-art best results while exhibiting enhanced robustness against membership inference, image reconstruction attacks and poisoning attack.

title: Identifying Influential Nodes in Complex Networks: A Neighborhood Potential-Edge-Weight Gravity Centrality
authors: Ru Feng, Yali Wu, Chen Zhang, Jiangtao Wei, Yanxi Yang, Yanghu Hu, Zhenhua Su
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Identifying influential nodes in complex networks has developed into a prominent research focus. Classical centrality measures such as degree centrality (DC), betweenness centrality (BC), and K-shell (KS) are increasingly being supplemented or replaced by more effective gravity-based alternatives such as gravity centrality (GC), KS based on GC (KSGC), and GGC. However, existing gravity-based methods further enhance node quality based on single attributes, often neglecting the crucial role of edges as communication channels for information dissemination in unweighted networks. A neighborhood potential-edge-weight gravity centrality (NPGC) considering both the degree of node and the information interaction capability of its neighbors for identifying key nodes is proposed. The potential edge weights, which represent the strength of information interaction between nodes, are defined to capture neighborhood information. The simulation of SIR model is employed on nine real-world unweighted and undirected datasets to assess the efficiency of NPGC. Experimental results show that, compared with eight existing methods, the proposed method has high accuracy and good differentiation.

title: Dynamic Coordination-Decoupling Control Strategy for Torsional Vibration Suppression and Power Stability in Electro-mechanical Transmission Systems under Asymmetric Load Conditions
authors: Dianzhao Yang, Hui Liu, Pu Gao, Qi Yan, Wei Zhang, Jiaxin Jiao, Changle Xiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: With the rapid electrification of construction machinery, the Electro-Mechanical Transmission (EMT) system for heavy-duty tracked vehicles has emerged as a core power unit. The coupling effects of its dual power output ports under asymmetric load conditions exacerbate the coordination challenges between torsional vibration suppression and speed stability control, leading to transmission failures in complex transient scenarios such as unilateral track sinking or encountering obstacles. To address this, the paper investigates the dual-motor coupled-drive EMT, revealing the impact mechanisms of vibration energy coupling effects on dynamic behaviors under asymmetric loads. Based on the discovery of this effect, an EMT input-output decoupling control framework is proposed. By employing dynamic compensation for asymmetric disturbances and incorporating considerations of the dynamic response-elastic oscillation trade-off into the control framework, an EMT dynamic coordination-decoupling control strategy for torsional vibration suppression and power stability is ultimately developed. Simulation and experiments validate that this strategy is capable of addressing the dynamic response-elastic oscillation trade-off under asymmetric load conditions, significantly reducing system torsional vibrations while maintaining output power stability.

title: Moiré-Effect-Inspired Reconfigurable Electromagnetic Wavefront Modulation Based on Cascaded Metasurfaces
authors: Yusheng Yang, Dongfang Guan, Zhangbiao Yang, Hantao Xu, YiHao Xu, Yongxiang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a novel Moiré-effect-inspired reconfigurable electromagnetic wavefront modulation method based on cascaded metasurface, achieving dynamic conical beam generation with a variable tensor angle. The phase distribution is transformed from Cartesian coordinate to polar coordinates to meet the requirements of the Moiré effect. By rotating the cascaded metasurface, the Moiré effect is excited, achieving changes in the equivalent total phase, thereby realizing the reconfigurable tensor angle of the conical beam, which is a challenging yet important issue that is difficult to achieve in traditional conical beamforming. Furthermore, a low-loss transmission unit is designed for constructing the proposed Moiré-effect-inspired electromagnetic modulator and experimental verification, which is designed to overcome the high loss introduced by the cascaded metasurface structure. Simulation and measurement results indicate that the proposed device can generate conical beams with different and discrete tensor angles by rotating the cascaded metasurfaces. The proposed modulator achieves reconfigurable conical beamforming while avoiding the complex reconfigurable feeding networks and substantial loading of active components in traditional reconfigurable methods. Owing to its passive structure, the system offers a compact and cost-effective solution for reconfigurable conical beamforming in 6G communications.

title: Low Earth Orbit Satellite (LEOS)-Assisted Integrated Access and Backhauling in xG Wireless Communication: A Generalizable RL Framework
authors: Fahime Khoramnejad, Ekram Hossain
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: In next-generation (xG) wireless communication networks, developing generalizable learning models that inherently adapt to diverse conditions is crucial. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning (RL) framework for subchannel (SC) allocation in low Earth orbit satellite (LEOS)-assisted integrated access and backhauling (IAB) networks. We consider an integrated terrestrial-satellite network, where a LEOS provides backhaul services to cellular base stations (BSs) in remote areas while forwarding data from mobile user equipments (UEs) to the core network. The objective is to maximize the achievable rate for UEs while satisfying demand requirements and backhaul constraints. To ensure generalizable and efficient SC allocation across environments, we formulate the resource management problem as an invariant policy learning framework, which is decomposed into two subproblems: state representation learning and policy optimization. Our approach learns state representations that remain invariant across diverse environments. Additionally, the invariant policy, obtained from the hypergraph output layer, captures the fundamental causes of successful actions, enabling robust decision-making. By embedding problem constraints into both the model architecture and the training objective, the framework enhances the transparency of the invariant policy optimization process. Furthermore, we derive a data-dependent generalization bound that characterizes the policy’s performance in unseen environments. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed policy consistently outperforms traditional methods across multiple environments.

title: Sensing as a Service: Can In-Band Distributed Fiber Optic Sensing Coexist With Coherent Metro DWDM Communication Network?
authors: Jingchuan Wang, Alan Pak Tao Lau, Chao Lu
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Distributed fiber optic sensing (DFOS) holds significant promise for providing real-time monitoring and surveillance capabilities in deployed metro networks. By leveraging dense wavelength-division multiplexing (DWDM) technology, sensing channels can be integrated alongside communication channels, thereby enabling simultaneous high-capacity data transmission and fiber sensing application. However, because of the shared propagation path, fiber nonlinearities can induce significant crosstalk between the communication and sensing channels, particularly in metro pointtopoint (P2P) links longer than 80 km. In this paper, we investigate the in-band WDM coexistence case of distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) and communication channels over metro link, considering both co-propagating and counter-propagating configurations. Penalties in communication channels, due to fiber nonlinearities caused by DAS pulse, are comprehensively analyzed through numerical simulations and experimental demonstrations across the full C-band, with a 40<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\lambda \times$</tex-math></inline-formula> 800Gb/s = 32Tb/s line-rate coherent transmission over a 90km fiber span. As less reported, the adverse effects on communication channels of stimulated Raman scattering (SRS) and nonlinear polarization rotation are investigated when the coexistence system utilizes conventional pulse-based DAS setup. In coexistence system, we observe that nonlinear polarization rotation can present a greater challenge to the receiver digital signal processing (DSP) of communication receiver than the commonly believed cross-phase modulation (XPM) induced phase noise. Furthermore, by comparing pulse-based DAS with pulse-compression DAS, our findings indicate that pulse-compression DAS imposes negligible performance penalties on legacy coherent receivers, highlighting its significant potential for adoption in future integrated sensing and communication coexistence systems.

title: Adversarial Attack Priors-Based Non-Divergence Diffusion Equation Model for SAR Speckle Removal
authors: Li Cheng, Zhichang Guo, Lifan Zhou, Hanwen Yu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Multiplicative Gamma noise poses a major challenge in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imaging, severely degrading image quality and complicating downstream interpretation tasks. Although deep learning techniques have demonstrated remarkable denoising capabilities, their performance often deteriorates on real-world data due to deviations from idealized noise models and various environmental interferences. To address these limitations, we propose a novel speckle noise removal model, named AAP-NDE, based on a non-divergence diffusion equation guided by adversarial attack priors. By incorporating prior knowledge of potential adversarial perturbations, the model adaptively adjusts diffusion coefficients: larger coefficients are applied in homogeneous or heavily corrupted regions to suppress noise effectively, while smaller coefficients are employed near edges and fine structures to preserve critical image details.We theoretically establish the existence and uniqueness of the model solution, ensuring mathematical soundness. Extensive experiments on synthetic and real SAR images demonstrate that AAP-NDE achieves strong robustness against adversarial attacks, consistently outperforming state-of-the-art methods in both noise suppression and structure preservation. These results highlight the potential of AAP-NDE for reliable and practical SAR image processing in challenging scenarios.

title: Evaluating the Influence of Interest Rates on Rooftop Solar Power Investments in Indonesia: A Techno-Economic Perspective
authors: Aryo De Wibowo Muhammad Sidik, Chris Salim, Anggy Pradiftha Junfithrana, Meiliani Luckieta, Alfonsus B Say, Reza Suriansha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Indonesia, with its strategic location on the equator, boasts an abundance of solar energy, making rooftop solar power systems (RSPS) a promising solution for sustainable electricity generation. However, the financial viability of these systems is significantly influenced by fluctuating interest rates. This study aims to assess how changes in interest rates impact the techno-economic performance of RSPS in Indonesia. Using HOMER Pro software, the research simulates different interest rate scenarios—low, medium, and high—to examine how they affect key technical factors, such as the optimal PV configuration and energy output, as well as economic metrics like capital costs, operating expenses, and return on investment (ROI). The findings reveal that while interest rates do not directly alter the technical aspects of the systems, they have a notable effect on the economic side. Higher interest rates lead to increased operating costs and a rise in the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE), making the systems less financially attractive. These results underscore the importance of considering economic variables like interest rates when planning solar energy projects and suggest that future policies should account for financial fluctuations to ensure optimal investment strategies.

title: Power Flow Control in Hybrid Microgrids Using Unified Interphase Power Controller
authors: Henna Dulkifily Sahira, Mabel Ebenezer
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: A hybrid microgrid uses a variety of energy generation and storage technologies to reliably and effectively meet the demand for electricity. It combines conventional energy resources such as natural gas generators with renewable energy sources like solar photovoltaic (PV)s, wind turbines and hydroelectric generators. In a hybrid microgrid, power flow control is essential to preserve stability, maximize resource use and incorporate renewable energy sources. Effective control strategies guarantee that power generation matches demand with a variety of resources including solar PV, wind and storage, preventing voltage and frequency instabilities. The power flow of hybrid microgrids can be controlled using converters and flexible AC transmission systems (FACTs) devices. Droop control method and unified interphase power controller (UIPC) will be discussed here. UIPC offers a potential solution by coordinating series and shunt converters to manage both real and reactive power flow dynamically.

title: True Random Number Generation with Pdl and Bias Reduction: a Nist Sp 800-22 Conforming Design
authors: Gunturu Sindhuja, D Muralidharan, Ananth Hari R, Gugan G S, Aishwarya M, Sivaraman R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: This work investigates the enhancement of True Random Number Generators (TRNGs) using Programmable Delay Logic (PDL). It examines how PDL influences the entropy and randomness of the generated random numbers. Furthermore, post-processing techniques were applied to remove bias and whiten the data. The methods we applied were: Von Neumann Compression, Serial and parallel LFSR-based whitening. The randomness of the data generated after postprocessing was statistically analyzed using the NIST Statistical Test Suite, specifically the NIST SP 800-22 Test. Autocorrelation and Hamming Distance were also performed to analyze the randomness. Hardware resource analysis was performed, comparing the power dissipated, the number of logic elements (LEs) used, and the block RAM used across all five architectures. Upon analysis, it was concluded that a PDL-based TRNG with a parallel LFSR as a post-processing technique generated highly random data, as it passed all 16 NIST tests while dissipating optimal power, consuming 3 % of the total LEs and 53.6% of the overall block RAM to produce 2 million true random bits.

title: Modeling of Pseudo-Measurement Physical Quantities Based on Differentiated Distributed Photovoltaic Grid-Connection Control Modes and Distribution Network State Estimation
authors: Rui Wang, Yuting Hua, Yueming Yu, Chen Luo, Lei Ding
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The large-scale integration of distributed photovoltaic (DPV) into the power system presents challenges for state estimation. Especially when some nodes lack actual measurement devices, pseudo-measurement techniques become essential for supplementing measurement data. This paper proposes a pseudo-measurement physical quantity modeling method for DPV grid-connected nodes without actual measurement devices, focusing on different grid-connected control modes. First, the output characteristics of three typical grid-connected control modes (PQ type, PV type, and PI type) of DPV are analyzed. Next, corresponding pseudo-measurement physical quantities are designed for each mode's core control objective, and a state estimation model is developed. Finally, simulation results verify that the proposed model meets the requirements of state estimation accuracy, thereby confirming the validity of the proposed pseudo-measurement physical quantity modeling method and the state estimation model.

title:
Regulating Electronic Structure of Sub-2 nm IrO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Nanocrystals with N Atoms for Enhanced Acidic Oxygen Evolution Performance
authors: Ligang Chen, Chunji Li, Wei Zhao, Maorong Chai
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: One of the key factors hindering the commercial application of proton exchange membrane water electrolysis is the high cost and low performance of anodic Ir-based electrocatalysts. Here we report an excellent Ir-based electrocatalyst consisting of sub-2 nm IrO2 nanocrystals (NCs) attached to porous <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N$</tex>-doped carbon supports <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(S N-I r O_{2} / P N C\right)$</tex>, exhibiting a high oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activity with a low overpotential of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$259 \text{mV}\left(10 \text{mA} \cdot \text{cm}^{-2}\right)$</tex> and high mass activity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.936 \text{mA} \cdot \mu_{g_{I r}}{ }^{-2}$</tex> at an overpotential of 300 mV and excellent stability of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 h$</tex> in acidic electrolytes. The formation of sub-2 nm <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{IrO}_{2} \text{NCs}$</tex> with an average size of about 1 nm is mainly attributed to the porosity of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N$</tex>-doped carbon substrate. Physicochemical characterization results show that the introduction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N$</tex> atom plays an important role in regulating the electronic structure of sub-2 nm IrO2 NCs, which is conducive to improving the catalytic performance. Density functional theory calculations reveal that the adsorption of the active site Ir to the intermediate oxygen-containing species is weakened after the introduction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N$</tex> atom into the carbon support, thus reducing the reaction free energy of the rate-determining step toward OER.

title: Comparative Analysis of Unsupervised Approaches for Land Cover Identification in a Localized Region Using Sentinel-2 Spectral Data
authors: Theeraya Uttha, Jantima Polpinij, Chunpong Chan, Anirut Chothanom, Chumsak Sibunruang, Thananchai Khamket
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: Land cover classification is vital for environmental monitoring, agricultural management, and urban planning. However, conventional supervised methods depend heavily on labeled datasets, which are costly and scarce in localized regions. This study investigates unsupervised approaches for land cover identification using Sentinel-2 imagery collected from the Kantarawichai District in Thailand. A dataset comprising 211 manually delineated regions was extracted, with each region represented by a normalized 10-dimensional spectral vector. Five unsupervised methods were evaluated: k-Means, Hierarchical Clustering, DBSCAN, Self-Organizing Maps (SOM), and Autoencoder-based Clustering. Experimental results show that Autoencoder-based Clustering achieved superior performance, yielding the highest Silhouette Score (0.62), the lowest Davies-Bouldin Index (0.62), and the best Adjusted Rand Index (0.71), indicating its effectiveness in capturing non-linear spectral relationships and enhancing cluster separability. SOM also delivered strong results, while traditional methods and DBSCAN exhibited moderate to lower performance due to their limitations in handling high-dimensional spectral data. Overall, the findings highlight that unsupervised techniques, especially those involving representation learning, offer a promising solution for land cover mapping in data-scarce environments without relying on external labeled datasets. Future work will explore integrating spatial information to further improve classification accuracy.

title: A Software-Based Approach to Optimize LoRa Antenna Positioning
authors: Dennis Kerr Coelho, Anita Maria da Rocha Fernandes, Mauricio de Campos, Jordan Passinato Sausen, Rudimar Luis Scaranto Dazzi, Fabio Focking
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: Ensuring an efficient communication network is fundamental to the performance and scalability of Internet of Things (IoT)-based monitoring systems. Low-Power Wide Area Network (LPWAN) technologies, such as Lora WAN, offer long-range data transmission capabilities combined with low power consumption, making them suitable for a wide range of monitoring applications. However, identifying optimal locations for antenna deployment remains a complex challenge due to terrain, environmental conditions, and signal propagation constraints. This paper presents the development of a software application designed to support the optimization of LoRa antenna placement using spatial analysis and radio frequency propagation models. The tool provides practical support for environmental, urban, and rural monitoring projects.

title: LSTM-CNN for Real-Time Financial Forecasting on Cloud Infrastructure
authors: Anjani Kumar Polinati, Shashank Majety, Chandra Sekhar Kubam, Vivek Ghatala, Varun Malik, Sanjay Singla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: In today's complex and volatile financial ecosystem, accurate forecasting of capital flow and market trends is essential for strategic planning, risk mitigation, and economic decision-making. Traditional financial forecasting models often fail to capture the nonlinearities and sudden shifts in time series data, particularly under conditions of high volatility and uncertainty. This research addresses these limitations by proposing a cloud-enabled hybrid deep learning model that integrates long short-term memory (LSTM) and convolutional neural network (CNN) for real-time financial forecasting. The main objective of this study is to enhance the predictive accuracy of capital inflow and outflow trends while improving the robustness and scalability of the forecasting process using cloud infrastructure. The proposed model leverages the red kite optimization (RKO) algorithm to intelligently allocate and optimize cloud computing resources, ensuring efficient deployment and execution of deep learning models. Experimental evaluations were performed on the financial dataset provided by the Alibaba cloud “Capital Flow Input/ Output Prediction” competition. The proposed CNN-LSTM model achieved an accuracy of 94.38 % and RMSE as low as 0.2024, outperforming ARIMA and other benchmark models. Additionally, RKO-based optimization improved CPU utilization to 80.1 % and reduced resource cost to $0.225/hour while maintaining high resource availability at 99.853 %. This work confirms the potential of combining deep learning techniques with cloud computing and metaheuristic optimization for real-time, high-accuracy financial forecasting applications.

title: Power Quality Characteristics of Electric Vehicle Charging Facilities
authors: Dai Shaojun, Liu Jianben, Li Ni, Yin Ting, Ni Yuan, Lu Yao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The development of electric vehicle charging facilities has been extremely rapid in recent years. The power quality issues of charging facilities have also become increasingly important. Traditionally, it was believed that the performance of charging piles based on PWM rectification technology was excellent, with no harmonic components in the AC current waveform and the current phase fully tracking the corresponding phase voltage. As a result, it was thought that there were no power quality problems. However, the charging piles and stations that have actually been put into operation have exhibited characteristics such as current waveform distortion and the current phase leading the voltage. At present, there is no clear research conclusion on whether these problems are isolated phenomena or common issues. This paper selects several typical DC charging piles and large-scale charging stations for field measurements. Through extensive data analysis, it has been clarified harmonic current and capacitive reactive power are common phenomena in charging piles and stations. A method using the APF device is proposed to solve the harmonic and reactive power problems of charging piles and stations, and the correctness and feasibility of the proposed method has been verified by the simulation results.

title: Coordinated Optimization Strategy for EV Reserve Potential Assessment and Real-Time Scheduling Considering User Willingness
authors: Wangchao Dong, Jinjin Ding, Bo Peng, Wenguang Zhao, Zheng Tian, Hongbin Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To improve the feasibility and incentive adaptability of EV cluster participation in demand response and V2G interaction, this paper proposes a hierarchical strategy integrating user response modeling, reserve potential assessment, and real-time rolling scheduling. A behavioralbased willingness function and response rate model capture the nonlinear relation between subsidies and participation. Reserve capacity is then evaluated considering charging constraints and SOC limits. Finally, the results guide a slidingwindow scheduling model with dynamic pricing and subsidies. Simulations show the strategy enhances grid flexibility, increases user benefits, and ensures alignment between reserve estimation and real-time execution.

title: Voltage Variation Estimation in Wind Farms Using Mlp Neural Networks
authors: Juan Magalhães B. de Oliveira, Denis V. Coury, Ricardo A. S. Fernandes, Mario Oleskovicz
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This study presents the application of Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) in the context of Power Quality (PQ) for the voltage estimation in a wind farm, aiming at monitoring voltage variation during short-circuit events in the electrical system. The objective is not monitoring directly the PQ regulation in the Point of Common Coupling, but estimate the voltages at the ends of the wind turbine circuits during short-circuit events. The integration of distributed generation into power systems poses significant challenges to PQ, both in monitoring and in managing the voltage profile, mainly due to the absence of measurement devices along feeder branches. In this context, this study proposes an alternative approach to estimate the RMS voltage magnitudes at wind turbine terminals, based on ANNs. The Power Systems Computer Aided Design (PSCAD) software is employed to model the studied power system, which is based on a real wind farm, as well as to generate the training and validation datasets for the aforementioned ANNs. The study results highlight the potential of the proposed approach, since 80.5% to 98.9% of the monitored RMS voltages were correctly calculated by the ANNs under single-line-to-ground fault conditions.

title: Enhancement of Sensitivity and Dynamic Range of 550-850 MHz Upgraded GMRT Receiver System
authors: Imran Khan, Ankur, S. Sureshkumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: The Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope (GMRT), operating in the 50-1450 MHz range, has undergone a major upgrade to enhance its sensitivity and bandwidth. In this work, we present a focused improvement to the GMRT 550-850 MHz system, achieving a measured sensitivity enhancement of approximately 1.6 dB through targeted reductions in receiver system temperature. Given the relatively low sky temperature in this frequency range, even modest reductions in receiver noise translate into significant gains in overall system sensitivity. Two key approaches were implemented. First, the frontend electronics were restructured by relocating the receiver system directly behind the feed, thereby minimizing pre-LNA losses from 0.5 dB to 0.1 dB. This architectural optimization yielded a sensitivity improvement of approximately 0.8 dB. Second, a new low-noise amplifier (LNA) was designed, offering enhanced performance with a noise temperature of 25 K, a gain of 35 dB, and improved dynamic range compared to the existing LNA. This design not only reduces the receiver noise temperature but also ensures linear operation under high signal conditions, thus improving the dynamic range of the entire receiver chain and the sensitivity by around 1 dB. The combined effect of these modifications leads to a substantial enhancement in GMRT antenna sensitivity, making it more effective for low-frequency astronomical observations.

title: Optimal Strategy for Smart Pole-Based Multi-Energy System Considering Sleep Mechanism of 5G Base Station
authors: Ai Du, Lucheng Hong, Zihan Zhu, Yuan Gao, Ziqiu Wang, Xingrui Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: 5G smart poles feature communication, energy, and sensing functions, enabling versatile applications across diverse areas. However, integrating multiple high-power devices, 5G smart poles often operate at full load without energy optimization, resulting in high power consumption and low energy efficiency. To address this issue, this paper proposes a coordinated optimization strategy for smart pole-based multi-energy system. Firstly, modeling of components in the system is constructed, including PV, charging piles, energy storage, lighting equipment, and 5G base stations. Secondly, following the introduction of a sleep mechanism for 5G base stations, a spatial migration scheduling model is formulated to optimize inter-station communication load redistribution, so as to reduce load consumption. Thirdly, aiming to minimize energy operation cost and maximize lighting safety, a coordinated scheduling strategy for multi-energy system is established. Finally, simulation experiments based on three typical areas validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in improving energy efficiency and coordination.

title: Lunar Satellite Position Estimation Based on Monocular Vision Localization
authors: Peng Cheng Hu, Bo Wen Li, De Yue Zou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: Lunar satellite navigation plays a vital role in future lunar exploration. Traditional ground-based pose estimation methods for lunar satellites encounter significant challenges, including ground control delays, restricted visibility of the lunar far side, and the lack of fixed monitoring stations. Therefore, achieving autonomous lunar navigation is essential. By leveraging the Moon's atmosphere-free environment and abundant craters, we integrate the monocular Perspective-n-Point (PnP) algorithm into lunar satellite positioning. By capturing lunar surface images, extracting Two-Dimensional (2D) crater feature points, and matching them with Three-Dimensional (3D) point cloud coordinates, the PnP algorithm calculates the satellite camera’s orientation and position. We theoretically elaborate on this method and validate its effectiveness through simulations. Experimental results demonstrate sub-millimeter localization accuracy, high computational efficiency, and robust stability across complex environments, providing a solid theoretical foundation for lunar pose estimation tasks.

title: Disaster Prediction in Data-Scarce Regions: A Comparative Study of Random Forest and XGBoost for Flood Severity Classification
authors: Nimra Mirza Baig, Qudsia Fatima, Rumaisa Ameena, Mohammad Pasha, Mohd Umar Farooq, Nasir Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Given the significant need for flood hazard early warning systems in monitoring scarce regions, producing reliable flood susceptibility assessments poses major challenges. This study develops a novel flood risk prediction framework combining unsupervised feature selection with ensemble learning to enhance accuracy in data deficient environments. The framework is accepted in flood prone basins of Eastern India using two refined models namely Random Forest and XGBoost. We benchmark against traditional methods using ROC curves and quantitative interpretability metrics. The integrated approach improves AUC by 5.2 percent over baseline RF while enhancing feature explainability. This methodology effectively mitigates prediction uncertainty caused by incomplete flood records, providing a transferable solution for global flood risk zones with limited observational infrastructure.

title: Reconnecting Artifacts and Place: A Review of Situated Visualization in Cultural Heritage
authors: Markus Passecker, Victor A. de Jesus Oliveira, Paolo Buono, Silvia Miksch, Wolfgang Aigner
publish: 2025 IEEE Workshop on Visualization for the Digital Humanities (VIS4DH)
abstract: Despite the growing availability of digitized cultural heritage (CH) data, these artifacts are often disconnected from their original locations or contexts. This disconnection represents a missed opportunity to combine situated visualization, augmented reality (AR), and CH in ways that meaningfully embed digital information into physical spaces. We conducted a systematic literature review to explore this potential but identified only 17 relevant papers, suggesting that this intersection is underexplored in academic research. Our findings reveal inconsistencies in terminology across disciplines, limited cross-disciplinary integration, and a stronger emphasis on user experience within Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) than on visualization. This suggests that much of the practical innovation in this area may currently reside outside formal research settings, missing opportunities to establish evaluation standards and reusable frameworks.

title: Wave Inversion Technology via System Identification and Adaptive Optimization
authors: Dongdong Mu, Guilin Xue, Yongsheng Zhao, Yukun Hu, Hongbiao Li, Jiasong Li, Yunsheng Fan, Xu Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Aiming at the problem of wave interference during the navigation of unmanned surface vehicles (USVs), this paper focuses on the issue of real-time acquisition of wave information to transform unknown disturbances into known ones, so as to provide a basis for better compensating wave interference in subsequent USV control. Specifically, a method combining system identification and adaptive optimization based on ship motion responses is proposed for real-time wave inversion. First, an Autoregressive model of the system is constructed to identify motion reaction function of ship. Second, the normalized singular value technique determines the order of ship model. The Recursive Least Squares method estimates the model parameters. Furthermore, wave parameters are obtained in real time using the adaptive optimization’s initial frequency response identification. Finally, the simulation results obtained from different scenarios based on SimuNPS demonstrate the accuracy and feasibility of the proposed method.

title: Optimal Control and Real-Time Simulation Validation of Large-Scale Electric Vehiecles Paticipating in Frequency Regulation
authors: Xun Jiang, Meiqin Mao, Xing Ge
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Large-scale electric vehicles (EVs) can be aggregated into flexible frequency regulation resources for the power system. However, the overall regulation capacity of EV Aggregator (EVA) is susceptible to the randomness of EVs' behaviors and the prices in the frequency regulation market, increasing the complexity and risk of the frequency control in the power system. To address the problem, in terms of the frequency regulation market mechanism, two-layer stochastic optimal frequency control model with EVA is developed in this paper. The first layer takes the frequency regulation cost as the optimization objective and the frequency deviation as the probability constraint to optimize the dispatch power of different frequency regulation players, such as EVAs and thermal power plants. The second layer adopts a multivariate Gaussian Copula function to formulate an optimal decomposition of EVA's dispatch instructions considering the EVs' risk preferences and the randomness of the electricity prices. Incorporating an EVA with 15000 EVs into regional grid frequency regulation, the IEEE39 node model is implemented by using a real-time simulation platform to validate the proposed model. The obtained results can provide technical support for the risky decision-making of frequency regulation of the power system with EVAs.

title: Modeling Methodology for Cascade Utilization of Waste Heat in Integrated Cooling, Heating, and Power Systems for HVDC Converter Stations
authors: Qihao Zhang, Jiehai Xu, Weijie Zhao, Sidun Fang, Chengjun Zhou, Wei Xiao, Shaojie Chen, Haofeng Zhang, Zheng Zhong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Combined cooling, heating, and power (CCHP) systems driven by internal combustion engines (ICE) have been prominently applied in integrated energy systems (IES) for their energy-saving potential, economic benefits, and operational flexibility under variable loads. However, existing frameworks still fail to fully harness their multi-energy coordination capabilities and dynamic adaptability. To address this, this study establishes an energy system morphology based on urban and energy structure analyses, constructs reliability assessment and uncertainty models to form an integrated energy system (IES), and evaluates its reliability through development path planning, electricity-gas system co-optimization, and user-side energy complementarity analysis. Finally, optimal capacity allocation is determined via a multi-objective optimization model, providing a systematic solution for urban integrated energy development.

title: A Prototype IoT-Based Modular Electronic System for Home Automation
authors: Vladimir Tsankov, Boris Evstatiev, Irena Valova, Tsvetelina Kaneva
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: This publication presents a prototype smart home system, implemented using a combination of Arduino UNO R4 WiFi microcontrollers and Raspberry Pi 5 as a central server. The system integrates various sensors - for temperature (DS18B20), air quality (ENS160), motion (DG55+), and magnetic contact (MC-38), as well as a Shelly Pro EM 50 energy meter for consumption monitoring. The control of actuators (heater, lighting, motorized window, and IP video camera) is carried out using relay modules and contactors. Communication is based on Wi-Fi and LAN infrastructure, with data stored and analyzed on a Raspberry Pi. The developed system provides automation of heating, lighting, and ventilation, improves the quality of the indoor environment, and offers basic security functions through video surveillance. The experiments conducted demonstrate the reliability of communication and fast response time at a critical level of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. Lower energy consumption was achieved compared to manual control. These results show that the proposed system is applicable for small offices, classrooms, or smart homes with the possibility of future expansion through machine learning or cloud synchronization. The architecture is flexible, modular, and allows for future upgrades with modern standards for compatibility and intelligent control.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Generative AI and Student Solutions in Java Programming Assignments
authors: Htoo Htoo Sandi Kyaw, Tomoyuki Hata, Nobuo Funabiki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Currently, Java serves as the core object-oriented programming language that is essential for students studying ICT. To support learners in acquiring Java programming skills, we have developed the Java Programming Learning Assistant System (JPLAS). In JPLAS, Code Writing Problem (CWP) is designed for the students to write the source code from scratch by following the test code and problem statement. However, with the advancement of generative AI, it has become possible for students to generate answer code from the given test code and problem statement. To address this issue, this study investigates the impact of generative AI in solving CWP by generating 54 sample codes from three major generative AIs. Then, these generated codes were compared with students’ codes using the code plagiarism checking program. The average similarity is found to be 38.17%, and the analysis showed that simpler problems tend to produce higher similarity scores. In addition, different coding styles were observed for each AI, with certain prompt patterns resulting in higher similarity.

title: Vision-Based Real-Time Drowsiness Monitoring System Using OpenCV
authors: A Ezil Sam Leni, Jagdish Chandra Patni, Kodidhi Hemanth Reddy, Nagavardhan Pujala, Kateneni Abhishek, Vadde Sanjay, Harshala Shingne, Poorva Agrawal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Driver's sleepiness is a leading cause of crashes, and sometimes even leads to fatalities. In this paper, we propose an effective and real-time drowsiness detection framework to track and analyze the important facial indicators with the help of state-of-the-art computer vision and machine learning algorithms. It uses the OpenCV and the Dlib libraries for fast reliable facial landmark detections and tracking, allowing to monitor three relevant physical drowsiness markers, namely, eye closure, yawning, and head position. Eye Aspect Ratio (EAR) is calculated to recognize the blink period of eye, whereas Mouth Aspect Ratio (MAR) is employed to recognize yawn by detecting elongated mouth openings. Head pose estimation is also used to track attentiveness and detect nodding or head tilting as signs of sleepiness. The system runs in real-time and can accommodate changes in illumination, face poses, and driver appearance. Experimental studies show that its accuracy and reliability are quite high under different conditions, which indicates that it is a feasible and cost-effective non-invasive method for an ITS. The proposed design can shed light on the design of Advanced driver assistance system (ADAS) to bring down fatigue related crashes and thus to improve road safety.

title: Cellular-to-Aerial Downlink Coverage under Inter-Cell Interference
authors: Mohammed Elsagher, Akram Al-Hourani
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are emerging as agile IoT platforms for sensing and relaying, yet their elevated, Line of Sight (LoS)-rich vantage points make them unusually exposed to inter-cell interference in cellular-to-UAV links. This paper develops a tractable framework for quantifying connectivity under interference-limited conditions in both downlink and uplink. Using stochastic geometry, we derive a computable lower bound on coverage probability, explicitly capturing altitude, basestation density, and path-loss regimes typical of low-density urban settings. We expose how altitude dynamically trades LoS gains against aggregate out-of-cell leakage, yielding altitude bands that maximize coverage. Monte Carlo experiments corroborate the analysis and map performance across practical flight envelopes. The results guide interference-aware flight planning and robust UAV-IoT deployment in existing cellular networks.

title: Implementation of Energy Communities: How to Overcome Barriers with Best Practices?
authors: Andrei Morch, Raymundo E. Torres Olguin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: The implementation of energy communities across Europe presents both a promising opportunity and a significant regulatory challenge. Although the EU has provided a robust legal foundation, this paper explores the critical barriers hindering energy community development, such as lack of secondary legislation, unclear definitions, and limited financial incentives and analyses how best practices from frontrunner countries can support replication strategies in less developed contexts. By applying a taxonomy-based assessment and drawing on experiences from selected countries, the study highlights the diversity in implementation approaches and the resulting need for adaptable solutions. The study concludes by proposing a set of replicability factors for a structured transferring best practices to accelerate the deployment of energy communities and support the EU's energy transition goals.

title: Improved PMBM Filtering in Multi-Target Tracking with Node-Induced Clutter
authors: Yihang Liu, Yichen Li, Wenbin Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: In multi-target tracking scenarios, clutter generated by static interference nodes is a critical yet often overlooked factor that can significantly affect tracking performance. This paper introduces the concept of node-induced clutter and investigates its impact on tracking accuracy. To address this challenge, an improved Poisson multi-Bernoulli mixture (PMBM) filter is proposed, specifically designed to operate in environments containing such clutter. The proposed algorithm enhances tracking performance by addressing the strong correlation between the cost in the association matrix and the measurements of node-induced clutter, thereby effectively mitigating its impact on multi-target tracking. Simulation experiments are conducted to evaluate the performance of the improved algorithm, with results showing a clear advantage over the original PMBM filter. This work highlights the importance of considering node-induced clutter in tracking environments and provides a practical solution to enhance tracking performance in complex scenarios.

title: Logic-Probabilistic Approach in the Failures and Reliability Analysis of a Fire Detection System
authors: Emiliya Dimitrova, Vasil Dimitrov, Emil Borisov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This paper presents a logic-probabilistic reliability analysis of a fire alarm system. A fault tree is constructed, Markov model is developed and Markov matrix is compiled. The top event is defined as failure to alert in case of fire. Key reliability indicators such as failure and recovery rates, MTBF, availability coefficient are determined. The results show that the system has a high level of reliability due to the selection of quality components, provision of regular maintenance and training of personnel. The approach provides a useful tool for engineers and safety experts aiming to optimize fire alarm system design and operation.

title: An Emerging FET Compact Modeling Framework for Artificial Neural Networks Based on Physics
authors: Anukolu Abhiram Reddy, Anjana J G
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: The rapid development of new field-effect transistors (FETs) has made it necessary to create precise and effective compact modeling frameworks in order to forecast device behavior. Traditional modeling approaches often struggle to balance computational efficiency with precision, especially for nanoscale devices. This project proposes a novel physical based artificial neural network (ANN) compact modeling framework tailored for emerging FETs. By integrating physical equations governing device behavior with the adaptive learning capabilities of ANNs, the framework achieves a high degree of accuracy while maintaining computational efficiency. In order to describe intricate, non-linear interactions in FET characteristics, such as current-voltage (I-V) and capacitancevoltage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{V})$</tex> behaviors, the suggested framework leverages the advantages of artificial neural networks (ANNs. The model exhibits improved performance in terms of accuracy and scalability when benchmarked against other compact models and confirmed using experimental data. By offering a scalable, physics-informed ANN framework which can be modified for a variety of cutting-edge FET technologies, such as FinFETs, nanowire FETs, and 2D material-based FETs, this work advances the field of semiconductor device modeling. The findings demonstrate how ANNs have the ability to completely transform compact modeling, facilitating quicker design cycles and more accurate forecasts for electronic products of the future.

title: Comparative Analysis of Vector-Current Control and Power-Synchronization Control in an MMC-HVDC Connected to a Weak Grid
authors: Vinícius B. Fetter, Sidelmo M. Silva
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This work compares the performance of two control approaches for an HVDC link connected to a weak AC network. A detailed modeling of a modular multilevel converter (MMC-HVDC), derived from a validated benchmark, was employed to implement both vector-current control (VCC) and power-synchronization control (PSC) strategies. The analysis focused on regulating active power injection and supporting the voltage magnitude at the point of common coupling under various operating conditions. Different short-circuit ratio (SCR) levels and power reference setpoints were considered. The results indicate that the PSC approach provides superior stability, especially in very weak grids with SCR values close to 1.

title: Infrared Thermography for Beamforming Antenna Measurement
authors: Annamaria Sârbu, Cătălina Neghină, Mihai Neghină, Robert Papa
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: This paper presents an original algorithm based on infrared thermography (IRT) used to characterize the field distribution in the proximity of an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \times 4$</tex> antenna array with beamforming capabilities. A thermal camera was used to measure the temperature increase of a thin layer of liquid placed near the emitting antenna operating in the 3.53 GHz frequency range and a custom designed algorithm was developed to detect the temperature increase rate. The results of the proposed algorithm were compared to the field mapping obtained from a conventional electromagnetic field (EMF) spatial scanning device. Our results validate the proposed algorithm and show that infrared thermography can be a viable method for spatial mapping of electromagnetic fields, especially in the context of beamforming antennas where high spatial variability is present, offering advantages in speed and diagnostic capability.

title: Towards Robust and Generalizable Air-to-Air Object Detection and Tracking for Non-Cooperative Aerial Vehicles
authors: Christos Skliros
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: This paper presents a robust and generalizable vision-based system for detecting, tracking, and estimating the depth of non-cooperative unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in air-to-air scenarios. Advances from prior work in monocular depth estimation, robust object detection, and domain generalization to form a comprehensive real-time pipeline are integrated. The proposed system enhances a state-of-the-art detecting and tracking architecture by integrating a lightweight monocular depth estimator and incorporating domain agnostic training strategies using uncertainty-guided adversarial augmentations. Furthermore, robustness under domain shifts using a dataset enhanced with environmental and sensor corruptions such as fog, rain, blur, and noise to test data is assessed. The system was able to perform in real time in low Size Weight and Power consumption edge devices and accepting inputs from multiple camera types (i.e. RGB, low-light).

title: ParallAdapt: A Holistic Adaptive Framework for Parallel Task Scheduling and Caching
authors: Jiale Li, Yuanlun Wei, Zhenguo Bi, Xinyan Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: The deep integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet-of-Things (IoT) has given rise to the Artificial Intelligence of Things (AIoT), a paradigm demanding resource-efficient distributed learning and inference. In this context, mobile edge servers can form a cooperative AIoT network, providing on-demand perception services to ground-level devices. However, optimization challenge involving the orchestration of server mobility, task offloading and the management of AI models, which act as semantic resources. Existing frameworks often overlook the problem of dynamic model caching. This paper introduces ParallAdapt, a novel framework for semantic-aware resource management framework in cooperative AIoT networks. Specifically, it addresses the joint optimization of server path planning, task scheduling, and dynamic model caching. In addition, We tackle this NP-hard problem with a two-stage heuristic, using a Genetic Algorithm for global planning and a window-based Hyper-Heuristic for online, semantic-aware decisions. Extensive simulations demonstrate that ParallAdapt significantly outperforms existing baselines, enabling efficient inference and reducing deployment cost by adaptively managing the trade-offs between server mobility, task execution, and the availability of semantic AI models.

title: Flexible Industrial demand control in response to variable energy resources
authors: Metody Georgiev, Alexandra Georgieva
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: Power interruptions in industrial facilities can lead to significant material and financial losses. It is crucial to have multiple energy sources-grid, primary, and secondary power supply backups. Proper management of all power capacities and available loads is the foundation for a reliable, non-intrusive power supply to industrial consumers. Typically, this is achieved by supporting enterprise power with diesel generators or alternative energy sources such as PV installations. This article introduces an algorithm for automatic switching of reserve generating capacities across different parts of an industrial system, utilizing the energy from a photovoltaic power plant and load management based on the availability of energy sources. The algorithm combines a state machine with an optimization model to select consumers and includes considerations for emergencies, such as the failure of generation units. Its goal is to provide uninterrupted power to high-priority consumers while maximizing renewable energy usage and adhering to the energy load schedule.

title: 8-Bit Pipelined Accuracy-Configurable Radix-4 Adder with Dynamic Output Adjustment
authors: Hamsavardini C, R Muthaiah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: The development of mobile, embedded and Internet of things applications is driving a growing need for arithmetic processors with high processing speeds and low battery consumption. These programs often have moderate to high computational accuracy requirements and operate within high power constraints. The trade-offs between accuracy, power, and performance are often not optimally balanced by adder implementations like Carry Look Ahead Adders (CLA) and Ripple carry Adders (RLA) under dynamic workloads. To overcome these limitations, an 8-bit pipelined Radix-4 adder with programmable accuracy is proposed in this work, enabling the system to meet its needs. Radix-4 improves performance by reducing propagation time and logic depth through the concurrent processing of four bits. Real time and logic depth through the concurrent processing of four bits. Real-time switching between accurate and approximation modes in a reconfigurable output adjustment system saves energy without sacrificing required accuracy. Targeting a Zynq-7000 FPGA (Zedboard), the architecture is written in Verilog HDL and Vivado tool. Modelsim is used to verify functionality. The architecture minimizes the latency and power consumption while achieving during approximation mode, according to experimental comparisons. These results show that the proposed adder is suitable for digital systems that are adaptive, low power, and high speed.

title: Dual-Channel Adaptive NMPC for Quadrotor under Instantaneous Impact and Payload Disturbances
authors: Xinqi Chen, Xiuxian Li, Min Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Capturing target objects using the quadrotor has gained increasing popularity in recent years, but most studies focus on capturing lightweight objects. The instantaneous contact force generated when capturing objects of a certain mass, along with the payload uncertainty after attachment, will pose significant challenges to the quadrotor control. This paper proposes a novel control architecture, named Dual-Channel Adaptive Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (DCA-NMPC), which cascades a nonlinear model predictive control with two lower-level model reference adaptive controllers and can resist drastic impact and adapt to uncertain inertial parameters. Numerical simulation experiments are performed for validation.

title: GSOD-KD: Knowledge Distillation for Lightweight and Accurate Object Detection in Space Situational Awareness
authors: Kewalee Srithongtae, Borirak Kitrattana, Purin Tanirat, Sittiporn Channumsin, Setthanun Thongsuwan
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: Space Situational Awareness (SSA) is a critical conceptual framework for monitoring, tracking, and analyzing the space environment—particularly for detecting and tracking small, high-velocity space objects that pose potential risks to satellites and assets both in space and on Earth. A major challenge in SSA is developing models that accurately detect such objects under the constraints of real-world operational systems. This paper focuses on developing a lightweight yet high-accuracy object detection model by exploring and selecting models within the YOLO (You Only Look Once) series, which are widely recognized for their efficiency and strong performance in object detection tasks. To enhance model effectiveness, the study incorporates the Knowledge Distillation (KD) technique, wherein knowledge is transferred from a larger, more complex Teacher Model to a smaller Student Model. We propose a novel model named GISTDA’s Space Object Detection using Knowledge Distillation (GSOD-KD), which is distinguished by its processing speed and detection accuracy. The model is evaluated using real observational data obtained from the Geo-Informatics and Space Technology Development Agency (GISTDA), captured through ground-based telescope systems for space object monitoring. The GSOD-KD model achieves a mAP@50 of 0.951, which is equivalent to that of the Teacher Model. However, GSOD-KD requires only 1,971,174 parameters, compared to the 2,503,334 parameters of the Teacher Model—a 21.25% reduction in parameter size. This result demonstrates that GSOD-KD can maintain detection accuracy comparable to the Teacher Model while utilizing significantly fewer parameters, highlighting its potential for deployment in real-time SSA systems with limited computational resources.
