title: Building Urban Resilience Through Circular Smart City: Insights from Valencia Flood
authors: Pedro Núñez-Cacho, Aida Molina-Prados, Jaroslaw Górecki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: The Isolated High-Level Depression (IHD) that struck Valencia in October 2024 exposed the fragility of urban systems facing extreme weather events. This study explores how circular smart cities—combining digital technologies with sustainable planning—can anticipate, absorb, and recover from such climate-driven crises. Focusing on the cascading effects caused by the IHD, the paper highlights the strategic use of digital twins, IoT-based early warning systems, and hybrid predictive models. It also underlines the importance of green infrastructure and integrated emergency governance. The findings offer a roadmap for enhancing urban resilience in Mediterranean regions increasingly threatened by compound and extreme climate phenomena.

title: Minutiae Extraction Optimization for ARM and RISC-V
authors: Andreea Violeta Păscociu, Andrei Eduard Solomon, Csaba Zoltán Kertész, Cătălin Bogdan Ciobanu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Biometric recognition has become an indispensable component of modern authentication systems, driven by the need for secure and user-friendly access control. In this work, we introduce an optimized fingerprint processing pipeline that includes preprocessing, skeletonization, and minutiae extraction, implemented in C++ with OpenCV and evaluated on ARM (Raspberry Pi 4B), RISC-V (BeagleV-Fire) and x86 (Intel Core <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{i 7}-\text{1 2 6 5 0 H}$</tex>) processors and a CUDA-enabled NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2050 GPU. We employ multi-core parallelization and SIMD extensions. Our experimental results suggest a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.75 \times$</tex> speedup over the single-core baseline for the ARM-based CPU and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.98 \times$</tex> speedup for the RISC-V implementation when compared to the single-core RISC-V implementation. Furthermore, we analyze the energy consumption on the target platforms. These results highlight that platform-specific optimization enables real-time and energy-efficient fingerprint processing across diverse computing environments.

title: Coordination of surge protection and operation of thermal protection at metal oxide varistor (MOV)
authors: Naoyuki Tsukamoto, Mitsunobu Shiozaki, Masaru Ishii
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: In the design of MOV modules including a thermal cut off for low-voltage AC power supplies, PV, and DC applications, thermal coordination between MOV heat generation by impulses and protection for thermal runaway was investigated in order to realize a compact and reliable module.The surface temperature of an MOV element triggering thermal protection is estimated approximately 185 °C from the result of overcurrent testing. Surface temperature shall not exceed this temperature during specified impulse current application. In addition, it is feasible for thermal protection to operate stably with a mechanism that interrupts short-circuit current through thermal linkage.Thermal stability of the MOV modules with relatively high varistor voltage is confirmed to pass the test in accordance with SPD standards. Through this study, the importance of understanding the thermal behavior of MOVs is reaffirmed.

title: Gyrotrons: Same principles. Same mission. New models
authors: Mikhail Glyavin, Gregory Denisov, Evgeniy Tai, Aleksandr Litvak
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: Gyrotrons are most powerful and technically implemented radiation sources in millimeter and sub- millimeter wavelength band. The report provides a brief overview of the key results obtained by IAP RAS/GYCOM teams, present some new ideas of formation electron beams with parameters good enough for effective electron beam-microwave energy exchange, methods of mode selection and examples of most attractive gyrotron applications.

title: Performance Evaluation of Feature-Selected Vanilla LSTM for Water Level Forecasting in Lower Mekong River Basin
authors: Chanreng Sey Nhim, Chaodit Aswakul
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: This research investigates the performance of Vanilla Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) models for water level forecasting in the Lower Mekong River Basin. The methodology integrates three main components: (i) grid search hyperparameter tuning to identify the best Vanilla LSTM configuration, (ii) feature selection based on Spearman rank correlation to determine the most relevant predictors, and (iii) forecasting strategy evaluation by varying lookback windows and forecasting horizons. The accuracy of the model has been assessed with standard evaluation metrics, including Nash–Sutcliffe Efficiency, Mean Absolute Error, and Root Mean Square Error. The results indicate that optimized feature subsets significantly enhance model stability compared to univariate approaches, particularly in long-term forecasting. Moreover, analysis of forecasting strategies reveals that univariate Vanilla LSTM model requires longer lookback window for stable performance. In contrast, feature-selected Vanilla LSTM model achieves robustness with fewer inputs but is sensitive to excessive historical dependencies. The findings provide practical guidelines for balancing model complexity, input selection, and temporal design in LSTM-based hydrological forecasting.

title: Research on Design Methods of Large-Capacity Grid Simulators
authors: Wei Dong, Yixin Yan, Long Jing, Jia Deng
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To meet the requirements of grid-connected test platforms for high-power new energy inverter equipment, this paper proposes a novel topology suitable for large-capacity grid simulators, specifically a Hybrid Modular Multilevel Converter (HMMC) topology that combines Integrated Gate-Commutated Thyristors (IGCTs) and Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistors (IGBTs). It adopts a mode of energy transmission at low switching frequency combined with energy control at high switching frequency. For different device combinations of the HMMC, a hybrid modulation strategy involving fundamental frequency modulation combined with high-frequency modulation compensation is designed. While reducing the switching frequency, this strategy precisely controls the output inverter voltage waveform and realizes functions such as adjustable amplitude and frequency of grid voltage, and three-phase unbalance of grid voltage. Finally, grid fault simulation of the grid simulator is completed through simulations, verifying the feasibility of the proposed design scheme.

title: AI-Driven Script-to-Scene Translation for Automated Cinematic Pre-Visualization
authors: Nihar Das, Sakthivel Muthu, Birju Kumar Rajak, Simrandeep Kaur, Hemalatha Than Hemalatha Thanganadar, Abdul Azeem Khan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: As the need for quick and cheap ways to make movies grows, people are looking into AI-powered options that can help with different stages of production. This paper describes a new way to use script-to-scene translation to handle AI-based movie pre-visualization (Pre-Viz). Traditional pre-viz methods involve a lot of human work, like complicated storyboarding and pricey CGI simulations that take a lot of time and resources. To solve this problem, we suggest an AI-powered system that can turn written texts into visual models. This would make the early steps of film creation much more efficient. Using natural language processing (NLP) methods, we pull out important parts of the story, like scenes, actions, and conversation. Then, we use computer vision models to make realistic images of the scenes. These drawings show how the space is set up, the camera views, the lighting, and how the characters move in a way that fits with the story format in the script. Deep learning models, such as transformers for reading text and generative adversarial networks (GANs) for creating scenes, are used by the system to improve visual accuracy and stay creatively true to the director's vision. Utilising real-life cases, we show that this method works by showing a substantial decrease in the time needed for Pre-Viz creation. The method also makes it easier for directors to work together by giving them a graphic guide that matches the written plot.

title: Detecting Implicit Aspects and Sentiment in Hotel Reviews via Hybrid Embedding Methods
authors: Jantima Polpinij, Thananchai Khamket, Chunpong Chan, Theeraya Uttha, Anirut Chothanom, Jatuphum Juanchaiyaphum
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: The limitations of traditional aspect-based sentiment analysis, which frequently ignore indirect expressions, are addressed by this study's hybrid approach for identifying implicit aspects and categorizing sentiment polarity in hotel reviews. In order to detect implicit mentions, semantic expansion was carried out using the Skip-gram Word2Vec model to find terms that were closely related to predefined aspect keywords. Semantic embeddings with TF-IDF weights were combined to create hybrid feature vectors in three different configurations: 100% Word2Vec, 75% Word2Vec + 25% TF-IDF, and 50% Word2Vec + 50% TF-IDF. The 75/25 hybrid scheme improved the identification of implicit expressions and had the best alignment with expert-annotated aspect categories, according to k-means clustering experiments. Five models were tested for sentiment classification: SVM, CNN, Random Forest, Logistic Regression, and LSTM. Deep learning models outperformed conventional techniques. Under the 75/25 hybrid scheme, LSTM in particular achieved the highest F1-score, showcasing a strong ability to capture nuanced sentiment cues and sequential context. These results demonstrate how well semantic and statistical features can be combined for sentiment analysis and aspect detection, providing a promising framework for more reliable user-generated content interpretation in the hospitality domain.

title: Digital Twins for Climate-Positive Cities: Integrating Local Climate Zones with Solar Energy Technologies and Nature-Based Solutions
authors: Nikolaos Skandalos, Tsampika Dimitriou, Dimitrios Karamanis, Ilkim Canli Akyol, Sinan Kalkan, Ipek Gursel Dino
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: This study introduces a digital twin framework for assessing climate-positive interventions at the neighborhood scale, integrating Building-Integrated Photovoltaics and Nature-Based Solutions within the context of Local Climate Zones. By linking urban morphology and climate data with energy simulation and feedback–driven optimization, the approach enables targeted, scalable solutions for decarbonizing urban areas. Three representative case studies, Ioannina (Greece), Prague (Czech Republic), and Ankara (Turkey), were modeled using a detailed digital twin that simulates solar energy generation, building energy demand, and carbon offset potential. While physics-based methods were used for smaller areas, Ankara employed machine learning-driven Urban Building Energy Modeling for large-scale evaluation. A feedback-enabled framework allows the refinement of design interventions based on simulation results. Findings revealed significant variation in PV yield, energy savings, and selfsufficiency across LCZs, confirming the importance of local context. The study demonstrates how digital twins can serve as dynamic planning tools for urban decarbonization, offering a replicable and scalable approach to climate-sensitive urban design.

title: Inception of lightning discharge from water drops inside thundercloud
authors: Hasupama Jayasinghe, Liliana Arevalo, Vernon Cooray
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: This paper presents the initial stage of the lightning inception inside a thundercloud from hydrometeors in the form of ellipsoidal water drops, at 263.15 K temperature and 0.5 atm pressure. The streamer discharge from three, two and isolated water drop during lightning inception is simulated using a plasma chemical 1.5D model including 19 charged species and 38 chemical reactions among them. Streamer discharges from both isolated and two water drops are modeled at 70%, 90%, and 110% relative humidities to analyze the effect of humidity on streamer behavior inside a thundercloud. The results indicate that in the configuration with three aligned water drops, two positive streamers initiate and propagate simultaneously within the two air gaps, while a negative streamer originates in each air gap from the bottom drop. In the two drop configuration, a single positive streamer forms in the air gap, and a negative streamer develops from the lower drop. In single drop configuration, only a positive streamer is observed. Humidity plays a minor role in streamer inception and propagation inside a thundercloud for single and two drop configurations. In conclusion, the positioning and quantity of water drops within the thundercloud affect the streamer’s behavior, and therefore significantly impact the conditions necessary for lightning initiation.

title: Harmonic Source Identification Under Location Uncertainty: A Behavioral Analysis of the Grey Wolf Optimization Algorithm
authors: D. Crnkowise, R. A. S. Fernandes, D. Barbosa, F. B. Costa
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: Harmonic Source identification in radial distribution networks is of utmost importance to provide solutions that mitigate harmonic distortions and, consequently, improve the quality of power delivered to the consumers. This paper evaluates the effectiveness of the Grey Wolf Optimization algorithm in identifying industrial harmonic sources when their location is uncertain. The proposed approach employs 20 steadystate cycles acquired at a sampling rate of 128 samples/cycle, obtained through the simulation of the IEEE 34-bus test feeder in the ATP/ATPDraw software. The results demonstrate high accuracy even at considerable distances from the power quality meter, exhibiting root mean square errors below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$11.7 \times 10^{-3}$</tex> p.u. and weighted absolute percentage errors below 10%. Thus, metaheuristics appear to be promising techniques for power quality monitoring, even with limited measurement infrastructures.

title: Research on Polarization Current Line Protection for Characteristic Identification of Weak Faults in New Type Power Systems
authors: Zexin Zhou, Yarong Guo, Xingguo Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The paper introduces the concepts of polarization current and working current, which are used to construct the current complex plane and design the operation zone of the working current. Two dimensions of a distributed capacitor branch and a short circuit resistance branch are utilized to construct the amplitude criterion and the phase criterion, which are applied for fault identification by determining the presence of a short-circuit branch in the line. Due to the alteration in the relationship between the polarization current and the working current before and after the fault, which reflects the change in the equivalent parameters of the line, the protection principle remains unaffected by the fault characteristics of different types of power. Moreover, this alteration has considerable benefits in terms of adaptability, sensitivity, and rapidity, providing effective assurance for the safe and stable functioning of the new power system.

title: Remote Laboratory Setup Using Raspberry Pi for a Digital Signal Processors Course
authors: Csaba Zoltán Kertész, Cătălin Bogdan Ciobanu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Digital Signal Processors (DSP) are dedicated processor architectures optimized for executing specialized tasks usually employed in signal processing algorithms and represent a fairly large share of the embedded processing market. Because of this, dedicated courses are usually included in the Electronics Engineering curricula either at undergraduate or postgraduate level. This paper presents a laboratory setup for such a course, where several Raspberry Pi 4 single board computers are used as experimental platform. Students can connect remotely to these boards and implement various signal processing algorithms using the dedicated DSP instructions and the SIMD extension inside the ARM Cortex-A72 processor to check the performance of the given algorithm when optimizing to dedicated instructions compared to plain CPU instructions.

title: Electric Vehicles as Grid-Flexible Resources: Coordinated Charging and V2G Strategies Toward 2050
authors: Chen Jin, Jinming Hou, Xunyan Lyu, Qing He, Haiyang Jiang, Ershun Du
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The large-scale deployment of electric vehicles (EVs) brings both challenges and opportunities to future power systems with high shares of renewable energy. This study investigates the flexibility potential of EVs under three different charging scenarios: stochastic charging, coordinated charging guided by time-based pricing, and vehicle-to-grid (V2G) bidirectional energy flow. A generation and transmission expansion planning (GTEP) model is used to simulate the power system of China operation in 2035 and 2050. The results reveal that coordinated charging can reduce the required renewable capacity installation by up to 40 % and cut curtailment by over 30%. Furthermore, with partial participation of EVs in V2G (40 % participation rate, 20% capacity depth), the effective grid-side energy storage reaches 3 TWh in 2050, equivalent to 7.5 % of the daily electricity demand, enhancing system flexibility and reducing overall system cost. These findings highlight the pivotal role of EVs as decentralized, mobile, low-cost flexibility resources in future carbon-neutral power systems.

title: A Single-End Protection Principle for Flexible DC Collection System based on Energy Polarity
authors: DAI Feiyang, CAO Hong, SONG Yonghui, LIU Jiaqi, LIU Ningning
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In order to pursue economy and stability, DC collection transmission systems differ from conventional flexible DC systems in terms of primary system topology, and the adaptability of existing line protection configurations in such systems is insufficient. In this study, the particularity of the traveling-wave process in a four terminal flexible DC collection system is analyzed, and the relationship between traveling-wave polarity and fault location is revealed, based on which a single terminal quantity protection principle utilizing reflected-wave polarity identification is constructed. The PSCAD/EMTDC simulation results have verified the effectiveness of the protection principle.

title: Advance Data Ingestion Framework - Integration, Processing, Transformation, and Loading
authors: Samiksha Gupta, Ajay Kumar, Neha Mishra, Ramesh Chandra Poonia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The research introduces a new concept known as the Advanced Data Ingestion Framework, which is aimed at enhancing the process of getting into stored information through some intelligent methods like data preprocessing, transformation and loading. By making use of Azure services, the platform considers distributed computing and parallel processing so that structured as well as unstructured data can be incorporated from various origins without any difficulty. To begin with, the proposed framework starts with setting up scalable Azure infrastructure and integrating SAP S4/HANA for secure and efficient data transfer purposes. Within Azure Data Factory the ingestion occurs while Delta Lake ensures proper housekeeping & integrity within the system. It includes creating Power BI dashboards which allow users to see patterns easily and make better decisions based on what they know or can learn. The study brings out the flaws of current data input solutions and emphasizes the urgent requirement for a highly scalable low latency system that can support real time data processing efficiently. It tests the framework under different performance environments showing that it can effectively manage modern data within it. Finally, there is discussion about future improvements such as incorporating more sophisticated analytics or ML models thereby strengthening the decisionmaking process based on available facts.

title: Distributed Control of Multi-agent Systems via Robust Graph Neural Networks
authors: Yangtian Lu, Tong Duan, Xuefei Yang, Xin Gong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Learning-based approaches have gained more and more proven effective practices in multi-agent systems, where graph neural networks(GNNs) perform well in distributed control. However, there is a lack of work to address the security issues involved. In order to reduce the problem of complex convergence of malicious nodes to normal nodes by tampering with the communication content, we propose a novel algorithm named GCN-MSR to ensure the robustness of distributed control. In short, the gradient manipulation by malicious nodes is suppressed by removing a portion of the extremes passed to normal nodes through the idea of mean subsequence reduced. In addition, since the node states in our task are expressed through vectors, we achieve quantification of the extreme values by transforming the vector values into scalars using the Mahalanobis distance. The final distributed multi-agent control strategy is obtained by comparing the strategy learned from the network with the strategy from the expert template through imitation learning.

title: Online Assessment of Dynamic Reactive Power Reserve in Power Systems Based on Graph Convolutional Networks
authors: Tian Wang, JinMing Wang, ZhenDong Cui, ZiKang Zhao, JinQuan Zhao, ZiChen Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of renewable energy, short-term voltage stability (STVS) issues in power systems has become more prominent. A key challenge is how to accurately and promptly assess the support capability of dynamic reactive power devices for STVS. However, existing online evaluation methods are mostly based on a voltage perspective, which makes it difficult to provide clear guidance for reactive power control. To address this problem, this paper designs a dynamic reactive power reserve (DRPR) index suitable for online computation and proposes a graph convolutional network (GCN)-based online assessment method. By taking the steady-state reactive power injection space as the analytical perspective, the proposed method enables both the assessment of STVS. and the provision of explicit and direct control guidance for preventive strategies. The effectiveness of the proposed index and assessment model is validated through simulations on the CSEE-VS test system.

title: Analog Audio Signal Equalizer Circuit for Hearing Aids
authors: Doris Csipkes, Gabor Csipkes, Robert Groza, Alin Grama, Adelina Ilies, Ovidiu Aurel Pop, Elena Stetco
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Although digital hearing aids dominate the current market, analog solutions remain relevant due to their power efficiency, inherent capability for real-time signal processing, and the necessity of signal conditioning for dynamic range adjustment before performing analog to digital conversion. This paper proposes a low-power analog front end architecture intended for low power hearing aids. The circuits are built with MOSFETs biased in the subthreshold region. This minimizes energy consumption while enabling real-time, frequency-selective signal processing. The design includes a bank of nine second-order GmC bandpass filters for spectral decomposition and programmable gain amplifiers that allow an audio signal equalization based on individual hearing loss profiles. Each filter in the bank features adjustable gain and a variable quality factor to control inter channel leakage and audio band equalization. A programmable gain amplifier adjusts the final output level for volume control, without altering the bank frequency response. Transistor level circuit simulations confirm that the system can accurately reproduce audiometric characteristics and equalize the channel amplitudes to achieve the desired frequency response. This validates the efficiency for low-complexity, power-efficient frontend designs intended for hearing aid applications.

title: A Design of a Histopathology Image Augmentation Pipeline for Colon Cancer Image Processing
authors: Jie Li, Weiwei Goh, NZ Jhanjhi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Robust data augmentation is essential for training histopathology classifiers that generalize across scanners, centers and staining protocols. We evaluated three augmentation pipelines on 204 colon-tissue tiles from the LC25000 collection, benchmarking realism with Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) and colour fidelity with mean lightness drift (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta L^{*}$</tex>). A stain-only strategy, Macenko normalization plus direct stain transfer, produced the poorest match to the original distribution (FID <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 37.4$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left.\Delta L^{*} \approx 5.10\right)$</tex>, indicating that color manipulations alone can severely distort global image statistics. Adding purely geometric and mild morphological transforms (flips, small rotations, elastic shifts) sharply reduced both metrics (FID <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 13.8, \Delta L^{*} \approx 1.27$</tex>) while preserving diagnostic appearance. Building on this baseline with an AugMix-light branch yielded only a modest rise in FID <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\approx 16.4)$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta L^{*}(\approx 1.45)$</tex> yet injected richer local contrast and color variation-attributes that improve robustness to scanner and slide-ageing artifacts. Qualitative inspection confirmed that nuclei, gland borders and stromal textures remained intact across all augmented sets. These findings advocate a tiered augmentation curriculum: prioritize shape-preserving operations to anchor photometric realism, then layer in blended low-severity transforms for diversity, while monitoring both distributional and color metrics to avoid overshooting. The proposed recipe balances realism with variability, offering a practical path toward more generalizable and trustworthy computational pathology models.

title: External Quantum Efficiency Evolution of Light-Emitting Diodes under γ-rays, Electrons, Neutrons and Protons
authors: Luca Weninger, Adriana Morana, Matteo Ferrari, Aziz Boukenter, Youcef Ouerdane, Emmanuel Marin, Philippe Paillet, Marc Gaillardin, Olivier Duhamel, Cornelia Hoehr, Camille Bélanger-Champagne, Michael Trinczek, Sylvain Girard
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: Thanks to their many advantages over traditional light sources, light-emitting diodes (LEDs) are being more and more deployed worldwide. Accordingly, they are inevitably making their way to radiation environments as well. This implementation needs to be accompanied by the proper tools to assess their capability to withstand the effects of ionizing radiation. This work proposes the external quantum efficiency (EQE) as a figure of merit capable of investigating the currentdependent light emission of LEDs and their degradation when exposed to radiation. The capabilities of this method are here proven, investigating the effects of different radiation types, such as Co<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">60</sup> γ-rays, 6 MeV electrons, 63 MeV protons and atmospheric neutrons on commercial LEDs combining different technologies on the same component.

title: Prediction of Operational Risk in Rural Credit Banks Based on CNN and LSTM Methods
authors: Yang Run, Soobia Saeed, Muhammad Tayyab, Toh Leow Bin, Khalid Hussain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of artificial intelligence, its implementation in financial institutions has raised concerns regarding new risk management policies, particularly for rural credit banks. This research proposes the development of a predictive system for operational risks in rural credit banks based on two deep learning techniques namely (1) Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and (2) Long Short-Term Memory Networks (LSTM). While CNN identifies and captures video footage to analyze risky commands issued by internal staff, LSTM processes real-time server logs to detect patterns that could lead to system failures. This research aims to enhance the prediction of risks associated with internal operations, including staff errors, equipment/system failures, and environmental risks. The results demonstrate that this approach significantly improves the effectiveness of risk management in rural credit cooperatives and offers valuable insights into other institutional risk management strategies.

title: An Integration of Fine-Tuned RoBERTa, Support Vector Machine, and Differential Evolution in Enhancing Multi-Label Text Classification for Academic Publications
authors: Dongming Zhang, Rachsuda Setthawong, Pisal Setthawong
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Two important challenges in multi-label classification are dataset imbalance and overlapping features shared among two or more class labels. This study addresses both challenges as a problem of classifying multi-labels in academic publications by proposing an integration of three main techniques: Robustly Optimized BERT Approach (RoBERTa), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Differential Evolution (DE) algorithm. In a nutshell, a fine-tuned RoBERTa captures domain-specific semantic features of academic papers; SVM performs initial multi-label classification; and DE optimizes the label-specific threshold combination for each label improving the accuracy of classification decisions. This integration jointly addresses dataset imbalance, overlapping features, and threshold selection issues, which are rarely considered together in prior studies. The experiments were performed on academic papers, collected from arXiv repository with five core subfields of Computer Science. Experimental results showed that the Macro-F1 score of the proposed approach that integrates the fine-tuned RoBERTa model, SVM classifier and DE achieved 0.8018 while the best performance of benchmark methods achieved 0.7218. The significant performance improvement highlights the effectiveness of integrating semantic feature extraction, robust classification, and adaptive threshold optimization to overcome the challenges of dataset imbalance and feature overlap in multi-label classification of academic publications.

title: Ai Virtual Inspection and Environmental Monitoring Platform
authors: Guo Jiawen, Afizan Bin Azman, Husin Bin Jazri, Anbuselvan Sangodiah, Khalid Hussain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: In recent years, with the continuous improvement of industrial automation demand, intelligent inspection and environmental monitoring technology is more and more widely used in manufacturing, public places and industrial parks. The traditional inspection and environmental monitoring methods are not only inefficient, but also prone to human omissions because of excessive reliance on labor. Therefore, the use of artificial intelligence technology for intelligent inspection and environmental monitoring has become an inevitable trend. This research aims to develop an AI-based virtual inspection and environment monitoring system, which uses deep learning algorithms to conduct real-time monitoring of personnel identity, and improves the automation level of the system through the analysis of environmental data and anomaly detection. The proposed system will be combined with face recognition technology for identity verification, and environmental data monitoring and analysis based on the uploaded data set, in order to achieve intelligent integration of security inspection and environmental monitoring.

title: Online Platform for Readers: Virtual Library Management
authors: Daria-Elena Dima, Rodica-Claudia Constantinescu, Dragoș-Ioan Săcăleanu, Bogdan Alexandrescu
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: The paper presents the development of a web platform dedicated to readers for the efficient management of their personal virtual library, using the MERN stack (MongoDB, Express.js, React.js, Node.js). The platform allows viewing books, giving reviews and organizing them into reading lists (“Read”, “Want to Read”, “Currently Reading”). The novelty lies in the intuitive interface, fully implemented CRUD functionalities and the administration panel that allows managing users, books and reviews, as well as viewing statistics (PieChart, BarChart). Authentication is secured with bcrypt, and the database is hosted in MongoDB Atlas. The platform solves the limitations observed on similar sites (outdated interfaces, hard-to-access functionalities) and demonstrates the practical applicability of MERN technologies in the development of modern educational web solutions. The authors intend to further develop the application to be used for an electronic packaging library.

title: Single Mode Multifiber Expanded Beam Connector for Immersion Cooling System Using GRIN Lens
authors: Alexander William Setiawan Putra, Yusuke Ishibashi, Motohito Takezaki, Kazutaka Aboshi
publish: 2025 IEEE CPMT Symposium Japan (ICSJ)
abstract: A multifiber single-mode expanded beam optical connector that can provide a stable connection without fiber physical contact has been developed. The connector is less sensitive to the effects of contaminants at the end-face of the connector than an MPO. It can be mated and unmated with ease in an immersive environment.

title: Multi-Objective Optimal Control of CHB-Based Energy Storage Converters Under Unbalanced Grid Voltage Conditions
authors: Xiang Fang, Yanan Wu, Yunxiang Tian, Jing Lu, Jun Li, Huafeng Mao, Liang Tan, Gang Li, Guifa Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To address the challenges of active/reactive power oscillations, and current imbalance in cascaded H-bridge (CHB) energy storage converters under unbalanced grid voltage conditions, this paper proposes a multi-objective optimization control strategy. By investigating the relationship between CHB converter operational characteristics and coordination factor, the strategy formulates a multi-objective function to simultaneously achieve active/reactive power balance and suppress current imbalance. Leveraging a particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm, the coordination factor is globally optimized under constraints such as active power fluctuation threshold and reactive power fluctuation threshold. Simulation results validate that the proposed approach enables coordinated optimal control of the converter, significantly improving system performance in terms of protection capability.

title: Electricity and Carbon Trading Considering Carbon Emission Environmental Pollution of Industrial Customers
authors: Juefei Wang, Yingjun Wu, Jing Chen, Weijie Yao, Xueyan He, Zhengxi Yin
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper proposes a bilevel P2P trading model for industrial customers considering environmental pollution caused by carbon emissions. A CEEPF-based diffusion theory (Carbon Emission Environmental Pollution Flow, CEEPF) is introduced to quantify the degree of environmental pollution from carbon emissions. Based on the Environmental-aware OPF (EOPF) model, a pricing mechanism for P2P trading is developed. By leveraging the decomposable Environmental-aware Local Marginal Price (ELMP), the DSO's service price is derived to guide downstream P2P trading. Simulations on the improved IEEE-33 test system validate that the proposed model effectively controls total carbon emissions while ensuring optimal economic benefits for industrial customers participating in P2P trading.

title: 4D Millimeter-Wave Radar Point Cloud Processing via Global Optimization and Dynamic Enhancement
authors: Zhixi Xu, Guohua Wei, Xing Cui, Xiao Kang, Bao Jin, Yukun Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: To address challenges in 4D millimeter-wave radar point clouds for unmanned ground systems (UGS), such as false alarms, elevation artifacts, sparsity, and under-utilization of velocity information, a collaborative optimization framework is proposed. It integrates point cloud optimization and dynamic target enhancement. Elevation artifacts are suppressed using an enhanced Shapiro-Wilk joint test with spatial entropy preservation, coupled with a cross-domain multimodal cascade optimization filter for progressive verify-cation and filtering. For dynamic targets, a dual-enhancement strategy generates directional perturbation noise along motion trajectories and applies curvature-adaptive gain modulation to improve geometric consistency. Experiments on the View-of-Delft (VoD) dataset exhibit a 65.07% anomaly reduction with intact spatial structure, increased GT box point densities, enhanced shape matching and refined trajectories precision. This process framework establishes an effective approach for sparse point cloud processing in UGS perception.

title: ThreatsMaps: Automatic adjustment of CTI with the Running System
authors: Sebihi Mouhcen, Kenaza Tayeb
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Advanced Systems (ICNAS)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce ThreatsMaps, an automated Cyber Threat Hunting (CTH) system specifically designed to detect Advanced Persistent Threats (APT) through the matching of provenance and query graphs. ThreatsMaps leverages Linux Security Modules to collect provenance data and acquires Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) reports pertinent to the protected system from various CTI platforms. The system then extracts the query graph from the CTI data using a method that automatically identifies Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) and attack behaviors. To mitigate the high computational and memory overhead associated with matching large graphs, ThreatsMaps employs the HistoSketch optimization technique. Furthermore, the system reformulates the graph matching problem into a clustering task using the k-medoids evolutionary algorithm, which is particularly suitable for streaming systems. We evaluated ThreatsMaps using the DARPA dataset, where it demonstrated high accuracy in identifying attacks, achieving a detection score of 97%.

title: Smart EV Charging via Federated Meta-Dueling Double Deep Q-Network with Prioritized Experience Replay
authors: Atefeh Alirezazadeh, Vahid Disfani, Hamed Mohsenian-Rad
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Green Energy and Smart Systems (GESS)
abstract: This paper aims to address the challenges of real-time electric vehicle (EV) charging under uncertainty. A new EV charge scheduling strategy is proposed based on Federated Meta-Dueling Double Deep Q-Network with Prioritized Experience Replay (FM-D3QN-PER) to maximize the number of fully charged EVs, reduce energy costs, balance transformer load, and adapt to stochastic factors such as random EV arrivals and dynamic electricity pricing. In this framework, the system is divided into multiple local agents, referred to as clients, where each client represents a group of EVs with similar behavior. Each client learns locally while preserving data privacy by keeping raw EV data on-site and only sharing model parameters. This framework is evaluated using real-world data from a designated parking lot in Chattanooga. By using meta-learning, the FM-D3QN-PER approach enables rapid adaptation to new or changing EV behaviors and uncertain conditions, making it well-suited for dynamic and heterogeneous environments such as real-time EV charging networks.

title: Optimal Battery Life Cycle Management in PV/Wind/Diesel/Fuel Cell Based DC Microgrids using Secretary Bird Optimization
authors: Manoj B. Lonkar, Sushil S. Thale
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: This paper presents an optimized battery management strategy for a DC microgrid powered by hybrid renewable energy sources (RES) including photovoltaic (PV), wind turbines. energy storage elements such as hydrogen-based fuel cells (FC), and battery energy storage system (BESS) are integrated to this DC Microgrid. The Secretary Bird Optimization (SBO) algorithm is employed to identify optimal system configurations that minimize the Annualized Cost of System (ACS) and Cost of Energy (COE) while improving system reliability and extending battery life. Four cases are examined, combining different energy sources in varied proportions. Among these, Case 4, integrating 5 kW PV, 15 kW wind, 5 kWh battery, and a 15 units of hydrogen system, achieves the best reliability with a very low Loss of Power Supply Probability (LPSP) of 0.226%, moderate battery life of 6 years, and optimized energy availability. Although it incurs the highest ACS (₹128,171.51) and COE (₹7.241/kWh), it offers the most balanced and robust solution, ideal for applications requiring continuous, high-reliability power. Comparative analysis shows that single or dual-source systems like Case 1 and Case 3 are more cost-effective but suffer from higher LPSP or reduced functionality. The study concludes that a comprehensive hybrid design, particularly with wind energy, significantly enhances microgrid reliability and long-term sustainability.

title: GTA: A Graph-Transformer Architecture for Micro-Expression Recognition
authors: Ke Wang, Hua Xu, Mengyao Wu, Xunxiang Yao, Peng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Micro-expressions are subtle yet informative facial cues that reveal genuine emotions and have broad applications in security, healthcare, and human-computer interaction. However, the inherent characteristics of micro-expressions such as brief duration and low motion intensity make automatic recognition highly challenging. To address the challenges, this paper proposes a novel Graph-Transformer Architecture (GTA) that integrates Vision Transformers and static graph modeling for effective micro-expression recognition. Particularly, the proposed method firstly extracts magnified shape features and motion information from onset and apex frames to capture fine-grained facial dynamics leveraging offline MagNet and TV-L1, respectively. To exploit relative movement between facial action units, we propose a facial graph that encodes semantic similarities between facial patches in terms of facial landmarks. Built on the graph, a stacked Graph-Transformer that alternates GCN and Transformer layers with learnable graph weights is therefore introduced to further enhance dynamic modeling for discriminative micro-expression feature learning. Extensive experiments are conducted on two benchmark datasets, i.e., CASME II and SAMM, and the results demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in both accuracy and F1 score metrics, highlighting its effectiveness and robustness.

title: Rethinking ISAC Limits over Doubly-Dispersive Channels: A CRLB Analysis Exploiting ISI and ICI
authors: Xueting Xu, Xueyang Hu, Luyang Liu, Yanyu Ma, Fan Jiang, Weichao Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) has become a key technology for next-generation wireless networks, enabling simultaneous data transmission and environment perception. However, in rapidly time-varying channels, inter-symbol and inter-carrier interference (ISCI) can severely degrade ISAC performance. Conventional waveforms are often designed to treat ISCI as pure interference or completely ignore it, which overlooks its potential to carry valuable sensing information. In this work, we revisit this conventional assumption and present an analytical framework to discuss the impact of ISCI in time-frequency domain signaling systems. Specifically, we introduce two perspectives: an interference-dominant viewpoint treating ISCI as useless noise, and an information-bearing viewpoint that exploits ISCI as a source of sensing information. Furthermore, we derive the Fisher information matrix and conduct a comprehensive Cramér–Rao lower bound analysis to quantify the fundamental limits of sensing accuracy under ISCI influence. We also include analysis for position error bound and velocity error bound, showing that ISCI-aware processing can improve sensing precision. Extensive simulations are conducted under different SNRs and mobility conditions to validate our theoretical results.

title: API&APDR Control Applied to LLC Resonant Converters with Output Current Control
authors: Maikel Fernando Menke, Rodrigo Varella Tambara, Álysson Raniere Seidel
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel dual-loop control method, termed API&APDR (Adaptive PI & Adaptive Periodic Disturbance Rejection), applied to an LLC-type resonant converter with output current control. The proposed method enables accurate tracking of constant reference signals while effectively rejecting periodic exogenous disturbances. The control scheme is fully adaptive and follows a quasi-model-free approach. It is particularly well-suited for the second-stage power processing in AC/DC offline applications, such as LED drivers and onboard battery chargers for electric vehicles. Experimental results are provided to validate the proposed control strategy, demonstrating its performance across various operating points of the LLC resonant converter.

title: Beyond the Black Box: A Framework for Explainable and Attack-Resilient Federated Anomaly Detection in IIoT
authors: Andrea Pinto, Yezid Donoso, Jairo A. Gutierrez
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is a promising paradigm for anomaly detection in Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) environments. However, existing FL frameworks suffer from vulnerabilities such as model poisoning attacks, privacy leakage, and a lack of model interpretability, which is critical for IIoT environments. This paper introduces a novel framework, Federated Learning with Explainable Anomaly Signals (FL-EAS), designed to overcome these limitations. FLEAS fundamentally alters the federated learning process by exchanging compact, 21-dimensional feature vector derived from the reconstruction errors of local, explainable models, rather than raw model parameters. The framework incorporates a server-side supervised classifier to detect and reject malicious contributions, thereby ensuring attack resilience. By propagating explainability from the client edge to the global model, FL-EAS provides transparent, human-interpretable results. The efficacy of this approach is contextualized for evaluation using the physical process data from the BATADAL 2.0 dataset, demonstrating a state-of-the-art F1-score of 0.9511 on concealed attacks, and demonstrating its potential for secure, efficient, and trustworthy anomaly detection in real-world Cyber-Physical Systems.

title: On Resolving Non-Preemptivity in Multitask Scheduling: An Optimal Algorithm in Deterministic and Stochastic Worlds
authors: Wenxin Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: The efficient scheduling of multi-task jobs across multiprocessor systems has become increasingly critical with the rapid expansion of computational systems. This challenge, known as Multiprocessor Multitask Scheduling (MPMS), is essential for optimizing the performance and scalability of applications in fields such as cloud computing and deep learning. In this paper, we study the MPMS problem under both deterministic and stochastic models, where each job is composed of multiple tasks and can only be completed when all its tasks are finished. We introduce NP-SRPT, a non-preemptive variant of the Shortest Remaining Processing Time (SRPT) algorithm, designed to accommodate scenarios with non-preemptive tasks. Our algorithm achieves a competitive ratio of ln α + β + 1 for minimizing response time, where α represents the ratio of the largest to the smallest job workload, and β captures the ratio of the largest non-preemptive task workload to the smallest job workload. We further establish that this competitive ratio is order-optimal when the number of processors is fixed. For stochastic systems modeled as M/G/N queues, where job arrivals follow a Poisson process and task workloads are drawn from a general distribution, we prove that NP-SRPT achieves asymptotically optimal mean response time as the traffic intensity ρ approaches 1, assuming the task size distribution has finite support. Moreover, the asymptotic optimality extends to cases with infinite task size distributions under mild probabilistic assumptions, including the standard M/M/N model. Finally, we extend the analysis to the practical setting of unknown job sizes, proving that non-preemptive adaptations of the M-Gittins and M-SERPT policies achieve asymptotic optimality and near-optimality, respectively, for a broad class of job size distributions. Experimental results validate the effectiveness of NP-SRPT, demonstrating its asymptotic optimality in both theoretical and practical settings.

title: Design Approach of Broadband Phase-Dispersive Metasurface for EM Illusion Using Deep Learning-Based Method
authors: Weizhi Chen, Xin Xiu, Jiawei Liu, Wenquan Che
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This work proposes an intelligent optimization algorithm-driven deep learning method for the inverse design of phase-dispersive metasurfaces, enabling broadband electromagnetic (EM) illusion. First, a reflection phase retrieval approach based on the 2-D extension of the generalized Snell’s law and the least-square method is introduced to achieve complex target illusions. On this basis, a genetic algorithm (GA) optimizes an equivalent circuit model (ECM) to generate multilayer configurations designed for broadband reflection phase dispersion. Subsequently, deep learning is utilized to perform the inverse design of the unit cells with two-layer structures based on the target phases over the frequency range of 4.0–7.4 GHz. Finally, a pair of two-layer metasurface arrays, each consisting of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$21\times 21$</tex-math> </inline-formula> unit cells with a thickness of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.11\lambda _{L}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and a periodicity of 10.0mm, is designed and simulated for sloped surface and ellipsoidal cap target illusions. For further validation, two prototypes were fabricated and measured. The results demonstrate a broadband EM illusion spanning 4.0–7.4 GHz (59.6%) under dual linear polarization (LP). The scattered far-field patterns closely replicate those of the actual target structures, indicating the validity of the proposed method.

title: Neural Machine Unranking
authors: Jingrui Hou, Axel Finke, Georgina Cosma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: We address the problem of machine unlearning in neural information retrieval (IR), introducing a novel task termed neural machine unranking (NuMuR). This problem is motivated by growing demands for data privacy compliance and selective information removal in neural IR systems. Existing task-agnostic or model-agnostic unlearning approaches, primarily designed for classification tasks, are suboptimal for NuMuR due to two core challenges: 1) neural rankers output unnormalised relevance scores rather than probability distributions, limiting the effectiveness of traditional teacher–student distillation frameworks and 2) entangled data scenarios, where queries and documents appear simultaneously across both forget and retain sets, may degrade retention performance in existing methods. To address these issues, we propose contrastive and consistent loss (CoCoL), a dual-objective framework. CoCoL comprises 1) a contrastive loss that reduces relevance scores on forget sets while maintaining performance on entangled samples and 2) a consistent loss that preserves accuracy on the retain set. Extensive experiments on two datasets, across four neural IR models, demonstrate that CoCoL achieves substantial forgetting with minimal retention and generalization performance loss. CoCoL facilitates more effective and controllable data removal than existing techniques.

title: A 24.5–45.2-GHz Low-Jitter Compact Differentially Injection-Locked Clock Multiplier With Folded-Inductor-Based Magnetic-Flux Cancellation
authors: Feifan Hong, Jiawen Chen, Pingda Guan, Sayan Kumar, Robert Bogdan Staszewski, Teerachot Siriburanon
publish: IEEE Journal of Solid-State Circuits
abstract: In this article, we present a differentially injection-locked clock multiplier (ILCM) featuring an ultrawide frequency tuning range (TR) and low jitter, achieved through a compact folded-inductor-based magnetic-flux cancellation technique. A codesigned series-LC dual-mode quadrature ring oscillator (QRO) and edge-combining frequency doubler operating in the mm-waveband jointly extend the TR while suppressing phase noise (PN). Furthermore, a differential time-aligning technique enables an exceptionally wide loop bandwidth ( $f_{\text {BW}}$ ). Fabricated in 28-nm HPC+ CMOS, the prototype QRO exhibits a 59.46% TR (12.25–22.6 GHz), while the doubler output spans 24.5–45.23 GHz. Despite its compact core area of 0.037 mm2, the ILCM achieves an rms jitter of 32.83 fs at 39.5 GHz.

title: Bridging the Modality Gap: Enhancing Channel Prediction with Semantically Aligned LLMs and Knowledge Distillation
authors: Zhaoyang Li, Qianqian Yang, Zehui Xiong, Zhiguo Shi, Tony Q. S. Quek
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Accurate channel prediction is essential in massive multiple-input multiple-output (m-MIMO) systems to improve precoding effectiveness and reduce the overhead of channel state information (CSI) feedback. However, existing methods often suffer from accumulated prediction errors and poor generalization to dynamic wireless environments, making it challenging to maintain high prediction accuracy. Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable modeling and generalization capabilities in tasks such as time series prediction, making them a promising solution. Nevertheless, a significant modality gap exists between the linguistic knowledge embedded in pretrained LLMs and the intrinsic characteristics of CSI, posing substantial challenges for their direct application to channel prediction. Moreover, the large parameter size of LLMs hinders their practical deployment in real-world communication systems with stringent latency constraints. To address these challenges, we propose a novel channel prediction framework based on semantically aligned large models, referred to as CSI-ALM, which bridges the modality gap between natural language and channel information. Specifically, we design a cross-modal fusion module that aligns CSI representations with the language feature space using a pretrained corpus. Additionally, we maximize the cosine similarity between word embeddings and CSI embeddings to construct semantic cues, effectively leveraging the latent knowledge in LLMs. To reduce complexity and enable practical implementation, we further introduce a lightweight version of the proposed approach, called CSI-ALM-Light. This variant is derived via a knowledge distillation strategy based on attention matrices, which extracts essential features from the teacher model, CSI-ALM, and transfers them to a compact, efficient student model, CSI-ALM-Light. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that CSI-ALM consistently outperforms state-of-the-art deep learning methods across various communication scenarios, achieving substantial performance gains. Moreover, under limited training data conditions—where all models are trained using only 10% of the original training dataset—CSI-ALM-Light, with only 0.34M parameters, attains performance comparable to CSI-ALM and significantly outperforms conventional deep learning approaches. These validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach for accurate and efficient channel prediction in m-MIMO systems.

title: Recursive Gaussian Process Based Safety Assurance Exploration Control in Unknown Environments
authors: Kento Kanou, Tatsuya Ibuki
publish: IEEE Control Systems Letters
abstract: This article presents a novel method for environmental exploration that takes safety into account in unknown areas by using recursive Gaussian process regression (RGPR). Safety in unknown environments is ensured by an RGPR-based control barrier function, which are constructed non-parametrically from the posterior mean of RGPR. Simultaneously, an exploration function inspired by a control Lyapunov function is presented. This function utilizes the posterior variance of RGPR to achieve efficient exploration. Moreover, the use of RGPR mitigates the cubic growth in computational cost inherent to conventional Gaussian process regression, thereby enabling online learning. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, an experiment using differential-drive robots equipped with a LiDAR sensor is conducted.

title: Cargo UAVs Pick-up Systems for Low-Altitude Economy With Communication Quality, Battery Energy, and Time Window Constraints
authors: Mingjian Chen, Liang Yang, Jiangling Cao, Guangxu Zhu, Weijie Yuan, Hongbo Jiang, Dusit Niyato
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: The rapid development of the low-altitude economy (LAE) has accelerated the deployment of cargo unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for intelligent logistics and delivery services. However, large-scale UAV operations still face multiple practical challenges, including unstable communication connectivity, limited onboard battery energy, and strict customer time-window constraints. To address these issues, this paper investigates the trajectory and task scheduling optimization problem for multi-UAV cooperative cargo pick-up under joint communication, energy, and time-window constraints. We develop a collision-aware cooperative multi-UAV optimization algorithm (CACMO) that integrates a Dueling Deep Q-Network (D3QN) for communication-aware trajectory learning with a simulated annealing (SA) based global task-sequence planner and an explicit inter-UAV conflict-resolution mechanism. The D3QN module enables adaptive trajectory generation in unknown and time-varying radio environments without requiring an a priori radio map, maintaining stable connectivity while reducing flight cost, whereas the SA module determines efficient task orders and enforces safe coordination among multiple UAVs through collision-aware refinement. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed CACMO algorithm framework achieves an optimal balance between task completion time (1,719 seconds) and user satisfaction (score of 0.9969) under typical operating conditions, delivering a 70–75% reduction in total weighted cost compared to representative baseline methods. Crucially, this substantial improvement is achieved while explicitly enforcing multi-UAV collision avoidance-a critical constraint absent in most baseline methods. The framework maintains zero communication outage and guarantees safe inter-UAV separation throughout the mission while satisfying all energy and time window constraints in realistic urban environments, confirming its robustness and scalability for cooperative multi-UAV logistics operations within the LAE.

title: A Weakly Supervised Machine Learning Procedure for Acoustic Emission Quench Diagnostics
authors: Maira Khan, Steven Krave, Vittorio Marinozzi, Jennifer Ngadiuba, Stoyan Stoynev, Nhan Tran
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Voltage taps remain the standard and reliable diagnostic tool for detecting quenches in superconducting magnets. However, they identify a quench only at the time of voltage rise and do not provide information on earlier physical precursors. In this work, we investigate whether acoustic emission data can reveal precursor activity that occurs before conventional voltage detection using machine learning techniques. We introduce an event selection method and a weakly supervised machine learning procedure to learn data-driven criteria for identifying potential acoustic precursors to quenches. Two Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architectures are trained: one on acoustic sensor events from our selection procedure and one on the Fast Fourier Transforms (FFTs) of these events. Both networks are trained iteratively using confidence-weighted loss functions to associate certain subsets of training data with a precursor label. We evaluate the performance of these models by examining the time distribution of events classified as potential precursors relative to the quench onset. Results indicate that the proposed approach can possibly distinguish acoustic emission events occurring closer to the quench from earlier acoustic activity during ramping, suggesting the potential for flagging quench precursors in acoustic data.
