title: Transmission Capacity Analysis of Low-Frequency AC Transmission Overhead Line Under New Energy Delivery Scenario
authors: Ruonan Hu, Gaoshan Hou, Lijun Xie, Xiaoyu Zhang, Cheng Zhao, Minghao Fan
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Flexible low-frequency AC transmission(FLFAC) technology can be widely used in long-distance renewable energy transmission scenarios with its advantages of small reactive power loss and large transmission capacity. In order to effectively design and plan the renewable energy transmission system via FLFAC, this paper carries out the analysis and research of overhead line transmission capacity, and proposes a novel method of calculating voltage along the line. First, the function of voltage distribution along the line is established with respect to voltage level, transmission distance, capacity of renewable energy plant and line impedance, based on which the voltage overrun condition is proposed. Then, renewable energy transmission models with different voltage levels are established in PSCAD to verify the validity of the analysis of voltage along the line, and different distribution characteristics of the voltage along the line under different voltage levels are analyzed. Finally, transmission capacity calculation method of overhead line is proposed. According to the method, the transmission capacity of power frequency and low frequency are compared and analyzed under different voltage levels. Based on the proposed voltage calculation method, this paper analyzes in detail FLFAC advantageous intervals as well as the fundamental principle of FLFAC to enhance the transmission capacity.

title: Intellectus: An AI Model to Enhance Student Cognitive Performance, Increase Knowledge Acquisition, Boost Academic Integrity and Mitigate AI Over-Reliance in Education
authors: Afrin Fathima Razvi, Engie Bashir
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: This study presents Intellectus, a fine-tuned large language model (LLM) designed to enhance student cognitive performance, boost knowledge acquisition and mitigate AI over-reliance in education. In contrast to traditional AI tools that provide direct answers, Intellectus engages learners through Socratic questioning, adaptive scaffolding, and structured prompting. Developed using a no-code Custom GPT approach and grounded in a systematic literature review, Intellectus was evaluated through a triangulated methodology combining student self-assessments, expert ratings, and plagiarism analysis. A/B testing with twelve university students showed significant gains across ten higher-order cognitive skills when using Intellectus compared to ChatGPT, alongside a dramatic reduction in plagiarism rates. Expert evaluations further validated these findings, confirming Intellectus' ability to promote deeper thinking and academic integrity, and T-testing proved statistical significance across domains.

title: Research on the Efficiency of Different Classes of Electric Cars
authors: Vasil Dimitrov, Atanas Nikolov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: Electric cars can be divided into different classes for comparison - from small five-door electric hatchbacks, through larger sedans, SUVs and crossovers, to cargo or passenger vans. For a valid measurement and comparison of energy consumption, cars must be tested under the same or realistically close driving conditions - the same route, certain maximum and average speeds, as well as driving style. This paper presents such measurements, and after analysis it is concluded that Tesla cars have lower consumption than their competitors. The energy consumption of Tesla Models 3 and $\mathbf{Y}$ is similar and, in some cases, lower than that of smaller hatchbacks despite their greater mass, power, frontal area, as well as tires with a larger diameter and width. This is mainly due to the low drag coefficient of 0,23 and the optimization of the electrical drive and the electric vehicle in general.

title: Smart Building-Robot Cooperation via Delegated Control: Enabling Lightweight Elevator Integration
authors: Katsutoshi Amano, Hangli Ge, Yasuhira Chiba, Noboru Koshizuka
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Service robots for delivery, security, and cleaning are increasingly being deployed in urban smart buildings. However, conventional robot-centric approaches face scalability and security limitations, especially when (i) multiple robots must share the same facility and (ii) guest or newly deployed robots must be onboarded instantly. We propose a Delegated Control framework that shifts high-level logic to the building side. A centralized agent server orchestrates elevators and other facilities, publishes commands via MQTT-based publish-subscribe communication protocol, and issues session-scoped capability tokens that grant each robot only the minimum required privileges. The framework has three features: (1) Infrastructure-centric asynchronous orchestration that coordinates many robots and facilities; (2) Fine-grained, time-bounded security realized by static ACLs and dynamically generated MQTT topics; and (3) Hardwareagnostic interfaces that remove the need for additional special devices on the robot. We implemented the system in a fivestory research building and evaluated it using two delivery robots operating with a shared elevator. The evaluation achieved 100% coordination success with MQTT latency below 2 ms, demonstrating that policy-aware MQTT orchestration combined with delegated control enables scalable and secure robot-building cooperation.

title: A Survey on Generative AI Applications for Geo-Economic Pattern Modeling and Predictive Mapping
authors: Eirini Lagiou, Chrysostomos Stylios
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: This survey explores the transformative role of Generative Artificial Intelligence (GAI) in geo-economic modeling and predictive mapping. It reviews key applications of GAI in urban growth, economic inequality, migration, trade networks, and environmental risk assessment. The study also examines performance evaluation metrics and benchmark datasets essential for validating GAI models in spatial-economic contexts. Furthermore, it discusses current challenges—including model generalization, explainability, fairness, and multimodal data integration—and outlines future research directions. The survey highlights the potential of GAI to advance adaptive, transparent, and equitable geo-economic analysis, supporting data-driven decision-making for sustainable regional development.

title: Research on Line Loss Prediction Method for Low Voltage Distribution Stations Based on GWO-SVMD and LSTNet
authors: Yifan Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Line loss in low-voltage distribution station areas is a critical operational metric for power systems, and accurately predicting line loss rate in these areas is essential for efficiency of power grid. Addressing the limitations of current methods for predicting non-stationary signals and identifying factors influencing line loss rates, this paper introduces a novel prediction approach for line loss in low-voltage distribution networks. It leverages a successive variational mode decomposition optimized by gray wolf optimizer (GWO-SVMD) and employs a long- and short-term time-series network (LSTNet), taking into account local climatic characteristics and other relevant influencing factors within the station area. By integrating the precise separation of non-stationary line loss data provided by GWO-SVMD with LSTNet's comprehensive exploration of temporal and spatial characteristics, this method enhances prediction accuracy while reducing computational complexity. Verified against specific station district line loss data, the approach was able to predict the line loss rate over extended periods with an average prediction error of less than 0.55%. GWO-SVMD-LSTNet is superior to traditional time series forecasting models, achieving effective fusion of long-term and short-term patterns in complex time series forecasting tasks, demonstrating its effectiveness in capturing complex time patterns in time series data. The proposed method offers a promising new strategy for minimizing power grid losses and enhancing efficiency.

title: SPEP: Adaptive Resource Orchestration in Quantum Networks through Strategic Entanglement Pre-Positioning
authors: Vineet Kumar Dwivedi, Vivek Shukla, Chandrashekar Jatoth, Rajesh Doriya, Rajkumar Buyya
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: Quantum networks promise unprecedented capabilities for secure communication and distributed quantum computing through entanglement distribution. However, the fragile nature of quantum entanglement and its exponential decay present significant challenges for efficient resource allocation. This paper introduces SPEP (Strategic Predictive Entanglement Pre-positioning), a novel framework that leverages machine learning techniques to anticipate communication demands and proactively establish entangled links. We implement and evaluate multiple prediction models including LSTM neural networks and ARIMA time series analysis, comparing them against traditional reactive and greedy routing approaches. Through comprehensive simulations across four distinct network topologies with over multiple simulation runs, our SPEP framework demonstrates significant improvement in success rates, $15 \%$ reduction in average latency, and $25 \%$ better resource utilization compared to baseline methods. The results provide strong evidence that machine learning-driven prediction can significantly enhance quantum network performance, particularly in networks with temporal demand patterns.

title: Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks for Marine Aquaculture Site Suitability: A Case Study in the Southeastern Sea of Tamil Nadu
authors: Dhivya Kalaiinban, Venkatesan. M, Prabhavathy. P
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Aquaculture plays a pivotal role in ensuring food security and boosting coastal economies, yet its sustainable growth relies on precise site suitability assessments driven by complex marine dynamics. This study introduces a deep learning-based framework using Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks (KANs) to evaluate aquaculture zone suitability along the southeastern coast of Tamil Nadu, India. The model integrates remote sensing–derived oceanographic parameters—including Chlorophyll-a, Colored Dissolved Organic Matter (CDOM), Sea Surface Temperature (SST), Suspended Particulate Matter (SPM), and Dissolved Oxygen (DO)—sourced from NASA MODIS and VIIRS datasets. The KAN model dynamically captures nonlinear relationships and spatial variability across eight predefined coastal zones, from Nagapattinam to Pondicherry. Among the zones, Tharangambadi (Zone 3) emerged as the most suitable location, achieving the highest prediction accuracy of 83.2%, followed closely by Karaikal and Cuddalore. SST showed the best model performance, while CDOM and DO also demonstrate strong predictive accuracy above 80%. Compared to conventional GIS-MCDA techniques, KAN offers superior interpretability, adaptability, and performance in complex oceanographic environments. The results highlight the potential of KANs as a robust, scalable, and data-driven decision-support tool for marine aquaculture zoning and sustainable coastal resource management.

title: Deep Learning-Driven Sustainable Data Architecture for Financial Forecasting and Decision Support in Financial Institutions
authors: Himani Fnu, Mahatma Reddy Marri, Shweta Gupta, Raju Katukam, Priti Singla, Kavita Arora
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: In today's fast-evolving financial landscape, modern financial institutions face increasing challenges in managing vast volumes of dynamic and heterogeneous financial data. Sustainable financial forecasting has become crucial for ensuring accurate budget planning, risk mitigation, and informed decision-making. However, traditional financial prediction systems often lack the ability to efficiently handle temporal dependencies, leads to inaccurate forecasts and suboptimal decisions which fail to adapt to rapid market shifts and evolving economic patterns. To address these challenges, this study introduces a deep learning-driven sustainable data architecture used for financial forecasting and decision support in financial institutions. The proposed model uses the Swin transform attention network (SAttNet) to process timeseries financial data and extract contextual dependencies across multiple temporal layers. The deep reinforcement learning (DRL) is used to adapt forecasting strategies in response to fluctuating financial conditions, thereby enhancing prediction robustness and model adaptability. The proposed STAttNet+DRL architecture is validated using a real-world hospital cost prediction dataset, demonstrates capability to model institutional-level financial dynamics. Experimental findings confirm that the proposed model outperforms traditional methods in terms of prediction accuracy and execution efficiency. The proposed deep learning architecture offers intelligent forecasting solution, empowering financial institutions to make accurate and strategic financial decisions.

title: Single-Phase Grounding Protection Method for AC Microgrids Based on Single-Ended Ranging
authors: Liuming Jing, Qinghua Liu, Jinxuan Guo, Jiahe Wei
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: AC microgrids are typically small current grounding systems and use a high proportion of power electronics-based renewable energy sources, resulting in unclear fault current characteristics in the microgrid. Secondly, the fault transient time in microgrids is short, and fault characteristics are easily influenced by factors such as harmonics and phase shifts, making fault localization challenging. To address these issues, this paper proposes a local protection method for single-phase ground faults in AC microgrids based on single-ended instantaneous voltage and current components. This method is similar to traditional differential equation-based distance measurement algorithms, with the key feature being the full utilization of local information. enabling fault distance estimation in AC microgrids without relying on communication methods. The algorithm employs a weighted recursive least squares algorithm for parameter estimation and integrates a sliding window average value filtering algorithm to compensate and correct the estimated values, thereby achieving precise fault distance estimation. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed protection method was thoroughly validated under a typical AC microgrid model based on PSCAD/EMTDC. The results demonstrate that the method exhibits high fault location accuracy, response speed, and noise robustness.

title: Fabrication of Flexible Electrochemical Sensor for Interstitial Fluid Biomarker Monitoring Using Pattern Transfer Method
authors: Boyu Qin, Jongho Park, Beomjoon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE CPMT Symposium Japan (ICSJ)
abstract: In this study, a flexible electrochemical sensor patch was fabricated using a pattern transfer method. The sensor could continuously detect glucose concentration using amperometric measurements with a sensitivity of 49 nA/mM.

title: Non-Intrusive Load Disaggregation Based on TimesNet and Transfer Learning
authors: Qifang Chen, Jiayi Yu, Mingchao Xia, Guangyu Liu, Chong Meng, Qianhao Sun, Yubin Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Accurate electricity consumption monitoring at the individual appliance level is pivotal for enhancing energy efficiency and enabling sophisticated demand-side management. Traditional Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring (NILM) methods, leveraging deep learning, frequently encounter challenges such as data scarcity and inadequate generalization. A novel Non-Intrusive Load Disaggregation (NILD) model integrating the TimesNet architecture with transfer learning is proposed. The TimesNet model excels in decomposing time-series data into multiple periods, thereby capturing intricate temporal relationships. To address the limitations of deep learning in NILD, a transfer learning approach based on Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD) Loss for domain adaptation is introduced. Additionally, a two-stage dynamic training strategy is devised to enhance model performance. Experimental validations on the UK Domestic Appliance-Level Electricity (UK-DALE) dataset and simulated data demonstrate that the method significantly improves the accuracy of electricity load disaggregation, outperforming conventional approaches in scenarios with limited data and diverse domain distributions.

title: Evaluating Building Damage Classification Accuracy: A Benchmarking Study of UNet
authors: Sajitha. Ikkara, Rakoth Kandan Sambandam, Saju P John
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Building damage classification must be done accurately and quickly in order to support disaster response and recovery activities. Deep learning models, particularly U-Net, have demonstrated strong potential in automating damage assessment from satellite and aerial imagery. This study benchmarks the accuracy of U-Net in classifying building damage across multiple datasets, evaluating its performance against ground truth labels. Key factors such as data preprocessing, augmentation techniques, and model variations are analyzed to determine their impact on classification accuracy. The results provide insights into the strengths and limitations of variations in U-Net for damage assessment, highlighting areas for improvement and future research directions

title: Analyzing the Reactive Power Compensation Influence on Small Oscillation in Distribution Network Operations
authors: Luu Huu Vinh Qunag
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: We propose the new expressions combined by the cumulative value of transient voltage stability estimation (TVSE) with the values of the transient kinetic energy (KE) and potential energy (PE) involved in the dynamic states caused by the transitory structures of medium voltage power distribution network operations under different conditions impacted by optimal power capacitor planning with the transformer tap settings. A new analysis algorithm is built and applied to evaluate the small oscillation stability in medium voltage power distribution networks. Typical examples of the simulation of the transitory process of power distribution network structure, including the sudden increase and decrease of some load bus power values and the switching operations of some power distribution lines to ensure the continuous power supply, causing the small oscillation states in power distribution networks, are calculated and analyzed to evaluate the small oscillation stability under the impact of optimal power capacitor planning operation in power distribution networks. The proposed algorithm with new formulas demonstrated is proved with effective results, allowing the comparative analysis and assessment of small-oscillation stability in medium-voltage distribution networks under different conditions of the typical small disturbances in medium-voltage power network operation.

title: A Multidimensional Framework for Evaluating Socio-Technical Innovation Readiness in Urban Living Labs: Methodology and Application
authors: Augusto Velasquez Mendez, Jorge de Jesús Lozoya-Santos, Gabriel Felipe Dicelis Ramos, Eduardo Vanegas Quijano, Gabriel Felipe Dicelis Ramos, Juan David Salguero Medina
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Urban Living Labs (ULLs) are increasingly used as platforms for co-creation and experimentation of socio-technical innovations in real-world settings. However, evaluating these innovations often lacks integrated frameworks considering both technological and social aspects. This paper proposes a multidimensional evaluation framework designed to assess the maturity and scalability of innovations developed within ULLs, incorporating four complementary perspectives: Technological Readiness Level (TRL), Societal Readiness Level (SRL), Organizational Readiness Level (ORL), and Scaling Readiness (ScR). The framework is applied to a pilot project carried out in the urban garden of the ULL in Fenicia, Bogota, where an IoTbased soil monitoring sensor was implemented and iteratively codeveloped with community members, a tech startup, government actors, and academic researchers. The analysis shows how each dimension offers critical insights into the innovation's development, adoption potential, and capacity for replication beyond the local context. This approach provides a replicable tool for guiding decision-making and increasing the impact of experimental interventions in ULLs, especially in complex urban environments of the Global South.

title: Pid Controlled Hybrid Renewable Energy System with Load Sharing Topology
authors: Sangeetha V, Vinita Chellappan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: As the world rapidly moves towards sustainability and clean energy, making our sources renewable is a mandatory goal across all sectors. Renewable energy sources have different limitations when used independently due to temporal fluctuations in the availability of renewable resources. Using a combination of two or three sources can help achieve maximum benefits in the power sector. A topology is proposed to optimize the hybridization of two renewable energy sources, which can be utilized in the electric vehicle sector. Energy from solar and fuel cells is shared using a load-sharing topology. The input from the sources is applied to a Zeta Converter, which is used to boost the input voltage to a constant and desired output voltage. A converter is mathematically modeled, and a PID controller is designed for the linearized model, which helps to maintain a constant output voltage despite variations in input irradiance and temperature conditions.

title: Distributed Cooperative Target Search Method for Multiple UAVs Under Communication Range Constraints
authors: Jin Luo, Mingzhu Wei, Hongyu Zhang, Qiuyun Tan, Xiaomei Xie, Yunfan Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Target searching problem in an unknown area for the Multi-UAV system is difficult because of the dynamic targets and limited communication, target searching problem in an unknown area for Multi-UAV system is difficult to solve. This study proposes a model predictive control algorithm to solve the target searching problem with Multi-UAVs. By introducing information sharing and target prediction strategies, the algorithm can achieve better detection accuracy. Simulation results show the effectiveness and advantages of the proposed algorithm compared with other strategies.

title: Experimental Evaluation of the Influence of Current Measurement Point on DC Arc Fault Detection in Photovoltaic Inverters
authors: Murilo Lucher da Silveira, Lucas Vizzotto Bellinaso, Leandro Michels, Leonardo Emmendorfer, Carlos Eduardo Weidle Simon, Alencar Fernandes Farias, Maria Clara Bohn Silva, Eduardo Bao de Oliveira, Charles Andre Haab, Gilberto da Cunha, Márcio Sari, Rafael Alberto dos Santos
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: The detection of direct current (DC) arc faults is a fundamental requirement for the safety of photovoltaic (PV) systems, as established by IEC 63027. Although several approaches have been proposed for arc fault detection, few studies have experimentally investigated the influence of the current measurement point on detection performance and the feasibility of self-test implementation in PV inverters. This work addresses this gap by evaluating four measurement points in a commercial inverter with an input Boost DC-DC converter: on the faulty string, on the non-faulty string (reference), after string parallelization, and at the input capacitor. The acquired signals were analyzed using spectrograms, frequency response, and spectral metrics in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10-50 \text{kHz}$</tex> range, which is typically associated with arc fault signatures. The results indicate that the choice of measurement location directly impacts spectral sensitivity, the feasibility of performing self-tests through Boost converter PWM excitation, and the ability to identify the faulty string. The comparative analysis provides practical insights for the integration of sensors into embedded Arc Fault Protection Equipment (AFPE) in PV inverters, in compliance with regulatory requirements.

title: Equivalent Circuit Modelling in Pumped-Hydro Energy Storage Systems
authors: Shuangqing Yan, Yang Zheng
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The pumped-hydro energy storage plant is a complex nonlinear system with strong hydraulic-mechanical coupling feature. To establish a mathematical model of the flow passage in the power plant that can precisely describe the complicated hydraulic characteristics, the equivalent circuit modeling theory is introduced in this study. The flow passage is divided into several parts, and the differential equations of the equivalent circuit of the pipeline and the hydraulic boundaries in each part are deduced. The accuracy of the proposed model is validated through simulating the transition process of the load rejection condition of the pumped storage unit. Differences between the equivalent circuit model and the conventional characteristic line method are compared, and the slack constraint on temporal-spatial steps and the computational efficiency of the equivalent circuit model are analyzed.

title: Study of Small Target Defect Detection on Packaging Surface Based on Improved YOLOv5n
authors: Shifei Jiang, Zhaoguo Zhang, Faan Wang, Zhi Li, Yanbo Lu, Jinhao Liang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: To improve the detection accuracy of small defects on the packaging surface of industrial products, the YOLOV5 network model is improved in this paper. The primary contributions of this work are threefold: Firstly, an improved YOLOv5 network model is AiSpBc-YOLOv5n proposed, in which a BCSP1 module network structure combining series and parallel connection is added to the backbone network, and this improvement enhances the ability of feature extraction for small target defects, which can improve the detection accuracy of small target defects. Secondly, The SPLIT slice structure is added to the backbone network of the YOLOv5 model, which enhances the shallow feature extraction ability of the model and improves the expression ability of the defective features of small targets. The improvement avoids feature information being lost during processing and provides reference ideas for the optimization of other models. Lastly, AiSpBc-YOLOv5n model training and validation is accomplished through the small target defect dataset of a product package, which includes the defects on box packaging surface and on the roll packaging surface of a product, and the results show that the improved model has significant effect on the detection of small target defects, and it provides a reference for the detection of small target defects of the same kind of packaging surface.

title: Implementation of a Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) at an existing hydroelectric power plant
authors: Daniel Dobrilov, Ivan Tenchev, Lyudmil Kirilov, Valeri Uzunov, Slav Dimitrov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: The subject of this paper is the implementation of a Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) at an existing hydroelectric power plant. The system is currently being constructed and will be connected at 6.3 kV to the existing plant equipment. Its control system will be fully integrated into the plant’s existing SCADA system, enabling complete automation. The newly installed system is designed to operate on market principles, independently of the hydro plant’s operation, and can also provide grid balancing and ancillary services when required.

title: Research on Real-Time Electromagnetic Transient Simulation Modeling of High Proportion New Energy Power System with Multiple DC Feed-in
authors: Xiaoli Zhang, Xiao Lei, Limin Yang, Lin Liu, Guangheng Pang, Yan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the rapid development of new energy power generation technologies, as well as large-capacity HVDC and flexible DC technologies, a large-scale deployment of high proportions of renewable energy and power electronic equipment in actual power grids has brought profound changes to the steady-state and dynamic characteristics of interconnected power grids. To understand the behavior patterns and operational characteristics of multi-type HVDC feed-in power systems with high proportions of renewable energy and power electronic equipment, the accuracy and scale of simulation models need to be significantly improved. The simulation models should cover the 220 kV and above power grid structures of the AC system simulation area, including multi-type of HVDC models, and power electronic equipment models such as photovoltaic and wind turbines. This paper proposes modeling methods for electromagnetic transient precise models of power electronic equipment including renewable energy units and multiple types of DC, and builds a simulation model of high-proportion renewable energy power systems with multi-type HVDC feed-in based on the HYPERSIM simulation platform. Based on this simulation model, a series of AC and DC faults are studied, and the steady-state operation and fault response characteristics are investigated. This model can be used for subsequent simulation research on the stability characteristics and control strategies of high-proportion renewable energy power systems with multi-type HVDC feed-in, providing decision-making support for planning and design, as well as operation and dispatch.

title: Coordinated Beamforming for Interference Management in a CoMP-Based Integrated Terrestrial and Non-Terrestrial Network
authors: Arnold Odongo, Hafswa N. Babirye, Denise Joanitah Birabwa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Integrated Terrestrial-Non-Terrestrial Networks (ITNTNs) play a vital role in supporting ubiquitous 5 G and beyond wireless coverage, leveraging both ground base stations (BSs) and aerial platforms such as Low Altitude Platforms (LAPs), High Altitude Platforms (HAPs) and satellites collectively working together to boost network connectivity in underserved areas. However, the coexistence of terrestrial and aerial platforms create substantial interference challenges due to overlapping coverage and the use of shared or harmonized spectrum. Coordinated Multi-Point (CoMP) has proven effective in overcoming interference in terrestrial networks through careful coordination of the different BSs, it has not been fully exploited in ITNTNs. This paper proposes a centralized CoMP architecture that employs static clustering scheme where the ITNTN cluster is composed of one LAP and three macrocell BSs, and coordinated beamforming framework to minimize interference and boost the Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR) for users within the ITNTN coverage. The framework employs Semi-Orthogonal User Selection (SUS) and Regularized ZeroForcing (RZF) beamforming to jointly schedule users and design beamforming vectors, with the objective of maximizing the minimum user SINR. Through comprehensive simulations, we aim to validate the effectiveness of our proposed method and analyze its performance against non-CoMP baselines and other precoding techniques like Zero-Forcing (ZF) and Maximum Ratio Transmission (MRT). Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly enhances SINR.

title: A Multi-Object Tracking Method Based on Multi-Drone Collaborative Perspectives
authors: Zide Fan, Pengfei Li, Xiaohe Li, Haohua Wu, Keqing Zhu, Ying Geng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: For the multi-object tracking problem from multi-drone perspectives, we proposes a method based on measuring trajectory feature similarity. It leverages appearance, position, and projection features from local trajectories observed by individual drone to calculate global trajectory similarity comprehensively. By optimizing the trajectory-target association matrix, we yields interpretable optimal matching results across perspectives. Synergistically utilizing complementary information from multi-drone perspectives, the approach computes global multi-object tracking results. Experimental results on MDMT dataset demonstrate our method’s excellent performance across multiple evaluation metrics, effectively addressing common issues of target occlusion and reappearance in complex scenes.

title: Robust Sleep Bruxism Detection Using Multimodal Physiological Signal Classification and Crossdataset Machine Learning
authors: Daniela Ana Ioana Piritu, Dragos Daniel Taralunga
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of different machine learning approaches for improving the diagnosis of sleep bruxism based on multimodal physiological signals, like the electromyogram (EMG), the electroencephalogram (EEG), and the electrocardiogram (ECG). These signals capture muscle electrical activity, cortical motor control, and autonomic cardiac response, respectively, recorded during polysomnography experimental setup. Sleep bruxism affects approximately 22% of the global population and is associated with dental wear, musculoskeletal pain, and sleep disturbances. The proposed methodology involves extracting relevant features from each biosignal and applying machine learning algorithms for binary classification. A comparative evaluation is conducted to assess the diagnostic value of each biosignal individually and in multimodal combinations. The approach is validated on two physiological signal datasets processed to simulate real-world clinical variability. The results aim to identify the most effective signal or fusion strategy for automated, accurate detection of bruxism, contributing to the development of non-invasive diagnostic tools and advancing multimodal biosignal analysis in sleep disorder research.

title: Sensorless Speed Control of Induction Motor Using SMO
authors: Mumna M Najeeb, Vidya M.S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: This paper presents a simulation-based approach for sensorless speed control of an induction motor by estimating rotor position and speed using only stator voltage and current measurements. The proposed method eliminates the need for mechanical sensors, enhancing system reliability and reducing cost. A mathematical model of the induction motor is developed in a stationary reference frame, and rotor speed and position are estimated using a model-based observer technique. The estimated values are integrated into a vector control scheme to achieve precise speed regulation under varying load conditions. Simulation results in MATLAB/Simulink demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, showing accurate dynamic performance, robustness to parameter variations, and rapid convergence of the estimation algorithm. This method provides a practical solution for high-performance industrial drives where sensorless operation is desirable. The key contribution of this work is the integration of SMO with FOC, which achieves higher estimation accuracy, improved robustness, and lower implementation cost compared to conventional observer techniques.

title: Carbon-Aware Scheduling of Software Updates in Personal Computers
authors: Jiwan Jung
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Green Energy and Smart Systems (GESS)
abstract: The increasing energy demand for personal computers contributes to carbon emissions, particularly through software updates. To address this, we propose a carbon-intensity-aware update scheduling scheme. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme, we applied it to operating system updates. By scheduling these updates during periods of low carbon intensity, the approach successfully reduced the total carbon footprint. The evaluation results show that our approach can reduce carbon emissions by up to 7.10% with minimal compromise to system integrity.

title: In-Situ Error Detection Flip Flops for SEU and SET in 180 nm Bulk CMOS
authors: Karel Appels, Stefan De Raedemaeker, Wim Dehaene, Jeffrey Prinzie
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: This paper presents an in-situ Error Detection Flip-Flop (EDFF) which can detect Single-Event Transients (SETs) at its data input and Single-Event Upsets (SEUs) internally in the cell. Its circuit design is fully automated and implemented only using digital design flow. The corresponding constraints are elaborated in the paper to address additional hold constraints on the design. The EDFF was implemented in a 180 nm bulk Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor (CMOS) technology and was functionally tested using 62.5 MeV.cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/mg heavy ions. Additional tests were performed during a Two-Photon Absorption (TPA) laser campaign.

title: Investigation of the Mechanical Properties of Electrical-Grade Aluminum (Al 99.9%) Modified with Carbon Nanomaterials
authors: Ana Dimitrova
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: The crystallization process in technically pure metals typically results in the formation of a coarse-grained structure, which limits their mechanical and operational performance. This study investigates the mechanical properties of electrical-grade high-purity aluminum (Al 99.9%) modified with nanodiamonds and carbon nanoparticles. The primary objective is to evaluate the effect of nanomodification on the strength and ductility of aluminum and to identify patterns in the mechanical behavior changes induced by the modification. Tensile strength, yield strength, elongation, and Brinell hardness were determined for both unmodified and modified specimens. The influence of the modified microstructure on the material’s performance characteristics is also discussed.

title: OpenAtlas Discovery: A Cross-Domain Visualization Platform for the Digital Humanities
authors: Olivia Reichl, Katharina Wünsche, Bernhard Koschiček-Krombholz, Nina Richards, Alexander Watzinger
publish: 2025 IEEE Workshop on Visualization for the Digital Humanities (VIS4DH)
abstract: Over the past years, publishing structured and semantically enriched research data has become more and more important in digital humanities projects. To present this data to a broader audience, however, many research projects rely on custom-built, one-off presentation sites that are difficult to maintain, adapt, or reuse. This paper introduces the concept of reusable and configurable presentation site templates as a means to promote sustainability, accessibility, and interpretability in digital humanities interfaces. We present OpenAtlas Discovery, a web-based visualization frontend designed to support exploratory interaction with semantically enriched data across a variety of domains. Drawing on six core design requirements, we describe how the system enables spatio-temporal and relational exploration through maps, networks, and detail views. Case studies and a recent workshop illustrate the platform’s adaptability, usability, and potential to serve as a lightweight alternative to custom-built sites. We argue that reusable presentation site templates can lower development barriers for projects with limited technical resources and play a key role in supporting inclusive, long-term digital scholarship.

title: Analysis of failures in the medium voltage power distribution network
authors: Georgi Dimov, Svetlana Tzvetkova, Yavor Lozanov, Angel Petleshkov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This paper presents a study of the impact of various causes of failures on the quality of electrical energy and power supply in medium voltage power distribution networks. An analysis of the causes of power outages in the power distribution network for a period of five years has been made.

title: Improving Wind Speed Forecasting using a Novel hybrid model of Convolutional Neural Network and Transformer with Multi-head Attention Mechanism
authors: Thu Nguyen Thi Hoai, Ky Pham Phong, Tuan Anh Nguyen Trung, Bach Do Xuan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: In this paper, a hybrid model combining Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Transformer architectures is proposed for wind speed forecasting. In this model, the CNN is employed to extract sequential patterns and trends from the input data while also reducing its dimensionality, serving as a preprocessing step for the Transformer. The Transformer then generates forecast results, leveraging its strong data modeling capabilities. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed model, wind speed data from the Hong Phong 1 power plant in Binh Thuan, Vietnam, were collected and applied. The dataset was first cleaned by handling missing values and outliers, after which it was passed through the CNN and Transformer components to produce the final forecasting. The performance of the CNN-Transformer model was compared with Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM), standalone CNN and CNN-LSTM through by using RMSE, NRMSE, MAPE and R2 as the main performance indicators. The results show that the CNN-Transformer hybrid model achieved low forecasting errors, with a MAPE of 1.93% for single-step forecasting, 1.52% for 4-step forecasting, and 4.02% for 16-step forecasting. These error rates are the lowest among the compared models, including LSTM, CNN, and CNN-LSTM, confirming the strong performance of the proposed approach. Overall, the findings highlight the effectiveness of the CNN-Transformer model for wind speed forecasting, as it consistently produced accurate forecasts with minimal errors.

title: Absorptive and Highly Selective Band-Pass Polarization-Selective Surface
authors: Zhiliang Yang, Weiliang Yu, Guo Qing Luo, Zhongxiang Shen
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: This paper proposes a polarization selective surface that achieves third-order high selectivity and wide passband transmission under one polarization by cascading band-stop FSS, air layer, and second-order bandpass FSS. There are transmission zeros on both sides of the passband, and it has broadband absorption effect under the other orthogonal polarization. Through full wave simulations, it is shown that |S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</inf>| of the proposed design is lower than -10 dB from 3.25 GHz to 9.75 GHz under X polarization. A transmission of less than 1 dB loss is achieved from 6 GHz to 7.7 GHz under Y polarization, with two transmission zeros at 5 GHz and 10.2 GHz, respectively. The excellent performance of the metasurface for two different polarizations makes it potentially useful in multi-polarization antenna systems.

title: A Linear Transformation-based Temporal-Continuous Approach of Aggregating GDERs
authors: Zhaocheng Zhang, Mingyu Yan, Yize Liu, Tianyu Sima, Chunmiao Zhang, Yijia Zhou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: With the escalating penetration of renewable energy resources, the composition of power generation sources is now a diverse array of generator-like distributed energy resources (GDERs), including combined heat and power (CHPs), photovoltaics (PVs), wind turbines (WTs) and beyond. This trend has introduced significant challenges in two aspects: 1) the effective management of these GDERs as a cohesive entity and 2) considering GDERs dynamic characteristics. In this context, this paper proposes a linear transformation-based temporal-continuous (TC) approach specifically designed to aggregate GDERs. The study commences with an extensive review of the current state of modeling and aggregation research, highlighting the limitations of existing methods in capturing sub-hourly characteristics and addressing computational complexity. To bridge these gaps, a TC model of GDERs based on Bernstein polynomials is proposed, followed by the derivation of their polytopes and base polytope. Subsequently, the linear transformation of the base polytope into the aggregated polytope is executed. The efficacy of the proposed method is rigorously evaluated through numerical tests on a set of GDERs, with its performance compared against traditional TD model. The manuscript concludes by presenting results that demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach and by outlining potential future research directions.

title: Pseudo-Relevance Feedback with Deep Learning for Automated ICD-10 Coding
authors: Kitti Akkhawatthanakun, Lalita Narupiyakul, Konlakorn Wongpatikaseree, Narit Hnoohom, Paisarn Muneesawang
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: Thailand’s decentralized healthcare system faces ongoing difficulties with ICD-10 coding, including staffing shortages and coding errors that affect reimbursement processes and clinical operations. We developed a deep learning framework that combines pseudo-relevance feedback (PRF) with the Rocchio algorithm to improve how clinical notes are mapped to ICD10 codes. Our approach was tested using the MIMIC-IV-Note dataset, where we achieved a micro F1-score of 59.5 and Precision@8 of 70.8 after applying iterative PRF improvements. We also built a web-based tool that provides real-time coding predictions through an easy-to-use interface, automated data processing, and API connections that work with existing hospital systems. The results demonstrate that our approach provides hospitals with an effective tool for more accurate medical record coding while lightening the workload for clinical staff. Because the system integrates smoothly with existing healthcare IT systems, it presents a realistic option for enhancing coding efficiency in actual clinical environments.

title: Real-Time Radiation Dosimeter Using SRAM Power-Up State
authors: Abishek Stephen Vellankanni, Umeshwarnath Surendranathan, Justin Bell, Alexander Brandl, Lei R. Cao, Indranil Chatterjee, Biswajit Ray
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: We propose to utilize the power-up state of SRAM memory as a radiation dosimeter. Experimental evaluation shows monotonic response of SRAM-dosimeter up to 350 krad(Si) with minimum dose-sensitivity of 200rad(Si).

title: Exploring the Adoption and Loyalty Factors in Wondr by BNI Using an Extended UTAUT2 Model
authors: Madek Purnama, Cokorda Pramartha, Christina Dewi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: This study investigates the adoption and sustained use of Wondr by BNI, a next-generation mobile banking application launched by Bank Negara Indonesia (BNI) in 2024 to replace the previous BNI Mobile Banking platform. Using an extended Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology 2 (UTAUT2) model, the research integrates perceived trust, perceived risk, self-efficacy, and user loyalty to better capture psychological and behavioral dimensions in mobile financial services. A quantitative, cross-sectional survey was conducted with 159 respondents from various regions in Indonesia. Data were analyzed using Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM) via SmartPLS 3.0. Results reveal that habit and price value significantly influence users’ behavioral intention to adopt the app. Additionally, behavioral intention and user loyalty significantly predict actual system usage, with loyalty serving as a key mediating variable. In contrast, original UTAUT2 predictors, performance expectancy, effort expectancy, social influence, and hedonic motivation did not show significant effects on behavioral intention. Similarly, the extended constructs, perceived trust, perceived risk, and self-efficacy were also insignificant despite high mean scores. This may reflect high digital confidence among younger users and strong institutional trust, leading to reduced risk perception and low variance in responses. The findings suggest that emotional engagement, habit formation, and perceived value are more critical than utilitarian or social factors. The study offers practical implications for mobile banking design and highlights the need for future research in highly digitalized user environments.

title: Fault-Tolerant Control Strategy for High-Voltage Fault-Tolerant Permanent Magnet Synchronous Generators under Open-Circuit Faults
authors: Pengzhao Wang, Xiangjun Zeng, Fang Wang, Wei Song, Wei Ran, Yiping Luo
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: This paper proposes a fault-tolerant (FT) control strategy for high-voltage fault-tolerant permanent magnet synchronous generators (HVFTPMSGs) operating under open-circuit faults. To ensure generality, an equivalent circuit model is developed to analyze output power characteristics of the HVFTPMSGs under normal and open-circuit scenarios. Based on the analysis results, the NSGA-III algorithm is employed to optimize the current allocation among the healthy phases, with the constraint of unity power factor operation. The control strategy aims to maximize average output power, minimize power ripple, and effectively address the challenge of current-limited control under generator-side constraints. The efficacy and applicability of the proposed FT control strategy are validated through simulation analysis conducted on a 10.5 MW, 18-phase HVFTPMSG system.

title: Design of Virtual Trainer (VITRI) Based on Virtual Reality Using Immersive Methods to Enhance Hard Skills and Soft Skills of Vocational High School Students in LKS Competitions
authors: Muhamad Syariffuddien Zuhrie, Puput Wanarti Rusimamto, Aries Dwi Indriyanti, Irfan Fakhri Habibi, Sheylania Cheysa Aulia Wijaksono, Subhan Ramadhan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: The Virtual Reality Trainer Kit (VITRI) is developed as an innovative training solution utilizing Virtual Reality (VR) technology to improve human resource skills across various industries. The kit comprises a VR headset with high-resolution displays, motion sensors for precise interaction, and integrated training software designed to simulate realistic training environments. Users can engage in tailored training scenarios, such as product assembly and emergency response simulations, enhancing both hard and soft skills. The system also incorporates performance evaluation tools to monitor user progress and identify improvement areas. This research aims to demonstrate that immersive VR-based training can provide a more effective and engaging learning experience compared to conventional methods, ultimately contributing to the development of better-skilled workforces in modern workplaces.

title: Goal-conditioned Trajectory Generation for Planning with Flow Matching in Offline RL
authors: He Diao, Jingkui Zhang, Ping Zhang, Bei Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Autonomous planning capability is pivotal for the effective operation of most unmanned systems. In some planning tasks, agents are required to learn how to achieve specific goals from a demonstrative dataset, such as navigating to a target location or satisfying certain conditions. Such tasks can be categorized as offline Goal-Conditioned Reinforcement Learning (GCRL), which are characterized by sparse rewards, with feedback signals provided only upon goal achievement. Recently, applying generative models to offline RL has become a mainstream approach, which models the trajectory distribution within datasets and achieves planning through trajectory generation and optimization. In this paper, we propose TFM (Trajectory Flow Matching). It models the trajectory distribution through Flow Matching, which accelerates the sampling process for trajectory generation. Additionally, we employ a hindsight mechanism for goal re-labeling of trajectory data, enriching the reward signals during training to address the sparse rewards problem. We conduct experiments in standard GCRL tasks under both single-task and multi-task settings. Through comparisons with baseline algorithms, our method demonstrates superior performance, along with strong adaptability and transferability across different tasks.

title: Electronic Component Waste Identification and Classification System Based on Deep Learning
authors: Zhang Yuze, Toh Leow Bin, Shakheel Ahmed, Sayan Kumar Ray
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: With the rapid popularization and replacement of electronic devices, electronic waste (e-waste) has become an important challenge in global environmental management. Ewaste contains heavy metals and other hazardous substances, which will have a serious impact on the environment if not handled properly. To solve this problem, this paper proposes an electronic component waste recognition and classification system based on deep learning. The system can automatically detect whether the input image contains electronic component waste, and further identify the specific type of electronic components, such as batteries, circuit boards, etc. The system is designed to handle a variety of input images and support the classification needs of single waste and mixed waste. By building and training a deep learning model, we hope to achieve efficient electronic waste recognition, thereby promoting resource recycling and environmental protection.

title: Synthetic Climate Data Generation Using Generative Adversarial Networks for Drought Modelling in Southern Africa
authors: Jimmy Katambo, Lars Ribbe, Victor Kongo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: This study investigates the application of generative adversarial networks (GANs) for generating synthetic climate data to support drought modelling in datascarce regions of Southern Africa. The primary focus was to reconstruct long-term time series of soil moisture and sunshine duration. These variables are crucial for understanding drought dynamics but are often characterised by incomplete records. Soil moisture and sunshine duration data were obtained from online sources. Subsequently, the GAN model was trained on these real-world datasets containing substantial gaps to learn their temporal structures and generate realistic synthetic values for the missing periods. A key contribution of this work is the application of GANs to reconstruct these critical variables, producing a 50-year hybrid dataset (1972-2022) that combines observed and synthetic data. The GAN discriminator achieved an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve score of 0.889. This indicates strong classification capability and aligns with results reported in comparable studies. To evaluate the practical utility of the synthetic data, the hybrid datasets were employed as inputs for random forest and feedforward neural network models for drought prediction. The results demonstrate that integrating these synthetic variables improved drought prediction model accuracy, with some synthetic variables outperforming traditional ones in feature importance rankings. This underscores the potential of GANs to mitigate observational data limitations in climate applications. The study contributes to developing hybrid modelling strategies and highlights the role of generative models in enhancing predictive capabilities in regions with limited observational data.

title: Development of an AI-Based Speech Recognition System for Chinese Dialects: A Case Study
authors: Liu ZhengJie, Mohsen Marjani, Fatima-Tuz-Zahra, Siva Raja A L Sindiramutty, Danish Javaid
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Recently, speech recognition technology has moved forward, and now it can be applied with the help of advanced deep learning methods such as CNN. Exact match is recorded for well-known languages like Mandarin and English due to their flat phonological structure. However, existing systems fail to respond to Jin dialects, which are complex and more regional; neither has a focused effort been made to generalise Jin data by scholars, researchers, or developers as a result, and the recognition accuracy remains relatively low. The chief aim of this project is to design an AI-based speech recognition technique that is customised for Jinn. To achieve the recognition, a large amount of acquisition and training from various sources can be introduced into the model to pick out the speech sign parts unique to Jinn. This methodology contributes greatly to the roof of a building that will provide accurate and reliable speech recognition for Jinn speakers and improve dialect recognition technology. Alongside this, the system can be a tool not only for educational research but also for practical use in the area of communication technologies, education of children learning their first language, and many others. In this respect, the article is of great value in speech recognition research because it improves the accuracy of the dialect systems and makes dialectal speech recognition more advanced.

title: Multimodal Intelligent Dynamic Network Slicing for V2X: A Review
authors: Werkineh Eshete Yifru, Dharm Singh Jat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The evolution of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 G}$</tex> and beyond <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{B 5 G})$</tex> has enabled a new paradigm in area of vehicular communication: 5G Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X), which promises ultra-reliable, low-latency connectivity critical for V2X applications such as autonomous driving, platooning, and pedestrian safety. To achieve the diverse and dynamic requirements of V2X applications, 5 G introduced the network slicing technique, which is a logical partitioning of a single physical network infrastructure. However, resource management and orchestration in V2X network slicing remain challenging due to the high mobility, real-time demands, and heterogeneous service requirements. This paper presents a systematic review of literature from 2018 to 2025 focused on AI-driven resource management and orchestration in 5G-V2X network slicing. We categorize state-of-the-art(SOTA) by their domain scope such as End to End solutions, RAN only solutions, and core network solutions and by orchestration architectures (centralized, distributed, O-RAN-based). Finally, we identified current gaps and outlined future research directions in the area of 5 G Network slicing.

title: Research on Error Characteristics of Low-Frequency Electromagnetic Voltage Transformers
authors: Xuan Li, Min Dai, Jiang Guo, Hui Li, Yong Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To investigate the influence of frequency on the error characteristics of low-frequency electromagnetic voltage transformers and support the optimal design of transformers for flexible low-frequency power transmission systems, this study first derived calculation formulas for no-load errors and load errors based on the equivalent circuit model of electromagnetic voltage transformers. Subsequently, a lowfrequency voltage transformer calibrator was designed using differential measurement principles. A three-stage progressive voltage ratio traceability system was established by combining low-voltage electromagnetic and high-voltage capacitive standards, forming a complete low-frequency voltage ratio traceability framework. Based on this system, a low-frequency VT error measurement system was developed. Finally, comparative error tests were conducted on 12 kV and 35 kV lowfrequency electromagnetic voltage transformers at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0 H z}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 H z}$</tex> frequencies. Theoretical and experimental results demonstrate that: Frequency variations show minimal impact on no-load errors, with ratio error variation within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.01 \%$</tex> and phase error variation within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 2^{\prime}$</tex>. In contrast, frequency fluctuations significantly affect load errors, causing ratio error variations up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{0. 1 \%}$</tex> and phase error variations up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{2 5}$</tex>. The frequency-dependent variation of load-induced ratio error remains relatively stable, while the frequency effect on loadinduced phase error becomes more pronounced with increasing load. This research reveals the frequency-dependent error characteristics of low-frequency electromagnetic voltage transformers, providing theoretical foundations and optimization directions for improving measurement accuracy in flexible low-frequency power transmission systems.

title: Channel Estimation for Triple-IRS Aided Communication Systems
authors: Yijie Liu, Weidong Mei, Dong Wang, Peilan Wang, Zhi Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: Intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) is deemed as a promising technology to improve the spectral and energy efficiency of wireless communications. Unlike conventional single-and double-IRS reflections, this paper investigates the channel estimation problem in a triple-IRS-reflection aided wireless communication system, which offers greater flexibility to bypass dense obstacles in the environment. However, due to the complex cascaded channel formed by the three IRSs, conventional IRS channel estimation techniques cannot be directly applied. To tackle this difficulty, we propose a new channel estimation method for triple-IRS-reflection channels. Specifically, we first recast the triple-IRS-reflection channel into a more tractable form, which is the inner product of the composite reflection pattern of the three IRSs and their cascaded channel. Based on this form, the cascaded channel can be efficiently estimated by varying the composite reflection patterns and applying the least-square method. To minimize the mean squared error (MSE), we optimize the reflection patterns of the three IRSs and show that their optimal patterns can be independently determined based on three arbitrary unitary matrices. Numerical results show that our proposed channel estimation algorithm can achieve significantly lower MSE than other baseline schemes.

title: Multi-Objective Sizing of Bess for Frequency Regulation
authors: Hennry Villanueva Panocca, Luis A. Oroya, Jéssica Alice A. Silva, Marcos J. Rider
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: The battery energy storage system (BESS) is a key component in the energy transition. It helps manage the variability of renewable energy sources by storing energy for use as needed, thereby facilitating their integration into the grid. However, the high initial cost and the lack of ancillary services markets that promote its installation limit its large-scale implementation. This study proposes a method to determine the optimal sizing of a BESS providing frequency regulation within a distribution system. To achieve this, a multi-objective approach is used to evaluate aspects related to financial issues, BESS degradation, and grid impact, through which candidate sizings (BESS solutions) are classified based on Pareto optimality to identify non-dominated solutions. The methodology determines the optimal size by balancing non-dominated solutions using the Nash equilibrium, providing stakeholders with a final solution. Three cases are examined, each with a different combination of the proposed objective functions. The aim is to take on the role of an independent investor or a grid operator, who base their decisions solely on the information available to them. The results show a preference for BESS with a C-rate of 0.25, and demonstrate that the proposed method effectively supports decision-making for their installation in distribution systems.

title: Non-Destructive Diagnosis of Cracks in SMD Capacitors Using Deep Learning on Impedance Spectra
authors: Minkyu Kang, Namgyeong Kim, Hyunwoo Nam, Tae Yeob Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE CPMT Symposium Japan (ICSJ)
abstract: This study proposes a deep learning framework using impedance spectra to nondestructively classify crack stages in SMD capacitors, achieving up to 94% accuracy and enabling cost-effective, continuous fault monitoring in electronic packaging applications.

title: Towards Requirements Engineering for RAG Systems
authors: Tor Sporsem, Rasmus Ulfsnes
publish: Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Evaluation and Assessment in Software Engineering
abstract: None

authors: Delfina Ramos-Vidal, Alejandro Cortiñas, Miguel R. Luaces, Oscar Pedreira, Ángeles Saavedra Places, Wesley K. G. Assunção
publish: Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Evaluation and Assessment in Software Engineering
