title: Agent-Based Approaches Towards Smart Higher Education: A Preliminary Review
authors: Marzie Sadat Kasaii, Rosaldo J. F. Rossetti, Pedro Campos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Higher education institutions face increasing challenges, necessitating advanced technological solutions. This systematic review analyzed 35 articles to map the application of Multi-Agent Systems (MAS), Agent-Based Modeling (ABM), and simulation in higher education. Findings show these AI techniques are widely used for simulating complex systems, curriculum design, academic planning, and personalized learning, with simulation also supporting virtual environments. Other AI and Machine Learning (ML) techniques, such as Learning Analytics and Reinforcement Learning, are also applied to enhance student performance, engagement, and self-regulation. Critical gaps identified include the limited adoption of emerging technologies like Generative AI and Large Language Models (LLMs), reliance on small and homogeneous samples, and a general lack of complex implementations. This review highlights these gaps, offering recommendations to guide researchers, educators, and policymakers in advancing AI integration towards smart higher education strategies.

title: From Blind Exploration to Structured Search: A LLM-Enhanced MARL Framework via Subgoal Planning Forest
authors: Jiabao Zhang, Haoyu Wang, Kai Lv, Youfang Lin, Sheng Han
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: In multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL), the size of the state-action space grows exponentially with the number of agents, making traditional-greedy exploration often blind and inefficient. This low exploration efficiency hinders the system’s ability to identify optimal strategies in complex scenarios with sparse rewards, resulting in suboptimal policies. To address this issue, we propose a subgoal-based exploration method enhanced by large language models (LLMs). This method decomposes multi-agent tasks into multi-stage sub-tasks, providing explicit guidance for policy learning. Specifically, we leverage the reasoning and planning capabilities of LLMs to identify ordered subgoals in collaborative tasks, and generate both subgoal discriminators and subgoal-specific reward functions. Furthermore, we design a Subgoal Planning Forest (SPF) to store sequential subgoal interactions. Building upon this, we develop a dual-dimensional exploration decay mechanism (horizontal and vertical) that dynamically balances exploration and exploitation based on depth and temporal factors. Experimental results in SMAC demonstrate that, compared to baselines, our approach achieves faster convergence and higher task success rates in scenarios with sparse rewards and high-dimensional state spaces.

title: Research Progress on Rogowski Coil Errors in the Context of New-Type Power Systems
authors: Chengcheng Zhang, Zhongran Yao, Jingke He, Zhenhua Li, Zhenxing Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This review examines Rogowski coil error mechanisms critical for renewable-integrated power systems. Analysis of three primary error sources-thermal deformation, electromagnetic interference, and eccentricity-reveals limitations in existing models: oversimplified material-thermal interactions, inadequate EMI characterization under highharmonic penetration, and insufficient experimental validation. A thermal-eccentricity coupling model quantifies nonlinear error propagation, identifying critical zones (60 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150^{\circ} \mathrm{C},>35 ~\text{mm}$</tex> eccentricity) where errors surge to 9.7 % due to gradient transitions. Key research gaps persist in: Multi-scale EMI quantification during grid transients, Coupled-model experimental verification, and Standardized dynamic compensation. Future work requires intelligent architectures integrating material advances, structural optimization (winding uniformity control, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${k}<20$</tex>), and adaptive algorithms to achieve Class 0.2 accuracy.

title: Research on the Transmission Capacity of the Renewable Power Sources VSC-HVDC Islanded Delivery System under Steady-State Voltage Constraints
authors: Yujiao Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This article mainly studies a calculation method for the maximum transmission distance of the collection line of VSC-HVDC islanded transmission system based on steady-state power flow continuous calculation, and empirically verifies the method based on two typical collection systems of renewable energy. The proposed calculation method can obtain the voltage curve family of renewable energy under different power output through continuous power flow calculation. The influence of the reactive power compensation in the system can be considered in the calculation. Through calculation, the safety boundary of the maximum transmission distance of the renewable energy collection line can be quickly obtained, providing a fast calculation method for the steady-state voltage analysis of the renewable energy VSC-HVDC islanded transmission system. An analysis was conducted on typical photovoltaic radiation collection system and chain collection system, and the results showed that the electric distance boundary of the collection line in the radiation collection system can reach over 400km, the maximum boundary of a single section of the line in the chain collection system can reach 100km, and the total length of the collection line in the chain collection system can reach 500km.

title: Optimal Transmission Model Development for Japanese Electricity System under Carbon Neutrality Scenario
authors: Qizhou Yang, Shigeru Bando, Bo Jie, Jumpei Baba
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Integrating renewable energy is vital for achieving carbon neutrality, yet Japan faces challenges due to its uneven resource distribution. To address the need to transmit electricity from wind-rich regions to high-demand areas, the model proposed in this study incorporates both tie line capacity enhancement and the addition of four planned wind farms equipped with battery storage, along with four new high-voltage direct current (HVDC) transmission lines. The Japanese power system is modeled as nine regions connected by ten inter-regional lines (4 AC and 6 DC), with various energy storage options in each region. The model simulates optimal system operation over 8,784 hours with the goal of minimizing total cost under a carbon neutrality scenario. Results show that reinforcing tie lines and integrating offshore wind are critical. In high-demand areas such as Tokyo, PV and battery storage dominate, while wind-rich regions like Tohoku and Kyushu serve as major exporters of renewable energy. Thermal power and CO₂ emissions remain major cost contributors, highlighting the need for further renewable deployment and grid upgrades.

title: Effect of Impulse Corona on Lightning Withstand Level and Overvoltage Under Multiple Lightning Strikes
authors: Tongshu Ding, Jiachen Gao, Zhikang Shuai, Jianwen Nie, Tingxiu Jiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Multiple lightning strikes pose a significant threat to transmission line, but the effects of impulse corona during such events remain unexplored. This paper has investigated the impact of impulse corona on the lightning withstand level and lightning-induced overvoltages in transmission lines under multiple lightning strikes using ATP-EMTP simulations. Results demonstrated that corona effects significantly influence both lightning withstand levels of transmission line and overvoltages at substation entrance. For lightning withstand level, the corona model increased protection levels by 11.7% to 20.0%, with the most pronounced effect observed for the third strike. Regarding the overvoltages at substation entrance, the impulse corona has effectively reduced the peak value and led to a later peak time. These findings conclusively show that the influence of corona under multiple lightning strikes cannot be neglected in lightning protection studies, and have provided theoretical support for more accurate lightning protection design by quantifying the beneficial effects of corona under multiple lightning strikes, potentially leading to more economical insulation coordination strategies while maintaining adequate protection levels for power system equipment.

title: Distributed Game-Based Control for Open Multi-USV Systems under Directed Networks
authors: Jianxiang Ren, Huixiong Wang, Tingwen Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper investigates the time-varying formation control problem of an open unmanned surface vessel (USV) system. During the formation process, the number of USVs may vary due to the joining and leaving of USVs at specific system switching instants. To address the task requirements of USVs, a non-cooperative game model is constructed to balance the conflicting sub-tasks, transforming the formation control problem into a Nash equilibrium seeking problem of a non-cooperative game. By designing piecewise distributed control laws that adapt to system switching for the USVs, the states of the USVs are driven to asymptotically converge to the Nash equilibrium of the non-cooperative game, thereby achieving the control objective. It is theoretically proven that when the average switching interval is greater than an appropriate threshold and the USV control parameters are properly designed, the states of the USVs can achieve convergence. Finally, numerical simulations are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the designed control laws.

title: AI-Powered Environmental Monitoring for Urban Industrial Disaster Prevention: Transferring Deep Learning Contamination Detection to Urban Resilience Frameworks
authors: Zainab Ashkanani, Rabi Mohtar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Three decades after the Gulf War created one of history's worst petroleum disasters, Kuwait's Burgan Field remains severely contaminated, offering unique insights for industrial monitoring worldwide. We developed an AI framework combining Sentinel-2A satellite imagery with machine learning to detect petroleum contamination across <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$195 \text{km}^{2}$</tex> of desert landscape. Our approach analyzed over 200 multispectral images against 180 field samples containing up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$129,726 \text{mg} / \text{kg}$</tex> Total Petroleum Hydrocarbons. The system identified 18-20 contamination sources maintaining maximum sensor values after thirty years, revealing how arid climates preserve industrial disasters indefinitely. We mapped 463 contamination hotspots and eight migration corridors threatening millions, with extraordinary spatial clustering (Moran's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I=0.9636$</tex>) showing contamination coalescence into mega-structures. Most critically, the framework provides 15-30 days advance warning of contamination spread, enabling preventive action. By targeting intervention zones representing just 4.9 % of contaminated areas, remediation costs could drop significantly. This matters because developing nations facing rapid industrialization cannot afford traditional monitoring. The framework demonstrates direct transferability to urban industrial contexts where petroleum facilities, refineries, and storage tanks pose similar contamination threats to dense populations. Our methods work with free satellite data and opensource algorithms, democratizing environmental surveillance. This transferability provides municipalities worldwide with operational capabilities for proactive contamination management.

title: Passive Hybrid Common-Mode Emi Filter for Dcac Converters with Reduced Common-Mode Inductance
authors: Zhuo Qing, Peng Guo, Qianming Xu, An Luo
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The higher switching frequencies of widebandgap (WBG) semiconductors enable higher power density but intensify common-mode (CM) electromagnetic interference (EMI). Passive EMI filters (PEFs) are widely recognized for their effectiveness in suppressing CM noise; however, traditional designs face challenges such as excessive volume, limited broadband attenuation, and the necessity for overdesigning parameters. In this paper, a passive hybrid CM filter design approach is proposed to address these issues by utilizing insertion loss resonance characteristics. The passive hybrid filter is developed by integrating a balance technique with a PEF. Firstly, its CM equivalent circuit is established, and the insertion loss expression is derived. The key parameters influencing resonance are identified through sensitivity analysis. The impacts of the balance technique and PEF parameters on resonance are examined. Then, the resonant frequency can be shifted by appropriate configuration of these parameters, allowing for the insertion loss to be tailored across the desired attenuation band. Finally, the effectiveness is validated through simulations.

title: Band Selection for Hyperspectral Image Classification using DBSCAN-Informed Spectral Attention Network
authors: Abhiroop Chatterjee, Susmita Ghosh, Ashish Ghosh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) classification presents substantial challenges due to the high spectral dimensionality and significant inter-band correlation, which often lead to increased computational costs and reduced generalization capability. To ad-dress these issues, we propose a novel framework that integrates unsupervised spectral band pruning with a trainable attention mechanism for selecting bands for efficient HSI classification. Initially, spectral bands are clustered using DBSCAN algorithm, which identifies groups of correlated bands as well as isolated, un-correlated outliers. Initial importance score assigned to each band is inversely proportional to the cardinality of the corresponding cluster, with outlier bands receiving the highest scores. Based on the cluster representative, the top-n bands from each cluster will be selected while the remaining ones of the same cluster will be pruned for further processing. However, the outliers will always be included into the list of selected bands. To further enhance the discriminability of the unpruned bands, we introduce a Trainable Band Attention (TBA) mechanism that updates attention weights of the bands in an end-to-end fashion, initialized using the DBSCAN-derived scores. The images with these prior-informed attention-guided reweighted spectral bands are fed into the ResNet-18 for feature extraction and classification. Experimental comparison with ten other CNN/ Transformer-based state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods for benchmark HSI datasets demonstrates the efficacy of the proposed method. Our CNN-based method achieves the highest overall accuracy (OA) of 98.82% on Indian Pines, a competitive OA of 97.07% on Salinas, and a strong OA of 98.46% on Botswana, while reducing the number of spectral bands with improved performance in terms of classification accuracy and training time.

title: Utilizing Data Science to Address Gender Disparities in Health in Africa: A Review
authors: Simisani Ndaba, Alton Mabina, Christophe Mumaragishyika
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: The need for critical attention to study methodology in studying gender inequities in health is reinforced in this review. Applying the PRISMA checklist to studies published between 2017 and 2024, 27 studies were selected to evaluate models for their performance in terms of accuracy, efficiency and computational cost. Bayesian and Small Area Estimation (SAE) techniques provided the best estimates, up to 92 %, but they are also the most computationally intensive methods. Logistic regression was selected as a compromise between efficiency and validity, particularly in the prediction of healthcare payment inequities. While providing a more encompassing picture of the available studies, this process was limited by the issue of bias and heterogeneity of the data used. Results show the growing use of Bayesian and spatial modeling and highlight the importance of the intersectional approach. Nevertheless, there are still some research gaps as the few studies in rural healthcare are using AI driven predictive models and are not validated in real- world studies. There is a need for a multi-pronged approach combining A.I., spatial modeling, and policy strategies for increasing gender equity in healthcare and supporting evidence-based policy-making in Africa more broadly.

title: Use of Single-phase Transformers in Distribution Power lines in Bulgaria: Economic and Reliability Analyses.
authors: Velichko Atanasov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This article examines a current problem related to the quality of electricity supplied by distribution companies. A method for changing the model of medium voltage power lines in Bulgaria that has been imposed over the years is presented. A technical and economic analysis of the advantages and possible problems in connecting single-phase distribution transformers to existing power lines is performed. Examples of the behavior of a power line with connected single-phase transformers during short circuits and in emergency situations are examined in order to assess the impact on the reliability and stability of the network.

title: Data-Driven Health Management Model Construction: A Review of Methods for Small-Sample and Imbalanced Scenarios
authors: Mengxuan Zhai, Fuhong Kuang, Peng Hou, Xiaojian Yi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: With the growing use of unmanned systems in military, transportation, and environmental fields, ensuring their reliability and continuous operation is crucial. Traditional health management methods, relying on physical models and expert knowledge, struggle to handle complex and changing conditio ns. Recently, data-driven approaches have gained attention for their adaptability and flexibility. This paper reviews data augmentation, transfer learning, and resampling techniques applied to health management models, focusing on challenges like small samples and class imbalance. The work offers theoretical support for building data-driven health management models.

title: Innovative Applications Based on Supercapacitor Products in Construction Site
authors: Jimin Zeng, Renge Li, Entao Qin, Xiangcong Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: For the increasing demand with sustainable energy and intelligent management in the building industry, supercapacitors become a potential solution for building energy storage and energy recovery systems due to their high power density, fast charging and discharging, and long cycle life. In this paper, the technical principle, product design and optimisation methods of building supercapacitors are systematically analysed, and a design scheme of supercapacitor devices suitable for architectural scenarios is proposed, combined with the application scenarios of engineering lift energy recovery in architectural scenarios. Through the actual case, the charging and discharging rate of the module (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>10 \mathrm{C}$</tex>) and the dynamic response requirements of the system (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<500 \text{ms}$</tex>) are matched to reduce the volume cost of the energy storage system by 35%, the system energy saving rate to 50.5%, and the average daily energy saving to 66.5 kWh while ensuring the safety redundancy, which provides an empirical reference for the optimal design of the energy storage system in the construction industry.

title: Design of Quick-Open/Quick-Close Arc Extinguishing Switches Common to 10kV and 35kV Cable Line Power Supply Operation
authors: Zhenning Chen, Shaolei Wu, Meitang Xie, Bowen Liu, Yuxi Zhang, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the rapid development of China's electric power industry and the continuous improvement of the non-stop operation technology of the distribution network, the power distribution system has put forward higher requirements for the safety, reliability, and operation efficiency of the equipment for power-carrying operation. Unloaded cable lines with high-frequency Disconnection, due to the presence of capacitive current, easily cause contact re-ignition and arcing phenomenon, posing a threat to operational safety. Currently, the arc extinguishing switch used in 10 kV lines has largely matured, but it still primarily relies on manual operation of the arc extinguishing rope in 35 kV line operations, which has weak arc extinguishing capability, poor versatility, high operating intensity, and other issues. For this reason, this paper designs an insulated pole-type electric arc extinguishing switch suitable for 10 kV and 35 kV distribution lines. The device employs a main contact and arc contact time-sharing structure, combined with a mechanical energy storage mechanism, that enables fast splitting and closing, significantly improving the reliability of arc extinguishing and operation efficiency. The contact opening distance and electrical performance parameters are optimized based on the 35 kV withstand voltage standard. The mass of the physical prototype is only 2.49 kg, which is 25.6% lighter than that of traditional devices, and it has good ergonomics and field adaptability. Structural validation tests demonstrate that the switch can effectively control the process of arc generation and propagation, making it feasible to popularize its application in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \sim 35 \text{kV}$</tex> distribution networks. The research results provide technical support for the automation and lightweight development of high-voltage distribution equipment.

title: Integrated Design of a Wall-Climbing Hexapod with Negative-Pressure Adsorption and Cable-Driven Manipulator for Power Equipment Maintenance
authors: Yufeng Zhang, Di Hu, Jinfeng Zhang, Zhongxiang Liu, Xingfu Jin, Zhong Chen, Wei Yang, Guofei Xiang, Xingxing You, Songyi Dian
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This study addresses the limitation of existing mobile cable-driven flexible manipulators in lacking wall-climbing capability, hindering their application in the intelligent operation and maintenance (O&M) of critical power equipment. To overcome this, a novel integrated system combining a negative-pressure adsorption-based hexapod mobile platform and a cable-driven flexible manipulator is proposed. The system incorporates six structurally independent and functionally dedicated legs, symmetrically distributed about the longitudinal axis. Each leg integrates dedicated actuation and adsorption units, ensuring reliable adhesion to typical non-ferromagnetic vertical surfaces encountered in power facilities. This design enables the system to achieve omnidirectional mobility on vertical surfaces while the cable-driven flexible manipulator concurrently performs diverse O&M tasks. Finally, a multi-physics-based virtual simulation platform is developed to validate the structural and functional feasibility of the proposed design.

title: Integration of a Sink Node and Django Platform for Solar-Powered Battery-Free Wsns: Enabling Ip Connectivity and Cloud Data Management
authors: Bernardo Yaser León Ávila, Carlos Alberto García Vázquez, Osmel Pérez Baluja, Luis Alberto Quintero Domínguez, Daniel Tudor Cotfas, Petru Adrian Cotfas
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive solution for integrating solar-powered battery-free Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) devices into IP-based infrastructures, focusing on the design and implementation of a dedicated sink node and a cloudbased web platform. The WSN motes, powered by solar energy stored in supercapacitors (SCs), achieve up to 23 hours of operation without sunlight using nRF24L01 radios. The sink node acts as a critical router/proxy/data logger, bridging the low-power WSN protocol to standard WiFi/Ethernet and IP networks. It facilitates HTTP/HTTPS communication with a custom Django web platform for real-time data visualization, storage, and analysis. Architecture addresses key challenges in energy-neutral deployments, including protocol translation, secure data transmission, and scalable cloud integration. Experimental results validate the system's reliability in maintaining seamless connectivity between resource-constrained motes and cloud services, enabling long-term environmental monitoring with zero battery dependency.

title: An Energy Management Strategy for Islanded DC Microgrids: A Case Study on Efficient Energy Exchange Among Residential Houses
authors: Muhammad Salman, Luigi Martirano, Maria Carmen Falvo, Chiara Boccaletti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: This paper proposes an effective energy management strategy for residential microgrid systems, specifically integrating battery energy storage systems and photovoltaic (PV) arrays. Given the increasing adoption of solar PV systems in both residential and industrial sectors, often operating in off-grid or hybrid configurations, efficient energy management is crucial. The presented strategy optimizes energy exchange among interconnected households by continuously monitoring battery state-of-charge (SOC), prioritizing critical loads, and intelligently utilizing surplus PV energy for secondary applications. This approach introduces three distinct operational modes, dynamically adapting to varying power generation and load demands. The proposed methodology ensures efficient energy distribution, prolongs battery lifespan, and significantly reduces reliance on conventional backup generators. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the developed strategy in maintaining system stability while concurrently minimizing operational costs.

title: Load Dispatch Applying Koopman MPC for Non-Convex Optimization in Interconnected Power Systems
authors: Tongming Liu, Tian Liu, Xiaofei Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To address the non-convex Economic Load Dispatch (ELD) optimization problem in power systems, this paper proposes a hybrid approach integrating a Model Predictive Control (MPC) with data-driven Koopman method. The nonlinear dynamics of interconnected power systems are modeled using the Koopman operator to derive a linear representation in a high-dimensional space, converting non-convex objectives into convex forms. Robust MPC is then applied within this space to mitigate model approximation errors and solve the convex optimization. Results demonstrate that the approach achieves the global optimum, validating its effectiveness for addressing non-convex economic dispatch issues.

title: Face Anti-Spoofing Through Perspective Distortion of Facial Landmarks
authors: Juan C. Martinez, Manuel Henao, Santiago Perez, Carolina Jimenez, Juan D. Vergara, Jose Gomez, Christian Arcos
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: A critical challenge in facial authentication systems is balancing robust security against presentation attacks with minimal user friction. Detection methods based on the evolution of facial geometry features captured at different times may address this challenge without the need to direct users to perform complex actions. However, they use limited representations of facial characteristics and show insufficient robustness against sophisticated 3D attacks. This paper introduces a low friction face anti-spoofing method exploiting perspective distortion, requiring only two images captured at varying distances from the camera. This method relies on three key contributions: a distortion encoding strategy based on a high-density facial landmark grid, a hybrid feature extraction method combining color and geometry information, and three-dimensional facial modeling strategies to perform domain randomization. Our method performs competitively when compared to recently published methods in our comprehensive dataset and successfully satisfies levels 1 and 2 of the iBeta evaluation protocol accredited by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST).

title: Stealthy False Data Injection Attacks in Smart Grids with Different Anomaly Detectors
authors: Yongyu Li, Yang Yu, Chensheng Liu, Jian Long, Chengnian Long, Jing Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: With the advancement of power systems, the vulnerability of state estimation has gradually become apparent. Although many studies have explored false data injection attacks (FDIAs) against power system state estimation and achieved promising results, most existing methods primarily target either traditional bad data detectors (BDDs) or neural network-based anomaly detectors (NADs). When both detectors coexist, the attack success rate of existing attacks typically declines significantly. To address the aforementioned challenge, a novel method based on diffusion models is proposed, leveraging the uncertainty caused by renewable energy sources (RESs) fluctuations. This method integrates attack area selection, region-aware diffusionbased generation, and targeted deployment to enhance both stealth and effectiveness. Extensive experiments on IEEE 14bus, 57 -bus, and 118 -bus standard test systems demonstrate that the proposed method can simultaneously bypass both BDD and NAD, maintaining a high attack success rate even under dualdetector scenarios. These results highlight the potential threat posed by advanced FDIAs in modern grid environments and underscore the urgent need for more robust and comprehensive defense mechanisms.

title: Investigating the Fine-Tuning of Large Language Models for Indonesian Sentiment Analysis
authors: Ahmad Yusuf Indrarahmana, Pongsathon Janyoi, Pusadee Seresangtakul, Sarawoot Kongyoung
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Sentiment analysis of user reviews is vital for product evaluation, yet the behavior of large language models (LLMs) in lower-resource languages such as Indonesian remains under-explored. We compare three LLM families (Gemma, Llama, Qwen) against classic RNN baselines (Bi-LSTM, Bi-GRU) on a three-class Indonesian app-review dataset (InfoBMKG, 8,000 reviews) under two settings: zero-shot and LoRA fine-tuning. In the zero-shot setting, a domain-trained Bi-LSTM outperforms all LLMs (macro-F1 0.84), indicating that general pre-training alone is insufficient for this domain. After LoRA fine-tuning, all LLMs improve substantially; Gemma3-4B-it attains an Accuracy of 0.92 and a macro-F1 score of 0.89. Paired, stratified bootstrap testing (B is 10,000; two-sided) with Holm–Bonferroni correction shows that only Gemma3-4B-it achieves a statistically significant macro-F1 gain over Bi-LSTM, while other LLMs exhibit positive but non-significant trends. Despite these gains, Bi-LSTM remains more than 70 times faster under a unified inference protocol, underscoring a practical accuracy-latency trade-off. Overall, LLMs are not uniformly superior to classic deep learning models in this setting; parameter-efficient fine-tuning is key to unlocking LLM performance for Indonesian sentiment analysis. However, deployment choices should balance accuracy targets with latency budgets.

title: Voltage Control Strategy to Improve the Power Transmission Capacity of Wind Storage Power Station in Weak Grid
authors: Jingyuan Yang, Zhen Xie, Lele Cai
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Equipped with energy storage has become the trend in the development of wind power, at the same time, with more new energy sources being integrated into the power grid, the short-circuit ratio (SCR) of the grid-connected point of the wind storage power station is decreasing, which has an impact on the power exchange between the wind storage power station and the power grid. In order to study the influence of the wind storage power station connected to the weak grid on the active power transmission capacity of the wind storage power system, a line impedance model was established based on the doubly-fed induction generator (DFIG) and battery energy storage systems(BESS), and the influence of different short-circuit ratios on the voltage and power of the wind storage system was analyzed and studied. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed strategy is verified through simulation.

title: Rate-Distortion Driven Overfitting of Quality Enhancement Neural Networks for Video Coding
authors: Yuriy Kim, Evgeny Belyaev
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: In this paper, we study the problem of efficient application of quality-enhancement neural networks for hybrid video coding. First, we introduce a video compression scheme in which the enhancement network is fine-tuned (or overfitted) using the reconstructed frames available on the encoder side. Then, the updated weights of the network are compressed using the initial weights as side information and transmitted to the decoder, which uses them for quality enhancement of the decoded frames. Second, we propose to use the number of overfitting epochs and the configuration of frozen (non-overfitted) weights as parameters which should be tuned in order to find the trade-off between distortion reduction and the number of bits needed for the updated weights transmission. We compare the Lagrange sum minimization and BD-Rate minimization for parameter selection via full search and show that the BD-Rate minimization provides better rate-distortion performance. Finally, since the full search is computationally complex, we propose a model which is trained to select the parameters that minimize BD-Rate in one pass and show that when the MFQE 2.0 enhancement network is used, the bit rate savings from $\mathbf{4 . 8 \%}$ to $\mathbf{1 4 . 0 \%}$ for H.265/HEVC standard are achieved.

title: Impact of EV Charging on Voltage Margin in High PV Penetration Tourist Regions
authors: Jun-Hyuk Nam, Dong-Il Cho, Yun-Jin Cho, Seong-Jun Park, Byung-Ki Kim, Won-Sik Moon
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: The rapid expansion of photovoltaic (PV) systems can cause overvoltage in distribution systems during the daytime. This study investigates the impact of EV charging on voltage margin in distribution networks with high PV penetration, particularly in tourist regions. Using Jeju Island, South Korea, as a case study, voltage variations are evaluated based on different EV charging scenarios using the Voltage Margin Evaluation Index (VMEI). The results indicate that high daytime fast-charging demand in tourist areas naturally coincides with peak PV generation, increasing local power consumption and improving the voltage margin by mitigating overvoltage. The most significant voltage margin improvements are observed in feeders with higher PV penetration. These findings suggest that EV charging can serve as a passive voltage regulation mechanism in high-PV penetration tourist regions. The proposed methodology can be applied to other areas with similar characteristics, providing insights into optimizing EV charging strategies for grid stability.

title: Energy-Aware Resource Allocation for Multi-Operator Cell-Free Massive MIMO in V-CRAN Architectures
authors: Derya Nurcan-Atceken, Özlem Tuğfe Demir, Aysegul Altin-Kayhan, Emil Björnson, Cicek Cavdar, Bulent Tavli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: Cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) implemented in virtualized cloud radio access networks (V-CRAN) has emerged as a promising architecture to enhance spectral efficiency (SE), network flexibility, and energy efficiency (EE) in next-generation wireless systems. In this work, we develop a holistic optimization framework for the efficient deployment of cell-free massive MIMO in V-CRAN with multiple mobile network operators (MNOs). Specifically, we formulate a set of integer programming models to jointly optimize access point (AP) selection, user equipment (UE) association, cloud resource allocation, and MNO assignment while minimizing the maximum total power consumption (TPC) across MNOs. We consider two different scenarios based on whether UEs can be assigned to arbitrary MNOs or not. The numerical results demonstrate the impact of different deployment assumptions on power consumption, highlighting that flexible UE-MNO assignment significantly reduces TPC. The findings provide key insights into optimizing resource management in cell-free massive MIMO V-CRAN, paving the way for energy-efficient wireless network implementations.

title: Deep Learning for Pulsed Electric Field Treatments in Cardiology and Oncology
authors: R. Crusi, G. Monti, L. Tarricone, M. S. Zappatore, C. Merla, N. Colistra, F. Camera, M. Tanori, A. Casciati
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: Electroporation is an electromagnetic method based on pulsed electric fields, with very promising biomedical applications. The effectiveness of electroporation protocols is highly dependent on the selection of optimum initial setup parameters, such as waveforms and electrode characteristics, and this process is complex and time-consuming. To streamline these procedures, a novel deep learning framework was developed and trained on data collected both from the literature and from experimental setups, thus enabling accurate predictions of key target parameters and reducing the need for extensive preliminary testing. This approach is applied to cardiac pulsed field ablation, used in the treatment of various cardiac arrhythmias, as well as to high-frequency irreversible electroporation for cancer ablation. Furthermore, it is used here for the first time to optimize the application of microsecond electric pulses in combination with ionizing radiations to target cancer stem cells, with the goal of reducing radiation doses in cancer care. The achieved accuracy is promising and represents a significant step toward personalized therapies and the development of next-generation medical devices.

title: Infrared Analysis of Sulfur Hexafluoride Gamma Irradiation Degradation Products
authors: Chen Ying, Ma Feng Xiang, Zhao Yue, Xu Zheng Jie, Xu Xiao Xiao, Cheng Wei
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Sulfur hexafluoride (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex>) is a widely used arc extinguishing and insulating medium in the field of electric power, which is very stable and difficult to degrade naturally. It is a greenhouse gas that needs to be strictly reduced emissions. Many methods are used to degrade <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex>, such as pyrolysis, plasma treatment, electron beam degradation, etc. In this paper, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex> was irradiated by a cobalt- 60 gamma ray source, and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex> was irradiated in an infrared spectroscopic gas cell. The infrared spectrum of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex> after absorbing different irradiation doses was monitored, and the vibration mode of each peak of the infrared spectrum was attributed according to the literature work. In the experimental time range, the intensity of the characteristic infrared absorption peak of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex> decreased linearly with the increase of absorption dose, indicating that <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex> was nearly linearly degraded in the experimental range. Infrared spectroscopy analysis showed that the infrared absorption signals with significantly enhanced intensity after <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex> irradiation mainly came from oxide-containing substances, such as sulfuryl fluoride <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{SO}_{2} ~\mathrm{F}_{2}\right)$</tex>, sulfoxide fluoride <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{SOF}_{2}\right)$</tex> and sulfur dioxide. After the irradiation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}, \text{SF}_{4}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F}_{2}$</tex> are mainly generated, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F}_{2}$</tex> is non-infrared active. SF4 reacts rapidly with adsorbed water on the solid surface to finally form <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SO}_{2} ~\mathrm{F}_{2}$</tex> and HF, so the absorption peak of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SO}_{2} ~\mathrm{F}_{2}$</tex> increases with the increase of absorption dose. It was found by attenuated total reflection infrared spectroscopy that thionyl fluoride and sulfur dioxide were infiltrated into the potassium bromide salt window, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SOF}_{2}$</tex> reacted with water to form trace amounts of SO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. Thionyl fluoride could penetrate into the KBr window of the gas pool and accumulate with multiple irradiation reactions, resulting in the cumulative background absorption of potassium bromide salt sheets, which was not reported in the literature. Gamma rays have strong penetration, which is suitable for irradiation reaction in metal autoclave, which is conducive to the centralized treatment of decommissioned <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex>. If a large batch reaction is used in a corrosion-resistant metal kettle, the oxidation reaction of the product in this paper will be avoided. In addition, the work in this paper finds that the gamma irradiation products of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex> are relatively simple, which is particularly conducive to the subsequent resource utilization of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SF}_{6}$</tex>.

title: A Multi-Criteria Optimization for Parallel System Restoration Planning in Power Grids with PV-BESS
authors: Hasini De Silva, Adland Pradana, Mithulananthan Nadarajah
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Power system restoration requires careful planning to restart generators, energize transmission lines and critical loads. Some system operators use parallel restoration by considering pre-planned islands of the network. However, research on planning these islands for modern grids with photovoltaic-battery energy storage systems (PV-BESS) is limited. This research aims to develop a novel algorithm for optimal island formation in modern grids, with PV-BESS as black start units. The characteristics of PV-BESS such as PV availability, time of the day and BESS discharge curve are proposed in formulating its role as a black start unit. To energize the non-black start units and critical loads from the black start unit, the depth-first search algorithm is proposed. It identifies all possible cranking paths. Power and energy reserves in each path are analyzed to formulate a fitness function for determining optimal islands. Transmission lines not connected to the optimal islands are identified as cutsets and excluded from the restoration plan. The algorithm developed is tested on the IEEE 9 bus test system. Simulation results verify the requirement of having two restoration plans for the daytime and nighttime when using parallel system restoration.

title: Distribution Losses Projection based on Asset and Target Sales Energy
authors: Pradita Octoviandiningrum Hadi, Nanang Hariyanto
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: The distribution system plays a vital role in delivering electrical energy from transmission networks to end users and comprises medium voltage networks, transformers, and low voltage networks. However, technical energy losses are inevitable and tend to increase disproportionately with demand. This paper introduces a novel approach to estimating distribution losses by integrating asset expansion planning—such as MV/LV network lengths, feeder counts, and transformer capacities—with targeted energy sales. The proposed method supports utilities in enhancing distribution efficiency through informed infrastructure planning.

title: Performance Variations of Transistor Amplifier Circuits Due to Lightning Transient
authors: Ganga Lokuhettige, Sankha Nanayakkara, Mahendra Fernando, Vernon Cooray
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: In the modern world, using sophisticated electronic and electrical items in industries and daily life is prevalent. With the increasing use of electronic items, damage to them by lightning and other switching impulses is severe worldwide. Circuitry-level studies with lightning transients are very limited. Therefore, this research reveals the performance variation of bipolar junction transistors (BJTs) and metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs) amplifiers when subjected to a 1.2/50 μs lightning voltage transient. The collector resistor was susceptible to damage from destructive level impulses in the BJT amplifier. MOSFET failure is visible with the impulse injection into the MOSFET amplifier circuit. Further, repetitive pulses with the peak voltage close to the destructive level could also damage the circuit or degrade the amplifier performance.

title: ThaiScamBench: Toward a Benchmark Dataset for Scam and Phishing Detection in the Thai Language
authors: Nutthakorn Chalaemwongwan
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Recent reports from Thai financial regulators reveal a sharp increase in online scams, resulting in major financial damage each year. While English-language research has made considerable progress, Thai-language scam detection remains underexplored and lacks standardized benchmarks. The study establishes *ThaiScamBench (pilot)*, a curated corpus of 1,750 Thai messages labeled as scam or legitimate across seven categories. Reproducible baselines (Logistic Regression, Linear SVM) and a rigorous evaluation protocol are provided to address class imbalance, Thai–English code-switching, and adversarial obfuscation. All scam texts contained URLs; none appeared in legitimate messages, revealing dataset bias, with all scam samples containing a URL and none among legitimate texts, artificially inflating headline metrics. We addressed this issue by introducing URL-masked and domain hold-out evaluations. We outline our roadmap toward version 1.0 (around 50k messages), focusing on dataset scaling and robust benchmarking for Thai scam detection, adversarial stress tests, and PDPA-compliant release artifacts. *ThaiScamBench* establishes the first standardized evaluation for Thai scam detection, enabling transparent comparison and artifact-conscious evaluation. This benchmark provides a reproducible foundation for robust Thai-language scam detection.

title: Research on the Design and Control Method of Controllable Demagnetization Module of Magnet Power Supply Based on Synchronous Rectification
authors: Hao Yin, Liuwei Xu, Jun Li, Yanan Wu, Baocan He, Zhiwei Mao, Huafeng Mao, Liang Tan, Anyong Cai, Yueping Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The magnetic confinement fusion device relies on the power supply to generate a strong magnetic field to constrain and maintain hundreds of millions of degrees of plasma. The fusion magnet power supply is the core actuator to achieve controllability. At present, the fusion magnet power supply in the form of low voltage and high current mostly adopts the thyristor rectifier scheme. Under the condition of long-term steady-state operation of large current, the magnet power supply in the form of thyristor rectifier will bring large reactive power and energy loss, and the large volume of rectifier transformer leads to low power density and poor flexibility of magnet power supply. In order to effectively improve the power density and working efficiency of the magnet power supply, the high-frequency synchronous rectification scheme using full-controlled devices has been applied to the magnet power supply. Based on the problem that the synchronous rectification scheme cannot output negative pressure to meet the demagnetization demand of the magnet, a control module composed of MOSFET and resistor is designed at the output end of the power supply, and the controllable demagnetization of the superconducting magnet is realized by cooperating with the magnet converter. Finally, the simulation model is built by PSIM and the prototype and control module are developed for testing, which verifies the feasibility and effectiveness of the magnet power supply scheme and the control module.

title: Embedded ECG Analytics for Remote Health Monitoring
authors: Vlad Veliciu, Septimiu Pop, Rajmond Jano, Liviu Viman
publish: 2025 IEEE 31st International Symposium for Design and Technology in Electronic Packaging (SIITME)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases remain the leading global cause of death, motivating continuous monitoring solutions beyond hospital settings. This work presents a resource-efficient electrocardiogram (ECG) and temperature monitoring system integrating calibration, validation, prediction, and remote visualization. An AD8232 module and LMT85 sensor interface with an Arduino Uno for calibrated acquisition and feature extraction, while a Raspberry Pi 4 provides baseline validation using NeuroKit2. Bland-Altman analysis quantifies bias and enables regression-based correction, improving agreement across parameters. Prediction is performed with an incremental logistic regression model (River), warm-started offline and adapted online using signal-quality-based weighting. Data and predictions are uploaded to ThingSpeak and visualized in MATLAB App Designer. Real-world tests demonstrate accurate beats-per-minute (BPM)/QRS estimation, robust online adaptation, and accessible cloud-based monitoring.

title: Unsupervised Learning Methods Applied to Honeypot Data for Detecting Cyberattacks
authors: Ni Putu Suci Meinarni, I Putu Agus Eka Darma Udayana, Aniek Suryanti Kusuma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: The increasing sophistication and volume of cyberattacks demand detection strategies that go beyond traditional signature-based systems. Honeypots generate rich behavioral data from unsolicited traffic, but the scale and variability of such logs make manual analysis impractical. This study investigates the use of unsupervised learning methods, K-Means, DBSCAN, and Isolation Forest for detecting and characterizing cyberattack patterns from Dionaea and Cowrie honeypot logs collected at INSTIKI. The dataset comprises over 12,000 entries collected over a 14-day period, capturing diverse activities such as SMB scans, SSH brute-force, and web probing. After preprocessing and feature engineering, Principal Component Analysis (PCA) was used for dimensionality reduction, and Dynamic Event Clustering (DEC) was applied to identify temporal bursts. K-Means clustering revealed three dominant behavioral groups with a silhouette score of 0.59. DBSCAN identified smaller, dense clusters and labeled 31% of data as noise, while Isolation Forest flagged 28% of entries as anomalies—many overlapping with DBSCAN noise points. These results highlight the models’ complementary strengths in detecting both common and novel threats. Visualization and temporal analysis further enhanced interpretability and real-time threat correlation. The findings support the integration of unsupervised learning into CSIRT workflows and early-warning systems, especially in data-rich but label-scarce environments. Future work includes real-time deployment, multi-institution datasets, and payload-level inspection.

title: Optimization-Driven Design and Research of Piezoelectric Vibration Energy Harvesters Based on Shape Geometry
authors: Wanying Huang, Yunxiao Zhang, Yuhao Liu, Hao Hu, Jinlin Zheng, Chengfeng Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This study introduces an innovative arc-shaped cantilever beam design for piezoelectric energy harvesting targeting low-frequency environmental vibrations. Through a comparative analysis of stress distribution, frequency response characteristics, and output performance under identical volumes between arc-shaped and rectangular configurations leveraging Euler-Bernoulli beam theory and Erturk's distributed parameter model - simulations and experiments demonstrate the arc-shaped harvester's significant advantages. Key results show the arc-shaped configuration achieves uniform stress distribution with a peak of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4} \times \mathbf{1 0}^{\mathbf{7}} \mathbf{N} / \mathbf{m}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 H z}$</tex> resonance, outperforming the rectangular counterpart's concentrated stress at the fixed end (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> at 20 Hz), thereby substantially reducing fatigue fracture risk. Under equivalent acceleration conditions, the arc-shaped design generates 2.50 V open-circuit voltage, doubling the rectangular harvester's 1.25 V output while operating at 47% lower resonant frequency <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(12 \text{Hz}$</tex> vs. 20 Hz simulated). Experimental validation via a vibration test platform comprising a signal generator, power amplifier, electromagnetic shaker, and oscilloscope confirmed less than 5% deviation in resonant frequencies from simulations while maintaining closely matched output characteristics. These findings collectively establish the arc-shaped piezoelectric energy harvester as a superior solution for powering wearable devices and microsensors in low-frequency environments, owing to its optimized strain distribution and resonant frequency reduction capabilities.

title: RSRefSeg 2: Decoupling Referring Remote Sensing Image Segmentation with Foundation Models
authors: Keyan Chen, Chenyang Liu, Bowen Chen, Jiafan Zhang, Zhengxia Zou, Zhenwei Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Referring Remote Sensing Image Segmentation (RRSIS) facilitates flexible scene analysis by leveraging vision-language collaborative interpretation. However, conventional coupled frameworks typically perform pixel decoding after cross-modal fusion, conflating target localization (“where”) with boundary delineation (“how”). While recent decoupled approaches utilizing foundation models (e.g., SAM) attempt to separate these tasks, they predominantly rely on reductionist “box-to-mask” or “prompt-to-mask” pipelines. Such simple interfaces compress rich referring expressions into simplistic geometric constraints, severing semantic consistency and failing to leverage open-vocabulary visual-semantic alignment, particularly in multi-entity scenarios. To address these limitations, we propose RSRefSeg 2, an framework that logically reformulates the workflow into sequential subtasks of “slack localization” and “refined segmentation.” Central to our approach is a novel cascaded second-order referring prompter, designed to construct a robust semantic bridge between CLIP’s open-world understanding and SAM’s segmentation capabilities. Specifically, we introduce an orthogonal subspace decomposition mechanism that separates text embeddings into complementary components. This enables implicit cascaded reasoning to isolate target attributes from background noise: first performing slack localization via cross-modal interaction to identify potential regions, and subsequently generating refined prompts to guide SAM’s precise delineation. Furthermore, we incorporate parameter-efficient tuning to align natural image priors with remote sensing domains. Extensive experiments on RefSegRS, RRSIS-D, and RISBench demonstrate that RSRefSeg 2 significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an approximate 3% improvement in gIoU while offering superior diagnostic interpretability. The code is available at: https://github.com/KyanChen/RSRefSeg2.

title: TinyForestCD: A lightweight approach for enhanced detection of forest changes in Sentinel-2 imagery
authors: Changlong Lei, Enping Yan, Kaiqi Li, Dengkui Mo, Jiawei Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Detecting forest changes through remote sensing imagery is essential for effectively managing and monitoring forest resources. algorithms for forest change detection leveraging deep learning have shown remarkable performance across diverse scenarios. However, these algorithms face challenges such as imbalanced forest change samples and high false detection rates. To address these issues, this paper proposes a Global Grouped Coordinate Attention (GGCA) mechanism, which improves the model’s detection accuracy by emphasizing key features while suppressing irrelevant changes during the feature reconstruction process. Based on this, a lightweight forest change detection model, TinyForestCD, is designed. Furthermore,a hybrid loss function integrating CEloss and Diceloss is employed alongside an Online Hard Example Mining (OHEM) strategy, aiming to accurately extract key features from highly imbalanced forest change data. Extensive experiments conducted on a custom-built forest change detection dataset demonstrate that the Tiny-ForestCD model outperforms other comparative models across various performance metrics, achieving a performance metric of 80.65% in F1 score and 67.57% in IoU. Moreover, in the practical deployment in Hunan Province, the average F1 score and IoU for accuracy assessment of six sample plots are 81.06% and 68.25% , respectively, which are consistent with the test set results. In addition, in the deployment results of the Shaoguan area, the model also showed the best performance compared with other models, validating the model’s robustness and applicability in large-scale forest change detection. The research indicates that the TinyForestCD model has the potential for large-scale practical deployment, significantly improving the efficiency and accuracy of forest change surveys.

title: A Multi-Stage Vernier Effect-Based Fiber Sensing Strategy With Multi-Gear Operation for Wide-Range and High-Sensitivity Unambiguous Detection
authors: Xingkai Wang, Yu Zhang, Tianyi Zhong, Xiang Li, Wei Jin, Longxiang Guo, Liang Zhang, Heping Shen, Zhihai Liu, Libo Yuan
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-gear fiber-optic sensing strategy to resolve the long-standing trade-off between high sensitivity and wide dynamic range. The approach employs an array of parallel-connected Fabry–Pérot interferometers (FPIs), whose free spectral ranges (FSRs) are precisely designed to excite a multi-stage optical Vernier effect. This enables a cooperative “coarse-to-fine” measurement mode: the FPI with the largest FSR first operates independently, using its wide unambiguous detection range (UDR) to coarsely locate the target interval. The system then switches to a high-sensitivity mode, leveraging multi-order beat-frequency amplification for precise measurement within that interval. We constructed a sensing system using four intrinsic FPIs with cavity lengths of 11111 μm, 10000 μm, 1000 μm, and 100 μm, respectively. Experimental results demonstrate simultaneous unambiguous detection and high-sensitivity response across a temperature range of 30–90°C, achieving a maximum amplification factor of 668.5× and a sensitivity of –17.38 nm/°C. This work provides a novel and effective approach to designing high-performance fiber-optic sensors, successfully integrating wide dynamic range with high sensitivity in a single, flexible system.

title: Development of a Novel Deep-Sea Acoustic Measuring Device for Quantifying In Situ Methane Bubble Flux From Cold Seeps at the Seafloor
authors: Pengfei Di, Jianjun Long, Niu Li, Shuhong Wang, Dong Feng, Duofu Chen
publish: IEEE Journal of Oceanic Engineering
abstract: Natural cold seeps in the marine environment are significant contributors to atmospheric greenhouse gases. To accurately quantify the methane flux from cold seeps, a novel in situ acoustic measuring device was designed to determine the methane bubble flux using the attenuation in acoustic signal intensity caused by bubbles passing through a set pipe. The acoustic measuring device consists of an inverted conical tent and an acoustic measurement pipe with a rectangular cross-section. The acoustic measurement pipe comprises a bubble-fragmented homogenization unit and an acoustic cross-correlation sensor subsystem. The bubble-fragmented homogenization unit adjusts the rising gas bubbles to a diameter of less than 3 mm with a uniform spatial distribution. The acoustic cross-correlation sensor subsystem measures the bubble-rise rate and section void fraction to calculate bubble flux. The accuracy of the bubble rising rate is ±3%, and the relative error of bubble flux is 4.6%. The bubble flux of a single vent in the Lingtou promontory seep area is 2358.1 L, and the bubble rising rate ranges from 0.29 to 0.52 m/s, controlled by changes in ocean tides. Therefore, we believe this device can be a powerful tool for quantifying bubble flux in deep-sea environments.

title: Chain-Visage: Blockchain-Assisted Visual Content Ownership and Tamper Tracing in CIoT Multimedia Ecosystems
authors: Jing Yang, Vijay Govindarajan, Gyanendra Kumar, Achyut Shankar, Zaffar Ahmed Shaikh, Fabio Arena, Lip Yee Por, Kun Qi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: With the rapid proliferation of smart home cameras, wearable vision devices, and user-generated Consumer Internet of Things (CIoT) content, ensuring visual media authenticity, rightful ownership, and tamper detection has become increasingly challenging. We propose Chain-Visage, a blockchain-assisted framework for secure content authentication and tamper tracing in decentralized CIoT multimedia ecosystems. The term Chain reflects the consortium blockchain backbone that guarantees immutable provenance, decentralized ownership management, and copyright revocation, while Visage symbolizes the unique visual identity of multimedia content achieved through dual-stage visual hash embedding. The proposed framework integrates Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) for privacy-preserving ownership verification and employs optimized smart contracts to manage visual rights, provenance records, and ownership transfers efficiently. Evaluations on a large-scale dataset of over 10,000 real-world images and 3,850 video clips from diverse CIoT devices demonstrate Chain-Visage’s superior performance, achieving 97.5% traceability accuracy, 93% tamper detection sensitivity, and low verification latency even under resource-constrained environments. This work addresses a critical research gap in secure, privacy-preserving, and energy-efficient multimedia ownership control and tamper-resilient content authentication for next-generation CIoT ecosystems.

title: Heterogeneous Accelerated FDTD for Electromagnetic Scattering Problem of Large-Scale Targets
authors: Qiran Lu, Mengmeng Li, Jihong Gu, Hanyu Li, Haijing Zhou, Dazhi Ding, Ahmed A. Kishk
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: A large-scale parallel strategy for the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method on heterogeneous architectures is presented. A multilevel cooperative parallel framework is developed on heterogeneous accelerator platforms to improve load-balancing efficiency and intersubdomain communication efficiency. An asynchronous remote communication optimization strategy based on temporal updates is proposed to address the high communication intensity of FDTD. With the multilevel cooperative parallel framework, load-balancing efficiency is improved by approximately 40% in weak scaling tests, and a maximum acceleration ratio of about <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> can be achieved as the number of nodes increases. With the asynchronous remote communication optimization, the communication overhead is reduced from 69% to 11%, and a maximum acceleration ratio of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.49\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> is achieved. Finally, the combined optimization strategy is validated through electromagnetic scattering simulations, demonstrating that the algorithm sustains approximately 61% strong-scaling efficiency when scaling from 2800 processes (1.15 million cores) to 28 000 processes (11.5 million cores) on the Tianhe supercomputing platform.

title: Analysis of the Geographic Variation of Components in the Venom of the Scorpion Centruroides Bicolor
authors: Octavio A. Samudio C, Maricruz M. Morán, Hildaura Acosta, John Cleghorn, Gerardo Corzo, Lorena Hernández Orihuela, Marcos H. Salazar
publish: 2024 International Congress of Science and Technology for Sustainable Development (CITDES)
abstract: Analyzing the variability in scorpion venom composition is crucial for antivenom production due to its impact on the effectiveness of these products. This variability can arise from genetic differences among individuals of the same species, which could affect toxin synthesis mechanisms and, consequently, venom composition. A dditionally, diet, predator exposure, and specific climatic conditions also influence venom composition leading to adaptive responses. The study employed techniques such as High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC), SDS-PAGE, and mass spectrometry. Chromatographic methods including reverse-phase chromatography and electrophoresis under reducing and non-reducing conditions were used to study protein variability. The results revealed significant differences in venom composition between individuals of the species Centruroides bicolor in the David district compared to individuals from other adjacent regions. These variations suggest the presence of genetic variability that may impact antivenom effectiveness.

title: Towards Heterogeneity-Aware and Energy-Efficient Topology Optimization for Decentralized Federated Learning in Edge Environment
authors: Yuze Liu, Tiehua Zhang, Zhishu Shen, Libing Wu, Shiping Chen, Jiong Jin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising paradigm within edge computing (EC) systems, enabling numerous edge devices to collaboratively train artificial intelligence (AI) models while maintaining data privacy. To overcome the communication bottlenecks associated with centralized parameter servers, decentralized federated learning (DFL), which leverages peer-to-peer (P2P) communication, has been extensively explored in the research community. Although researchers design a variety of DFL approaches to ensure model convergence, its iterative learning process inevitably incurs considerable cost along with the growth of model complexity and the number of participants. These costs are largely influenced by the dynamic changes in topology in each training round, particularly its sparsity and connectivity conditions. Furthermore, the inherent resources heterogeneity in the edge environments affects energy efficiency of the learning process, while data heterogeneity degrades model performance. These factors pose significant challenges to the design of an effective DFL framework for EC systems. To this end, we propose Hat-DFed, a heterogeneity-aware and cost-effective decentralized federated learning framework. In Hat-DFed, the topology construction is formulated as a dual optimization problem, which is then proven to be NP-hard, with the goal of maximizing model performance while minimizing cumulative energy consumption in complex edge environments. To solve this problem, we design a two-phase algorithm that dynamically constructs optimal communication topologies while unbiasedly estimating their impact on both model performance and energy cost. Additionally, the algorithm incorporates an importance-aware model aggregation mechanism to mitigate performance degradation caused by data heterogeneity. Extensive experiments demonstrate that Hat-DFed outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving an average 1.8% improvement in test accuracy while reducing total energy cost by 36.9% throughout the learning process.

title: Phase- and Amplitude-Assisted Adaptive Model for Interference Mitigation in UAV-Enabled Multi-Cell Systems
authors: Weiyan Chen, Boyi Tang, Zhen Chen, Kai-Kit Wong, Chan-Byoung Chae, Xiu Yin Zhang
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are emerging as a promising platform for enabling integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) in multi-cell systems due to their deployment flexibility. However, this flexibility also introduces significant challenges, particularly co-channel interference at the UAV receiver. In this paper, we propose a novel adaptive co-channel interference mitigation model for UAV-enabled multi-cell systems. Specifically, the proposed model consists of two key components: a cost function and an update algorithm. First, we derive a new cost function that incorporates both magnitude and phase errors–critical metrics for guiding the estimated signal toward the desired signal. Second, the cost function is extended to formulate a parameter update algorithm, whose effectiveness is analyzed using both geometric and entropy-based approaches. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques, establishing it as a robust solution for interference mitigation in UAV-enabled multi-cell ISAC systems.

title: High-Efficient Rectifier With Wide Dynamic Range Using Self-Bias Junction Capacitance Compensation
authors: Xuanhao Shen, Peng-Yu Yu, Yuhua Cheng, Yi-Dan Chen, Pengde Wu, Changjun Liu
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a novel rectifier assisted by a self-bias junction capacitance compensation (JCC) for high-efficiency RF-to-dc conversion across a wide input power range. Unlike conventional tunable matching networks at the input, the proposed approach dynamically turns on the JCC in parallel with the rectifying diode by sampling the output voltage. This compensation mitigates intrinsic junction capacitance drift caused by the input power, significantly enhancing impedance stability without introducing extra matching circuit or requiring external bias power. The power consumption of the proposed JCC is less than 0.2% of the output dc power, making it negligible. Measured results show that the power conversion efficiency (PCE) remains above 50% over the input power range of −2 to 24 dBm, and exceeds 70% between 8 and 22 dBm, with a peak efficiency of 81.5% at 21 dBm. Compared to a reference design with a fixed impedance matching, the proposed JCC significantly broadens the ranges of input power and dc load at the same time.

title: Open Data for Smart Urban Innovation: A Dimensional Study of European Datasets
authors: Paraskevi Tsoutsa, Vyron Damasiotis, Vasileios Kyriatzis, Panos Fitsilis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Open data plays a crucial role in fostering urban innovation and transformation. However, challenges persist due to a lack of metadata standardization, diverse data schemas, difficulties in discovering relevant datasets, and issues related to multilingualism. This study investigates the landscape of open datasets related to smart cities in Europe, based on data retrieved from data.europa.eu. We employ SPARQL queries to extract metadata and apply thematic mapping based on Giffinger's Smart City model alongside keyword-based classification. Subsequently, datasets are identified and categorized across six smart city dimensions. Our findings reveal the distribution patterns, thematic gaps, multilingual barriers, and emerging opportunities for advancing data-driven urban innovation through open data.

title: A Multi-Agent Multi-Objective Coverage Method Based on Spectral Clustering Grouping in Complex Obstacle Environments
authors: Ruopu Bai, Jian Yang, Tianshuai Xu, Yanqi Bu, Taotao He, Ya Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: To tackle the task allocation challenges in MultiAgent Multi-Objective Coverage Problem (MAMOCP) within complex 3D obstructed environments, this paper proposes an optimized framework integrating obstruction-aware accessibility metrics. By fusing geometric distance and obstacle- penalized accessibility into a hybrid similarity matrix, we develop an enhanced spectral clustering algorithm that clusters target points into balanced subgroups. This strategy reduces inter-cluster interference while optimizing path smoothness and energy efficiency. By designing the simulation experiment of UAV swarm in 3D obstructed environment and proposing the path length and flight energy loss evaluation indexes to compare our proposed algorithm with the classical algorithm, proving its superiority in computational efficiency and adaptability to obstacle scenarios.

title: Short-Term Power Prediction Method for Wind Farms Based on Feature Selection and Power Characteristic Guidance
authors: Yuxi Liu, Xiaosheng Peng, Changxiao Liu, Ming Cheng, Xinyi Lai, Siyu Lu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To address the issues of single-dimensional meteorological data screening and the lack of mechanistic interpretability in purely data-driven models for wind farm power prediction, this paper proposes a short-term power prediction method for wind farms based on feature selection and power characteristic guidance. Firstly, a multi-indicator feature selection mechanism is designed to extract the optimal feature subset by integrating multi-dimensional correlation metrics. Secondly, a dual data-knowledge driven model is constructed by embedding prior knowledge of wind farm power characteristics into the loss function, achieving a coupled mapping between data patterns and turbine operation mechanisms. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed feature selection method improves prediction accuracy, while the introduction of the knowledge-guided term further reduces the RMSE of the BiTCN model, validating the synergistic advantages of data-knowledge fusion.

title: Review of Electronic Transformer Condition Assessment
authors: Chenyi Yang, Xingyan Wu, Jian Liu, Zhenhua Li, Zhenxing Li, Yanchun Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the rapid development of smart grids, how to effectively monitor and evaluate the status of electronic transformers has become an important research topic in the field of power measurement. In order to track and analyze the operation error of the transformer, experts and scholars worldwide have been exploring new methods of transformer calibration and condition assessment. This paper summarizes the main methods of transformer condition assessment according to different assessment ideas, covering the techniques of “on-site calibration”, “on-line calibration” and “on-line assessment”. The article elaborates on the principles, research status, and achievements of these methods, while also comparing and analyzing their advantages and limitations. Online evaluation technologies that do not rely on standard devices, do not disrupt normal grid operations, and enable real time monitoring of transformer conditions are expected to become a research hotspot and future development direction, driven by the increasing demand for efficient and real time assessment in smart grids.

title: A Survey on AI Applications in the Open Classroom Approach
authors: Ines Boutabia, Abdelmadjid Benmachiche, Ali Abdelatif Betouil, Messaouda Boutassetta, Makhlouf Derdour
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Advanced Systems (ICNAS)
abstract: The open classroom approach emerged as a practical and adaptable learning environment that promotes not only student-centered learning but also the collaboration of students and modern technology.
