On the other hand, artificial intelligence (AI) has been very dynamic in the education industry, serving as a facilitator of smart tutoring systems, adaptive learning platforms, learning analytics, and virtual assistance. This survey study delves deeper into the area of AI technologies and the open classroom paradigm. AI-powered systems like intelligent tutoring systems, adaptive learning platforms, and learning analytics tools have envisioned, fostered, and realized the goals of open classrooms, such as personalization, engagement, and self-regulated learning. In addition, the article describes the latest AI solutions that have been tested and evaluated in open classrooms, accentuates the features that they share, and identifies the persistent problems that arise from privacy protection and technology constraints. It is in the development of future research directions that the fusion of AI and open classrooms is proposed as the best approach to work on personalized learning paths, the integration of multimodal data, and finally, human-AI collaboration in education.

title: Analysis of the Integration Potential for Offshore Wind Power Plants Located Along the Western Coast of the Black Sea
authors: Dimitar Hristov, Yulian Rangelov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: The factors that imply including more Renewable Energy Sources (RES) into the energy mix of the Bulgarian Power System are numerous. Starting with the “Zero Emission” policy adopted by the European Union and its representative countries, continuing with greenhouse gases concerns, continuing to localized load increases and overall economic benefits of the RES power plants. The current situation with renewables in the country veers heavily towards Photovoltaic generation, with a daily production during hot summer periods, at times higher than the daily nuclear facilities production. There are ample reasons to consider expanding the share of Wind Power both on- and offshore in order to diversify and improve the mix of the power grid. This publication will be tracing possibilities for establishing such expansion in the coastal regions of Bulgaria, revising possible locations with regard of multiple key factors, to identify the future integration potential and challenges.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Objective Energy Management in Hybrid Vehicles
authors: Bin Liu, Cong Li, Hui Jing, Xiaoyuan Zhang, Huanqin Feng, Ziqiang Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: To improve the fuel economy of hybrid vehicles under complex driving conditions while maintaining the battery state of charge (SOC) within a desirable range, this study proposes an energy management strategy based on the Double Deep Q-Network (Double DQN). By employing two decoupled neural networks for action selection and value estimation, the strategy effectively mitigates the Q-value overestimation bias commonly observed in standard DQN approaches, thereby enhancing training stability and convergence. The state space includes instantaneous power demand, SOC, and historical power outputs. A reward function is designed to minimize equivalent fuel consumption, with SOC controlled through soft constraints to maintain it within the target range. A series hybrid powertrain model is developed in Simulink, and the proposed strategy is trained and validated under typical urban and mission-oriented driving cycles. Simulation results demonstrate that the method outperforms conventional rule-based and standard DQN strategies in terms of fuel efficiency and SOC regulation, while also exhibiting improved generalization and robustness in multi-objective energy optimization tasks for hybrid vehicles.

title: Phenotype-Based Classification of Sugarcane and Rice Fields Using One-Class SVM from Satellite Imagery
authors: Punnawit Kotosri, Thanawin Rakthanmanon, Soravis Supavetch
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Crop type classification is essential for agricultural monitoring and planning. Although rice and sugarcane are prominent crops in Thailand distinguishing between them is challenging due to overlapping growth cycles and similar spectral patterns. Traditional methods often necessitate fully labeled balanced datasets which are difficult to obtain through natural investigation. This study proposes a phenology-based approach utilizing a sinusoidal equation to characterize crop growth throughout their complete life cycles. Satellite indices specifically the Soil Adjusted Vegetation Index (SAVI) and the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index (MNDWI) were employed to represent the sinusoidal signal. A One-Class Support Vector Machine (OCSVM) based on likelihood principles will be utilized to ascertain crop types. The OCSVM allows for the classification of a single label from unknown multi-labeled data supported by the phenological approach. This research presents a novel methodology aimed at overcoming the limitations of machine learning classification when datasets are insufficient. The results demonstrate the success of the proposed research concept.

title: Impact of Demand Response on Abnormal Electricity Consumption Behavior: A Data-Driven Analysis
authors: Xidong Zheng, Jingzheng Li, Huangbin Chen, Wanghao Wang, Qinyu Huang, Tao Jin
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Aiming at the abnormal electricity consumption behavior of power users under the time-of-use (TOU) electricity price environment, for the first time, this paper constructs a demand response (DR) model that incorporates user elastic heterogeneity and behavioral decision-making mechanisms. By introducing price incentives, elasticity coefficients, and behavioral inertia factors, the load adjustment process of users under various price signals is simulated. Combining cost savings, behavior correction levels, and changes in abnormality indices, the impact of DR on improving abnormal behavior is assessed. The simulation results demonstrate that TOU price-driven user-side behavior regulation can effectively enhance load elasticity and mitigate abnormal risks, providing data support and methodological references for distributed load management and smart grid operations.

title: Cost-Effective Installation of Externally Gapped Line Arresters for Lightning Protection of Medium Voltage Distribution Lines
authors: Tomohiro Maeda, Akifumi Yamanaka, Ryota Mori, Kazuyuki Ishimoto, Katsunori Fujii, Akihisa Takahashi
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: For lightning protection of medium voltage (MV) distribution lines in Japan, zinc oxide surge arresters (SAs), which suppress lightning overvoltages, are generally used. These SAs require grounding electrode with low resistance dedicated to them, and distribution operators are struggling to obtain and maintain low resistance especially in areas with severe soil conditions. In recent years, externally gapped line arresters (EGLAs), which do not require grounding, are expected to be introduced. This study evaluates the cost– performance ratio of SAs and EGLAs under varying installation intervals and numbers of protected phases. First, the flashover characteristics of EGLAs were obtained by an experiment. Next, lightning protection rates for SAs and EGLAs were calculated using electromagnetic transient analysis. The total cost of installation required by each element was calculated, and the lightning protection rate and total cost were comprehensively compared. The calculation results showed that installing EGLAs every 100 m in two phases offers high lightning protection rates and low cost for the studied distribution lines. The findings support more cost-effective lightning protection design for MV distribution lines.

title: Advancements in Power Regulation of a 90 kW Dynamic Wireless Charging System Through Frequency and Duty Cycle Control Algorithms
authors: Edemar O. Prado, Zariff Meira Gomes, Yann Le Gall, Yacine Sehimi, Hamiltom C. Sartori, Hussein Al Haj Hassan, Gilney Damm, Christophe Ripoll, José Renes Pinheiro
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: The electrification of the transport sector constitutes a key point in the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. However, the electrification process is accompanied by several challenges, notably the requirement for larger batteries in vehicles and the need to expand the infrastructure of charging stations, due to limitations in vehicle range. Dynamic wireless charging systems offer an innovative solution that allows vehicles to recharge while driving, reducing the reliance on large-capacity batteries and stationary charging stations. However, further analysis and enhancements are required to achieve higher power levels. This paper presents a multiscale evaluation of an inductive wireless power transfer system, which is applied to a 90 kW electric vehicle charger that utilizes three active coils on both the primary and secondary sides. To ensure accurate output power regulation, algorithms are implemented for tracking the resonance frequency and adjusting the duty cycle, enabling effective power control within the system. Under optimally aligned conditions, a total power output of 95 kW is achieved at the load. The results in a misaligned condition show an equivalent output power close to 90 kW.

title: Design of a Novel Wireless Charging System with a Secondary Transformer for Efficiency Improvement
authors: Guozheng Zhang, Haoran Li, Yuyu Zhu, Jie Deng, Yuying Zhu, Haoyu Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The wireless power transfer (WPT) system has been extensively studied for its safety, convenience, and aesthetics and has gradually been introduced into our life applications. As this technology has matured, recent broad applications of wireless power transfer systems have indicated a trend toward to higher power, and higher efficiency of designs. However, realizing high power poses significant design challenges because the battery equivalent resistance changes during charging and the wireless charging system is in a low load phase. This paper addresses the issue of low efficiency in the LCC-S topology at low equivalent loads by proposing, using the principle of transformer impedance transformation, a transformer is added to the LCC-S to achieve system impedance matching and high-efficiency transmission at low loads. The transformer parameters are also analyzed and designed to obtain the optimal design parameters of the transformer for the wireless charging system requirements. wireless charging system with a power level of 1 KW was built, and when the load resistance is 1Ω, the efficiency of the improved LCC-S is 78.9 %. In contrast, the efficiency of the LCC-S topology is 59.3 %, and when the equivalent load reaches 2.4Ω, the efficiency of the improved LCC-S topology is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{8 4. 4 \%}$</tex>. The efficiency of the LCC-S topology is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{8 2. 9 \%}$</tex>. At low equivalent loads, the efficiency of the improved LCC-S topology has an overall better transmission efficiency than LCC-S.

title: Assessment of Leakage Current on Polymeric Insulators Under Non-Uniform Saline Pollution Conditions
authors: Ana B. F. Oliveira, Elaine S. Araújo, Johnny H. P. Oliveira, Bruno V. S. Araujo, Gustavo A. Rodrigues, George V. R. Xavier, Tarso V. Ferreira
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This study investigates the influence of saline pollution on the leakage current behavior of polymeric insulators. Laboratory tests were conducted on insulators exposed to different artificial pollution distribution patterns, following the procedures outlined in the IEC 60507 and IEC 60815-1 standards. Leakage current measurements were analyzed using Digital Signal Processing, considering odd harmonic components up to the 15th order. The results demonstrate that leakage current intensity increases with pollution levels, with the primary indicators being the H7 and H11 components. Additionally, the occurrence of leakage current depends on the spatial distribution of pollution, environmental conditions, and the electrical context. The findings may contribute to developing more effective monitoring and preventive maintenance methods for polymeric insulators.

title: Quantifying the Carbon Footprint of Electric Vehicles in Sustainable Urban Mobility
authors: Thommas Flores, Morsinaldo Medeiros, Marianne Silva, Daniel G. Costa, Ivanovitch Silva
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: Real-time measurement of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> emissions allows assessment of both the carbon footprint and indirect environmental impacts of electric vehicles (EVs) in urban areas. This study presents a TinyML framework that estimates <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> emissions using lightweight regression models deployed on microcontrollers interfaced with the vehicle's OBD-II system. Eight compact machine learning models, including Decision Tree, Multilayer Perceptron (MLP), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), were evaluated. The Decision Tree model was selected for embedded implementation due to its high predictive accuracy and low computational requirements. A case study using real driving data from a BMW i3 (EV) and a Volkswagen Polo (ICVE) showed that the embedded model achieved a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \mu$</tex> s inference latency, requiring only 432 KB of Flash memory and 21 KB of RAM. On the same urban route, the model estimated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.39 ~\mathrm{g} / \text{km} \text{CO}_{2}$</tex> for the EV and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$129.33 ~\mathrm{g} / \text{km}$</tex> for the ICVE, representing a 95.06 % reduction. This approach escalable, low-cost <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> monitoring directly at the edge, supporting data-driven policy and mobility.

title:
Indoor SF
                    <sup>6</sup>
                    Leakage Monitoring Technology Using Pumped Infrared Spectroscopy with Intelligent Purging and Its Application in High-Voltage Insulation Equipment
authors: Yunhua He, Bin Li, Xueting Cheng, Lei Liu, Zheng Zhong, Ruijian Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Sulfur hexafluoride (SF<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>) is a key insulating medium used in high-voltage circuit breakers, gas-insulated switchgear (GIS), and gas-insulated transformers. Its leakage can pose a threat to the safe operation of power equipment and exacerbate the greenhouse effect. To address issues such as response delay and low sensitivity in traditional diffusion-based detection technology, we proposed a self-diagnostic pumped SF<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> leakage monitoring method. This approach combines active sampling with infrared spectral analysis, focusing on the SF<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> characteristic absorption peak at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10.55 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> to avoid spectral interference from air and decomposition products. Furthermore, a stainless steel filter sleeve fabricated via powder metallurgy was integrated with an intelligent feedback purge module to address the degradation of accuracy caused by particulate contamination. Validation using a trace SF<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> detection platform demonstrated that the proposed technique has a detection error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leq \pm 0.7 \%$</tex>, a response time that is 35 % faster than the diffusion-based method, and a minimum detection limit as low as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.3 \mu \mathrm{L} / \mathrm{L}$</tex>. The study results provide an innovative solution for real-time monitoring of SF<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> leakage in high-voltage insulation equipment.

title: AI-Powered Tourist Behavior Prediction Using Multi-Modal Big Data from Social Media, Reviews, and Location Data
authors: Kumar Bhaskar, Diptee Tanmay Shete, Lalita Sureshrao Korade, Nihar Das, Pushp Lata Rajpoot, Simranjit Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Tourism is growing quickly, and digital tracks are becoming easier to find. This gives us a chance to understand and predict how tourists will behave by using advanced data-driven methods. This study suggests using multi-modal big data from social media sites, online reviews, and geolocation data to guess how tourists will behave. The system is driven by AI. Using deep learning and natural language processing to find trends in text, pictures, and location histories is made possible by combining different types of data sources. Posts and reviews on social media give us real-time information about what tourists like, how they feel, and what they've experienced. Location data, on the other hand, shows us trends of behaviour in space and time. The suggested model uses a multi-stream neural network design that blends picture recognition, textual mood analysis, and trajectory mining to make very accurate guesses about how people will behave. With this allaround method, people involved in tourism can predict travel trends, find sites that are in high demand, and tailor their services to each visitor's needs. Using large datasets from the real world, a lot of tests show that the model can accurately predict the activities, tastes, and moving patterns of tourists. The structure is useful for smart tourism, location management, and urban planning because it lets people make decisions based on data and without waiting for information. This study adds to the growing field of AI in tourism by showing how multi-modal big data fusion can be used to improve behavioural analytics.

title: Intelligent Malware Detection System using Chi Square-based Feature Selection and Machine Learning Classification
authors: Anubha Pearline S, Afzal Ahamed A, Geetha S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: With Android devices accounting for over 70 % of the global smartphone market, the threat of sophisticated malware such as trojans, ransomware, and spyware has escalated rapidly. Traditional signature-based detection methods struggle to address polymorphic and zero-day attacks. This paper presents a machine learning-based malware detection system that leverages the TUANDROMD and Drebin datasets to classify Android applications using selected permission-based features. Feature selection was performed using the Chi-Square Test to identify the most discriminative attributes, enhancing model efficiency. Experiments were conducted using Extra Trees, Logistic Regression, Random Forest, SVM, and Gradient Boosting classifiers. The Extra Tree Classifier achieved the highest accuracy of 97.42% on TUANDROMD, and 95.75% on Drebin dataset. A Flask-based web interface enables real-time APK analysis, making the system accessible to end-users. The results demonstrated state-of-the-art performance for Android malware detection and highlight the potential for deployment in mobile and enterprise environments.

title: Cluster Methods Analysis for Defining Electricity Supply Continuity Indicators
authors: Giovane Nunes Cornelio Rêgo, Kleber Melo e Silva
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This paper analyzes clustering methods (KMeans, K-Medoids, DBSCAN, and HDBSCAN) for defining electricity supply continuity indicators (SAIDI and SAIFI) in Brazil. After evaluating the algorithms with statistical metrics (WCSS, Silhouette Score, DaviesBouldin Index, and Calinski-Harabasz Score), the most suitable approaches were used to set annual regulatory limits over an eight-year period. These limits were compared to ANEEL's official benchmarks using RMSE and MAE. The results show that the proposed methodology achieves comparable performance to the official method, with minimal deviation, while offering a simpler and more efficient alternative with fewer steps for regulatory applications.

title: Intelligent Control for Power Quality Enhancement and Voltage Stability in Grid-Connected and Islanded Microgrid Operations
authors: Akhila M S, Akhil Chacko
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: A Dynamic Voltage Restorer (DVR) plays a crucial role in improving power quality in both grid-connected and islanded microgrid environments. In the grid-connected scenario, the system is analyzed under both linear and non-linear load conditions. Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) levels are compared for three cases: without DVR, with DVR using a Proportional-Integral (PI) controller, and with DVR employing a Fuzzy Logic Controller (FLC). Simulation results indicate that both PI and FLC-based DVRs significantly reduce THD compared to the case without compensation, with the FLC offering slightly improved performance in harmonic mitigation. In the islanded mode, the DVR controlled by a PI strategy is implemented to address voltage disturbances and harmonics during disconnection from the main grid. The results confirm that the DVR, particularly with intelligent control techniques, is effective in maintaining voltage stability and power quality in both operational modes.

title: Enhancing Wholesale Management Through Machine Learning-Based Customer Behavior Analysis
authors: Samuel-Soma M. Ajibade, Muhammed Basheer Jasser, Ghassan Saleh ALDharhani, Lee Wei San, Adefemi Ayodele, Anthonia Oluwatosin Adediran, Almighty Cortezo Tabuena, Kayode A. Akintoye, Mbiatke Anthony Bassey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: This study concentrates on the analysis of wholesale customer data to enhance the understanding of consumer behavior and expenditure trends. The dataset has information about how much people spend each year on Fresh, Milk, Grocery, Frozen, Detergents_Paper, and Delicassen, as well as what kind of client they are (Retail or Horeca) and where they live. A Random Forest Classifier was used with machine learning (ML) to forecast the types of clients, and it worked quite well. K-Means clustering was then used to split customers into categories depending on how much they spent. The analysis gives firms information about how to group and classify customers, which helps them make better decisions and adjust their marketing tactics. This study demonstrates the efficacy of integrating classification and clustering approaches for substantive customer analysis by tackling problems such as high-dimensional data. These findings underscore the potential of machine learning in bolstering the wholesale sector and establish a foundation for subsequent research.

title: A Multi-stage Resilience Enhancement Method for Integrated Energy Systems Considering Gas/heat Dynamic Characteristics
authors: Mingxuan Jiang, Yiheng Bian, Gengfeng Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Existing studies on resilience assessment and enhancement of integrated energy systems (IES) under disasters lack heat network models, do not consider inherent gas/heat dynamic characteristics, and do not adequately exploit flexible resources. This paper proposes an IES resilience enhancement method considering gas/heat dynamic characteristics for the whole disaster process. Optimization of energy storage allocation based on a bi-level model, enhancement of critical components based on component importance assessment, and Copeland ranking are proposed for the pre-disaster stage. Multiple flexible resources which contain repair crews, emergency mobile energy storage vehicles, reconfiguration and islanding, source-side coupled components and energy storage dispatch, and load-side integrated demand response are considered in the post-disaster stage for IES repair and restoration. The validity of the proposed method and the rationality of the process are verified with an arithmetic example.

title: Personalized Vacation Planning: An Efficient Heuristic Approach
authors: Nikolaos Vathis, Grammati Pantziou, Charalampos Konstantopoulos, Damianos Gavalas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: We present a heuristic-based algorithmic framework for solving the Vacation Planning Problem (VPP), which involves the generation of optimized, personalized multistop road trip itineraries across wide geographical regions. Our approach addresses key challenges in road trip planning, including the selection and sequencing of overnight destinations, allocation of stay durations, and daily tour planning that maximizes tourist satisfaction. The proposed solution operates in two distinct phases: an offline preprocessing phase that clusters Points of Interest (POIs) based on their geographic distribution and precomputes personalized profit estimations based on user stereotypes and stay durations; and an online phase that formulates destination selection as a constrained Multiple-Choice Knapsack Problem, followed by tour sequencing and route planning. Compared to previous VPP solutions, our approach maintains comparable itinerary quality but dramatically improves computational efficiency, thus enabling real-time performance. The algorithm has been integrated into the TouristHub platform and evaluated on both real-world and synthetic datasets, demonstrating its robustness, efficiency, and adaptability to different regional and user-specific configurations.

title: Design and Analysis of a Low Read Latency Sram Architecture Using Cmos 45nm Technology
authors: Addepalli Venkata Naga Sai Ruthivik, D Muralidharan, Sivaraman R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: As computing hardware gets more powerful and requires less power, memory design takes centre stage in this advancement. This paper presents the design, implementation, and performance analysis of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 K b}$</tex> low-power, high-speed Static Random Access Memory (SRAM) array based on the conventional 6-transistor (6T) CMOS style. It satisfies the stringent needs of the current system on chips (SoCs), processors, and mobile handhelds. The memory block integrates the peripheral and core circuits into a small and efficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 2} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{3 2}$</tex> matrix. Cadence Virtuoso simulations reveal that the design runs at a 16 ps read latency and a 26.4 ps write latency, with good performance continuing at a read static noise margin (SNM) of 470 mV and a write SNM of 538 mV. Array total power consumption is reduced to 0.7 mW, and per-cell power usage is only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$14.99 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>. Performance and reliability are improved by techniques like differential sensing, symmetrical transistor sizing, and low-power write drivers. It is a good compromise between speed, energy efficiency, and stability and can be used in future embedded memory applications. Future work will emphasise more bit densities, inserting error correction, and measuring resilience to process variation and ageing.

title: Studies on the Reliability of Power UMOSFETs in the Terrestrial Radiation Environment
authors: Saulo G. Alberton, Alexis C. V. Bôas, Marcilei A. Guazzelli, Jeffery Wyss, Vitor A. P. Aguiar, Nemitala Added, Claudio A. Federico, Tássio C. Cavalcante, Evaldo C. F. Pereira Júnior, Rafael G. Vaz, Odair L. Gonçalez, Luca Silvestrin, Serena Mattiazzo, Carlo Cazzaniga, Maria Kastriotou, Christopher Frost, Saulo Finco, Alessandro Paccagnella, Nilberto H. Medina
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: The trench gate or U-groove MOSFET (UMOSFET) has become one of the most widespread semiconductor devices globally, currently supplanting the traditional double-diffused MOSFET (DMOSFET) in numerous applications. It is essential to assess its reliability regarding radiation effects induced by ubiquitous atmospheric neutrons. This study directly compares the SEE response of similarly rated UMOS and DMOS power FETs when exposed to monoenergetic and quasi-atmospheric neutron beams. Experimental results suggest that UMOSFETs are more susceptible to experiencing and prematurely triggering destructive radiation effects during operation in the terrestrial environment under reference conditions.

title: Optimized Control Strategy of M3C Based on the Third Harmonic in Equal Frequency Interconnection
authors: Chen Zhang, Zhichang Yang, Gaoshan Hou, Yingpei Wang, Guoliang Zhao, Bao Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Modular multilevel matrix converter exhibits superior power regulation capability for partitioned grid interconnection owing to its modular design. However, under equal frequency operation, arm power imbalance leads to unstable floating capacitor voltages. To address this issue, the paper proposes an optimized closed-loop control strategy. First, the circuit topology of M3C is analyzed, revealing the intrinsic mechanism of voltage fluctuations during equal frequency operation. Subsequently, based on the decoupled relationship between capacitor voltages and corresponding power components, a coordinated control method employing fundamental circulating current and high-order harmonics is developed to eliminate arm energy imbalance. Moreover, the proposed control strategy maintains excellent dynamic performance during system power variations.

title: UAV Path Planning Using Improved Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Yu Jiang, Qizeng Zhang, Xu Peng, Hongyu Fan, Yongqi Wen, Yihao Zhong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Aiming at the traditional particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm which is easy to fall into local optimum and slow convergence speed in UAV 3D path planning, this paper proposes an improved particle swarm algorithm. The path is optimised by introducing dynamic inertia weight adjustment strategy, adaptive variation mechanism and Bessel curve. At the same time, a multi-objective fitness function is designed to integrate the path length cost, obstacle threat cost and sailing altitude cost to construct the fitness function and optimisation indexes such as energy cost. Based on the 3D simulation environment, the performance of the improved algorithm is compared with that of the traditional PSO, and the experimental results show that the total cost of the path planned by the improved algorithm is reduced and the iterative convergence speed is improved. An efficient solution is provided for the UAV path planning problem.

title: A Low Dropout, High PSRR LDO Design for Power Management Unit of Wearable Devices
authors: Abu Mahamed Adil, D Muralidharan, Sivaraman R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: This work presents the design and simulation of a low-dropout (LDO) voltage regulator optimized for the power management unit (PMU) of wearable devices. Implemented using 180nm GPDK CMOS technology in Cadence Virtuoso, the proposed LDO regulates 1.64 V output from a 1.8 V supply with a reference of 1 V. The design achieves a low dropout of 160 mV, a gain of 77.58 dB, and a phase margin of 65°. The Power Supply Rejection Ratio (PSRR) is measured as −60 dB at kHz and - 62 dB at MHz frequencies. Power consumption is kept at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$884.26 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>, confirming the circuit's suitability for energyconstrained wearable systems. With a VDD fluctuation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 10 \%$</tex>, several corner checks were carried out over a temperature range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to 125° C. The LDO's robustness and efficiency are confirmed by simulation results under various PVT situations.

title: Application and Discussion of RPA Technology in Electric Power Dispatching System
authors: Donglin Hu, Min Zhang, Yaquan Wang, Yuanpei Chen, Haozhen Zhang, Runsong Ma, Yang He
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the continuous advancement of integrated dispatching and control, power dispatching operations face dual pressures: a sustained increase in system module complexity and exponential growth in data volume, which imposes more stringent requirements on the professional competencies and operational skills of dispatchers. Leveraging the technical advantages of robotic process automation (RPA), this study achieves automated processing of high-frequency repetitive tasks, thereby liberating human resources from low-value-added operations. Rooted in practical power dispatching scenarios, this research establishes a process optimization model for typical business workflows and elaborates on the implementation of RPA technology in core procedures such as dispatch maintenance request decomposition and panoramic indicator analysis in dispatching centers. Furthermore, it explores associated optimizations in operational practices, system architecture, management frameworks, and personnel training. The proposed approach aims to enhance operational efficiency and accuracy while safeguarding the secure and stable operation of power grids, thereby providing technical support for constructing a safety assurance system for new power system.

title: Lithium-Ion Battery Soc Estimation Based on the Joint Algorithm of Mils Online Parameter Identification and Fuzzy Control-Improved Extended Kalman Filter
authors: Haozeng Wang, Kun Yin, Shiyu Wang, Jiahong Li, Ziqiang Du, Jianhui Su
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The safe, stable, and efficient operation of a Battery Management System (BMS) is fundamentally dependent on the precise estimation of the lithium-ion battery's State of Charge (SOC). Under dynamic operating conditions, existing online parameter identification methods have limitations such as low data utilization and slow convergence, which restricts the accuracy of SOC estimation. This paper presents an integrated strategy that concurrently performs online battery parameter identification and SOC estimation. The foundation of this approach is a second-order RC equivalent circuit model. Then, the Multi-Innovation Least Squares (MILS) algorithm is introduced to identify battery parameters online in real time and continuously update the model, effectively utilizing historical information to improve identification accuracy and convergence efficiency. Meanwhile, to tackle the issue where the accuracy of traditional Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) based SOC estimation is constrained by errors in the observation equation, an adaptive EKF method based on fuzzy logic control is designed to mitigate the impact of observation errors. This joint strategy achieves precise online dynamic correction of model parameters through MILS and combines it with fuzzy adaptive EKF for robust SOC estimation under environmental disturbances. Capitalizing on the complementary benefits of both method, the accuracy and operational efficiency of SOC estimation are significantly enhanced.

title: Drone Nest Deployment on Expressways Using Traffic Flow Data and Graph Attention
authors: Hao Chen, Jiaxin Zhao, Yang Jiao, Haining Zhao, Jing Lai, Tao Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: With the increasing demand for efficient expressway monitoring, deploying drone nests along expressways has become a promising solution to support continuous aerial inspection. This paper introduces a data-driven method for drone nest deployment. Firstly, the expressway is discretized into candidate circular regions at regular intervals. Then, a modified Spatio-Temporal Graph Attention Network (ST-GAT) is introduced to model both spatial dependencies among road segments and temporal dependencies on traffic flow. The proposed method takes full account of the distribution of critical highway infrastructure as well as expressway traffic flow data. A composite loss function is further designed to balance coverage performance, deployment redundancy, and budget constraints. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method over baseline approaches.

title: Generating Critical Scenarios of Transmission Interfaces Based on Denoising Diffusion Model
authors: Quan Zhang, Jiajie Ling, Wei Du, Jun Wang, Guangchao Geng, Quanyuan Jiang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Generating critical scenarios of transmission interfaces with low safety margins is essential for developing power systems operation mode and contingency preparation. This paper proposes a data synthesis framework based on denoising diffusion model (DDM) to improve the efficiency of scenarios generation. First, the total transmission capacity (TTC) and safety margin of transmission interface are solved with the objective of maximizing its power flow, which accumulates scenarios with different features for training DDM. Furthermore, DDM is pre-trained on all training scenarios and subsequently fine-tuned on critical scenarios. Case studies in modified IEEE 39-bus test system demonstrate that the proposed method can generate batches of desired scenarios, and it outperforms baselines in terms of scenario quality and synthesis speed.

title: Ultra-Short-Term Forecasting of Distributed Photovoltaic Based on Multivariate Interpolation and Electrical Clustering
authors: Lidanlan Tao, Ming Yang, Qiangsheng Bu, Fei Luo, Zhigang Ye
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In order to solve the problems of missing data, difficult dynamic clustering and insufficient fusion of multisource information in the ultra-short-term power prediction of Distributed Photovoltaic(DPV) clusters, this paper proposes a prediction method combining data-driven and model optimization. Firstly, the missing data are made up by using joint decomposition in time-frequency domain, natural neighborhood spatial interpolation and cubic spline temporal interpolation, and soft-DTW algorithm is used to realize sequence alignment; secondly, a dynamic clustering strategy is constructed based on the electrical distance, and the PV clusters are adaptively divided; lastly, the Transformer prediction model is constructed, and the historical interpolated power and real-time meteorological data are used as inputs to realize the ultra-short-term power prediction. short-term power prediction. Simulation results show that compared with the traditional method, the NAME of the proposed method in this paper is lower than the comparison method in both weather scenarios, which verifies that the method in this paper can effectively improve the accuracy of DPV ultra-short-term prediction, and provides theoretical support for the efficient scheduling of DPV clusters.

title: Multi-USV Collaborative Energy-Efficient Regional Coverage Path Planning
authors: Xiaofan Zou, Junhan Huang, Bufan Zhou, Sicheng Zhang, Yangmin Xie
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper addresses key challenges in energy-efficient coverage path planning (ECPP) and multi-agent energy-efficient coverage path planning (MUECPP) for unmanned surface vehicles (USVs), including the limited consideration of environmental influences, oversimplified energy consumption models, and difficulties in balancing coverage area and energy distribution. To tackle these challenges, we propose an enhanced energy consumption estimation model that incorporates both ocean currents and USV steering energy costs. Based on this model, we introduce a novel three-stage algorithm, DARP-CTSTC-TENE, designed to optimize the efficiency of multi-USV collaborative coverage tasks. The proposed approach consists of three key phases: energy-aware region allocation, which partitions the workspace while considering energy balance constraints; spanning tree-based coverage path generation, which constructs energy-minimal coverage paths by accounting for environmental forces and maneuvering costs; and energy-aware end-node exchange, which iteratively refines the region allocation and coverage paths to achieve better energy distribution and task efficiency. Comprehensive evaluations, including comparative experiments with DARP-STC and DARP-ACO-IS algorithms, as well as realistic marine simulations, demonstrate that DARP-CTSTC-TENE significantly reduces total energy consumption while maintaining a balance between area coverage and energy distribution.

title: Efficient Vision Transformers Optimized with Pruning and Quantization for HMD
authors: Geon-Hee Lee, Seyong Jin, Woong Choi, Jiwon Kim, Jaemin Oh, Hyeonjoon Moon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: Recently, the importance of using high-performance computer vision models in lightweight mobile devices such as HMDs has increased due to the extension of computer vision into AR/VR and metaverse. However, existing Transformer-based vision models have problems in directly applying them to resource-constrained environments due to their high computational and memory requirements. This study aims to reduce the structural size of existing high-performance Transformer-based vision models and evaluate their performance in an HMD that supports AR/VR environments. To this end, this study designed lightweight models Light-1 and Light-2 by applying the block pruning and quantization based on MobileViT and verified the effectiveness of the lightweight strategy in the HMD. The experimental results confirmed that the lightweight strategy significantly reduced the size of the model and the number of parameters while maintaining the performance of the original model. This study laid a practical foundation for integration with HMDs through lightweighting high-performance vision models, and is expected to serve as an important foundation for research that provides more intelligent and immersive AR/VR and metaverse experiences.

title: Privacy and Security in Decentralized Cyber-Physical Systems: A Survey
authors: Djaber Abbas, Abdelmadjid Benmachiche, Makhlouf Derdour, Brahim Khalil Sedraoui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Advanced Systems (ICNAS)
abstract: With the growing demand on cutting edge technologies specially in the field of internet of things (IoT) cybersecurity the intersections between blockchain and federated learning (FL) is a promising research field. Blockchain based systems, which are inherently decentralized and trustless, allow local immutable logging for transparent, tamperproof security frameworks that support automated threat response via smart contracts while really being able to understand the integrity of the data being shared across a distributed network of machines. FL represents a powerful new paradigm, allowing organizations to create an accurate intrusion detection system (IDS) without needing to centralize sensitive data, a fundamental problem to solve in healthcare, finance, or Industrial IoT. Both technologies have important synergies within hybrid architectures that offer a balanced alternative by leveraging the privacy of FL and the security and auditability of blockchain to create a viable path to robust, scalable, and reliable cyber defense. There remain numerous challenges yet to be resolved around scalability, interoperability between devices and legacy systems, real-world deployment, and energy efficiency, but the cybersecurity landscape appears to be rapidly evolving to incorporate decentralized technologies. This survey material has highlighted the areas in which progress is being made, outlined the core strengths and limitations of the technologies and approaches employed today, and suggested innovative ideas to pursue in shaping secure, and privacy-conscience, adaptive technologies in forthcoming generation of distributed and networked environments.

title: Optimal Scheduling of Hybrid Pumped Storage Considering Peak-Shaving and Flexibility Enhancement
authors: Zhanxing Xu, Qiang Liu, Yizhou Wang, Haowei Wu, Na Zhong, Feilong Hong, Yang Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The development of wind and photovoltaic power has brought impacts to the safe and stable operation of the power grid. It is urgent to expand flexible power sources to regulate renewable energy. Constructing pumped storage units between two adjacent reservoirs is an effective way to increase flexible power sources. This paper proposes a quantification method for flexibility supply capacity and evaluates the impact of pumped storage transformation on the peak-shaving and flexibility enhancement of cascade hydropower plants based on an optimal scheduling model. The study shows that hybrid pumped storage hydropower plant performs better in smoothing the power grid load fluctuations and reducing the peak-valley difference. It also enhances both the upward and downward supply capacities.

title: Power Coordination Control in Distribution Transformer Areas to Enhance the Integration Capacity of High-Penetration Distributed Photovoltaic
authors: Nanchun Zhang, Ming Wu, Yu Ji, Geng Niu, Rongjun Jin, Liangzhong Yao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In recent years, the rapid growth in the proportion of installed distributed photovoltaic (PV) capacity within distribution transformer areas has led to significant challenges, including reverse power flow and voltage violations. Considering the different time scales of voltage regulation devices and the impact of prediction errors in source-load forecasting, this paper proposes a multi-timescale coordinated power control method. During the day-ahead and intra-day optimization stages, a centralized optimization model is established with the objective of minimizing network loss and PV curtailment, thereby generating pre-control instructions for each voltage regulation device. In the real-time stage, the absolute power instructions for PV output are converted into relative ratio commands through proportional mapping, and a local-centralized two-stage control strategy is employed to mitigate voltage violations caused by random source-load fluctuations. Finally, simulation analysis conducted on a 21node distribution transformer area verifies that the proposed coordinated power control method can effectively improve the overall voltage profile of the area with minimal losses.

title: Lightning Induced Effect on Solar PV Systems Due to Lightning Discharges
authors: Ganga Lokuhettige, Sameera Viswakula, Sankha Nanayakkara, Mahendra Fernando, Vernon Cooray
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: The usage of solar photovoltaic (PV) panels has rapidly increased worldwide, with the increasing demand for green energy. Direct and indirect lightning could damage solar PV systems. Most studies conducted over the past years were either simulations or laboratory experiments. Our study aimed to investigate the voltage and current induced on PV systems due to indirect lightning through a field experiment. We measured the induced voltage and current of two series panels connected to the off-grid solar PV system with simultaneous vertical electric field signatures. Induced voltage was observed on both solar panel output terminals for preliminary breakdown, return stroke, and all other cloud activities. Induced current flows at the return stroke, not at the preliminary breakdown stage or small cloud activities. DC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> terminal induced voltage retains an average time of 170.44±18.99 µs, while DC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> terminal induced voltage lasts for an average of 4.18±0.42 ms. The magnitude of the DC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-</sup> terminal induced voltage is higher compared to DC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> terminal induced voltage, and it exhibits a nonlinear relationship with the vertical electric field, while DC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> terminal induced voltage shows a linear relationship. DC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-</sup> terminal induced voltage implies the nonlinear nature of the semiconductors inside the panel. As the derivative of the vertical electric field is similar to the DC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> induced voltage in shape, it indicates that the metallic parts of the solar panel behave as an antenna. Further research is essential, along with field experiments, to reveal the indirect lightning effect on solar PV systems and to help design effective protection.

title: Evaluating the Use of Biometric Tools for Securing Computer Systems in Congolese Academic Institutions
authors: Othniel Mukena, Robert Makila, Jovita Mateus, Guy-Alain Lusilao Zodi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: This paper explores the use of biometric technologies to improve physical access authentication in academic institutions across the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). In many Congolese universities, campus entry remains largely unsecured, with 88% of surveyed institutions still allowing open access, 10% using student ID cards, and only 2% using biometric tools. This raises major security concerns, including unauthorized entry and potential threats to staff and students. To address this, we propose a fingerprint-based authentication system built using the open-source SourceAFIS library. We analyzed survey data from 60 universities in Kinshasa and Lubumbashi and conducted technology experiments, including the development of a biometric processing pipeline and the simulation of spoofing and replay attacks. Our results reveal that while fingerprint recognition enhances physical access control, it remains vulnerable to certain threats if not protected by additional measures such as encryption and liveness detection. These findings support the integration of secure and ethical biometric solutions to modernize physical access control in Congolese academic settings.

title: Fault-Tolerant Control Strategy for Active Steering in Distributed Drive Electric Vehicles Facing In-Wheel Motor Failure
authors: Jinhao Liang, Faan Wang, Feiyang Tan, Yanyi Feng, Yanbo Lu, Guodong Yin, Jiwei Feng, Jian Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: To improve the stability of distributed drive electric vehicles when single wheel or single side in-wheel motors fails, an active steering fault-tolerant control strategy based on event triggering mechanism is proposed. A fault state observer based on linear matrix inequalities is designed, and a fault-tolerant switching mechanism based on residual evaluation function is established. The distributed model predictive cooperative control strategy based on Pareto optimization theory is adopted to realize the optimal distribution mechanism of fault-tolerant control for vehicle chassis active steering system and yaw moment control system. Based on the integration of Matlab/Simulink and CarSim, the experiment was carried out on the hardware-in-loop platform. The results show that the yaw rate and lateral displacement tracking errors can be reduced by 14.9% and 28.2%, respectively, in the case of constant deviation or variable gain fault of in-wheel motor under double lane change condition with high/low road adhesion coefficient. Therefore, the fault tolerance and stability of distributed drive electric vehicle under the failure of in-wheel motor are realized.

title: The Cost-Effective Frontier: Optimal IMU Selection for UAV Navigation via Q-R-IMU Triad Coupling Analysis
authors: Xianglu Ma, Manhong Shi, Yali Dong, Jin Zhou, Xinglin Du, Jianbing Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This study resolves a paradox in UAV loosely coupled navigation: high-precision IMUs can underperform lower-grade sensors due to misaligned Kalman filter trust mechanisms. Through simulations quantifying IMU accuracy, process noise, and observation noise interactions, we demonstrate that excessive trust in high-precision IMU predictions suppresses GNSS corrections, causing significant drift. Conversely, lower-precision IMUs with balanced Q-R tuning achieve superior cost-effectiveness. Key insights reveal: Q adaptation dominates over IMU-grade selection, conservative R settings disproportionately penalize high-precision IMUs. We establish practical guidelines: High grade IMU for GPS-denied environments (precise Q required), Moderate grade IMU for urban areas (tolerant tuning), and Low grade IMU for open-sky RTK (large Q recommended), redefining selection around Q-R-IMU synergy rather than standalone hardware specs.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Enhancement and Domain Prompt Guidance Based Auxiliary Decision-Making for Differentiated Scenarios in Power Equipment Operation and Maintenance
authors: Xu Jiannan, Zhu Jiazheng, Zhao Ruyi, Zhao Qi, Zhao Baohua, Shi Mengjie
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The operation and maintenance of power equipment is an important part of the construction of the new power system. The transformation of artificial intelligence represented by large language models has provided new opportunities for the digital and intelligent transformation of traditional power equipment operation and maintenance. For two typical business scenarios in the power operation and maintenance field, namely knowledge service and equipment condition evaluation, considering the differences in demand and technical adaptability of different scenarios, a customized technical route for adaptation based on large language models is designed, and a hybrid retrieval enhancement and domain prompt guidance based auxiliary decision-making method for differentiated scenarios in power equipment operation and maintenance is proposed. By constructing a knowledge base for the operation and maintenance of power equipment and a sparse-dense hybrid retrieval strategy, the associated knowledge of queries can be efficiently retrieved and integrated through the large language model to generate precision responses. By incorporating multi-dimensional condition evaluation rules into the prompt, the large language model is guided to conduct logical reasoning of the equipment operation condition, and the complete reasoning process and condition evaluation results are output. Finally, the superiority and effectiveness of the operation and maintenance knowledge service and equipment condition evaluation method proposed in this paper were verified on the power dataset.

title: A Systematic Review of AI-Based Image Processing Techniques for Colon Cancer Diagnosis
authors: Jie Li, Weiwei Goh, N.Z Jhanjhi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Colon cancer remains a major global health challenge, with early and accurate diagnosis being critical for improving patient outcomes. This paper provides a comprehensive review of recent advances in AI-driven biomedical image processing techniques for colon cancer diagnosis. This paper encompasses traditional modalities as well as cutting-edge digital pathology. In this review, the findings indicated the integration of AI has significantly e nhanced image interpretation, automated lesion detection, and enabled robust quantitative analysis, thereby reducing inter-observer variability and supporting more consistent clinical decision-making. Furthermore, the fusion of multimodal data-including histopathology, radiology, and molecular profiles offers a holistic view of disease for precision diagnostics and treatment strategies in clinical settings. Despite these advances, challenges remain in terms of clinical resource limitation, data integration and management, and lightweight model with data fusion. The paper concludes by outlining future research directions, including the development of lightweight AI models, end-to-end diagnostic pipelines, and scalable data fusion frameworks, all of which are poised to transform the landscape of colon cancer diagnosis.

title: Post-Stall Maneuver Attitude Control for Tailless Aerial Vehicle with Thrust Vectoring
authors: Yingyang Wang, Peng Zhang, Yuan Bian, Junqiang Bai, Jin Li, Zihou He
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Tailless layout is one of the best aerodynamic solutions for the next generation fighter jets, with its good aerodynamic efficiency and stealth. However, since the Tailless Aerial Vehicle (TAV) eliminates the flat tail and vertical tail, its post-stall maneuver flight control is a technical challenge. Currently, most literature focuses on the aerodynamic modeling and stability control of TAVs, with relatively little research on flight control problems in special environments and tasks. Therefore, a post-stall maneuver problem of TAV with model perturbations and external disturbances is addressed. Firstly, an uncertain affine rotation model and a TAV non-affine rudder effect model for controller design are established. Then, an expanded state observer (ESO) is used to estimate the model perturbations and external disturbances in a unified way. Finally, a Nonlinear Dynamic Inverse (NDI) controller is innovatively designed based on the backstepping method for the rotational subsystem, and a composite control allocation method considering vector thrust is designed based on the effective set quadratic programming under the limitations of actuator amplitude and bandwidth. The designed control method not only achieves stable attitude control but also has strong robustness, and the simulation results prove the effectiveness and real-time performance of the controller.

title: Utilizing SPAISE3 for Maritime Monitoring over the Indian Ocean and Neighboring Regions
authors: Daichi Hirahara
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: This paper presents the first observation results of SPAISE3, launched in 2024 and equipped with eight antennas and ground-based DBF. The system enables wide-area and simultaneous multi-regional maritime observation, including the Indian Ocean, South China Sea, East China Sea, Red Sea, and the European region. Key findings show enhanced detection performance in congested zones and the potential of sparse array configurations.

title: Counter-Adversarial Learning with Inverse Interactive Multiple Model Kalman Filter
authors: Jiacheng He, Jian Chen, Mingming Bai, Zhenyu Feng, Xuemei Mao, Bei Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of unmanned systems, counter-unmanned systems technologies have received increasing attention, and inverse estimation has emerged as a critical component. To address adversarial scenarios where the defender exhibits multiple maneuvering modes, this paper proposes an inverse interactive multiple model Kalman filter (I-IMM-KF). Theoretically, the proposed algorithm is proven to be unbiased in the mean sense, and its computational complexity is shown to be of the same order as that of the classical IMM-KF. Numerical simulations further validate the stability and fast convergence of the algorithm under maneuver transitions, demonstrating that the proposed method can effectively enhance inverse estimation performance in complex dynamic environments.

title: Hosting Capacity Assessment of Distributed Renewable Energy Resources Integrated into Distribution Networks Via Microgrids
authors: Jian Chen, Youjun Wang, Lulu Du, Qiang Xu, Ming Li, Hao Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Traditional hosting capacity assessment methods predominantly address scenarios in which distributed renewable energy resources (DRES) are directly connected to distribution networks, while largely neglecting the emerging paradigm of integrating DRES via microgrids. To address this, this paper proposes an assessment framework for evaluating the hosting capacity of distribution networks with coupled microgrid integration. A probabilistic model is established to characterize uncertainties in photovoltaic generation, wind power, and loads. A collaborative optimization framework is then formulated, capturing intra-microgrid power balance, renewable curtailment, and multi-level network constraints on power flow, voltage, and current. To enhance computational efficiency, the nonlinear problem is reformulated as a convex program using second-order cone relaxation. The method is validated on a modified IEEE 33-bus system, demonstrating its effectiveness in accurately assessing hosting capacity under microgrid integration scenarios.

title: A Two-Tier Secure Federated Learning Framework with Lightweight Cryptography for Edge-Cloud Collaboration
authors: Shahid Latif, Djamel Djenouri
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: This paper deals with scalability and security for large-scale deployments of Federated Learning (FL) and proposes a two-tier secure FL architecture that incorporates edge servers as intermediate aggregators between clients and the cloud. This hierarchical framework enhances scalability and minimizes cloud communication by utilizing edge-level aggregation. Security is maintained with lightweight cryptographic protocols, including X25519 for key exchange, HKDF with BLAKE2b for key derivation, and ChaCha20-Poly1305 for authenticated encryption, ensuring end-to-end confidentiality and integrity of model updates. An experimental evaluation on the MNIST dataset across three deployment scenarios (ranging from 9 to 100 clients) reveals improvements in model accuracy from 93.90% to 96.04%. Communication overhead to the cloud was reduced by up to 90%, and cryptographic overhead remained under 5.3ms per operation. Additionally, the architecture achieved 100% resistance to model poisoning, 97.8% prevention of gradient leakage, and 100% confidentiality preservation. The proposed approach outperformed existing state-of-the-art methods by a margin of 1.27% to 7.64% and demonstrated a strong balance between performance, security, and communication efficiency in edge-cloud FL environments.

title: Research on the Control Method of DC Microgrid with Multi-Module Pulse Load
authors: Tangan Wang, Yongqi Liu, Tao Lei, Xiaobin Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In recent years, pulsed power systems (PPSs) have been widely deployed in defense and military applications, with most featuring high-power, high-repetition-rate characteristics such as airborne radar systems, pulsed directed-energy weapons (laser/railguns), and electromagnetic catapults. Contemporary finite-capacity standalone power systems, extensively utilized in ground vehicles, naval vessels, and aircraft, face increasingly complex operational demands. The main power supply must simultaneously satisfy conventional loads and high-repetition-rate pulsed power loads while ensuring system stability and power quality-critical technical challenges requiring urgent resolution. This paper proposes a hierarchical control approach for multi-module pulsed load DC microgrids, combining Model Predictive Control (MPC) at the upper layer for coordinated power allocation among generation units and Sliding Mode Control (SMC) at the lower layer to enhance individual module control performance. The DC microgrid architecture integrates a motor-generator set, lithium-ion battery, and supercapacitors as power sources, driving a multi-module pulsed load configuration. Simulation analysis via Simulink validates the feasibility and superior performance of this control strategy in addressing stability challenges and improving dynamic response characteristics.

title: Blockchain Throughput Optimization under Computational Constraints: Bayesian Optimization Study on Acquisition Functions
authors: Yury Yanovich, Ernest Gatiyatullin, Mark Prikhno, Yash Madhwal, Robert Vasilyev, Vladislav Amelin, Andrei Shcherbakov, Alexey Zaytsev
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: The performance of blockchain systems within distributed networks is critically governed by a complex interplay of network and protocol parameters. Fine-tuning these parameters is a promising path to enhanced operational efficiency, though it is hampered by computationally expensive, black-box evaluations that limit experimental scale. This work tackles the challenge of maximizing transaction throughput (TPS) in the Solana network under a strict zero-drop-rate constraint. Building on previous demonstrations of Bayesian Optimization’s (BO) efficacy, we present a comparative analysis of four acquisition functions (AFs)-Upper Confidence Bound (UCB), DYCORS, Expected Improvement (EI), and Thompson Sampling (TS)-for this high-dimensional optimization problem under a limited evaluation budget. Utilizing a simulated blackbox testnet environment to evaluate parameter configurations, our numerical experiments demonstrate that the UCB method is the most efficient strategy, achieving the highest TPS. The study also confirms DYCORS as a valuable, robust subsequent strategy. By rigorously examining the impact of AF choice, this research provides a practical and efficient framework for optimizing blockchain performance, offering valuable insights for enhancing throughput in distributed computing, IoT networks, and adaptive control systems.

title: ΛI-Architecture: A Software Design Model Demonstrated on the Example of an Electrical Equipment Diagnostic System
authors: Pavel V. Matrenin, Alexandra I. Khalyasmaa, Stanislav A. Eroshenko
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: The rapid expansion of digital systems in industrial domains has intensified the need for software architectures that balance strict modularity with engineering pragmatism. This paper introduces the $\Lambda\mathrm{I}$ (Lambda-Integration) architecture - a software design model intended for long-lifecycle engineering systems combining data acquisition, computation, and decision logic. Unlike classical Clean, Hexagonal, or Onion architectures, $\boldsymbol{\Lambda} \mathbf{I}$ enforces a directional dependency flow from low-level I/O components to high-level control logic, while selectively permitting horizontal integration at lower levels through explicit integration gateways. The model supports a gradient application of the dependency inversion principle and defines a dedicated computational layer for physical and mathematical models - a feature critical for domains such as electrical engineering. The $\Lambda\mathrm{I}$ architecture conceptually addresses the problem of interface complexity and provides a structured balance between modularity, testability, and engineering feasibility.

title: Selecting the appropriate Digital Elevation Model (DEM) for flood inundation modelling: Insights from Two Indian Coastal Cities
authors: Vivek Ganesh, Santonu Goswami, Harini Nagendra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Accurate prediction of future coastal inundation is crucial for developing effective adaptation strategies to mitigate loss of life and economic damage. Hydrological models rely on Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) and streamflow data to simulate flood extent and depth. DEMs, derived from satellite data, represent surface terrain in a uniform gridded format, and their accuracy significantly influences flood vulnerability and exposure assessments. Since freely available DEMs vary in resolution, selecting an appropriate dataset is critical for reliable inundation modelling. This study evaluates the effectiveness of six freely available global DEMs—ALOS PALSAR, SRTM, CoastalDEM, CartoDEM, NASADEM, and FABDEM—for flood modelling in two major Indian cities: Mumbai and Chennai. We reconstructed two historic flood events, the August 28–29, 2017 Mumbai flood and the November 16–17, 2015 Chennai flood, using these DEMs. Our analysis indicates that FABDEM performed best in capturing flood depth and extent across both study regions. The findings offer valuable insights into the strengths and limitations of global DEMs for flood modelling applications. By assessing their reliability, this study supports researchers and practitioners in making informed decisions when selecting DEMs for inundation modelling across diverse regions and scenarios.

title: A Cognition-Driven Multi-vehicle Cooperative Decision-Making Approach under Complicated Highways
authors: Jinhao Li, Zehong Ke, Yuning Wang, Junkai Jiang, Shaobing Xu, Jianqiang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Highway is one of the most promising application scenarios for cooperative multi-vehicle planning. Although some current studies have preliminarily achieved vehicle collaboration, two major challenges still exist. Firstly, current decision-making methods rely on manual discretization of planning mode, failing to adapt to the continuous highway scenes and lacking generalization ability. Meanwhile, manual discretization leads to the result that the derived equilibrium states are not optimal. To address the issues, this research refers to human driver intelligence and establish a cognition-driven unified multi-vehicle cooperative decision-making framework towards complicated highway environments. Inspired by human cognition, vehicle driving behaviors are represented by serials of relative areas, and the least action principle is utilized to derive the optimal equilibrium state of the multiple controlled vehicles at each timestep. Then, a collision-free control planning method is designed to generate control commands from the relative area decision outputs. The proposed methods are validated in 35 different scenarios that involve all typical highway components and a long highway scene with continuous traffic flow. Compared with five baselines, our method increases efficiency by 12.4% and safety by 8.3%. In addition, the results show good consistency across various highway scenes, proving better generalization ability. Validation on real vehicle-road-cloud platforms in Suzhou, China also proves the feasibility.

title: Research on Outlier Detection for Retired Batteries Based on Variational Autoencoder
authors: Yuhang Wang, Xiaoming Wang, Jingyi Ni, Wenguang Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the rapid development of electric vehicles, a large number of power batteries face the challenge of post-retirement disposal. Echelon utilization of retired batteries involves matching their residual performance (such as State of Health, SOH) with secondary application requirements to fully exploit their remaining value. However, SOH assessment effectiveness is highly susceptible to the training dataset, making the accuracy and reliability of training data particularly crucial. Typically, training sets consist of hundreds to thousands of battery cells, where outliers inevitably occur due to measurement errors. These outliers can distort the original data distribution and compromise the accuracy of battery data modeling. To address this issue, this paper proposes using Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) to identify outliers, thereby reducing their impact on training models and ultimately improving SOH estimation accuracy.

title: DCAS-EMAdp: Small Space Object Detection with Lightweight DCAS and Directional-Pooling Enhanced EMA
authors: Pakin Nuamnoi, Ratchainant Thammasudjarit, Subhorn Khonthapagdee, Purin Tanirat, Sittiporn Channumsin, Setthanun Thongsuwan
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Small Space Object Detection is a key component of Space Situational Awareness (SSA), which is essential for tracking and detecting fast-moving small space objects under complex environments. A major drawback is that detection models often cannot preserve the structural and contextual details of small or occluded objects. To address this problem, we propose a model named DCAS-EMAdp model, which combines a Dynamic Context-Aware Aggregation Strategy (DCAS) to dynamically expand the receptive field with an Efficient Multi-Scale Attention with Directional Pooling (EMAdp) module to enhance directional feature learning. The model is evaluated using real observational data obtained from the Geo-Informatics and Space Technology Development Agency (GISTDA), captured through ground-based telescope systems for space object monitoring. The experimental results show that DCAS-EMAdp achieves an mAP@50 of 91.4%. Furthermore, evaluations on mAP50@95, Precision, Recall, and F1-score confirm that DCAS-EMAdp has high capabilities in detecting small space object detection and occluded objects, and its performance is sufficient for practical applications in resource-constrained real-time SSA systems.
