title: Automated Cloud-Based InSAR Displacement Mapping Workflow Enhanced by GNSS-Assisted Calibration
authors: Priti Girohi, Ritwek Khosla, Rahul Sharan, Neda Rojhani, Vern Singh Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Land subsidence poses critical risks in coastal cities like Houston, where natural and anthropogenic factors drive complex ground deformation. This study introduces a scalable, cloud-based Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) processing framework that integrates Sentinel-1 data with GNSS observations for enhanced displacement monitoring. Leveraging parallel-asynchronous computing, the system processes 70–80 Single Look Complex (SLC) scenes over 2500 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> in 3–4 hours—significantly outperforming conventional tools requiring over 35 hours. It generates high-precision ortho-displacement products with vertical and horizontal components, while GNSS-based calibration improves line-of-sight (LOS) accuracy, applying 58% and 71% correction for ascending and descending tracks, respectively. The framework supports global-scale subsidence assessment and geohazard monitoring.

title: Decoding of Generalized LDPC Codes Using the BCJR Algorithm
authors: Alexey A. Bandyukov, Andrey A. Metlyakov, Fedor I. Ivanov
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: Generalized low-density parity-check (GLDPC) codes have emerged as a promising class of error-correcting codes that extend the capabilities of traditional LDPC codes by incorporating more powerful component codes. This paper investigates an approach to construct long GLDPC codes using short component codes. In this scheme, the BCJR algorithm is used as a component decoder and integrated into the belief propagation algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate that constructions incorporating quasi-cyclic LDPC codes yield the best performance. Compared to the conventional decoding approach for LDPC codes, the proposed generalized constructions demonstrated better bit and frame error rate performance. This approach is promising for communication systems that require low latency. A comparison is also provided with LDPC codes constructed using the Progressive Edge-Growth (PEG) algorithm.

title: ISAC for AAM: Integrated Sensing and Communication Technology for Advanced Air Mobility
authors: Evangelos Vlachos, Giorgos Alexiou, George Papastefanatos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: This position paper explores how future 6 G Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) technology can enhance U-space services, such as e-registration, geo-awareness, and tactical conflict resolution, for cooperative UAVs flying Beyond Visual Line of Sight (BVLoS) at low altitudes. We investigate two critical scenarios: GNSS failure and network outage, each addressed through dedicated workflow procedures that link relevant U-space services to safety and continuity requirements. By enabling real-time RF sensing, telemetry, and vehicle-tovehicle communication, ISAC provides a scalable foundation for secure UAV integration in fragmented airspace, where traditional systems and current standards fall short.

title: Field study of the soil resistivity near a 110 kV pole site by vertical electrical sounding and geological survey
authors: Rositsa Dimitrova, Milena Ivanova, Georgi Georgiev
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: The study investigates the soil resistivity under actual field conditions in the vicinity of a $\mathbf{1 1 0 ~ k V}$ transmission line tower located near Varna, Bulgaria. Field measurement data were utilized to develop a numerical model of the subsurface using specialized software for processing and interpreting vertical electrical sounding (Wenner method) results. The model was validated through comparison with geological survey data obtained from the same site to evaluate its accuracy and applicability.

title: Impact of Using Off-Chip Memories on Reliability of Edge Computing Systems to Single-Event Upsets
authors: Luiz Henrique Laurini, Leonardo Alexandrino de Melo, Alberto Bosio, Rodrigo Possamai Bastos
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: This work investigated the impact of using either an off-chip or an on-chip non-volatile memory on the reliability of two different RISC-V (reduced instruction set computer V) based edge computing systems operating under 14-MeV neutrons. Radiation testing results suggest the single-event upset (SEU)-induced failure rate of the case-study system with off-chip memory would be around 2.5 times higher than its counterpart with on-chip memory. Additional results of classical RISC based edge computing system running neural networks are also reported.

title: Induction motor modelling for field–oriented control considering the magnetic saturation
authors: Emil Rachev, Vladislav Petrov, Gergana Vacheva, Dimitar Pavlov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: This paper presents an analysis of a lumpedparameter mathematical model of an induction machine, taking into account the effect of magnetic core saturation. Experimental studies were conducted to determine nonlinear dependencies under various supply methods and configurations. The results are compared with data from a distributedparameter finite element model developed in FEMM 3.3. Based on these studies, a lumped-parameter program model was implemented in MATLAB/SIMULINK. Comparison between the simulation and experimental data confirms its validity in both steady-state and transient operating conditions.

title: Reinforcement Learning Based Planning Control of Unmanned Surface Vehicles
authors: Huanran Fu, Kai Zhang, Jielin Zeng, Jie Ren, Baochang Zhu, Yanran Zhang, Yong Liu, Weiwei Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Unmanned surface vehicles (USVs) face significant path planning challenges in dynamic aquatic environments due to wind, waves, and currents. Traditional methods exhibit non-smooth trajectories, high computational costs, and poor adaptability. This paper presents a novel framework that integrates data-driven disturbance compensation with reinforcement learning (RL). A multilayer perceptron (MLP) learns the disturbance-affected USV dynamics, embedded into an RL framework using recurrent proximal policy optimization (RPPO) with a multi-objective reward. Smoothed waypoints guide trajectory planning. The system employs a hierarchical PID controller for motion execution. Trained and validated in Gazebo simulations, the proposed method enables effective trajectory tracking, obstacle avoidance, and safe goal-reaching with smooth paths. This study confirms RL’s feasibility for enhancing USV autonomous

title: On the Correcting Capability of Hard-Decision Error-and-Erasure Iterative Decoding of LDPC Codes for Data Storage
authors: Vladimir Kuzmin, Ilia Chevtaev, Maya Chernaya, Alexey Frolov, Pavel Rybin
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: Modern storage systems such as NAND flash solidstate drives are increasingly exposed to channels where both errors and erasures coexist. Classical Reed-Solomon (RS) codes provide strong error-and-erasure protection but suffer from high decoding complexity and latency, limiting their applicability in high-throughput storage architectures. Low-Density ParityCheck (LDPC) codes, with iterative message-passing decoders, offer near-capacity performance at low complexity and are therefore the preferred solution in practice. While the decoding behavior of LDPC codes has been well studied for pure error or pure erasure channels, the mixed error-and-erasure case has received less attention, despite its direct relevance to storage. In this work, we analyze the potential correction capability of iterative error-and-erasure decoding for LDPC codes under hard-decision channels. Using density evolution, we derive recursion equations for the joint evolution of error and erasure probabilities and establish bounds on the region of correctable error-erasure patterns. The presented results provide theoretical correction bounds that complement existing studies on error-only and erasure-only channels, and offer guidelines for LDPC code and decoder design in storage systems where errors and erasures naturally coexist.

title: Electrified Shipboard Dynamic Positioning System Control Strategy Integrated with Physics Constraints under Harsh Marine Environments
authors: Jiangfan Huang, Yingbing Luo, Sidun Fang, Tao Niu, Guanhong Chen, Ruijin Liao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Aiming at the issues of low accuracy of dynamic positioning (DP) systems under harsh marine environments and the lack of modeling and analysis methods for electrical ship loads. A DP control strategy and corresponding simulation models is proposed. First, mathematical models of DP ships are established and its kinematic and dynamic characteristics under marine environments are analyzed. Then, a DP ship control strategy integrated with physical constraints is proposed. Finally, an electric propulsion system model is established to obtain accurate DP electrical power.

title: Attractive Space Resolution Examination of HVDC Transmission Lines
authors: György Kálecz, István Kiss, Bálint Németh
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: An updated version of the Attractive Space Matrix method created by the authors for lightning attachment modeling of HVDC transmission lines is presented. The effect of the positive DC pole voltage on the attachment properties can be considered using this method. The method has been further developed in order to enable a more accurate simulation of the expected direct strike region into the conductor. This is achieved by changing the resolution of attractive space matrix in order to focus on the attractive space of the positive conductor. With this, the calculation time can be less compared to the original version due to the smaller physical extent of the highlighted, in-depth investigated zone. The results can be used for a more optimized external lightning protection system and the determined shielding failure current range can be highly beneficial for overvoltage protection calculations on the transmission line.

title: Machine Learning for Geospatial Data in the Cloud: A Comprehensive Analysis of Architectures, Challenges, and Next-Generation Solutions
authors: Anu Sai Surya Kumari Bonam, Varanasi Charan Srihaas, Sohan Gandla, Ch. Dhruva Teja Reddy, V. Sai Venkatesh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: The integration of machine learning (ML) with geospatial data in cloud computing environments represents a paradigm shift in spatial analytics, offering unprecedented capabilities for processing petabyte-scale datasets while introducing complex technical and methodological challenges. This paper provides a comprehensive examination of cloud-native geospatial ML systems, analyzing their architectural evolution, domain-specific implementations, persistent bottlenecks, and emerging optimization frameworks. Our meta-analysis of 15 production systems and 43 research initiatives demonstrates 18--35% improvements in agricultural yield predictions and disaster response timelines compared to traditional GIS systems, though critical limitations in real-time processing fidelity and spatial bias mitigation remain unresolved. We propose next-generation solutions, including spatial-aware neural architectures, cloud cost optimization strategies, and hybrid architectures combining serverless computing with edge-based preprocessing. This study synthesizes insights from both industry implementations and academic research to outline a framework for advancing cloud-based geospatial analytics.

title: A general and robust active fire detection method using Sentinel-2 and Landsat shortwave infrared measurements
authors: Lu Gui, Rong Li, Minghui Tao, Zhe Jiang, Lunche Wang, Jun Wang, Jiaxin Huang, Yi Wang, Liangfu Chen, Santo V. Salinas
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate detection of active fires (AF) is crucial for improving estimates of biomass burning emissions and environmental management. Satellite remote sensing at shortwave infrared (SWIR) bands with 10-30m spatial resolution has a great potential in identifying the numerous small active fires missed by fire-monitoring systems using coarse spatial resolution data, but is challenging due to heterogeneous backgrounds and multiple interferences. By combing enhanced threshold method and abundant prior information, we developed a generalized and robust fire detection algorithm using the daytime Sentinel-2 SWIR observations over complex surfaces in China. To discriminate with high reflecting surface targets such as rooftop and solar panels, more thresholds with visible and SWIR bands along with land cover datasets are utilized. Moreover, industrial thermal anomalies are excluded by time series satellite images. Validations of Sentinel-2 AF detection through visual inspection show very low commission rates (<1-3%) over selected regions of the world. Since burnt areas in fire boundaries with higher temperature than backgrounds were taken as AFs, the average omission rates increase to ~3-4%. A maximum omission rate of ~7-8% occurs in African grassland, which has a short burning time. Despite consistent spatial patterns, 1 km MODIS and 375 m VIIRS detections performed in the medium infrared bands missed more than 90% of Sentinel-2 AFs. With the flexible framework, our method also has robust performance in similar Landsat 8/9 SWIR observations. By combing Sentinel-2 2B/2C and Landsat 8/9 observations, our reliable AF detection at fine scales (20-30 m) can provide a significant supplement for the biomass burning emission estimation with a temporal resolution of 2-3 days.

title: Global Assessment of Vegetation Ozone Exposure Using a Remote Sensing-Based Index: A New Potential Reference For Critical Levels and Gross Primary Production Simulations
authors: Peng Zhou, Jieming Chou, Shan Ye, Mengting Sun, Jie Luo, Zhaoxiang Cao, Qian Yao, Hao Zhang, Muhammad Bilal, Li Dan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Ozone pollution suppresses plant photosynthesis and reduces crop yields, yet many global assessments still rely on indicators or models that are difficult to compare across regions. We propose a concise and scalable remote sensing index, called Ozone Vegetation Exposure Intensity ( VEI<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">O<sub>3</sub></sub> ), that combines near-surface ozone concentrations with the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) to characterize the spatiotemporal distribution of vegetation ozone exposure. Using global observations from 2003 to 2019, we find pronounced spatial and seasonal contrasts, with higher exposure in industrialized and densely vegetated regions, particularly during spring and summer in the Northern Hemisphere. VEI<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">O<sub>3</sub></sub> is consistently associated with independent vegetation metrics: regions of higher ozone exposure generally correspond to lower Solar-Induced Chlorophyll Fluorescence (SIF), indicating ozone-induced stress on vegetation activity. In site-level evaluations using the Community Land Model (CLM5.0) and FLUXNET eddy-covariance data, we identify a new potential critical ozone concentration of 42.38 ppb, which yields improved performance over the traditional AOT40 (Accumulated exposure Over a Threshold of 40 ppb) in broad, non-cropland contexts – suggesting it can complement existing ozone exposure indices. VEI<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">O<sub>3</sub></sub> can be operationalized for ozone risk management: for example, by screening hotspots to prioritize field inspections and expand monitoring networks; by serving alongside AOT40 as a metric for evaluating seasonal mitigation plans and issuing alerts during peak growing seasons; and by coupling with land-use and crop distribution data to support emission-control planning and scenario analysis. Key limitations of our current approach include reliance on monthly ozone and NDVI products (with uneven monitoring coverage), a predominantly linear statistical framework that does not capture time lags or nonlinear dose–response behavior, and the absence of explicit stomatal-flux representation. Priorities for future work include controlled experimental validation, integration of VEI<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">O<sub>3</sub></sub> with stomatal flux schemes in land-surface models, expansion of ground observations in data-sparse regions, and testing of alternative vegetation indices with stricter cloud and reflectance screening. VEI<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">O<sub>3</sub></sub> represents a new remote sensing index for detecting vegetation ozone exposure. The critical levels and model-improvement directions inferred here should be treated as potential references that, with further validation and refinement, can help bridge the gap between observations, models, and policy, ultimately providing a reliable remote-sensing-based decision support tool for managing risks to ecosystem productivity and food security.

title: Ultralow-crosstalk Strain and Temperature Sensing with a Hybrid Fabry-Pérot Interferometer Using k- Domain Lock-In Demodulation
authors: Xiaoyang Li, Liuchen Lyu, Weihang Hou, Jinfeng Li, Jiashun Luo, Yongjun Liu, Tao Geng
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: A dual-cavity hybrid Fabry-Pérot interferometer (FPI) sensor composed of an air cavity and a polymer cavity is proposed for low-crosstalk strain and temperature measurements. The device is fabricated at the end face of a strongly coupled seven-core fiber (SSCF), where the inter-core coupling merges light from multiple cores into a common supermode, enabling single-ended retrieval of interferometric spectra. By intentionally designing distinct cavity lengths, the two FPIs exhibit markedly different optical path differences (OPDs), allowing their interference components to be naturally separated in the spatialfrequency domain. A phase-locked demodulation technique is then employed to independently track OPDs variations, thus enabling simultaneous dual-parameter measurement. Experiments demonstrate a strain sensitivity of 6.49 nmμε with only 0.00129 crosstalk in the temperature channel and a temperature sensitivity of -6.62 nm/°C with 0.0882 crosstalk in the strain channel. Leveraging the dual-FPI configuration on the SSCF, the proposed sensor provides a compact and robust approach to ultralow-crosstalk, high-sensitivity strain and temperature sensing.

title: Spatial-Temporal-Spectral Mamba with Sparse Deformable Token Sequence for Enhanced MODIS Time Series Classification
authors: Zack Dewis, Zhengsen Xu, Yimin Zhu, Motasem Alkayid, Mabel Heffring, Lincoln Linlin Xu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Although MODIS time series data are critical for supporting dynamic, large-scale land cover land use classification, it is a challenging task to capture the subtle class signature information due to key MODIS difficulties, e.g., high temporal dimensionality, mixed pixels, and spatial-temporal-spectral coupling effect. This paper presents a novel spatial-temporal-spectral Mamba (STSMamba) with deformable token sequence for enhanced MODIS time series classification, with the following key contributions. First, to disentangle temporal-spectral feature coupling, a temporal grouped stem (TGS) module is designed for initial feature learning. Second, to improve Mamba modeling efficiency and accuracy, a sparse, deformable Mamba sequencing (SDMS) approach is designed, which can reduce the potential information redundancy in Mamba sequence and improve the adaptability and learnability of the Mamba sequencing. Third, based on SDMS, to improve feature learning, a novel spatial-temporal-spectral Mamba architecture is designed, leading to three modules, i.e., a sparse deformable spatial Mamba module (SDSpaM), a sparse deformable spectral Mamba module (SDSpeM), and a sparse deformable temporal Mamba module (SDTM) to explicitly learn key information sources in MODIS. The proposed approach is tested on MODIS time series data in comparison with many state-of-the-art approaches, and the results demonstrate that the proposed approach can achieve higher classification accuracy with reduced computational complexity.

title: ArtCrafter: Text-Image Aligning Artistic Attribute Transfer via Embedding Reframing
authors: Nisha Huang, Kaer Huang, Yifan Pu, Jiangshan Wang, Jie Guo, Yiqiang Yan, Xiu Li, Tong-Yee Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Recent years have witnessed significant advancements in text-guided style transfer, primarily attributed to innovations in diffusion models. These models excel in conditional guidance, utilizing text or images to direct the sampling process. Traditional style transfer focuses on low-level visual features, such as brushstroke textures and color distributions, and appears more like applying an artistic filter to an image. Artistic attribute transfer, however, transcends the limitations of traditional style transfer by achieving the transfer of visual concepts from color and brushstrokes to high level aesthetic attributes such as composition, pose, and key semantic elements, resulting in more natural outcomes. Therefore, we propose an innovative text-to-image artistic attribute transfer framework named ArtCrafter. Specifically, we introduce an attention-based style extraction module, meticulously engineered to capture the subtle artistic attribute elements within an image. This module features a multi-layer architecture that leverages the capabilities of perceiver attention mechanisms to integrate fine-grained information. Additionally, we present a novel text-image aligning augmentation component that adeptly balances control over both modalities, enabling the model to efficiently map image and text embeddings into a shared feature space. We achieve this through attention operations that enable smooth information flow between modalities. Lastly, we incorporate an explicit modulation that seamlessly blends multimodal enhanced embeddings with original embeddings through an embedding reframing design, empowering the model to generate diverse outputs. Extensive experiments demonstrate that ArtCrafter yields impressive results in visual stylization, exhibiting exceptional levels of artistic attribute intensity, controllability, and diversity. The code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/haha-lisa/ArtCrafter</uri>.

title: Hybrid Attribute-Based Access Control Framework for Intelligent Computing in Consumer IIoT
authors: Wahib Jamal Khan, Weifeng Sun, Meshari Huwaytim Alanazi, Muhammad Shahid Anwar, Mueen Uddin, Naqash Younas
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: The protection of consumer and industrial IoT (CIoT/IIoT) systems against modern cyber threats including AI-based attacks needs suitable access control systems. Current access control models fail to provide flexible operation and strong security because they do not support real-time policy changes and multiple data sources. The research establishes HY-ABAC as a hybrid Attribute-Based Access Control system which unites blockchain technology with machine learning algorithms (policy gradient and random forest) to enhance security and operational speed and enable flexible policy administration for IoT systems. The system depends on a random forest classifier for making exact decisions and policy gradient for creating and updating policies in real-time. The system uses a local blockchain to track access transactions through decentralized and transparent and immutable methods which establish trust and defend against unauthorized changes. The proposed model supports the complete integration of sensing technology with communication systems and computing power and control mechanisms for secure intelligent system operation in consumer IoT. Using the ToN-IoT dataset, the model achieves 98% accuracy and processes 25% more transactions per block than Fabric-IoT and 11% more than ABAC-HLFBC. It further reduces policy configuration and verification time compared with Fabric-IoT, ABAC-IoT, ABAC-HLFBC, and DACSB.

title: Affective Touch with Mid-Air Ultrasound: A Psychophysical Comparison with Real Materials
authors: Rika Oya, Ryoya Onishi, Soichiro Matsumura, Zen Somei, Shun Suzuki, Hiroyuki Shinoda, Ryo Kitada
publish: IEEE Transactions on Haptics
abstract: Affective touch has attracted significant interest due to its positive effects on child development and adult well-being. Studies showed that light and slow stroke of soft brush on hairy skin elicits affective sensation by activating C-Tactile fibers. Mid-air haptics, which uses focused ultrasound to create tactile sensations in free space, offers a promising method for eliciting affective changes. However, it remains poorly understood to what extent mid-air haptics can produce the perception similar to a brush stroke on hairy skin. Here, we conducted a psychophysical study comparing the tactile perception of mid-air ultrasound stimulation with that of real materials (sandpaper, aluminum resin, urethane rubber, cloth, and soft brush). Participants rated each stimulation on the dorsum of hand along three affective touch dimensions (pleasantness, surprise, ticklishness) and three discriminative touch dimensions (smoothness, softness, warmness). Univariate analyses revealed that ultrasound stimuli differed from aluminum resin, sandpaper, and urethane rubber in one or more dimensions of discriminative touch. Ultrasound stimulation with 10 Hz amplitude modulation significantly felt more pleasant than sandpaper, while no consistent differences between ultrasound and real textures ratings was observed in surprise and ticklishness. Multivariate analyses showed that ultrasound stimuli with amplitude modulation at 10 Hz and 100 Hz were significantly closer to real textures than unmodulated ultrasound. Questionnaires showed that over half of the participants identified ultrasound stimulation as a brush or cotton. These findings suggest that mid-air haptics can evoke perceptual attributes overlapping with those of real textures, including soft brushes, on hairy skin. Moreover, amplitude modulation may enhance the perceptual resemblance to realistic textures.

title: DirMixE: Harnessing Test Agnostic Long-tail Recognition with Hierarchical Label Vartiations
authors: Zhiyong Yang, Qianqian Xu, Sicong Li, Zitai Wang, Xiaochun Cao, Qingming Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: This paper explores test-agnostic long-tail recognition, a challenging long-tail task where the test label distributions are unknown and arbitrarily imbalanced. We argue that the variation in these distributions can be broken down hierarchically into global and local levels. The global ones reflect a broad range of diversity, while the local ones typically arise from milder changes, often focused on a particular neighbor. Traditional methods predominantly use a Mixture-of-Expert (MoE) approach, targeting a few fixed test label distributions that exhibit substantial global variations. However, the local variations are left unconsidered. To address this issue, we propose a new MoE strategy, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathsf {DirMixE}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, which assigns experts to different Dirichlet meta-distributions of the label distribution, each targeting a specific aspect of local variations. Additionally, the diversity among these Dirichlet meta-distributions inherently captures global variations. This dual-level approach also leads to a more stable objective function, allowing us to sample different test distributions better to quantify the mean and variance of performance outcomes. Building on this idea, we develop a general Latent Skill Finetuning (LSF) framework for parameter-efficient finetuning of foundation models. We provide implementations based on LoRA and Adapter. Theoretically, we derive upper bounds on the generalization error for both standard learning and PEFT. Under mild assumptions, we show that the variance-based regularization helps tighten these bounds. Furthermore, we prove that the covering number of the PEFT hypothesis class scales with the number of trainable parameters. Finally, extensive experiments on CIFAR-10-LT, CIFAR-100-LT, ImageNet-LT, and iNaturalist validate the effectiveness of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathsf {DirMixE}$</tex-math></inline-formula>.

title: Modeling Brain-Heart Interaction: A Review of Mechanistic Dynamical Models
authors: Sara Nour Sadoun, Arnaud Boutin, François Cottin, Taous-Meriem Laleg-Kirati
publish: IEEE Reviews in Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Brain–heart interaction (BHI) is fundamental to autonomic regulation and also shapes perceptual salience, attentional control, decision-making under load, and affective reactivity. Beyond these functions, BHI has been consistently implicated in clinical studies in cardiovascular, neurological, and psychiatric conditions. This reality makes the investigation of bidirectional BHI mechanisms—and the derivation of interpretable biomarkers– - indispensable for cardiovascular, physiological, and neuroscientific research that treats the body as an interoceptive network of interacting organs rather than isolated systems. The growing interest in this perspective has generated a broad spectrum of frameworks, from signal-processing pipelines and computational models to dynamical systems. Building on previous surveys that have thoroughly mapped the field and deepened our understanding, this review offers a complementary perspective centered on mechanistic, physiology-inspired models of dynamical systems. For each model, we identify the physiological subsystem described, clarify core assumptions, and assess strengths and limitations. We then outline the technical perspectives necessary to realize the full potential of these approaches — especially for inferring latent interoceptive quantities that govern directional BHI but are not directly observable, and for integrating explicit brain modeling into these frameworks to better capture the neural mechanisms driving autonomic and cardiovascular dynamics. Mechanistic dynamical modeling has, over decades, deepened our understanding of physiology and pathology and informed the mapping and treatment of diverse conditions. Our objective is to provide a comprehensive account of state-of-the-art dynamical models, delineate methodological directions, and highlight application areas where such models can yield explanatory insight, reliable prediction, and actionable clinical targets.

title: WLRT-DR: Dual-Stage Wavelet Low-Rank Tensor Completion With Deep Networks for Cloud Removal in Satellite Imagery
authors: Yu Zhang, Peng Zhang, Zhangxin Cai, Kai Yu, Feng Wang, Hongjian You, Hairong Tang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Cloud contamination in multi-temporal remote sensing images, particularly due to thick clouds, significantly impacts the accuracy of environmental monitoring tasks. While existing Low-Rank Tensor Completion (LRTC) methods address cloud removal, they struggle with strict multi-temporal correlation requirements and poor generalization due to parameter sensitivity. To overcome these limitations, we propose WLRT-DR, a novel two-stage framework combining Wavelet-domain Low-Rank Tensor Completion with Deep Regularization. First, we introduce discrete wavelet transform (DWT) to decompose multi-temporal imagery into frequency-specific subbands (LL, LH, HL, HH). Empirical analysis reveals distinct low-rank properties in each subband, enabling targeted low-rank processing that better preserves spatial textures and structural continuity compared to unified spatial-domain LRTC. Second, we develop a dual-phase architecture where wavelet-domain LRTC (Stage 1) is synergistically combined with deep network regularization (Stage 2). This hybrid strategy leverages the complementary strengths: wavelet-domain low-rank recovery efficiently reconstructs fundamental spatial features, while pretrained deep networks impose non-linear constraints to enhance spectral fidelity. Comprehensive validation on simulated (Landsat data covering diverse Beijing landscapes) and real-world data demonstrates that WLRT-DR delivers enhanced reconstruction accuracy, robustness to complex spatio-temporal patterns, and improved processing efficiency. The framework provides an effective alternative for cloud reconstruction by integrating traditional tensor completion and deep learning in a novel manner.

title: A Markov Chain Monte Carlo Method for Efficient Finite-Length LDPC Code Design
authors: Ata Tanrıkulu, Mete Yıldırım, Ahmed Hareedy
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes are among the most prominent error-correction schemes in today’s data-driven world. They find application to fortify various modern storage, communication, and computing systems. Protograph-based (PB) LDPC codes offer many degrees of freedom in the code design and enable fast encoding and decoding. In particular, spatially-coupled (SC) and multi-dimensional (MD) circulant-based codes are PB-LDPC codes with excellent performance. Efficient finite-length (FL) algorithms are required in order to effectively exploit the available degrees of freedom offered by SC partitioning, lifting, and MD relocations. In this paper, we propose a novel Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC or MC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) method to perform this FL optimization, addressing the removal of short cycles. While we focus on partitioning and lifting of SC codes, our MC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> approach can effectively work for other procedures and/or other code designs. While iterating, we draw samples from a defined distribution where the probability decreases as the number of short cycles from the previous iteration increases. We analyze our MC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> method theoretically as we prove the invariance of the Markov chain where each state represents a possible partitioning or lifting arrangement, i.e., sample, that has a specific probability. Via our simulations, we then fit the distribution of the number of cycles resulting from a given arrangement on a Gaussian distribution. By analyzing the mean, we derive estimates for cycle counts that are close to the actual counts. Furthermore, we derive the order of the expected number of iterations required by our MC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> approach to reach a local minimum as well as the size of the Markov chain recurrent class through approximating the probability of getting arbitrarily close to the local minimum. Our approach is compatible with code design techniques based on gradient-descent. Experimental results show that our MC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> method generates SC codes with remarkably fewer short cycles and substantial gains in error/erasure-rate performance compared with the current state-of-the-art. Moreover, to reach the same number of cycles, our MC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> method requires orders of magnitude less overall time compared with the available literature methods.

title: Multipath Exploitation-Based 3D Environmental Perception and NLOS Moving Target Reconstruction for Mmwave MIMO Imaging Radar
authors: Zhihao Zhu, Zihan Xu, Jiahui Chen, Shisheng Guo, Guolong Cui, Xiaobo Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Multipath exploitation techniques have attracted considerable attention over the past decade, as they expand the detection coverage of conventional radar systems to Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) areas. However, existing methods rely on fully or partially known reflector surface information to achieve detection and localization of NLOS targets, which poses challenges for practical applications since scene information is often not available a priori. To overcome this issue, we present a multipath exploitation-based millimeter-wave (mmWave) multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) imaging radar framework, which first performs three-dimensional (3D) environmental perception and then transfers the reflector surface parameters to assist NLOS target reconstruction. To implement this process, we explore several key problems and propose corresponding solutions. First of all, we propose a joint multiple linear array beamforming (JMLA-BF)-based imaging algorithm to achieve high-resolution sparse imaging as well as extract weak echoes of NLOS reflector surface. Then, an iteration algorithm is proposed for NLOS building layout recognition and relocation. Meanwhile, we propose an unambiguous direction-of-departure (DoD) and direction-of-arrival (DoA) estimation method for multipath signals from NLOS moving target using colocated MIMO radar. Finally, a path-oriented strategy is introduced to achieve NLOS target localization. Real experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework and solutions in accurate 3D environmental perception and reliable NLOS target reconstruction.

title: False Target Jamming Suppression in Distributed Coherent Aperture Radar
authors: Mengmeng He, Yizhen Jia, Maria Sabrina Greco, Fulvio Gini, Wen-Qin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Distributed coherent aperture radar (DCAR) operating in MIMO mode is vulnerable to self-defense dense false target jamming, which closely resembles the true target signal and is therefore difficult to suppress. To address this challenge, based on the difference between the jamming and the target signal in the frequency modulation slope domain, we designed an algorithm combining biorthogonal Fourier transform (BFT) and echo preprocessing, so that there is a significant difference between the jamming and the target signal in the matched filtering (MF) outputs. First, the BFT analysis is employed to separate the echo components corresponding to up-chirp (UC) and down-chirp (DC) before multi-channel MF. Then, echo preprocessing is performed on the separated echoes using reference signals that have different chirp rates. This causes misalignment in the peaks of jamming after MF and enables discrimination between false and real targets. Finally, to prevent the jamming from obtaining higher gain in the process of coherent integration, time-domain filtering is applied before coherent integration. Experimental simulations validate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method in terms of jamming suppression.

title: A Cosine Network for Image Super-Resolution
authors: Chunwei Tian, Chengyuan Zhang, Bob Zhang, Zhiwu Li, C. L. Philip Chen, David Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Deep convolutional neural networks can use hierarchical information to progressively extract structural information to recover high-quality images. However, preserving the effectiveness of the obtained structural information is important in image super-resolution. In this paper, we propose a cosine network for image super-resolution (CSRNet) by improving a network architecture and optimizing the training strategy. To extract complementary homologous structural information, odd and even heterogeneous blocks are designed to enlarge the architectural differences and improve the performance of image super-resolution. Combining linear and non-linear structural information can overcome the drawback of homologous information and enhance the robustness of the obtained structural information in image super-resolution. Taking into account the local minimum of gradient descent, a cosine annealing mechanism is used to optimize the training procedure by performing warm restarts and adjusting the learning rate. Experimental results illustrate that the proposed CSRNet is competitive with state-of-the-art methods in image super-resolution.

title: A Variable Frequency Technique for EMI and Efficiency Improvements in High-Level Count Flying Capacitor Multilevel Converters
authors: Francesca Giardine, Sahana Krishnan, Yixuan Wu, Logan Horowitz, Robert C. N. Pilawa-Podgurski
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: This work proposes a variable switching frequency scheme for a flying capacitor multilevel (FCML) converter in dc-ac operation to better utilize the output inductor for its rated peak-to-peak current ripple and substantially reduce converter losses over the ac modulation cycle. The proposed technique holds the inductor current ripple constant by leveraging the duty-cycle-dependent inductor current ripple and varies the switching frequency to hold this current ripple constant at its rated design value. Furthermore, this technique can be leveraged to spread conducted electromagnetic interference peaks at both the input and output ports of the inverter. Practical lower switching limits are derived and taken into consideration in developing this approach, and experimental results validate the feasibility in a common microcontroller framework. Hardware results are provided for both 6-level and 8-level FCML inverters and showcase loss reductions and improved electromagnetic interference performance.

title: Optimization of Receiver Coil with Minimized Coupling Coefficient Variation and High Coil Inductance for High Efficiency 2-Stage WPT System of EVs Based on SAE-J2954
authors: Chang-Yeob Chu, Sungryul Huh, Dong-In Lee, Youngseok Lee, Han-Sin Youn, Ki-Bum Park
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In wireless power transfer (WPT) systems based on SAE J2954, a wide variation in the coupling coefficient is inevitable due to misalignment between the transmitter (Tx) and receiver (Rx) coils. Designing a 2-stage system to be robust against this wide variation imposes high maximum electrical stresses on components and leads to significant efficiency variation across the coupling coefficient range. To alleviate this issue, a 3-stage configuration incorporating a post-regulator on the Rx side is typically employed, but this increases the overall system size and cost. Therefore, this article proposes an optimized Rx coil with a simple structure, which exhibits a narrower coupling coefficient range and a higher coil inductance than a conventional Rx coil. This enables a 2-stage system to be realized without a post-regulator, while significantly reducing the maximum stresses on components. In addition, it mitigates the efficiency variation and improves the overall system efficiency. This approach is particularly advantageous for electric vehicles, as it minimizes the design burden of the Rx side. Finally, 3.3 kW 2-stage and 3-stage WPT systems with a conventional Rx coil as well as a 3.3 kW 2-stage WPT system with the optimized Rx coil are implemented to experimentally verify and compare their performances.

title: Probabilistic Shaping and Residual Carrier Modulation for FSO Turbulent Channels
authors: Xiong Deng, Bin Lv, Yunjie Hu, Zhinan Sun, Hao Chen, Wenyuan Ma, Wei Pan, Xihua Zou, Lianshan Yan
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: Free-space optical (FSO) communication has emerged as a promising technology for high-capacity wireless links, offering advantages such as unlicensed spectrum and immunity to electromagnetic interference. However, atmospheric turbulence introduces intensity scintillation and phase distortions that significantly degrade link performance. To address these impairments, we propose a hybrid probabilistic shaping (PS) and residual carrier modulation (RCM) scheme. A residual carrier is generated by slightly adjusting the bias point of the in-phase and quadrature (IQ) modulator, enabling robust phase recovery without additional pilot tones or high-power direct current (DC) components. Concurrently, PS reshapes the symbol probability distribution to mitigate turbulence-induced intensity fluctuations. Numerical and experimental results show that the proposed PS-RCM approach effectively suppresses turbulence-induced impairments. The proposed method provides a power-efficient and hardware-compatible solution for reliable coherent detection in turbulent FSO channels.

title: Decoupled Precoder and Receiver Design for Massive MIMO Multiple LEO Satellite Communication
authors: Ziyu Xiang, Ding Shi, Rui Sun, Feng Zhu, Xiqi Gao, Xiang-Gen Xia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the decoupled designs of precoders and receivers for both downlink (DL) and uplink (UL) in massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) multiple low earth orbit (LEO) satellite communication systems. We first establish the beam based satellite channel model, where the beam matrix is constructed with sampled steering vectors. Then, we propose a decoupled precoder and receiver design for both DL and UL, which allows precoders and receivers to be designed independently at each satellite and user terminal (UT), respectively, with only local statistical channel state information (sCSI). Moreover, with the established beam based channel model, the design of space domain DL precoder and UL receiver can be converted into that of lower-dimensional beam domain vectors with only local sCSI, and the resulting space domain precoder and receiver are beam structured. Furthermore, we propose a low-complexity design and implementation for the beam structured DL precoder and UL receiver by exploiting properties of the beam matrix, significantly reducing the computational complexity. Simulation results validate the proposed approaches.
