title: An Analytical Study on Security and Privacy of Personal Data with Special Reference to Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity
authors: Raphael Olakunle Olaniyi, Kamal Kant Hiran, Ruchi Doshi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) becomes more widely used in vital industries, worries about data privacy, security flaws, and moral dilemmas have increased. Because AI systems are vulnerable to algorithmic bias, data breaches, and adversarial attacks, strong security measures are required. This study examines the relationship between privacy protection, AI security, and regulatory compliance and suggests a thorough security strategy to reduce these risks. The study uses a multifaceted approach that includes threat analysis, literature review, and assessment of current AI security measures. Additionally, to guarantee the legal deployment of AI, compliance with international standards like the GDPR and India's Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDP), 2023, is evaluated. Critical gaps in AI security are highlighted by a review of previous research, such as the lack of standardised regulatory frameworks, difficulties in protecting large-scale AI models, and inadequate resilience against adversarial attacks. According to the findings, AI system security is considerably increased by combining cutting-edge security mechanisms, moral AI principles, and regulatory compliance procedures. The suggested approach demonstrates its efficacy in government, healthcare, and financial applications, hence enhancing AI's robustness and credibility. This study highlights how urgently comprehensive security measures are required to handle the changing terrain of AI dangers and guarantee its moral and responsible application.

title: A Deep Learning Approach for Recognizing Characters in Thai Ancient Inscriptions
authors: Poramin Sunun, Sanya Khruahong
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Ancient Thai inscriptions, such as the Ramkhamhaeng Inscription, recognized by UNESCO, are invaluable cultural artifacts that preserve linguistic and historical knowledge. However, the recognition of these inscriptions poses major challenges due to character erosion, irregular stroke patterns, and the scarcity of annotated datasets. While modern OCR systems are effective for contemporary printed scripts, they fail to handle the complexity of ancient Thai characters. This paper presents a deep learning–based framework for Thai epigraphic character recognition, systematically evaluating three state-of-the-art convolutional backbones—ResNet50, MobileNetV2, and EfficientNet-B0— under a 5-fold cross-validation protocol. Experimental results demonstrate that MobileNetV2 achieves the best overall performance, with an average accuracy of 0.7984, precision of 0.7709, recall of 0.7915, and F1-score of 0.7568, outperforming both ResNet50 and EfficientNet-B0. The findings highlight the effectiveness of lightweight CNN architectures for resource-constrained OCR tasks, particularly in domains where data scarcity and degradation are critical issues. This work provides the first systematic benchmarking of CNN backbones for Thai epigraphic OCR under a controlled evaluation.

title: RF Antenna Design and Integration for Neuromorphic Devices
authors: Romain Alcesilas, Divitha Seetharamdoo, David Sodoyer, Kevin Carpentier, François Danneville, Christophe Loyez
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: Neuromorphic devices are systems made up of artificial neurons that replicate the function of biological neurons by generating spike trains. It offers several advantages for sensing such as the encoding of the measured signal in space and time domains with a very low power consumption. Integrating an antenna with the neuron is however challenging and differs quite significantly from the common scenario where an antenna is first designed for free-space operation, matched to a 50 Ω load and subsequently integrated on complex platforms to fine-tune the radiation properties and input impedance. Indeed, the antenna open-circuit voltage must first be precisely calculated and designed to correspond to the excitation voltage range of the neuron. This paper presents the methodology to design and integrate an antenna to a neuromorphic neuron at a frequency of 20 MHz.

title: Evaluation and Identification of Weak Link in Power System Under Extreme Storm Condition
authors: Haijun Yu, Jinjin Ding, Yuanzhi Li, Lijun Wang, Weibo Yuan, Xunting Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The safe and stable operation of power system is significantly challenged by extreme weather. To effectively reduce the damage caused by extreme weather conditions to the power system, it is essential to identify the weak links in the power system under extreme weather conditions. A vulnerability assessment method is proposed in this paper, which provides a quantifiable decision-making tool for improving the resilience of power system under extreme weather conditions. First, a typical storm scenario is modeled. We introduce a dual-parameter Weibull distribution to describe the variation of line failure probability. Moreover, a piecewise failure probability calculation method is employed to quantify the dynamic impacts of storm conditions on the power system. Then, we use the direct current optimal power flow model (DC-OPF) to calculate the load shedding and power flow changes. Next, to evaluate the operating status of power system, a comprehensive evaluation index system that considers both safety and optimization is proposed. Finally, the non-sequential Monte Carlo method is applied to generate evaluation data, and the analytic hierarchy process (AHP) is utilized to calculate the comprehensive evaluation index to identify the weak links on the system. Simulation results based on the IEEE 39-bus system show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: A Coordinated Control Method of PEM Electrolyzers Based on Dynamic Response to PV Fluctuations
authors: Zhangxi Wu, Bin Li, Jiawei He, Ye Li, Zhongjian Kang, Hongyang Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources (RESs) with hydrogen storage for power generation represents a promising pathway toward a cleaner energy transition. However, the inherent variability and intermittency of renewable energy, particularly photovoltaic (PV) power, pose significant challenges to the reliability and stability of power systems. Based on the dynamic response characteristics of proton exchange membrane electrolyzer (PEMEL), this paper proposes a coordinated control method suitable for photovoltaic fluctuations, and realizes the efficient and stable operation of renewable energy hydrogen production system. Firstly, the operational characteristics of PV systems are analyzed, and a mathematical model describing PV fluctuations is established. Subsequently, the dynamic response characteristics of PEMEL under variable load conditions are thoroughly investigated. The key influencing factors on the dynamic response of the PEMEL are identified and decomposed. Finally, a coordinated control method is then proposed to adapt the fluctuation patterns of PV power. This method effectively balances the slow response dynamics of the PEMEL with the intermittent nature of PV generation, enabling rapid tracking of PV power variations through dynamic adjustment of control parameters.

title: Active Distribution Network Coordination Optimization Strategy Integrating Controllable Loads and Energy Storage Resources
authors: Xiaoming Wang, Wenguang Zhao, Jingyi Ni, Haojie Song, Xinlong Liang, Hongbin Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: To achieve coordinated scheduling of economic efficiency and reliability in active distribution grids, this paper constructs an integrated optimization scheduling model that combines distributed power sources, load aggregators, and energy storage systems. The model introduces a load aggregator response mechanism and constructs a multi-objective optimization model based on two dimensions, operational reliability and economic efficiency, to minimize system volatility indicators and operating costs. To coordinate the conflicting relationships between multiple optimization objectives, the weighted Tchebycheff method is used to convert the multi-objective problem into a single-objective problem, and the differential evolution algorithm is introduced for global optimization. Simulation based on an IEEE-33 node distribution system, designing three typical scenarios to compare and analyze the optimization effects under different resource allocation strategies. The results show that the “source-load-storage” coordinated optimization strategy can effectively smooth the load curve, reduce system operating costs, improve renewable energy utilization and system regulation flexibility, and verify the practicality and robustness of the proposed method.

title: The Node Type of Grid-Forming Converter from the Perspective of Small-Signal Stability of Grid-Following Converters
authors: Guang Hu, Huanhai Xin, Yu Tang, Jiang Dai, Shiyang Li, Yan Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: The coexistence of grid-forming (GFM) and grid-following (GFL) power electronics converters (PECs) in power systems has emerged as an increasing trend. This paper investigates the influence of GFM-PECs on the small-signal stability of GFL-PECs from a circuit-based perspective. An eigen-subsystem is firstly introduced for analyzing the complex multi-machine system. The eigen-subsystem method simplifies the analysis of complex to an equivalent two-machine model with one GFM-PEC and one GFL-PEC, while retaining the dominant stability modes of GFL-PECs. Futhermore, from the circuit viewpoint, it is identified that the GFM-PEC node can be equivalently modeled as a Vθ node in series with an equivalent inductance, which is related to the control dynamics of the GFM-PEC. Matrix analysis is also employed to explore the effect of GFM integration on network connectivity. The results indicate that GFM-PECs with appropriate control enhance network connectivity, thereby improving the small-signal stability of GFL-PECs, vice versa. Simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed analytical approach.

title: Learning Robust and Diverse Humanoid Jumping via Curriculum-Guided Whole-Body Coordination
authors: Bingchen Li, Ruiyu Tan, Songli Yang, Shengwen Tan, Yankun Wang, Xiangyu Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Versatile jumping remains a significant challenge for humanoid robots, as it involves highly dynamic motions such as take-off, aerial flight, and landing impact absorption. These phases demand rapid force generation, precise posture regulation, and dynamic balance under underactuated conditions, placing stringent requirements on control strategies. This paper presents a multi-stage curriculum-assisted reinforcement learning frame-work, where the robot first acquires fundamental jumping skills through reference motion imitation, and subsequently generalizes to multi-target jumping tasks. A tailored reward mechanism promotes whole-body coordination, particularly focusing on torso orientation and arm movements, thereby improving both stability and versatility. Simulation results on the Unitree G1 humanoid robot show that the learned policy enables various jumps, including a forward jump of 1.8 m, lateral jump of 0.8 m, vertical jump of 0.4 m, and aerial yaw rotation of up to 115°. Under 0.1 s impulse perturbations up to 250 N, the robot maintains over 80% success rate in stable landings, indicating strong robustness and task generalization capabilities.

title: A Reconfigurable Converter-Based Centralized Equalization System for Battery Energy Storage Systems
authors: Changhao Li, Wei Lou, Jiaqing Zhang, Shuping Wang, Binbin Zhang, Xianbin Qi
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper presents a novel reconfigurable converter-based equalization system for battery energy storage systems. The proposed system addresses the inefficiencies of conventional fixed-structure DC/DC converters in managing state-of-charge (SOC) imbalances among series-connected battery cells. The key innovation lies in the reconfigurable converter, which dynamically switches between multiple circuit structures with varying voltage gains to accommodate different numbers of unbalanced cells. The proposed system comprises a battery string, a switch array, a reconfigurable converter, SOC and current monitoring circuits, and control unit. The verification results demonstrate that the proposed system significantly improves equalization efficiency and reduces energy loss compared to traditional methods, making it particularly suitable for long series-connected battery strings.

title: Hourly Estimation of Irradiation on Tilted Planes Using Meteorological Data
authors: Luis Fernando Boff, Ana Karen Apolo Peñaloza, Alexandre Balbinot, Roberto Chouhy Leborgne
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: This study focuses on estimatin solar irradiation on inclined surfaces using meteorological data. To achieve this goal, machine learning models including K-Neighbors, SVR, Decision Trees and Random Forests were applied. The predictive performance of the models was evaluated based on metrics such as Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). The Random Forest presented the best performance with an RMSE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$17,34 \text{Wh} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> per hour. It is concluded that predicting solar irradiation using only meteorological data is an effective and viable approach, especially when using well-tuned machine learning models. This research highlights the importance of hyperparameter optimization to improve model accuracy and highlights the potential of these techniques to increase the efficiency of solar energy systems.

title: Weak Link Identification and Security Assessment Method Based on Critical Line
authors: Biao Wang, Xi Ye, Jiawei Hu, Jian Gao, Xinwei Sun, Chuan He
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Weak links are essential in power system operation and monitoring. The accurate and rapid identification of these weak links is crucial for maintaining system stability. This paper introduces a vulnerability index for lines based on their operating characteristics. It further conducts cascading fault simulations to construct a fault propagation matrix, utilizing the complex network theory to calculate the risk index of lines during cascading faults. By weighing the vulnerability and risk indices, a line criticality index is proposed to identify critical lines, facilitating the search for weak links. Additionally, the importance of weak links in thermal and voltage stability is proposed, evaluating their significance under varying security constraints. A simulation using the IEEE-39 Bus system validates the effectiveness of the proposed weak link identification method.

title: Ad-hoc network management using mixed reality hand-tracking manipulation
authors: Kouichi Genda
publish: 2025 IEEE 35th International Telecommunication Networks and Applications Conference (ITNAC)
abstract: Ad-hoc networks are expected for routine applications such as environmental monitoring in agricultural fields, as well as emergency scenarios including temporary connectivity during backbone network disruptions caused by natural disasters. However, because device-to-device connections are unstable due to power supply restrictions and frequent device failure, network operators face a heavy maintenance burden and require advanced management skills. To simplify network management, this study proposes an ad-hoc network management method incorporating mixed reality (MR) technology, enabling sub-optimal visualization and simple gesture manipulation. The network is visualized using virtual objects in the MR environment, where an MR goggle automatically selects an appropriate indicator among multiple options based on the usage environment. In addition, an ad-hoc network is updated by directly manipulating virtual objects in the MR environment with the operator’s gestures, called handtracking. Fundamental operations for network visualization and updating were validated through experiments using HoloLens2 as an MR goggle. The results indicate that MR technology can simplify ad-hoc network management, offering a more intuitive and efficient approach for use in dynamic environments.

title: Analysis of one chain of McEliece system’s modifications
authors: Grigory A. Kabatiansky, Evgenii A. Krouk
publish: 2025 XIХ International Symposium on Problems of Redundancy in Information and Control Systems (Redundancy)
abstract: In this article, we summarize the interim results of cryptanalysis of several recently proposed variants of the classical McEliece cryptosystem. All of these variants share the use of a public linear transformation of a given error vector. Moreover, the public code may not be equivalent to the secret code used for error correction.

title: Analysis of Human Factors Contributing to Outages in the Operation of Electrical Power Systems
authors: Milena Ivanova, Rositsa Dimitrova
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: A frequent cause of disturbances, malfunctions, and accidents in the power grid is human error committed by maintenance and operational personnel. The aim of the present report is to analyze the impact of human errors during the operation of electrical equipment on power losses, the duration of power outages, and the main causes for these errors. Additionally, the annual distribution of human errors, the most common types of errors, and their consequences have been examined. On this basis, the research outlines potential applications of the findings, such as the development of regression models for predictive purposes, optimization of operational processes and shift organization, assessment of the effectiveness of preventive measures, and scenario-based simulations.

title: STN-MRI: A Spatial Transformer Network-Based Pipeline for ROI-Aware Brain MRI Preprocessing and Alignment
authors: Vyshnavi Ramineni, Faizaan Fazal Khan, Goo-Rak Kwon
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Accurate analysis of brain MRI is essential for early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s. However, variability in brain orientation and structure often leads to misalignment of critical regions of interest (ROIs), limiting the performance of automated classifiers. Traditional preprocessing methods, such as affine registration, are rigid and detached from the learning process. To address this, we propose STN-MRI, an end-to-end deep learning framework that integrates a Spatial Transformer Network (STN) as a learnable preprocessing module. The STN predicts affine transformations that align anatomical structures, producing ROI-focused inputs for a CNN classifier. We evaluate our approach on T1-weighted sagittal slices from the ADNI dataset and compare it to a baseline ResNet-18 model. STN-MRI improves classification accuracy from 84.7% to 89.6% and achieves higher F1-scores across all classes. Grad-Cam visualizations further confirm enhanced attention to disease-relevant regions. These results demonstrate the value of task-driven spatial normalization for robust and interpretable brain MRI classification.

title: The Impact of Allocating Weights and Biases in SRAM Parity Checking Areas on the Soft Error Reliability of CNN Inference Models
authors: J. Gava, L. Laurini, R. Possamai Bastos, F. Moraes, R. Reis, L. Ost
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: This paper promotes a novel semi-automated compiler-based technique that allocates CNN weights and bias to SRAM parity checking areas. Radiation results suggest that it is possible to reduce critical SDC events by up to 90%.

title: Operating Principle and Experimental Study of Hybrid Commutation Converter Valve
authors: Weihan Hao, Jinchuan Guo, Guanglin Yu, Yongwen Chen, Yanhua Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In response to the national “dual carbon” strategy, the development of a new power system centered on renewable energy has become a critical objective. Ultra-high voltage direct current (UHVDC) transmission is an essential solution for large-scale renewable energy integration and longdistance power delivery, yet it faces significant challenges such as commutation failure in conventional line-commutated converters (LCC). To address these limitations, the Hybrid Commutated Converter (HCC), based on fully controllable Integrated Gate-Commutated Thyristors (IGCTs), has been proposed as an innovative alternative. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the engineering application of the HCC technology in the Lingbao Converter Station retrofit project, including valve topology design, IGCT selection, and full-scale operational testing. A dedicated experimental platform was constructed to conduct key tests such as maximum continuous triggering, protective turn-on under fault conditions (BOD), and transient overload operation. The results demonstrate that the HCC converter valve achieves reliable turn-off, exhibits strong self-protection capabilities, and ensures stable operation under extreme conditions, confirming its potential for large-scale deployment in future UHVDC projects.

title: Efficient Dynamic Zoned Capacitor Voltage Balancing Algorithm for MMC with Full-Bridge and Half-Bridge Hybrid-Submodules
authors: Hongying Peng, Qing Mu, Xin Zhou, Li Peng, Xing Zhang, Chongming Leng
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Modular multilevel converter with full-bridge and half-bridge hybrid-submodules (SM-Hybrid-MMC) is gradually being applied in flexible DC transmission projects due to its economic efficiency and fault-tolerant capabilities. Balancing the capacitor voltages of submodules within the same converter arm is fundamental for the normal operation of MMC. The exist dynamic layered sorting approach enhances computational performance substantially without compromising the control effectiveness achieved by conventional capacitor voltage balancing algorithms. However, these algorithms are only applicable to half-bridge submodule MMC (HBSM-MMC). This paper proposes an efficient dynamic zoned capacitor voltage balancing algorithm for MMC with full-bridge and half-bridge hybrid-submodules, which significantly reduces the number of submodules involved in the sorting process. The proposed algorithm substantially decreases the quantity of submodules requiring active sorting operations. Implementation and verification are conducted using the ADPSS-EMT, with validation performed through an LCC-MMC HVDC test case. Simulation results demonstrate that the novel approach maintains equivalent voltage regulation performance to conventional methods while achieving two key advantages: (1) consistent capacitor voltage stability across all valve arm submodules; (2) the acceleration ratio reaching <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1104{\%}$</tex> compared to conventional sorting algorithms.

title: Mobile-Based Location-Based Service (LBS) Attendance System for Operational Efficiency and Environmental Sustainability in Automotive Services
authors: I Gusti Ayu Agung Mas Aristamy, Ni Made Astini Rahayu, I Gede Adnyana, I Kadek Budi Sandika, Ni Luh Wiwik Sri Rahayu Ginantra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: In response to the operational inefficiencies and sustainability challenges posed by conventional attendance tracking methods, this study presents the design and evaluation of a mobile-based attendance system utilizing Location-Based Services (LBS). Targeted at small and medium-sized automotive service enterprises, the system leverages Android smartphones, GPS technology, and Firebase cloud services to facilitate geofenced check-in/check-out processes within a 100-meter radius. The development follows the Waterfall model, encompassing requirement analysis, system design, implementation, testing, and deployment. Functional validation was conducted through black-box testing, while user satisfaction was assessed using the User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ). Results demonstrate that the system performs reliably and offers an excellent user experience across most dimensions, with significant contributions to operational transparency and environmental sustainability. Scalability testing with up to 50 concurrent users showed stable system behavior and response times under 1.5 seconds, confirming its readiness for SME-scale environments. The findings suggest that mobile LBS solutions are a viable, low-cost alternative to biometric systems in industrial contexts, and offer a foundation for future development in intelligent attendance and workforce monitoring systems.

title: Studying Joint Evolution of Urban Growth, Land Surface Temperature, and Nightlight
authors: Mohammed Hatim Khan, Sudipan Saha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: The growth of cities is leading to the absorption of nearby regions to accommodate the increasing population. This is causing significant urban land use changes and a rise in land surface temperatures (LST) and night-time light. This study focuses on Kolkata, India, a major city with a large population and a rich historical background, to capture the impact of this urban expansion. By applying clustering techniques, we categorize the region surrounding Kolkata into distinct zones based on LST time-series and night-time light time series. Additionally, we employ an unsupervised deep transfer learning-based change detection method to identify urban changes over the past few years. The results of this analysis reveal that new urban development is predominantly occurring at the city’s periphery, gradually converting more land into built-up areas. This transformation is bringing a larger portion of the region under warmer LST zones, highlighting the effects of urbanization on local climate conditions. By understanding these patterns, we can better grasp the implications of urban growth on environmental and thermal dynamics, which is important for sustainable city planning in rapidly developing urban areas like Kolkata.

title: Thai Tune: Enhancing Communication for Deaf through Technological Integration
authors: Ramita Deeprom, Kittipich Aiumbhornsin, Burit Sihabut, Thanapon Noraset, Pawitra Liamruk
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: Deaf individuals in Thailand face communication barriers, particularly in mastering written Thai, due to a lack of tailored tools for vocabulary and grammar improvement. This project addresses these challenges by developing a mobile app that enhances Thai language proficiency, facilitating communication between Deaf and hearing individuals. Utilizing NLP and intuitive design, the app features synonym suggestions, sentence restructuring, and mood adjustments to improve clarity. Motivated by the goal of social inclusion, Thai Tune aims to bridge the communication gap, empowering Deaf individuals and fostering inclusivity in social and professional contexts.

title: Towards AI-Driven Water Quality Assessment: A Computer Vision and Machine Learning Approach
authors: Khang Nguyen, Warut Pannakkong, Tanatorn Tanantong, Nuttapong Sanglerdsinlapachai
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Access to clean water is a critical global challenge, particularly in developing countries where rapid industrialization contributes to wastewater pollution. Traditional water quality assessment methods rely on laboratory analysis and machinery, which are costly, time-consuming, and not feasible for all laboratories. This study proposes a Water Quality Assessment approach that leverages computer vision and machine learning to evaluate water transparency and contamination. The assessment utilizes digital image analysis and deep learning frameworks such as YoloV11 to detect wastewater samples and extract key parameters such as HSV and RGB color spaces. Extracted data is then trained with various Machine Learning models, and the results are compared with standard laboratory measurements to validate accuracy and reliability. The proposed solution aims to complement existing testing methods, making Water Quality Assessment to be more accessible for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

title: Agentic AI for Severity Extraction in Clinical Notes: Enhancing Disease Diagnosis Beyond Rule-Based and Traditional ML Models
authors: Lino Murali, Aleena Thankachan, Daleesha M Viswanathan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: The accurate interpretation of symptom severity in clinical information extraction is critical for timely and informed disease diagnosis and treatment planning. Traditional natural language processing (NLP) models often struggle with contextual understanding and domain-specific nuances in clinical text. Transformer-based pretrained models such as BioMedNER and BioClinicalBERT accurately extract entity mentions such as symptoms, disease names, treatments, and drug names efficiently. Despite growing advancements in clinical NLP, current models fail to capture contextual severity terms associated with the symptoms, which are crucial for accurate diagnosis. This paper proposes an Agentic AI framework designed to improve severity extraction by leveraging advanced large language models (LLMs) in a structured, multi-step reasoning process. The pipeline supports modular and interpretable architecture, which enables cross-model evaluation and fine-grained t esting, a nd a reusable workflow. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T$</tex> he <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p$</tex> roposed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$f$</tex> ramework <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$w$</tex> as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$e$</tex> valuated on the MTSamples dataset, comparing the performance of Granite and Llama models against an established biomedical NER model. Experiments demonstrate that the agentic framework with Granite and Llama significantly outperforms existing models in accurately identifying and extracting disease severity cues from unstructured clinical narratives. The results highlight the potential of Agentic AI in clinical NLP, offering a more robust solution for real-world healthcare applications.

title: AI Text Analytics for Identifying Trends in IT Job Demands
authors: Jaruwan Suraseing, Kanyanut Homsapaya
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Global labor markets are changing because of the rapid adoption of artificial intelligence (AI), which is replacing regular activities and opening up new opportunities. The need for strong technical and analytical abilities is growing as more businesses incorporate AI into business operations, especially in areas such as machine learning, deep learning, natural language processing, cloud computing, and AI ethics. Determining the most in-demand AI talents requires finding discrepancies between the supply of workers and employer demands, and highlighting reskilling and upskilling goals. To this end, we applied AI-driven text analytics to job advertisements, labor market information, and industry reports. The results highlight the urgent need for workforce solutions by exposing serious mismatches in domains including deep learning, natural language processing, and responsible AI. This report presents a framework for creating flexible policies that improve workforce preparedness in an AI-driven economy, thereby providing evidence-based insights for decision-makers in government, education, and business.

title: Comprehensive Credit Risk Evaluation in Supply Chain Enterprises using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Gunasekar Thangarasu, Kayalvizhi Subramanian, Nattar Kannan, Carmel Mary Belinda M J, Saravanan Muthaiyah, Thein Oak Kyaw Zaw
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Supply chain finance management has emerged as a viable solution for addressing the latest financial challenges that mostly faced by the small and medium-sized manufacturing enterprises (SME). Relevant to this, credit risk assessment poses a critical concern in the supply chain financing in which currently follow traditional models often fall short in accurately. Recent research has explored the potential of utilizing machine learning methods to predict credit risk in the supply chain enterprises. However, the consensus on the most suitable approach for credit risk assessment in the manufacturing sector remains indefinable. This study mainly focuses on small and medium-sized manufacturing enterprises and goals to grow a credit risk evaluation system by selecting relevant risk evaluation indicators such as financial and non-financial tailored to their specific characteristics. The sample data from Malaysia's stock market, surrounding SMEs from 2018 to 2023, has been analyzed consuming SVM and Gradient boosting machine learning algorithms to measure corporate credit risk. The appraisal results are extra analyzed using a partial requirement plot method to visually identify significant indicators. The answers reveal that an active credit risk evaluation system for supply chain finance in manufacturing SMEs should consider the financing companies' outline and asset status, the outline of core companies in the supply chain, and the general operation of the supply chains. The request of a Gradient boosting algorithm enhances the accuracy of credit risk assessment in manufacturing supply chain finance. Given the diverse impacts of dissimilar indicators on the evaluation results, supply chain enterprises and financial facility institutions should grow customized plans based on specific circumstances.

title: Semantic-Aware Channel Access for Virtual Power Plants Considering Jamming Attacks
authors: Chengrong Lin, Bo Hu, Changzheng Shao, Kaigui Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: A public wireless communication network enables virtual power plants (VPPs) to manage massive demand-side resources, but it also exposes them to jamming attacks. Existing anti-jamming channel access methods primarily aim to maximize network throughput. However, they fail to balance the distinct communication requirements of VPPs and other users. This is because of the non-equivalence between throughput maximization and a VPP's regulation capacity. To address this issue, this article proposes a semantic-aware channel access method for VPPs, where channel access decisions are made based on information semantics rather than throughput. First, the communication requirements of the VPP and other users are analytically modeled. Then, the channel access problem is formulated as a game. It is proven that the resulting game is a potential game with at least one Nash equilibrium. Finally, a distributed channel access algorithm is proposed to find this equilibrium-representing the VPP's regulation capacity under jamming attacks. Four jamming modes (fixed, sweep, dynamic sweep, and random jamming) are analyzed in case studies. Results validate the effectiveness of the proposed semantic-aware channel access method.

title: Research on Power Grid Data Storage Fault Prediction Technology Based on LightGBM
authors: Huabing Zhang, Yingyao Zhou, Jinge Zhang, Jing Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the development of the big data era and the in-depth advancement of enterprise digital transformation, the data storage scale and complexity of the power grid cloud data center have increased significantly, which has brought huge challenges to the reliability of hardware storage devices and the operation and maintenance work. The prediction of power grid data storage faults is helpful for timely replacing potentially faulty hardware devices and migrating important data in advance, which is of great significance for the protection of power grid data security. Modern data storage generally adopts SMART (Self-Monitoring, Analysis and Reporting Technology) technology to monitor the internal working state of data storage and issue warnings for existing problems. However, the judgment of data storage faults by SMART technology is limited by the experience settings of the manufacturers, and it is unable to predict possible future faults. This paper proposes a power grid data storage fault prediction technology based on LightGBM, constructs a fault prediction system and conducts testing and verification. The test results show that this technology has high accuracy and effectiveness in predicting data storage faults.

title: A Novel Hierarchical Optimal Scheduling and Control Method Based on Prediction–Tracking–Correction for Advanced Distribution Systems
authors: Tianqin Mao, Shouxiang Wang, Qianyu Zhao, Dongli Jia, Zhaoying Ren
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the large-scale integration of renewable energy sources and emerging loads, the prediction errors and uncertainties in both generation and consumption can lead to significant deviations between the actual and expected operating states of distribution systems. These deviations may hinder the achievement of anticipated economic performance. To enhance the economic efficiency and operational flexibility of the system, this paper proposes a predictive - tracking - correction hierarchical optimization scheduling control method. In the day-ahead stage, a data-driven forecasting method based on long short-term memory (LSTM) neural networks is developed. With the objective of minimizing total operating cost, an optimization model is established and solved using the adaptive particle swarm optimization (APSO) algorithm to obtain the day-ahead unit output schedule combination. During the intraday stage, model predictive control (MPC) is adopted to correct the day-ahead economic scheduling plan, thereby addressing the impact of prediction errors and operational uncertainties on the system. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through case-study simulations.

title: Online Mtpa for Synrm Drives Considering Magnetic Saturation With Rls-Based Commissioning and Smc Current Control
authors: Paulo H. A. S. e Silva, Gustavo X. Prestes, William K. Moreira, Emmanuel A. de Moura, H. Pinheiro, Rodrigo P. Vieira
publish: 2025 17th Seminar on Power Electronics and Control (SEPOC)
abstract: This work proposes an online MTPA strategy for SynRM drives, combining parameter estimation via Recursive Least Squares (RLS) during commissioning and optimization of the MTPA dq currents using the Brent algorithm. The approach accounts for motor nonlinearities, such as magnetic and crosssaturation, and employs current control based on Sliding Mode Control (SMC) to ensure robustness against parametric variations. The methodology is validated in a discrete-time simulation environment for a 2.2 kW motor, and the results are compared with the classical MTPA technique. The main contributions include automated commissioning and efficient control with high robustness.

title: Examining Intelligent Tutoring Systems and Their AI Underpinnings in the Design of the Future of Learning
authors: Boufaida Soundes Oumaima, Benmachiche Abdemadjid, Maatallah Majda, Redjimi Mounira, Makhlouf Derdour
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Advanced Systems (ICNAS)
abstract: This Intelligent tutoring systems (ITS), which generate scalable, adaptive, and individualized learning, have recently become one of the most promising areas of artificial intelligence in learning. This survey identifies promising ITS architectures, such as AutoTutor, DeepTutor, ELM-ART, Wayang Outpost, and DeMINT and discusses their underlying technologies, pedagogies, and learning impacts. We propose the need for ongoing scrutiny to recognize challenges in the field, including content authoring costs, occurring scalability across disciplines and languages, privacy and security of students, and potential bias and learners' autonomy. We suggest various aspects of development to improve the challenges and limitations of ITS, including: the consideration of pedagogical and ethical issues in the adoption of large language models (LLMs), the exclusion of cultural factors in development and use, the need for explainable AI, and design which excludes and is inclusive to neurodiverse and marginalized learners. This work has acknowledged the nature of interdisciplinary context, with this work suggesting a clear need for collaboration to ensure that future ITS are pedagogically sound, technologically enhanced, ethical, and caters for diverse learners.

title: Electric Field Optimization of Basin Insulator in 550 kV Gas Insulated Switchgear Using Functionally Graded Insulation Structure
authors: Guobao Zhang, Lan Sun, Jianlin Li, Hengyang Zhao, Lei Zhang, Wenhu Han, Weimin Huang, Hao Li, Wendong Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: In gas-insulated switchgear (GIS), basin-type insulators are prone to partial discharge and surface breakdown (flashover) due to uneven electric field distribution, threatening the reliability of GIS devices and electric power system. While traditional geometric optimization methods exhibit limited effectiveness and structural complexity, functionally graded materials (FGM) offer a novel approach for electric field optimization. This paper proposes permittivity gradient design method for 550 kV GIS basin insulators with FGM structure, based on the topology optimization. The goal is to improve electric field uniformity of both convex and concave surface of the basin insulator. Results demonstrates significant improvements in FGM insulators: the maximum electric field strength on the convex surface decreases from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 3. 2 4 ~ k V} / \mathbf{m m}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$11.50 \text{kV} / \text{mm}$</tex> (13.14 % reduction), while the concave surface field strength drops from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15.42 \text{kV} / \text{mm}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$11.50 \text{kV} / \text{mm}$</tex> (25.42 % reduction). Moreover, both surfaces meet the engineering limits of electric field strength on the surface of GIS (less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12 \text{kV} / \text{mm}$</tex>). This study validates the effectiveness of topological optimization in functionally graded insulation design, providing an innovative solution for enhancing insulation performance in high-voltage power GIS equipment.

title: A Risk-Guided Deep Reinforcement Learning Framework for Collision-Free Navigation in Narrow Environments
authors: Shaojie Jian, Changyun Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Navigating robots safely in narrow, mapless environments while avoiding collisions with transported goods presents a significant challenge. To address this, we propose a novel framework that integrates deep reinforcement learning (DRL) with a Risk Prevention mechanism. The framework comprises two key modules: a Risk Perception module assessing potential hazards in the environment, and a Risk Adjustment module, designed to accelerate learning and guide the robot towards safer paths. Both simulation and real-world experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, demonstrating improvements in both safety and efficiency.

title: An Interactive Visualization System for Historical and Forecast Weather Data in Sugarcane Fields
authors: Sukanya Chansamorn, Auttanit Wongjak, Wichaya Somgiat, Yotsapat Ruangpaisarn
publish: 2025 22nd International Joint Conference on Computer Science and Software Engineering (JCSSE)
abstract: The objective of this research is to develop a weather data visualization system for sugarcane plantations using heatmap-based color classification. The system integrates both historical and forecast weather information, enabling users to assess spatial variations in weather patterns across plantation areas. This capability facilitates more informed decision-making and enhances management efficiency in sugarcane cultivation. The system is designed to allow users to specify the date and geographic zone of interest for weather data visualization. It also includes functionality to configure or modify the maximum rainfall threshold, which affects the color intensity displayed in the heatmap. Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio serves as the system’s primary database, and development was conducted using Microsoft Visual Studio Code. System testing demonstrated that the implementation meets its intended objectives. User evaluations further affirmed that the system is practical and supports effective monitoring of weather conditions in sugarcane plantations using heatmap-based visualization.

title: Virtual Reality as a Tool for Mechanical Workshop Training in TVET Institutions
authors: M Khairul Shaleh Asari, Norhaida Mohd Suaib, Mohd Nazif M Baharuddin, Mohd Haffis Abd Razak
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Consumer Technology (ISCT)
abstract: This paper explores the integration of Virtual Reality (VR) technology into mechanical workshop training within Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) institutions, with a focus on IKM Johor Bahru. VR technology offers an immersive, interactive environment that addresses the limitations of traditional training methods, such as safety risks, high costs, and the inability to simulate complex scenarios. The study highlights the benefits of VR, including enhanced learning outcomes, increased safety, and greater student engagement. It also discusses the challenges related to VR implementation, such as hardware limitations, software compatibility, financial constraints, and resistance to change from educators and students. Strategies to overcome these challenges are proposed, including technical solutions, phased implementation, and stakeholder engagement. The findings suggest that VR technology significantly improves the quality and effectiveness of mechanical workshop training, making it a valuable tool for TVET institutions.

title: AI in Satellite Image Processing and Earth Observation-A Systematic Review of Methods, Applications, and Challenges
authors: Karthikeya Jayaram Shettigar, Prathamesh Shetty, Sambram Hedge, Rahul Koti, H. Harshavardhan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Next-Gen Technologies of Artificial Intelligence and Geoscience Remote Sensing (EarthSense)
abstract: Recent advances in satellite technology have ushered a new era of Earth observation by providing an unmatched level of high-fidelity information that captures intricate details concerning our world's natural and urban landscapes. This vast data set provides a global perspective that is essential to the study of dynamic processes, such as climate change, urbanization, deforestation, and natural disasters. However, the large extent and complex character of raw satellite imagery limits its applicability, since such data sets require high-end processing streams that transform pixel-level data into practical research outcomes for industry, policy, and academic professionals. This present systematic review will examine the integration of artificial intelligence (AI), with particular emphasis on deep learning techniques, into satellite image processing workflows. Our analysis encompasses a wide range of methodologies that optimize feature extraction, enhance classification accuracy, and enable the analysis of complex spatial and temporal remote sensing data patterns. We evaluate both on-board processing solutions designed to minimize data transfer loads and facilitate real-time decision-making, and ground-based processing techniques that enable more computationally demanding algorithms. Furthermore, this review addresses upcoming trends in edge computing, energy optimization, and super-resolution approaches that attempt to mitigate inherent hardware constraints and functional limitations. By incorporating current research trends, pinpointing key challenges like data heterogeneity and processing delay, and sketching out possible guidelines for future development, this article is a comprehensive resource for researchers and practitioners striving to leverage the broad applications of artificial intelligence to augment Earth observations and informed decision-making.

title: Multilingual Lie Detection via Emotion and Multimodal Cues
authors: Tao Guo, Changhe Xiao, Yiming Kan, Zhiang Zhang, Yaxin Zheng, Humaira Ashraf
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: This project presents a multilingual lie detection framework that integrates three behavioral modalities-text, audio, and visual-to identify deception using deep learning and multimodal fusion techniques. The system extracts linguistic cues using mBERT, acoustic features using Librosa, and facial emotion distributions using DeepFace. These features are synchronized and fused to train a binary classifier. Experimental results on a controlled video interview dataset demonstrate that the fusion model outperforms all unimodal baselines, achieving 88.2% accuracy. Feature importance analysis reveals that hedging phrases, tonal fluctuations, and micro-expressions are highly indicative of deceptive behavior. The proposed framework highlights the potential of artificial intelligence in crosscultural behavioral analysis and remote deception detection.

title: Attitude Control of Quadrotor UAV Based on Parallel LADRC
authors: Leiping Xi, Yin Lv, Xijun Gao, Xiaoguang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: To address the issues of nonlinearity and strong coupling in the flight control of quadrotor Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), a parallel Linear Active Disturbance Rejection Control (LADRC)-based attitude controller is designed. For the nonlinearity problem the LADRC algorithm is employed to linearize the nonlinear Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC) from a frequency-domain perspective, making the parameters more interpretable and easier to tune. For the coupling problem, a parallel design approach for the LADRC controller is adopted between the controlled output and the virtual control input, achieving decoupled control of the quadrotor UAV's attitude. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits excellent control performance.

title: Reliability Assessment of Power Conversion System Considering Lifetime Damage of Key Components
authors: Xingrui Zhang, Lucheng Hong, Yuan Gao, Ai Du, Minghe Wu, Jie Gu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: Battery energy storage system (BESS) plays a positive role in mitigating the output fluctuations of renewable energy and ensuring the safe and stable operation of power systems. However, participation in distribution network optimization and regulation can accelerate the aging of critical components in BESS, thereby reducing its reliability. Existing studies on BESS reliability have primarily focused on the impact of battery degradation on system reliability, while neglecting the impact of lifetime damage of the power conversion system (PCS) and its key components. To address this gap, this paper proposes a PCS reliability assessment method that considers the lifetime damage of its critical components. First, a thermoelectric coupling model is employed to convert the BESS mission profile into a thermal load profile for the components. Then, the lifetime damage of each component is calculated by applying a high-fidelity physical lifetime model and Miner's rule. Subsequently, the lifetime distribution of each component is obtained through Monte-Carlo simulation. Finally, an accurate device-level reliability assessment is achieved by integrating these component-level results based on the system's electrical topology. The simulation results indicate that providing reactive power support significantly reduces the lifespan of both IGBTs and capacitors within the PCS, which in turn affects its overall reliability.

authors: Zhigang Wang, Wenke Li, Ning Lv, Yu Zheng, Xinbiao Li, Chenyi Liu
