title: Distributed Time-Varying Optimization of Networked Heterogeneous Systems
authors: Chengxin Xian, Yu Zhao, Guanghui Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: This paper addresses the fully distributed time-varying optimization (DTVO) problem for networked heterogeneous systems, where each agent only has access to its own local time-varying cost function. Most existing distributed optimization studies focus on time-invariant objective functions and homogeneous agent dynamics, which cannot meet the requirements of dynamic optimization tasks in practical scenarios with diverse agent characteristics. To tackle this challenge, a fully DTVO algorithm is proposed by integrating output regulation techniques and adaptive parameter methods. This algorithm enables the outputs of networked heterogeneous systems to asymptotically converge to the optimal trajectory without relying on any global network information (such as topology structure or node quantity). Compared with existing DTVO studies, the proposed algorithm makes two key improvements: first, it expands the scope of agent dynamics from simple homogeneous models to more general heterogeneous dynamical equations, enhancing practical applicability; second, the introduction of adaptive dynamic gains eliminates the need for pre-known network global information, realizing a truly fully distributed control framework. Finally, simulation experiments on a multi-UAV system with heterogeneous dynamics verify that the algorithm can effectively solve time-varying optimization tasks, demonstrating its theoretical validity and engineering practicality.

title: Movable Antenna-Enhanced Near-Field Beamforming: Impact of Antenna Position Errors
authors: Nianbing Su, Weidong Mei, Xin Wei, Zhi Chen, Boyu Ning
publish: 2025 International Conference on Future Communications and Networks (FCN)
abstract: Due to practically finite accuracy of antenna positioning, position errors in movable antenna (MA) arrays can affect its capability to perform flexible beamforming. To characterize their effects, this paper analyzes the performance of MA-enhanced flexible beamforming in two typical scenarios of beamforming, namely, beam nulling and multi-beam forming towards multiple directions in the near field. In particular, we aim to derive the worst-case sum beam gain towards these directions in the presence of antenna position errors given an optimal beamforming design. To tackle the intricate near-field steering vectors, we introduce Taylor expansion to approximate the near-field beam gain in each direction. By this means, we show that the worst-case sum beam gain in the beam nulling scenario can be derived by solving a quadratically constrained quadratic programming (QCQP) problem, for which the semidefinite relaxation (SDR) technique is applied. While in the multi-beam forming scenario, we derive the worst-case sum beam gain in closed-form, revealing several key factors affecting the performance degradation by antenna position errors. Numerical results validate the efficacy of our analytical results.

title: An ISO-certified high-dose γ-ray irradiation facility with applications for space technology
authors: X. Li, T. Azzouni, J. Jeschke, P. Müller-Buschbaum, A. Röhrmoser, L. V. Spanier, V. Hutanu
publish: 2024 24th European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Components and Systems (RADECS)
abstract: A high-dose gamma-irradiation facility has been developed for irradiation experiments in the spent fuel elements (SFE) at the research reactor FRM II. The irradiation is performed underwater. The process is certified to ISO-9001:2015. The typical γ dose rate ranges from 0.05 kGy/h up to 100 kGy/h, depending on the cooling time of the fuel elements. The decay of the γ dose rate and its axial profile in a total length of 70 cm in the active fuel zone are investigated using PMMA dosimeters. The energy spectrum and its temporal change in SFE are analyzed. Very low neutron flux (<3000 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-2</sup>s<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>) in SFEs is determined via activation of gold. Organic solar cells containing the donor:acceptor bulk-heterojunction PBDB-T-2F:BTP-eC9 are irradiated with different doses at 5 kGy, 10 kGy, and 15 kGy to investigate the degradation mechanisms according to the ESCC specification. The results show significant and complex changes in the material's structure, absorbance properties, and solar cell performance.

title: Development of a Vision-Transformer Based Web Platform for Bean Leaf Disease Detection
authors: Taurai George Rebanowako, Kevin Moyo, Daniel Tendenedzai, Aspinas Tigere, Dzinaishe Mpini, Tinomuda Mzikamwi, Noreen Sarai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Trends in Networks and Computer Communications (ETNCC)
abstract: Sugar beans is a vital crop for global food security, yet its productivity is threatened by diseases such as angular leaf spot and bean rust. Early detection is critical in improving crop yield, but farmers often lack access to expert diagnosis. This study leverages advances in artificial intelligence (AI) to develop an automated Vision Transformer (ViT)-based system for bean disease detection using bean leaves. A pre-trained ViT model (google/vit-base-patch16-224-in21k) on the Makerere AI Lab Bean Disease Dataset was fine-tuned, achieving state-of-the-art performance with 99.25 % accuracy, 99.26 % precision, 99.25 % recall, and 99.25 % F1 score. Unlike prior works that focused solely on model accuracy, this research bridges the gap between lab performance and real-world application by deploying the model via a web platform. The platform was evaluated by farmers and scored highly on usability (4.8/5) and usefulness <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(4.6 / 5)$</tex> but revealed challenges in scalability <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(3.8 / 5)$</tex> due to internet connectivity constraints. Key limitations include the model's specificity to bean leaves and dependence on high quality images. Future work should expand disease coverage, optimise for offline use, and explore lightweight edge computing solutions.

title: Multi-Parameter Identification Method for Wide-Frequency Oscillation in New Power System
authors: Yudun Li, Zheng Xu, Chen Fan, Na Li, Kongming Sun, Deling Fan
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Wide-frequency measurement technology and its associated devices can effectively overcome the limitations of Wide-Area Measurement System (WAMS), facilitating real-time monitoring of wide-frequency oscillations. Nevertheless, practical implementations indicate that equipment produced by different manufacturers, owing to disparities in oscillation monitoring algorithms and strategies, is susceptible to false alarms when the grid operating environment undergoes changes, which has an impact on power grid dispatch operations.To tackle this problem, this paper proposes a multi-parameter identification approach for grid wide-frequency oscillations. Based on wide-frequency measurement data, a comparative analysis of multiple parameters can effectively eliminate false alarms caused by external interference or equipment measurement anomalies. This approach overcomes the drawbacks of single monitoring targets' inability to adapt to complex and dynamic operating environments, thereby substantially enhancing the accuracy of oscillation monitoring alarms. It can offer support for the safe operation monitoring and dispatch control of new power systems.

title: Decomposition Method for Medium- and Long-Term Trading Electricity of Renewable Energy Based on Lagrange-Soft Actor Critic
authors: Yiqian Sun, Jun Zhao, Yuehui Huang, Guoqing Li, Siyang Liu, Dagui Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the increasing proportion of renewable energy power generation and participation in market trading, due to its randomness and volatility, the current decomposition method for medium- and long-term trading electricity based on the electricity balance and verification is difficult to apply to the power systems with high-proportion renewable energy. In this paper, a decomposition method for Medium- and Longterm trading electricity of renewable energy based on Lagrange-Soft Actor Critic is proposed. First, from the construction of the long-term output curves for the renewable energy, the coordination optimization decomposition for the trading electricity, and multi-scenario simulation calculation, a coordination optimization method for medium- and long-term trading electricity is put forward to deal with the randomness and volatility of the renewable energy. Then, with the goal of promoting the accommodation of high-proportion renewable energy, an optimization decomposition model of medium- and long-term trading electricity for the renewable energy based on Lagrange-Soft Actor Critic is established.Finally, case studies are conducted by actual data of a provincial power grid in China. The results show that The proposed method achieves significant computational acceleration while maintaining prescribed accuracy requirements, demonstrating superior efficiency for practical power system applications.

title: Indet-Yolo: an Optimized Yolo-Based Framework for Accurate Insulator Defect Detection
authors: Zhiwei Zou, Wei Sun, Weihao Shi, Rujia Qiu, Lu Xing, Yunan Jin
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: Insulator defect detection plays a crucial role in ensuring the stability and reliability of power transmission systems. However, traditional detection methods often suffer from inefficiencies and limited robustness in complex environments. To address these challenges, we propose InDetYOLO, an optimized YOLOv11-based framework that enhances detection accuracy for insulator defects. Specifically, we introduce three novel modules: (1) the Adaptive Fusion Feature Enhancement Module, which strengthens the backbone's feature extraction capability; (2) the Dynamic Scale-aware Feature Pyramid Network, which incorporates Channel Attention, Selective Feature Fusion, and Dynamic Sampling to enhance multi-scale feature; (3) the Efficient Unified Convolutional Detection Head, which reduces parameter redundancy while maintaining high detection accuracy. Experimental results on a self-constructed insulator defect dataset demonstrate that InDet-YOLO exhibits superior detection accuracy with low computational cost compared to other methods. In particular, InDet-YOLO achieves an mAP50 improvement of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 4 \%}$</tex> over the baseline YOLOv11n model with 1.1 fewer GFLOPs, making it an efficient solution for practical insulator defect detection.

title: A Robust Co-Design Method for Ensuring Stability in Observer-Integrated Microgrids Under Sensor Attacks
authors: Sen Tan, Peilin Xie, Juan C. Vasquez, Baoze Wei
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: The growing prevalence of cyber-threats poses significant security concerns for microgrid (MG) operations, creating an urgent need for effective attack mitigation technologies. Traditional model-based techniques, which combine observers with resilient control, offer potential solutions. However, the introduction of observers transforms the MG into an observer-integrated MG (OIMG), whose performance and stability can be affected not only by cyber-attacks but also by the observers themselves. Despite this, current resilient control strategies often overlook the impact of observer characteristics in the control design process, potentially reducing overall mitigation effectiveness. To overcome this limitation, this paper introduces a novel control design methodology that simultaneously accounts for MG dynamics and observer interactions. The proposed approach ensures stability and rapid response of OIMGs under cyber-attack scenarios by jointly designing the controller and observer. The stability and robustness of the method are rigorously analyzed through theoretical evaluations, and its effectiveness is further demonstrated via numerical simulations in MATLAB and PLECS.

title: A Multiple Switching Processing Method for Electromagnetic Transient Simulation
authors: Minghui Su, Yixuan Peng, Bingtao Wei, Haijun Tang, Lu Gao, Fucun Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: This paper proposes a multiple switching processing method for electromagnetic transient simulation, which, compared with the combination of the classical backward Euler method and interpolation, has a simpler process, smaller numerical oscillations, higher computational accuracy, facilitates theoretical analysis of stability. It is suitable for structure-preserving algorithms, and helps to carry out the research on structure-preserving algorithms for high-precision and strong-stability electromagnetic transient simulation in the future.

title: Attention-Driven Transformer Architectures for 1D Thyroid Disease Classification
authors: Balagi V, Murali Prasanth M, Vinora
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Instrumentation, Control, and Computing (PICC)
abstract: Thyroid disease classification from high-dimensional data is challenged by complex feature interactions. Using the UCI Thyroid Disease Dataset, we preprocess data via standardization and reshaping into (samples, 21, 1) for three 1D transformer models. The 1D Convolutional Transformer Encoder combines Conv1D for local feature extraction with pre-normalized transformer blocks, achieving 97.53 % accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0874 \pm 0.0227$</tex> test loss). The Reformer (Memory-Efficient Transformer) leverages reversible blocks and split tensor processing for memory efficiency, attaining 97.88 % accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0805 \pm 0.0445$</tex> test loss). The Standard Transformer Encoder with Post-Normalization employs multi-head self-attention and sinusoidal positional encoding, yielding 97.53 % accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0850 \pm 0.0248$</tex> test loss). Evaluated through 5-fold cross-validation, the Reformer outperforms, advancing memory-efficient attention mechanisms for robust 1D medical classification.

title: A Collaborative Virtual Reality Platform for Medical 3D Data Interaction and Training
authors: Mohamed Amine Guerroudji, Samir Benbelkacem, Kahina Amara, Leila Boudine, Samya Taright, Nadia Zenati, Fatima-Zohra Touia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Advanced Systems (ICNAS)
abstract: The main goal of our project was to provide a distributed and cooperative mini-platform allowing users to share a 3D scene on several supports, with configurations different (head-sets, computers, etc.). From an application point of view, we plan to use the mini-platform in question in order to allow doctors to cooperate and make a diagnosis on a pathology (described in virtual reality environment). Thus, each doctor can be provided with a support dedicated for visualization and can share 3D data on the pathology to be treated. As a result, we were interested on the one hand in the realization of a communication architecture distributed, cooperative integrating a set of modules constituting the information system. On the other hand, to design an ergonomic, user-oriented representation of the different dedicated 3D interfaces.

title: Find My Meow: A Platform for Locating Lost Cats
authors: Jindaporn Sookying, Kulisara Wiangin, Paruj Ratanaworabhan
publish: 2025 29th International Computer Science and Engineering Conference (ICSEC)
abstract: Find My Meow" is a centralized web application developed to address the challenges cat owners in Thailand face when searching for lost cats or seeking adoptive homes for stray cats. Traditional methods rely heavily on fragmented efforts across various social media platforms, resulting in inefficiencies, duplicated posts, and difficulty in collecting and managing comprehensive data. This platform offers a streamlined solution by serving as an all-in-one hub where users can report lost cats, share information about found cats and connect with potential adopters.By integrating advanced artificial intelligence technologies including object detection, and image similarity search, users can upload photos of lost cats, and the system will identify similar cats to aid the search. The platform also incorporates features such as location-based search filters, post editing and updates, and automated email notifications to enhance user experience and increase the chances of successful outcomes.With its user-friendly interface and comprehensive functionality, Find My Meow enhances the efficiency of locating lost cats and facilitating successful adoptions through streamlined features and intelligent search capabilities.

title: Parallel Restoration of Transmission System Based on Breadth-First Search Assisted Partitioning and Skeleton Path Selection
authors: Dai Cui, Zhaowei Ling, Guangyu Zhu, Meishan Zhang, Yang Liu, Gengfeng Li, Yiheng Bian
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of renewable energy and multiple types of electronic equipment in the power system, it is Challenging to cope with complex outages caused by extreme weather. In order to improve the resilience of the power system to cope with large-scale outages caused by extreme weather, and to accelerate the fast and reliable restoration of power supply after an outage, this paper proposed a two-stage recovery method. Firstly, a partitioning scheme based on Breadth-first search (BFS) is established to accelerate the power restoration, then a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP)-based restoration scheme is formulated to achieve the lowest cost recovery path selection. Verify with numerical examples, the case has significantly improved the recovery efficiency.

title: Bayesian Curriculum Learning for Semi-Supervised Remote Sensing Image Classification
authors: Xuanyu Zhang, Jie Geng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Unmanned Systems (ICUS)
abstract: Semi-supervised learning (SSL) offers a practical paradigm for remote sensing image classification, where labeled data is scarce and expensive. Nevertheless, the effectiveness of this approach is fundamentally limited by the presence of noisy pseudo-labels and rigid training curricula. To overcome these challenges, we design a Bayesian Curriculum Learning (BCL) framework customized for remote sensing data analysis. Specifically, we estimate epistemic uncertainty via Monte Carlo Dropout and apply a Dirichlet Process Gaussian Mixture Model to jointly cluster samples in the loss–uncertainty space. This enables dynamic partitioning of data into confident, ambiguous, and noisy subsets. Each subset is then processed with a curriculum-guided strategy: label sharpening, temperature-controlled Mixup, and subspace projection, respectively. Experiments on multiple benchmarks show that BCL consistently improves performance and training stability under limited supervision.

title: The Study of New Characteristics of Hysteresis Current Control for Parallel Inverters
authors: Honglin Zhou, Jingbo Liu, Xiaotian Wu, Chuan Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Power System Technology (PowerCon)
abstract: As power ratings exceed 10 MW, wind turbine power converters increasingly adopt parallel configurations of smaller modular converters. However, direct parallel operation can lead to several challenges, including power quality degradation, common-mode voltage (CMV) issues, electromagnetic interference (EMI), and mechanical vibrations. Although phase-shifted PWM carrier techniques can mitigate these issues, they require fast synchronization among modules, which compromises system reliability and increases cost, thus limiting their suitability for modular designs. This paper presents, for the first time, the observation that hysteresis current control enables the inverter currents of parallel branches to naturally evolve into an interleaved state without the need for explicit synchronization. This self-interleaving behavior significantly simplifies system design and enhances reliability, as it eliminates the need for additional control algorithms or inter-module communication. Moreover, this phenomenon leads to a notable reduction in total harmonic distortion (THD) of the grid current, thereby allowing a reduction in the capacitance of the grid filter. This, in turn, reduces both system cost and physical footprint. Through system modeling and analysis, the underlying mechanism of self-interleaving is investigated. It is shown that the phenomenon arises from two key factors: the physical feedback of common-mode voltage and inherent system delay. Experimental results from a megawatt-scale prototype validate the stability and reliability of the self-interleaving operation, demonstrating its potential for application in high-power wind energy conversion systems.

title: Synthesis of Isotropic Impedance Plane
authors: T.Yu. Privalova, Yu.V. Yukhanov
publish: 2025 IEEE Radio and Antenna Days of the Indian Ocean (RADIO)
abstract: The two-dimensional synthesis problem for an isotropic impedance structure with a positive resistor based on a given nonmirror reflection of a homogeneous incident wave is solved. The values of the maximum achievable amplitudes of the scattering diagram lobes in the given directions are obtained. The results of calculations are given. The analysis problem is solved by the method of integral equations.

title: Reinforcement Strategy for Distribution Networks with Distributed Generation under Typhoon Disasters
authors: Qirui Shen, Chenwei Gao, Yuxiong Huang, Fujia Han, Ji Qiao, Zhen Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: The safety of power systems is an important guarantee for the development of modern society. Typhoon disasters can easily cause large-scale line failures in distribution networks, so it is crucial to formulate scientific reinforcement plans. This paper proposes a reinforcement strategy for distribution networks with distributed generation in response to typhoon disasters. First, a line vulnerability model is established by simulating typhoon scenarios to calculate the failure probability of distribution network lines under different wind speeds. Second, an optimal power flow model that considers network reconfiguration is constructed to evaluate the load loss of the system under each fault scenario. Third, the importance of each line is ranked based on its load loss contribution, and a reinforcement strategy is formulated accordingly. The simulation results based on the improved IEEE 123 node system show that the proposed method can effectively improve the typhoon resistance of distribution networks.

title: Assessing Urban Emergency Response Based on Historical Ambulance Calls: A Case Study in Brazil
authors: Elivelton Rangel, Daniel G. Costa, Maycon L. M. Peixoto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference (ISC2)
abstract: The increasing need for efficient emergency response in urban areas has led to the integration of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and data-driven approaches to optimize resource allocation and reduce response times. This paper presents a new methodology for assessing emergency response in urban areas, taking historical ambulance call data as input. By utilizing geospatial analytics, we convert raw emergency data into enriched geospatial information, enabling the identification of spatial and temporal patterns in emergency incidents. For that, through the integration of tools such as PostGIS, Nominatim, and GeoPandas, it is possible to visualize hotspots and calculate Estimated Time of Arrival (ETA) across different regions, providing actionable insights for optimizing emergency services. This proposed approach was evaluated in the Federal District of Brazil, demonstrating how emergency mapping-planning can contribute to urban management and mobility improvements.

title: Analyzing the Impact of Phase-Locked Loops on Voltage Support Grid Code from Grid-Following Inverter-Based Resources Under Fault Conditions
authors: Pedro Henrique de Morais Martins, Felipe Vigolvino Lopes, Luciano Sales Barros, Karcius Marcelus Colaço Dantas
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This paper evaluates the influence of different Phase-Locked Loops (PLLs) on the fault response of a grid-following (GFL) Inverter-Based Resource (IBR), focusing on the grid code requirements set by the Brazilian Transmission System Operator (TSO). According to this code, voltage support is required through reactive power injection or absorption based on the voltage magnitude at the point of common coupling (PCC). The analyzed IBR represents a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ M V A}$</tex> wind power plant with 50 full-converter wind turbines, each rated at 2 MVA. The Synchronous Reference Frame (SRF) PLL, the Quadrature Signal Generator-based Second-Order Generalized Integrator (QSG-SOGI) PLL and the Multiple SRF (MSRF) are evaluated under interconnection transmission line faults. Results show that PLLs can induce significant instabilities during faults, potentially compromising grid code performance.

title: Reinforcement Learning to Reduce Papr in Communication Systems
authors: Bianca S. de C. da Silva, Luiz A. M. Pereira, Luciano L. Mendes
publish: 2025 Workshop on Communication Networks and Power Systems (WCNPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach for Peak-to-Average Power Ratio (PAPR) reduction in Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) systems using the Q-Learning algorithm, a model-free Reinforcement Learning (RL) technique. Despite its simplicity, the proposed method achieves significant improvements in PAPR performance in contrast to traditional techniques in the literature. The Complementary Cumulative Distribution Function (CCDF) results confirm that Q-Learning provides lower peak values over the entire distribution. Additionally, Bit Error Rate (BER) analysis is carried out under an Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN) channel, showing only a slight degradation due to the reduced spectral efficiency introduced by pilot subcarriers. These findings highlight the potential of RL-based strategies, even in their basic forms, to outperform traditional signal processing techniques and pave the way for the integration of more advanced machine learning methods in next-generation communication systems.

title: Lightning Observatory in Rzeszów including a new system for lightning current measurement mounted on a 220 m high residential skyscraper
authors: Grzegorz Masłowski, Grzegorz Karnas, Kamil Filik
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Lightning Protection (XVIII SIPDA)
abstract: The aim of this paper is to present the improvements and new measurement possibilities introduced at the Lightning Observatory in Rzeszów, including the latest installation on a skyscraper made in March 2025, which enables lightning current recording. The observatory reached full operational capacity in 2013 after few years of configuration and testing of individual components. Its initial configuration consisted of GPS synchronized with electric field antennas and high-speed video registration. In 2019 a new mobile Lightning Registration Station was lunched and added an antenna for orthogonal magnetic field measurements. In 2024 thunderstorm season the high speed camera was equipped with an omnidirectional optical system made in accordance with our design which enabled monitoring of the entire area around the lightning observatory. The mirror calibration allowed photogrammetry of lightning channel. The last significant extension of the station's measurement capabilities was made this year and consisted of installing a system for measuring lightning current on a nearby skyscraper, currently being the highest residential building in Poland, which is situated 1.5 km away from our stationary observatory. Research at our lightning observatory has so far focused on analyzing and modeling the development of various stages of downward lightning and intracloud lightning, and in the upcoming thunderstorm season the behavior and parameters of upward lightning will also be registered.

title: Lithium Batteries Scrap - A Valuable Raw Material For Recycling Or An Environmental Threat For EU
authors: Nikolai Vitkov
publish: 2025 17th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference - Energetics and Efficiency (BulEF)
abstract: In the last decade, the production and use of lithium batteries has increased dramatically worldwide. Increased demand for lithium batteries is forecast in the future mainly due to EV and BESS. Europe’s ambitions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions using renewables requires large-scale electricity storage systems. The heart of electric vehicles is the lithium battery.The implementation of the Green Deal is impossible without huge quantities of lithium batteries. This implies that within a decade, Europe will see huge flows of scrap lithium batteries that will have to be managed. Whether the huge quantities of scrap will prove to be a valuable raw material for the production of new lithium batteries or will become an environmental threat to Europe remains to be seen.

title: Research on Cross-Regional Negative Reserve Market Clearing Model Considering the Regulation Capability of External Power
authors: Chunying Shi, Lizi Zhang, Bo Jie, Jumpei Baba
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Power Systems and Electrical Technology (PSET)
abstract: As the proportion of new energy sources in the power system continues to increase, the regulation resources under the system are becoming increasingly scarce, and the regulation capacity of external power is often ignored in the past models of electricity market. In order to explore the regulation value of external power through market-oriented means and determine the negative reserve capacity provided by external power required by the system the next day, the cross-regional negative reserve market clearing model considering the regulation capability of external power and variety of regulatory resources within the region is designed. The model takes the minimum cost of the system as the objective function, and simulates a typical week with high net load peak-to-valley difference and difficult power system regulation. It verifies that by considering the regulation capacity of external power, the total cost of the system can be reduced, the number of starts and stops of thermal power units can be reduced, and more new energy can be absorbed, which is conducive to the safe, economical and eco-friendly operation of the system.

title: Synthesis of Nano Sensing Film of Stannic Oxide and use of Split IDT for SAW Gas Sensor for Dichloromethane Gas Detection
authors: Rupesh Kumar, Deenbandhu Sharma, Nirupama Mandal
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: This Paper discusses the improved performance of the split electrode IDT-based SAW DCM gas sensor over the conventionally used bidirectional type IDT-based SAW DCM gas sensor. The S<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> sensing film was synthesised, characterised (SEM, TEM, XRD, and elemental mapping), and subsequently deposited onto the fabricated IDTs. Electrical characterisation, like V–I plot and impedance measurement of the fabricated device, is also carried out. Characterisation results confirm the particle size of nano sensing material to be 161nm. So, this proposed work is primarily focused on the design, simulation, fabrication feasibility, and characterisation of a SAW gas sensor using S<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> sensing film and a split-IDT configuration for dichloromethane (DCM) detection. Split IDTs based sensor causes more shift in frequency, i.e., sensitivity is increased. Also, optimisation of the thickness of sensing film for maximum shift in frequency of SAW sensor for detection of volatile Dichloromethane (DCM), CH<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>Cl<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>, an organic gas, using split electrode IDTs has been done. Sensor response has been analysed using three piezoelectric materials, namely Lithium Niobate (L<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</sub>N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">b</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>), Lithium Tantalate (L<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</sub>T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>) and Zinc Oxide (Z<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sub>O). Maximum change in frequency is observed for Lithium Niobate because of its high electroacoustic coupling coefficient and SAWvelocity compared to other materials. COMSOL Multiphysics has been used to simulate and optimise the sensing layer thickness. Sensor is designed for the Eigen frequency of 872MHz and simulated Eigen frequency is 933.55MHz, 866.12MHz and 594.72MHz for L<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</sub>N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">b</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>, L<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</sub>T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> and Z<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sub>O respectively at 0.5μmthickness of sensing layer. Thickness of the sensing layer is varied from 0.2μm to 1.2μm and the maximum shift in frequency is 2693.455Hz for Lithium Niobate at the thickness of 1.1μm. The designed sensor is also exposed to various concentrations of gas from 20ppm to 220ppm, and a corresponding linear shift in frequency is observed. Therefore, the proposed SAW gas sensor is not only modelled but also experimentally validated in terms of Material level (S<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> synthesis and characterisation) and Device level (Fabrication of IDTs and electrical characterisation using probe station and a digital multimeter).

title: A Dual-Branch Deep Learning Approach for Passive Sonar Underwater Target Classification
authors: Qiong Yang, Junxian Dong, Ying Li, Chengkai Tang
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Underwater target recognition faces significant challenges due to complex noise interference, which results in signal attenuation and distortion during propagation. These factors lead to blurred features and increased intraclass variance, ultimately degrading recognition performance. To overcome these challenges, the proposed model incorporates the GAM attention mechanism, the Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN), and a dual-channel structure, where each component is designed to mitigate noise interference, capture nonlinear feature relationships, and exploit multi-feature complementarity, respectively. The model processes various types of underwater acoustic features through two independent network channels and fuses the outputs from both channels for final classification. This architecture fully exploits the complementarity of different features, thereby enhancing the model’s target recognition capability in low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) environments. To validate the model’s effectiveness, multiple experiments were conducted, and its performance was compared with existing methods under low SNR conditions. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed dual-channel model achieves superior recognition accuracy.

title: An LDO With 4.8-NA Quiescent Current and Improved Transient Response Within a 50-MA Load Current Range
authors: Zaitian Yang, Qiujin Chen, Dixian Zhao, Shaowei Zhen, Mo Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Low-power systems, such as IoT devices, require low- dropout regulators (LDOs) featuring 1) minimized quiescent current (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${I_{\mathrm{Q}}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>) to extend battery usage time, 2) high stability over a wide load range, and 3) fast transient response. This paper presents an LDO fulfilling these requirements through a variable capacitance tracking zero compensation (VCTZC) scheme. Meanwhile, it extends the bandwidth in heavy-load conditions, reducing the output voltage overshoot under a step-down transient response. Furthermore, via an adaptive biasing scheme, it retains transient enhancement while reduces <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${I_{\mathrm{Q}}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> at the steady state. Designed with a 65-nm CMOS process, the proposed LDO consumes a 4.8-nA <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${I_{\mathrm{Q}}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> and provides a maximum 50-mA load current. The output undershoot is 204mV when the load current transitions from 5 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula> A to 50mA with a 2-ns edge time.

title: Obstacle-Avoidance and Anti-Swing Trajectory Planning for Aerial Transportation Systems With Double-Pendulum Swing Effects
authors: Yu-Chun Li, Chong-Xiao Shi, Yi-Ming Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article studies the trajectory planning problem for aerial transportation systems. Current research mainly focuses on the trajectory planning for quadrotor and single-pendulum aerial transportation systems. However, how to generate an effective trajectory for aerial transportation systems with double-pendulum swing effects remains a problem to be solved. To address this problem, a novel trajectory planning approach for the double-pendulum aerial transportation systems that incorporate obstacle-avoidance and swing suppression is designed. First, the corresponding constraints for generating the obstacle-avoidance trajectory are constructed by integrating the physical structure and nonlinear dynamics of the double-pendulum aerial transportation systems. Based on these constraints, the obstacle-avoidance trajectory is generated via mathematical programming techniques. Further, an anti-swing term is added to the trajectory to compensate for the swing-induced energy from the hook and payload during obstacle-avoidance, which ensures both obstacle-avoidance and swing suppression. Through Lyapunov analysis, it is proven that the position of the quadrotor asymptotically converges to the target point, and the hook’s and payload’s swing angles asymptotically converge to zero. Finally, the feasibility of the approach is verified through an actual double-pendulum quadrotor aerial transportation platform.

title: A Transferable Topology-Aware Graph Pooling Network for Remaining Useful Life Prediction Under Cross-Domain Conditions
authors: Jiusi Zhang, Hao Luo, Juncheng Hu, Chao Cheng, Shimeng Wu, Pengfei Yan, Jilun Tian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: Remaining useful life (RUL) prediction is critical for ensuring the safety, reliability, and efficient operation of complex industrial systems. Conventional deep neural networks, such as long short-term memory network and convolutional neural network mainly adopt local recurrent and pooling operations, which have notable limitations in global modeling in RUL prediction for complex industrial systems. Although the emergence of graph neural network (GNN)-based approaches can solve the above-mentioned problems, there are few reports on using GNN for RUL prediction under cross-domain conditions. Consequently, a novel transferable topology-aware graph pooling network is proposed for RUL prediction under cross-domain conditions. Specifically, this article integrates local and global voting to construct a topology-aware graph pooling network. Furthermore, a loss function is constructed to describe domain differences, so that the RUL prediction under cross-domain conditions is accomplished. Considering most of the existing deep learning approaches are closed-box models, this article designs an in-depth interpretability analysis based on the feature distribution and integrated gradient for the proposed approach. The effectiveness of TTAPGN is demonstrated by a commercial aircraft turbofan engine dataset, and a bearing degradation dataset from Xi'an Jiaotong University.

title: A Weakly-Hybrid Decoding Algorithm for Staircase Codes via Multi-Level Bit Marking
authors: Yi Lei, Xiang Wang, Bin Chen, Minghua Cao, Zhongyi Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Reducing the complexity of soft-decision (SD) decoding algorithm or improving the performance of hard-decision (HD) decoding algorithm becomes an emerging trend on forward error corrections to ensure reliable optical transmission with high performance and low cost. In this paper, a hybrid decoding algorithm is proposed for staircase codes (SCCs), which performs HD decoding with the help of channel soft information via multi-level bit-marking (MLBM). The HD and SD in the proposed MLBM decoding algorithm is weakly hybrid that the soft information is only used for one-shot bit marking and does not involve in the decoding directly, thus providing good performance-complexity tradeoff. The marked bits indicate four reliability levels that are used to prevent miscorrections by checking conflicts with highly reliable bits and to enhance the error-correcting capability of the HD decoder by flipping unreliable bits. Particularly, three priority levels are set for bit flipping by combining with the decoding statuses of the associated component codes. The decoding results will, in turn, help to update the marked bits among the four reliability levels. Numerical results show up to 1.22 dB gains with steeper waterfall region and lower error floor when compared to conventional HD decoding for SCCs, at the cost of approximately a two-fold increase in the memory storage.

title: Virtual Self-Excited Induction Generator-Based Grid-Forming Inverter Control for Robust Voltage Regulation Under Nonideal Loading
authors: Vikram Roy Chowdhury, Gab-Su Seo, Barry Mather
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: This paper presents a generator-inspired control methodology for grid-forming (GFM) inverters that deliberately emulates a self-excited induction generator so that the inverter can hold its voltage and frequency under difficult loading and severe terminal disturbances across wide voltage and frequency ranges. The design integrates a Lyapunov energy function-based inner loop to provide high bandwidth and strong disturbance rejection, and it complements this with a passivity-based argument that furnishes a coherent large-signal stability guarantee beyond small-signal limits. Analytical insights are developed via the Krylov-Bogoliubov-Mitropolsky averaging method, which reveals an intrinsic resistive droop characteristic; these closed-form relations both explain the observed dynamics and yield simple, decentralized tuning rules. The methodology is validated on a controller-hardware-in-the-loop platform and exercised in real time across balanced, unbalanced, and nonlinear loads, as well as during parallel operation. Across these scenarios, the inverter maintains balanced three-phase voltages, limits harmonic content, settles quickly with well-damped transients, and remains resilient when multiple units operate in parallel. The contributions are a self-excited-machine–inspired GFM controller with enhanced dynamic performance and robustness, a single stability rationale grounded in passivity, closed-form expressions that guide tuning, and comprehensive hardware-in-the-loop validations demonstrating effectiveness and superiority under challenging operating conditions.

title: DePerio: Innovative Deep Learning-based Framework for Periodontal Disease Diagnosis and Severity Evaluation Using Saliva Samples
authors: Mahdi Amrollahi Biouki, Fatemeh Soheili, Niloufar Delfan, Negin Masoudifar, Navid Mohaghegh, Shahin Ebrahimi, S. M. Mahdi H. Daneshvar, Yasaman Tahernezhad, Chunxiang Sun, Michael Glogauer, Ebrahim Ghafar-Zadeh
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Recent research has identified salivary oral polymorphonuclear neutrophils (oPMNs) as reliable cellular biomarkers for monitoring the progression of periodontal disease (PD). While conventional diagnostic tools such as periodontal probing and radiographic imaging are effective at detecting advanced disease stages, they lack the sensitivity required for early diagnosis. oPMNs, derived from circulating white blood cells (WBCs), transmigrate through the oral epithelium and appear in saliva with diverse morphological characteristics. Although deep learning-based WBC quantification has been extensively explored using peripheral blood datasets, the unique morphology of oPMNs necessitates the development of new image datasets and retraining of models tailored to their detection. To address these challenges, we introduce DePerio-an AI-powered diagnostic pipeline that integrates a novel oPMN isolation protocol with deep neural network (DNN) architectures. We evaluate the performance of multiple DNN models to achieve accurate detection and quantification of oPMNs. Validated against standard quantification methods for oPMNs and oral inflammatory load (OIL), DePerio achieved a detection error rate of less than 5%. In a clinical study involving 111 human saliva samples, spanning individuals from healthy to severe periodontitis cases, and successfully classified five distinct OIL levels. This robust and low-complexity platform provides a scalable and practical solution for early PD detection and longitudinal monitoring in clinical dental practice.

title: A Self-Driven Energy Recovery Snubber for a Single-Switch Resonant Pulsed Power Converter
authors: Qunfang Wu, Baitang Hou, Qin Wang, Fei Gao
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Single-switch resonant pulsed power converters provide advantages for applications like ozone generation, due to the inherent defects of the topology, the stress of the switch exists, the leakage inductance energy of the transformer cannot be released, and the switching loss is high. It is necessary to rely on the snubber to achieve highly reliable operation. There are significant power losses in traditional diode-resistor (DR) snubbers, especially at high loads. This paper proposes a self-driven energy recovery snubber to overcome this limitation. The solution replaces the lossy resistor with a flyback circuit comprising a clamping capacitor, inductor, switch, and diode. A hysteresis controller, powered by and directly responding to the snubber capacitor voltage, autonomously regulates the snubber’s switch. This self-driven approach eliminates external control, synchronization, or auxiliary supplies. Key features include: (1) Recycling of dissipated snubber energy back to the input source; (2) Down-frequency operation in discontinuous conduction mode (DCM), minimizing switching losses, and (3) Inherent simplicity and reliability from decoupled operation. The paper details the working principle across operational stages and provides practical design guidelines. Compared with the DR snubber, the experimental verification of the prototype shows that the power loss recovery and efficiency improvement are effective. The core concept offers a viable approach for enhancing efficiency in resonant pulsed-power converters and is readily adaptable for replacing the widely used RC/RCD snubbers.

title: Optimization and Mitigation of Access-Transistor-Induced Reliability Degradation in 28 nm 1T1R RRAM Arrays
authors: Yuhang Yang, Zongwei Wang, Shengyu Bao, Zheng Zhou, Lin Bao, Yimao Cai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: Recent investigations of one-transistor-one-resistive random access memory (RRAM) (1T1R) memory arrays at 40 and 28 nm technology nodes indicate that access transistor reliability represents a critical limiting factor for array endurance in scaled technology nodes, particularly due to overdrive stress-induced degradation effects. This work presents a comprehensive solution for enhancing access transistor reliability in 1T1R RRAM arrays at advanced technology nodes. By engineering the gate oxide and channel profile of the access transistors, significant improvements in array endurance are demonstrated at the 28 nm node. Furthermore, a voltage optimization scheme is developed to mitigate degradation in half-selected devices, enabling further endurance enhancement. This work offers new insights and practical design guidelines for developing high-reliability 1T1R memory arrays in advanced technology nodes.

title: Hypergraph Foundation Model
authors: Yue Gao, Yifan Feng, Shiquan Liu, Xiangmin Han, Shaoyi Du, Zongze Wu, Han Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Hypergraph neural networks (HGNNs) effectively model complex high-order relationships in domains like protein interactions and social networks by connecting multiple vertices through hyperedges, enhancing modeling capabilities, and reducing information loss. Developing foundation models for hypergraphs is challenging due to their distinct data, which includes both vertex features and intricate structural information. We present Hyper-FM, a Hypergraph Foundation Model for multi-domain knowledge extraction, featuring Hierarchical High-Order Neighbor Guided Vertex Knowledge Embedding for vertex feature representation and Hierarchical Multi-Hypergraph Guided Structural Knowledge Extraction for structural information. Additionally, we curate 11 text-attributed hypergraph datasets to advance research between HGNNs and LLMs. Experiments on these datasets show that Hyper-FM outperforms baseline methods by approximately 13.4%, validating our approach. Furthermore, we propose the first scaling law for hypergraph foundation models, demonstrating that increasing domain diversity significantly enhances performance, unlike merely augmenting vertex and hyperedge counts. This underscores the critical role of domain diversity in scaling hypergraph models.

title: Accurate Monocular Road Depth Estimation for Ground Vehicles Using Suspension Feedback
authors: Ming Bai, Jian Wu, Weichao Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Road depth estimation plays a crucial role in vehicle chassis control and autonomous driving. Monocular depth estimation, due to its low cost, energy efficiency, and ease of deployment, remains an important area for research. However, challenges persist in improving the accuracy of monocular depth estimation, reducing the impact of errors, and ensuring the convergence of errors over long-term operation. This paper proposes an improved monocular depth estimation approach that integrates deep learning techniques with feedback from vehicle suspension states. Under the DispNet architecture, we replace traditional neural networks with the Standard Nonlinear Operator Form (SNOF) and incorporate vehicle suspension information to build a delayed state observer for real-time depth estimation error compensation. State compensation is achieved through solving Linear Matrix Inequalities (LMI), ensuring error convergence during extended operation. Extensive real-world experiments using signal-collecting vehicles demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits excellent generalization capabilities across diverse environments and lighting conditions.

title: Dynamic Pricing for On-Demand DNN Inference in the Edge-AI Market
authors: Songyuan Li, Jia Hu, Geyong Min, Haojun Huang, Jiwei Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: The convergence of edge computing and Artificial Intelligence (AI) gives rise to Edge-AI, which enables the deployment of real-time AI applications at the network edge. A key research challenge in Edge-AI is edge inference acceleration, which aims to realize low-latency high-accuracy Deep Neural Network (DNN) inference by offloading partitioned inference tasks from end devices to edge servers. However, existing research has yet to adopt a practical Edge-AI market perspective, which would explore the personalized inference needs of AI users (e.g., inference accuracy, latency, and task complexity), the revenue incentives for AI service providers that offer edge inference services, and multi-stakeholder governance within a market-oriented context. To bridge this gap, we propose an <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</u>uction-based <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">E</u>dge Infe<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r</u>ence Pr<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</u>cing Mech<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</u>nism (AERIA) for revenue maximization to tackle the multi-dimensional optimization problem of DNN model partition, edge inference pricing, and resource allocation. We develop a multi-exit device-edge synergistic inference scheme for on-demand DNN inference acceleration, and theoretically analyze the auction dynamics amongst the AI service providers, AI users and edge infrastructure provider. Owing to the strategic mechanism design via randomized consensus estimate and cost sharing techniques, the Edge-AI market attains several desirable properties. These include competitiveness in revenue maximization, incentive compatibility, and envy-freeness, which are crucial to maintain the effectiveness, truthfulness, and fairness in auction outcomes. Extensive simulations based on four representative DNN inference workloads demonstrate that AERIA significantly outperforms several state-of-the-art approaches in revenue maximization. This validates the efficacy of AERIA for on-demand DNN inference in the Edge-AI market.

title: Machine Learning Prediction for Experimental Quench Voltage of HTS Coils Using a Combined Framework With Time-Series Generative Adversarial Network and Long Short-Term Memory Techniques
authors: Yahao Wu, Wenjuan Song, Mohammad Yazdani-Asrami
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Fast and reliable quench detection is critical for protecting high temperature superconducting coils, magnets, and devices, yet experimental datasets remain limited due to cryogenic constraints and risk of conductor damage. This limitation is one of the key challenges in developing machine learning (ML) techniques for predicting quench through regression-based forecasting of voltage signals. To address this, we propose a framework that combines Time-series Generative Adversarial Networks (TimeGAN) for artificial sequence generation with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) predictors. From 36 measured voltage sequences, TimeGAN generated 90 artificial sequences to expand the dataset and mitigate overfitting. Augmenting the LSTM improved quench prediction accuracy to ∼3% mean relative error. This study demonstrates the first application of TimeGAN to superconducting quench signals and highlights the benefit of ML-driven augmentation for improving quench prediction robustness.
